column2: With the announcement yesterday by Secretary Frederick W. Rubien of five additional committees for the 1936 Olympic Games, the American Olympic Committee was ready for its two-day organization session at the New York Athletic Club. Today will be given over to separate gatherings of the twenty-three subgroups in secret session, with the entire committee assembled for the main conclave tomorrow.

Although the $10,861,291 new State and municipal bond issues announced for award next week are only about 50 per cent of this week's total of $20,339,259, the new financing for later in the month will be relatively heavy. The weekly average for the year to date new stands at 14,982,313.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 2. -- A commercial treaty between Chile and Germany, the first agreement of this nature reached with any European country, went into force today. It is expected to aid Chilean nitrate and copper exports and the liquidating of German credits frozen here.

Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan granted an injunction yesterday to the members of the American Cloak and Suit Manufacturers Association, composed of contractors, against the Merchant Ladies Garment Association, Inc., made up of jobbers, to restrain the violation of a contract under the NRA dress code by which the jobbers agreed to designate specified members of the contractors' association to make up all the garments sold by them.

BERLIN, Feb. 2. -- Alfred Rosenberg, whose book "Mythology in the Twentieth Century" advocated the elimination of the crucifix from German worship, has been appointed to supervise" the entire intellectual and philosophical schooling" of the Nazi party and its coordinated associations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The text of President Roosevelt's talk today to the directors of the National Emergency Council follows:

A recently completed symphony by Roy Harris, of the rising generation of American composers, was the novelty of the program given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall. This Symphony was prefaced by Stravinsky's ballet-suite, "Apollon Musagete" and was followed by the Fourth symphony of Brahms.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP). -- Opposition to restrictive provisions in the proposed motor carrier regulation legislation that would hamper contract carriers utilized by newspapers was expressed before the House Interstate Commerce Committee today by spokesmen for the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- President Roosevelt this afternoon exhorted the forty-eight State directors of the National Emergency Council to be "absolutely hardboiled" in keeping politics out of the relief program, "even if you hit the biggest political boss in the United States on the head."

The annual convention of the New York Province of the Federation of College Catholic Clubs started last night with a reception at the Hotel Biltmore in honor of the more than 3,000 Catholic students, members of Newman Clubs at twenty-six colleges and universities in New York and New Jersey.
Poly Prep vanquished Jamaica High, 3 to 1, and Manual Training defeated St. John's Prep, 2 to 0, in non-league hockey games at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

For the year ended on Dec. 31, 1933, the S.S. Kresge Company reported a net profit of $8,441,098 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent, after 7 per cent preferred dividend requirements, to $1.50 a share on 5,517,929 shares of $10 par common stock, and compares with a net profit of $5,656, 719, or $1 a common share, in 1932.

Supreme Court Justice Valente approved yesterday a compromise agreement made by the Superintendent of Banks with Irwin S. Chanin, builder, on his liability to the Bank of United States in the $60,000,000 action against him and other directors for damages for approving alleged illegal and improvident loans to affiliates and subsidiaries.

COPENHAGEN, Feb. 3. -- A Danish bondholder, August Soederberg, who on behalf of a group of bondholders brought suit against the Copenhagen Telephone Company following the devaluation of the dollar, has lost the first round in the proceedings.

THE author of this little poem, essay, history, geography, treatise and manual is admirably named as well as fitted for this task of love. The Highlands speak in him. Like his Roman predecessor, he brings back the old pieties and gods.

The City College Alumni Football Committee yesterday completed arrangements to have Benny Friedman, former All-America quarterback at the University of Michigan, come to C.C.N.Y. next Fall as head coach of football.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- A decision by the Supreme Court is imminent on the constitutionality of emergency legislation extending broad powers to governmental agencies to fix prices. The decision will directly involve the validity of the New York Milk Control Law.

Joseph Abrams brought his career as a De Witt Clinton High School tennis player to an unusually successful conclusion yesterday by winning the interscholastic indoor tourney sponsored by his school for the second year in a row.

IT may be a source of some small comfort to dancers in the midst of the perennial battle between those who would sacrifice everything to the preservation of traditional methods and those who are equally ardent in their pursuit of change in the name of progress, to find that the same battle rages pretty well all over the world.

TORONTO, Ont., Feb. 3. -- A forecast of what may be expected from the annual reports of gold-mining companies appeared in the preliminary operating statement of Hollinger Consolidated Gold Mines Ltd., which revealed net profits of $5,997,049, equivalent to about $1.21 a share.

DR. Brown traces the influence of Rabelais upon English literature, notices the modifications that the famous characters in Pantagruel undergo when treated by the somewhat more serious and, in a sense, more moral English genius.
RYE, N.Y., Feb. 3. -- The first annual supper dance of the Westchester-Southern Society was held at the Westchester Country Club here. Mrs. Humphrey J. Lynch was in charge.
TWO huge and highly mobile government funds, dedicated to the control of the foreign exchange values of their national currencies, now face each other and a more or less bewildered world.

EVERY playwright finds himself with the same problem to solve. His problem is to reconcile two opposites. For his idea, if it is to have any value, must be an idea comprehensible in every age. But the form in which he clothes his idea must represent his own time.

The undefeated New York University basketball team recorded its seventh consecutive victory by triumphing over Manhattan, 31 to 26, at the 102d Engineers Armory last night. In the opening contest of a double header, St. John's of Brooklyn repulsed Villanova, 31 to 29.

Thus far this session of Congress has thrown to the ground the predictions made in advance of its meeting. There was to be a vigorous assertion of its power as a coordinate branch of the Government. It would not comply with every request of the President as it did after the crisis of last March.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 3. -- Godfrey J. Olsen, Hudson Avenue, this borough, sailed yesterday with three assistants for Haiti to conduct archaeological research in the West Indies for the Museum of the American Indian, Heye Foundation, New York City.

AS "press agent for the British Empire," a title which he bestows upon himself in this diary, George Riddell (later Lord Riddell) served his country well. Within their limited vision, most of the men appearing in these pages served their countries well -- and the world badly.

PERHAPS the Greeks evolved or created their ideal of feminine beauty and then hung garments on it. At all events, what has been passed on to us of the Greek ideal of beauty expressed in human form, whether male or female, is independent of garments.

CONCRETE runways 4,800 feet long; an administration building having modern hotel accommodations and a roof to be used for dining and dancing at night; a dining room with murals by Xavier Gonzales; sculptural decoration by such men as Enriqno Alferez, William Proctor and John Lachin; more murals by A.J. Drysdale; runways lights with a combined candle power of more than 20,000,000; a port sign illuminated by 800 bulbs of sixty-candle power each --

Technological change is inherent in applied science, and in few fields is this more apparent than that of mechanical engineering. In the past ten years important applications of new knowledge in the related fields of aerodynamics, metallurgy, mechanics and petroleum technology have created a host of novel problems and placed a serious responsibility on those concerned with the preparation of young engineers of the coming generation.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1. -- Controversy over the projected merger of the University of Chicago and Northwestern University is reaching that stage where the heat emitted is stronger than the light. President Walter Dill Scott of Northwestern has been compelled to call a member of his faculty to time for utterances which reflected on the University of Chicago.

By providing a common denominator for the measurement of all industrial, business and agricultural performances, the kilo man-hour method offers the soundest base for the establishment of national planning ever devised, L.P. Alford of the Ronald Press, and J.E. Hannum, editor, the Engineering Index, co-authors of the plan, declared here yesterday.

A general tightening of many NRA codes to close "loopholes" through which a minority of producers in scores of industries are reported as attempting to evade both the spirit and the letter of their code agreements was forecast here yesterday by manufacturers.

For the second straight year Beekman Pool of the Harvard Club successfully turned back the gallant bid of William E. Coyle Jr. of the Montclair Athletic Club for the metropolitan Class A squash racquets singles title when he defeated the New Jersey youngster in the final at the University Club yesterday.

MOSCOW, Feb. 3. -- Delegates to the All-Union Communist Party Congress cheered today when the Communist International presented its report that a world revolution and victory for communism throughout the world was approaching.

THERE has been an increasing demand for opportunities of hearing the works of contemporary American composers.'' The quotation is from the circular of New Music Quarterly Recordings, a non-profit organization affiliated with New Music, a quarterly published under the editorship of Henry Cowell and which for the last six years has circulated compositions by American composers.

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- The season's initial polo game, a drag hunt, dancing, bridge and a fashion show will be the principal activities in Augusta's resort colony this week. The Wichita Falls (Texas) team and the Augusta Polo Club team, the latter composed mostly of Oklahoma players, will appear in the opening polo game today.

THIS, the second novel by the brilliant author of "Inheritance," is likewise a novel the scene of which is laid in the great textile district of England. But "A Modern Tragedy" differs from "Inheritance" in two all-important particulars.
PERHAPS a man's confession is good for other souls as well as his own.

YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif. -- Hundreds of Winter sports enthusiasts are participating in the season's activities in Yosemite, which are now at their height and will continue until Feb. 26, and beyond if the snow lasts.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3. -- A special conference on the subject of "The Medical Profession and the Public," under the joint auspices of the College of Physicians of Philadelphia and the American Academy of Political and Social Science, will be held here on Wednesday.

Governor Clifford Pinchot of Pennsylvania, who is expected to enter the campaign this Fall for United States Senator, broadcast his views on "Public Utilities in the New Deal" in a radio talk yesterday from his bedside in the Leroy Sanitarium, 40 East Sixty-first Street, where he has been for a month recovering from an attack of shingles.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3. -- Before a cheering crowd of 9,000 Penn rallied in the closing minutes to defeat Yale at the Palestra tonight, 26 to 22, and tie the Elis for the lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League. Yale led at the half, 12 to 10.

LION FEUCHTWANGER'S new novel, "The Oppermanns," to be published in March by the Viking Press, is a story of modern Germany. It is said to present a picture of what actually happened to a Jewish family at the time of Hitler's accession.

Plans are going forward rapidly for the musical revue and dance in behalf of Irvington House which will be held on the nights of Feb. 15 and 16 in the ballroom of the Plaza. It will be called "Vanity Fair," and several novel features have been arranged.

GLOUCESTER wharfs and the pleasant New England countryside have attracted E.A. Dennison, whose breezy water-colors are on exhibition at the Architectural League. These fresh, forthright impressions display a feeling for color and design.

BOSTON, Feb. 2. UNDER a fortnight's test in Boston for the expected run in New York, "Richard of Bordeaux" is as brave a medieval show as the speaking stage often receives. The characters are many; the scene shifts from palace to palace; while we are in an age in which men, and not women, wore the plumage.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 4. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 72.8, which compares with 72.5 a week before, 72.1 two weeks before, 72 three weeks before and 72 four weeks before.

WITH the advent of Gregorio Lopez y Fuentes's "Tierra, La Revolution Agraria en Mexico," a new Mexican novelist has arrived. For many years the colorful Mariano Azuela, author of "The Under Dogs" and "Marcela," dominated the scene.

LONDON. CHRISTOPHER COLUMBUS made his way across the Atlantic in a little over two months. It takes much longer than that nowadays for some popular American novels to accomplish the passage in he reverse direction.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Coincidentally with published attacks by the steel executives, who said that the National Labor Board was "encouraging unionism," Chairman Wagner declared today that "the sum-total of impressions based on reports from New England to California is that the overwhelming majority of employers and employes use, trust and support this system of industrial adjustment."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The callers who troop to the White House day and night say they find there a man physically untouched by almost a year of concentration on the nation's problems.

Religion in its relationship to the individual human being and the growth of character was the theme of the Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson's first sermon yesterday morning as the rabbi of Congregation Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at Sixty-fifth Street.
Clarence C. Pell and Stanley G. Mortimer today will seek their tenth national amateur racquets doubles championship.

In protest against recent mass lay-offs and pay cuts, 50,000 employes on CWA and CWS projects in New York will stop work for fifteen minutes at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning, it was announced yesterday by the Relief Workers League, 29 East Twentieth Street.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 3. -- Three men and a woman, carrying $35,000, believed to be part of the $130,000 seized in a payroll robbery at Penns Grove yesterday, were captured this afternoon as they stepped from a Camden dwelling to enter an automobile.

A cross-fire of criticism from both protectionists and importers was directed last week at Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury under President Hoover, for his public advocacy of a more liberal tariff policy for the United States.

AN exciting thing is taking place in the realm of clothes today; it is the advancement of young New York designers to a position of importance. Through them the American woman is finding a new interpretation. They seem to understand her moods -- since they are also their own, whether they be gay or serious, practical or frivolous -- and to find a genuine expression for them in color and line.

With twelve of the leading three-cushion players entered, including Welker Cochran, the present title-holder, the world's championship tournament will get under way tomorrow night at the Capitol Acadery, 1,680 Broadway.

EVERY ship on the seas carries a binnacle, that all-important case which holds the compass. Usually the binnacle is severely plain, a model of scientific neatness and efficiency, though in older days it was sometimes embellished by imaginative shipwrights.

Yeshiva College, the most recent addition to intercollegiate circles, tied New York University, 2 1/2 to 2 1/2, in their New York City Intercollegiate Chess Association match at the West Side Club yesterday. Yeshiva won at the first and third boards, N.Y.U. triumphed at the fourth and fifth and one game was drawn.

The National Board of Review of Motion Pictures will celebrate its twenty-fifth anniversary at its annual conference which will open a three-day session at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Thursday. Representatives of motion picture study groups in all parts of the country will attend the conference, the feature of which will be a review of twenty-five years of public interest in the films.

ALBANY, Feb. 3. -- A constitutional amendment to permit county judges and surrogates to act as Supreme Court justices on designation of the Appellate Division will be proposed in a resolution Senator John L. Buckley will offer Monday.

VIENNA, Feb. 2. -- Public discussion of the plan launched by the Czechoslovak Minister of Finance, Karel Englis, to manage the Czechoslovak currency by granting a 15 per cent premium to exporters while charging a similar premium to importers has had a dangerous effect on the stability of the Czechoslovak crown, the only currency in Eastern Central Europe which has withstood the financial storms of the past twelve years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Fear of House leaders that increasing sentiment for a greater amount than that requested by President Roosevelt for continuation of the Civil Works Administration might lead to a serious revolt when the $950,000,000 CWA and relief measure is called up in the House Monday was aggravated today by rumors that the Senate would increase the fund recommended by the administration.

Gordon Ridings led the New York A.C. basketball team to victory over Union Temple last night on the victor's court in the George V. McLaughlin Trophy tournament. The score was 29 to 23. Trailing at the end of the half, 12 to 10, N.Y.A.C. rallied in the second half to win.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Government workers are increasing in number and their salaries are averaging more. This was disclosed today by Civil Servive Commission statistics on Federal workers under executive civil service, not including those in the legislative and judicial branches nor the armed forces.

THIS is not a mystery story, but it is a detective story of much more than ordinary merit. The detective in it is Inspector French, who has many admirers among the readers of crime fiction. In this story he is called in to investigate a murder about which the reader already knows all that there is to be known.
ST. PAUL, Feb. 3 (AP). -- An aged father tonight voiced his third public appeal for the return of his son, Edward G. Bremer, St. Paul banker, seized for $200,000 ransom more than two weeks ago.

Upstairs, above the temple of the Great Laughing Buddha in Mott Street, a queer ceremonial involving the correct uses of the drum, the gong and the cymbals was going forward yesterday. The thunder of it caused the little bells hanging on the seven-porched pagoda in the temple below to Jingle merrily, and passers in the street to squint curiously up the darkened and rickety stairway.

Further evidence of the city's financial dilemma was given yesterday by Controller W. Arthur Cunningham. He wrote to the heads of half a dozen city departments, embracing 670 employes, whose payroll funds come not from the annual budget but from the sale of corporate stock, warning that unless the city's credit is speedily restored these employes face payless paydays.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 3 (AP). -- The Erie Railroad announced today that it had placed an order for 3,725 freight cars, subject to a financial arrangement with the Public Works Administration. Its orders will go to the American Car and Foundry, Standard Steel Car, Pressed Steel Car, Greenville Steel Car and Ryan Car Companies, and the Magor Car Corporation.
SHERLOCK ROW, England, Feb. 3. -- The United States women's squash racquets team, led by Miss Eleonora Sears of Boston, today defeated an English team headed by Mrs. L.H. Cristes, 6 to 1.

Many of the best known stamps collectors in the United States will exhibit at the exhibition opening next Saturday on the thirty-fourth floor of the main Rockefeller Center Building. The event will continue through the following week. Postmaster General Farley is expected to open the exhibition with a short address.

Aviation promoters are not the only ones who can run up an investment of a few dollars into a fortune. A lonely spinster who lived and died in cheap lodgings in Paddington surprised her friends last week by leaving an estate of 50,000 or so, all made out of pennies.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Feb. 3. -- Everett Gillam's Comet captured the Commodore's Pennant as the Long Branch Ice Boat and Yacht Club opened its 1934 ice yacht racing season on the South Shrewsbury River today. It was the first race club members have been able to carry out since the season of 1930-31.

BERLIN, Feb. 2. -- While composition of the schism in German Protestantism and translating of the concordat with the Catholic Church into a working operation are marking time, there are plenty of signs of continuing tension and confusion.
Ireland today is an economic paradox -- "a dog living on its own tail" -- Andrew Jameson, Irish Free State Senator and director of the Bank of Ireland, said yesterday in the Hotel Ambassador.

The transportation of fresh fruits and vegetables was seriously interfered with last week by the cold and heavy snowfall, it was said yesterday by George G. Royce, director of the New York office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets.

AT An American Place, Alfred Stieglitz has arranged a one-man show of Georgia O'Keeffe's work, retrospective in that it goes back virtually to the beginning of her career, 1915, although little of recent date is included.

PALM BEACH, -- So closely dotted with outstanding affairs is the month of February that each week promises a program for which not one but several days have been set aside. Because of the unusual activity of the past two months the colonists foresee a strenuous period ahead and have made plans for major events far in advance.

WARSAW, Feb. 2. -- Last Monday Marshal Pilsudski received the French Ambassador and the Rumanian Minister, the diplomatic representatives of Poland's two allies. It was left to Foreign Minister Joseph Beck to inform a host of other diplomats, including the Soviet Ambassador and the envoys of the Baltic countries, all vitally interested in the Polish-German non-aggression declaration, of its terms and significance.

A LARGE-SCALE map of New York stubbed with colored pins adorns a wall in the office of Arthur S. Tuttle, State engineer for the Federal Emergency Public Works Administration. The colored pins represent 267 projects, involving the improvement of street and sidewalk facilities in the five boroughs of the city for which Federal funds are sought.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Feb. 3 (AP). -- Determined to try to effect a better understanding between the peoples of the United States and Japan, Hiroshi Saito, 47-year-old Japanese Ambassador to Washington, sailed today for the United States.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 1. -- Drastic changes in the Civil Works Administration in Kentucky are in prospect and a complete new set-up may be effected soon. The changes are expected to follow a widespread investigation now under way in which two men have been arrested for irregularities.

The psychological background of the Nazis, offering an explanation of the National Socialist movement in Germany, is presented in the first issue of a new magazine, Social Research, an international quarterly printed in English by members of the University in Exile of the New School of Social Research.

The Topeka address of Ogden L. Mills is an important contribution to the discussion of national policies. Mr. Mills is an outstanding leader of the Republican party. He was a member of the Hoover Cabinet. It does not matter much whether the views he expressed are wholly personal or whether in some measure they reflect collective party leadership.

AS first published a dozen years ago this little work was composed of four lectures which Mr. Beard had given in 1916 at Amherst College. Because its contents are so applicable under present circumstances the book is republished now with a new preface, the revision of the fourth chapter in the light of post-war happenings, without, the author explains, the altering of its main conclusions, and with other minor changes.

DUBLIN, Feb. 2. -- When the Dail Eireann reassembled this week one of the first acts of the government was to introduce a bill to give the administration authority to introduce a quota system for the Free State. At present the government limits imports by imposing heavy tariffs.

Not a few Protestant clergymen and Jewish rabbis will refer in their sermons today to the crusade against "the foul and vicious reading matter" with which Cardinal Hayes, in his pastoral letter to be read in all his 454 churches today, declares the country is "deluged."

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- The English Football League had a new leader today in the fighting Derby County eleven, Arsenal being toppled from the top of the heap by Everton. In a surprising result the Toffee Makers defeated Arsenal, 2-1, while Derby County was routing Stoke City, 5 to 1.

GEORGE GERSHWIN is out on his concert tour, but only until the end of this week. After that he'll settle down to making an operatic version of Du Bose and Dorothy Heyward's "Porgy." He hopes to finish it n time for a production next season.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1. -- Out of the Northwest, as January ended, came freezing misery for the poor of the Lakes and prairie regions. A Winter that had been piling up surplus temperature, and sparing the jobless multitudes who are dependent on public aid, suddenly showed its biting teeth.

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- A demand is arising from many quarters here that the British Government explain clearly for the benefit of the suspicious American public exactly what it is trying to do with its exchange equalization fund.

Entries will close on Saturday for the tenth annual show of the Kennel Club of Buffalo, which is to be held in the Broadway Auditorium on Saturday and Sunday, Feb. 24 and 25. The Buffalo organization is noted for its warm welcome to visitors and the usual party for exhibitors will be held at the Lafayette hotel the first night of the show.

Not quite as rapidly and gracefully as in a dance figure, two couples change marriage partners in Peggy Shane's latest novel. It is a rattling good story of young New Yorkers. The plot itself rattles a bit at the beginning. But it soon swings into a smooth pace that makes amusing reading.

An expansion in industrial buying policies so manufacturers will be covered for at least three months ahead on requirements was urged by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents in its January report on business conditions made public yesterday.

A statement denying that he had ever read or heard of a story by Richard Washburn Child. "The Avenger," before he wrote the play "One Sunday Afternoon" was issued yesterday by James Hagan, author of the play, through his attorney, Harry Weinberger.

With their commanding officer, Major F.A. Vietor, returned to action and turning in a fine game at back as Phillip Brady went on a scoring spree at No. 1, Squadron A won convincingly over the Riding Club in a Metropolitan Indoor Polo League game at Squadron A Armory last night, 11 1/2 to 5 1/2.

The State of Kansas, striving toward the stars through hard ways, as her Latin motto proclaims, celebrated her seventy-third birthday last week with a satisfaction that only one to the manner born can make adequately articulate. She does not wait for quinquennials or decennials.
SIALKOT, Punjab, India, Feb. 3 (AP). -- Fierce rioting due to renewed conflicts between Hindus and Moslems flared today in the mountain kingdom of Kashmir.

MONTE CARLO, Feb. 2. -- A report that Prince Louis of Monaco is prepared to negotiate a complete cession of his principality to France, which has been current for some time, is a principal subject of conversation this year on the Riviera.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Secretary Ickes, as oil administrator, modified the Oil Code today to assure adequate supplies of crude oil for small refiners, while at the same time preventing excessive withdrawals from storage. To this end he announced cancellation of one section of the code, and he issued a new regulation to cover withdrawals.

IN spite of its emphasis upon the havoc wrought by war, it must not be thought that "The Unforgotten Prisoner," as a novel, is a mere peg on which Mr. Hutchinson has hung pacifist theories. It is an interesting and at times a wildly exciting story, holding the reader's rapt attention through all its considerable length, for the author is a master in all the arts of suspense and pleasant digression.

The Cambridge University rugby team will play a series of games in this country next Spring in the first international collegiate competition of the kind, it was announced yesterday by the Sportsmanship Brotherhood, which will sponsor the visit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- About 36 per cent of all deposits in all banks of the United States are protected by temporary insurance of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, E.G. Bennett, the director, revealed today.

COLDER weather had a tonic effect upon the demand for Winter goods and cut down materially upon retail stocks. Earlier in the week there was a tendency for trade to drag, but it picked up again toward the close. House furnishings were purchased in volume.

Judging assignments and the table of the three-day exhibition to be held in Madison Square Garden on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday of next week, were announced yesterday by the Westminster Kennel Club.

GENEVA, Feb. 3. -- The League of Nations' secretariat received word from Vienna after today's Cabinet meeting that Chancellor Dollfuss planned to send a communication to the League Monday afternoon. It is not known here what the message will contain, but it is supposed it will invoke the covenant against Germany, as Austria has warned Berlin she will do.

THE powerful fire engines and elaborate equipment used by New York's firemen in fighting menacing fires contrast strikingly with that of the companies in pioneer days. A description of one of these organizations, the Friendly Fire Society of Portsmouth, N.H., founded in 1762, recently came into possession of the Business Historical Society of Boston.

A critical evaluation of the first month of the Fusion administration produced slight adverse criticism and much praise at a four-sided discussion held yesterday in the Rand School, 7 East Fifteenth Street.

THE selling of legal liquor in New York City is at present going through a chaotic phase. The State Legislature has yet to pen laws giving a permanent form to liquor control; in the meantime the temporary State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board and the police have the difficult task of enforcing what law there is and at the same time trying to eliminate the bootlegger and the speakeasy.

Numerous new courses and special lectures are on the Spring semester schedules beginning this week in local universities and colleges and in the city's public schools, which began the new term last Thursday.

NO economic action is exclusively of private and individual concern. From the day man surrendered himself to the community or adapted himself to it, he has performed no act which might be said to begin, develop and end with himself, for it has had reactions beyond his person.

A comprehensive exhibition of dancing is scheduled to take place in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on the evening of Feb. 11, when the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., holds its benefit for members.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- Women enthusiastically welcome Germanine Bailly's first Summer collection. Her black linen lace afternoon and evening frocks are special favorites. The pink linen thread lace collarettes, made by her, are Spring-like afternoon accessories.

Talented young students of theatre arts at the Neighborhood Playhouse will be aided by a pre-view performance of "Richard of Bordeaux" on the night of Feb. 13 at the Empire Theatre, which has been taken over by the Neighborhood Playhouse Associates to augment their scholarship fund.

A floor coverings opening reaching 1929 proportions as far as buyer attendance and orders are concerned is forecast for the rug trade here tomorrow, when Spring lines of rugs and carpets will be opened to the trade. Stores in all parts of the country are sending representatives here for the event and have allowed them appropriations larger than those granted at any of the last six seasonal openings.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, with headquarters at 69 Fifth Avenue, will celebrate its twenty-fifth anniversary on Lincoln's Birthday, Feb. 12. It was organized on that date in 1909.

The "dishonest manipulator" and the "crooked gambler" of the Stock Exchange and must go, and the New York Stock Exchange and "all other security markets" must be brought under Federal regulation and control, Ferdinand Pecora declared last night.

The fight for the Democratic leadership of Brooklyn, which has been in progress since the death of John H. McCooey, reached an acute stage yesterday with the arrival of Postmaster General James A. Farley, State and National Chairman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Our exports of merchandise were larger in December to twenty-nine of the forty principal foreign markets than in the preceding month, and the value of all shipments increased $8,362,582 over November to a total of $192,618,809.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 1. -- Cuyahoga County, which is Cleveland and its suburban fringe, is experimenting in the painful field of attempting to make overdue taxpayers cough up. The results to date are not exactly encouraging, but the means employed have some elements of novelty, forced perhaps by the straitened financial condition of the county and thereby the city, the school systems and the multiple suburban governments.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Feb. 3. -- W.H. (Wiffy) Cox won the fifth annual Agua Caliente open golf championship with a 72-hole score of 282 today to establish a new scoring record for the event and knock a pet golf superstition into the nearest trap.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- President Roosevelt is expected to make a definite move early next week for solution of the sugar problem which has been accumulating complications since he took office last March 4.

ROME, Feb. 3. -- The biggest financial operation ever undertaken by Italy was decided on at today's Cabinet meeting, which approved the immediate conversion from 5 to 3 1/2 per cent of the entire Italian consolidated loan of about 70,000,000,000 lire.

The midwinter meeting of the New York State Bankers Association will open tomorrow morning in the Federal Reserve Bank and end with a dinner at night in the Hotel Roosevelt, at which Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, will speak.

APROPOSAL which has won the approval of the House Naval Affairs Committee to purchase 1,184 planes for the navy is bound to arouse a great deal of interest abroad. The facts are that about half these planes will be necessary replacements, that even then the navy will not be up to the strength warranted by the London treaty and then the program is to be spread over five years

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Crude petroleum production in December totaled 72,060,000 barrels, or a daily average of 2,325,000 barrels, the Department of Commerce announced today. There was no change in December from the daily average of the preceding month, but it was considerably above that of a year ago, when the East Texas field was shut down for half a month.

AFTER eighteen months of statements, rumors, interviews, stern denials and modest affirmations, Samuel Goldwyn has revealed the Muscovite Garbo, Anna Sten, to American audiences in "Nana," which is at the Radio City Music Hall.
The maze at Hampton Court, which made a fortune in pennies for the late Emily Smith, according to a recent dispatch from London, is one of the finest examples of such devices to be found anywhere.

PARIS, Feb. 2. -- What may fairly be described as the beginning of "new things" is occurring in France. It is too early yet to speak of revolution, for that is a word too closely associated in the popular conception with violence. Yet in its proper meaning revolution is in full ferment just now in France.
Trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday was the largest for a short session in several months, while prices advanced more decidedly than they had done earlier in the week.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 3. -- The volcano Quizapu and the adjoining cones in the Andes opposite Talca, which were the centre of the volcanic eruptions in 1932 that covered the southern part of South America with volcanic ash over a radius of more than 2,000 miles, will be closely examined in the next few days by a scientific expedition which has already set out.

SINCE "renaissance" has acquired considerable vogue in our present-day art vocabulary, it may not be extravagant to apply to this season's sculptural developments the regal term that betokens a rebirth or significant kindling.

At its second concert here this week, the Boston Symphony Orchestra under Serge Koussevitzky played Schonberg's "Verklarte Nacht," Edward Burlingame Hill's concertino for piano and orchestra and Rimsky-Korsakoff's "Scheherazade" yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area was at a slightly slower pace last week, although the volume was increased toward the weekend. Low temperatures revived the demand for Winter goods, stocks of which were already at low ebb. Increased consumer interest was shown in homefurnishings items.

Retail trade was mixed last week, with special sales still unusually scarce but with Winter goods moving freely under the influence of the return of colder weather. Wholesaling and jobbing was mixed as well, buyers who had completed their Spring liner in this area having transferred their activity to other sections.

THE two sons of Mad Tim Storm had been taught by their father to shoot straight and fast. But they never carried guns. The big Crazy S ranch he left them was prospering, and the country roundabout was peaceful enough. Tom, the elder, was strong physically and morally, but the weakling Tam gambled himself into a nasty jam.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 3. -- Mrs. Frank A. Carreaud's Time Supply merely galloped along in front of a field of ten fleet 3-year-olds to win the third running of the six-furlong Hialeah Stakes at Hialeah Park today. At the finish the son of Time Maker held a five-length advantage over Mrs. F.J. Heller's Agrarian, with W. Graham's Open Range a length and a half further back in third place.

Gene Venzke has yet to beat Glenn Cunningham at a mile. Over the same worn board trail at Madison Square Garden that served as their battleground last year, the Kansas nemesis of the Penn sophomore raced the second fastest eight furlongs ever recorded indoors to win the Rodman Wanamaker Mile that featured the twenty-seventh annual Millrose A.A games last night.

MANY years ago I stood with my father in a side-show and saw a miracle happen on a screen. A little man in a top hat was shown diving from a high platform, into a swimming pool and then springing back out of the water and onto his perch again.

The Barringer High School fencin team, interscholastic champion of New Jersey, captured metropolitan district honors last night when its superbly balanced trio defeated George Washington High, 5-3, in the final round of the first prep school team foils championship.

THE whimsical but very apt title of this latest addition to Appleton's excellent Popular Health Series means that the book is concerned with physical therapy, that recent development of the science of medicine which has had during the last two decades a phenomenal development.

Once more we meet Dennis Tyler, formerly chief of the State Department's Bureau of Current Political Intelligence, in which capacity he exercised his detective ability in several earlier "Diplomat" novels. In this book we find him in Geneva, where a world political conference is in session.

EXETER, N.H., Feb. 3. -- An even break in two sports was scored by Exeter Academy today. The school's hockey team trounced the Northeastern University freshmen. 9 to 1. The St. John's Prep basketball five, however, downed Exeter, 34 to 31, in an exciting struggle.

A substitute performance of "Mid-summer Night's Dream" will be given at 2:30 o'clock next Thursday afternoon at St. Augustine High School, 167th Street and Franklin Avenue, the Bronx, where, due to an "unfortunate misunderstanding," emergency stage recruits of the Civil Works Service Bureau of the CWA failed to appear for a scheduled performance of "She Stoops to Conquer" last Thursday afternoon.

GUAYAQUIL, Jan. 30. -- The reaction in local commercial circles to the Japanese trade mission which visited this city recently indicated that Japan cannot expect to sell to Ecuador without buying here or paying special import duties on its own low-priced goods sold here.

" We have started on the greatest and most widespread restoration program for wild waterfowl in the history of the country," according to Colonel Arthur F. Foran, president of the More Game Birds Foundation, an organization which, for the past three or four years, has been searching the country for data concerning the wild waterfowl situation.

Because of recent developments, in Washington some of the group interested in aiding silver have come to the conclusion that it can be done only through higher worldwide commodity prices or an international agreement for the greater use of silver as subsidiary coinage, or both.

The theory that it is more difficult to preserve capital values in a period of normal deflation than during artificial and regulated inflation, expounded recently by the head of a speculative institution, has been the subject of thorough discussion among leading operators and students of investment trusts in the last week.

Racketeers in fraudulent stocks have renewed their activities here and in Buffalo, as the result of the recent rise in prices on the stock market, State Attorney General John B. Bennett Jr. declared yesterday. He warned the public not to buy securities over the telephone without knowledge of the seller's character and reputation.

CHRISTOPHER DAWSON is neither, like Spengler, a prophet of Western doom, nor, like the Pollyanic Marxists, does he offer us, in this book, a utopian panacea for the world's headache. He sees the present "world disorder" and threatened collapse of at least Western civilization realistically, without either undue alarm or excessive optimism.

An appeal to all Protestant congregations in the city to support Mayor LaGuardia's fight for passage of his Economy Bill by the Legislature was contained in letters sent yesterday by the Greater New York Federation of Churches to ministers in all boroughs except Brooklyn, which has a separate organization.
Andre Lefebre de Laboulaye, French Ambassador to the United States, will be guest of honor here during the celebration of French Day on Tuesday.

MADRID, Feb. 3. -- The Spanish Supreme Court today pardoned the four Americans who were sentenced on Jan. 19 by its military division to six months' imprisonment for assaulting a Civil Guard after a drinking party at Palma, Majorca.

THE Metropolitan Museum's current neighborhood exhibition at University Settlement will continue through Feb. 18. The Art of Ancient Egypt will open there on Feb. 24. At the Hudson Park branch of the Public Library, until March 18, Chinese and Japanese art will be shown under the auspices of Greenwich House.

Speculative enthusiasm flared up anew in the two-hour trading period on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The turnover was 2,081,000 shares, almost double that of the previous Saturday and the heaviest for any Saturday since July 22 of last year. The market closed strong and active after an irregular and hesitant opening.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 3. -- The Naval Academy opened its swimming season today by defeating Colgate, 46 to 25. Colgate's points were largely made up by its victory in the relay and Pankow's first in the backstroke event. The Navy took the six other firsts.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 3. -- In honor of their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Crocker of New York, who arrived today, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Minot Amory were dinner hosts tonight at their villa. Others present were:

WHILE theatrical interests are objecting to the broadcasters entertaining capacity studio audiences, thereby encroaching on the realm of theatrical entertainment, the headquarters of the major networks report the ticket demand for the popular broadcasts is "terrific."

JOSEPH M. SHENCK, president of United Artists and Twentieth Century Pictures, announced on his arrival in New York from Europe that he had arranged for the production of twenty films in England. London Films, headed by Alexander Korda, will make eight of the features and British and Dominions will produce twelve.

BUFFALO, Feb. 1. -- Erie County's archaic system of government is doomed. It must go the way of other antiques by action of the State Legislature, which will spend much of its 1934 session in discussion of county government reform. Though there will be few, if any, defenders of the old government, there will be much controversy in the Legislature over various reform plans.

MADRID, Feb. 2. -- The consolidation of Spain's Right Wing republican forces, as recommended without equivocation to Spanish Catholics by Pope Pius XI, advances steadily while dissension increases daily in the ranks of the Socialists, the Left Wing minority's backbone in the Cortes.

THIS book discusses the administration's program as seen by professional economists. The authors begin with the statement: "It is in no sense a pronouncement from the departments of Harvard University." They have avoided the use of too much technical language, and, as a whole, the book is a fair .discussion of the economics of the Roosevelt plan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Charges of contempt against William P. MacCracken, former Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Aeronautics, may be ordered by the Senate Monday, following further revelations made today before the Black committee in relation to the destruction of correspondence between Mr. MacCracken and airmail lines which were his clients.

Baseball's 1933-34 off season is scheduled to reach its dramatic moment tonight when more than 600 guests will crowd into the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore to attend the eleventh annual dinner and frolic of the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America.

The first few chapters of this novel make rather difficult going, for the author skips from one scene to another in a manner that is most confusing. But once one gets the idea of the story, one sees that it could scarcely be told so effectively in any other way.

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- The stock market was surprised today by the price of gold falling 1s 3d to 138s 3d an ounce although 960,000 of the metal was sold to the United States. Silver jumped to 19 5-16d an ounce, the highest since May, largely on Eastern and speculative account in view of possible developments in the United States monetary situation.

NEW ORLEANS. -- The claim that New Orleans has not known carnival, properly speaking, for these fifteen years gone by is to be tested on Feb. 13. which is "fat Tuesday," or Mardi Gras, the fittin and legal occasion for every soul in the city to get behind a mask and dance down the street.

ONE can believe that in Mr. Richard Stokes, the librettist of "Merry Mount," there burns a flaming hatred for religious fanaticism and the hypocrisy engendered in its train. One may suspect this as he peruses the text and the music, by Howard Hanson, of the opera which will be given its first performance on any stage by the Metropolitan Opera Association next Saturday afternoon.

Freight rates on motor truck and shipping codes should be based on the actual cost of service rather than on the rates charged by competing rail lines, according to leaders of shippers' groups in the metropolitan district.

MORE than a hundred painters and sculptors are represented in the exhibition of work by Brooklyn and Long Island artists at the Brooklyn Museum. Geographical boundaries have been kept elastic enough to permit inclusion of canvases by Shulamith Wittenberg, who was described at the time of her Roerich Museum show of Near East scenes and types, a few weeks ago, as "the first native Palestinian artist to exhibit in America."

This is the third of Mr. Gardner's stories about Perry Mason, the criminal lawyer who believes in taking chances and who suspects everybody, including his clients, of unworthy motives. He is engaged for the purpose of exposing a swindling racket and is paid a handsome fee.
In the interest of historical accuracy, may I correct some errors which appeared in THE TIMES regarding origin and early history of my great-grandfather, Isaac Moses.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 3. -- Rutgers defeated New York University in a dual swimming meet tonight, 38 -- 33. The Scarlet swimmers accounted for all the first places except the relay. Ted Brick was the only double winner of the evening, defeating Hower of N.Y.U. in both the 50-yard free style and the century.

The annual dinner dance in behalf of St. Vincent's Hospital will be held tomorrow at the Central Park Casino. During the evening there will be divertissements in which Miss Frances Maddux; Maurice and Cordoba, dancers, and Eddie Garr, impersonator, will take part.
BERLIN, Jan. 18. A WEEK or so ago the short announcement was given out that Hanns Johst had asked leave of absence from his position as artistic director of the Staatstheater.
BERLIN, Feb. 3. -- The German Government today published the text of its reply to the French disarmament proposals embodied in the memorandum delivered to Chancellor Hitler on Jan. 1.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will be welcomed to membership in the Women's University Club at a dinner in her honor Wednesday night at Sherry's, 500 Park Avenue.

GENEVA, Feb. 3. -- Seven moves have been made in quick succession in the past week on the European squares of the world's war-peace chessboard, on which the action is momentarily centred on pending Far Eastern developments.

THE aerodromes at Lympne, England, and St. Ingelvert, France, thirty-five miles apart, are now joined by a micro-wave radio communication system. Several engineering novelties are included; the aerials are less than an inch long and the power is less than required to light a pocket flashlamp.

THIS Spring brings the welcome news that Alpines and other serviceable garden plants from the mountains and from the high meadows of our own Northwest are to be much more easily obtained by gardeners ill other parts of the country.

Two additional parents' groups have been admitted to membership in the United Parents Associations, Mrs. Roger A. Johnson, president, announced. They are the Parents Associations of Public School 46, Bronx, of which Mrs. Herman Schulman is president, and of Public School 102 Bronx, of which Mrs. Celia Brownstein is president.

THERE is no such thing as "dated" music, according to Artur Rodzinski, director of the Cleveland Symphony Orchestra, who is guest conductor of WJZ's sixty-piece symphony orchestra this evening from 6 to 7 o'clock. The date on music means nothing, he asserts, because "the year in which music is written means absolutely nothing."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- As a result of complaints by employers, directed not at the President's Executive order on Wednesday concerning employe elections, but at the press release summary issued by the Recovery Administration, General Johnson and Donald R. Richberg, chief counsel of the NRA, issued a joint statement today to clarify the meaning of the order.

The next few years of railway operation are expected to disclose the relative merits of electrification as opposed to air-conditioning in the attracting of passengers to the rails. One electrical demonstration will be furnished by the Pennsylvania Railroad, which is embarked on a $180,000,000 project for applying the new power from New York to Washington.

Discoursing in The Quarterly Review on "The Taboo in-Music," Mr. CLEMENT HARRIS confesses that he got his general knowledge of taboos out of the encyclopedia, where he found no reference to those connected with music and its instruments. He might have added that they aren't mentioned in the one-volume edition of "The Golden Bough."

THE town of Mexicali, which lies just south of the California-Mexico boundary line, is reputed to be the toughest community near our own borders, an ill fame that seems to be solidly authenticated in the lurid pages of Mr. Graham's novel.

AFTER all these years the French are performing an act of poetic justice in restoring Longwood, on St. Helena, where Napoleon lived and died in exile. Compared to the Tuileries, Fontainebleau, Malmaison and the many palaces of others in which he had billeted himself as a conqueror, Longwood, it is true, was not much to look at.
TELL CITY, Ind., Feb. 3 (AP). -- Miss Alice Martin, who left the swinging trapeze of the circus tent about ten years ago, was found slain today on the 150-acre farm to which she had retired.

What was believed to be a forerunner of a shake-up in the Police Department's detective division was seen yesterday in changes announced by Commissioner O'Ryan. Besides promoting two deputy inspectors and two captains and demoting an inspector, he transferred Detective John J. Broderick, one of the best-known members of the department, a former member of the industrial and strong arm squads and a veteran of many fights with underworld characters.

SOFIA, Jan. 20. -- When the Agrarian ex-Minister Plenipotentiary Kosta Todoroff, who was allowed under amnesty to return to Bulgaria last March after ten years in exile, brought an action for libel against M. Krabtcheff, the editor of Zora, he partially won his case, to every one's surprise.

MONTREAL, Feb. 3. -- The New York Rangers took an undisputed lead in the American group of the American Hockey League with a 4-2 triumph over the Montreal Maroons before 6,000 fans tonight. The Rangers' victory gave them a two-point margin over the idle Chicago Black Hawks.
Alumni reunions, special conferences, social gatherings and other activities are included on the mid-Winter programs of several Eastern universities and colleges during February.

ROME, Feb. 3. -- In a regime such as the present Italian one, which exercises the strictest control over the press, it is more difficult to keep a finger on the pulse of public opinion than in other countries.

LONDON. TO the large number of strange insurance policies written at Lloyd's, another was recently added: A British circus proprietor, who offered to pay $100,000 for the capture alive of the "monster" reputed to inhabit Loch Ness, covered himself against the disbursement of this sum.

Subpoenas were served yesterday morning upon Austin H. MacCormick, Correction Commissioner, and his first deputy, David Marcus, by order of District Attorney Dodge, requiring them to appear before a grand jury at 11:30 tomorrow morning to tell what they know of crimes committed in the Welfare Island penitentiary.

ARCHIBALD MACLEISH has the extraordinary gift of being able to make the waste land of modern poetry bloom with infinite fertility. Many sanguinary rows rage around his head. He is vulnerable to the perpetual rediscovery that he has lived in the same age as Ezra Pound and T.S. Eliot without failing to be enriched by them.

This looks to be a novel. Its jacket hints at the fascinations of one story, "Such Men Are Dangerous." But it actually contains five stories -- three long and two very short. This really doesn't matter; it's all Elinor Glyn.

With a view to schooling its 500 employes thoroughly in the precepts of tee Securities Act of 1933 and to insure a high degree of ethical responsibility in all partners and employes who sell securities, one of the largest Stock Exchange firms has prepared a book of advice and suggestions dealing with questions raised by the act.

THIS little book is written by a young man -- after reading it one feels instinctively that he must be young -- who has returned to the Victorian age. Of course, there is nothing remarkably original in this, because for some years almost every one, especially in fashionable circles, has been reverting to Victorianism.

THE UNFINISHED DAY" is a simple chronicle novel of the sort that falls under the general heading of "success story." In it Alberta Stedman Eagan has drawn the portrait of an ambitious country youth, determined to go out into the world and make his fortune.

The LaGuardia administration gained control of the Triborough Bridge Authority yesterday when the Mayor dismissed John Stratton O'Leary as a commissioner and replaced him with Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

MIAMI -- The fourth annual international tropical flower show will be held in the Garden Theatre on March 1, 2 and 3. Mrs. J. Julien Southerland, president and founder of the show, is assured that the rarest orchids of growers in South American countries will be shown.

GREENWOOD, Miss., Feb. 3 (AP). -- The State today opened testimony in an attempt to prove that 33-year-old Dr. Sarah Ruth Dean, child specialist, caused the death of her friend and associate, Dr. John Preston Kennedy, prominent surgeon, by giving him a poisoned whiskey highball.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3. -- Captain Moe Goldman led the C.C. N.Y. basketball team to a 33-29 triumph over Temple at Mitten Hall tonight. The spectators, numbering ever 3,000, witnessed a thrilling court battle.

J. Howard Shoemaker successfully defended his national amateur pocket billiard title by defeating Edward Widtman, 125 to 82, in thirty-eight innings in the last match of the tournament at the New York A.C. yesterday. It was the nineteenth time Shoemaker has annexed the championship.

More than 200 guests, representing major and minor league baseball, celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the International League at a golden jubilee dinner last night in the Hotel Pennsylvania. All eight clubs in the circuit, the second oldest organization in organized baseball, were represented.

If you are fond of menus of chile con carne and enchiladas, romance spiced with danger and adventure seasoned with mystery, "The Caballero" should be your dish. It is served hot in Mexico and garnished with bandits and Mexican beauties.

PARIS, Feb. 3. -- Resentment against the American monetary policy is mounting fast in France. Despite official efforts to disguise this feeling, those who are following the situation closely here are convinced that there is not only great anxiety over the turn developments are taking but also anger against what is being characterized as a deliberate effort to embarrass France.

THE "Green Gold" expedition into Honduras has been postponed for the moment because of the unsettled conditions in that country. Charles R. Rogers planned to dispatch a camera unit very shortly from Hollywood to gather authentic locale and atmosphere scenes for "Green Gold," a novel of the banana industry by Rex Beach.

THE entire stretch of the Pan-American Highway running through Mexico from Laredo, Texas, to Mexico, D.F., will be sufficiently completed for comfortable travel next October, it was reported here last week by Mexican engineers visiting New York.

AFTER having ascended to a record height of 67,585 feet (12.79 miles), the Soviet stratosphere balloon Osoaviakhim came to a tragic end. In some way which will never be fully established the gondola, with its crew of three, crashed the ground, the gas bag rising again to drift off among the clouds.

Four gunners tied for the High Scratch Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday They were T.H. Lewis, Z.G. Simmons, T.H. Lawrence and Fred Cauchois. Each had 97 out of 100 targets. In the shoot-off Lewis prevailed by breaking 25 straight.

Word has been received here by the American Bible Society in Astor Place of the dedication of its new Bible house in Tokyo. The ceremony was attended by many notables of the empire, and addresses were made by Joseph Clark Grew, the American Ambassador and by His Excellency Ryutaro Nagai, Minister of Overseas of the Japanese Government.

BERLIN, Jan. 20. -- Germany, fifteen years after her collapse, feels that she is within the grasp of the third main objective of her after-war foreign policy -- military equality. The first two objectives in this policy of liberation were the evacuation of the Rhineland and the abolition of reparations.

The New York Curb Exchange announced yesterday that it had received from the Gatineau Power Company a notice relating to the payment of interest on the company's 6 per cent sinking-fund gold debentures due on June 15, 1941; its 6 per cent gold debentures.

THE twenty-fourth annual dinner and entertainment of the New York State Motor Truck Association will be held next Thursday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The entertainment will be staged by Earl Carroll and others.
GENEVA, Feb. 2. -- Washington's decision to register all its treaties with the League of Nations causes general satisfaction here, especially because of its psychological effect.

RADIO as a missionary for music is winning a multitude of converts, according to Sir Henry Wood, conductor of the Queens Hall concerts in London and guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.
Nancy Garner, cousin of the Vice President, will be heard with Paul Whiteman's Orchestra at the Biltmore tonight in soprano airs from "Rigoletto" and Herbert's "Sweethearts."

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Feb. 3 (AP). -- Under $100,000 bond, Verne Sankey and Gordon Alcorn, confessed kidnappers of Charles Boettcher 2d of Denver, were held in solitary confinement cells at State prison tonight while Federal officials laid plans for quick disposition of their case under instructions from Washington.
MILWAUKEE, Feb. 1. -- The Groundhog Club of Milwaukee celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary last Friday. It held a luncheon at the Blatz Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- On the heels of an adverse opinion from Attorney General Bennett of New York on the constitutionality of its milk-control program, the Agricultural Administration began its second attempt today to control prices paid to milk producers in the Chicago area.

NONSUCH ISLAND, the twenty-five-acre spot where Dr. William Beebe and his staff spent two seasons exploring the ocean's depths and studying the undersea life, has become a training school for Bermuda's delinquent boys. The buildings that served the scientists are now schoolrooms and dormitories.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- Many of the leading golfers wintering here and at Knollwood will meet on the links at Southern Pines Country Club on Tuesday in the opening of the men's tournament to be played over the No. 1 course.

Younger members of the American Woman's Association will give an entertainment to be known as "Hearts and Flowers, or the Stray Nineties," on the night of Feb. 10 at the clubhouse of the organization, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street. The ballroom will be decorated with the elaborate festooons and favors that characterized entertainments during the "mauve decade."

The Riverdale Country Day School blanked St. John's Prep of Brooklyn, 5 to 0, and the La Salle Military Academy of Oakdale turned back a Long Island rival, Lynbrook High School, 3 to 1, as play in the Inter-County Scholastic Ice Hockey League got under way at the New York Coliseum yesterday.

THE crime problem we have had with us always in recurring waves of intensity. It touches every one of us. It cannot be solved overnight or by any legislative or administrative nostrum. Its challenge can be met only by the cooperation and determination of every citizen.

William J. Bingham, director of athletics at Harvard, was elected yesterday as chairman of the 1936 Olympic track and field committee, the most important chairmanship of the twenty-three subcommittees that operate under the American Olympic committee.

GRADUALLY but quietly New York's police force is being reorganized. This is not surprising when one considers the career of its new commissioner. If past performances give any indication of future activities, the entrenchments of organized crime will fall before a steady and constant onslaught, unmarked by any unnecessary ballyhoo.

THE National Industrial Recovery Act introduced the most advanced labor legislation of a national character which this country has ever adopted. To the workers these labor provisions added a bright touch of color to an otherwise sombre picture of enhanced employer organization; to employers this color was much too red.

Two collections of etchings, color engravings and original drawings, assembled by Mrs. Henry D. Hughes of Philadelphia and a Brooklyn connoisseur, will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday evening.

Believe it or not, here is an Oppenheim story without a single scene laid in Monte Carlo. And high time, too, for that lode, profitable as it no doubt has been, has shown signs, of petering out. The entire action of this novel takes place in England, and most of the characters, with the exception of a few detectives, belong to the upper classes.

DENVER, Col.. Feb. 1. -- Climaxing a two months' undercover struggle between the State and national administrations, Harry L. Hopkins discharged the Colorado CWA committee this week and named C.D. Shawver, Civil Works Administrator, in its place.

A book that may owner of an irrepressible but delightful puppy will thoroughly enjoy. It is friendly, informal and spiced with humor. When Dashenka was born she was a white bit of nothing, but puppies grow rapidly and soon Dashenka is learning the mysteries of walking, drinking milk and climbing stairs.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 3. -- Exhibition matches featured the program as the Georgian Court College conducted its second annual sports day today with about 175 persons present. Miss Beatrice B. Moore, athletic director, was in charge of the event.

The differential set up in the master wholesale code will heavily penalize the small retailer in his efforts to compete with chains and other large distributers, John Block of the resident-buying firm of Kirby, Block Fischer, said here yesterday.

WITH the renewal of the Nazi campaign of violence in Austria and the possibility of an appeal to the League of Nations, the plight of Austria is again at the forefront of European politics. Though the Nazi agitation is directed and financed from Germany, by the party which is identical with the German State, Chancellor Hitler in a speech before the Reichstag last week denied responsibility for it and ridiculed the Austrian Government's protest.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The limited scope of operations under the Securities Act in the last three months of 1933 was shown today in a report by the Federal Trade Commission. Security issues which became effective during the period numbered 129, and the gross proceeds totaled $173,455,093.

NOMINATED in the prospectus as the New Boston Opera Company, an interesting group of singers will appear this week at the Boston Opera House. The promoter is Tommaso Nazzaro, who organized a single performance of "Tosca" there last November.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Confidence that stability of international exchange would be accomplished relatively soon and end many of the uncertainties hampering world recovery was expressed today in responsible quarters. France's importance in the picture is realized, and it is believed here that the drain on her gold supply will end before enough is withdrawn to endanger her standard.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- With an understanding that the Administration wants to do something more soon for silver, the House Coinage Committee outlined today a broad schedule for its study of the Dies Bill, under which the Treasury would accept silver in payment for exported farm surpluses.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 3. -- Yale defeated Army at wrestling. 27 to 5, in the outstanding athletic attraction here today. The Elis won in seven of eight classes, three blue-clad grapplers triumphing on falls.

The first in a series of musicales by children of the Third Street Musical School Settlement will be held this afternoon in the auditorium of the Nightingale-Bamford School, 20 East Ninety-second Street. Another in the series, which is given under the auspices of the Third Street Music School, will take place the afternoon of March 11 in the auditorium of Miss Chapin's School.

BERLIN, Feb. 3. -- The Boerse maintained firmness today, although it was less pronounced and less uniform than yesterday. Some issues closed with moderate declines, which were generally attributed to profit-taking for professional account, but most stocks were unchanged or higher.

The demonstration of strength in the bond market last week, with the volume of trading in domestic corporation bonds the heaviest on record, eclipsed the showing of the share and other markets. The 59.06- cent dollar, with its national and international ramifications, touched off the pent-up potential demand for bonds of virtually every shade of credit rating.

Restoration of the gold standard in the United States last week completely altered the relationship among the three great currencies of the world -- the dollar, sterling and the franc -- opening possibilities of further readjustments, the consequences of which were only dimly discernible to experienced bankers in this city.

WHAT is the college girl like today? How does she view the world, as compared with the college girl of five or ten or twenty years ago? Two things you may be sure of, whatever the date when these questions are asked.

ALEXANDRE TCHEREPNINE'S one-act opera of Russian student life, "Ol-Ol," is scheduled for presentation by the Russian Opera Company at the Casino Wednesday night on a double bill with Tchaikovsky's "Iolanthe." Both are said to be first New York performances, and the Tcherepnine work will constitute an American premiere.

HELSINGFORS, Feb. 3. -- Continued night flights over Northern Finland, Sweden and Norway by so-called "ghost" aviators, which have caused such apprehension here as to prompt the general staff to organize reconnoitring on a wide scale by army planes all over Northern Finland, still remain a deep mystery.

Gounod's "Romeo et Juliette" for the first time this season and the fiftieth in the records of New York's chief opera house, was sung at the Metropolitan last evening as a special performance for the benefit of the French Hospital. A personal incident was the return of another American singer, Charles Hackett, to opera on Broadway.
Governors Island tallied an upset triumph and the N.Y.A.C. registered an impressive victory in Metropolitan Indoor Polo League games at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night.

A wintry setting will lend an appropriate seasonal touch to the sixth annual Russian students' ball to be given on Friday night in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton. Proceeds from the dance are to aid unemployed students of the Russian Alumni and Students' Association.

THIS is an odd year in the theatre. With some few exceptions the drama has settled back comfortably into the old niche of public amusement. You hear very little about art these days. The old weary round of tawdry infidelities appears to be what the public ordered, and the moneychangers in the box-offices are fairly cheerful again.

Larry Hull and George Carter, who are leading members of both the Poly Prep hockey and wrestling squads, are two of the outstanding athletes at the Brooklyn school at the present time. Hull, who is captain of the hockey team, is a senior, but Carter has another year at Poly, for he is a member of the junior class.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1. -- "Tell me, why should an American worker work better for General Motors or Ford than our workers in their own proletarian country?" This question was asked in a speech made by one of the most important Bolshevist leaders, G.K. Ordzhonikidze, member of the Communist Political Bureau and Commissar for Heavy Industry.

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- Under the impetus of United States devaluation the transatlantic gold rush got well under way today, with airplanes, motor trucks and railways pressed into service to get bullion to the Berengaria and the Bremen, the first available liners out.

ANDOVER, Mass., Feb. 3. -- Andover's basketball and hockey teams were successful in their clashes today. The quintet defeated Worcester Academy, 24 to 23, and the sextet triumphed over St. Mark's, 4 to 3.

Commissioners of the West Park District, Chicago, announced yesterday a plan for rehabilitating the district's finances. The program, based on legislation passed by the Legislature last June, calls for issuing $19,500,000 of twenty-year funding and refunding bonds and selling for cash $2.000,000 of ten year working cash-fund bonds.

VIENNA, Feb. 3. -- There is still great uncertainty concerning the situation in Tyrol. Innsbruck and other cities are still filled with armed Heimwehr troopers. Prince von Starhemberg has gone down to investigate the situation following Dr. Richard Steidle, who left Vienna yesterday.

MOSCOW, Feb. 3. -- In a vigorous speech made Wednesday to the All-Union Communist Congress but issued only tonight, Klementi Voroshiloff, Commissar for War and Marine, declared the Red Army was now more mechanized than most Western forces.

PARIS, Feb. 3. -- Another Cabinet crisis occurred today as a result of the dismissal of Jean Chiappe as Prefect of the Paris Police by Premier Daladier. Francois Pietri, Minister of Finance and Budget, and Lieut. Col. Jean Fabry, Minister of War and National Defense, resigned.

The first drop since 1925 in the suicide rate was one feature of the health record of 1933 among the millions of industrial policyholders of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Louis I. Dublin, third vice-president and statistician of the insurance company.

Lacrosse, widely considered the only truly American game we have, because of its descent from the American Indian, appears to be going through something of an increase in interest and at present organized efforts are being made to spread its popularity.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 3. -- The annual invitation Class B squash racquets tournament of the Round Hill Club got under way today, and competition extended all the way through the quarter-final round. W.K. Rice of the Harvard Club of New York, first-seeded player in the tourney, was among those who survived the opening day's play.

SAPULPA, Okla., Feb. 3. -- National Guard troops tonight patrolled this city of 10,000, fourteen miles from Tulsa, to prevent the lynching of Eldon Wilson, a white man of Sand Springs, after Wilson and four or five companions had killed two police officers in a battle at an abandoned farmhouse a mile from here.

The Rev. Dr. Malcolm James MacLeod has resigned as pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, at the south corner of the Rockefeller development. Dr. MacLeod has asked that his resignation take effect on next Jan. 1, on his completion of a quarter of a century as pastor here and of forty years in the ministry.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 3. -- Buzz Borries, Navy's versatile sports star, played a brilliant game today as the Middie basketball team turned back the University of Maryland quintet, 46 to 27.

IT is the view of astute politicians that Senator Huey P. Long, self-styled Kingfish of Louisiana, is on his way out. They base their conclusions on the outcome of the recent city election, in which the Long ticket was snowed under; the recent election fiasco in the Sixth Congressional District, and a revolt among followers of the Senator that is said to be State-wide.

SO vigorous and so universal has been the swing toward extreme nationalism, which in some countries has lately become an article of faith not to be debated or questioned, that it has seemed as if the nationalists had the field to themselves.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 3. -- Hard riding and accurate hitting marked the play of Army's indoor polo team today as it defeated the Pennsylvania Military College trio, 14 -- 10. This event featured the day's sports program here.

LONDON. EVERY day when Parliament is in session the City Remembrancer sits behind the Speaker's chair in the House of Commons listening to, but never taking part in, the proceedings. His job -- or the main part of it -- is to see that bills laid before Parliament do not infringe the ancient rights and liberties of the City of London.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 1. -- Restoration of peace in the Oregon State system of higher education appears to be imminent. For two years there have been charges of discrimination against the University of Oregon by Chancellor William J. Kerr, former president of Oregon State College, but agreement approaches with the appointment of acting presidents for the State College and the university with power to prepare their own budgets.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 3. -- Tommy Goodwin, representing the Monroe (N.Y.) Country Club, won the seventh annual national championship of golf club champions by defeating Bill Stark, University of Florida football star, in the 36-hole final on the St. Augustine links today.

IF any one expressed doubt concerning the plausibility of the action of the film, "Four Frightened People," its producer, Cecil B. De Mille, might easily ask what the person knew about the Malay Peninsula or what study he had given to the way two men and two women might behave when lost in a jungle.

HOLLYWOOD. APRETENTIOUS start for John Hay Whitney's Pioneer Productions unit at RKO-Radio was indicated this week with the announcement of "Cyrano de Bergerac" and "The Last Days of Pompeii" as the first two films to be made by the new Technicolor process which Mr. Whitney controls.

Unusually cold weather beset the city again yesterday for the second time during the week, sending the mercury down to 4 degrees above zero at 8 A.M., the lowest point ever officially recorded here on a Feb. 3.
