PARIS, Feb. 4. -- Since the end of the last century there has not been a disturbance of the political structure of the French Republic like that resulting from the revelation and exploitation of the Stavisky scandal, in which large sums were lost in the collapse of the Bayonne municipal pawnshop.
SALISBURY MILLS, N.Y., Feb. 4. -- Executing both of his flights with grace and assurance, Harald Sorensen regained the New York State Class A ski-jumping championship today.

Avoiding any possibility of precipitate action on the all-important question of accepting or rejecting Germany's invitation to the 1936 Olympic Games, the American Olympic Committee sidestepped the issue at its meeting at the New York Athletic Club yesterday and referred the matter to its executive committee with full powers to act.

THE TIMES'S left-handed editorial about the speech of former Secretary of the Treasury Ogden Mills at Topeka provokes a weak smile. You expect, it seems, an angelic attitude of sweet reasonableness on the part of those who play the pawns of politics. Has "the application of reason and persuasion to public affairs," the lack of which you rightly deplore in the diatribe of Joe Robinson, ever obtained in mere politics?

LONDON, Feb. 4. -- Although $35,000,000 of gold is already on the Atlantic, there is no sign tonight that the gold rush to New York is slackening. Seven liners are scheduled to leave the Channel ports for America this week, and space on all has been booked for gold.

The resignation of the Rev. Dr. Malcolm James MacLeod as pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, has not yet been accepted by the Consistory of the Collegiate Reformed Protestant Dutch Church of the City of New York, it was learned last evening.

With reports on January retail trade showing the best gains since 1929, activity in the wholesale markets here last week was well maintained. While the cold weather in many sections retarded Spring merchandising to some extent, reorders on suits and dresses were received in good volume from stores in areas unaffected by the drop in temperatures.

Responsibility for preserving the democratic ideal and for setting and maintaining a high intellectual and ethical standard for the nation rests with the college student, Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, and other speakers told members of the Federation of College Catholic Clubs of New York at their annual communion breakfast at the Hotel Commodore yesterday.
The NRA has notified shipping interests that it will grant no further hearings on the proposed code of ethics for the shipping industry and that any new evidence must be submitted within seven days.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- About one-fifth of all internal revenue collected in the calendar year 1933 came from New York State, according to figures made public today by the Treasury Department.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- A bill to encourage enactment of State unemployment insurance or reserve laws by State Legislatures will be introduced in Congress tomorrow by Senator Wagner of New York and Representative Lewis of Maryland.

Suppose there was an important four-track railroad running through a fertile territory, some of the largest cities in America, a total population of 50,000,000, from New York to 200 miles west of Omaha. In every way the railroad was a great success, most vital and necessary, except the sixty miles at the east end, and this because these last few miles were single track and narrow gauge.

The police drive on gambling netted 185 prisoners over the week-end as activities against policy racketeers were broadened, permitting detectives and patrolmen to search known policy game collectors for evidence even if the suspects had not been caught collecting.

If present "false philosophies" should retain their influence in America, another 150 years would see the country divided into two camps -- one of Peter and the other of Pan, or paganism, it was predicted by the Rev. Fulton J. Sheen, Professor of Philosophy at Catholic University, Washington, D.C., at the annual communion breakfast given yesterday morning by the Catholic Club for the Board of Education Bureau of Attendance at the Waldorf-Astoria.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 4. -- Two new interstate outdoor speed skating champions were crowned today as Cliff Spellman and Miss Helen Bahil won by narrow margins on historic Hessian Lake.

BERLIN, Feb. 3. -- The fixation of the dollar's gold content was regarded favorably by banks and newspapers here but there was criticism that the possibility of a later alteration of value remained. This expresses the persistent German view that a return to gold currencies everywhere is inevitable.

The third performance of the Brooklyn season by the Metropolitan Opera Association will be the presentation of "Faust" tonight with Mmes. Rethberg and Swarthout and Messrs. Martinelli, Pinza and Bonelli.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Jan. 31 shows increases for the week of $138,000,000 in loans, $541,000,000 in United States Government securities, $46,000,000 in other securities and $605,000,000 in government deposits, and a decrease of $176,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5. -- Thirty New York and Philadelphia policemen and detectives raided a West Philadelphia apartment late today and captured William Sutton, who, they said, admitted participation in the $23,000 hold-up of the Corn Exchange Bank branch at 110th Street and Broadway, New York, on July 8.

The swallowing of three glasses full of a "reddish liquid" thirty years ago -- a liquid gulped in the interest of science -- may receive appropriate legislative recognition from Congress this year if George S. Ward wins his long fight.

" Dodsworth," the Sidney Howard-Sinclair Lewis play which began a try-out engagement in Philadelphia on Saturday, is expected to arrive on Broadway during the week of Feb. 26, at an unspecified theatre on Forty-fourth Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5. -- Prices of wheat were on the up-grade today on the Board of Trade, with much local and scattered buying induced by the strength in stocks. Outside trade, however, increased only moderately, despite further reports of dust storms over parts of South Dakota, Nebraska and Kansas.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Harry H. Woodring, Assistant Secretary of War, announced tonight that Joseph Silverman, described as a dealer in army surpluses with offices in New York and Washington, had been barred from doing business with the War Department.

For four months Frank Fisher, 23 years old, of 2,307 Tiebout Place, the Bronx, worked daily about the garage at 2,208 Folin Street, the Bronx, although the body of his predecessor as manager, Raymond Cortez, 48, was in an ash heap in the garage basement where he had buried it, Fisher told the police last night.

LIMA, Feb. 5. -- The government organ comments on the favorable reaction in New York in the last four weeks on Peru's external loans contracted by previous governments. A cable was received saying that national loans closed at 15 per cent and the tobacco loan at 13 per cent.

The Transit Commission applied yesterday to the Appellate Division for a writ of mandamus directing the Board of Estimate to appropriate $400,000 for salaries and expenses chargeable to the city under State law. The board, following the leadership of Mayor LaGuardia, recently turned down the commission's request for an appropriation of $76,000 to meet salaries and expenses for February.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- A bill to encourage the enactment of unemployment insurance laws in the various States was introduced in both houses today by the authors, Senator Wagner of New York and Representative Lewis of Maryland.

BERLIN, Feb. 5. -- Representatives of Germany's foreign bank creditors met at the Reichsbank today to discuss with the German debtors' committee the conditions under which the present standstill agreement is to be renewed for another year.

The fight to "dethrone" Joseph N. Weber as "czar" of the American Federation of Musicians will reach a climax on March 12, it developed yesterday after a turbulent meeting of more than 3,000 members of the Associated Musicians of Greater New York, comprising Local 802 of the federation, at 210 East Eighty-sixth Street.

A total of 5,686 liquor licenses were issued in New York City and adjoining counties up to Jan. 22, it was announced yesterday by Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board.

W.T. Grant--Sales of the W.T. Grant Company for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31 amounted to $78,206,121, the largest in the history of the company. This compares with $73,086,856 in the preceding fiscal year, an increase of 7 per cent. For January, sales were $4,832,562 against $4,272,879, a gain of 13.1 per cent over the same month last year.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 5 (AP). -- The round-by-round description of the Maxie Rosenbloom-Joe Knight bout tonight follows:

William L. Bragg, Professor of Physics at Manchester University, winner of the Nobel Prize in 1915 for his researches on the structure of solids and of the Franklin Gold Medal from the Franklin Institute in 1930 for his studies in atomic and molecular structures, arrived yesterday on the White Star liner Georgic.

M'SIEU LESTAIRRE PATRICK, bettairre he look out, bagosh! Those Canadiens, they go not home after they have pushed the Americans around the Garden rink. Lafayette, they are still here! They like the ice. They like the snow. They linger for more fun ce soir, name of a pipe!

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 5. -- The Lone Star Stable's lightly regarded Skunner led home eight other 3-year-olds in the featured Atlanteans Claiming Purse at the Fair Grounds today. Skunner finished two lengths before Samuel Molay's Otterrop in the six-furlong dash.

Mae West, the all-too-trustful sea lion, late of the Bronx Zoo, is dead -- dead, like Lycidas, ere her prime. It wasn't nostalgia for the seal washed Pacific promontories, it wasn't for love, and it wasn't of old age (for Mae was still in the first blush of her youth and beauty).

GREENWOOD, Miss., Feb. 5 (AP). -- With the calm attention with which she might have watched a clinical operation, Dr. Sarah Ruth Dean, 33 years old, today heard the State, which has charged her with murder for the death of Dr. John Preston Kennedy, introduce a deathbed statement in which Kennedy was said to have accused her of giving him a poisoned whisky highball at a midnight visit to her home.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Permission was refused to Alabama by the Supreme Court today to bring suit against Arizona, Idaho, Montana, New York and Pennsylvania to prevent them from enforcing laws prohibiting the sale of prison-made goods.

The executive committee of the Association of Federation Workers, which includes more than 500 employes of institutions and agencies supported by the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, voted unanimously last night to call for a "stoppage" of work in all federation agencies from 3 to 5 o'clock tomorrow afternoon.

Considerably refreshed after their twenty-four-hour respite following their participation in the baseball writers' dinner last Sunday night, the club owners of the National League will stage the concluding number of the current off-season today with the holding of their annual schedule meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria.

A commercial lease involving two floors in the building at 444 Madison Avenue has been signed by the Rubber Manufacturers Association, A.L. Viles president. The trade association, which has been at 250 West Fifty-seventh Street for the last twelve years, found larger quarters necessary because it has been designated as the administrative agency for the NRA Rubber Industry Code.

The Welfare Council, which is conducting a campaign for the eradication of street begging in the city, made public yesterday a list of places and agencies where homeless persons may obtain assistance.

Oil paintings and dental instruments, water-colors and false teeth are some of the ingredients of the combination art and historical dental exhibition to be opened today at the New York Academy of Medicine by the First District Dental Society, whose membership consists of Manhattan dentists.

Evidence that 1933 was a turning point in railroad history is afforded in a report for that period issued yesterday by the Bureau of Railway Economics which showed that freight revenue increased by 1.7 per cent while the percentage of decline in passenger revenues was the smallest to be reported in years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Pre-repeal prohibition cases, originating prior to Dec. 5, 1933, variously estimated at between 9,000 and 13,000, were in effect stricken from the dockets of Federal courts throughout the country today under a decision of the Supreme Court, written by Chief Justice Hughes.

MONTAGUE GLASS is dead before his time, yet for some years it has been obvious that his contribution to our literature and to his own place in it was completed. Playing around with the adjective "immortal" is a risky business, but Abe Potash and Mawruss Perlmutter belong in the gallery of the world's great comic characters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP). -- The long-standing boundary dispute between New Jersey and Delaware to determine jurisdiction over parts of the Delaware River and Bay was settled by a compromise today in an opinion delivered to the Supreme Court by Justice Cardozo.
KANSAS CITY, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Successful "pinch hitting" at the piano for an exacting prima donna has brought Miss Gayle Giles a six-week concert contract at a salary she describes as "handsome."

Continued low temperatures in many sections of the country were reflected in some slowing up of the recent pace of buying in the wholesale markets here. There was, however, some call for Winter goods, stocks of which have been sharply depleted at retail.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 5. -- A decision of Federal Judge Jones of Cleveland, announced here today, declared that patents held by the General Electric Company for the manufacture of incandescent electric bulbs were invalid.

John J. Broderick, Patrick D. Kennealy and Thomas A. Smith, the three detectives who denied before Police Commissioner O'Ryan on Saturday reports that they obtained assignments in the District Attorney's office through political influence, were put back into uniform yesterday.

Directors of the Yorkville Music School headed by Mrs. George S. Dearborn have taken over the performance of "The Shining Hour," the night of Feb. 16 at the Booth Theatre to augment the scholarship fund and to further the social service work of the organization.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Search for insurance papers was planned tonight by officers investigating the murder of the Rev. Gaylord V. Saunders. Fred Simon, chief of Indianapolis detectives, received reports from Wabash indicating that the minister carried policies amounting to $15,000.

Mayor LaGuardia has ordered a study of the cost to the city of street lighting and of the lighting of public buildings, it became known yesterday. He acted on reports that the city has paid the companies with whom it has contracts about $10,000,000 a year for the last five years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Property owners whose tenants go into bankruptcy do not have a provable claim as creditors for the difference between the sum due under a lease and the amount likely to be realized from re-renting the property, the Supreme Court held today in an opinion by Justice Roberts.

In a letter sent to stockholders of the Hupp Motors Corporation, Charles D. Hastings, president, and Charles E. Gambill, chairman of the administrative committee, have urged the shareholders not to submit proxies for their stock to a minority group, known as Hupp Stockholders, Inc. F.W. Burnside Jr., president of the latter corporation, requested the proxies in a recent circular.
Winthrop Aldrich Rockefeller, fourth son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr., has resigned from Yale University, where he has been a student for three years, it became known last night.
Two investment purchases of large industrial buildings on the West Side were among the Manhattan realty items reported yesterday.
Coach Hubert Glendon had twenty-five varsity rowing candidates working out yesterday on the machines in the Columbia gymnasium as the Lions staged their first official drill of the year.

His department survey almost completed, Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Hospitals Commissioner, announced yesterday plans to slash his payroll by $250,000 a year through the elimination of useless jobs, including about 300 held by "political appointees."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The National Labor Board moved for a "showdown" with the Weirton Steel Company today by assigning its general counsel, Milton Handler and James F. Dewey, of the United States Department of Labor, to proceed to ascertain the sentiment of the 10,000 steel employes toward an election of spokesmen for collective bargaining.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Three 1901-1905 Gibson Girls, pompadours and all -- Eleanor Roosevelt, Mary Harriman and Isabella Selmes -- will be belles of the Junior League ball here Friday night.

The money market was quiet at the opening of business in the new week. Quotations for all classifications were carried forward without change from last week. Stock Exchange call loans were done at 1 per cent and Street funds 3/4@7/8. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were steady.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5. -- Dr. H. Parker Willis, Professor of Banking at Columbia University, declared here today that the economic policies of the New Deal did not have the general academic support attributed to them.

Lord and Lady Sackville, Lord Marley and Lady Clipperton are among the passengers arriving today from Southampton and Havre on the White Star liner Olympic. Others coming on the ship include Captain Alfred Anson, youngest son of the Earl of Lichfield; Senator Lorne C. Webster of Canada, Dr. Harvey Farmer and the Rev. Margaret Joshua.
MONTREAL, Feb. 5 (Canadian Press). -- The big three in National Hockey League scoring this season advanced solidly during the past week to gain a wide margin over all other marksmen.

Teachers of the city oppose the LaGuardia Economy Bill in its present form because "it would turn over the control and direction of education to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment," Rufus M. Hartill, president of the Protestant Teachers Association, told the Greater New York Federation of Churches at its annual union meeting of metropolitan churches yesterday morning.

Justices Flood, McInerney and Caldwell in Special Sessions yesterday handed down the first decision in this city upholding the State Schackno law, the enabling act against price-cutting under the NRA code. They found the Spotless Dollar Cleaning Corporation, the main office of which is at 245 West Seventy-second Street, guilty of ignoring the act and imposed a $500 fine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The possibility of a new step in connection with the monetary use of silver was indicated today when Secretary Morgenthau said that the Treasury Department had begun an inquiry into speculative holdings of the metal within the United States.

LONDON, Feb. 5 (Canadian Press). -- Before an enthusiastic audience which jammed the Hammersmith Theatre tonight, Sir Henry Lytton, famous exponent of the principal characters of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, received a testimonial from his admirers all over the world.
LONDON, Feb. 5. -- Austria's decision to appeal to the League of Nations is highly embarrassing to the British Government while disarmament negotiations are still in progress.

PARIS, Feb. 5. -- Schiaparelli develops her stormy weather line into a typhoon with stiffened trimmings imitating exotic fish fins soaring from the shoulder blades and huge bird-tail bustles for afternoon and evening. Her belted sports coats often have funnel-shaped reveres and pockets or pleats in front.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- An injunction which aimed to check the New York "poultry racket" was upheld by the Supreme Court today in a ruling on an appeal by organizations and individuals from the order which was issued by the Southern District Court of New York.

After the regional labor board had intervened yesterday in the strike of hotel and restaurant workers in an effort to bring about a settlement, violence broke out with a riot in front of the Waldorf-Astoria and an attack by a mob of strikers on the Casino de Paree in Fifty-fourth Street near Eighth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Sharper regulation by the Shipping Board Bureau of steamship rates subject to its jurisdiction was thought imminent today after an announcement by Secretary Roper of a general reorganization of that agency.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 5. -- Lieutenant Thomas Hamilton will supplant Edgar A. (Rip) Miller as head football coach at the United States Naval Academy, it was learned today.

Senator Wagner's hill for Federal encouragement of the enactment of unemployment insurance laws by State Legislatures was characterized last evening as an inadequate step in the right direction by Louis Waldman, co-chairman of the national public affairs committee of the Socialist party.

Net profit of the Bohn Aluminum Brass Corporation and subsidiaries in 1933 amounted to $1,494,552 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This was equal to $4.24 a share on 352,418 shares of $5 par capital stock and contrasted with a net loss of $720,568 after interest, depreciation, taxes and inventory write-offs in 1932.

BERLIN, Feb. 5. -- A growing tendency to reject Christianity altogether instead of trying to Germanize it is adding to the acerbity and confusion of the church conflict in Nazi Germany. The confusion is worse confounded by the circumstance that the advocates of Nordic paganism are even more divided in their ideas of the proper Germanic substitute for Christianity than they are united in their opposition to Christianity.

Having considerable material on hand, Anne Morrison Chapin has distributed it with a lavish hand throughout "No Questions Asked," which was played at the Masque last evening. Mrs. Chapin is the Anne Morrison who collaborated two or three seasons ago with J.P. Toohey on a frolicsome skit labeled "Jonsey."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- A bill for regulation of Stock Exchanges, with the Federal Trade Commission as the enforcing agency and a licensing system, is being prepared for presentation in the Senate by Senator Fletcher, chairman of the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 5. -- The new Balkan pact is regarded by Bulgarian political circles as a manifestation of no particular importance for the Balkans. It is pointed out here that the pact will lack the signatures of Bulgaria and Albania as the only two countries in the Balkans that have territorial claims against the beneficiaries of the peace treaties.

HAVANA, Tuesday, Feb. 6. -- A twenty-four hour general strike of all workers in all lines in Havana has been called for midnight tonight in sympathy with the striking employes of the Compania Cubana de Electricidad.

Those of your readers who are unable to see whence the government will obtain the enormous profit on its gold holdings through remonetization may be interested in a problem once placed before me by a professor of political economy of similar stripe to those guiding our present administration. The problem follows:

An informal presentation of the City College alumni's plan to have Benny Friedman coach the C.C. N.Y. football team next Fall was made yesterday in a conference among President Frederick B. Robinson, the committee, and Maurice Deiches, a member of the college board of trustees.

Every day, almost every hour, the taxicab strike passes into a new phase. Yesterday its leaders said that the thing had gone far beyond the first demand that the tax money be given to the drivers. It had become, they said, a question of recognizing their union. But, as Ar. ERNST, appointed arbitrator by the Aayor, at once said to them, such recognition is already guaranteed to them under the National Recovery Act.

LONDON, Feb. 5. -- The movement of American capital back to the United States which set in three weeks ago, has not yet assumed anything like the total of its flight from home during the latter part of 1933.

Strong protests against the Vinson naval building program, now pending in the Senate, were made yesterday at a luncheon of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom at the Fraternity Clubs Building, Thirty-eighth Street and Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Life in the capital in these times is not wholly given up to somber or momentous things. It contains other elements than epochal experiments, owlish pronouncements from brain-trusters and predictions of approaching national doom from those who are frightened by the New Deal.

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- A bill to create an authority to supervise construction and operation of a $10,000,000 marine parkway and causeway in Kings and Queens Counties with the aid of PWA funds was introduced tonight in the Senate.

Jim Londos, the sturdy Greek, made a triumphal return to Madison Square Garden last night after an absence of three years and threw Ernie Dusek, Omaha, Neb., in 46 minutes 38 seconds. Londos scored with an airplane spin and body slam in a finish exhibition that attracted 8,000 fans.

Commissioner McELLIGOTT'S statement reveals a remarkable drop last year in both fires and fire losses. The former fell from 31,000 to 26,000, in round numbers; the latter from $18,000,000 to $10,000,000, a decrease of 46 per cent. The fire loss per capita has run as follows during the last four years: $2.61, $2.17, $2.48, $1.32.

" Long Remember," by MacKinlay Kantor, is to be the Literary Guild book for April. Coward-McCann, which had scheduled this novel about the Civil War for Feb. 26, has moved the publication date on to April 2.

A warning expressly "intended for all banks and bankers" was uttered here last night by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. He said that if they did not assume their full share in the recovery program by providing proper credit for private enterprise, "there can be but one alternative -- government lending."

Resuming dividends after a lapse of more than two years, directors of the International Nickel Company voted yesterday to make a payment of 10 cents a share on common stock, payable on March 31 to stock of record of March 1. Robert C. Stanley, president, said:

At the suggestion of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare, called a meeting at his office yesterday to consider a program of assistance for unemployed and needy women who are homeless and unattached.
MOSCOW, Feb. 5. -- For the first time since September, 1932, the Soviet Government publishes the joint figures for chervontzi and treasury notes in circulation and the gold backing for them.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 5. -- The Paraguayan War Ministry announces the capture yesterday of the Bolivian stronghold, Fort Lachina, and the seizure of a large quantity of war materials.

CANNELTON, Ind., Feb. 5 (AP). -- To Perry County authorities today Ernest Wright, 32-year-old farm hand, told a weird story of having witnessed the murder of his employer, Miss Alice Martin, and of having been compelled by the slayer to bury the woman's body in the barn lot of her farm home on an Ohio River bluff.

Wall Street was not surprised, after Saturday's unexpected outburst, to see the market so active yesterday, but the Stock Exchange picture was somewhat remarkable nevertheless. What seemed to be the most logical explanation for the increase in speculative enthusiasm was that the bond market had begun to attract attention everywhere.
The obituary notices for Montague Glass naturally did not contain an account of two minor but interesting events in his life.

In a tense and exciting match that marked the opening of the world's three-cushion billiard championship last night, Alfredo De Oro, 71-year-old Cuban veteran, defeated the defending titleholder, Welker Cochran, 50 to 49.

Police Commissioner O'Ryan's drive against the policy racket resulted yesterday in the arraignment of the first group of seventy-five offenders before Justices Herbert, Kernochan and Murphy in Special Sessions. It was the largest number of such cases ever called in that court in one day.

Ferdinand S. Pecora, special counsel to the Senate Committee on Banking and former chief Assistant District Attorney of New York County, testified before Supreme Court Justice William Harman Black and a jury yesterday that he believed it virtually impossible for the Health Commissioner to eliminate graft by department inspectors.
A drop of 19,405 in the number of passenger and commercial cars registered in New York City compared with the corresponding period of last year was revealed yesterday at the Bureau of Motor Vehicles.

I always thought there existed a city ordinance compelling shopkeepers and owners of property to clean the snow from their sidewalks. Even in the times of so-called graft-ridden Tammany, I have never witnessed such flagrant disregard for the safety of the pedestrian.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 (AP). -- An unscheduled death drama broke into the broadcast of radio station KHJ here today.

In the third of a series of attacks on the proposed treaty with Canada for the development of the St. Lawrence waterway, the Merchants Association charged yesterday that inaccurate data had been used by a special interdepartmental committee in a report on the economic aspects of the project which it submitted on Jan. 10 to President Roosevelt.

Announcement was made yesterday by Colonel Walter A. DeLamater, acting Civil Works Administrator for New York City, that in the future requisitions for skilled labor for CWA projects would be made upon recognized labor unions of the city.

Graduation exercises were conducted yesterday afternoon by the Hospital Service department of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross at the Chapter House, 315 Lexington Avenue. There were thirty women in the graduating class.

The annual dinner dance in aid of St. Vincent's Hospital took place last night at the Central Park Casino. During the evening there were divertissements by Miss Frances Maddux, Maurice and Cordoba, dancers, and Eddie Garr, impersonator, all of whom donated their services.
LONDON, Feb. 5. -- Gold rose 1s 9d today to a new high record of 7 an ounce, and 1,540,000 was sold in the bullion market in keen bidding for shipment to the United States.

Again the Administration is trying to work out a plan for sugar. Six months ago quotas were allotted tentatively to various groups of producers. But nothing came of this scheme, since Secretary WALLACE finally decided that it was not practicable, partly because of "uncertainties regarding Cuban production" and partly because of "difficulties of operation" revealed by further study of the proposed arrangement.

VIENNA, Feb. 5. -- The Austrian Cabinet sat all afternoon considering Austria's situation in regard to Germany in the light of the German note replying to Austrian complaints. The outcome of these deliberations was that the Chancellor was empowered to carry Austria's case to the League of Nations and take any further steps which might be necessary to prosecute that appeal.

A further advance on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried quotations of near months to the highest levels since in 1930, although the most distant delivery fell 4 points short of the 12.52-cent mark made last July. For several hours buying orders poured in from foreign and domestic quarters, absorbing heavy profit-taking operations at a gain of nearly $1 a bale at one time.

In a deal reported to involve more than $2,000,000, the Trinity Church Corporation yesterday announced the purchase of a skyscraper in the downtown district of Manhattan. Part of the structure is to be used for the corporation's new headquarters.

MEXICO, D.F., Feb. 5. -- Treasury Department agents besieged a Catholic girls' school in the suburb of Micoac vainly this evening, trying to seize it for the government under a law enacted in December.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Senator Huey P. Long has a $500,000 libel suit on his hands.
Dwelling deals comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.
A sharp increase in underwriting profit is shown by the Aetna Insurance Company for the year ended on Dec. 31, according to the annual report of the company and its affiliates yesterday.

Ferdinand Pecora, who receives only $225 a month as counsel for the Senate sub-committee on banking and finance, appeared yesterday in Federal Court to ask postponement of a criminal case until April, so that he could represent the defendants.

For more than thirty-seven of the forty-seven years he spent in the Police Department, John J. Donohue covered the waterfront, but he is a shy man and when he applied for retirement yesterday was disinclined to discuss his career.

MADRID, Feb. 5. -- A Lufthansa seaplane, inaugurating the German all-airway mail service between Europe and South America, left Las Palmas, Canary Islands, this morning for Bathurst, Gambia, according to advices reaching the Spanish War Ministry.

Thomas McDonagh, 21 years old, who arrived yesterday as a stowaway from Belfast, Ireland, on the Anchor liner Cameronia, made a desperate effort to escape from the ship at Pier 54, North River, and would have succeeded but for the vigilant bos'n who chased him across the street and captured him.
Mayor LaGuardia and his administration were warmly praised last night by Bishop William T. Manning at the annual dinner of the Church Club of New York at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The President is taking no part in the Senatorial campaign in New York, the White House announced today in denying published reports that he had encouraged Thomas F. Conway, former Lieutenant Governor, to oppose Senator Copeland in the Democratic primary.

The long-anticipated meeting of Glenn Cunningham, Bill Bonthron and Gene Venzke was made a certainty yesterday by the receipt of their entries for the Baxter Mile, featured event of the New York Athletic Club games at Madison Square Garden a week from Saturday.

Science rapidly is developing the new field of air conditioning to a point where "manufactured weather'' may be economically feasible even for small dwellings, according to experts attending the annual convention of the American Society of Heating and Ventilating Engineers at the Hotel Biltmore.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 5. -- Weekly instead of monthly payments by communities of county and State taxes were recommended today by the legislative committee of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors. Herbert C. Gerlach, chairman of the committee, pointed out that this method would prevent accumulation of large amounts in the community treasuries and obviate the temptation of using the money for purposes other than taxes.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 6. -- According to The Daily Express, Douglas Fairbanks Sr. has been cited as corespondent in a divorce action that Lord Ashley, eldest son and heir of the Earl of Shaftesbury, has instructed his solicitors to bring against his wife.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 5. -- Jockey Eddie Litzenberger scored a triple at Hialeah Park today when he won with all three of his mounts. Ha was up on Bender First, Off Duty and Haggerson. Litzenberger, who rode Off Duty at 96 pounds, is one of the highest jockeys at the course.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The Senate ratified late today an extradition treaty with Turkey as the government moved further to close every international avenue of escape for Samuel Insull.

Hundreds of Staten Island commuters were delayed about twenty minutes yesterday morning when the municipal ferries the Queens and the Richmond were in collision off Robbins Reef, between St. George and the Statue of Liberty.

MADRID, Feb. 5. -- Rumors of an imminent Cabinet crisis were heard here tonight, following an announcement that the Agrarian party would interpellate the government tomorrow in the Cortes on what it intends to do about Socialist threats to precipitate a class war in Spain as a preliminary to the establishment of a proletarian republic.

PARIS, Feb. 5. -- The disturbed political situation in France reacted strongly on the Bourse today when the franc fell in relation to all other currencies. Rentes and virtually all national securities declined, while foreign securities rose.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP). -- After learning that a contractor made a 50 per cent profit on one $10,000,000 navy airplane engine order, a House Naval Affairs subcommittee today set out to determine why, and Chairman Delaney of New York expressed the opinion that the "real profit might have been even more."
DETROIT, Feb. 5. -- Business recovery depends on industry's resourcefulness in putting forth under high wage scales, new and improved products at low cost, Henry Ford said today in an interview.

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- With one negative vote the Assembly passed the bill of Senator O'Brien of New York tonight extending the emergency powers of the State Superintendent of Insurance until March 1, 1935, and validating all acts of the Superintendent under the law enacted in last year's emergency.
" La Frochard et Les Deux Orphalines," a French language film, with Yvette Guilbert, will be presented at the Fifty-fifth Street playhouse tonight.

Hope for immediate settlement of the taxicab strike vanished last night as the drivers, after an earlier rejection of the peace program put forward on behalf of Mayor LaGuardia, formulated new demands upon their employers and the latter demanded time for consideration.

A flood of buying orders for domestic corporation bonds from foreign, as well as domestic sources sent prices sharply higher in the most active trading in these issues in any one day in the history of the Stock Exchange. The turnover in domestic bonds was $24,038,000 of the total of $30,645,000 in the listed market. The latter total was the largest since mid-April, 1922.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Private investment in the home mortgage field was encouraged today by John H. Fahey, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, who said in a statement that this was a "major objective" of the board.

Without arousing the suspicion of passers-by outside, two armed men obtained $2,600 at 6 o'clock last night in a hold-up of the Washington Heights branch office of Wood, Dolson Co., a real estate and insurance concern at 4,234 Broadway near 180th Street.

Martin Conboy, Federal Attorney here, declined yesterday to predict what effect the decision of the Supreme Court would have upon 1,181 criminal prohibition cases still pending in the Southern District of New York.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 6. -- Heckled in the Diet regarding a statement in the magazine Gendal on Jan. 15 attributing to Admiral Suetsugu a suggestion that Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh had been spying, Admiral Osumi, Navy Minister, repeated that the article had not been written or revised by Admiral Suetsugu.

After an opening burst of strength yesterday, some commodity futures on local exchanges settled back slightly in profit-taking. Most of the markets, however, closed higher on the day. Trading was in good volume. The great majority of cash commodities also was higher.

Departing from the roster of national champions in many instances for his choice of athletes, Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the Amateur Athletic Union, yesterday named his annual All-America track and field team. This will appear in the new Spalding Athletic Almanac, just off the press, along with the All-College and All-Scholastic combinations.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 5. -- Richard King Mellon, 34 years old, today succeeded his late father, Richard Beatty Mellon, as president of the Mellon National Bank, key institution in the family's financial empire. He was elected at the annual meeting, as had been expected in financial circles.
PARIS, Feb. 5. -- Paris is somewhat feverishly awaiting tomorrow's events when Premier Edouard Daladier will face the Chamber of Deputies with his new Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Mme. Lillian Evanti, Negro lyric coloratura soprano, will sing at the White House on Friday at a luncheon honoring Miss Mary Bewson, head of the woman's division of the National Democratic Committee.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 5. -- Clipping five strokes from the course record, Miss Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., four times Metropolitan champion and runner-up for the national title in 1927, won the medal in the qualifying round for the annual Miami Biltmore women's golf championship today.

A small quantity of heroin contained in an envelope addressed to a narcotic addict prisoner was found yesterday in the Tombs Prison by Warden Robert Barr acting on information he had received from David Marcus, Deputy Correction Commissioner.

The by-laws of the Bank of United States permitted its executive committee to pass on all loans and purchases of stock, according to Herbert Singer, lawyer and son of Saul Singer, former executive vice president of the bank.

Ever since the war, Austria has racked the brains of the statesmen who made the treaty of peace. She has required help both financially, commercially and territorially. When Germany abruptly proposed the Anschluss with Austria, the rest of Europe was convulsed. But Italy and France hastened to file a strong protest in which Great Britain diplomatically joined.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Statements made in the Toronto newspaper Mail and Empire, and employed by American opponents of the St. Lawrence Waterway Treaty, to the effect that Canada would contribute much less to its cost and derive far greater advantages from it than the United States were answered by State Department officials today.

VIENNA, Feb. 5. -- The situation in Tyrol is again obscure. Reassuring news last night that the Heimwehr were packing up at Innsbruck and going home after their four-day mobilization and abandoning their demand for the dissolution of political parties, was contradicted by messages tonight which said big Heimwehr reinforcements were again pouring into the city.
SEATTLE, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Franklin D. Roosevelt's policies have put Alaska on the highroad to recovery, leaders of the territory said today.

Unusual interest is being shown by salt-water anglers in the proposed legislation regulating the sport. Yesterday at Sayville, L.I., boat captains, sportsmen, members of the Nassau Chapter of the Izaak Walton League and representatives of the State Conservation Department went over the entire program which Commissioner Lithgow Osborne has prepared.

VIENNA, Feb. 5. -- Austria's appeal to the League will deal with what it regards as the infiltration from Germany of Nazi propaganda and terrorism. It was not made clear when the complaint actually would be filed at Geneva. It was pointed out that the technical details, such as the translation of the Austrian document into French, English and other languages, would occupy several days.

In reorganizing the Triborough Bridge Authority Mayor LAGUARDIA did a disagreeable job with energy and dispatch. He is already rewarded by a promise of full and prompt cooperation on the part of the Federal Government. The mere fact that the three hold-over commissioners were old-line Democrats was naturally not in itself sufficient ground for their removal.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Retail food prices rose by .7 per cent in the two weeks ended Jan. 16, the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Labor Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- By solemn decision of the Supreme Court, children are not to be allowed to gamble by buying candy with prizes concealed therein.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- With only one negative vote the House passed the $950,000,000 appropriation bill to allow for continuance of the Civil Works Administration and direct Federal relief to States. There were 382 affirmative votes after only forty minutes' debate.
A demonstration of unemployed, in which thousands were expected to join, brought out only a few hundred persons yesterday at the Battery.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Feb. 5. -Miss Elizabeth Woolsey of New Haven, Conn., and Miss Barbara Beresford of Short Hills, No. 1 and No. 2 seeded players, respectively, led the field of the fourth annual women's New Jersey State squash racquets tournament into the quarter-final round at the Plainfield Country Club today.
On last Sunday's art page we glancingly reviewed the pronounced increase in the showing of plastic work here this season. The present week adds several exhibitions to the list.

Stocks competed with bonds yesterday for leadership of the security markets, but in spite of the fact that transactions in the former approached 5,000,000 shares, the bond business was considered the more reliable barometer of the day, as it has been for some time past.
ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Feb. -- The State's attempt to punish leaders of the mob that lynched Lloyd Warner, Negro youth, here the night of Nov. 28 collapsed today.

The Moreland Act investigation of the State Insurance Department and the fourteen mortgage companies in rehabilitation turned yesterday to the groups of speculators that are trying to induce hard-pressed certificate holders to part with their holdings for a small fraction of their real worth.

An answer was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by John D. Rockefeller Jr., Rockefeller Center, Inc., and other defendants in the suit by August Heckscher's Anamaha Realty Corporation and the Broadway Exchange Corporation for $10,000,000 damages and an injunction restraining the Rockefeller Center interests from inducing tenants in other buildings by alleged coercion and other improper methods to vacate their quarters and move to the Rockefeller Center buildings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Bearing promises of the speedy release of $68,000,000 of Public Works Administration funds for New York City projects, Mayor F.H. LaGuardia prepared to return to New York late tonight after a busy day of conferences with Federal officials here.

BERLIN, Feb. 5. -- The Boerse opened firm and fairly active today, with buying both for public and professional accounts. Optimism concerning the conference on short-term debts and favorable expectations from an internatoinal monetary conference in the early future were among the stimulating factors.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 5. -- The Senate by a vote of 12 to 2 passed tonight a bill introduced by Senator Joseph A. Wolber of Essex County to take the naming of jury commissioners from the Governor and to vest it in Supreme Court justices.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5. -- Largely attended was the benefit recital for the Girl Scout Camp at Jupiter, given this afternoon at Casa Ananda, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred G. Kay, by the Misses Dorothea Benson and Marjorie Kelly, sopranos and pupils of Mme. Homer, and by Miss Mildred Carlisle, pianist.
HAVANA, Feb. 5. -- President Mendieta and his Cabinet again, at noon today, took their oaths of office, this time under the New Provisional Constitution signed yesterday.

Definitions as to "Who is the head of the family" were issued here yesterday by the Bureau of Internal Revenue. It is permissible for a widower to claim an exemption of $2,500 plus $400 for each dependent if he maintains a household with dependents "by blood relationship, relationship by marriage or by adoption" over whom he exercises control.

The Rev. Dr. William Lloyd Imes, pastor of St. James's Negro Presbyterian Church, St. Nicholas Avenue and West 141st Street, was elected president of the New York Alumni Club of Union Theological Seminary yesterday. The election took place at the reunion, luncheon and business meeting of the alumni in the seminary, Broadway and 120th Street.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 5 (AP). -- E.W. Backus, president of the Minnesota and Ontario Paper Company, now in receivership, filed an answer in Federal court today to the suit by which Eastern holders of fifty promissory notes seek collection of $2,457,575.

An answer was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by John D. Rockefeller Jr., Rockefeller Center, Inc., and other defendants in the suit by August Heckscher's Anamaha Realty Corporation and the Broadway Exchange Corporation for $10,000,000 damages and an injunction restraining the Rockefeller Center interests from inducing tenants in other buildings by alleged coercion and other improper methods to vacate their quarters and move to the Rockefeller Center buildings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Bearing promises of the speedy release of $68,000,000 of Public Works Administration funds for New York City projects, Mayor F.H. LaGuardia prepared to return to New York late tonight after a busy day of conferences with Federal officials here.

BERLIN, Feb. 5. -- The Boerse opened firm and fairly active today, with buying both for public and professional accounts. Optimism concerning the conference on short-term debts and favorable expectations from an internatoinal monetary conference in the early future were among the stimulating factors.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 5. -- The Senate by a vote of 12 to 2 passed tonight a bill introduced by Senator Joseph A. Wolber of Essex County to take the naming of jury commissioners from the Governor and to vest it in Supreme Court justices.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5. -- Largely attended was the benefit recital for the Girl Scout Camp at Jupiter, given this afternoon at Casa Ananda, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred G. Kay, by the Misses Dorothea Benson and Marjorie Kelly, sopranos and pupils of Mme. Homer, and by Miss Mildred Carlisle, pianist.
HAVANA, Feb. 5. -- President Mendieta and his Cabinet again, at noon today, took their oaths of office, this time under the New Provisional Constitution signed yesterday.
Dr. O'Shea's article on radicalism in the public schools, in his last annual report as Superintendent of Schools, is a noble testament of patriotic sentiment.

Producers of milk in distant parts of the State, joined in discussions yesterday with representatives of cooperative groups and State control boards in this and adjacent States, at the hearing of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration on the proposed marketing agreement for milk distributed in the metropolitan area.

Basketball competition in two divisions of the Public Schools Athletic League, Manhattan and Upper Manhattan-Bronx, got under way yesterday, with two games played in each. In the Upper Manhattan-Bronx group, James Monroe, city titleholder, triumphed over Evander Childs, 31 -- 27.

Harold Dahlquist, baritone, who sang here last Winter, gave his first recital of the season last night in the Town Hall. His program consisted entirely of lieder: Schubert's "Im Abendrot," "Die Sterne," "Nachstuck," "Das Lied im Grunen," and "Auflosung," Schumann's complete "Dichterliebe" cycle of sixteen songs and five songs of Wolf.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- President Roosevelt was confined to the Executive Mansion with a cold and received no callers.

An effort to bring about a strike of the 1,450 employes of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, said to be sponsored by Local 994 of the Amalgamated Association of Street and Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employes of America, failed last night. Drivers and conductors on Fifth Avenue buses ignored a widely circulated handbill urging them to follow the example of the striking taxicab drivers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Important questions as to whether the price-fixing practices carried on under some NRA codes tend to create a monopoly forbidden by the act are raised in an investigation of the steel industry code begun today by the Federal Trade Commission.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 5. -- Making his first bid for a world's championship, Joe Knight, slugging southpaw from Cairo, Ga., tonight battled Maxie Rosenbloom, wearer of the light-heavyweight crown, to a well-earned draw in a fifteen-round title bout at the Madison Square Garden open air arena.

WOODS HOLE, Mass., Feb. 5. -- Four socially prominent young people were forced to race for their lives over disintegrating ice encountered while walking this afternoon from Clark's Cove on the mainland to Naushon Island.

In trading activity reminiscent of last July, stocks soared in January, after some irregularity in the first week, to levels close to the high point established for the market in 1933. The enhancement in values of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange was 11 1/2 per cent, the largest appreciation since August, measured 240 stocks listed there and arranged in twenty groups.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5. -- Prices of fresh pork loins advanced sharply today to 9 to 11 1/2 cents a pound, the highest in three months, but this failed to have much effect on the market for hogs. Light weight hogs suitable for relief purposes were 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight lower than on Saturday and heavier kinds were generally steady.

LONDON, Feb. 5. -- Four members of the American team emerged victorious from the first round of the thirteenth annual women's British squash racquets championship at the Queens Club today. The other three members of the United States squad, including the captain, Miss Eleonora Sears, were defeated.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 5. -- The Republican Senators met in conference after the session this evening and pledged their support to the LaGuardia Emergency Economy Bill, which would vest powers in the Board of Estimate to cut salaries and effect economies to set the city on its feet financially.
The Federal Government, which moved last June to break up a group of alleged racketeers monopolizing trade in fresh fish struck another blow yesterday against the fish trust in Fulton Market.
LONDON, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Mrs. W.F. Howe Jr. of Boston and Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia won easily today in the first round of the women's British squash racquets championship.

The report of the stockholders' investigating committee of the Texas Corporation, mailed to stockholders last night, recommends that the Lapham family be represented by a single director, to be chosen by Lapham stockholders, and that R.C. Holmes, former president, be not reelected a director.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5. -- Rex Beach, noted novelist, scored 41, 39 -- 80 on the Palm Beach Country Club course today to win the qualifying medal in the seventh annual Winter championship tournament of the Artists and Writers Golf Association.

PARIS, Feb. 5. -- A challenge to the week-old government of Premier Daladier in the form of a demonstration by 1,000 war veterans in front of the President's residence was put down by mounted Republican Guards tonight.

THE UNFORGOTTEN PRISONER," by R.C. Hutchinson (Farrar Rinehart, $2.75), is the novel of a literary spendthrift, careless of his many gifts, with absolutely no sense of husbandry. A novelist of another temperament would have made three books out of "The Unforgotten Prisoner." But perhaps Mr. Hutchinson doesn't need to dole out his talents.

A point of interest in real estate trading in this city yesterday was the payment of all cash for business properties in Manhattan. Activity in this borough and in Brooklyn indicated a demand for buildings occupied for business purposes.

A mother of two children, who decided to return to college after an absence of thirty years, yesterday received her Bachelor of Science degree from the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance. She is Mrs. Emily B. Stevenson, 52 years old.

Club owners of the National League, meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, ratified their 1934 championship schedule, examined minutely specimens of the ball which they are to use jointly with the American League this year, and inducted a new club executive into their councils.
British audiences continue under the spell of American gangster plays. A new underworld production with the scene laid in New York "held the suspense" of a London audience on the first night.

Daily gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,121,650 barrels, compared with 2,222,750 in the preceding week, a decrease of 101,100, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The most important change was a drop of 83.950 barrels in the average daily output of Oklahoma, reducing the production of that State 63,200 barrels below its daily quota.

After finding that the Municipal Court's calendar in tort cases was more than two years behind, Resident-Justice William Chilvers announced yesterday that, beginning on March 5, eight new parts would start hearing cases in the Central Jury Court, 30 West Thirty-fifth Street.
A policeman accidentally shot himself on the street near the Pennsylvania Station last night but after he did so he captured his man, a Federal prisoner who was trying to escape.

Addressing the New York State Bankers Association on Monday evening, Mr. JESSE H. JONES, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, reverted to the dispute whether private banks are extending as they should credit to industry. This controversy began as long ago as President HOOVER'S program in 1932, to enlarge facilities for private bank credit through the purchase, by Federal Reserve Banks, of government obligations held by member institutions.

Christodora Settlement, at Avenue B and East Ninth Street, in the heart of the tenement area, has been very fortunate in securing the cooperation of the Civil Works Service Bureau and the University of the State of New York in establishing practical educational classes for adults.

Just when interest in other groups of stocks was diminishing yesterday, with the general market drifting lower, speculative operations for the advance were transferred to the public utilities, which had been more or less neglected lately.
The fight between the taxi driver and the taxi owner to determine which one gets the passenger's nickel is all wrong. I have solved this question by discontinuing all tips.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- As the first draft of a bill to regulate the practices of Stock Exchanges neared completion under the supervision of Ferdinand Pecora today, Senator King of Utah introduced a regulatory measure based, he said, on the recommendations of the President's interdepartmental committee.

Colonel Thomas W. Hammond, a retired West Pointer, was sworn in yesterday as Deputy Commissioner of Sanitation by Mayor LaGuardia in his office at City Hall. Colonel Hammond is an old personal friend of the Mayor. He retired from the army Saturday after having been asked by Mr. LaGuardia to take his new post, and had already spent two days on the job before his formal induction into office.
Walter Seligman of J. Seligman Co. has been elected a director of the Tri-Continental Corporation.

The sugar refiners who last week raised the price to 4.50 cents a pound have announced the same price again, effective at the close of business yesterday. Two large Eastern refiners indicated no intention of going along with the group.

BERLIN, Feb. 6 (Jewish Telegraph Agency). -- A victory for the section of the Reich Cabinet headed by Minister of Economics Kurt Schmitt, which has steadfastly insisted on liberal treatment of the Jews in commerce, was seen here tonight in an order to be published officially tomorrow in the press by Dr. Wilhelm Frick, making government officials responsible for insuring undisturbed Jewish trading.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6 (AP). -- There's a potential grand opera star in almost ever home in America, believes Otto H. Kahn, but "there is a cruel gap between preparation and opportunity for the young artist."

Buying enthusiasm was not quite so much in evidence yesterday in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange as on the preceding few trading days. THE NEW YORK TIMES average of forty domestic corporation bonds was lower for the first time in eight straight sessions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- President Roosevelt, fully recovered from his head cold, acted as host tonight at the annual dinner to Speaker and Mrs. Rainey. This is the last formal White House function before the Lenten season.

Objections to several phases of price fixing and methods of distribution were voiced by producers yesterday at the hearing on the proposed Federal plan to regulate the marketing of milk in the metropolitan area before officials of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

Passage in the Senate at Washington yesterday of the Walcott migratory bird sanctuary measure, which carries with it the duck stamp tax, provided a vital impetus toward a new deal in conservation in this country. The bill, which goes to the House, was passed under the unanimous-vote procedure, so that it can be taken for granted that the Roosevelt administration is behind the measure.
ATHENS, Feb. 6. -- Dr. Anthony Haniotis, who examined Samuel Insull last month, declared today that there was "physically no question that Insull is able to travel."

PARIS, Feb. 6. -- Paris was not alone the scene of manifestations and violence today. Police and troops were called out in a score of provincial centres to disperse mobs of demonstrators. In the provinces, however, no fatalities had been reported up to late tonight, although great excitement prevailed in many cities and towns as news from Paris, more or less exaggerated, reached different parts of the country.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 6. -- The Chicago North Western Railway filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today the first comprehensive plan for a sinking fund to retire bonded indebtedness prior to maturity, along lines which President Roosevelt suggested for all public utilities.

ALBANY, Feb. 6. -- Governor Lehman had a heart-to-heart talk this afternoon with the sixty-five Democratic members of the Assembly. Threescore of the Democrats voted last week against the LaGuardia Economy Bill when it was up on third reading in the lower house.

The nickels collected as an impost on taxicab fares between Oct. 1 and Nov. 11, when the tax was declared illegal, are in the possession of the taxicab operators in accord with a court order, pending the city's decision on whether to appeal from the adverse ruling. This money is one of the major objectives of the striking taxicab chauffeurs.

PARIS, Feb. 6. -- Paris is experiencing a night of extreme excitement, with sanguinary rioting in many parts of the city. Censorship has been clamped down, and all press dispatches must pass through official hands.

BUFFALO, Feb. 6 (AP). -- Henry T. Harriman, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said in an address here tonight that a nation-wide house-building program to add 50,000,000 to 75,000,000 rooms to America's homes through the use of private capital would be the best thing that could be done to lift the country out of the depression.

The plan proposed by Lauritz Melchior, the Metropolitan tenor, to organize a committee of distinguished musicians to cut Wagner's operas so that they will fit into the tempo of modern times was endorsed yesterday by Fritz Reiner, conductor, and Lotte Lehmann. Metropolitan soprano.

An arrangement by which the Lawyers Westchester Mortgage and Title Company, now in rehabilitation, permitted an outside company to profit on its foreclosed mortgages while it sustained losses was disclosed by Miss Lillian Levine, an examiner of the State Insurance Department, in her testimony yesterday before George W. Alger, Moreland Act Commissioner.

Former Lieut. Gov. CONWAY, inadvertently taking a farewell blessing for a recommendation of his zeal to add to the intellectual strength of the Senate, has drawn from the Administration a declaration of neutrality in the politics of this State this year. Senator COPELAND hardly has to wonder if that neutrality is to be benevolent or malevolent in regard to himself.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 6. -- Four firemen were injured and nine persons were rescued during a fire early this morning which caused about $200,000 damage to four buildings on South Main Street in the business area of this village.

Municipal control and the possibility of public ownership and operation of public utilities was included in a plan for charter revision and reorganization of the City Government submitted yesterday to Mayor LaGuardia by eighteen members of the faculty of New York University.

Marthe Krueger, a dancer from Vienna, made her New York debut last night in the Town Hall in a program of "theatre pieces." These proved to be something quite different from the type of work made familiar under that title by Dorsha and Paul Hayes; they were, in fact, merely dances more suitable to the theatre than to the concert stage.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The administration is considering whether to recommend to Congress changes in the Securities Act and the Federal Deposit Insurance Law.

Dr. L.S. Rowe, director general of the Pan American Union, said on his return from the Montevideo conference yesterday that the "deep sense of continual responsibility for the maintenance of peace" in the Western Hemisphere was one of the most inspiring features of the conference.

In the first suit filed in this district under the Securities Act of 1933, the Federal Trade Commission sought an injunction in United States District Court yesterday to restrain Maison Pichel Inc., liquor importers of 100 Warren Street, from making "false and unlawful statements" in the sale of its stock.

Lord Marley, one of the Deputy Speakers of the House of Lords and chairman of the world committee to aid victims of German fascism, arrived last night from London on the White Star liner Olympic. He will make a national lecture tour in behalf of the victims of the Hitler government.

Acting Lieutenant Patrick J. (Paddy) Fitzgibbons became yesterday an ordinary police sergeant, assigned to the Bedford Avenue station in Brooklyn, as part of the continuing shake-up in the Police Department.

Colonel John Means Thompson, 69 years old, Spanish-American War veteran and formerly of the 108th Infantry, New York, will be married Saturday to Miss Elizabeth S. Bacsen, 24, of 150 Sherman Avenue, Jersey City. Colonel Thompson recently was divorced at Hot Springs, Ark.

The New York Rangers took a firmer grip on first place in the American group of the National Hockey League by defeating the Canadiens of Montreal in Madison Square Garden last night. The Flying Frenchmen waged a bitter struggle against Lester Patrick's sextet, but they were unable to score, and skated off the ice on the short end of a 3-0 count.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The administration is studying the possibility of a Federal old-age pension system with a view to possible legislation at this session of Congress.

LONDON, Feb. 6. -- While the House of Commons was debating disarmament, George Bernard Shaw tonight scored the futility of disarmament talks to prevent war. He was the speaker in the "Whither Britain?" series of broadcasts to England and the United States.

Mayor LaGuardia laid aside the cares of public office last night and went into Greenwich Village for a few hours of music and conversation. As guest of the Greenwich Village Neighborhood Association he greeted about 400 residents of the neighborhood, praised the work of Greenwich House, the centre of the association's activities at 29 Barrow Street, and apparently enjoyed the musical program and dancing provided by groups which it is sponsoring.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP). -- The Washington Post will say tomorrow that the National Emergency Council has approved a plan to increase the appropriations for the Civil Works Administration to $2,500,000, 000 to continue this work-giving program until January.

The election of R.J. Baker as president of the American Steamship Owners Association was announced yesterday after the annual meeting of the association at 11 Broadway. Mr. Baker succeeds the late H.B. Walker, who died in June, 1932. Mr. Baker has been secretary and treasurer since 1926, and since Mr. Walker's death has also carried on the duties of the president.

PARIS, Feb. 6. -- The rioting in Paris streets tonight was preceded by a day of tumult and clamor in the Chamber of Deputies. The furor inside and outside the French Parliament grew out of the Stavisky pawnshop scandal which has set France by the ears.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The Weirton Steel Company is reported to be preparing to make a court test of President Roosevelt's executive order, issued Thursday, governing a method of procedure by the National Labor Board to determine spokesmen for collective bargaining.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Parliamentary disorder is no novelty in France. From the time of the French Revolution it has been almost a national habit. Even when unexciting and non-contentious subjects are under debate in the Chamber of Deputies, "manifestations" may break out any minute.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward more than $1 a bale yesterday and closed in new high ground for the year with gains of 16 to 22 points.

A police radio car did taxicab duty yesterday for Mrs. Jeanette Glickman, 22 years old, of 1,970 Vyse Avenue, the Bronx. Mrs. Glickman, an expectant mother, and her husband, Emmanuel, decided about-11:30 A.M. that it was time for her to go to the Bronx Maternity and Women's Hospital at 1,072 Grand Concourse, about a mile and a half away.

The question of meeting the $20,000,000 which the city owes property owners in outstanding condemnation awards became pressing yesterday, when Supreme Court Justice Burt J. Humphrey in Brooklyn granted a peremptory writ of mandamus to Mrs. Mabel O. Parker.

Price movements were irregular on local commodity exchanges yesterday in a good volume of trading. In some instances, profit-taking was engendered by prolonged rallies. Cash prices continued to advance to new high marks for the year.

Huge pension costs in behalf of American war veterans are attacked by Katherine Mayo in "Soldiers, What Next?" published today by Houghton Mifflin. Miss Mayo is the author of "Mother India,'' which created a sensation when it was published several years ago.

An old-fashioned fracas in modern dress and setting threw the blue and gold Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria into an uproar last night when several "strike missionaries'' tried to get the diners to walk out in a gesture of sympathy to striking waiters.

Low temperatures nipped the ears and noses of New Yorkers yesterday for the fifth consecutive day, and the Weather Bureau last night foresaw no relief. The cold wave will probably remain at least until Friday and possibly longer, it said, with perhaps some light snow today.

VIENNA, Feb. 6. -- The revolt of the Tyrolese Heimwehr spread tonight in Upper Austria. The Heimwehr, in steel helmets and armed with rifles and machine guns, poured into Linz, the Upper Austria capital, tonight, camped in the principal squares and occupied some public buildings.

LONDON, Feb. 6 (AP). -- Lord Ashley, having instituted divorce proceedings against his wife, naming Douglas Fairbanks as corespondent, today secluded himself at Swindon, seventy miles from London. There the 33-year-old son and heir of the ninth Earl of Shaftesbury waited the serving of the petition on Lady Ashley and the American actor. It was delivered to her at her Mayfair home.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP). -- The Senate today passed and sent to the House the Walcott Bill to acquire areas for use as migratory-bird sanctuaries by requiring hunters of waterfowl to buy $1 "duck stamps" for attachment to their hunting licenses.

The taxicab drivers' strike caused a temporary modification of traffic rules in the theatre district last night. The new deal for those who go to the theatre in their own machines will last only as long as the strike, under orders issued by Chief Inspector Valentine as a result of pleas by theatre officials.

An attempt by the New York Chapter of the Knights of Columbus to sponsor a trip to the United States by Luigi Beccali of Italy for the Columbian mile that will feature their indoor games at the Garden on March 17 has failed.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 6. -- Colonel Jacob Ruppert, owner of the New York Yankees, would have paid as high as $150,000 for Lefty Grove if he had been given the opportunity to bid on the Athletics' star southpaw.

In his statement before the United States Senate Banking and Currency Committee Professor James Harvey Rogers declared that raising the price of gold creates a profit. "Literally out of thin air does such a profit appear," he declared. "Suddenly the government finds itself in the possession of entirely new funds which have come from no one and have to be returned to no one."
MR. WILLIAM TERRY was not in his room. A bellboy couldn't find him around the lobby. Probably he was riding a bicycle through Central Park to get in shape to win his bet with Max Carey.

Commissioner ALGER used strong language in denouncing those who might attempt to turn to their own selfish account the investigation which he is conducting into the State Insurance Department and the mortgage companies. "Scavengers and carrion," he called them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The administration decided today, following the warning to bankers delivered by Jesse H. Jones in New York last night, upon a close heck-up of capital market activities. The President wants to know at frequent intervals whether an easier policy of making loans to what Mr. Jones called "deserving borrowers" is or is not to follow the various governmental moves made recently to restore confidence.
LONDON, Feb. 6. -- Airliners which were literally golden argosies groped their way through the mist to Croydon Airdrome today bringing in 5,000,000 gold (about $24,825,000) from Paris and Amsterdam.

The regional labor board announced yesterday the results of the election conducted under its auspices in eighteen shops of the boot and shoe industry in this city to determine which of two unions the workers wished to join.

BERLIN, Feb. 6. -- America is hostile to the new Germany and completely lacking in understanding of her, Professor Friedrich Schoenemann declared tonight in a lecture before the Academy of Political Science.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Officials watched developments in France closely today, apparently confident that France would not be forced to abandon the gold standard. In one quarter, the opinion was expressed that France could withstand any temporary drain of gold incidental to the working out of the gold policy of the United States, and that only internal conditions threatened its ability to safeguard its position.

Helped by what appeared to be official support from the Bank of France, the franc rallied yesterday on Premier Daladier's declaration of support for the gold standard. The French exchange recovered 14 1/2 of the 16 1/2 points it lost on Monday, and closed at 6.31 cents, a discount of 4.8 per cent from parity, compared with a discount of 7.06 per cent the previous day.

GREENWOOD, Miss., Feb. 2 (AP). -- The State today for the first time offered a possible motive for the alleged "poisoned whisky highball slaying" of Dr. John Preston Kennedy in presenting "love letters" District Attorney Arthur Jordan claimed were exchanged between Dr. Kennedy and Dr. Sarah Ruth Dean, on trial for murder.

Following a six-weeks' investigation of complaints regarding conditions in the plate-glass industry, Abraham Glasser, 40 years old, of 529 Monroe Street, Brooklyn, and Sam Kaplan, 39, of 759 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, were arrested yesterday on charges of coercion and conspiracy.
" After Such Pleasures" -- playlets fashioned after Dorothy Parker's book -- will open tonight at the Bijou Theatre.

ABOARD THE S.S. JACOB RUPPERT, Bay of Whales, Antarctica, Feb. 5. -- The Jacob Ruppert, flagship of the second Byrd Antarctic expedition, is scheduled to sail from the Bay of Whales tomorrow. She will remain in New Zealand for a year.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6. -- Honoring her house guests, Lord and Lady Ashburton of London and Mr. and Mrs. Julian Stuart Jones of Baltimore, Mrs. Peyton J. Van Rensselaer entertained today with a large tea at Casa Rosada del Lago.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 6 (AP). -- Harold Bell Wright, whose book sales have reached 9,000,000 copies, plans to live the secluded life of "a shepherd of the hills."

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 6 (AP). -- The New York State Grange was told today by Fred Freestone, Master, that President Roosevelt had "put into effect a monetary program which is in entire accord with the Grange's proposal."

The demand for lawyers "who are able to envisage and understand the social problems involved and the manner in which the law may be used most advantageously in their solution" under the present national administration greatly exceeds the supply, Dean Young B. Smith of the Columbia University School of Law says in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, made public yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 6 (AP). -- Opposition of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to a $19,000,000 deal between the Van Sweringen brothers of Cleveland and the Missouri Pacific Railway, involving terminal property at Kansas City and St. Joseph, Mo., was termed "a tempest in a teapot" by O.P. Van Sweringen today.

License Commissioner Paul Moss said yesterday that he planned to educate theatre managers to the realization that if they wish to make money they must produce clean plays. He spoke at an informal luncheon session of the Cheese Club, an organization including theatrical publicity men, at Leone's Restaurant, 239 West Forty-eighth Street.

A new peak was reached yesterday in the number of buyers registered in the markets here. The total was 628, the highest for any one day since Aug. 5, 1930, when 651 buyers were listed. This high total raised the number reported during the week ended yesterday to above the figures for the preceding week and for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.
McGRAW, N. Y., Feb. 6. -- Four pet dogs, convicted of mangling a little girl's arm, today were condemned to death.

PARIS, Feb. 6. -- Augustabernard makes her slim elongating line softly casual by shirrings, full-gathered ruffles and gathers replacing all pleats. Her skirts are either narrow or with the fullness concentrated at the back, and easy movement is achieved through graduated gathered diagonal bands.

TRENTON; N.J., Feb. 6. -- Agreements were reached by the Republican Joint Conference Committee of the Legislature today whereby the Municipal Bond and Budget Bills introduced by Senator Joseph G. Wolber of Essex County and the Municipal Debt Refunding Bill sponsored by Senator John C. Barbour of Passaic County, will be taken up for final passage next week.

LONDON, Feb. 6. -- Speculative interest in the stock markets today shifted from gold mines to internationals and oils, encouraged by Wall Street's strength. There was further profit-taking in gold mines, and business was considerably reduced, with prices weakening.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6. -- Samuel Insull Sr. was denounced at a Federal court hearing today as "a cowardly crook" and extolled as "superbly courageous." The occasion was the opening of a battle over the integrity of the receivership of his Middlewest Utilities Company before Judge Walter C. Lindley.
