LONDON, Feb. 6. -- Douglas Fairbanks was thoroughly angry today when Lord Ashley's divorce petition, citing him as corespondent, was served on him. A copy of the complaint in a sealed envelope was handed to him this morning at the home of F.M. Guedalla, his solicitor. Mr. Guedalla instructed him not to say a word of comment on the case because of the risk of being cited for contempt of court under English law.

One thing was proved, if that had been necessary, by the concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. This was, that Issay Dobrowen, guest conductor of the occasion, is not by nature a classicist. His reading of the Cherubini overture to "Anacreon," which opened the program, was plausible and respectful to the work, but not more than that.

Although published nearly five years ago, "All Quiet on the Western Front" is still selling all over the world, with total sales nearing 5,000,000 and new translations being prepared. A Bengali edition for India is the latest. In Germany, where 1,200,000 copies have been sold, it is estimated that at least 50 per cent of the population has read the book.

Encouraged by a new president, Powel Crosley Jr., who seems eager enough to do all that is humanly possible to attain that end, the Cincinnati Reds made heroic efforts yesterday to lead the way in major league trading activities in the fervent hope of lifting themselves out of the cellar this year.

BUDAPEST, Feb. 6. -- Hungary, next to Germany probably the most anti-Communist country in Europe, has signed a treaty recognizing the Soviet Government and providing for the resumption of diplomatic relations, it was announced tonight to the surprise of the public. A Russian delegation will come to Budapest immediately to conclude a commercial treaty.
Plaintiffs bid in thirteen Manhattan and Bronx properties at auction sales yesterday, including the eighteen-story house at 7-11 West Ninety-sixth Street, near Central Park West.

ALBANY, Feb. 6. -- Acting witch record speed, the Republican-controlled Assembly passed today the bills containing Governor Lehman's recommendations for $249,984,431 expenditures under the annual executive budget. The budget figure is exclusive of about $12,500,000 in bond money and other funds which will be voted later.

Hrs. Francis C. McMillin gave a luncheon yesterday in the Egyptian room of the St. Regis. Her guests were Mrs. Randolph S. Warner, Mrs. John Calvin Thorne, Mrs. N. Leslie Carpenter, Mrs. Roy L. Cox, Mrs. E. McDonald Bowman, Mrs. Joseph N. Carpenter, Mrs. Charles L. Woody, Mrs. Thomas L. Tinsley, Mrs. Arthur U. Chaney, Mrs. Earl K. Williams, Mrs. M.L. Davidson of Pasadena, Calif., Miss Virginia Paull and Miss Mae Meurer.

PARIS, Wednesday, Feb. 7. -- Following a night of rioting in which at least ten persons were killed and more than 500 injured, Premier Edouard Daladier issued a proclamation early this morning in which he denounced the disturbances as "a real armed attack on the security of the State" and promised determined efforts to insure the safety of the people and the republican regime.

Despite Mayor LaGuardia's opposition to abolition of the recent 50 per cent increase in water rates, the Board of Aldermen adopted a measure yesterday giving to itself the power to fix the rates with the object of restoring them to the old basis.

A suit to foreclose a mortgage for $6,500,000 on the twenty-six-story office and loft building occupying the site of the Park Avenue Hotel on the west side of Park Avenue, between Thirty-second and Thirty-third Streets, was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by the Continental Bank and Trust Company as trustee of the mortgage made in 1926 against the Two Park Avenue Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Former navy officials and representatives of manufacturers who have sold airplanes and equipment to the navy in the last seven years were requested today to appear before a subcommittee of the House Committee on Naval Affairs and tell about the profits accruing from government contracts.

Because of the refusal of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to deal with its striking cooks and waiters through the Amalgamated Hotel and Restaurant Workers Union, the strike organization, the Millinery Code Authority was compelled last night to cancel arrangements for a luncheon which was to have been held at the hotel today marking the inauguration of the NRA label in the millinery industry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Early developments in the administration's tariff and foreign trade policy are expected in view of an announcement today by Secretary Hull that he has about completed his study of the proposals before him.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 6. -- The confidence which the veteran trainer James Fitzsimmons has in the chestnut colt Repaid was again sustained today when the son of Kai-Sang and Granny won his second victory in three starts at Hialeah Park.

The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway will spend $20,355,392 in 1934, against $18,000,000 in 1933, and $25,352,000 in 1932, S.T. Bledsoe, president, said yesterday. Of the total for this year, $16,553,347 represents carryover and $3,802,045, new projects.
The Place de la Concorde, scene of some of the most serious of yesterday's rioting, is one of the most historic spots in Paris.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 6. -- Harmony prevailed this afternoon at the annual meeting of the Gray Telephone Pay Station Company, and both factions which until a week ago were battling for control united by agreement in electing a new board of directors which later re-elected George A. Long as president.
AUSTIN, Texas, Feb. 6. -- The cottage in Austin to which Sidney Porter (O. Henry) brought his bride will be preserved as a shrine for future generations of admirers.

Fillmore Van S. Hyde of the Harvard Club, defending champion, yesterday advanced to the third round of the national veterans' squash tennis tourney on the courts of the Harvard Club in his first match of the competition.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- As the fate of the St. Lawrence treaty hangs in the balance in the Senate with no time set for a vote, Senator Copeland of New York discounted today predictions of its supporters that it will be ratified. A recent canvass, he said, showed that the treaty would not obtain more than 47 votes, 17 less than the two-third necessary for ratification.
England and the United States will meet in the Davis Cup challenge round this year and there is an even chance that the Americans will lift the trophy, in the opinion of Henri Cochet.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Recovering from a cold, President Roosevelt spent the day in the Executive Mansion but entertained tonight at a dinner for Speaker Rainey.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 6. -- Federal Judges Guy L. Fake and William Clark, sitting jointly on the first building and loan receivership application ever made in Federal court in this State, reserved decision today on an application of two stockholders for appointment of a receiver for the Warranty Building and Loan Association of this city, which has listed assets of more than $7,500,000.
PARIS, Feb. 6. -- The storm which hit the franc yesterday died down as suddenly as it came, and French currency became restored today to its quoted normal relationship to the dollar and the pound.

Aaron Schwartz, 25 years old, a pugilist and possessor of a long criminal record, was found guilty of murder in the second degree last night by a jury before Judge Rosalsky in General Sessions. The jurors had deliberated nine hours after Judge Rosalsky, in charging them, had eliminated a charge of first-degree murder.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 6. -- Frank D. Seremba's Zekiel returned to winning form at the Fair Grounds today to capture easily the six-fur-long Mithrah Handicap, which featured the program. Beaten by a length, John J. Robinson's Eva B. ran second, with Wood F. Axton's Frank Ormont third.

District Attorney William C. Dodge objected heatedly last night to the criticism already leveled at him. In an extemporaneous address at the annual dinner of the Greater New York Federation of Churches his expressions of resentment rose finally to an angry shout which brought startled looks to the faces of his audience of 300 men and women in the assembly room of the Riverside Church.

Looking as if he, too, were a victim of the depression and surprising veteran policemen by his seedy appearance, Arthur (Dapper Don) Collins, an internationally known confidence man with a long record of convictions, and four other men were arrested last night on orders of Secret Service officials.

A news report of a corporation suit last week ended with these words: "The defendants [directors] denied any wrongdoing as alleged in the complaint and stated that everything they did was not only legal but honest."

Free concerts to be given today include those of the New York Civic Orchestra, American Museum of Natural History, 3 P.M.; University Concert Orchestra, Lutheran Church of the Redeemer, Brooklyn, 8:30 P.M.; New York State Symphonic Band, Bowery Y.M.C.A., 8 P.M.; Capitol String Quartet, Bruce Public Library, West 125th Street, 8 P.M.; Harlem String Trio, 135th Street Y.M.C.A., 7 P.M.; University Chamber Trio, Central Y.W.C.A., Brooklyn, 6:30 P.M.

PATERSON, N. J., Feb. 6. -- Six men arrested in the first skirmish of Passaic County's war against the slot machine racket were convicted today of conspiracy to operate and distribute the gambling devices. The jury required only two-and-a-half hours deliberation.

ALBANY, Feb. 6. -- The State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board put its ideas for permanent State liquor regulation before a group of legislative leaders today. Discussions at the conference and at others to follow are expected to provide a basis for a measure which will have the backing of the leaders of both parties.

The report of Montgomery Ward Co. for January and twelve months was the ninth consecutive monthly statement to show an increase in sales over the corresponding period of the previous year. Sales last month were 80.67 per cent larger than the year before in the mail-order division and 20.81 per cent larger in the retail division.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP). -- An $84,170,577 appropriation bill for the State, Commerce, Justice and Labor Departments was sent to the Senate by the House today, but only after it had beaten down persistent attempts to write another $2,110,000 into the bill.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Feb. 6. -- Miss Barbara Beresford of Short Hills, second seeded player, was relegated to the sidelines of the fourth annual women's New Jersey State squash racquets tournament today when she lost to Miss Elizabeth Pearson of Philadelphia in the quarter-final round.

Total assets of the Firemen's Fund Insurance Company on Dec. 31 were $31,976,239, based on convention valuations for securities. This compares with $32,529,610 the year before. Based on actual market value for investments, however, assets increased $756,000 in the year to $29,000,155.

Twenty-four employes of the New York Civil Works Administration have been assigned to compile traffic statistics at the Commerce Building of the Port of New York Authority, Eighth Avenue and Sixteenth Street. Their reactions to different types of illumination will be observed with a view to determining the best type of lighting for the proposed new midtown tunnel between Thirty-eighth Street and Weehawken.

The money market continued dull. the shading in the Street rate on call loans to 3/4 from 7/8 on Monday being the only incident of the day. The Stock Exchange quotation held at 1 per cent. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were steady in light trading.

Mayor LaGuardia has accepted an invitation to address the Queens County grand jury at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow in its investigation into court conditions in the borough, according to an announcement yesterday by District Attorney Charles S. Colden of Queens.

In many respects the share market yesterday tracked that of the day before. The volume was 4,331,000 shares, compared with 4,941,000, and the breadth, measured by the number of separate issues dealt in, just about matched that of Monday.

Passport reports of the Department of State show that 106,000 persons applied for passports last year, as compared with 196,000 four years, ago -- "the greatest travel year in the country's history." In that year 35 per cent gave "family reasons" in stating why passports were desired. This is understood to mean "visiting relatives."

May I cite as a splendid example of service in the field of health the fine record of the National Jewish Hospital at Denver? This famous old institution is now entering upon its thirty-fifth year of service, and the national annual meeting will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria on Feb. 4.

Tammany members of the Board of Aldermen caught the spirit of the Fusion administration yesterday and sponsored a move to make a complete survey of the city administration in the interest of economy and paralleling the inquiry already started by Mayor LaGuardia and his associates.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (2P). -- More than 1,000 citizens and corporations were disclosed today to have flied claims with the State Department against Soviet Russia, seeking any financial benefits to be derived through the fast-climaxing American - Russian debt negotiations.

Liberty and liberalism, as exemplified by the American and French Republics, will triumph despite anti-liberal doctrines so much in the ascendancy throughout the world today, it was predicted last night by Andre de Laboulaye, French Ambassador to the United States.

BOSTON, Feb. 6. -- The Boston Bruins tonight virtually abandoned their hopes for an American Division play-off berth when the aggressive New York Americans outplayed them for a 1-0 victory before a slim crowd of 6,000 at the Boston Garden.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6. -- The favorites, headed by the medalist land defending titleholder, Rex Beach, won their first-round matches today in the seventh annual Winter championship of the Artists and Writers Golf Association. Beach scored the easiest victory in the first division, eliminating R.J.B. Denby, 8 and 6.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6. -- Operators in grains on the Board of Trade paid relatively little attention today to strength in Eastern markets, and several traders turned to the selling side of wheat, owing to lack of aggressive outside support. As a result, prices were depressed about a cent a bushel before support appeared.

An agreement providing a basis for ending the taxicab strike, but not actually settling it, was arrived at last night in the office of Morris L. Ernst, mediator appointed by Mayor LaGuardia, after the fleet operators had announced their intention of resuming service today under police protection.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Detroit bankers sensed as far back as the Fall of 1931 that the financial skies were darkening, and did everything in their power to strengthen their own as well as the banking lines of the country generally, Wilson W. Mills, who was chairman of the board of the Wayne First National Bank of Detroit, told the Banking and Currency Committee today.

Frank V. Kelly has been rejected by the Roosevelt administration for Democratic leader of Brooklyn to fill the vacancy caused by the death of John H. McCooey, it became known last night from an authoritative source.

The season's first performance of "Lohengrin," the only presentation of "Das Rheingold" and the return to the company of Maria Olszewska and Richard Crooks will mark the Metropolitan Opera's eighth week next week as the season enters on its second half.

The annual exhibition of the American Society of Miniature Painters, which was organized in 1899, opened with a preview yesterday afternoon at the Grand Central Galleries, where it will remain through Feb. 17. The Levantia White Boardman Memorial Medal (which carries with it a cash award of $100) was given to Mabel R. Welch for her portrait of William J. Baer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- William E. Boeing, chairman of the board of the United Aircraft and Transportation Company made paper profits of more than $51,000,000 and actual profits of about $12,000,000 from an original investment of $487,119 in the Boeing Aircraft and Transport Company, he admitted today at a hearing held by the Senate committee investigating ocean and air mail contracts.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 6. -- Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L.I., former women's national champion, and Miss Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., runner-up for the American crown in 1927, scored double victories in the Miami Biltmore golf championship today.
DETROIT, Feb. 6. -- Henry Ford said in an interview today that "wages have got to come back in this country before we can say we have come very far out of the hole."

HAVANA, Feb. 6. -- One man was killed and ten persons were injured this afternoon when police fired into a crowd of university, high school, normal and technical school students, including many girls and also mothers whose sons were killed during the Machado regime.

Six burlap sacks, containing 300 pounds of' German pamphlets and circulars described by customs officials as "Nazi propaganda," were seized on the German freighter Este yesterday morning. Members of a searching squad under Deputy Surveyor John McGill found them hidden in the cook's locker.

A new issue of $2,500,000 State of West Virginia refunding bonds, due $125,000 annually from June 1,1934 to 1953, was awarded yesterday to a syndicate composed of the First National Bank, New York; Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., Bancamerica-Blair Corporation, Salomon Bros. Hutzler and Phelps, Fenn Co.

PARIS, Feb. 6. -- There were at least five principal groups of organized manifestants among those who took part in today's demonstration, converging on the Chamber of Deputies, from different parts of Paris.

A special committee of the State Bar Association appointed by Samuel Seabury before he retired recently as president of that body will investigate the conduct of the Terzani murder investigation by District Attorney Charles S. Colden of Queens County.

BERLIN, Feb. 6. -- Instructions were issued today by Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Minister of Interior, to the chief administrative officers of the Reich and to the Governors of the several States to see that German Jews lawfully engaged in business remain unmolested by Nazi zealots.
In the fourteen Winters that I have lived in New York I have watched the present method of handling snow and have long wished to see another tried out.

The Pennsylvania Water and Power Company reports gross revenue of $5,432,883 for 1933, the highest in the history of the company, comparing with $5,240,708 for 1932. Net earnings after expenses, depreciation and taxes amounted to $3,169,639, against $3,184,006 in 1932.

Because of the rising volume of inquiries from unemployed persons seeking jobs on Civil Works projects since the promulgation of the Washington "stop-hiring" order, William H. Lange, executive director of the New York Employment Service and the National Re-employment Service, announced yesterday the opening of five borough information bureaus.

BERLIN, Feb. 6. -- The Boerse showed weakness today and price levels sagged uniformly, due to a decrease of public buying. Neither the firm closing in New York yesterday nor the conciliatory statement of the Polish Foreign Minister on German-Polish relations succeeded in maintaining the favorable tenor of the last few days.

An attempt by an inspector in one of the city's public markets to explain away an over-long lunch hour by blaming spaghetti turned out yesterday to be a dismal failure. Deputy Market Commissioner Michael Fiaschetti dismissed the inspector instanter.

The Transportation Conference of 1933 11 open its eighth general session in the Hotel Commodore this morning. It is expected to review the points raised in the recent Eastman report, namely, the imminence of government ownership and the consolidation of railways, both of which question have been the subjects of protracted study by the conference.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Organized labor today submitted to the National Labor Board a complaint illustrating its charge that undue delay in adjudicating disputes under the labor provision of the Recovery Act practically assures defeat of the organized wage-earners.
The brilliant playing of Willie Hoppe marked the return of the New Yorker last night to the world's three-cushion billiard championship after a five-year absence.

LONDON, Feb. 6 (AP). -- The United States women's squash racquets champion and the runner-up today advanced to the third round of the British title tournament as the American survivors were reduced to three.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 6. -- Yale's basketball team, staging a strong drive in the second half, turned back the Manhattan College quintet, 31 to 21, in the Eli gymnasium tonight.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society announced last evening that Arturo Toscanini, the Italian conductor, "will personally acknowledge all contributions sent directly to him at the Hotel Astor" in the society's campaign for the $500,000 guarantee fund to save the orchestra's concerts for three years to come.

Ten officers of the Private Waiters Association, the motto of which might be "They also serve who only stand and wait," met yesterday in the dignified atmosphere of their headquarters, at 120 East Fifty-ninth Street, to formulate plans for their fourteenth annual ball, to be held at the Yorkville Casino, 210 East Eighty-sixth Street, Thursday night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Two moves against the Roosevelt program were made in the Senate today, when Senators Nye and Steiwer, Republicans, introduced resolutions intended to find out how the new governmental enterprises are being carried on.
Primo Carnera, world's heavyweight champion, came back to New York last night for an appearance that was not even remotely connected with the prize ring.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.
PARIS, Feb. 6 -- Premier Daladier flatly accused the Opposition Deputies in the Chamber today of trying to install "a new power in the republic through that of agitation in the streets."

PARIS, Feb. 6 (AP). -- Although the monumental Stavisky scandal and the fall of the Bayonne pawnship which mulcted the French public out of some $40,000,000 provided the immediate cause of today's fatal rioting, the trouble had its roots deep in the economic condition of France.

Frank Charlton, financial manager and director of the White Star Line, who, it is reported, will be the general manager of the new Cunard-White Star Company, arrived last night on the Olympic to discuss with P.A.S. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marine Company, the arrangements for the termination of the activities of the I.M.M. as agent for the White Star Line here on July 1.

Members of New York Lodge, 1 of the Elks are preparing to give up their large clubhouse at 108-16 West Forty-third Street and move to modest quarters elsewhere as the result of a mortgage foreclosure action which is scheduled to be filed today.

Scientific tests indicate that in purity of air New York rapidly is becoming one of the cleanest cities in the country, according to the committee on atmospheric dust and air-cleaning devices of the American Society of Heating and Ventilating Engineers, now holding its annual convention in the Hotel Biltmore.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 6. -- In the presence of the Governor of the State, the Mayor of the city and thousands of prominent men and women of Hartford County, the Avery Memorial Museum, which has been in the course of construction a year at a cost of $600,000, was formally opened tonight to members of the Wadsworth Atheneum and their guests.

Recently the Merchants Association of New York announced that a protest had been sent to Senator Copeland against the report of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, which recommended the ratification of the St. Lawrence waterway treaty, that it "failed utterly to comprehend the magnitude or the variety of the interests opposed to ratification."

The market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $4,270,239,147 last month, according to the monthly table issued yesterday by the Exchange. This was the sharpest gain in stock values since last May.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6. -- Prices of hogs rose 10 to 40 cents a hundredweight today, with weights suitable for relief purposes in the lead. The top was $4.65, up 30 cents from yesterday and to the highest level since Oct. 23, while the day's average was up 25 cents at $4.15.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- An investigation of factors in the award of army contracts was begun today by a Federal grand jury, after Secretary Dern requested the Department of Justice to lay before Leslie C. Garnett, United States District Attorney, all information obtainable on the subject.

A rebuke to Senator Royal S. Copeland for sponsoring the American Legion four-point program was made public yesterday by Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, commander of the New York chapter of the American Veterans Association.

Cathedral Boys High continued its unbeaten pace in the New York division C.H.S.A.A. basketball competition by defeating De La Salle Institute, 34 to 9, yesterday in the East Fifty-fourth Street gymnasium.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 6. -- President Getulio Verges signed today the debt-service agreement negotiated by Valentim F. Boucas with J. Reuben Clark, representing American holders of Brazilian bonds.

New "pages" in the "Book of the Stars," composed of light waves that started on their way more than a million years ago and now being caught in the "nets" of giant telescopes and deciphered by astronomers, were "thumbed" last night at the Gould Memorial Library, New York University, by Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard College Observatory and 1934 winner of the gold medal of the Royal Astronomical Society of England.

The six-story Kingdale apartment house at 515 ,V. 187th St., was sold by the 515 V'o 1S7th St. Realty Corp. to the Five Fifteen Corp., Samuel A. Lichtensteln, president, the buyer giving to the Cortland Savings Bank of Cortland, N. Y., a mortgage for $7,250, due Feb. 1, 1939.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 6. -- Regardless of Vienna, Tyrol is initiating a strong line of its own in the last desperate battle for Austrian independence. The leaders here expect the other provinces to follow.

Continuing his policy of informing the citizens of the city's financial problems, Controller W. Arthur Cunningham made public yesterday a report on municipal construction projects involving contracts totaling about $70,000,000 which are being held up as a result of the city's inability to pay instalments aggregating $4,407,157.33.
LONDON, Feb 6. -- Sir John Simon, the Foreign Secretary, said in the House of Commons in a debate on disarmament today that "Germany's right to equality could not be resisted."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 6. -- During the first seven months since the return of beer the brewing industry has contributed $113,000,000 to the tax income of the government, according to Colonel Jacob Ruppert of New York, president of the United States Brewing Association.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- A continuation of the steady reopening of national banks which remained closed after the March holiday was announced today by the Controller of the Currency, J.F.T. O'Connor.

The importance of a definite and continued navy policy was stressed by Admiral W.H. Standley, Chief of Navy Operations, at a "Navy Night" dinner meeting last night of the Rotary Club of New York at the Commodore. Another speaker was Rear Admiral Yates Stirling, Commandant of the Third Naval District.

Supreme Court Justice Lydon held yesterday that the interest of depositors of the defunct Bank of United States was superior to that of the stockholders and upheld argument in behalf of the State Banking Department for the dismissal of defenses raised in the suit against 13,000 small stockholders for an assessment of $25 a share.
TOKYO, Feb. 6. -- Interpellations in the House of Peers regarding naval and military expenditures have elicited from the government renewed assurances that Japan's naval policy is peaceful.

A complete shutdown of the New York neckwear industry next Monday was threatened yesterday by the New York Neckwear Manufacturers Association, with a consequent dismissal of 5,000 workers, unless the neckwear code, which has been pending in Washington for many weeks, is signed immediately.

For the second consecutive month production of steel ingots increased in January, according to a tabulation issued yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute. The output of all American companies was estimated at 1,996,897 tons, against 1,819,648 in December, 1,540,882 in November and 1,030,075 in January, 1933.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Settlement of a century-old boundary dispute between Peru and Ecuador will be attempted soon in Washington, President Roosevelt announced today. Both Peru and Ecuador have requested permission to send negotiating commissions here and the President has assented.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7. -- Members of the Seven O'Klockers Club, commuters who pay $38.24 each in train fare every month in order to live in Philadelphia and work in New York, elected officers for 1934 during yesterday morning's ride to work in their private car attached to a Reading Company train.

TORONTO, Feb. 7. -- Herb Flack of Toronto won the North American indoor speed-skating championship tonight with a total of 100 points scored in the two-day meet at Maple Leaf Gardens. Lamar Ottsen of St. Louis took second place with 80 points and Ray Darmstadt of Astoria, L.I., finished third with 70.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Secretary Wallace gave his "unqualified support" today to the use of the taxing power of the government to compel a reduction in the production of Cotton. He had opposed such a plan for months.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 7. -- Testimony that Municipal Court Justice Harold L. Kunstler of New York said he "had to pay $10,000 for a municipal judgeship" and that he represented he could get a defendant out of jail through George W. Olvany, former leader of Tammany Hall, was given in a civil action before Supreme Court Justice George H. Taylor Jr. here today.
An increased demand from the automobile manufacturers accounts for the present sharp upturn in steel business, according to The Iron Age.

Raymond B. Stevens, president of the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, issued a statement yesterday expressing gratification with the debt-service agreement signed by the Brazilian Government. J. Reuben Clark, a member of the directorate of the council, conducted the negotiations in Rio de Janeiro in the interests of bondholders in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- After a suggestion had been made in Senate debate that failure of an investigating committee to call former Postmaster General Brown "might be through a disinclination to grant him immunity in a criminal prosecution," Senator Fess expressed the belief today that Mr. Brown would waive such immunity and appear.

A worthy project which is not obtaining the support it deserves because of lack of publicity is the Outlet Shop, a non-profit organization which serves as a clearing-house for the work of persons who do not wish to ask for charity yet have no means of disposing of the goods they are able to make themselves.

A broad survey of the city's public school system by a committee of seven members, four of whom will be appointed by Mayor LaGuardia, was authorized by the Board of Education at a special meeting last night.
An exhibition showing algebra, geometry and trigonometry correlated with music, poetry and art will open today at Teachers College of Columbia University.
Ambassador William C. Bullitt and his staff are scheduled to sail for Russia Feb. 15, leaving on the United States liner Washington from New York.

Joseph P. Day, real estate man and a director of the New York Guaranteed Mortgage Corporation, held out hope to certificate holders last night that they would soon be able to borrow from the $50,000,000 fund made available for that purpose by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 7. -- Columbia University scored its second victory in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League at the Harvard Indoor Athletic Building tonight, turning back the Crimson, 29 to 25, in an exciting and hard-fought game.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- An intensive study of all phases of civil, commercial and military aviation will be undertaken by a special interdepartmental committee, at the request of President Roosevelt, with a view to formulating a national policy on this imoprtant agency of transportation and national defense.

The new Federal conservation program may be put into official operation this week. So much support has been expressed in recent days that there now seems little likelihood of any hitch occurring which might delay putting the program to save and propagate our wild-life resources into effect.

PARIS, Feb. 7. -- The Bourse today reflected the turbulency of events outside its walls, but, benefiting by skillful handling from quarters which had good reasons to desire it, rentes and French stocks made a spectacular recovery after a weak opening.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 7. -- The Harvard Liberal Club, recently reorganized on less radical lines than previously, today launched a militant, nation-wide student movement to oust Huey P. Long from his seat in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Ten companies making practically all of the viscose rayon yarn produced in the United States were accused by the Federal Trade Commission today of combining and conspiring to form a price-fixing monopoly.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday its intention to investigate the desirability of requiring railroads serving New York City to sell commutation tickets good for a reduced number of trips a month at a lower rate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Senator James Hamilton Lewis of Illinois was appointed today chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee and predicted that the issue in the elections this Fall would be the endorsement of the President's policies.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- George Bernard Shaw will sail for New Zealand tomorrow to see the only country in the British Empire where white men and natives have lived for a century on terms of perfect equality and friendship.
THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 4 published a telegram from J.H. Rand of the Committee of the Nation, part of which follows:

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP). -- Francis X. Bushman, movie matinee idol of more than a decade ago, late today obtained a marriage license to wed Carmela Ponselle, a soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company and a sister of the opera star, Rosa Ponselle.
U. S. Department of Agriculture.

New York will get its first glimpse of the Yankees in championship competition this year on April 24, according to the official 1934 schedule of the American League, released for publication today. On that day Manager Joe McCarthy's forces will inaugurate their home season at the Stadium against the revamped Athletics.

Control of small private hospitals by a board selected by the Commissioner of Hospitals, and forbidding such institutions to take maternity cases unless they provide adequate facilities, were urged in resolutions adopted yesterday at the annual meeting of the Children's Welfare Federation at the Red Cross Building, 315 Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Conferences between Secretary Ickes, oil administrator under the petroleum code, and Walter C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, resulted today in dropping the administration's suit against the company for holding a "Babe Ruth" prize contest and discontinuance of the contest by the company.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 7. -Displaying the brand of golf that brought her the women's national title in 1931, Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L.I., scored an easy victory in the quarter-final round of the Miami Biltmore championship today. She overwhelmed Mrs. Estelle Weill of New York, 8 and 6, without relinquishing a single hole.

Edgar J. Kohler, attorney of 25 West Forty-third Street, supported the Board of Estimate's refusal to appropriate $76,000 for Transit Commission salaries in a letter yesterday to Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch.
ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- Both houses of the Legislature gave their approval today to two bills sought by Robert Moses, the new city park head, to coordinate the park systems of the city and State.
The premiere of "Sing and Whistle,'' scheduled for this evening at the Fulton Theatre, has been postponed until Saturday evening at the same house.

GREENWOOD, Miss., Feb. 7 (AP). -- Using a State witness as the medium, attorneys for Dr. Sarah Ruth Dean, on trial for the alleged poisoning of Dr. John Preston Kennedy, laid testimony before the jury today that Dr. Kennedy had once been ill from an overdose of drugs several months prior to his fatal illness.
Abraham Lincoln forgeries of such exceptional cleverness as to deceive several collectors and dealers have appeared recently in New York, New England and Chicago, it has been learned here.

After having served a month's sentence in the bleak northern spaces of this city, Dorothy Parker's satirical sketches. "After Such Pleasures," settled down cozily into the Bijou last evening. This reviewer can only echo the sentiments of cheer that appeared in these columns after the previous opening.

Babe Ruth negotiated his fortieth milestone yesterday, feeling not as hale and robust as he would like, but tolerably well, all things considered, and highly optimistic over his chances of a swift and sure recovery once he is able to shake New York's frigid climate. Accompanied by Mrs. Ruth, the noted Yankee home run slugger will entrain for St. Petersburg, Fla., at 9:30 o'clock this morning.

Hailing the NRA as an instrument of "a better day for all of us," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt sewed yesterday the first of 140,000,000 NRA labels to be used annually in the millinery industry under its code.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 7. -- New York State's stricken racing industry may soon be governed by a State commission similar to those in existence in many other States.

Mayor LAGUARDIA has done well to appoint a special committee to look into the much-debated question of tax-exempt property in New York City. The principles underlying the present system of exemptions are rooted deep in American history and tradition. The problem is far too complex to be disposed of overnight.

The New York Athletic Club continued to hold its narrow lead over the Columbia University Club last night as both teams added one more victory to their long string in the Class A championship of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7. -- The American Medical Association was assailed as the mouthpiece of "an ostrich philosophy" on the part of a "recalcitrant minority" in the medical profession, and was defended with equal vigor against the "attempted dictation" of non-medical groups at a joint meeting today of the College of Physicians of Philadelphia and the American Academy of Political and Social Science.

The money market was at a standstill. Business was light and quotations for all classifications unchanged from Tuesday. Stock Exchange call loan rate remained at 1 per cent, but Street trades were done at 3/4 7/8.
BERLIN, Feb. 7. -- Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller carried the Protestant church war into the camp of the opposition today by a new edict that "legalizes" measures for stifling it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Federal Trade Commission today announced the effectiveness of the registration statement filed by the Konversionskasse fur Deutsche Auslandsschulden [the Conversion Office for the Handling of German Foreign Debts] of Berlin, covering about $13,000,000 in scrip to be issued in part payment of interest due in this country on certain German dollar bonds.

The franc rallied further yesterday on what appeared to be official support, cutting down its discount against the dollar to 4.2 per cent, against 4.8 per cent on Tuesday. Corresponding to this improvement of the franc, the premium on the dollar was reduced .7 cent to 4.4 per cent.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- A debate on whether Britain should now rearm was terminated with the honors evenly divided in the House of Commons tonight. No vote was taken, but the general sense of the House was that the possibility of war must be faced.

An exhibition of recent work by Charles Burchfield has opened at the Rehn Gallery, 683 Fifth Avenue, there to remain until Feb. 24. Mr. Burchfield is one of our most accomplished and best known American water-colorists. In the present exhibition all save one of the pictures are in the water-color medium, the exception being a large oil landscape, "November Evening."
ATHENS, Feb. 7 (AP). -- The dragging issue of whether Samuel Insull Sr. should be expelled from Greece will be placed on the doorstep of Premier Panayoti Tsaldaris tomorrow.

Sascha Gorodnitzki, pianist, who made a brilliant debut at a Schubert memorial concert several seasons ago, when he played the Liszt E flat concerto, and who has since made other concert appearances in this city, gave a piano recital last night in Carnegie Hall.

A fast final-period attack enabled New York University's undefeated basketball team to record a 39-to-26 victory over Rutgers at the University Heights gym last night. It was the Violet quintet's eighth consecutive triumph.

Wall Street was plainly agitated yesterday by the detailed explanation of the proposed regulatory bill, and this was the chief topic of discussion. In point of interest, it overshadowed even the news of the grave political situation in France.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- How mistrusting bankers balked Samuel Insull in his last effort to keep control over his utilities system twenty-two months ago was recalled today at the Insull "town meeting" called by Federal Judge Walter C. Lindley to discover whether fraud was practiced on his court in the receivership of the Middle West Utilities Company.
VIENNA, Feb. 7. -- An "instrument such as the Kellogg pact" was described tonight by Harold Nicholson, British author and former diplomat, as a "danger to international amity."

During the last years of Dr. Hyman G. Enelow's life he had enriched Hebrew literature by the editing of some monumental works which assure him a permanent place of distinction in the realm of scholarship. The four volumes of a fourteenth-century Hebrew ethical work (Menorat ha-Maor), which he published in 1929-32, and the startling discovery of a long-lost Midrash (Mishnah of R. Eliezer), published by him only last November, are of outstanding value.

Sending a tally into the net in each period, the Atlantic Sea Gulls triumphed over the fighting All-Star sextet, 3 to 1, at Madison Square Garden last night. The encounter was staged as a benefit for the parents of the late Albert Ritchie, former Sea Gull star who died as a result of injuries sustained in a hockey game.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Spurred by President Roosevelt, House and Senate leaders agreed today as to the form Stock Exchange regulation shall take and that a bill providing it, now in the making, will be introduced in the two houses on Friday.

PALMA, Majorca, Feb. 7 (AP). -- The four Americans who had been sentenced to six months and a day in prison for assaulting a Civil Guard were released today on condition that they leave this Spanish island.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The House Ways and Means Committee issued a table today showing how much a married man with no dependents would have to pay under the normal income and surtax rates proposed in the new Revenue Bill. The normal rate is 4 per cent and the surtax rates begin at 4 per cent on incomes of $4,000 and are graduated to 59 per cent on those over $1,000,000.

The Spring semester at Columbia University opened yesterday with an enrolment that indicates that economic improvement has reached the universities, according to Edward J. Grant, registrar. Incomplete registration figures show the number of new students in University Extension has increased 17.3 per cent over the Spring session of last year.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- An undertone of uneasiness prevailed today in the grain trade and selling of wheat on the Board of Trade by houses with Eastern connections that were recently on the buying side started a liquidating movement which carried wheat off as much as 3 cents a bushel from yesterday's closing prices and other grains followed.

A net loss of $7,285,421 in 1932 was converted into a net profit of $7,053,088 in 1933 by the American Woolen Company, according to the annual report, issued yesterday. The company voted to pay a dividend of $1.25 a share on the 7 per cent preferred stock, the first payment since April 15, 1927.

LYONS, Feb. 7. -- A riot much more violent than yesterday's was started here this evening when the young Royalist Camelots du Roi and Young Patriots in the centre of town ran counter to a Communist demonstration. Dozens of fights began at once.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- An invitation to send a team of English women golfers to the United States to meet an American side for the Curtis Cup was officially accepted today by the Ladies Golf Union at its annual meeting.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- Judge William J. Lindsay of the Superior Court today signed the contract under which the Hercules Life Insurance Company, a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck Co., takes over the reinsurance of the 112,000 policy holders of the National Life Insurance Company of the United States of America, which was placed in receivership on Oct. 17, 1933.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- President Roosevelt feels that interest rates on many outstanding obligations of industry, municipalities and foreign governments held by the American people are too high, and that readjustment downward, voluntarily or through legislation, would pave the way for principal repayments which in some instances now are found to be extremely difficult or impossible.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Eugene R. White, director of the international mail division of the Post office Department, testified today before the Senate mail investigating committee that he and W. Irving Glover, an Assistant Postmaster General in the Hoover administration, received a free trip to Europe in 1931 on the Hamburg-American Line.

Tracing the efforts of the petroleum industry in recent years to bring about stability, C.B. Ames, chairman of the Texas Corporation, said yesterday in an address before the Bond Club of New York that the industry had made progress under the NRA code.

YONKERS, N.Y., Feb. 7. -- While Yonkers and Mount Vernon were considering today the feasibility of adopting the city manager form of government, reports came from New Rochelle, where that system is established, that there was considerable dissatisfaction over the alleged failure to abide by the economy program as recommended by the Citizens' Committee on Finance.

About 400 employes of the ninety-one institutions affiliated with the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies put into effect yesterday a two-hour "stoppage" of work which they had decided upon last week as a protest against a continuation of reduced wages.
PARIS, Feb. 7. -- The 6th of February, 1934, will long leave its mark on the guiding policy of France.

A hearing on an application for a revision of the method of computing rentals of wharfage space by barges and lighters attracted yesterday about 150 ship-owners and representatives of trade groups to the office of Dock Commissioner John McKenzie.

PARIS, Feb. 7. -- Battles in the Paris streets were not reflected in the exchange market today, which remained remarkably calm. Neither the dollar nor the pound showed important variations and, while psychologically and in the long run, the present turmoil may prove harmful to the franc, its momentary effect has been virtually nil.

Certain news items from Paris which may have eluded a reader's attention here and there are of basic interest. For instance, AUGUSTABERNARD makes her slim elongating line softly casual by shirrings, full-gathered ruffles and gathers replacing all pleats.

Brokers reported a large volume of business leases yesterday. The bulk of these rentals involved contracts for space in buildings in the midtown section of Manhattan, especially in the fur trades district in the West Thirties. Some tenants renewed their leases and others added to their present facilities by taking additional space.
NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 7. -- Conflicting statements were made today by two officials of the National Recovery Administration concerning the attitude of the Federal Government toward State codes.

PARIS, Feb. 7. -- Editorials in the Paris press today reflect horror and indignation at the "day of civil war" which took place yesterday. But, although the newspapers are unanimous on that aspect of the situation and nearly all welcome the coming of a Government of National Union, there is a natural division of opinion between the Right and Left regarding responsibilities.
MOSCOW, Feb. 7. -- The Communist Party Congress has unanimously ratified the second Five-Year Plan after three days of debate.

Thomas Jefferson and Samuel J. Tilden High won Brooklyn P.S. A.L. basketball games yesterday. Jefferson, defending Brooklyn champion, triumphed on its home court over Eastern District, 30 to 18. Tilden turned back Brooklyn Tech, 32 to 13, at the Central Methodist Episcopal Church.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Still surrounded with secrecy, a Federal grand jury continued its investigation today of the alleged use of improper influence in connection with the award of War Department contracts.

Any hasty supposition that a mob in the streets of Paris could overthrow the French Republic is already dissipated by events. President LEBRUN took his courage in both hands and called for a Government of concentration to be headed by an outstanding figure in French public life.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 7. -- Raymond Workman, contract rider for C.V. Whitney, got his first double of the year at Hialeah Park today when he scored with Mr. Whitney's Love Sick in the second race and then came back with James Kelley's General A. in the featured Naples Purse.

The heaviest advance buying on men's Fall wear since 1929 was placed by stores in the last two weeks, according to reports here yesterday. Convinced that prices will go higher, retailers are covering heavily on staple items, such as underwear, suede jackets, leatherette sheep-lined coats and other cold-weather goods.

Two children were burned to death, and their mother, another child of the same family and a fireman were injured yesterday afternoon when fire mushroomed through a five-story tenement at 349 East 118th Street, near First Avenue.

ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn, who is also Democratic leader of the Bronx and one of the big figures in the Democratic anti-Tammany movement, held a long conference with Governor Lehman today. The Governor declined to discuss the conversation, and Mr. Flynn departed for New York City without submitting to an interview.

Whether it was because of an oversold condition, further realizing or fright over the possibility of Federal regulation, all of which were mentioned as influences, the share market passed yesterday through a severe reaction. To Wall Street it seemed to be a tardy but "corrective'' readjustment; to many margin speculators it was a costly experience.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The handing of about a billion dollars to American farmers during 1934 as benefit payments for production control and corn loans is planned by the Farm Administration.
PARIS, Thursday, Feb. 8. -- The streets of this city were cleared of rioters at 2 o'clock this morning after a night of sporadic clashes more widespread but less violent than those of Tuesday.

PARIS, Feb. 7. -- The rioting of yesterday and today proved fallacious the belief that the modernization of Paris and improved mobile police methods had abolished what in revolutionary times was called "the rule of the mob."

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- Features on the Stock Exchange today were a sharp advance in rayons, under the lead of British Celanese; improvement in rubber shares on a fresh rise in the commodity, and further buying of aviations. Rubber touched a new high record since 1930 of 5 3-32d a pound on the report that the Dutch Premier was coming to London on Friday in connection with the restriction negotiations.
Banks took over eight of thirteen properties bid in at foreclosure auctions in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday. Most of the offerings were tenement houses.

Net income of the Continental Can Company jumped from $4,819,322, or $2.78 a share on common stock, in 1932 to $7,547,401, or $4.31 a share, in 1933. This increase, amounting to 57 per cent, was after making provision for all charges and Federal taxes.

VIENNA, Feb. 7. -- The Austrian Trade Commission departed for the United States yesterday with the warmest wishes for its success from it he entire populace and particularly from Chancellor Dollfuss, who hopes greatly for concrete achievements from the visit.

When Sinclair Lewis read the galley proofs of his novel, "Work of Art," he eliminated a long section about the progress of a bad writer, Ora Weagle, brother of Myron, his principal character. He thought Ora's introduction to New York's Bohemia impeded his major story.

Is there not some error in your statement on the editorial page that the French price level was only 15 per cent above the level in 1918? My understanding is that the level is 600 to 700 per cent of the level of 1918.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 7. -- A warning to brewers that prohibition is not permanently relegated to oblivion if racketeering and intemperance are permitted to abound was given tonight at the convention of the United States Brewers Association by Dr. Max Henius of Chicago, head of the Wahl-Henius Institute of Chemical Research.
The screen rights to "Oil for the Lamps of China," the novel by Alice Tisdale Hobart, have been purchased by Warner Brothers.

PARIS, Feb. 7. -- With a view to sparing diplomatic officers and the clerical Staff of the United States Embassy from the possibility of serious involvement in the turbulent events taking place before the United States Government building in the Place de la Concorde, Ambassador Straus ordered every one home at 4 o'clock.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 7. -- Penn State won from the Army five at basketball today, 28 to 24. The contest was hard-fought throughout, although Army led at half-time, 14 to 9.

Lord Marley, a Deputy Speaker of the House of Lords, and chairman of the World Committee to Aid Victims of German Fascism, told more than 600 persons at a dinner in his honor last night stores of Nazi atrocities. Speaking quietly, and declaring that he did not intend to "harrow" his audience, Lord Marley quoted from case records compiled by the international committee from sources that he said were "above all suspicion."
PARIS, Feb. 7. -- Former President Gaston Doumergue has been called from his retreat at this dramatic moment to take the leadership of the government of France.

Turning in the most spectacular exhibition in the world's three-cushion billiard championship thus far, Jay N. Bozeman Jr., the 27-year-old Vallejo, Calif., player over-Philadelphia veteran, whelmed the Otto Reiselt, by 50 to 19 in thirty-four innings last night at the Capitol Academy.

BERLIN, Feb. 7. -The Boerse today rallied from yesterday'S depression, although the buying public continued to hold aloof. Uncertainty over international currency stabilizatlon continued to influence the rnarke. A. E. G. and Siemens Halske showed strength in early trading, but weakened toward the close.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 7. -- Yale triumphed over Dartmouth by 4 to 3 tonight after 80 minutes of thrilling hockey before 1,100 spectators in the New Haven Arena. Warren Colby, taking Bob Cooke's pass within three minutes of the close of the second overtime period, propelled the rubber into the Green net for the winning counter.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 7 (AP). -- Three men and a woman were arrested today and placed in jail at Clayton on warrants charging them with complicity in the kidnapping of Dr. Isaac D. Kelley, ear, nose and throat specialist, on April 20, 1931.

Morris Weinberg, vice president and one of the directors of the Bank of United States, a defendant in the $60,000,000 suit against the directors by the Superintendent of Banks, got permission yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Valente to settle for $400,000. A judgment will be entered against him.

THE red shift in the solar spectrum has been studied. Now the scientists might turn their telescopes, spectroscopes and logarithms on the Red shift in the baseball spectrum. All the citizens of Cincinnati are agog so to peak. Even the dignified Lieutenant Governor of Ohio, Charles L. Sawyer, has enlisted under the Red banner.
LONDON, Feb. 7. -- As his first offering with the English Theatre Guild, Norman MacDermott presented tonight Scan O'Casey's impressionistic fantasy of Hyde Park, "Within the Gates."

Rudolph J. Schaefer's new cruising sloop, being built at Nevins's yard, City Island, from designs by, Sparkman Stephens, is to he entered in the Bermuda race, which will start from New London in June. She will be named Edlu Robert N. Bavier will sail the craft in the ocean contest. With him will be Butler Whiting, Larry Reybino and O.P. Merrell.

The arrest yesterday afternoon of Irving May, an Insurance adjuster, with an office at 111 John Street, on an arson indictment, revealed that for two days last week Sam Skoblow, confessed Brooklyn incendiary, had testified before the New York County grand jury in a series of suspicious fires in Manhattan.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- The three surviving members of the American women's squash racquets team today reached the quarter-finals of the British championship, all winning their matches at the Queen's Club.

A further sharp improvement established new high prices for the year on the Cotton Exchange yesterday under the broadest, most active trading since last July. An opening rise of a dollar a bale met heavy realizing, and reports of political developments in France started a 30-point setback.

LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP). -- Three American invaders and five English women remain in the British squash racquets championship. Miss Susan Noel, the defending English champion, is among those still present.

Mayor LaGuardia disclosed yesterday that he was trying to have the Federal Government advance money to the city against its uncollected taxes. He said this step would permit termination of the bankers' agreement with a substantial saving to the city.

PARIS, Feb. 7. -- Most of the animosity of the crowds seemed to be vented today on the Mobile Guards. The attitude toward the police, once it became known the Ministry had resigned, became good natured. The Civil Guards, young helmeted cavalrymen carrying carbines slung over their shoulders, were followed wherever they went by cries of "assassin."
Harry Lanza, brother of Joe (Socks) Lanza of Fulton Fish Market, has been appointed an assistant clerk of the Municipal Court in the Second district, it became known yesterday.

Controller W. Arthur Cunningham made public yesterday a report of the city's financial condition which not only showed the budget to be $30,820,000 out of balance, but also that the city must raise $185,222,000 within a year to meet extra budget obligations.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The wife of the President is in no way immune from the bitterest kind of verbal attack, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt confessed last night at a dinner given in her honor at Sherry's by the Women's University Club. She recently was elected an honorary member of the club.

Although Mayor LaGuardia announced yesterday that he regarded the walkout of taxicab drivers as settled, the worst disorder since the strike began broke out last midnight when a crowd of 500 men went on the rampage in midtown. This outbreak followed a day of violence in all parts of the city.

PARIS, Feb. 7. -- Chanel is showing some new high-relief prints that are creating a textile sensation. They give the illusion of being covered with festoons of fringe, ribbons, bead motifs or feather trimmings.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 8. -- The descent from serious politics to trivialities which occurs at some period in every session of the Diet came yesterday when Baron Kumachi Nakajima, the Minister of Commerce, was assailed regarding a magazine article he had written on Takauji Ashikaga, who played the part of the Japanese Benedict Arnold 600 years ago.

Primo Carnera, the world's heavyweight champion, is probably the world's most incompetent and indifferent person about financial matters, the boxer's manager, Louis Soresi, testified yesterday in a bankruptcy hearing before Referee Peter B. Olney Jr. at 19 Rector Street.

Twice Mayor LAGUARDIA has announced a settlement of the taxicab strike and each time the agreement has been rejected by the strikers themselves. The first time it was by almost unanimous vote. The second time drivers in the Bronx and in Brooklyn agreed to accept the terms offered, but the Manhattan leaders and many of their followers declared that the strike must go on.

Irregularity again prevailed yesterday in price movements for commodity futures on local exchanges. In most instances the volume of trading was maintained at a good level. Silver and sugar were higher, while the others closed with losses. Gains and losses were about evenly divided in the cash markets, and several new high records were made.

Nothing could have given more satisfaction to the scholar, statesman and friend of America, EDOUARD LABOULAYE, than to know that a grandson of his would some day be Ambassador to the United States, as he is today. It is recalled by this grandson that the idea of a memorial symbolizing the kinship of the two republics, resulting in the construction of the Bartholdi statue, was first proposed in the house of his grandfather.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- After six months of negotiation, the national trucking code, covering more than 1,250,000 employes, has been completed and is now on General Johnson's desk for signature.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 7. -- T.E. Keating's 8-year-old gelding Pacheco scored handily in the mile and three-quarters of the Advanced Guard Purse at the Fair Grounds today. Two lengths behind the winner at the finish was T.C. Worden's 7-year-old gelding Lahor, with the 4-year-old Bourbon Prince third.

TOKYO, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Japan's neighbors -- the United States, Russia and China -- "knowing Japan is likely to be confronted with various international difficulties in November, 1935, are steadily preparing for war," was the statement attributed today to Major Gen. Eiki Tojo, chief of the War Office's Military Investigation Bureau.

Robert E. Christie Jr., president of the Investment Bankers Association, announced yesterday the members of the committee to administer the Investment Banking Code under the NRA, following a conference with NRA officials. The committee, comprising twenty-one members, includes both members and non-members of the association and is designed fully to represent all parts of the country and all types of investment banking houses.

The murder of Anthony Fierro at a meeting of the Khaki Shirts of America in Astoria, Queens, last Summer, for which his friend, Athos Terzani subsequently was tried and acquitted, was solved yesterday when a man arrested in Philadelphia confessed he had fired the fatal bullet.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- A special stamp over the cork of bottled whisky so the public may know whether the liquor has been legally produced and the tax paid was ordered today by the Treasury.

EVANSTON, Ill., Feb. 7 (AP). -- Most of the Protestant ministers in Chicago, answering a questionnaire sent out by the School of Education of Northwestern University, agreed today they did not want children to believe that God sends storms, earthquakes and other disasters to punish people for their sins.

A delegation of striking hotel workers, headed by B.J. Field, secretary of the Amalgamated Hotel and Restaurant Workers Union and leader of the strike, called on Mayor LaGuardia at City Hall yesterday in an effort to enlist his support of the strike.
W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, announced yesterday that he would be a candidate in the Republican primaries this Fall to succeed himself.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7. -- Pink roses formed the table decorations for the luncheon with which Mrs. Eben Howes Ellison of the Breakers entertained today in the North Lounge. At its conclusion the guests attended the first lecture in the current events series, held at the villa of Mr. and Mrs. Emil J. Stehli, where J. Frederick Essarey, Washington correspondent for The Baltimore Sun, spoke on "Politics in Washington."

Billy, the maltese cat of the Times Square Building, is gone. Ironically, he lost his life because of some unsuspected and untimely ptomaine germ, although no cat on Broadway ever had a more delicate fancy in foods, or was able to indulge that fancy more freely.
VIENNA, Feb. 7 (AP). -- Several provincial sections of Austria were under virtual Fascist control tonight, with Heimwehr troops occupying strategic positions after drastic demands.

Dr. Christian J. Beck, managing director of the Hamburg-American Line and North German Lloyd in this country, issued a statement yesterday characterizing the presence of a quantity of German pamphlets and circulars aboard the Este as "a great offense" against strict orders issued by the company and also by the National Socialist party.
The bond market on the New York Stock Exchange suffered a rather severe sinking spell yesterday, issues of all classifications ending lower on the day on the average.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 7. -- Receivers for the Willys-Overland Company were authorized today to manufacture between 5,000 and 7,500 cars and to issue receivers' certificates for between $352,000 and $750,000 to finance the work. The orders were signed by Judge George P. Hahn in Federal court at a hearing where receivers, general creditors, the National City Bank of New York, as bondholders' trustee, and other interests, were represented.

ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, filed with the Labor Committees of the Senate and Assembly today a protest against the Warner-Hollowell Bill which he said would open the way to restoration of unduly long hours for women in canning factories.
ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- The State received $608,067 in taxes on liquor and wine in the first 26 days after repeal went into effect, Mark Graves, president of the Tax Commission, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Senator Borah called for restoration of the anti-trust laws in a radio address tonight over the National Broadcasting Company's network, urging that it was impossible otherwise to protect the consumer and the small business man from extortion on the one hand and ruin on the other from the price-fixing complained of under NRA codes.
Federal and State authorities were warned yesterday that any attempt to lower the milk standards in New Jersey would lead to a milk strike.
Clyde Cole, Eastern intercollegiate heavyweight wrestling champion, enabled Penn State to gain a 15-13 victory over Columbia yesterday in the Morningside Heights gymnasium.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 7. -- Harry E. Henneman, a vice president of the National City Bank of New York, concluded today two days of testimony before United States Judge Cooper in the United Porto Rican Sugar Company receivership case.
Mrs. J. Andre Fouilhoux gave a luncheon yesterday at Mayfair House. Among her guests were:

A tribe of Brazilian Indians whose men may marry not only a wife, but the mother-in-law as well, was described yesterday by J.H. Blumensohn, Columbia University student, who returned after spending thirteen months with the Indians gathering material for his Ph. D. degree in anthropology.
PARIS, Feb. 7. -- One side issue of the French political drama this week was raised, as it were, to heights Shakespearean.

Alexander Tcherepnine's one-act opera in three scenes and two entr'acts, "Ol-Ol," had its American premiere last night at the Casino with the Russian Opera Company. The score was written in 1928 and revised in 1931. It is said to have had many performances in Central Europe, and to have been frequently broadcast.

Bertha Brodsky, 14 years old, was the happiest and the proudest girl in the Orthopaedic Hospital, 420 East Fifty-ninth to be, for Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt found time at the end of a crowded day to pay her a visit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- An easing of the tax burden on incomes ranging between $8,000 and $25,000, and an additional 1/2-cent-a-gallon tax on imported petroleum were voted today by the House Ways and Means Committee.

PARIS, Feb. 7. -- Reports reaching Paris from the provinces clearly indicate that yesterday's bloody riots have brought on a virtual political revolution in most sections of France. There was no doubt here tonight that the country had gone overwhelmingly to the Right, whereas in the elections just two years, ago it was demonstrated that the prevailing sympathies were with the Socialists and Radical Socialists.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- With the scene set for a vigorous attempt tomorrow to increase appropriations for the Civil Works Administration to $2,500,000,000, Senate debate today centred on an amendment to the $950,000,000 bill passed last week by the House, which would give to those disabled while on the CWA payrolls the benefits of the Workmen's Compensation Act.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 7. -Threats of kidnapping and bodily harm made against Assistant State Attorney General James D. Carpenter Jr. and his aides will serve to intensify their efforts to clear Passaic County of jury-fixers, gamblers and racketeers, Mr. Carpenter said today as he confirmed reports that a series of anonymous warnings had been received.

MONTREAL, Feb. 7. -- Plans for a hockey game to be played in Toronto Feb. 14 between the Toronto Maple Leafs and an all-star team of National Hockey League players for the benefit of the injured Irvin (Ace) Bailey were completed today with the selection of the players who will comprise the all-star squad. Two were named from each of the other clubs in the league.
When the cry for "another Poincare" rises in France the politicians turn their eyes to Gaston Doumergue, President of the republic from June 13, 1924, to June, 1931.

A syndicate composed of Estabrook Co., Phelps, Fenn Co. and Graham, Parsons Co. won yesterday the award of a new issue of $875,000 Suffolk County (N.Y.) bonds, topping seven other bidders. The price paid was 100.66 for the bonds as 3.90s.

MADRID, Feb. 7. -- The Cabinet headed by Alejandro Lerroux survived today the most severe test of its existence thus far when it won a vote of confidence in the Cortes on its ability to cope with Socialist threats to plunge Spain into a sanguinary class war. The vote was 235 to 54.

In 1894 the late Mrs. Schuyler Van Rensselaer's son Griswold, a student in Harvard University, died in Colorado Springs suddenly and tragically, just as he was believed to have recovered from a dread disease. Shortly after her return to New York she came down to work at the old Neighborhood Guild in Delancey Street, later the University Settlement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The Controller of the Currency in the last two years of the Hoover administration was accused by a witness before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today of being responsible for the Michigan bank collapse last February. The Controller at that time was John W. Pole, but during the latter part of the period F.G. Awalt was Acting Controller.
The effects of the weather on public health were discussed yesterday at the annual convention of the American Society of Heating and Ventilating Engineers at the Hotel Biltmore.

Everything good to eat except hominy has had public notice since the return of legal drinking. When beer made its lawful return, there occurred a rise in interest in pig's knuckle and sauerkraut. With liquor sold openly, the hotels and fashionable restaurants offered not only to "set 'em up" to any one who ordered a drink they could not produce, but also announced menus of endless variety.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- The British have just built a small secret fighting aircraft that can climb 20,000 feet in a little more than nine minutes, it was stated during an armament debate in the House of Commons tonight. The machine is too light to carry bombs, but is fitted with two machine guns operated by the pilot who flies alone.

Beginning next Monday retail liquor stores will be permitted to remain open for business two hours longer from Monday to Friday and one hour longer on Saturday, Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, announced yesterday.
Guiomar Novaes, the Brazilian pianist, will play Schumann's A-minor concerto with the Philharmonic-Symphony under Hans Lange this evening and tomorrow afternoon at Carnegie Hall.

Acting in accordance with a resolution adopted by the Senate several days ago, the Federal Trade Commission has begun an investigation of price-fixing under the NRA. It is specifically instructed to discover what has been done in that line under the Steel and the Oil Codes, and to report its findings to the Senate with the least possible delay.

PARIS, Feb. 7. -- The charge of a plot against the safety of the State, with which the Daladier government rang down the curtain on last night's sanguinary rioting, seems to have been forgotten today.

In a letter sent yesterday to creditors of the McCrory Stores Corporation, C.T. Green, president, urged prompt approval of the company's reorganization plan. He said majority assent of the creditors, subject to court approval of the plan, would render unnecessary the cost of continuing bankruptcy proceedings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Naval auditors were probably "negligent" in auditing the books of the Pratt-Whitney Aircraft Company at Hartford, Captain T.P. Ballenger, chief of the Navy Department Accounts Division, admitted today to a House naval subcommittee investigating charges of exorbitant profits.

Further testimony in connection with the charges against the production management of "The Lake," current attraction at the Martin Beck Theatre, for alleged violations of the Legitimate Theatre Code was taken at a meeting yesterday of the Legitimate Theatre Code Authority.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 7. -- Vice Chancellor Malcolm G. Buchanan, sitting as vice ordinary in Prerogative Court, upheld today inheritance taxes levied by New Jersey against the estate of Dr. John T. Dorrance.

As had been forecast, the President asked Congress yesterday to make sugar a "basic commodity" under the terms of the Agricultural Adjustment Act. This is the first step in a new Administration plan to remedy a situation which Mr. ROOSEVELT describes as unsatisfactory "to virtually every one interested."

Several important changes in Federal Reserve statistics were disclosed in the weekly report of the Reserve System published yesterday. All of these changes showed up in the summary of changes in Reserve Bank credit and related items.

LONDON, Feb. 8. -- The dream of a unified British steamship service on the North Atlantic became a reality today with the announcement in the House of Commons that the Cunard-White Star merger had been completed. It will become effective as soon as the shareholders of the two companies approve it.

Contributions of over $150,000 to the Philharmonic-Symphony Society's $500,000 guarantee fund were reported at a meeting yesterday in the home of Mrs. Vincent Astor, where a group of sixty guests completed the organization of the women's division for carrying on the drive.

Guaranteed mortgage companies were permitted by the State Insurance Department to continue in business after its investigators had reported numerous violations of the law, it was disclosed yesterday by the Moreland Act investigation of the Insurance Department and the title companies.

The annual report of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company shows for 1933 a net income of $4,769,125 after taxes, charges and depreciation, equal to $3.96 a share on 1,203,952 common shares, comparing with $6,839,695, or $5.68 a share, earned in 1932. There was deficit of $2,454,587 after dividends of $6 a share, comparing with a deficit of $1,888,957 after dividends of $7.25 a share paid in 1932.

DUBLIN, Feb. 8. -- General Owen O'Duffy was re-elected president of the United Ireland party at its first convention in Mansion House here today. Blue-shirted men and blue-bloused women thronged the streets leading to Mansion House as delegates from all counties of the Free State assembled.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- "Merchants in control of the government under Presidents Coolidge and Hoover plundered the Treasury" to the detriment of national defense, Brig. Gen. William Mitchell, resigned, today told the House Military Affairs Committee, adding that the present states of the Army Air Corps is "pitiful."

Mayor LaGuardia and Controller W. Arthur Cunningham expect a sharp rise in the basic tax rate this year, to possibly as much as $2.70 per $100 of assessed valuation, it was learned yesterday. Last year's rate was $2.33 per $100.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The patient housewife turned on the canning industry today and, in vigorous terms, reminded assembled canners at a code hearing that, "while this is your industry, remember it is our money that supports it."

A fresh coat of gilt for General Sherman, a thorough overhauling for Admiral Farragut and a bright new countenance for the lady of the Pulitzer fountain are in prospect as a result of arrangements made yesterday with Mayor LaGuardia to have all statues, and monuments in the city cleaned and repaired.
Pennsylvania has embarked upon a widespread fish stocking program which, according to those who have studied it, is one of the most scientific ever attempted in this country.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 8. -- Displaying the same sailing qualities that won for the North Shrewsbury Ice Boat and Yacht Club the Class A championship pennant of North America in 1930 from the Long Branch Club, Pirate II, the Marconi-rigged flier owned by George Ruppert and George Gillig of New York City, flashed home a winner in two ten-mile races today.

After early irregularity, the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange rallied and closed generally higher on the day. Foreign loans averaged best in strength, with THE NEW YORK TIMES average of ten of such leading issues reaching the highest level since the compilation was started in 1922.

Three hundred butlers, personal maids, footmen and other servants from the household staffs of New York's prominent families danced last night in the formal atmosphere of the fourteenth annual ball of the Private Waiters Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- President Roosevelt sent a special message to Congress today urging the addition of sugar beets and sugar cane to basic commodities under the Agricultural Adjustment Act, and allocation of the American market for sugar, through quotas, to the various domestic, Cuban and insular sources.
