The School of Nursing of the Mount Sinai Hospital, a member of the United Hospital Fund, held its fifty-first annual commencement exercises last night in the Blumenthal Auditorium, Ninety-ninth Street, east of Fifth Avenue.

Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "Gold certificates on hand and due from U.S. Treasury," and "Redemption fund F.R. notes." Title to actual gold in possession of Federal Reserve was transferred to United States Government by law of Jan. 30, 1934.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The House of Representatives, wholly dominated by the Chief Executive, is getting more than its share of ridicule these days. But its plight is better than that of the Chamber of Deputies, to whose ten-year domination of the Executive in France an important cause of the Paris rioting can be traced.
The George Washington, Textile, Seward Park and Franklin K. Lane High quintets scored victories yesterday in P.S.A.L. basketball games.

The Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations, Inc., went on record yesterday as favoring a State-wide system of compulsory unemployment insurance reserves, and urged all related organizations to support the efforts of Governor Lehman to obtain prompt action to that end by the Legislature.

A general program of improvement for New York racing in 1934 was forecast yesterday by William Woodward, chairman of the Jockey Club, which held a meeting of stewards and members. The stewards adopted formally the amendment to the rules of racing, which is expected to cause large fields of horses to compete in the week-day handicaps.

The Rev. Dr. Charles Trexler, pastor of St. James Lutheran Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street, was re-elected yesterday for the third year as president of the Greater New York Federation of Churches at the annual meeting of the board of directors held in the Hotel Wolcott, 4 West Thirty-first Street.
" Broomsticks, Amen!" by Elmer Greensfelder, will have its premiere this evening at the Little Theatre.

Replying to Ogden L. Mills's charge in his recent Topeka speech that the NRA was an obstacle to recovery, Donald R. Richberg, general counsel of the NRA, asserted last night that this was not true if recovery was taken to mean reemployment and higher standards of living for the people at large.

SOME weeks ago Professor Irving Fisher of Yale was requested to name ten persons in the world who really understood the meaning of money. Professor Fisher went further than that. He listed eighteen men who understood the meaning of money. But Primo Carnera's name was not on the list. The professor was coruscatingly correct in leaving Primo's name off the list.

VIENNA, Feb. 8. -- Austria's appeal to the League of Nations against German interference in her internal affairs will be accompanied, it is learned, by a detailed and voluminous dossier enumerating Nazi outrages and presenting evidence that these were planned in Germany, that their execution was supervised from Germany and that the Nazi campaign here is armed and financed from Germany.

GENEVA, Feb. 8 (AP). -- The United States has informed Joseph Avenol, as secretary of the World Economic Conference, that it is impossible for the American Government at present to guarantee that gold or currency belonging to the Bank for International Settlements will be immune from all prohibitions and restrictions, it was learned today.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 8 (AP). -- A greater variety of plays and more of them, at no general increase in prices, is believed by Don Melrose, veteran Kansas City showman and playwright, to be in store for Middle Western and Southwestern patrons of the tent dramatic theatres next Summer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The Federal grand jury investigating charges of improper influence in the award of War Department contracts enlarged the scope of its inquiry today to include aviation contracts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Delegates from fifty-three active chapters of the American Veterans Association will gather here on Saturday for a three-day convention to may the future program of the association. This group is the only veterans' organization which has endorsed the entire Economy Act.
LONDON, Feb. 8. -- The return of "the popular and experienced Doumergue" is taken in the London press as an indication that he may shortly change the method of governing France.

DEL MONTE, Calif., Feb. 8 (AP). -- The steel industry has entered whole-heartedly into support of national recovery, W.A. Irvin, president of the United States Steel Corporation, said in an address at the annual steel industries conference here today.

Futures price movements on local commodity exchanges were again irregular in yesterday's dealings. Trading was maintained at a fairly high level, although there was some shrinkage on the decline. Cash prices were mostly higher.

As unconcernedly as if he were the proprietor, a hold-up man cleaned out the window of the Kobrin Brothers jewelry store, at 2,291 Broadway, between Eighty-second and Eighty-third Streets, of watches, pins and rings valued at about $20,000 shortly before 8 o'clock last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Senator Copeland, after a conference with President Roosevelt and Assistant Secretary Tugwell of the Agricultural Department, announced today that the President had approved the final draft of a pure food and drug bill.
ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- Imposition of a 2 per cent retail sales tax was recommended today in the report of the State Commission for the Revision of Tax Laws.

The appointment of thirty-two teachers to the instructional staff of New York University was announced yesterday by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase. The list includes twenty-one instructors, nine assistants, one lecturer and one faculty lecturer.

A ten-year lease on the seven-story building at 400 Fifth Avenue, near Thirty-seventh Street, has been taken by Worth's, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Riker Co., brokers in the deal. The building, a modern structure formerly occupied by Hixbee Co., is being extensively altered for occupancy by the lessee, a new company headed by Batnick Brothers, who operate the coat departments in the Emily Shops.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- With the apparent approval of President Roosevelt, administration leaders in the Senate moved tonight by a concession to avert a pro-veteran revolt in Congress which might in turn strain the good relations existing this session between the White House and the Capitol.

A recent publication of J. Pryse Goodwin's letter inspired several other communications to the editor of THE TIMES having for their subject the congestion that prevails at Grand Central and other important transfer stations on Inter-borough subway lines and offering suggestions for the improvement of such conditions.

Total assets of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company jumped $91,388,766, or from $3,769,372,425 to $3,860,761,191 last year, according to the annual report made public yesterday by Frederick H. Ecker, president, at the annual convention of the company's field managers.

President Roosevelt's proposal for allotments of domestic, insular and Cuban sugar was regarded in the sugar trade here as very favorable for Cuban sugars without working undue hardships on other producers. In general the belief is that if the plan can be placed in operation it should bring about a moderate increase in the price of sugar in this country.
A new cold wave that, in some sections, brought the lowest temperatures so far this Winter, held almost the entire region east of the Rocky Mountains in its grip yesterday.

The tenure of Harry Lanza, younger brother of Joseph (Socks) Lanza, as an assistant clerk in the Municipal Court of the Second District came to an abrupt end yesterday. He had reported for work two days before for the $4,000-a-year job.

By virtue of an unusual rally, Johnny Layton of Sedalia, Mo., ten times champion, overtook Otto Reiselt of Philadelphia last night in the world's three-cushion billiard championship play and won, 50 to 48.

A formal settlement of the taxi-cab strike was reached yesterday when representatives of the unionized drivers signed the peace terms under which nearly normal service had already been resumed in the city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding for the week ended Feb. 7, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,616,000,000, a decrease of $24,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $547,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1933.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The new tax bill was trimmed today to produce an estimated $235,000,000 in added revenue instead of the $300,000,000 expected from the measure in its original form.
CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 8. -- After one of the most tumultuous public hearings conducted on a budget here the City Commission adopted unanimously today the 1934 estimates.

Announcement by W. Kingsland Macy that he is a candidate for reelection as chairman of the Republican State Committee brought yesterday to leaders of the so-called Old Guard faction of the party realization of the necessity of picking a candidate for the nomination for Governor.

Despite the announcement early that Secretary of Agriculture Wallace favored legislation limiting ginnings from the coming crop to 9,000,000 bales, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved uncertainly yesterday for several hours. Trading diminished and quotations held near Wednesday's closing figures, May selling around 12 cents a pound just after midday.
The Triborough Bridge Authority by unanimous vote has selected Corporation Counsel Paul Windels to serve as its general counsel, Chairman Nathan Burkan announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 (AP). -- Two officers of the defunct Khaki Shirts of America -- the self-styled commander-in-chief and one of his captains -- were in custody today in connection with the slaying of a New York taxicab driver during a meeting of the "Shirts" in July on Long Island.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the proposed new partnership of Young, Clarke Co. of Los Angeles and New York, to be composed of John S. Young, Fred L. Clarke, Walter Dreyfus, Clarence C. Mullen, John L. Rowe, Gene B. Heywood, and special partners Ruth Young and Cecil Frankel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The American Waterworks and Electric Company, Inc., of New York, holding company for utilities in twenty States and Cuba, filed with the Federal Trade Commission today a registration statement under the Securities Act, proposing for issuance of collateral trust bonds of $15,000,000, and of no par value common shares totaling 2,500,000.

Wallach's, Inc., a subsidiary of Wallach Brothers, Inc., men's clothing and furnishings, has leased space in the Empire State Building for ten years, H. Hamilton Weber, rental manager of the structure, reported yesterday. The store space fronts 85 feet in Fifth Avenue and 65 feet in Thirty-third Street, with a basement 95 by 90 feet. The shop is to open about April 1.
Stripped of its saber championship a week ago, the New York Athletic Club came back to annex the national senior three-weapon team title last night at the Fencers Club.

The probability that a fund now totaling $338,395, collected by policemen after the World War for a memorial to the members of the Police Department who participated in the war, will be used for charity was disclosed in the Supreme Court yesterday. A.A. Berle Jr., City Chamberlain, applied for an order directing that the fund be turned over to him.
Here are some of the outstanding kidnapping cases in the past year, culminating with the release of Edward G. Bremer, banker, of St. Paul, Wednesday night:

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Feb. 8. -- The Alva II, sailed by her owner, George Seger of Lake Hopatcong, traversed the ten-mile Pleasure Bay course in record time this morning in winning the fourth race of the series conducted by the Long Branch Ice Boat and Yacht Club for Class B ice boats.
ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- Governor Lehman signed today two bills sought by Park Commissioner Moses to coordinate the State and city park systems.
TOKYO, Feb. 8. -- Baron Nakajima, the Minister of Commerce, resigned today and was succeeded by Joji Matsumoto, a non-party civil servant and member of the House of Peers.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8. -- The highest prices for hogs in carload lots in February in three years were established today with a top of $4.85 a hundredweight. This was 5 cents above yesterday's best level. The early general market was steady to 10 cents higher than yesterday, but close barely steady.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 8. -- R.E. Kelly's Heart Break was an easy winner in the featured Tampa Shores Handicap at Tampa Downs today as horse racing returned to the Florida West Coast after an absence of seven years. A crowd of 5,000 turned out.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- New York led all other States in liquor taxes during 1933 with a collection of $27,434,971, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today. Wisconsin was second with $16,498,761.

Yesterday's raising of its discount rate by the Bank of France, from 2 1/2 per cent to 3, fixed the highest rate since May, 1930. In view of the sudden and large withdrawal of gold this was orthodox action; but it can hardly be interpreted as a gesture of misgiving.

From two British sources on Wednesday, the United States got blamed once more for all the troubles in Europe. Mr. STANLEY BALDWIN declared that the refusal of this country to ratify the Versailles treaty and join the League of Nations brought about all the diplomatic and economic difficulties with which European statesmen have since been compelled to struggle.

From the founding of the Jewish Agricultural Society, Inc., in 1900 to the close of 1933 it granted through its farm-loan department 11,060 farm loans totaling $7,002,787.32 to Jewish farmers in forty States. This is announced in the society's annual report, made public yesterday by Gabriel Davidson, general manager of the society.
BUDAPEST, Feb. 8. -- For the first time since the end of the World War the Austrian anthem was played in the Budapest State Opera House tonight at a gala performance given for Chancellor Dollfuss.

Liberal orders on wash goods and blankets were placed by dry-goods wholesalers this week, but the total volume of business was reported to be slightly below that of last week. Jobbers reported a steadily strengthening market, with a scarcity of spot merchandise developing on many fabrics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- President Roosevelt's decision to seek stock and commodity exchange control legislation at this time was prompted by a desire to safeguard the present upward movement in commodity prices against too great a speculative influence in the market.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8. -- Samuel Insull's abdication from his utilities rule of thirty-five years and his farewell to the scene of his former triumphs were sketched in a few hundred words of testimony today at the Insull "town meeting" in progress before Judge Walter C. Lindley.

The child labor amendment now before the States for ratification received direct support from President Roosevelt in a letter in which he declared that in his opinion the matter "hardly requires further academic discussion."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 8. -- A Yale football eleven well drilled in fundamentals and ready for Columbia and Pennsylvania, its first foes, is visualized for 1934 by Malcolm Farmer, director of athletics, in an article in the Yale alumni weekly.

The Association of Stock Exchange Firms notified its members yesterday that the Bureau of Internal Revenue had ruled that the special reports that it is requiring from all brokers on transactions of customers whose purchases or sales of stocks or commodities amount to more than $25,000, must show the actual totals of the transactions, rather than the debit and credit items on the brokers' books.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- President Roosevelt will send to Congress tomorrow a message recommending early enactment of legislation for the Federal control and regulation of stock exchanges.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- A petition signed by sixty-five Mayors of cities in the Great Lakes littoral was presented to Vice President Garner today, endorsing the St. Lawrence seaway treaty and urging its ratification by the Senate.

WHILE the Mariolaters are thrilling on Broadway or in their library chairs to the undoubted beauty of Maxwell Anderson's play, "Mary of Scotland" (Doubleday, Doran, $2), and getting their Tudor and Stuart Queens all tangled up with a romantic legend that is not one-tenth as absorbing as the actual historic story, J.E. Neale comes along with a first-rate biography of "Queen Elizabeth" (Harcourt, Brace, $3.75), which sets things to rights.
LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

The victim of a labor row shooting and the principal witness against two fellow-members of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers pleaded with Judge Corrigan in General Sessions yesterday for clemency for his assailants.

One of the last season's most captivating events was the large Boldini show at the Wildenstein Galleries, organized by Maud Dale. Now one of these days some enterprising impresario ought, really, to get up a show called "Boldini and His Followers."
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 8. -- With the thermometer rapidly approaching 30 below zero and plenty of snow on the ground, the largest number of competitors in the twenty-four years of the Dartmouth Winter Carnival was on hand tonight ready for the opening events tomorrow.

After having gone aground on Roamer Shoals off Ambrose Channel, the 330-ton auxiliary schooner Uvira was reported returning to rooklny early this morning a few hours after she had sailed with a party of amateur explorers for a six-month cruise in Central American waters.

HAMMOND, La., Feb. 8. -- By as fine a piece of piloting as had been seen in many a day, Bernard L. Whelan, chief test pilot for the Pratt Whitney Company of East Hartford, brought a six-and-one-half ton Boeing transport, en route from New York to New Orleans, into the Department of Commerce emergency landing field here this evening, after he had been caught in a sudden Gulf storm.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Fear that the NRA administrative machinery may operate to assure complete employer and industry control, so that the aims of the Recovery Act, to spread employment and increase purchasing power, may be defeated, is expressed today by the American Federation of Labor's monthly survey of business.
Hiroshi Saito, newly appointed Japanese Ambassador to the United States, will arrive today from Europe on the Cunarder Berengaria. He was recently Ambassador to Holland. Also on board are:
Conveyance of a North Bergen silk mill featured the New Jersey realty activity reported yesterday:

Mayor LaGuardia spent two hours in Long Island City yesterday morning inspecting the quarters of the Queens County Court and addressing the Queens County Grand Jury on court conditions. When interviewed after the inspection, the Mayor said something must be done to get new court quarters, but he warned the Queens public "not to make a real estate squabble" of any court house or civic centre projects.

Charges by the heirs that an estate, said to have been valued four years ago at $11,000,000, has, through mismanagement, shrunk to a quarter of that sum are being heard by former Federal Judge Thomas D. Thacher as referee in a suit by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, as trustee of the estate of Mary A. Ott, for the approval of the accounts.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 8. -- Scarred, exhausted and unkempt, Edward G. Bremer, 37-year-old bank president, returned home today from twenty-two days and twelve hours of captivity after $200,000 ransom money had been paid to the criminals who kidnapped him on the morning of Jan. 17.

PARIS, Feb. 8. -- With the wise words, "After all, politics is only a matter of common sense," former President Gaston Doumergue came back to Paris today to try to drag France out of the mess into which, it is generally conceded, too much politics and too little common sense have landed her.

King Levinsky will take the firs step in his campaign for recognition as one of the outstanding challengers for the world's heavyweight championship when he opposes Charley Massera of Pittsburgh in the feature bout of ten rounds in Madison Square Garden tonight.

VIENNA, Feb. 8. -- The use of Heimwehr auxiliary police in the raid on the Socialist newspaper Arbeiter Zeitung early this morning, although plenty of ordinary police were available, was taken as a deliberate provocation by knots of sullen workmen who gathered but were quickly dispersed.
Luigi Criscuolo of Merrill, Lynch Co. has resigned as a director of the McCrory Stores Corporation. Arnold L. Davis of Davis, Wagener Heater has been placed on the board.

The expected increase in the tax rate was protested last night at a meeting of the Council of Real Estate Associations at the Hotel Commodore. The council is made up of representatives of real estate and property owners' organizations in all boroughs of the city.

A rise of 1.0 for the Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices in the week to 105.8 on Tuesday, reflected primarily, higher prices for cotton, hogs, sugar, butter and gasoline. The index compared with 104.8 on the Tuesday previous, and is now the highest since Oct. 3.

Appearing for the first time since Howard G. Cann resigned as football coach at New York University, The Washington Square College Bulletin yesterday declared in its leading editorial that N.Y.U. either should return to big-time football or abolish the sport from an intercollegiate standpoint.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- President Roosevelt sent to Congress a message asking that sugar beets and cane be made basic commodities under the AAA; agreed to a compromise on veterans' compensation; prepared to send a message to Congress tomorrow asking Stock Exchange control legislation, and entertained at a formal reception tonight.

Strict Federal regulation of the security markets with a view to curbing speculation in this country is urged by the Twentieth Century Fund, endowed by Edward A. Filene, in specific recommendations which were forwarded to President Roosevelt by Mr. Filene yesterday.
" Tannhauser" opens the matinee Wagner cycle at the Metropolitan at 1:45 P.M. today with a cast including Rethberg, Branzell, Lorenz, Schorr and List.
A dozen properties in Manhattan and the Bronx were bought in at foreclosure auctions yesterday. All the parcels went to the plaintiffs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP). -- In a formal complaint the Federal Trade Commission charged today that the Crown Zellerbach Corporation of San Francisco, a large holding concern of the paper products industry, had violated the Clayton Anti-Trust Act.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Selection of first-class postmasters on merit as necessary to the building up of the postoffice system on a business basis was advocated today by Postmaster General Farley. The administration is represented as considering a request for legislation to put the first-class postmasters under civil service, or authority to make promotions based upon examinations held by the Postoffice Department.

Mr. and Mrs. William James Filbert gave a supper dance in the Seaglade of the St. Regis for their daughter, Miss Estaire Filbert, and Frederiek Sidley Cummings, who will be married tomorrow in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.
PARIS, Feb. 8. -- Paris watched and waited a little nervously while the debris of two days of rioting was cleared away today.

All quotations for money were unchanged. Business was light, chiefly replacements of expiring obligations. Stock Exchange callloan rate was 1 per cent, while a fractional concession from this prevailed in counter market.

Dealings in stock of the Insuranshares Corporation of Delaware on the New York Stock Exchange were suspended at a special meeting of the governing committee of the Exchange yesterday. No explanation of the action was given.

Federal funds to aid in relieving the overcrowded conditions which exist in the city hospitals will be available if a bill to be introduced in Congress is passed, Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Hospital Commissioner, said yesterday.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 8. -- Two of America's foremost women golfers will meet in the thirty-six-hole final for the annual Miami Biltmore championship as the result of close victories in the semifinal round at the Miami Biltmore Country Club today.

Although neither team was at full strength, the New York Americans and the Toronto Maple Leafs staged a bristling battle at Madison Square Garden last night. There was plenty of scoring, but it was equally divided, and the teams had to be content with a 3-to-3 overtime tie.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Sale of bonds acquired from municipalities and States as collateral for PWA loans is being considered by the Public Works Administration.

The annual St. Valentine Kettledrum, always a feature of society at this season of the year, and which aids the Samaritan Home for the Aged, will be an event this afternoon in the ballroom suite of the Plaza. Various attractions have been arranged for the special amusement of children, and at tea hour there will be a program under the direction of Gene Lockhart.
The community should give a greater impetus to the development of the arts, especially the musical arts, so that the largest number of people shall be able to enjoy them.

A ruling by the Public Service Commission on the city's request for a temporary reduction in the gas rates of the Bronx Gas and Electric Company will be made by next Tuesday or Wednesday, according to Commissioner George R. Van Namee, who presided yesterday afternoon at a hearing into the joint facilities agreement of that company, the Consolidated Gas Company and its other affiliates.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- A governmental audit showing that private contractors had made profits as high as 90 per cent on army airplane orders was submitted to members of Congress today for their study.

LONDON, Feb. 8. -- The stock markets were quiet and irregular today. A feature was activity in Brazilian bonds following announcement of the terms of the debt agreement. Gold mines recovered, responding to a rise in the price of gold to 136s 9d an ounce. About 1,590,000 of the metal was sold to the United States.
Gifts to Columbia University aggregating $21,684.16 were announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

Representatives of the State and municipal governments and the Port of New York Authority will urge the Federal Government to appropriate funds to finance an immediate improvement of the State Barge Canal at a hearing in Washington today before the House Committee on Rivers and Harbors.

The special attention given Beethoven last season and this one has a significance that is not to be underestimated. Mr. Toscanini's Beethoven series; the London String Quartet's series of concerts devoted to Beethoven's works for the four stringed instruments, and the second of the programs of Beethoven violin and piano sonatas, given last night in the Town Hall by Albert Spalding and Ossip Gabrilowitsch, are extraordinary testimony to the power of the Bonn master's music.

Boards of censorship, the "resolution-passing type of so-called civic motion," and the judging of motion pictures by "transient moral standards or by standards personal to the censor" were decried yesterday by speakers at the twenty-fifth anniversary conference of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Hans Lange, returning for this week to conduct the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, presented the following program at Carnegie Hall last night: Haydn's Symphony in A (B. 64), Schumann's Piano Concerto, with Guiomar Novaes as soloist; the adagio from Bruckner's String Quintet in F. arranged for string orchestra; Walter Piston's Suite for Orchestra and Robert L. Sanders's "Barn Dance," both in their first New York performances. There was a good audience.

The first public utility financing since the Securities Act of 1933 became a law last June was announced yesterday by the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc. The corporation stated that it had filed yesterday with the Federal Trade Commission a registration statement and prospectus covering a proposed issue of $15,000,000 of ten-year 5 per cent convertible collateral trust bonds to be dated March 1, 1934.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Persistently beating down efforts to increase appropriations for civil works and other relief agencies far beyond administration wishes, Roosevelt leaders finally forced approval in the Senate tonight of a bill carrying $950,000,000, the amount they asked.

Brokers contended yesterday that the share market "took" the realizing, short selling and liquidation with a minimum amount of dislocation. But the decline, at least in the first few hours, was not a minor incident by any means. It threatened for a period to get out of hand.
ATLANTA, Feb. 8. -- The architects of football, men who design the code governing the college game, assemble tomorrow to decide whether the rules shall be altered for next Fall's campaign.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Wholesale commodity prices last week were .6 per cent higher than the previous week because of a further strengthening of market prices of farm products and foods, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- President Roosevelt's sugar message to Congress was interpreted in State Department circles as recommending the greatest cooperation in the economic rehabilitation of Cuba that the United States could possibly offer at present.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8. -- Prices of wheat declined about a cent a bushel early today on the Board of Trade. Weakness in stocks and cotton, and reports of good rains, which had been needed, in parts of Texas and Oklahoma, started scattered liquidation, which quickly ran its course.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 8. -- The fabulous rumors of an all-Negro cast singing in tan-face and costumed in cellophane; of a libretto whose words were unintelligible and an opera whose stage directions were set to music -- all this crammed the new Avery Memorial Theatre with a highly sophisticated and curious audience tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- A thornier road for lobbyists before government departments is being charted by administration officials.

The franc continued to advance yesterday under the combined influence of official support, returning confidence in the French political situation and buying of francs to finance gold exports. Relatively little support was needed for the exchange yesterday, according to bankers.

Comprehensive regulation of bus and truck traffic was advocated yesterday by the Transportation Conference, composed of railroad, banking and industrial representatives, meeting at the Commodore. The recommendations will be forwarded to Representative Rayburn, chairman of the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce.

District Attorney Dodge, for the first time since taking office on Jan. 1, appeared as a court prosecutor yesterday. He aided in the selection of a jury in Judge Freschi's part of General Sessions to try Felix Solomon, a fellow Tammany member from the Harlem section.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- New capital security issues totaling $3,165,150 and refunding issues totaling $36,458,000 are proposed in registration statements filed with the Federal Trade Commission under the Securities Act and made public today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt' message on the sugar situation:

PARIS, Feb. 8. -- The Bank of France raised its rediscount rate from 2 1/2 per cent to 3 today. It was the first rise since Oct. 30, 1931, and though it had been expected nearly every week during the last three months, financial circles were caught somewhat by surprise because it was thought these turbulent days would not offer a convenient opportunity for such an important change.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 8. -- Six Irvington officials were among twenty-six men named in ten indictments returned by the Essex County grand jury today, concluding its investigation of gambling in the county. Those indicted in addition to the officials are reputedly members of a Newark gang alleged to have conducted a "slot machine racket" in Irvington.

Appeals have been taken by the city in three condemnation cases in which awards granted by the courts are more than $1,000,000 in excess of the value placed on the property by city experts, Corporation Counsel Paul Windels announced yesterday.

George B. Cortelyou, president of the Consolidated Gas Company, declared last night that although the utility companies were cooperating fully with the national recovery program, they have been singled out for oppressive and discriminatory taxation and grossly unfair treatment.

BOSTON, Feb. 8. -- An operation never before attempted on an America's Cup yacht is to be performed on the Yankee, pride of Boston four years ago. The record-holding racer with the full-bronzed hull definitely will make another bid for international defense honors, a syndicate having been organized to finance her second appearance.

Henry B. Culver was elected curator of the Marine Museum of the City of New York yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of trustees at Fifth Avenue and 103d Street. Mr. Culver recently returned from Paris, where he was engaged in restoring several old ship models for the Louvre.

PARIS, Feb. 8. -- Mainbocher presents a dazzling variety of silhouettes and details at his showing of the new styles. A group of evening gowns, made of plain or figured organdie, faille and crepe, illustrates that these fabrics can be adapted to every type of woman.

Thirty-five Senators are to be elected in November. The seats to be filled are evenly divided between Democrats and Republicans. The odd man, Farmer-Laborite, is sure to succeed himself. The seventeen Democratic seats are all safely Democratic. There seems not even the slightest hope that Mr. FESS of Ohio and Mr. ROBINSON of Indiana will be able to continue their solemn services.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The question whether air mail contracts will be canceled as a result of testimony before the Senate committee investigating ocean and air mail contracts lies with Attorney General Cummings for final decision.

A tentative plan for the reorganization of the Bronx Terminal Market was outlined yesterday by William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Public Markets, in an address before members of the New York State Women's Committee for Law Enforcement at 135 East Fifty-second Street.

Young matrons and debutantes, wearing authentic Russian headdresses, will sell flowers and souvenir programs at the annual Russian Students Ball in behalf of unemployed students of the Russian Alumni and Students Association, which will be held tonight in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton.

A petition signed by 150 members of the Lambs Club, assuring Representative Samuel Dickstein of New York, chairman of the House Immigration Committee, of their support in his efforts to revive his bill limiting the entry of alien actors, was acted upon at a special meeting yesterday of the Council of Actors Equity Association.

Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, in his first speech in New York since becoming a member of the Roosevelt Cabinet, told an audience of more than 400 men and women at the annual dinner of Survey Associates last night that "a bloodless revolution has occurred, turning out from the seats of power the representatives of wealth and privilege."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 8. -- Westchester County was described as without leadership this afternoon in the first public statement on the county's government by a member of the newly appointed Westchester commission on reform of county government.

Sales of General Motors cars and trucks to consumers in the United States during January totaled 23,438, comparing with 11,951 in December and 50,653 in January, 1933. The decrease from last year does not reflect the current extent of consumer demand, a statement by the company says.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP). -- Alfred P. Leyburn, chief national bank examiner, told the Senate Banking Committee today that the First National Bank of Detroit was insolvent to the extent of $4,000,000 when the Michigan banking holiday was declared.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- The four Democratic legislators from Albany County, dominated by Daniel P. and Edward J. O'Connell, went on record today as opposed to the LaGuardia Economy Bill in its present form.

The Correction Department's investigation of the Welfare Island Penitentiary which has been carried on intensively since the prison was raided two weeks ago has disclosed a shortage of 2 4-5 ounces of morphine, or nearly enough to provide narcotic addicts with 3,000 "shots," it was learned yesterday.

It is pleasant to see from the proposed income-tax rates for next year that the Ways and Means Committee is determined to make wealth bear its proper share of the nation's fiscal burdens. Thus persons with a net income of $1,000,000, who get away with a mere tax of $571,100 under the present rates, will be called upon next year to pay $571,158.
Forty-five minutes after he entered the Yale Club court yesterday, Milton Baron, Fraternity club star, walked out as the winner of the Clyde Martin memorial tournament for 1934.

Stocks met further selling pressure yesterday and prices were sharply reduced for a time. There was, however, a lively recovery between 1:30 and 3 o'clock and the market closed with a demonstration of strength. The best-rated investment bonds were in demand at higher prices; breadstuffs and cotton rallied sharply while the dollar again lost ground in foreign exchange.

VIENNA, Feb. 8. -- What an official communique described as "an unprecedented criminal plot of Bolshevist and Marxist elements" was uncovered in a series of police raids on Socialist centres culminating in the occupation of the Socialist newspaper Arbeiter Zeitung today.

LONDON, Feb. 8. -- But for the depression the much discussed Codex Sinaiticus, fourth century biblical manuscript, probably would have been sold in the United States for more than the 100,000 Britain is paying, declared Dean Inge today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 8. -- The legal battle of Davenport Neck began today before Supreme Court Justice Raymond E. Aldrich in White Plains without a jury. It was the trial of an injunction suit brought by three residents of the Neck against Charles D. Beckwith, New York contractor and owner of a large estate in the district.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 8. -- The largest gathering of young women Hanover has ever seen will enliven the twenty-fourth annual Winter Carnival, opening tomorrow, and the task of selecting the queen from a thousand fair visitors will tax the judgment of Dartmouth's three deans.

MADRID, Feb. 8. -- General Manuel Gonzalez and six other defendants accused of participation with General Sanjurjo in the Seville rebellion of Aug. 10, 1932, were sentenced today to twelve years' imprisonment each by the military division of the Supreme Court.

Dr. Frank H. Russell, house physician for the Hotel Astor, was held for the grand jury yesterday by Magistrate H. Stanley Renaud in Yorkville Court on a charge of grand larceny brought by Mrs. Carolyn Pulitzer of 121 East Thirty-first Street.

The improvement in bank clearings over a year ago was again marked last week, according to the weekly compilation by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. For twenty-one leading cities clearings amounted to $5,268,536,000, against $4,723,637,000 in the same week last year, an improvement of 12.3 per cent.

HAVANA, Feb. 8. -- The hope that Cuba will be able to grind this year's sugar crop was stimulated today by dispatches from Washington to the local press stating that President Roosevelt had recommended to Congress that an import quota of 1,944,000 short tons be granted to Cuba.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 8. -- Golden Fate moved into fast company at Hialeah Park today and took the measure of some of the best sprinters at the track in the featured six-furlong Idle Hour Handicap.

Bill Graber of Southern California, holder of the world's outdoor pole-vault record of 14 feet 4 3/8 inches, arrived in New York yesterday by airplane and immediately flew on to Boston, where he will compete in the Boston A.A. meet tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (AP). -- The Detroit Red Wings and Chicago's Black Hawks failed to settle anything in their battle tonight for second place in the National Hockey League's American group, going overtime to a 1-to-1 tie.

Controller CUNNINGHAM'S latest tables are for the expert rather than the layman. They lack the plain analysis which Governor SMITH and his successors have been accustomed to include in their financial statements, so as to make them as intelligible as possible to the man who wants to digest his statistics on the run.

COLON, Panama, Feb. 8. -- General Rafael Simon Urbina, one of the chief leaders of the Opposition to the regime of President Juan Vicente Gomez of Venezuela, arrived here today from San Jose, Costa Rica. He refused to make a statement to the press regarding the object of his visit, which he says will be short, or on his future plans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The status of company unions, which now include about 1,500,000 employes in major industries, is jeopardized at least temporarily by a decision of the Petroleum Labor Policy Board, made public today by Secretary Ickes as oil administrator.

Babe Ruth, a day older than 40, shook himself loose from the icy blasts of New York yesterday and entrained for St. Petersburg, Fla., for a month of light conditioning work during which he hopes to recover the strength he lost during a fortnight's siege of influenza.

It seems strange that in discussing the question of the 5-cent taxicab tax these who are giving their opinions did not read the ordinance passed by the Board of Aldermen covering the subject. The ordinance clearly separates two subjects.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- An attack on the administration's emergency measures was published today by the Republican National Committee in the form of a pamphlet entitled "C.W.A. Scandals." The subtitle was "What Could You Expect."

The need for greater cooperation between private and public welfare agencies, particularly in the care of children and young men and women, was emphasized last night by several speakers at the annual dinner of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies in the Hotel Pierre.

A syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers won yesterday the award of a new issue of $3,000,000 city of Rochester (N.Y.) bonds, consisting of $2,000,000 public welfare, due on Feb. 1 from 1933 to 1935, and $1,000,000 of tax revenue bonds, due on Feb. 1 from 1936 to 1939.

At the University of Michigan about $15,000 is distributed each year to young writers, and Mildred Walker, whose novel, "Fireweed," is to be published this month by Harcourt, Brace, seems to have made a fair start toward cornering the awards.

MONTREAL, Feb. 8 -- (AP). -- Cy Wentworth broke up a fast and furious battle between Montreal's two National Hockey League teams, the Maroons and Canadiens, tonight. He scored on a pass from Earl Robinson after six minutes of overtime, to give the Maroons a 3-2 victory and undisputed possession of second place in the league's international division.
LONDON, Feb. 8. -- The three surviving Americans went down to defeat in the fourth round of the women's British squash racquets championship at the Queens Club today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 8. -- A bill was presented in Congress today for modification of a law passed in 1926 reserving the right of searching for and exploiting petroleum to the State. The new measure would permit foreign firms to participate on the understanding that concessions would be limited to a maximum area of 120,000 hectares.
LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP). -- The dominance of English women squash racquets players over their sisters from the United States today asserted itself again in the 1934 British title tournament.

HAVANA, Feb. 8. -- Havana omnibus and dock workers returned to their jobs this morning and it is expected the strike of employes of the Cuba Northern Railways, who have been out for several days, will be settled shortly. Newspapers have resumed publication and the workers in many small industries have returned.
SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Feb. 8. -- Verne Sankey, kidnapper, hanged himself in his cell in the State penitentiary tonight.

PARIS, Feb. 8. -- "I don't want anybody to say there has been a revolution in France," Gaston Doumergue, Premier-designate, told a reporter of Le Matin on his train en route to Paris this morning. "I want them simply to say 'France continues.'"

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 8. -- Drawing out easily after shaking off A.G. Tarn's Pulis at the half-mile mark, J. Burkes's Flying Cadet scored by two lengths over Mrs. James Chesney's Our Justice in the mile and a sixteenth of the featured Momus Purse at the Fair Grounds today.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 8. -- In its best performance of the year so far the Princeton hockey team overwhelmed the Middlebury sextet in Baker Rink tonight, 8 -- 2.

Service at the Forty-second Street Public Library does not meet with the approval of Charlotte Landau, according to her communication to THE TIMES. For fear it might be thought that her experience is general, I herewith report my own research adventures.

WHITEHOUSE, N.J., Feb. 8. -- The bodies of George Stillwell, 59 years old, and of his wife, Mrs. Helen DuBois Stillwell, 53, were found hanging side by side this afternoon from a rafter in the garage behind their home on the Flemington Road, three miles east of here.

ST. PAUL, Feb. 8. -- The $200,000 ransom for Edward G. Bremer, $85,000 in $5 bills and the rest in $10 bills, was delivered by Walter Magee, a friend of the Bremer family, on Tuesday night after a hitch in previous plans for payment had thwarted arrangements.

A former city employe and five contractors were sentenced to jail and fined yesterday for defrauding the city on school repair contracts. Judge Harry Stackell in Bronx County Court sentenced the men. He also gave a suspended sentence to a contractor who had turned State's evidence.

MADRID, Feb. 8. -- In a telephone conversation this afternoon with Clinton B. Lockwood, who with his wife and two other Americans were released yesterday from the military prison at Palma, Majorca, Ambassador Claude G. Bowers advised all four to leave the island as soon as they can.

The Commercial Solvents Corporation reported yesterday for 1933 a net profit of $2,327,846 after taxes and other charges. This was equal to 88 cents a share on 2,635,811 shares. For 1932 the corporation reported a net profit of $1,282,343, or 50 cents a share on 2,530,255 shares.

The first of the series of borough conferences between Police Commissioner O'Ryan and representatives of civic, welfare, religious and municipal groups was held in Queens yesterday afternoon at the Queens Borough Chamber of Commerce offices, Long Island City.

A certain group of children won the enviable right yesterday in Bronx Children's Court to attend public school only four days a week, praise be to Allah. The decision, regarded as a precedent, was made by Justice Charles Brandt Jr. in the case of Mrs. Sarah Smith-Bey of 244 East 136th Street, the Bronx, who was accused of keeping her four children from school every Friday since Christmas.

The conception which S.E. Harris says he originally held regarding the Committee for the Nation's work was correct. Its primary interest is to correct the deficiencies of the gold standard and make it workable. At no time has it advocated a currency unbacked by metallic reserves.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 9. -- Two youngsters in the game of golf, Byron Nelson, Texarkana Country Club professional, and Ky Laffoon of Denver, riddled the par of the Brackenridge Park course today to tie for leadership in the first eighteen holes of the $2,500 Texas open.

The twelve-story hotel at 3-7 East Twenty-seventh Street, near Fifth Avenue, was bought in by the trustees of Columbia University at an auction sale yesterday. The property was put up as the result of an action brought by the trustees against the Rolland Realty Company involving $246,498, plus taxes, , amounting to $13,220.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- New regulations for the Civil Works and the Federal Emergency Relief Administrations will be announced soon as the result of Senate amendments to the $950,000,000 relief appropriation bill passed yesterday, if the amendments remain in the measure, Harry L. Hopkins, administrator of both agencies, said today.

Paintings, water-colors and drawings by modern artists brought $16,723 last night at the Rains Auction Rooms, Inc. In the art world there was considerable interest in the dispersal, since it was one of the few such auctions in recent years and there had been speculation as to the market value of the work of many of the artists represented in the sale.

HELSINGFORS, Feb. 9. -- For the first time in its musical history, an American conducted an orchestra in Finland tonight when Werner Janssen led the Helsingfors Municipal Orchestra in a program devoted to the music of Jan Sibelius and consisting of the Fourth and Fifth symphonies, and the tone-poem, "Pojhola's Daughter."

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Feb. 9. -- Gordon Alcorn, pal of Verne Sankey, kidnapper who hanged himself in his prison cell here yesterday, pleaded guilty to the kidnapping of Charles Boettcher 2d of Denver, today, and was sentenced to life imprisonment in Leavenworth Penitentiary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- To avoid possible scandal or favoritism in NRA administration, General Johnson issued an order today excluding former executives or employes from appearing before the administration in the interest of any industry or trade with which their former official duties may have brought them into contact.
Small housing properties made up the bulk of the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.

Colonel Matt J. Winn, who made the Kentucky Derby a race of international importance, yesterday added his voice to the many others which have been raised on behalf of New York racing and the Jockey Club, which is at present engaged in a fight for open betting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Profits made by the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation of Buffalo on army contracts during 1927 were so large that Major Gen. Mason M. Patrick, then Chief of the Army Air Corps, forced the company to build fifty additional airplanes at a cost of $1 each to the government, Brig. Gen. H. Conger Pratt, Assistant Chief of the Air Corps, testified today before the House Military Affairs Committee.

An investigation by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, of the values and prices put on land and equipment by the Brooklyn Ash Removal Company was ordered yesterday by unanimous vote of the Board of Estimate after a discussion in which it was charged the company was trying to "hijack" the city for $1,000,000.

MADRID, Feb. 9. -- Following the murder of a student selling a Fascist newspaper, the government today banned radio broadcasting of political speeches until further notice. The order applies to an address former Premier Manuel Aza+/-a was scheduled to make next Sunday.

No roamer of the Hudson Highlands had more to do with bringing about the reservation of their hills and forests for playgrounds of the people than the late WILLIAM THOMPSON HOWELL of Newburgh. He was a nature-lover and not a politician. Day and night, in Winter as well as Summer, he was afoot in the wilderness.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Following is the text of Senator Fletcher's bill for the regulation of Stock Exchanges presented in the Senate and House today:

The Bank of the Manhattan Company received virtually all of the $4,000,000 in dividends declared by the New York Title and Mortgage Company in 1931 when it was invoking the eighteen-month grace clause and delaying payment to mortgage and certificate holders of principal and interest due, it was testified yesterday by John E. Diefendorf, chief examiner of the Insurance Department.

The Lindsey Morris memorial prize for bas-relief has been awarded to Carl L. Schmitz, honorable mention to Sylvia G. Dreyfus, in an exhibition that will remain current at the Architectural League Building, 115 East Fortieth Street, until Feb. 28.

An immediate audit of the books of community stores operated for the convenience of inmates in six city hospitals was ordered yesterday by Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Hospital Commissioner, to determine whether there has been graft or profiteering connected with the store operation.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 9. -- A demand that all books and records of the Dairymen's League and its affiliates be thrown open for an examination by Secretary Wallace was made today by Elmer D. Hayes, representing the Agricultural Adjustment Administration at a meeting here of 3,500 New York milkshed dairymen to thresh out provisions of the proposed milk code.

When the Cunarder Berengaria docked at West Fourteenth Street yesterday, officials of the company came on board to congratulate Sir Edgar T. Britten, master, who was included in King George's list of royal honors for the year.

Promises of the broad upturn in retail sales which developed at the start of the month have been fulfilled, with reports of a lagging tendency in demand emanating principally from those districts where CWA activities have been retarded by freezing temperatures, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- President Roosevelt took the troublesome air mail situation into his own hands today, ordered annulment of all existing domestic air-mail contracts and directed the army to fly the mail during the emergency created by his act.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 9. -- The Wildwood Purse at a mile featured the program at Hialeah Park today, Colonel E.R. Bradley's Florida Derby hope, Boy Valet, scoring by four lengths over A.A. Baroni's Bittybit.

PARIS, Feb. 9. -- While two ships sailed bearing large amounts of gold, the dollar today slowly pursued its course toward 59.06 cents parity, closing at :15.50 francs as against 15.57. The French point to the continuation of arbitrage transactions and yesterday's rise in the Bank of France's rediscount rate as further proof that they intend to continue faithfully observing the rules of the gold standard.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- President Roosevelt in a special message today asked for legislation to regulate stock exchanges and immediately the long-awaited bill was introduced in Senate and House. It proved to be one of the most drastic regulatory measures ever submitted to Congress.

MOSCOW, Feb. 9. -- An impressive parade of the Red Army was held in Red Square during a snowstorm to show the 2,000 delegates to the All-Union Communist Party Congress that the "Red Army is mechanized up to or above western levels," in the words of War Commissar Voroshiloff.

Clifford S. Sutter of New Orleans, fourth ranking tennis player of the country, led the field into the quarter-final round of the Heights Casino invitation tournament last night as play in the Brooklyn indoor fixture started with Gregory Mangin of Newark in the role of defending cup holder.

Upon the fulfillment of certain legal technicalities pertaining to the constitution of the Actors Betterment Association a charter will be issued to it to represent officially all vaudeville, presentation house, night club and circus entertainers except chorus members, it was decided yesterday at a hearing before the international board of the Associated Actors and Artists of America.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 9. -- Repre sentatives of the aviation industry gathered here for the Pan-American air races were stunned by resident Roosevelt's cancellation of air mail contracts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- An indication that the administration is considering a recommendation that industry voluntarily adopt the thirty-two-hour week in order further to spread employment was given today by General Johnson.
The Embassy Newsreel Theatre will be reopened as the Embassy Pathe News Theatre at 11 o'clock this morning. Mayor LaGuardia is expected to attend.

In scenes reminiscent of the former imperial Russian regime, the annual Russian students' ball took place last night in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton. A handsome decorative scheme and the appearance of many young women in authentic ancient Boyar costume and jeweled headdresses made the ball one of the most picturesque of the season.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Following is the text of the communication to the Senate today by William P. MacCracken Jr.:

PARIS, Feb. 9. -- Former President Gaston Doumergue has formed the government of national union and national safety that the country demanded, and tonight on public billboards throughout France the following declaration signed by him is being posted:...

The Chrysler Corporation reports for 1933 a consolidated net income of $12,129,119 after depreciation, taxes and other charges. This is equal to $2.78 a share on the 4,361,427 shares of capital stock of $5 par value outstanding. For 1932, the company reported a net loss of $11,254,232 after similar charges and reserves.

The Board of Estimate ordered Corporation Counsel Paul Windels yesterday to seek a court ruling to relieve the city of legal obligation to pay any part of the salaries or administrative expenses of the Transit Commission. This action was taken after the board had again refused to appropriate $76,000 to pay the city's share of the commission's salaries and expenses for February.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Following is the text of the message sent by President Roosevelt to Congress today on Stock Exchange control legislation:

Trust funds in custody of the City Chamberlain were consistently invested in securities of the State Title and Mortgage Company for more than four years, according to a report by Professor A.A. Berle Jr., the present City Chamberlain. Professor Berle has submitted his report to Mayor LaGuardia, who ordered a copy sent to George W. Alger, Moreland Act Commissioner, who is investigating the State Insurance Department.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 9. -- Under weather conditions that would have been ideal for an arctic expedition, Dartmouth's Twenty-fourth Annual Winter Carnival got under way today day with the University of New Hampshire scoring 24 points to take the lead for the championship of the Intercollegiate Winter Sports Union.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- Prices of light weight hogs dropped 5 to 15 cents a hundred pounds today, while other kinds were strong, with some sales of heavy kinds regarded as 10 cents higher than yesterday. Offerings of light weights were in excess of the demand today, although some of the larger packers showed interest in the market today for the first time since the rise got under way.

PARIS, Feb. 9. -- Premier Doumergue has grouped around him in the new government which he has given France representatives of every party, from Louis Marin, on the extreme Right, to Adrien Marquet, leader of the New Socialists, who some months ago broke away from the orthodox Socialists under Leon Blum.

The annual Wagner matinee cycle, which began yesterday with "Tannhauser," is among the Metropolitan's most treasurable fixures. At a time when orchestras and opera companies struggle for existence, these performances become a significant test of our fundamental artistic tastes.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 9 (AP). -- Judge Walter M. Pickett of the Court of Common Pleas ruled today that a New York banking law, under which the Bank Commissioner of that State seeks to collect assessments from ninety-seven New Haven county residents who were stockholders in the closed Bank of United States, was not enforceable in Connecticut.

Futures prices again moved irregularly yesterday and without the development of any general trend in dealings on local commodity exchanges. In most instances there was some increase in the volume of trading. Cash prices were mixed, with the trend higher.

Charles (Chuck) Hornbostel of Indiana University was named yesterday as the outstanding athlete of the twenty-seventh annual Millrose A.A. indoor games at the Garden last Saturday, and his name will be inscribed on the huge Rodman Wanamaker International Trophy.

PITTBURGH, Feb. 9 (AP). -- The Weirton Steel Company today denied the National Labor Board's request for a payroll list for use in taking a poll of employes to determine their attitude toward a new collective bargaining election.

The survey of real property in the city, being conducted by the Tenement House Department in cooperation with the Federal Department of Commerce, is expected to uncover "very substantial sources of revenue for the city," Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, said yesterday, following the organization in his office of the Mayor's Committee on Real Property Inventory.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 9. -- Brutal sluggings, bitter cold, scarcity of food, days and nights in darkness, and hours spent in bed or in a chair, during which his captors acted as doctors, nurses and barbers, provided the high lights of Edward G. Bremer's twenty-two days' experiences in the hands of his kidnappers.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9. -- t Small, flower decorated tables wereI arranged in the patio of Mrs.] Graham Fair Vanderbilt's villa to-I night for the dinner dance withI which Miss Elsa Maxwell, whoi visited her and is now the guest of/ Grand Duke Dmitri and Princess Anna Ilynski, entertained a group of her younger friends in compliment to Mrs. Shevlin Smith.

By defeating the Yale Club team, 4 to 1, in the concluding match on the schedule last night, the Bayside Tennis Club carried off the season's honors again in the New York group of the Metropolitan League Class B squash tennis tourney.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 9. -- A general increase in shipping at the port of Newark in 1933 was announced by Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein today in a statement analyzing the annual report for 1933 made by Chief Engineer James W. Costello.

PARIS, Feb. 9. -- The brief spell of peace that had followed forty-eight hours of rioting was broken tonight when the police battled for several hours against a Left reaction to the tumult of the previous days.

Unofficially characterized at the time of his appointment as an Ambassador who could bring about a friendly feeling for his country in the United States, Hiroshi Saito, the new Japanese Ambassador to Washington, arrived yesterday and fully demonstrated his qualifications.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 9. -- A hydroplane carrying German air mail arrived at 3:50 this afternoon, inaugurating a bimonthly six-and-one-half-day service between Stuttgart and Buenos Aires. This is one and one-half days faster than the French Aeropostale service.

BOSTON, Feb. 9. -- Nine deaths from the cold, seven of them in the Boston area, an almost complete stoppage of shipping, scores of serious fires and intense suffering among the poor marked the ninth day of the cold wave in New England.

There are three one-season repeaters on the Farrar Rhinehart Spring list. Colette, whose novel "The Innocent Wife" has just appeared, is author of another book due in May, "The Indulgent Husband." Faith Baldwin, whose "Innocent Bystander" started off the year for these publishers, has a new novel due on May 3.

Over the names of Clarence H. Mackay, Harry Harkness Flagler, Marshall Field, Walter W. Price, Edwin T. Rice, Charles Triller and Richard Welling, the executive committee of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York last night transmitted "to the friends and subscribers" of this country's oldest orchestra a detailed statement of its annual deficit.

On edge for several days because of fear that the proposed Federal regulation of the Exchanges might interfere with the normal business of the markets as now conducted, Wall Street found yesterday, after the close of business on the Stock Exchange, that it had not exaggerated in guessing at the scope of the legislative program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- The National Labor Board will not retreat from its plan of ascertaining the will of the Weirton Steel Company's employes on collective bargaining but will proceed to carry out the mandate of President Roosevelt's executive order, it was announced tonight by Senator Wagner, chairman of the board.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday the form of contract for a one-year franchise to the Green Bus Lines, Inc., covering Manhattan crosstown routes. The final public hearing will be held on March 9.

BERLIN, Feb. 9. -- The Boerse weakened today, but as offerings for both public and professional accounts were readily absorbed, declines remained in moderate limits and a number of issues closed above yesterday's finals.

The annual specialty show of the Associated Terrier Clubs will be held in the Grand Central Palace today, nine specialty organizations joining in the exhibition, which will open at 9 A.M. and continue until 6 P.M. Judging in all breeds will start promptly at 9 o'clock.
ATLANTA, Feb. 9 (AP). -- The high tribunal of football, the intercollegiate rules committee, began its annual review of the gridiron college code tonight.

Apologists, critics, and students of the motion picture industry took part in a symposium yesterday at the twenty-fifth anniversary conference of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, in the Pennsylvania Hotel. All agreed that the motion picture, while undoubtedly capable of improvement, never could be bettered by professional censorship.
Following are brief sketches of the careers of the members of the new French Cabinet:

The P. Lorillard Company reports for 1933 a consolidated net income of $2,380,254 after all charges and reserves, equal, after dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock, to 84 cents a share on the 1,890,646 shares of common stock outstanding.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Conflicting views on the reorganization plan of the McCrory Stores Corporation as issued by the management under the sponsorship of the board of directors were voiced yesterday by protective organizations representing creditors and security holders.

Despite the excessively low temperatures which prevailed, retail trade maintained an active pace during the week. Dollar volume for leading local stores was estimated as 12 to 15 per cent ahead of the same period a year ago. The cold spell served to clean out the last remaining stocks of Winter merchandise.

AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 9. -- A 3 per cent increase in prices of automobile tires to dealers was announced today by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. It was believed that the B.F. Goodrich Company and the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company would adopt a similar advance, although they did not comment.

Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, received the Italian silver medal of merit for distinguished accomplishment in education at a ceremony aboard the Italian liner Roma yesterday at the foot of West Fifty-seventh Street.

Curiosity to see and hear the latest opera by an American composer, which the Metropolitan is presenting for the first time this afternoon, has sold out the opera house, it was announced last night, and has occupied a large part of the company in rehearsals for a longer period than any similar production of recent years.

Every pastor and assistant in Catholic churches and chapels in the city will preach tomorrow at each mass, by direction of Cardinal Hayes, a sermon in propagation of "the crusade for Christian decency," begun last Sunday to rid the city of "obscene and immoral publications."

Handicapped by the semi-arctic temperature and ice-bound apparatus, fire-fighting forces in the city and suburbs fought yesterday against unprecedented hardships in subduing fires in widely scattered places.

Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, feels confident that President Roosevelt shortly will call for the "energizing" of industry and an increase of employment through greater production of goods, he said yesterday.

New Yorkers fled southward by air and rail routes in unprecedented numbers yesterday to escape the record cold, while commuters and city subway and trolley users were explaining to their bosses how the cold had delayed their arrival at shop or office by tying up transportation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Valid application for importation of intoxicating liquors filed with the Federal Control Administration call for a total of 49,840,006 gallons, it was announced today.

All classifications of bonds on the Stock Exchange closed irregularly lower yesterday despite a late rally in which some of the earlier severe losses were retrieved. The trading pace slackened materially on the decline, with the turnover amounting to $16,165,000, compared with $19,276,000 the day before.

The Board of Education has acted promptly on the recommendation of the joint committee appointed by the State Education Department. It has approved, bills introduced in the Legislature looking to the centralization of supervisory and administrative authority and responsibility in the Superintendent of Schools.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange rose again yesterday in response to Thursday's announcement that legislation to control ginning would be backed by the administration, and an advance into new high territory left the list with gains of 6 to 11 points.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 9. -- The Princeton basketball team overwhelmed Harvard, 46 -- 19, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game at the University Gym tonight.

LONDON, Feb. 9. -- The British Government today entered upon a tariff war with France by formally announcing an additional 20 per cent custom duty on a wide range of French products in retaliation for the French refusal to restore 100 per cent quotas for British goods.

Plans formulated by the reorganized Triborough Bridge Authority have been approved by Federal and State PWA officials. An agreement has been reached whereby funds to carry on the preliminaries of the $50,000,000 project for the next three months will be quickly advanced by Federal authorities.

Mrs. Gifford Pinchot, wife of the Governor of Pennsylvania, pledged her support to the striking hotel and restaurant workers last night when she addressed a meeting of the Amalgamated Hotel and Restaurant Workers Union, the strike organization, at its headquarters, 915 Eighth Avenue.
No changes were apparent in any section of the money market, either in the way of quotations or business. Rates were steady and turnover chiefly of routine character.

Assets of the New York Life Insurance Company increased from $1,974,076,041 to $2,010,943,112 last year, according to a report issued yesterday by the company listing some of the items from its statement as of Dec. 31.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 9. -- E.B. Shipp's Run On staged a fast finish in the featured fifth race at the Tampa Downs track today to overtake L. Thompson's Black Comet in the stretch and win by a length. Ninera finished third.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- Prospects that the long drought in parts of Texas, Oklahoma and Kansas might be broken caused a sharp decline in wheat today. This influence was augmented later by liquidation by local and Eastern longs when securities broke, and the downward movement was not checked until the price of the May had declined nearly 2 cents a bushel from yesterday's finish to the lowest level since Jan. 27.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issues of Tan. 25 and 26 you state that electrical engineer are advocating further governmental support of technological research, and take exception to such action as likely to lead to further unemployment.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 9. -- The Dartmouth swimming team took the short end of a 36 -- 35 score in its meet with Princeton today in Spaulding Pool.

All but one of the twenty-two chain-store and mail-order organizations that have reported sales in January showed increases over the same month of last year. The sales of all of them totaled $194,229,445, compared with $168,385,127 in January, 1933, representing a gain of 15.3 per cent.
Several leases for expansion were among the business items reported yesterday. Manufacturers, restaurateurs and retailers in various lines were included in the listings, as follows:

Elmer Greensfelder has found some engrossing material for "Broomsticks, Amen!" which was acted at the Little Theatre last evening. Among the Pennsylvania Dutch pow-wowing and witch-doctoring are still active superstitions, as newspaper readers have reason to know; and Mr. Greensfelder has wrung a folk-play out of this mystic lore.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 9. -- Clyde Troutt's Preferred won the six-furlong race which held the feature position on the program at the Fair Grounds today, scoring by half length over Kai-Finn, with Dr. Syntax in third place.
ATHENS, Feb. 9. -- The long-heralded Balkan pact of non-aggression was signed today amid great public rejoicing by the Foreign Ministers of Rumania, Turkey, Yugoslavia and Greece.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 9. -- Outclassing her famous rival -- Miss Helen Hicks -- off the tee and on the green, Miss Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., four times metropolitan titleholder and runner-up for the 1927 national crown, won the annual Miami Biltmore women's golf championship today.
Reports of a vast improvement in the fighting ability of King Levinsky, like those premature announcements of Mark Twain's death, are slightly exaggerated.

An additional share in the proceeds of State taxes was sought yesterday by the Board of Estimate, which moved to increase the rebate from the older State levies as well as to obtain a share of newer taxes from which the city now receives nothing.

A belated rally In the final period enabled the New York A.C. hockey team to upset the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, 3 to 1, at the Coliseum last night. The visitors scored two goals in the last four minutes of the hard-fought battle to win.
BERLIN, Feb. 8 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of Feb. 7 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

Plans advocated in many quarters for the establishment of a special banking corporation under the direction of the RFC for financing exports bring to a head a question that for many years has been stirring traders here with foreign countries, according to a statement issued yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP). -- Three men in governmental authority at the time the Michigan bank holiday was called last February told the Senate Banking committee today that Federal agencies did all in their power to assist the Detroit banks.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
Housing properties in the Bronx proved attractive to buyers yesterday, when brokers reported contracts on several multi-family buildings there. An operator made a quick turnover of one of the houses.
The Merchants Association complained to Mayor LaGuardia yesterday of the "lengths to which the school teachers were going to defeat your sound plan for the rehabilitation of the city finances."

More than 150 representatives of forty-five code authorities in New York City met yesterday at the NRA office, 45 Broadway, to discuss problems of enforcement and other questions. The meeting was called by Nathan Straus Jr., State director of the National Emergency Council, who presided.

Several important issues on next week's calendar of State and municipal financing are expected to cause keen competition. New bonds and notes totaling $10,117,739 will come up then for award, representing requirements of thirty-eight communities.
" Sing and Whistle," with Ernest Truex, opens tonight at the Fulton Theatre.

The undefeated New York University quintet had too much guile and experience for Brooklyn College last night and the Violet routed by 39 to 26 the team that had been expected to extend it to the utmost.

There are persons of average good memory and average honesty who may find it a bit hard to identify our recent past from Secretary ICKES'S description. He said it was an era of ruthlessness on top and purgatory for the plain people.

Particularly gratifying to Premier DOUMERGUE must have been the message sent to him by M. POINCARE. It was more than a greeting from one strong man to another. It implied confidence in the good sense of the French people and in the democratic institutions under which France has lived for more than sixty years.

Ir. and Mrs. Edward Norman Scott gave a large dance last night i in the Roof Garden of the PierreI to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Delia Gurnee Scott. Mr. and Mrs. Scott and their daughter were assisted in receiving by Mr. iand Mrs. Edward N. Scott Jr. and Dr. Alexander lqicoll, uncle of the dbutante.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP). -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner recommended today that the commission approve abandonment by the Long Island Railroad Company of its branch line from Port Jefferson to Wading River, L.I., a distance of about eleven miles.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- The United States will be officially represented in Russia by a staff of twenty-four.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 9. -- No plan to substitute graduates of the Naval Academy for the coaches now employed is contemplated, it was announced today by Lieut. Commander Harvey E. Overesch, Navy's graduate manager of athletics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- William P. MacCracken Jr., cited to appear before the Senate today to show cause why he should not be punished for contempt for allowing correspondence under Senate subpoena to be removed from his law office, defied that body by refusing to appear.

VIENNA, Feb. 9. -- The clerical Christian Social party, to which Chancellor Dollfuss belongs, joined forces with the Socialists in the Vienna Diet tonight against the dictatorial demands of the Heimwehr, which is calling for the dissolution of the political parties.

Mr. CURRY left New York, calm when his enemies were loudest. His resolution has ripened in the Florida sun. It is as stiff as the Northern cold to which he is about to return. squad of Tammany leaders still demands his scalp. Let them come and see if they can get it, says Mr. CURRY, in effect.

HAVANA, Feb. 9. -- President Mendieta believes labor troubles are no longer a major threat to his administration and the country is now on the road to tranquillity, he told the foreign press this afternoon.
Meat trade conditions'- and wholesale prices at New York.
Tashamira will speak on the dance at the theatre forum to be held at Essex House tomorrow afternoon.

OTTAWA, Feb. 9. -- Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, who is here for the wedding of her grandniece, Irene Helen Robbins, daughter of W.D. Robbins, Minister to Canada, chatted of her son today with the members of the Parliamentary press gallery.
