Feeling that many important angles may be overlooked by the government in creating a bank to finance foreign trade, exporters here last week authorized an advisory committee to consult with the RFC officials who plan to put the institution into operation with in the next few weeks.

Mussolini was being interviewed by an American correspondent on a Spring day in 1928. He had asked what the people in the United States thought of his regime. He had been told that it was the interviewer's opinion that many people across the Atlantic admired what he himself had been able to accomplish as an individual, but that Americans as a whole would probably not like to be governed under the Fascist system.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- Complete revision of the procedure in examination before trial would be effected in a bill to be introduced Monday by Senator John L. Buckley, chairman of the Commission on Administration of Justice, he announced today.

Designation by Mayor LaGuardia of seven members of an advisory council for the Department of Hospitals was announced yesterday by Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Hospital Commissioner. In addition to the seven, the council is to be made up of twenty-six other members, one representative being appointed by the medical board of each of the twenty-six city hospitals.
DUBLIN, Feb. 9. -- Isolated acts of violence in different parts of the country during the week are indicative of a general weakening of the sanctions of law and order.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Administration leaders who have been resisting negotiations for veterans benefits beyond President Roosevelt's program agreed today to withdraw technical objections and allow the whole question to be fought out on the Senate floor.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- The disputes of the present disarmament conference have already poisoned the atmosphere in which the naval conference of 1936 will have to convene, if by that time it is considered worth while for it to meet at all. There has been ample evidence of that fact this week in London.
LONG BEACH, L.I., Feb. 10. -- Mayor Charles Gold has arranged an appointment with Governor Lehman an State Controller Tremaine for next week to discuss the acute financial condition of this city.

TORONTO, Ont., Feb. 10. -- Echoes of pioneer mining days in Ontario will be heard next Spring when steps will be taken to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the discoveries of gold that brought the Porcupine Camp into being.

Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education, denied responsibility yesterday, on behalf of the board, for the communication sent Thursday to high school principals by William R. Lasher asking opposition to Mayor LaGuardia's economy bil.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 10. -- Cornell's midwinter social season, Junior Week, in the midst of wintry weather this year, was enlivened by outdoor sports, markedly absent in the festivities during recent years.

Accompanied by a New York detective and an Assistant District Attorney, Art J. Smith, self-styled commander-in-chief of the Khaki Shirts of America, and Frank Moffer, his erstwhile aide-de-camp, arrived by plane at North Beach Airport early last night after their extradition from Pennsylvania.

LITTLE AMERICA, Antarctica, Feb. 9 (Via Mackay Radio). -- All her lifetime the Bear of Oakland has been doing rescue and relief work. Now, at last, she is a full-fledged exploration ship and she is penetrating the unknown at a speed of seven and a half knots, bound on a cruise of exploration, probably as important as any done by any ship in the Antarctic in modern times.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The government tonight was weighing the idea of matching its wholesale cancellation of air-mail contracts with some similar action on the ocean mail contracts.

IT suited the humor of playful New Yorkers, when Fifth Avenue was still the metropolitan cocktail trail, to tag the two stone lions superciliously on guard in front of the Public Library "Hastings" and "Carrere," in compliment to the two men who were architects of the building.

DR. MONTAGUE, who is founder and medical director of the New York Intestinal Sanitarium, is a specialist in rectal and intestinal diseases, and his book is devoted entirely to troubles of that kind, but chiefly to the attempts of those who are thus afflicted to do self-doctoring.

Retail trade throughout the country encountered the handicap of unusually cold weather, but reports from the Federal Reserve districts indicate that in spite of this, the volume of sales was well maintained. In other respects, the reports are almost unanimous in their reference to further economic improvement.

THERE is little comparison between the Hardy Chrysanthemum of today and the favorites of a few years ago. Popular as this flower has always been, new admirers are now turning to it in ever increasing numbers to obtain rich colors in pleasing variety for the last big display in the Autumn garden.

An agreement has been reached by the copper industry on a code less comprehensive than those previously submitted, and it probably will be sent to the NRA officials in Washington this week. The new code, developed last week in meetings that brought out that the code already submitted was unacceptable to virtually the entire industry, is primarily a labor code.

The public reception of "Merry Mount," by Richard Stokes Jr. and Howard Hanson, which received its world premiere yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, was one of unmistakable enthusiasm as indicated by the number of curtain calls.

KATHERIIE MAYO has emerged from her extensive and painstaking investigation of the ex-soldier situation with the conviction that both the one-time members of the A.E.F. and the nation's treasury have been bilked, the former spiritually and the latter of many millions.

IN this spirituous garland there should be a book to suit almost very sort of drinking taste. The fine bouquet of a thousand wines and the extraordinary colors of uncounted cocktails adorn their pages. Abstemiousness in actual practice may arise from wisdom or from economics.

TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 11. -- The official celebrations of the birth of Crown Prince Akihito commenced this morning, with solemn worship at the ancestral shrines in the imperial palace after which the Emperor issued a proclamation granting general amnesty to prisoners.

It is a fact, noteworthy in American musical annals, that the opera, "Merry Mount," libretto by Richard Stokes, music by Howard Hanson, given its "world operatic premiere," as the announcement put it, yesterday afternoon by the Metropolitan Opera Association, had the most enthusiastic reception given any native music drama that has been produced in New York in ten years -- and probably in a much longer period.

ROUBEN MAMOULIAN extended a tired and suspicious face around the corner of the entrance to his hotel suite, keeping, one hand warily on the doorknob, When his visitor had assured him that the call bore no relation to the rumor which linked his name with that of a Miss Garbo he relaxed and smiled a pleasant, youngish smile.

Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, national chairman of the fund-raising activities of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, has sent a message on German-Jewish relief to about 5,000 Jewish leaders in this country and Canada, the committee announced yesterday.

Columbia University's sixth annual "Round-the-World Columbia Day" will be observed tomorrow on the Morningside Heights campus when thousands of alumni will return to the university to attend the annual Alumni Day luncheon and participate in the program for the day, it was announced yesterday by Major Clarence E. Lovejoy, alumni secretary.

CAMDEN, S.C. -- Owners and horses are arriving daily for the Washington's Birthday races, to be held on Feb. 22. At that time the Washington Birthday Plate will be run, a steeplechase of about two and one-half miles over timber.

Policemen and detectives stood in clouds of inky smoke from a cellar fire yesterday afternoon guarding jewels valued at $1,000,000 by Maximilian Casimir, proprietor of the jewelry store at Fifty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue. Two alarms were turned in, and three firemen, overcome by smoke, were taken to Flower Hospital.

ESCANABA, Mich., Feb. 7. -- Although Michigan stands to benefit the most from the completion of the St. Lawrence seaway, the people seem to view the news of the progress toward realization of this longtime dream with only casual interest.

LONDON. THE recent death of Sir Henry Dickens, the last surviving child of Charles Dickens, releases for public inspection a collection of his father's letters in the possession of the British Museum. They formerly belonged to Sir Henry's sister, Mrs. Perugini, who gave them to the museum with a stipulation that they should be reserved until the death of the last member of the family.

PARIS, Feb. 10. -- All over France today Premier Doumergue's appeal for a public truce and appeasement, which appeal has been plastered on the walls of every public building in the country, is being read with approval. But it will be still some days before the plan can be realized, for tempers are still hot.

WHENEVER the government of the French Republic gets into trouble one hears the cry in the streets of Paris: "Vive le Roi!" It does not mean a great deal, and yet one never knows. Much stranger things have happened.

THE actual throne room of Great Britain is the "gilded chamber" of the House of Lords. The actual thrones are the oaken Gothic chairs which stand beneath the richly pinnacled canopy at the head of the long, narrow chamber.

HAVANA. -- With the recent change of administration, which has brought a sense of stability and security back to the island, Cuba now looks forward to a late but excellent tourist season. Steamship companies have again placed Havana on their schedules for excursion vessels and hundreds of visitors are arriving daily.

THE nineteenth century bolstered its never too feeble self-esteem by spreading the news through the words of its artists and writers of its discovery of landscape. This claim is celebrated in Paris at the Orangerie this Winter by an exhibition of landscape drawings from that happy century of peace and plenty.

PARIS, Feb. 10. -- The new French Government today set up a four-man directorate headed by Premier Gaston Doumergue to handle foreign affairs swiftly and vigorously and strike hard against the possibility of a German union with Austria.

THE present book, Spengler tells us, grew out of a lecture on "Germany in Danger," which he delivered in Hamburg in 1932 "without meeting with much comprehension." The larger part of the first half of the book was finished a year ago, and that part is now published without alteration, "for I write," he declares, "not for a few months ahead or for next year, but for the future.

Breaking 99 out of 100 targets, A.L. Burns won the High Scratch Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. The second scratch trophy went to P. Garino, who had 97. In the handicap cup shoot the winner was F.A. Scola, who had a card of 94 -- 3 -- 97.

By a Presidential order the air mail system of the country suddenly finds itself completing a cycle and returning to the point whence it started on May 15, 1918, when army pilots undertook to fly the mail between New York and Washington.

BERLIN, Feb. 10. -- Friedrich Ebert Jr., a former Socialist leader and son of the late Socialist President of Germany, was the star witness in a sensational trial before the criminal bench of the Superior Court here which terminated in the conviction of Kurt Heim, a National Socialist lawyer, of breach of trust and extortion.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- So strong is the patriotic clamor for recapturing the Atlantic speed record that Parliament is expected to give quick approval to the government's plan to lend up to u9,500,000 for the combined Cunard-White tar fleets.

YOU are set for life, everybody, including your friends, tells you, when you have an important role in a great big hit. We all realize that the players share in the glory that comes with a genuine 100 per cent success. And so the friends advise you, after you participate in a smashing hit, all you have to do is find another play with another part in it like "this one"!

Striking back at industries which they feel have used NRA codes for the purpose of eliminating all profit uncertainty from business, purchasing agents for several major corporations this month are trying various methods of forcing suppliers to modify code regulations.

THE arrangement of cut flowers is no longer circumscribed by the limitations imposed by inadequate or inappropriate holders. The day of the inartistic glass paper-weight type is over. This holder was inpractical as well as ugly, because the openings never quite fitted any stem.

The New Jersey Zinc Company reported for 1933 a net income of $3,994,072 after taxes, depreciation depletion and other charges, including $588,705 proceeds from patents. This is equivalent to $2.03 a share on 1,963,26 shares of $25 par stock and compares with $2,013,120, or $1.02 a share, in 1932.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (AP). -- Chicago taxpayers will receive their first tangible benefit this month from the CRA -- Chicago Recovery Administration.

No audit has been made of revenue accounts in many city departments and county and borough offices for from five to seven years, with the result that the city may have lost as much as $1,000,000 through failure to check properly the collection of revenue, Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, declared yesterday.

Jens Nelson, of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., claimant to the $4,000,000 estate of Edward Albert Ridley, murdered real estate dealer, was recalled to the witness stand yesterday and examined by Surrogate James A. Foley about his maternal ancestors in Norway and Sweden.

PEIPING, Jan. 18. -- The American public must have its "hot dogs" so, here in China, intrepid souls have been running lone risks, in order that the American appetite might be satisfied -- that is, until the Chinese Government stepped in.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- William P. MacCracken Jr., sought for several days to answer charges of contempt of the Senate in connection with the air-mail contract investigation, is a "week-end guest" of the Senate's sergeant-at-arms, Chesley W. Jurney.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 10. -- With one of the most remarkable exhibitions of ski work the event has seen, Dartmouth came back to victory today in the twenty-fourth annual Winter carnival of the Dartmouth College Outing Club.

After over-night reflection the proposed bill to regulate the security and commodity exchanges may have seemed somewhat less terrifying to speculators, but the share market showed further concern yesterday by declining precipitately in response to heavy sales at the opening.

THIS is a violent, brutal book. There have been many so-called violent, brutal books in the past few years; it is the mark of this one that in spite of all the others, its harshness is emphatic. Had the author's only aim been to write a shilling-shocker, he could scarcely have contrived a bloodier or more horrific tale.

HOLLYWOOD. WITH the rewriting of the script of "Elizabeth and Mary" to care for the discrepancy in the ages of two actresses, a glamourous figure of the Belasco era may become well known to the newer cinematic age.
Arrangements protecting CWA workers against loss of pay because of lay-offs during the cold wave were announced yesterday by A1fred H. Schoelkopf. chairman of the State Civil Works Administration.

Officials and master workmen of the Brooklyn Navy Yard braved the cold yesterday morning to witness the laying of the keel of the U.S.S. Dale, sister ship of the destroyer Hull, which was launched at the yard on Jan. 31.

If it were practicable to register the degree of resistence usually asserted in opposition to reducing governmental expenses through economies, on the one hand, and to adopting new kinds of taxes for the purpose of raising additional revenue on the other, the results would probably show about an even score.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 10. -- The annual Winter meeting of the National Alumni Association of Princeton University will take place in Nassau Hall on Washington's Birthday, Feb. 22, according to plans announced today by John Colt, '14, chairman of the Alumni Day committee.

The American Paper Mill Supplies Institute of 62 William Street announced yesterday that charges that monopolistic control of its industry is being brought into being with governmental sanction have been filed with General Hugh S. Johnson, NRA administrator.

AS he looks back upon the breathless advance of scientific research in the last fifteen years Professor Colin G. Fink of Columbia University wonders, in The Engineering and Mining Journal, what the future will bring forth.
Jill Talcott was a young thing who lived "on the wrong side of the river" in Fairfield. near Chi-

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- Miss Susan Noel achieved a record when she gained the distinction of winning the English women's squash racquets championship for the third year in succession by defeating the left-handed Miss M.E. Lumb. 9 -- 7, 9 -- 0, 9 -- 6, today in the final, which lasted less than twenty-five minutes.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Feb. 10. -The last surviving member of Abraham Lincoln's bodyguard will be the next possessor of Ohio Wesleyan's alumni cane, traditionally awarded to the oldest alumnus of the university.

Wall Street finds, upon dissecting the National Securities Exchange Bill, that the worst fears have been realized. The proposed regulations, it is contended, go far beyond what President Roosevelt himself had in mind. The President, in his message to Congress, recognized that the security and commodity exchanges "are necessary and of definite value to our commercial and agricultural life."

THIS romantic and valorous tale of the Southwestern border contains in its tangled skein almost enough diversified material to furnish forth half a dozen ordinary yarns of Western adventure. Here is the story of Don Luis Romero, who dreamed of creating "The Republic of the Rio Grande" as a buffer State or shock-absorber between the United States and Mexico, and accumulated vast stores of munitions or his 1,500,000-acre Texas ranch.

Health Commissioner John L. Rice announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. William H. Best of 1,198 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, as a deputy commissioner. Dr. Best has been acting director of the department's Bureau of Preventable Diseases for the last two and a half years.

After many weeks of rehearsals, the Junior League Glee Club will bring its season to a climax with its eleventh annual concert on Friday night in the Great Hall of the clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. As in past years, the club will be assisted by a large unit of the Yale Glee Club and the entire program will be conducted by Marshall Bartholomew, director of both organizations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Set in motion by the President's message, commodity exchange regulation proposals followed a leisurely course today behind the Stock Exchange measure, but it is probable that bills will be ready for introduction within the next few days.

Fritz Kreisler, before sailing last night for England and points East, took his leave of American admirers till another season in a matinee that packed Carnegie Hall and put 200 seats on the stage. The Viennese violinist, once heard earlier in the season, reappeared with the rebound of spirits preceding an artist's holiday.

MOSCOW, Feb. 10. -- That the Soviet Union has attained economic independence, particularly in the construction of equipment and machines, and that the Soviet Union will not buy such products abroad unless credit conditions are "changed and improved," was stated categorically by Foreign Trade Commissar Rosengoltz in a speech before the All-Union Communist Party Congress.
THE atmosphere of "The Hawk and the Tree" is very different from the one Mr. Carleton described in his first novel, "Desirable Young Men." which was welcomed as showing signs of great promise.
Business will be suspended in Wall Street and in most other financial centres tomorrow in observance of Lincoln's birthday. The banks also will be closed.

Garden beginners, with new seed-packets on hand, worry and chafe over the continuance of wintry blasts and freezing weather that interfere with starting a hot-bed or fixing up a cold frame. The old-timer smiles and waits. From long experience he knows that one of the perennial marvels of gardening is the way seasons "average up"; that a few days lost now will be compensated by a favoring sun and warm rains later on.

That Federal taxes are excessive and burdensome there is no doubt, but they do not fall upon the people at large, as shown by the official report of the United States Treasury, dated July 31, 1933, except in the case of "non-necessities" and "luxuries" which they voluntarily assume.

Newark officials became alarmed yesterday at the decision of the government to have the army take over air mail flying and Mayor Meyer C. Ellstein sent the following telegram to Postmaster General Farley:

Evidence that short selling on the New York Stock Exchange in January was heavier than in any other month in the last two years, appeared yesterday when the Exchange announced that the short interest in listed stocks had increased 317,215 shares to 1,030,083, between Dec. 30, 1933, and Jan. 31, 1934.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- The stock markets again were cheerful today. A feature was heavy buying of West African gold mines, although the kaffirs were dull on Cape selling. The price of gold was lower at 137s. 1d. an ounce. About 650,000 of the metal was sold to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Sir Malcolm Campbell, British driver who seeks an automobile speed record of 300 miles per hour as his ultimate goal, will drive his five-ton Bluebird racer over the Salduro Lake bed near Salt Lake City, Utah, in August in an attempt to smash the mark of 272,108 miles an hour he now holds.

AT the beginning of this year there were 13,960 licensed pilots in the United States, according to figures gathered by the Aeronautics Branch, Department of Commerce. Of these licenses 7,103 are of the transport class, the license required, among other qualifications, if a pilot was to fly planes carrying passengers in interstate commerce.

Plans are now under way aimed at the development of uniform trade practices and regulations covering NRA labels in those industries dealing directly with the retailer, it was announced yesterday by Ralph Abercrombie, chairman of the fair trade practice committee of the dress and glove industries.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- Enactment of a "real" indeterminate sentence law and a uniform system of parole was recommended today by the State Parole Board in its annual report to Governor Lehman and the Legislature.

In THE TIMES of Feb. 4 Professor E.M. Dodd Jr., writing from the Harvard Law School, which is generally supposed to have been the source from which the inspiration for the form of the Securities Act was derived, comments on certain criticisms which I had offered of the arguments against any modification of that act.

HOW Captain Robert Falcon Scott, R.N., and his companions died on their march back from the South Pole, which was never completed but ended thirteen miles from plenty and shelter, is a story that will never die. Mr. Lindsay is right in calling it an epic.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 10. -Winning four first places and the relay, Harvard's varsity swimming team piled up enough points to submerge Columbia, 49 to 22, in the Harvard indoor athletic building tonight.

The interest of many New Yorkers and members of various clubs was centered in the outcome of the annual meeting of the Metropolitan Club yesterday, following a recent report that the club was considering "a union with some club of similar standing" because of hard times, and had a deficit of $51,435.76 in operating costs for last year.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 8. -- The mood of the Corn Belt changes. Three months ago it was in a ferment of discontent, which was the cue for Mile Reno, the big bad wolf of the farm drama, to start huffing and puffing at the house of the AAA with his farm holiday strike.

OF a total of 89,500 fatal accidents in this country last year, 30,500 were caused by motor vehicles, according to a report issued by the National Safety Council. Other public accidents accounted for 17,500 fatalities, home accidents killed 29,500 and occupational accidents 12,000.

BOSTON, Feb. 10. -- The elimination of the defending champion Philadelphia team in a first-round match and the defeat of all except one of four foreigners in the individual championship featured the first day's play in the national squash racquets tournament today.

WITH John F. Curry, leader of Tammany Hall, facing a revolt more serious than that encountered by any other recent Tammany leader, his political foes have been studying the election law and the rules of the Democratic County Committee of New York, the legal name for the Tammany political organization, to determine the best method to use in the attempt to put him out.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 8. -- The real cow-punchers, their sons and grandsons are having a great time at the expense of the William R. Nelson Gallery Art.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Hearings on the Stock Exchange control measure, introduced in the Senate and House yesterday following receipt of President Roosevelt's special message on the subject, were scheduled in the House for Wednesday and the Senate for a day next week yet to be selected.

Jacques W. Redway writes to THE TIMES under the heading: "Two Codices Are in Great Britain -- Sinaitic Manuscript Has Joined the Alexandrine." His interesting and instructive letter is taken from dispatches in The London Dispatch. He writes: "I am inclined to think that The London Dispatch asserting that it was 'rescued from a waste basket' is in error."

Crediting the original discovery of iron ore near Lake Superior to an Ojibway Indian named Marjigesik (variously spelled), as your Negaunee correspondent does, adds romance to this momentous event out of which has grown the enormous ore trade on which the iron and steel industry of the United States mainly depends.

BERLIN, Feb. 10 (AP). -- The triumphant declaration that Chancellor Hitler has definitely cast his lot with Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller and the Nazi German Christians in the long-standing Protestant Church controversy was made today in the Nazi weekly church organ, The Gospel in the Third Reich.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- Governor and Mrs. Lehman were lunching quietly in the Executive Mansion today when firemen burst into the historic structure on Eagle Street, which has housed three men who later became Presidents, and announced that flames were spreading from the third floor to the second.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 8. -- The approach of Spring sees Missouri returning to its favorite sport -- the game of politics in which the goal is a United States Senatorship, control of a Congressional delegation and the usual revolt but in new form against the machine power of Tom J. Pendergast in Kansas City with its ramifications into State politics.

AMERICANS have spent millions for school buildings and too little for knowledge. The mania for brick and mortar has used up the taxpayer's dollar, while the children must continue to study from books which in many cases are obsolete.

With transactions in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday amounting to only $8,377,000, the smallest turnover for a Saturday this year except one, prices showed considerable irregularity. Domestic corporation bonds drifted slightly lower, while foreign loans gained slightly on the average.

HAVANA, Feb. 10. -- Secretary of State Cosme de la Torriente this afternoon expressed the appreciation felt by the Cuban Government of the recommendation made by President Roosevelt to grant Cuba a sugar of quota 1,944,000 short tons or 1934.

The Consulate General of Brazil here announced yesterday the receipt of the full text of the agreement for service on the Brazilian debt reached by the Brazilian Government and J. Reuben Clark on behalf of the American bondholders, the salient features of which were published by THE NEW YORK TIMES on Wednesday.

EUROPE has had a grand reshuffle of wave-lengths, and slightly bewildered listeners are wondering why. Thirty-five countries took part in a conference at Lucerne. A new plan to clean up the ether was prepared, to which twenty-seven countries agreed and eight did not.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Acquisition of 17,000,000 acres of submarginal land, with an expenditure of $50,000,000 in a comprehensive program of wild life restoration throughout the country, was recommended to President Roosevelt today in a report by a special committee requested by him to outline a rehabilitation plan.

THE view of life which Colette presents in her novels -- and, taking them all together, it is a remarkably individual and consistent view -- has always been highly personal. The world to her is not a place of large and interacting physical and social and economic forces, with which man is forced to contend and by which he is helplessly conditioned.

BERLIN, Feb. 10 (AP). -- Relatives of George Dimitroff and Wassil Taneff, Bulgarians acquitted in the recent Reichstag fire trial, were reported today to have been threatened with expulsion if they did not cease communicating with foreign correspondents.

HOFFMANN, a distinguished German physicist, discovered that the cosmic rays do not pour in upon us steadily as light does from the sun. Sometimes there are what he calls Stosse, or bursts. Others have observed these rocket-like bursts and wondered what they are and how they are caused.

Declaring that the "most important single factor for the preservation of the breeding industry, and the welfare of the turf in America, is that the Jockey Club and New York racing shall go on," Rear Admiral Cary T. Grayson of Washington, internationally known figure on the turf, yesterday announced through the Jockey Club the result of an estimate of the racing situation in America.

On reading the letters concerning the Philharmonic's future in Sunday's TIMES, I am struck by the assumption of the writers that enough people exist who wish to support music. Mr. Costen-Bader says that the attendance at the concerts conducted by Walter and Lange was pitiably small, but he does not believe that only one man can make New York come out to listen to the Philharmonic.

It is almost imperative, by the laws of axe grinding, that every season turn up one letter by a producer, one letter by a critic, one letter by an author and one letter by an actor which will attempt to settle the problems of the theatre in general and the grievances of the writer's particular group in particular.

ONE of the big events of the year in New York City is the Spring Flower Show. Its continuing success is due to the fact that the show has never remained static. Plans perfected at two meetings last week indicate that this season the show will be more complete, diversified and beautiful than ever.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 10. -- Racquets enthusiasts from all parts of the metropolitan district gathered at the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club today for the opening round of the annual Gold Racquet tournament, which ranks next to the national championship in importance.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 10. -Two recently discovered portraits of Lincoln have been loaned to the John Hay Library at Brown University for exhibition on the annual visiting day, Feb. 22.

PUBLIC education in this country seems on the mend. A few months ago, with rural schools closing in two dozen States, educators believed it had received a blow from which it would take years to recover. Today, thanks to first aid from Uncle Sam, education is not only looking up, but is started, temporarily at least, on a career more ambitious than any before envisaged in this nation.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 10. -- Pirate II and Phantom, defending the North American Class A ice yacht championship pennant for the North Shrewsbury Ice Boat and Yacht Club finished first and second respectively, in the initial race today.

COLIN CLIVE, just released from his stage engagement in "The Lake," is to start for Hollywood today to play a prominent role with William Powell and Kay Francis in "The Key," which deals with the Black-and-Tan troubles of a few years ago in Ireland.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 10 (AP). -- Grover A. Whalen, president of the Advertising Club of New York City, said tonight that the nation is "on the high road to recovery."

IN "The Queen and Mr. Gladstone," which Doubleday, Doran Co. will publish early in March, Philip Guedalla has edited the correspondence between Queen Victoria and her most famous Prime Minister. For several years Mr. Guedalla has been engaged in selecting and arranging the more than 4,700 letters and telegrams that make up this correspondence, now made public with the consent of the trustees of the Gladstone estate.
The police continued their surprise gambling raids yesterday, arresting forty-one men at one establishment and eighteen at another.

MR. LUCAS is a twentieth-century Lamb. Not so robust as Lamb nor so emotional, he has, nevertheless, the same curiosity about the seemingly usual, the same amusingly eccentric type of learning. There is something of Addison in him, too -- his urbanity.

LONDON, Jan. 24. OF all the unlikely celebrities to appear on the stage, Thomas Carlyle is, one would have said, the most unlikely. Clive, who is to appear next week, had all the dramatic qualities; he rose suddenly to fame and fortune, he was bold, resolute, overbearing, spectacular; his life was a life of action, lived in a setting that compares favorably, in bloody splendor, with that of the Arabian Nights.

Substantial increases in cash and in investments in United States Government bonds are shown by leading life insurance companies in their financial statements as of the end of last year. In many instances almost the entire increase in total assets is represented by these two items.
CLINTON, N.Y., Feb. 10. -- In a triangular fencing meet today Yale defeated both Hamilton and Cornell. Hamilton gained an even break by conquering Cornell, 12 1/2 to 4 1/2.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 10. -- Byron Nelson, 22-year-old Texarkana Country Club professional, gained the undisputed lead today in the $2,500 Texas open at the end of the first thirty-six holes with rounds of 66, 70 -- 136, six under par.
The 1933 survey of the American Civil Liberties Union, made public here yesterday, charges that "too many employers confuse Roosevelt's New Deal with Coolidge's New Capitalism."

FIFTY years have elapsed since it was proved that a pen could hold its own supply of ink and write without flooding the paper with disfiguring blots. Before that time a pen with an attached reservoir of crude form had made its appearance in various countries, but it was unsatisfactory.

WHAT is water worth? How much can a city afford to pay for an ample supply of potable water? How much can a farmer in a region of insufficient rainfall afford to pay for irrigation water? With the continued development of the West these questions have been removed from the realm of theoretical speculation and have become realities, rather grim ones in certain localities.
PARIS, Feb. 10. -- The two war veterans killed in the rioting at the Place de la Concorde Tuesday night received impressive funerals today.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 10. -- Two American ideals, economic progress and self-government, are forever associated with Feb. 11 and Feb. 12, the one of the birthday of a great inventor, Thomas Alva Edison, and the other of a great statesman, Abraham Lincoln.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The Treasury will offer about $1,000,000,000 in new securities next week, it was authoritatively stated today, in connection with the government's program of borrowing about $6,000,000,000 in new money before June 30.

AMERICA is enjoying the Metropolitan Opera on the air. Mail is evidence. The applause letters and postal cards indicate that the appreciation spreads far across the countryside, from metropolis to hamlet, from New York apartments to homes on the range.

I am extremely saddened by the disclosure of the directors of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, that the year coming might dawn minus the Philharmonic's splendid concerts. Oh, might that year never dawn!

CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- Formulation of a code of fair practices, which will be submitted as a part of the Investment Banking Code, was undertaken here today when governors of the Investment Bankers Association, representative bankers and members of the National Code Committee assembled to iron out differences.

Ferdinand Pecora, counsel to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, who returned yesterday from Washington, made it plain that the proposed Federal act regulating the markets imposes upon banks the same restrictions, so far as the margining of security loans is concerned, as apply to brokers.

THIS carefully worked-out reference book contains 11,000 baptismal names, classified separately for men and women, each one with its origin and significance. That is, after each one, in parentheses, is the name of the racial stock from which it comes, and then in concise form appears its meaning.

Two of the greatest upsets ever recorded in metropolitan speed skating competition were registered yesterday at Conservatory Lake in Central Park, where the annual Silver Skates derby, the banner event of the season, was held.

The second in the series of Knickerbocker assemblies for this season was held last night in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton. The dance took place in a setting of greens, including cedar trees, palms and southern smilax.

THE directors of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra last week issued an appeal to the season-ticket subscribers and the public for funds to defray its deficit. This is the third leading symphonic organization in America to make such an appeal within a month, the other two being the Boston Symphony and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony.

The night life which is the lure of big cities to country folk and dwellers in towns not so big has always harbored in and hung about taverns. Witness master Francis Villon of Paris and Master Ben Jonson of London.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- The British Government told Austria today that she could not expect any action by London in support of her appeal to the League of Nations against German Nazi interference before the Council had taken up the matter.
Industry in England definitely is on the upgrade, according to Gerald Campbell, British Consul General here, who spoke yesterday before the English-Speaking Union, 19 West Forty-fourth Street.
My trip to America having come to an end, it occurs to me that many ready-made ideas on the United States are wrong.

THE National Association for the Advancement of Colored People will celebrate its twenty-fifth anniversary tomorrow. From a small group concerned with injustices suffered by members of the Negro race, the association has grown into a nation-wide organization with 375 branches and a membership of about 80,000.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Feb. 10. -Playing before a crowd of 1,200 that packed the local high school gymnasium, and with as many more fans clamoring outside, the Trenton High basketball team tonight registered its thirty-sixth consecutive victory by defeating Passaic, 33 to 25.

What a crime, and a senseless one, it would be against a weak country, Austria, to have it confiscated by Germany. Because the three great power, Britain, France and Italy, think only of their own interests they may be blind enough to allow Hitler to carry out his nefarious design.

James C. Sheridan, member of the Queens County Executive Committee, has been selected to succeed John Thoefel as leader of the Democratic party in Queens. His formal election to the post held by Mr. Theofel is expected shortly.

THIS is a book of exceptional interest and value which should have a very wide appeal. It is, in fact, difficult to think of any group of intelligent people who will not find it absorbing. We have already had from Mr. Adamic one autobiographical record of superior quality -- his "Laughing in the Jungle," which appeared somewhat less than two years ago.

What a crime, and a senseless one, it would be against a weak country, Austria, to have it confiscated by Germany. Because the three great power, Britain, France and Italy, think only of their own interests they may be blind enough to allow Hitler to carry out his nefarious design.

James C. Sheridan, member of the Queens County Executive Committee, has been selected to succeed John Thoefel as leader of the Democratic party in Queens. His formal election to the post held by Mr. Theofel is expected shortly.

THIS is a book of exceptional interest and value which should have a very wide appeal. It is, in fact, difficult to think of any group of intelligent people who will not find it absorbing. We have already had from Mr. Adamic one autobiographical record of superior quality -- his "Laughing in the Jungle," which appeared somewhat less than two years ago.

Long before the authorities have begun to suspect that the death of Captain Jay was anything but accidental, the reader is aware that he was murdered and knows who did the deed. It is the author's intention that the reader should know, for the interest of the story lies first in the gradual unfolding of the reasons for the murder, and, second, in the unforeseen circumstances that lead to the detection of the crime.
Performances of the new play, "Richard of Bordeaux," with Dennis King, which opens Wednesday night, have been taken over on dates in the near future to aid the work of two charitable organizations.

LONDON, Jan. 24. OF all the unlikely celebrities to appear on the stage, Thomas Carlyle is, one would have said, the most unlikely. Clive, who is to appear next week, had all the dramatic qualities; he rose suddenly to fame and fortune, he was bold, resolute, overbearing, spectacular; his life was a life of action, lived in a setting that compares favorably, in bloody splendor, with that of the Arabian Nights.

Substantial increases in cash and in investments in United States Government bonds are shown by leading life insurance companies in their financial statements as of the end of last year. In many instances almost the entire increase in total assets is represented by these two items.

A brilliant pageant of flags will feature the annual military ball of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, Department of New York, which takes place on Friday night in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore. The event is held each year to raise funds for the welfare and relief work of the organization among needy ex-service men and their dependents.

WITH the fast-shifting political scene daily affecting the trend of the nation's business, New Yorkers who deal in stocks have grown more and more impatient with financial quotations that are not up to the minute.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 10. -Led by Don Ruddy of the famous family of natators, the water polo team of the iew York Athletic Club defeated the Navy today, 28 to 14. Ruddy scored four touch goals and two foul throws to account for half of his teaxn's points.

New York University's intercollegiate championship fencing team won its annual dual meet with City College by 16 to 11 yesterday at the C.C.N.Y. School of Business gymnasium. It was the opening meet of the season for the Lavender fencers.
The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday to members the following notice regarding coupons on bonds:

PRAGUE, Feb. 10. -- The Czechoslovakian Government decided today to lower the gold content of the Czech crown by one-sixth to be able to compete with the export trade of countries with depreciated currencies. This announcement effected an increase of about 16 per cent in the quotation of foreign currencies on the Prague Stock Exchange.

BERLIN. THAT comprehensive history of the world, the "Propylaen-Weltgeschichte," has been completed. But can we speak of completion when it comes to that monumental work of history which the guiding spirit of the world cremates and will continue to create as long as living creatures inhabit our planet? That work is divided into millions, untold millions of chapters.

GREAT interest in American antiques is now directed toward pieces from particular localities. Usually, of course, the collector chooses the section in which he lives; museums in different parts of the country have for some time been making regional studies of great value.

Chief Justice Frederic Kernochan of the Court of Special Sessions, a close friend and yachting companion of the President, revealed yesterday that Mr. Roosevelt was fond of telling "tall fish stories." Justice Kernochan was confiding some of his vacation experiences to a group of youthful Izaak Waltons, a troop of Boy Scouts, that had been listening to the President's radio chat, marking the organization's twenty-fourth anniversary, at a luncheon for them in the Advertising Club.

THE love of money is the root of all evil and the need of money has been the source, in these days, of many memoirs. "As I had no experience of reduced circumstances." confesses the most madcap and mendicant of all countesses.

In canceling the air-mail contracts President ROOSEVELT shows anxiety to prevent under his Administration any scandalous use of public funds. This particular case deals with abuses which have been uncovered with respect to transactions which took place before he became President.

DENVER, Feb. 8. -- The spectre of race prejudice, which recurrently makes its presence felt in Colorado, has appeared again. Here the Spanish-American rather than the Negro is the target of discrimination and the current means seems to be the CWA.

Citing loss of cotton-textile markets in the Philippines to Japan, Walter S. Brewster, president of the Textile Export Association of the United States, in a letter to George A. Sloan, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute, yesterday urged government assistance for cotton-goods exports.

MAD HATTER'S VILLAGE" is a first novel. The publishers say that Miss Gore wore out three typewriters doing twelve unpublished stories before this one. It has a sure touch which proves those typewriters did not die in vain. It is a good book -- better by far than most of what has been written about the mad scene of Southern California.

DODGE CITY, Kan., Feb. 8. -- A one-man museum started a year ago by Merrit Beeson had more than 2,000 visitors in twelve months. Beeson calls his museum The Corral, and it is in the basement of the big Beeson home which formerly was the focal point of the Beeson ranch of more than 15,000 acres.

In spite of all disclaimers, the evidence is strong that Nazi Germany has marked out a good part of Austria for her own. It is stated that the appeal of Chancellor DOLLFUSS to the League of Nations will largely be documented with proof that the Nazi agitation and outrages in Austria have been directed and financed by the German Government.

CHOCCOLOCCO, Ala., Feb. 8. -- Ten acres of the most fertile soil in the Choccolocco River Valley have disappeared from the face of the earth. The tract simply dropped out of sight, leaving gaping holes filled with water where cotton flourished a few months ago.

Elaborate mechanical methods of school-room ventilation are entirely unnecessary and are costing American schools millions of dollars yearly, according to a survey on school ventilation issued at Teachers College. The study shows that open windows serve the purpose of ventilation systems, and at lower costs.

Further gold imports from abroad totaling $11,472,000 were reported yesterday by local banks and banking houses, following the receipt of $15,376,900 reported on Friday by the Federal Reserve Bank. Not all of yesterday's shipments arrived in time to be included in the daily gold statement of the Reserve Bank, which showed imports of $7,022,900, of which $2,396,900 was listed as additional for the previous day.

THE crisis which flared out in France last week has been brewing for months. In three directions -- in the field of economics, of diplomacy and of politics -- the issues have been developing. With these issues the new government must deal -- with energy and with speed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- An upward trend in productive activity, with the automobile industry re-cording a pronounced gain, was noted today by the Department of Commerce in its summary of domestic business conditions for the week ended on Feb. 3.

PARIS, Jan. 19, 1934. FOR the last two months the musical life of Paris has been so impoverished that I have not had the courage to report it regularly. But I can at least review the first part of the season.

TEN purring motorboats, the comfortable cabin cruiser type, moved off in a line from the dock of the Key Largo Anglers Club some fifty miles below Miami. It was early morning of a fine warm day as the fleet picked its way through Paradise Creek to the Atlantic Ocean.

I am heartily in favor of saving our grand Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra by any and all means, and all credit is due the sponsors for their generosity and unselfishness to date. But the question that arises in my mind is, "Will the policies of the orchestra be more progressive and forward-looking than heretofore?"

LONDON. ENGLAND'S toll bridges, which levy tribute on all those who travel by motor car, horse vehicle, bicycle or on foot, are slowly disappearing. After 107 years the penny toll at Menal Bridge, which connects Anglesey with the mainland of North Wales, was recently abolished, and since 1880 about 150 other toll bridges have gone.

Seven Russian philanthropic agencies will be the beneficiaries of the third annual Russian carnival to be held Saturday night on board the U.S.S. Illinois, the floating armory of the First Battalion, Naval Militia, which is anchored at the foot of West Ninety-seventh Street.

The New York County Lawyers Association has made known its position on nine bills pending in the Legislature. The association has approved three and has disapproved six. Similar reports on other bills will be made during the legislative session.

EXCEPT that his book may have an explosive and rending effect on the ideas and opinions of some of its readers, Mr. Harding's title has no connection with the efficient chemical of which so much was heard during wartime. He takes the letters from the initials of "These National Taxeaters," usually a derisive reference to the personnel of the Federal Government.

BOSTON, Feb. 10. -- Gordon Clark, whose running and kicking provided Exeter with a football triumph over Andover last Fall, contributed three goals to lead Exeter to a 5-to-2 hockey victory over Andover in their twentieth annual game at the Boston Arena today.

DALLAS, Texas, Feb. 8. -- Dr. John O. McReynolds, president of the Pan-American Medical Association, has outlined the program for the floating congress to Venezuela, March 14 to 30. All members of the medical profession are being invited to participate in the cruise on the S.S. Pennsylvania. The party will sail from New York.

The Republic of Colombia, if it chooses to do so, can resume the full interest on all of its external debts through the sale of newly mined gold to the United States Treasury at $35 an ounce as provided for under the Gold Reserve Act of 1934, according to a statement issued yesterday by Lawrence E. de S. Hoover, secretary of the Independent Bondholders Committee for Colombia.

HOW do ABRAHAM LINCOLN'S two best-known discoveries stand up on his 125th birthday? Superficially, one would say that government of the people, by the people, and for the people is not doing so well. It is under a cloud in Europe and a few advanced spirits are beginning to have their doubts in this country.

It became known yesterday that the Cunarder Mauretania had passed a sea monster 65 feet long, 2 feet across the head and 6 feet broad amidships, at 1:20 P.M. on Jan. 30, when the ship was steaming at twenty-four knots off the island of St. Eustatius in the Caribbean Sea.

New York State's failure to reapportion the legislative and Congressional districts within its borders is rapidly approaching a national scandal. A reapportionment of Congressional districts should have been made in 1931, following the Federal census of 1930; the State Senate reapportionment should have taken place in 1926, the year after the last State census.

Striking hotel and restaurant waiters smashed plate glass windows in four hotels last night in a noisy parade through the theatrical district, during which they injured two policemen and damaged two cars. The police said the strikers, numbering about 1,500, had no permit for the parade.

PARIS, Jan. 29. IF a wife shows no capacity for loving, it matters little that she be a perfect housekeeper, and the best way to awaken in her a capacity for loving is to beat her. These appear to be the two propositions which inspired Fernand Crommelynck to write his latest play, "Une Femme qu'a le coeur trop petit," which has just been produced by the Theatre de l'Oeuvre.

TWO trunk stand in all office of the State Department, unlocked but not yet unpacked, splashed with London labels which have been almost obscured by brilliant pasters from Montevideo. Bulging with books and papers, they testify to the travel habits of the most peripatetic Secretary of State this country has ever known.

A NEW deal for the parks of New York City is now being evolved. Heretofore the parks have been administered by borough commissioners, some of whom had little knowledge of the problems involved in maintaining and improving the areas under their jurisdiction.

The Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin will begin today his thirtieth year as pastor of the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street. Dr. Keigwin is known nationally as a radio preacher. He was formerly president of the Greater New York Federation of Churches.
The need for a new deal in trade organization was urged yesterday in a discussion under the auspices of the New York Chapter of the League for Industrial Democracy.

Plans are now under way for a novel post-Lenten entertainment to be known as the Better Citizenship Ball, which will be held on the night of April 7 at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street. The event will serve as a benefit for work being conducted among underprivileged boys of all nationalities by the Association of Better Citizenship, Inc., of which Alpheus Geer is president.

The quest of John Van Ryn for his third leg on the Heights Casino Challenge Trophy came to naught yesterday when the Davis Cup doubles veteran from East Orange and Philadelphia was put out in the quarter-finals of the indoor tennis tournament at the Brooklyn club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Despite denials of Congressional leaders that serious consideration is being given to further silver legislation, the administration was reported today to be working on a plan for partial remonetization of the "white" metal in order to avoid a fight with Congress on this issue.

Joseph Lordi of the New York A.C., seeded No. 1 in the National Class C squash tennis championship in progress at the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, yesterday swung into action for the first time and was carried to three games before he advanced at the expense of H. Henryson of the City A.C.

THIRTEEN stories of hunting and adventure, contributed by as many members of the Boone and Crockett Club, compose this handsome volume, the seventh published by that organization since it was started forty years ago.

TO set forth the drama of human life within the limits of a single volume is a project that might well daunt the most valiant. And Margaret Cushing Osgood, as if in recognition of this fact, has confined her scrutiny to one limited although highly important phase of human life.

FUNDS supplied by the Wisconsin Alumni Research Foundation have established in the University of Wisconsin the first and only "wild-game chair." To it has been called Dr. Aldo Leopold, an authority on wild game in America and formerly United States Forester.
PARIS, Feb. 1. -- In my two previous articles I have shown the obstacles in the way of a Franco-German reconciliation. Let us see if there are others more profoundly rooted.

BOSTON, Feb. 10. -- Glenn Cunningham of Kansas and Bill Bonthron of Princeton staged a dress rehearsal at the Boston Garden tonight for their forthcoming Baxter Mile meeting as they slammed through to victory in the twin features of the forty-fifth annual Boston A.A. indoor games.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 10. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 73.2, which compares with 72.8 a week before, 72.5 two weeks before, 72.1 three weeks before and 72 four weeks before.

BERLIN, Feb. 10. -- Competent authorities here, including the Institute for Studying Trade Fluctuations and Alfred Lansburgh, editor of Die Bank, visualize an open currency war of the dollar against the pound. The institute asserts that the world must be prepared for the possible further 9 per cent depreciation in the dollar, and that the tendency to undertake this will be strengthened in the United States if England allows sterling to drop further.
The mercury here rose above freezing yesterday for the first time since Feb. 1. As it remained there less than an hour, the ice-caked streets of the city were without the benefit of a thaw.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 11. -- Paraguay has achieved another notable victory in the Chaco by the capture of Fort Magarinos, sixty miles west of Fort Nunoz. Another communique announces that the northern army is within one mile of Fort Cabezon, fifty-one miles west of Fort Platanillos.
Seventeen of the twenty-six current Broadway attractions will give special holiday matinees this afternoon.

Not wealth itself, but the misuse of wealth is the curse of the present day that must be remedied, Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York Methodist Area declared in a sermon as guest preacher yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.
In a game packed with thrills the Crescent Athletic - Hamilton Club sextet turned back the formidable Niagara Falls Cataracts in Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. The score was 2 to 1.

BARCELONA, Feb. 11. -- Barcelona has for some two months become the centre of the workers' united front movement, now spreading throughout Spain, which has as its impulse the conviction that labor will find itself at death grips with fascism.
SAN JUAN, Feb. 11. -- A suggestion of a threatened strike against electric companies is seen in a letter sent by Governor Blanton Winship to Mayor Blas Oliveras of Ponce.

AMOY, Feb. ll. -- While the movements of the Nanking armies in Central Fukien Province have been conducted with the utmost secrecy, the central authorities apparently are devoting the major part of their time and energy to reorganization and consolidation of the Fukien provincial government, with headquarters at Foochow.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 11. -- The general price improvement was reflected in Argentina's export trade in January, which increased 21 per cent in volume and 47 per cent in value, according to the National Statistical Bureau's report published today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- An entirely new governmental policy for the transportation of ocean and air mail is expected to be written into law before Congress adjourns this session.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- Huntingdon D. Sheldon of New York continued his spectacular playing of the past two weeks and won his way to the final round of the Tuxedo gold racquet tournament today by defeating H.N. Rawlins Jr. in three straight games, 18 -- 15, 15 -- 18, 15 -- 11.

DENVER, Feb. 11. -- The love affair which Miss Anna E. Wendelin, pretty blond nurse, had hoped would result in her marriage today was ended instead, police said, by her suicide after she shot and killed Willis W. Case Jr., wealthy Denver clubman.

Working under the direction of agents of the Federal Public Health Service, 200 CWA workers will go forth in a few days to make war upon rats in all parts of the city. They will be equipped with 67,000 steel and snap traps and 2,000 flashlights.

The Westminster Kennel Club will open its fifty-eighth annual dog show at 9 o'clock this morning in Madison Square Garden with 2,462 dogs on the benches. The exhibition will continue through Wednesday evening, with three judging sessions daily.

Three thousand employes of the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service will undergo a period of instruction in efficiency and courtesy under the tutorship of Commissioner Daniel W. MacCormack, it was announced yesterday.

HONGKONG, China, Feb. ll. -- Foreign naval units along the South China coast, foreign business firms in Shanghai, Canton and Hongkong and Chinese banks are apprehensively watching developments along the Kwangtung-Fukien border, which are expected to lead to an early outbreak of civil war immensely exceeding in importance the recent Fukien rebellion.

Formation of the Fine Arts Foundation, a new national agency for the promotion of American painting and sculpture, under the leadership of the country's most prominent artists, was announced hero yesterday by F. Ballard Williams, member of the National Academy and chairman of the national executive committee of the American Artists Professional League, one of the organizations sponsoring the foundation.

Eddie Cantor gave his annual party last evening for the Summer pleasure of boys from the East Side of New York. The occasion was the benefit -- held at the New Amsterdam Theatre -- for the camp he inaugurated at Cold Spring-on-Hudson.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- In the good old days that hill near Warwarsing Town in Ulster County, N.Y., was called "Good Beer Hill," but now, despite repeal and advances in the art of brewing, it is merely "Beer Hill."

Medals to twenty-three graduates for conspicuous alumni service will be awarded at a luncheon of the Alumni Federation of Columbia University at John Jay Hall today. The luncheon will be the central event of the annual "Round-the-World Columbia Day" and simultaneous luncheon meetings will be held by alumni organizations in various cities of the United States and Canada.

BERLIN, Feb. 11. -- The factional War in German Protestantism has reached a quiescent state since Reichbishop Ludwig Mueller, aided by the police and the political authority of the Nazi State, has succeeded temporarily in silencing his foes.

Colonel Lindbergh started in aviation as a student in a private flying school at Lincoln, Neb. After working for months as a mechanic and learning to fly by acting as a wing-walker and parachute jumper with a flying circus, he bought his first plane, a war-time "Jenny."

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Feb. 11. -- What's all the hundreds of airplane pilots and the thousands of people who make an honest living in the airplane business going to do? It's like finding a crooked railroad president, then stopping all the trains.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES report of the recent annual meeting of the Maternity Medical Association, Thomas S. McLane, president of the Children's Welfare Federation and of the board of trustees of Roosevelt Hospital, is quoted as having said: "We hear of many rackets in this city, but the greatest racket is the proprietary hospital.

The nation celebrates today the 125th anniversary of the birth of its sixteenth President, Abraham Lincoln. Various societies, headed by the National Republican Club, have arranged special events in him memory, and in New York the climax will be reached tonight at the annual Lincoln memorial dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11. -- Enlarged activity in all lines of industry in this territory has been reported in the last week. Raw materials and finished goods are passing into consumption at a better rate, employment is increasing, prices are hardening and profits are better.

Resale by the Provident Institution for Savings of Jersey City of the three apartment houses at 409-17 Tenth Street, West New York, to the Sixteenth and Park Avenue Corporation, Morris Broadman, president, was the outstanding realty transaciton in New Jersey reported over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Security issues totaling more than $10,000,000 are proposed in registration statements filed with the Federal Trade Commission under the Securities Act and made public today. About $9,000,000 of the total represents deposits called for by bondholders' protective committees.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- "Heavy hydrogen" has been changed for the first time from a gas into both liquid and solid forms at the Bureau of Standards by R. B. Scott and Dr. F. G. Brickwedde, it was announced today. The experimenters used a large sample of "heavy hydrogen" manufactured at Columbia University, New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- The National Recovery Administration, faced with a growing enforcement problem under codes covering purely local enterprises, today urged the forty-eight States to enact statutes making code violations a breach of State laws.

The American team which will meet the British in the international matches for the Walker Cup at St. Andrews, Scotland, on May 11 and 12, will sail from New York on April 21, according to an announcement made yesterday By A.M. Reid, secretary of the U.S.G.A.

MOSCOW, Feb. 11. -- General Vassily Bluecher, commander of the Soviet Far Eastern Army, told the All-Union Communist Party Congress, in session here, that Japanese action in Manchuria was "not defensive but aimed at an attack upon the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics."

James A. Higgins, who served as Commissioner of Accounts under Mayor Walker and Mayor O'Brien, endorsed yesterday the recent proposal made by Commissioner Paul Blanshard, his successor, to transfer to the Finance Department the full responsibility for auditing all revenues received by city departments, county offices and courts.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11. -- Prices of hogs are the highest for February in three years, $4.85 a hundred pounds for the best light, compared with $4 on Feb. 1 and $3.50 two weeks ago. At this time in 1931 the price was $7.50. Last week's average was $4.25, or 5 cents under the previous week.

Prices of cotton moved higher again last week, continuing the advance that has carried them upward about 230 points a pound, or $11.50 a bale, since the middle of December. With the market breaking into new high ground last week for the season, the highest prices for future contracts since last July were recorded.

P. Garino and A.L. Burns tied for the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday, each returning a card of 95 out of 100 targets. On a toss the trophy was taken by Garino. J.E. Getman defeated J.P. Hennessy in a shoot-off for the handicap honors.

LONDON, Feb. 11. -- Hendryk Colijn, Holland's energetic Premier and Colonial Minister, arrived here yesterday, presumably for discussions of Anglo-Dutch trade relations and restriction of rubber production.
There will be no open lawn tennis tournament in the United States this year.

The bill proposed by the Senate committee for regulation of Stock Exchange business is in many respects extremely drastic. It covers immense ground, and so extends its restrictions and prohibitions that it is bound to invite from impartial sources a great variety of criticism. Having in view the large number of security markets in this country and their diversity, some of the bill's provisions are distinctly salutary.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $5,055,761,700. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

For the first time in the history of labor conflicts in this city, settlement of a strike was brought about yesterday as a result of pressure exerted by the city through its tax machinery. Mayor LaGuardia ordered on Saturday that the water supply be cut off from the Colonial Laundry, 16 Lexington Avenue, and the Sunshine Laundry, 824 Lexington Avenue, both in Brooklyn, for tax arrears of several years.

Mayor LaGuardia's proposal that charter revision and proportional representation be submitted to the voters as separate issues has the full support of Samuel Seabury and the others who led the Fusion campaign last Fall.
DETROIT, Feb. 11 (AP). -- Goals in the first and third periods tonight gave the Detroi. Red Wings a 3-0 victory over the Ottawa Senators in their National Hockey League match.

PARIS, Feb. 11. -- A dollar worth 100 cents gold lives on now only with the League of Nations. When the League began its pioneer work in detecting, measuring and comparing monthly economic and financial trends throughout the world it found it essential to choose some stable unit and convert all of the seventy national units to that value.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas., Feb. 11. -- Stout-hearted Wiffy Cox of Brooklyn increased the size of his wallet today when he won the $2,500 Texas open with a 72-hole card of 141,71, 71 -- 283, one under par.

Ethel Bartlett and Rae Robertson gave a recital of music for two pianos at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Among the most distinguished practitioners of this phase of chamber music, they gave vivid and finely grained readings to Bach, Clementi, Debussy, a trio of British composers, Schumann and Berlioz.

PARIS, Monday, Feb. 12. -- With a cessation of work in newspaper offices at midnight and erratic telephone service in the early morning hours, French labor began its nationwide general strike today to protest against reactionary, Fascist and Royalist elements in last Tuesday's "little revolution."
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1934, as well as last prices for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

Bryant Park offers to the public the only recreation space within a mile radius, a park where tired shoppers should be able to sit and rest a moment comfortably with some privacy and removed from all lanes of pedestrian traffic. Here they should be able to enjoy the beauty of shade trees and shrubbery.

Emma Goldman, the anarchist, appeared publicly in this country yesterday for the first time since her deportation fifteen years ago, and 2,000 persons stormed the Community Church services in the Town Hall in the hope of hearing her old fiery oratory.

Prices for commodity futures traded on local exchanges continued their upward trend last week, and in several instances moved to new high levels for 1934. Trading was maintained in good volume throughout the week. Cash prices were irregularly higher.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- News is received here that Senator Johnson has been endorsed by the Democratic Congressional Committee of the Eighth District in California, an action advancing the movement among Democrats of that State to make him the party's nominee next Fall.
ATLANTA, Feb. 11. -- The National Football Rules Committee today held out a helping hand to the offense, altering three portions of its code to give more strength to the attacking team.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11. -- An experiment in merchandising of electricity, projected by two California utility companies, is engaging the interest of power companies throughout the country.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- The London bullion market now is trading in record amounts of gold. Since the beginning of the week it has dealt in more than u9,000,000, with the daily figures steadily establishing new records.
Negotiations with the Royal Yacht Squadron for holding the races for the America's Cup having been completed, the conditions to govern the match were announced yesterday by the New York Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- A resolution asking the posting in post-offices of the names of all local veterans receiving government compensation, together with the amount, was adopted today by the American Veterans Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- The Public Works Administration today prepared to embark upon the new sea of security flotations; not of bonds issued by itself, but a potential total of $500,000,000 issued by the broad group of public agencies which have borrowed or will receive loans for self-liquidating projects.

SALISBURY MILLS, N.Y., Feb, 11. -- Ottar Satre of Salisbury, Conn., carried off the Class A honors at the invitation ski-jumping tournament today on the Norsemen's hill. The event was under the auspices of the Norway Ski Club of New York and was held with the sanction of the Eastern Amateur Ski Association.

ST. MARGARETS, Que., Feb. 11 (Canadian Press). -- Eighty pounds of skis topped by Bill Trower and an ordinary pair of jumping skis on the feet of Dick Ball today carried off the Canadian "flying kilometer" -- the first time an event like the famous skiing speed classic of St. Moritz, Switzerland, has been held in North America.

Outstanding in the week's local art calendar is the exhibition of paintings by French nineteenth century masters (including a canvas by Gericault lent by the Louvre in Paris), which opens today at the Durand-Ruel Galleries. The Children's Aid Society and the French Hospital of New York will share jointly in the proceeds.

The Americanism of Abraham Lincoln was hailed yesterday typical of "the spirit of our country" by the Rev. Dr. William P. Merrill, the pastor, in his sermon at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

Mrs. Julia T. Hooper Wynne, who was in her ninetieth year and was the mother of Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, former Health Commissioner, was found dead about 8 o'clock yesterday morning in a rear courtyard of 206 West Ninety-ninth Street.
The Prison Association of New York reaffirmed yesterday its praise and approval of the administration of Richard C. Patterson Jr., former Commissioner of Correction.

Large early sales of fertilizer in cotton-growing States are not necessarily indicative of a large use of fertilizer under cotton, nor does heavy fertilization necessarily indicate high yields, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service.

The Rev. Dr. William A. (Billy) Sunday delivered last night his farewell sermon in Manhattan after preaching here for a month. He spoke at the Cornell Memorial Methodist Church, 231 West Seventy-sixth Street, where he has been conducting a mission for the last two weeks. Before that he preached for two weeks in Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Deploring the tendency of the ministry to become too "funereal and sorrowful," the Rev. Dr. Malcolm James MacLeod, in his sermon yesterday at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, said a cardinal purpose of religion was to encourage "joyful living."

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP). -- The Little Red School House is getting out of the "red." Financial relief totaling many millions of dollars has been rushed by Legislatures in nearly a score of States, a survey showed today, to reopen poverty-stricken schools, meet overdue payrolls of teachers, and aid counties and townships suffering from decreased tax revenues.

PARIS, Feb. 10. -- The effects of last Tuesday's events in France appear to observers here to have been much exaggerated abroad. The attitude of the Daladier government had provoked the entire country to indignation, but nobody thought there would be a revolution because of this.

You style your correspondent "Skeptic" as "of little faith," but one can plainly see that he is a man of strong convictions. True, his letter is not strengthened by his somewhat bilious style. Nevertheless, it contains much truth and is fully supported by Mayor LaGuardia's radio appeal printed in full in your issue of Feb. 2.

Schwartz Brothers, jewelers and silversmiths, are to move to 580 Fifth Avenue from 1,454 Broadway. Benjamin and Frank Schwartz comprise the firm, established in 1899 at Broadway and Thirty-seventh Street. The present location is near Forty-first Street.

A new braille typewriter, described as "another epochal step in the development of mechanical appliances for blind people," has just been made available by the American Foundation for the Blind, Inc., a philanthropic organization at 125 East Forty-sixth Street.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Feb. 11. -- Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman and the Rev. Dr. Henry Lefavour of Boston are with Dr. and Mrs. Harry A. Garfield at Williamstown for the Midwinter trustees meeting of Williams College. Dr. Garfield entertained the board with a luncheon yesterday at the president's house.
The position of the committee on State legislation of the Bar Association was made known yesterday on some of the bills pending in the State Legislature in Albany.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 11. -- By a margin of 18 seconds, Commodore Edward C. Fielder's Drub, Rumson Ice Boat Club challenger, today captured the second race of the series for the North American Class A championship pennant.

President Eamon de Valera and his efforts to make Ireland a republic were praised last night by Mayor LaGuardia in an address at a Lincoln's Birthday celebration of the American Association for the Recognition of the Irish Republic, at Public School 17, 317 West Forty-seventh Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11. -- Study of a code of fair practice designed to slow down the tempo of the investment banking business occupied the attention today of a group of eighty-two investment bankers from financial centres of the country meeting at the Chicago Club.

Chicago's civic and cultural history has been told in the block-print medium. This series of prints, employing a simplified technique of white upon black, was made by students in the advanced class in design at Northwestern University, Evanston, Ill., under the direction of Clara MacGowan, assistant professor of art.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- Curtis Stevens and his Lake Placid A.C. Blue Birds retained their National A.A.U. four-man bob sled title on the Mount Van Hoevenberg Olympic run today by negotiating four heats of the tortuous mile and a half course in a total time of 7 minutes 29.42 seconds.

A rift in the Russian opera company now appearing at the Casino Theatre resulted yesterday in the resignation of Alexander Basy, its general manager, and disclosed what seemed to be a spirited political skirmish between Red and White sympathizers in the cast.

It is not quite correct to say that a temperature of 14 degrees below zero brings suffering to the homeless and the destitute. The suffering begins at a considerably higher point on the thermometer. If a family is without coal for the stove, or a man is without a home and an overcoat, 14 degrees above zero is bad enough.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- William P. MacCracken, against whom a Senate warrant has been issued in the air mail investigation, ended late tonight his game of hide-and-seek with Chesley W. Jurney, the Senate sergeant-at-arms, by ceasing to seek arrest.

MADRAS, India, Feb. 11 (Canadian Press). -England today ended its first innings in the third cricket test match with India with a score of 335. The invaders then provided a bowling barrage that limited the Indians to 145 runs for nine wickets.
