VIENNA, Feb. 11. -- It is understood in political circles that Chancellor Dollfuss has reached an agreement with the leaders of his Patriotic Front, with whom he has been negotiating since his return from Budapest.

Full of years, and honors, and a proud weariness, George Tenbroeck, the Negro handyman to Company B, Seventh Regiment. died yesterday at his home, 108 West 133d Street. The owner of four medals for length of service, George also had gained the coveted title of "Commandant of Company Servants" by dint of shining boots and sprucing up "quarters" longer than any other handyman in the regiment.

It was stated in Washington last week that Mr. ROO0SEVELT now intends to place all Presidential postmasters under the civil service rules. Perhaps the worry over these appointments has at last been too much for even his good nature. ABRAHAM LINCOLN said in his day that he had more trouble about postmasters than he did about winning the Civil War.

BOSTON, Feb. 11 (AP). -Arnold Adams of Worcester, former Bates track star, who made a sensational comeback to win the Boston A.A.'s 600-yard run by nipping Don Fleet of Boston at the tape, today was voted the outstanding competitor in the meet by a committee of Boston sports editors.

A new effort to minimize the law's delays, reduce the waste of time and money in appealing trial court verdicts to higher tribunals and give the poor man a chance to appeal from adverse judgments has just been made by the New York Law Society.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 11. -- Six hundred Williams College alumni, faculty members and students gathered in the Lasell Gymnasium here this evening for the final session of the midwinter reunions. Tribute was paid by the speakers to President Harry A. Garfield and Professors Henry D. Wills, George E. Howes and James L. Kellogg, all of whom retire in June.

The prison scandals lately uncovered should be dated lest blame fall where it is not deserved. This is to be said especially in behalf of RICHARD C. PATTERSON Jr., who retired as Commissioner of Prisons in September, 1932, after five years of service which brought from the Prison Association of New York praise for his "high efficiency," "rigorous honesty," "keen sense of responsibility" and "unusual devotion to the city."

Gregory Mangin of Newark, national indoor tennis champion and fifth ranking player of the country, will defend the Heights Casino Challenge Cup this afternoon against Clifford S. Sutter of New Orleans, fourth in the national list.

At the Harvard Law School, made famous by KIT LANGDELL'S case-system, Mr. EARL WOOD EVANS of the Kansas Wichita, president of the American Bar Association, spoke to the students on "Things Not Taught in the Law School," and centred their attention on their own case.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- The time-honored sporting adage "They never come back" was contradicted emphatically today ass Allan Potts, 29-year-old Brooklyn Olympian, regained the Middle Atlantic outdoor speed-skating championship, which he last held in 1931.

BERLIN, Feb. 10. -- The heavy depletion in the Reichsbank's reserves shown in the return for Feb. 7 is regarded in financial circles here as temporary, having been due, on one hand, to the transfer of 5,000,000 marks for service of the Dawes loan and deliveries of exchange to the bond-conversion fund and, on the other hand, to belated consequences of reduced export surpluses in November and December.

MADRID, Feb. 11. -- Tuesday is Mardi Gras and in connection with it the Spanish Government is not discounting the attempt of the Socialist press to organize a class war as being entirely a bluff. To play safe, the Cabinet met in extraordinary session until early this morning to decide on police measures to cope with possible attempts at mob violence under cover of the carnival festivities.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Hearings on the Fletcher-Rayburn Stock Exchange regulation bill will be speeded so as to bring the legislation to the floors of the two houses as soon as possible.
The twelfth annual pet show of the Madison Square Boys Club, at 312 East Thirtieth Street, proceeded quietly and without unexpected incident to a happy finale last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- The Anti-Saloon League will make a fight to nominate dry candidates for Congress in all State primaries, in addition to campaigning to maintain State dry statutes and prevent the enactment of laws which would liberalize those laws.

PARIS, Feb. 11. -- If it is to satisfy the demand of the country as expressed in last Tuesday's revolt, Premier Gaston Doumergue's Cabinet of national union must within the next few months so revise the French Constitution as to strengthen the administrative authority and limit the French legislative assemblies to their proper function.

A new event at the Westminster show this year will be the judging of the children's classes for the Grand Challenge Trophy offered by the Professional Handlers Association. These competitions were inaugurated a year ago in the Garden and have been held through the year at many of the leading shows.

Three women and one man were seriously injured last night by an automobile which struck them while they were crossing South Street near Pine. They were coming from a wedding party aboard the Morro Castle.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- Finishing with a burst of speed, Magnus Satre of the Salisbury Outing Club of Salisbury, Conn., won the Class A metropolitan cross-country ski race laurels in Palisades Interstate Park today. The event, held by the Swedish Ski Club of New York, was sanctioned by the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association.

With the passing of Professor Julius Sachs American culture has suffered a serious loss. He was born in Baltimore in 1849, when there was nothing in this country that could be properly called a university. He went to Germany, shortly after the Civil War, at a time when the German universities were enjoying their golden days.

0SLO, Norway, Feb. 11. -- Skating faultlessly to the cheers of a crowd of 15,000, including members of the royal family, Miss Sonja Henie, graceful Norwegian, retained her world's figure skating championship today.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 11 (AP). -- How the long-lost daughter and sole heir of D'Aubinge Eason was found in a Long Island hospital by a crippled Oklahoma City lawyer at the end of a search which carried him thousands of miles in his wheel-chair, was told today by the attorney, R. E. Wood.

ALBANY, Feb. 11. -- Taxation will come to the fore tomorrow night as the legislators return to the Capitol for another week's session, with a battle over a proposed 2 per cent retail sales tax featuring the deliberations.

Condemnation of the sales tax was voiced yesterday in a report on a nation-wide investigation, made public through the Columbia University Press. Describing the sales tax as "an unnecessary and backward step," the report declared that, "on the whole, experience with this form of taxation to date offers little support to those who contend that the sales tax should form a permanent element in a State tax system."
Welker Cochran of San Francisco came back to championship form in the world's title three-cushion billiard play last night at the Capitol Academy.

More than 125,000 roses, lilies and other plants being prepared for the Easter market where ruined last night when a fire destroyed nine greenhouses and four two-story frame buildings of Anton Schultheis, one of the largest flower growers in Queens, at 129th Street and Eighteenth Avenue, College Point.

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- P.M. McHugh did the best work at the traps of the Westchester Country Club today. He topped the field with a card of 91 -- 8 -- 99 in the regular event and led with 38 -- 12 -- 50 in the doubles test.

A garage worker was fatally burned and two others were seriously injured by an explosion in the boiler room of the Island Garage, 423 East Twenty-third Street, shortly after 8 o'clock yesterday afternoon. For three hours after the blast the neighborhood was filled with gasoline fumes and fire apparatus remained at the scene as a precautionary measure.

Entertainers from virtually every branch of the amusement world participated in last night's benefit at the Imperial Theatre in aid of the Treasurers Club of America, the membership of which is composed of local box-office men. Their annual entertainment to aid the ill and needy of their profession brought in about $3,900 from the sale of tickets and $4,500 from advertising in the program.

The extremely cold weather last week had some effect on retail activity with the result that reorders on Spring merchandise fell off slightly. Stores, however, continued to place a good volume of business. Men's wear orders reached the highest level in four years, while the activity in the dry goods markets brought about a general strengthening of prices.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 11. -- Demand for steel increased more rapidly in the last fortnight than in the first four weeks of the year, a sharp rise in sales from the automobile industry being accompanied by mild gains in miscellaneous demand, while railroad buying increased.

Next year's city tax rate is still conjectural. Real estate assessments have not been finally confirmed and the precise amount needed for debt service is apparently still in doubt. But if there are any property owners so sanguine as to expect the basic rate to remain at last year's level, $2.33 per $100, they had better be prepared for a shock.

Steel operations gained 3 points last week to 39 per cent of capacity, the highest rate since the second week in October, according to the magazine Steel. Rapidly mounting demand from the automotive industry and a broadening in general manufacturing requirements, the publication states, were chiefly responsible for last week's gain.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 11. -- H.A. Guess of New York, vice president of the American Smelting and Refining Company, has taken an option on 'a large mining tract at Smyrna, S.C., and electrified the old Terry gold mine there in preparation for resuming operations on a large scale.

BERLIN, Feb. 11. -- Woman "is the stage manager and man the general director in the drama of life," Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda and Public Enlightenment, told a meeting of Nazi women today.

Leading throughout despite a bad fall soon after the start, William Steiner of the German-American A.C. annexed the 15,000-meter (9 miles 564 yards) metropolitan championship race on Staten Island yesterday. The 22-year-old national twenty-mile champion ran over the snow-covered course in 48 minutes, a brilliant performance.
Yale and Penn scored victories over strong rivals on Saturday and are still tied for the lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League. Each has won five games and lost one.

The Right Rev. Rocksborough R. Smith, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Algoma, Ont., officiated yesterday at a two-hour ceremony which marked the ordination of Brother Andrew of the Order of St. Francis. The service was held at a pontifical high mass in the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 139 West Forty-sixth Street.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11. -- Railroad men tomorrow will have a preview of the Union Pacific's stream-lined, articulated train No. 123 at the shops of the Pullman Car and Manufacturing Corporation here.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- The turmoil produced in the foreign exchange market by the devaluation of the dollar and the serious political crisis in France is slowly subsiding. The severe reactions produced by these events so obscured the position of the market that President Roosevelt's objective of a devalued dollar was lost to view temporarily, but there now are signs of a gradual movement of exchange rates toward the new parities.

Champion Little Sahib, owned by Mrs. Vincent Matta of Astoria, L.I., yesterday was crowned best Pomeranian at the annual show of the American Pomeranian Club, staged in the Salle Moderne at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Judge Reuben Clarke of Brooklyn selected Little Sahib in a quality field of Pores numbering fifty-eight.

A cablegram from England on Saturday morning reported to Farrat Rinehart that the British sales of "Anthony Adverse" have topped 20,000 copies, an average of about 500 copies a day since publication some forty days ago. The sale of the book here is now more than 330,000.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Feb. 11. -- The flying personnel at this government airport was notified today that the United States has been divided into three areas, each to be commanded by a flight officer, for the proposed transporting of air mails by the service.

Investors whose long absence from the building field has been due in part to alleged questionable practices in that industry are expected to resume their interest in building as an investment medium after March 2, when the new construction code becomes operative, according to Myron L. Matthews in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 11. -- With the muzzle of a police captain's pistol pressed against his side, Basil Hugh Banghart, wanted by the Department of Justice in connection with the kidnapping of John Factor in Chicago, was arrested here early today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 11. -- Twenty-two varsity letters in football and eight in cross country have been awarded to members of the Rutgers University Fall sports teams, it was announced today by George E. Little, director of physical education.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh sent a strong protest to President Roosevelt last night against the President's action in canceling the air mail contracts. It is the right of any American individual or organization to receive a fair trial. Colonel Lindbergh asserted.

Photographs of coins said by archaeologists to establish the fact that Jewish autonomy existed in Jerusalem as early as the fifth century B.C. will be shown at a dinner to be given under the auspices of the American Friends of Hebrew University at the Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street, on Wednesday.

ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 11. -- Contrary to biographical reports, the deafness of the late Thomas A. Edison was considered by him as a "blessing" and was not caused by a blow, as commonly believed, but was a natural auricular deficiency, according to Arthur Walsh, a former associate of the inventor and vice president of the Thomas A. Edison Industries, Inc., West Orange.

When the assassinated LINCOLN died, Secretary STANTON exclaimed: "Now he belongs to the ages!" The somewhat grandiloquent phrase was, after all, a true word of prophecy. During the succeeding threescore years and nine, the private and public record of LINCOLN'S life has been searched as with a lighted candle, but nothing has been discovered which does not seem to add to his stature as the years have flown by.

The annual report of the Kroger Grocery and Baking Company for 1933, shows consolidated net income of $4.546.203 after all deductions, equal to $2.51 a share on 1,792,366 common shares after preferred dividends were paid. In 1932, on a comparative basis, net income was $2,441,089, or $1.34 a share.

From the pulpit of Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church, one of the few churches in the Times Square area, the Rev. Joseph A. McCaffrey, Police Department chaplain, began yesterday a campaign of protest against nudity and immorality in the city's amusement centre.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 11. -- Ice conditions along the New England coast are without precedent since the region was settled, and even with today's slightly higher temperatures, a large part of the shore was still ice-locked after ten subzero days.

Mrs. Anne R. Pettebone and Arthur Bowie, heads of teachers' organizations, attacked the LaGuardia Economy Bill in their addresses yesterday over WOR. The program on which they spoke was sponsored by the Joint Committee of Teachers' Organizations.

ALBANY, Feb. 11. -- The LaGuardia Economy Bill appeared tonight to be facing another week of delay, but there was a disposition at the Capitol to expect surprise developments in the strife within the Democratic party over the measure.
Conditions to govern the races for the America's Cup, as agreed upon by the Royal Yacht Squadron and the New York Yacht Club are as follows:

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Hans Lange, concluded its concert yesterday after noon with Brahms's second piano concerto. Vladimir Horowitz was the soloist. The other works of the program, the Haydn symphony in A major, the adagio from Bruckner's string quintet in F major and Ernest Bloch's very early poems for orchestra, "Winter-Spring," were repeated from recent concerts.

" Carolina," an adaptation of Paul Green's play, "The House of Connelly," will open at the Radio City Music Hall on Thursday. The principals include Lionel Barrymore, Janet Gaynor, Robert Young, Henrietta Crosman and Richard Cromwell.

VIENNA, Feb. 11. -- Austria's case against Germany has now been completely drawn up. The material is being printed and when it is ready it will be sent to Geneva with the government's formal application for intervention by the League of Nations.

The average of wholesale commodity prices compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics made last week its sixth consecutive advance and reached the highest level since 1931. It now tops by a margin of three points the figure for midsummer of last year, when speculative activity in some of the commodity markets was at its height.

MUNICH, Feb. 11. -- The shots fired in the night two weeks ago at the palace of Cardinal Michael von Faulhaber, Archbishop of Munich and Freising and Germany's most prominent prince of the Catholic church, have reverberated throughout the Reich and the world.

The proposed Mortgage Authority contemplated by the bill introduced in the Legislature last week by Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Orange County would save mortgage and certificate holders who have invested $2,500,000,000 approximately $25,000,000 at a cost of only $1,000,000 to maintain the Authority, according to Harold G. Aron, attorney.

CLARKSDALE, Miss., Feb. 11 (AP). -- About 400 National Guardsmen were mobilized in Mississippi tonight for duty tomorrow at Hernando, where mob violence has been threatened against three Negroes upon their appearance before the grand jury on charges of attacking a 17-year-old white girl.
DUBLIN, Feb. 11. -- Troops rushed from this city had to use tear gas to disperse fighting factions at Dundalk in County Louth after rioting there and in Drogheda over the week-end.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 11. -- Trading on the cotton-contract market here last week was active and prices moved upward rather sharply to the highest level of the season. All the trading months went above the 12-cent line and the new crop positions advanced to within striking distance of 13 cents a pound.

Last week carried further the gradual upturn of the business cycle. Steel output, though still only 38 per cent of capacity, compared with 17 a year ago. Railway freight loadings went 16 per cent above last February. Stock market prices fell back on the introduction of the regulatory bill at Washington, but not until the "averages" had passed the highest of last July.

The average American citizen's support of "obscene, salacious and nasty" publications, novels, plays and motion pictures endangers the morals of youth and is "a reflection on the mind and character of the American people," the Rev. Thomas L. Graham declared yesterday at high mass in St, Patrick's Cathedral.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- The Department of Justice tonight disclosed in the matter-of-fact report of its investigators how it had trailed Basil Hugh Banghart.

BOSTON, Feb. 11. -- Beekman Pool of New York, the defending champion, survived the semi-final round of the national squash racquets tournament after a terrific five-game duel with Donald Strachan of Philadelphia today.

BOGOTA, Feb. 11 (AP). -- Alfonso Lopez, Liberal leader who favors a peaceful solution of the Leticia controversy with Peru, today was conceded to have been elected President of Colombia in nation-wide elections. His only opponent was an Indian farmer, Estiquio Timote, the Communist candidate.

Passage in the Senate shortly of the game conservation measures which last week were favorably acted upon by the House is expected. The measures are the migratory bird sanctuary bill, which provides for the duck stamp tax, and the coordination bill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- The work of the more than 300,000 young men who are enlisted in the Civilian Conservation Corps will prove of "inestimable value to future generations" of Americans, Robert Fechner, the director, said in a report today to President Roosevelt.

Even if the New York Americans fail to make a play-off berth in the National Hockey League they will finish the season with a championship. They sealed their claim to the local big league title last night by administering a 4-3 defeat to the Rangers before one of the largest crowds ever to witness a hockey game in Madison Square Garden.

BOSTON, Feb. 11. -- A highly organized gang of criminals, including gunmen, politicians and policemen, is operating in territory between Boston, Providence and Stafford Springs, Conn., James E. Baum of New York, deputy manager of the protective department of the American Bankers Association, asserted here today after attending a meeting of representatives of State banking associations and the "Secret Six" of Needham.

Victory by the score of 6 1/2 - 1 1/2 rewarded the efforts of the players representing the Manhattan Chess Club in the second round of the Metropolitan League series at the Manhattan rooms yesterday. They defeated the team from the Stuyvesant Chess Club.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11. -- Prospects of Congressional action to regulate security exchanges have affected commodity markets also, especially those that are linked closely with farming operations. Many operators on the Board of Trade here attribute to this uneasiness last week's losses of 1 1/8 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel in wheat, 1 cent in corn, 1 3/8 to 1 5/8 cents in oats, 2 1/8 cents in rye and 2 5/8 cents in barley.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP). -- The two houses of Congress, at odds over the $950,000,000 Civil Works-Relief Bill sent them by President Roosevelt, are expected to compose their differences and approve the measure early this week.

LAST Spring Julia Newberry, a Chicago girl of the Sixties and the Seventies, walked sedately out of the attic trunk and into the fluttering hearts of a modern public with the posthumous publication of "Julia Newberry's Diary." Julia's father, Walter Loomis Newberry, was one of America's "smart men," and had grown rich by his foresight in picking Chicago real estate.

Reports in political circles that the State Title and Mortgage Company had received loans totaling $4,750,000 from the RFC, and that the loans had been negotiated by former Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee, were confirmed yesterday by Mr. McKee.

Praising Ogden L. Mills and denouncing Father Coughlin, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, in his sermon yesterday at Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, urged "more common sense and less intelligentsia" as America's need.
THE boxing situation is still muddled, but at least it is getting funnier. That's an improvement. For some time previous the area around the ring had been shrouded in deep gloom.

In a stirring competition, in which she was pitted against some of the greatest wire-haired fox-terriers in the country, Champion Leading Lady of Wildoaks scored a memorable victory yesterday at the exhibition of the American Fox-terrier Club in the roof garden of the Pennsylvania Hotel.

LAST Spring Julia Newberry, a Chicago girl of the Sixties and the Seventies, walked sedately out of the attic trunk and into the fluttering hearts of a modern public with the posthumous publication of "Julia Newberry's Diary." Julia's father, Walter Loomis Newberry, was one of America's "smart men," and had grown rich by his foresight in picking Chicago real estate.

Reports in political circles that the State Title and Mortgage Company had received loans totaling $4,750,000 from the RFC, and that the loans had been negotiated by former Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee, were confirmed yesterday by Mr. McKee.

In a stirring competition, in which she was pitted against some of the greatest wire-haired fox-terriers in the country, Champion Leading Lady of Wildoaks scored a memorable victory yesterday at the exhibition of the American Fox-terrier Club in the roof garden of the Pennsylvania Hotel.

The two Brooklyn laundries closed by Mayor LaGuardia last week for failure to pay their arrears of water taxes were permitted to reopen yesterday when they paid a total of $3,800 in payments on their back taxes.

VIENNA, Tuesday, Feb. 13. -- Socialism has lost its last European citadel, and it was a real stronghold -- the fourth capital in Europe. The green and white flag of the Fascist Heimwehr now flies over the Rathaus, where Sunday the red and white flag of Austria waved.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Feb. 12. -- Papers today say, "What would Lincoln do today?"
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- William P. MacCracken Jr. was a prisoner of the Senate Sergeant-at-Arms Chesley W. Jurney, tonight in Room 206 of the Willard Hotel.

Mayor LAGUARDIA'S suggestion that charter revision and proportional representation be submitted to the voters as separate proposals is sensible. Opposition to any attempt to give the city a new charter worthy of its historic liberties and adequate to its present-day needs will inevitably be powerful.

Three statements attributed to Hospital Commissioner S.S. Goldwater which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Saturday were in error, the commissioner explained yesterday. For one of these Dr. Goldwater assumed responsibility. He had reported that transactions at the community store at the Municipal Sanitarium at Otisville, N.Y., amounted to about $70,000 a year and that the store had a payroll of about $15,000 a year.

VIENNA, Feb. 12. -- The centres of Socialist resistance against the government forces in the present fighting are huge municipal dwelling blocks, constructed by the Socialist regime and inhabited mostly by organized Social Democrats.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 12. -- Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., 19-year-old Kentucky titleholder, tied Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City, the defending champion, for the qualifying medal in the women's championship of Florida on the course of the Palm Beach Country Club today.

BERLIN, Feb. 12. -- Whatever may be happening elsewhere in this troubled Europe just now, German official quarters were wholly preoccupied tonight in following the drift of the Austrian crisis. The developments in France temporarily have dropped to a secondary place in the news, but it may be the wish of the Wilhelmstrasse that such news should not be overemphasized to the embarrassment of the new French Cabinet.

More than 400 alumnae of Barnard College returned yesterday afternoon to their college campus for the annual alumnae day program. The returning graduates attended the annual alumnae luncheon and were guests at the tea of Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve.

LONDON, Feb. 6 (By Mail). -- The toothbrush is dismissed as of small importance in preventing decay, and cereals and lack of sun are blamed for the bad teeth of civilized people, in a report of the Medical Research Council.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 13. -- Andre d'Olivier, a representative of the French National Association for Economic Expansion, who has been in Manchukuo several months investigating markets, has concluded a draft agreement with the South Manchuria Railway.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- President Roosevelt conferred with Governor Pearson of the Virgin Islands, visited the Lincoln Memorial with Mrs. Roosevelt and entertained at a State dinner and musicale.

It is pleasant to learn that Mayor LAGUARDIA has virtually solved all his problems and that the city's troubles are at an end. The budget problem, the subway problem, the prison problem, the school problem, the markets problem, the Triborough Bridge problem, the slum clearance problems -- they must all be disposed of and out of the way.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Chief attention is being given to the New York market in the Treasury's investigation of speculative holdings of silver, Secretary Morgenthau said today. While holders of silver "are being followed up wherever they are," Mr. Morgenthau explained, the Treasury is particularly concerned with the country's principal market in New York City.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- The government will operate fourteen air-mail routes starting at midnight next Monday instead of the twenty-six now flown by mail contractors, Postmaster General Farley announced today. The lines selected as of primary necessity total 11,106 miles, less than half of the 27,079 miles now in operation.

The Beethoven Association, as if bent on heaping many riches on the plate of a single evening, last night presented its audience in the Town Hall with Myra Hess, pianist, Lotte Lehmann, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Association; Mishel Piastro, concert master of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, and Felix Salmond, 'cellist.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 12. -- Mrs. Payne Whitney's Florida Derby eligible, Nights End, a gelded son of Bunting, was a driving winner of the featured race at Hialeah Park today through heavy footing.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 12. -- A pledge made twenty-three years ago by three East Orange men to hold each year until the end of their lives a memorial service here on Feb. 12 for Abraham Lincoln was carried out today by the sole survivor of the trio, David L. Pierson, East Orange historian.

BERLIN, Feb. 12. -- The Boerse was so inactive today that no importance attached to stock-price movements, which within moderate limits, were predominantly upward. Issues in which some interest was manifested included Hoesch, Rheinstahl, Siemens Haelske and some specialties like Tietz and Berlin Machinery.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 12. -- With Lank Seibert scoring 15 points, the Princeton basketball team defeated Cornell tonight, 33 to 25, in an Eastern League game.

PARIS, Feb. 12. -- The French struck their expected blow in the tariff war with Britain today by announcing the denunciation of the Franco-British trade and maritime treaties of 1926 and 1882. The denunciation takes effect at midnight tonight, but three months must elapse before the treaties lose their force.
VIENNA, Tuesday, Feb. 13. -- A condition of civil war exists today in many parts of Austria. Scores of persons have been killed and hundreds wounded.

TRENTON, Feb. 12. -- Action was deferred for one week by the Legislature tonight on the pending municipal bond, budget and debt refunding bills to give the State League of Municipalities, the State Chamber of Commerce and the State Taxpayers Association an opportunity to write their respective views into one measure.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12. -- Sweeping through with a flurry of baskets in the last half, Notre Dame defeated Temple at Convention Hall tonight, 42 to 33, before a crowd of 6,000 wildly excited basketball followers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Two new note issues of $400,000,000 each to be dated Feb. 19 were announced by Secretary Morgenthau today as the second phase of the government's program of raising about $10,000,000,000 prior to June 30.

New York money market closed for holiday. Last week's closing rates: Call money, 1 per cent on the Stock Exchange; sixty-day time loans, 3/4 1 per cent; good three to four months' commercial paper, 1 1/4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Authority to borrow $12,000,000 from the Public Works Administration was granted to the Southern Pacific Railroad Company today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The proceeds will be used to finance a comprehensive maintenance program in which the road expects to spend $9,053,375 for materials and $4,917,360 for labor.

Station WNEW, the latest addition to the ranks of metropolitan broadcasters, opens tonight at 8 o'clock. President Roosevelt has been invited to press a button in his study in the White House at 9 P.M., which will illuminate a lamp at the transmitter in Carlstadt. N.J. Following the signal from Washington, Yvonne D'Arle, soprano, will sing "The Star-Spangled Banner," and Governor , A. Harry Moore of New Jersey will deliver an address of welcome.

The Penn quintet had little trouble in routing Columbia on the Lion's court last night and by means of a 31-to-15 victory over the New Yorkers vaulted into undisputed possession of first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League. Tied with Yale at the opening whistle, the Red and Blue broke away from its deadlock with the Elis when the gun signaled the termination of hostilities.

A victory in the final event, the mile relay, enabled St. Augustine's High to finish in a tie with Manhattan Prep for the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association senior indoor track and field championship yesterday at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Feb. 7 shows an increase for the week of $61,000,000 in United States Government securities, offset by decreases of $51,000,000 in other securities and $49,000,000 in loans; also increases of $34,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $12,000,000 in net demand and time deposits and $13,000,000 in government deposits.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 12. -- Mayor LaGuardia has indicated his willingness to accept a series of amendments to his emergency economy bill. These amendments include one which would eliminate from the measure a clause giving the Board of Estimate power during the emergency to order payless furloughs or salary cuts in the case of teachers and other employes of the New York City Department of Education, reserving that power to the Legislature through direct action.

MALONE, N.Y., Feb. 11 (AP). -- A four-line advertisement in The Malone Telegram has revived interest in the North Country's most thrilling murder mystery, the slaying of Orrando P. Dexter, wealthy and eccentric recluse, thirty-one years ago. The advertisement read:

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 12. -- High praise of Jockey Club administration of racing in New York State was cited in the annual report of Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn submitted to Governor Lehman and the Legislature tonight.

A popular illustion developed during the 1920 decade as to the duties of a bank. The public apparently came to the conclusion that a bank had a double duty: First, to pay its depositors promptly on demand, and, second, to lend out money to almost any applicant upon request.

The NRA and other recovery measures adopted since last March already have increased the purchasing power of the nation nearly $3,000,000,000 and have helped to restore about 4,000,000 men and women to jobs, in addition to those engaged on Civil Works projects, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins told the Institute of Arts and Sciences of Columbia University last night in the McMillin Theatre, Broadway and 116th Street.

ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- Two of Governor Lehman's minor budget bills were passed tonight by the Assembly. One appropriates $8,199,350 from bond money for permanent State improvements, and the other appropriates $3,000,000 for State hospitals. The Assembly last week passed the main budget bill.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Feb. 12. -- Liberation of the Republican party to free it from the domination of selfish interests was called for tonight by W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the State committee. Mr. Macy, who announced recently that he would be a candidate for re-election, spoke at the annual Lincoln dinner of the Grant Republican Club.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 12. -- Sandy-haired Otter Satre gave another beautiful demonstration of his ski-jumping ability today to score his second victory in as many days.
Mayor LaGuardia moved yesterday to include direct cash payments to the needy in the scheme of the city's unemployment relief program, holding that cash as well as food and clothing was necessary.

A resolution charging that the regulations of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board have caused "an imminent peril" to the existence of many of the city's 5,000 drug stores was unanimously adopted last night at a meeting of pharmacists.
Willie Hoppe of New York last night remained one of the two unbeaten players in the world's three-cushion billiard championship as the tourney entered on its second week at the Capitol Academy.
STRANGE rumors are being heard in Soviet Flatbush, where Comrade Carey has been doing his best to put over the Pennant-Piatiletka (Five-Year Pennant Plan) with Ebbets Field as his base of operations.
THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 30, in an article entitled "Baha'i Marriage for Miss Nadeau," reported that "Mr. Sohrab is a Persian scholar and one of the originators of the Baha'i movement."

About 115 Boy Scouts from the metropolitan area took part yesterday in a press conference sponsored by the Manhattan and Brooklyn Boy Scout Press Clubs and held at THE NEW YORK TIMES Annex, 229 West Forty-third Street. The purpose of the conference was to awaken interest in the establishment of Boy Scout press clubs.

SHERMAN, Texas, Feb. 12. -- A three-judge Federal court here today ruled that oil refining companies which have not signed the code and which engage only in intrastate business are not subject to NRA penalties.
PARIS, Feb. 12. -- Evidence that Premier Gaston Doumergue's hope for political appeasement is doomed to disappointment continues to pile up.

The University of Pennsylvania scored victories in both swimming and water polo over City College yesterday in their Intercollegiate Swimming Association meet at the C.C.N.Y. pool. The visitors won the swim meet, 48 to 23, and the water polo game by 21 to 11. They also set a pool record in winning the relay.
Rockefeller Center canceled its $21,005 investment in a fresco by Diego Rivera by destroying the offending mural over the week-end.

LITTLE AMERICA, Antarctica, Feb. 12 (Via Mackay Radio). -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, now on an exploration trip in the barkentine Bear of Oakland, Captain Robert A.J. English commanding, hopes to penetrate into the geographical mystery to eastward, which has twelve times eluded his assaults by ship and airplane.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 12. -- Coming soon after the seventh Pan-American Conference at Montevideo, the first conference of South American Chambers of Commerce, now in session at Valparaiso, promises to be the melting pot into which the Latin-American republics will cast their trade antagonisms in a serious endeavor to reach a practical understanding for the development of international commerce.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12. -- Denouncing "spineless men and weak-minded women" who would be lenient with criminals, Judge Harry S. McDevitt today sent William Sutton, bank robber and escaped Sing Sing convict, to prison for twenty-five to fifty years. The judge "promised" Sutton that further proceedings pending against him would mean a life sentence.

The New York Trust Company has leased 35,000 square feet of space on the ninth floor of the Port Authority Commerce Building at Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street. The activities of several departments, such as printing, purchasing, office supplies and records, now conducted on four floors of another structure, will be concentrated in the terminal space, which will give 3,000 square feet more than the old quarters.

International cooperative measures to increase world trade and to restore world prosperity were urged last night by leaders in business and industry here and abroad at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 12. -- The cotton market here was active today, although all the other leading domestic markets were closed for the Lincoln holiday. Prices advanced to new high levels for the season and at the top showed gains of a dollar a bale from Saturday's close.

PARIS, Feb. 12. -- Elie Sacazan, a banker who is alleged to have swindled French investors out of hundreds of millions of francs, was arrested at Beirut, Syria, today on a warrant issued by the Ministry of Justice.

WARSAW, Feb. 12. -- Foreign Minister and Mme. Beck left for Moscow this morning. Officially the visit is to repay former Foreign Commissar Tchitcherin's visit to Warsaw nine years ago, but the time chosen for the trip is to demonstrate that the recent Polish-German rapprochement in no way affects the Polish-Russian friendship.

WINNIPEG, Feb. 12 (Canadian Press). -- Buying near the end of trading today on the Grain Exchange here by houses with Continental connections ran wheat prices up 1/4 to 3/8 cent a bushel from Saturday's close. A small export business was reported worked out of Vancouver, but the movement failed to be reflected in pit operations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Reports in NRA circles today indicated that when the conference of code authorities and trade associations begins here, on March 5, the nation's industries will be urged to reduce hours by 10 per cent, if it is possible, and increase wage rates accordingly.
DUNEDIN, N.Z., Feb. 12 (By Wireless). -- The research ship Discovery II is leaving here Wednesday with a physician who will join the staff of Admiral Richard E. Byrd's expedition at Little America.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- A decline in large salaries paid to executives and other officers of public utility corporations was revealed today when the Federal Power Commission submitted a report in answer to a resolution passed by the Senate in May, 1933.

F. Cauchois and A.L. Burns tied for the High-Over-All Cup in the annual competition for the C.J. Winninger Trophy at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. Each finished with the excellent card of 99 out of 100 targets.

Aided by higher temperatures and the holiday, retail trade gave an excellent account of itself here yesterday. Dollar volume ran well ahead of the same day a year ago, with the totals in several departments being the best since the close of the Christmas shopping period.

HERNANDO, Miss., Feb. 12 (AP). -- As an angry crowd of men sought in vain to enter the court house, three Negroes who confessed to criminal assaults on a 17-year-old schoolgirl were sentenced late today to die on the gallows here March 16.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 12. -- Yale's unbeaten swimming team defeated Rutgers in an Intercollegiate Swimming Association meet today, 48 to 23, before an Alumni Day crowd of 2,000. The visitors were first in every event except the 220 and 440-yard free style, which were won by Walter Spence, veteran Scarlet ace.

" I Went to Pit College," the Literary Guild book for March, has nothing to do with advanced formal education. Lauren Gilfillan, the author, went to Smith College for that, and was graduated in 1931. She tried for two months to find a job here.

VIENNA, Feb. 12. -- The struggle which has now resulted in the capture of the Vienna Rathaus and its Socialist occupants and in the dissolution of the Socialist party began in the earliest days of the Austrian Republic.

Leaders of the principal organizations of merchant marine officers were summoned yesterday to a meeting in Washington today at which the status of labor under the proposed code for the shipping industry will be considered. The program remained uncertain last night but in shipping circles it was said that an attempt would be made to bring all groups into a single organization.

WALLA WALLA, Wash., Feb. 12. -- Driving captured guards ahead of them as living shields, fifteen long-term convicts attempted to storm a gate of the State penitentiary here this afternoon in the face of machine gun and rifle fire from the walls.

Any governmental attempt to restrict freedom of thought and expression will be opposed by the people of this country, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, warned in an address yesterday. He said that Americans might find themselves compelled to accept both temporary and permanent solutions of current problems that "may contradict our traditions and even our ideals."

PARIS, Feb. 12. -- France's general strike did not prevent the dollar from continuing its downward path toward gold parity today. The exchange market stayed open, as did the Bourse and all banks, and at the end of the session the dollar was quoted at 15.36 francs against 15.45 on Saturday.

Four major projects, definitely decided upon, form the groundwork for the initial advancement of the national duck-saving program which has been outlined by the President's Committee on Wild Life Restoration. The text of the report has been made public through the Department of Agriculture and the actual start on beginning the projects mentioned soon will take place.
The University of Pennsylvania wrestling team defeated Columbia, 15 -- 13, yesterday, in the Lions' gymnasium in an Alumni Day meet.
" The Shining Hour," by Keith Winter, opens tonight at the Booth Theatre.

A representative form of government no longer exists if without "any reason" air mail contracts may be canceled, Senator Lester J. Dickinson of Iowa declared yesterday at the Lincoln's Birthday luncheon of the New York State Woman's Republican Club in the Hotel Plaza.

The American Federation of Labor will be co-sponsor with the American Jewish Congress in the presentation of "The Case of Civilization Against Hitlerism" on March 7 at Madison Square Garden, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Regulation of copper production by voluntary agreements and the withholding of surplus stocks from the market are proposed in a code of fair competition for the copper industry made public today. The code was submitted by the United States Copper Association, said to represent 95 per cent of the industry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Award of War Department contracts for stoves, inner tubes and tires was investigated today by the Federal grand jury when it resumed its sessions after a three-day recess. Up to today's sessions its inquiries had been directed toward automobile and airplane purchases for the army.

Austin H. MacCormick, Commissioner of Correction, replied yesterday to critics of his work at a luncheon of the Alumni Federation of Columbia University at John Jay Hall. He was introduced by former Commissioner Richard C. Patterson Jr., who spoke in high terms of Commissioner MacCormick's previous career in penology.
In the brief account which ABRAHAM LINCOLN wrote in the third person of his own education he said:

The busiest aviation centre in the metropolitan district yesterday was Mitchel Field, where mechanics were tearing machine guns, seats and everything else detachable from the rear cockpits of Douglas and Curtiss observation planes to convert them into emergency air-mail machines.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Feb. 12. -- After prolonged preparations the High Court at Abo began today the trial of Mary Louise Martin, alias Mary Emma Schul, Latvian, as the leader of twenty-seven persons, including six women, who were arrested in October.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- If high profits have been made by manufacturers of airplanes and airplane engines for the army and navy, that has not been the experience of instrument manufacturers, representatives of two contracting companies told the House Naval Committee today.

LONDON, Feb. 12. -- British shipping interests expect to benefit if President Roosevelt decides to cancel American ocean-mail contracts. The British lines carry the mails from America on a poundage basis, and the assumption here is that cancellation of the American lines' contracts may mean heavier mails and bigger revenues for British ships.

Two singers made first appearances of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday. Richard Crooks scored a success as Alfredo in "La Traviata" in a special non-subscription matinee, with a cast headed by Lucrezia Bori -- who again gave a captivating reading of the title role -- and including Elda Vettori, Philine Falco, Giuseppe de Luca, Angelo Bada, Alfredo Gandolfi, Millo Picco and Paolo Ananian. Mr. Serafin conducted.
VIENNA, Feb. 12. -- Street fighting during a night of terror transformed this gay, good-natured and happy-go-lucky capital tonight into a city of darkness and death.

George S. Kaufman left yesterday for Hollywood by way of Rochester and Buffalo. As far as is known this will be Mr. Kaufman's first visit. He will remain there for only three days, during which time Sam H. Harris, Moss Hart and he will discuss the forthcoming Kaufman-Hart play.

VIENNA, Feb. 12. -- Austria welcomes with special satisfaction the American trip which leading Austrian economists and industrialists have undertaken following the suggestion of the American Minister, George H. Earle.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 12 (AP). -- Lieutenant John H. Murrel faced Miss Blanche Ralls as a witness in his own defense in Federal court today and denied he assaulted her following a night-club party on Oct. 22.

BASLE, Feb. 12. -- The spotlight regarding stabilization has swung from the United States to Great Britain as a result of President Boosevelt's dollar policy, in the view of the big European central banks whose governors held their monthly meeting here today as members of the World Bank board.

The first day of the reduced taxicab rates was marked yesterday by an increase in the number of riders, the vast majority of whom gave the "one-third off" to the drivers in tips, according to a survey made last night.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 12. -- The Paraguayan northern army has established contact with the Bolivians at Fort Cabezon and the southern army has advanced three miles west of Fort Magarinos, according to today's communique from Asuncion.

LONDON, Feb. 12. -- A wide area in England was shrouded in another dense fog today, which further curtailed or halted communications services to Paris and other Continental centres which already were restricted by strikes and disorders.
In the report recently forwarded by Edward A. Filene to President Roosevelt, a recommendation is offered relative to investment counsel. Reference is made to the following:

George Z. Medalie, former United States Attorney, yesterday urged delegates of the Aleph Zadick Aleph, Junior B'nai B'rith, not to attribute every clash and misunderstanding that the Jewish people might have to anti-Semitism.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Economically it would be most unwise for the army or any other government agency to continue permanently to carry the mail. It would also be unwise for reasons other than purely economic -- notably from the standpoint of military preparedness. I may say that I find very little sentiment in favor of continued government operation of air-mail lines either in the House of Representatives or in the Senate.
CHICAGO, Feb. 12. -- The first fully stream-lined train in America glided out of the shops of the Pullman Car and Manufacturing Corporation today and moved slowly up and down a half mile of track.

In a struggle lasting almost three hours, Gregory Mangin of Newark, national indoor tennis champion, defeated Clifford S. Sutter of New Orleans yesterday to win the Heights Casino Challenge Cup for the second successive year.

LONDON, Feb. 12. -- Timber in the process of preparation for use in the deck of T.O.M. Sopwith's America's Cup challenger Endeavour was destroyed by a fire in Howard's timber yards at Southampton today.

Mayor LaGuardia wrote yesterday to Harry Harkness Flagler, president of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, confirming and amplifying his endorsement of the drive for a $500,000 guarantee fund for the next three years of its concerts. The Mayor has been a subscriber during twenty-two of the orchestra's ninety-two years.
Julia Vardo, lyric soprano, and Orrin Bastedo, baritone, will sing at the home of Mrs. John Henry Hammond on Thursday evening.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- For the time being, at least, the Supreme Court will not pass on the validity of the administration's action against gold hoarding. It dismissed today a case carried to the high court by Frederick B. Campbell of New York City, who sought a ruling.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 12 (AP). -- The Register quoted Park A. Findley, superintendent of the State Bureau of Criminal Investigation, tonight as saying that Edward G. Bremer, kidnapped St. Paul banker, was held prisoner on a farm nine miles southwest of Creston, Iowa.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- President Roosevelt would be called upon, under a resolution introduced today by Senator Robinson of Indiana, to inform the Senate whether the administration had made any agreements regarding token payments by war debtors or compacts affecting tariff concessions or trade agreements.
My fondness and respect for a good old-fashioned food will not permit me to leave unchallenged part of THE TIMES editorial "Hog and Hominy."

One of the most powerful ships of her type in the world will be added officially to the navy list Thursday morning when the 10,000-ton, eight-inch cruiser New Orleans is commissioned at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 12. -- Joseph B. Keenan, Assistant Attorney General of the United States in charge of the Federal drive against kidnappers, racketeers and other criminals, declared today the next step contemplated by the government was to "find out who these gangster lawyers are and to what extent they benefit in large fees from huge ransom payments."

Radical reforms in bankruptcy practice here will be recommended at tomorrow's meeting of the New York Board of Trade, 41 Park Row, by the board's committee on bankruptcy, which has completed a two-year study. The committee has found that "rackets" have been developed by persons who make a business of obtaining proxies which enable them to control the election of trustees and the disposition of assets.
WALLA WALLA, Wash., Feb. 12. -- Here is the eye-witness account of H.M. Williams, chief turnkey, who was stabbed in the right knee and back, in today's riot at the Washington State Penitentiary.

The Treasury is offering this week $800,000,000 in new securities. This is the second offer to be made in connection with the large fiscal program announced by the President in his budget message of Jan. 4. The first, which amounted to $1,000,000,000, was divided evenly between thirteen-month notes paying 2 1/2 per cent and seven-month certificates paying 1 1/2.

Ash Wednesday, marking tomorrow the beginning of Lent, will be observed not only in the Roman Catholic, Protestant Episcopal and Lutheran churches but in denominational edifices as well. This will be true of the entire Lenten season.

The exhibition of paintings by French nineteenth-century masters which is being held for the benefit of the Children's Aid Society and the French Hospital of New York (admission $1), opened yesterday at the Durand-Ruel Galleries, where it will remain until March 10.

District Attorney Charles S. Colden of Queens announced yesterday that the grand jury investigating the Fierro murder there would demand from Samuel Seabury and the State Bar Association a statement as to what right the association had to "interfere" with the duties of the grand jury, particularly when the grand jury was under specific directions from the Supreme Court.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Feb. 12. -- Everett Sanders, chairman of the Republican National Committee, at a Lincoln Day dinner this afternoon declared that Lincoln had learned in a national emergency that "only the Constitution stands between the rights and freedom of the people and the tyranny of the few -- or even of one only."

MONTREAL, Feb. 12. -- Asserting that Canada's recovery had proceeded almost wholly without the experiments in government financing and government expenditure which had characterized the recovery program of the United States, Louis Wiley of New York expressed the hope here today that Canada would be first considered in any reciprocal tariffs arranged by Washington.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP). -- Senator Robinson of Arkansas, majority leader, drew a parallel today between President Lincoln and Franklin D. Roosevelt as tribute was paid in the Senate to the memory of the martyred, President.
LONDON, Feb. 12. -- Captain Brymor Eric Miles, chief of the London Salvage Corps, was sentenced today to four years in prison for corruption and "conspiring to pervert the administration of justice."

The Hitler regime in Germany is a recrudescence of the arrogance and "Schrecklichkeit" which brought about the World War, speakers declared at a testimonial luncheon at the Town Hall yesterday in honor of Charles Edward Russell.

ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- Details of a bill providing for a 2 per cent sales tax which, it has been estimated, would bring revenues of $120,000,000 to the State Treasury were made public tonight by Senator Fearon, Republican leader. The bill will be introduced in a few days.

The temple of sport in which the show of the Westminster Kennel Club is now being held offers two spectacles that transport people fond of dogs. There are almost 2,500 entries of seventy-six breeds in the basement, and on the floor above goes on the selection of dogs for prizes by conscientious judges in twelve rings.

More news has developed regarding sea serpents since the report of the one sighted on Jan. 30 by the officers of the Cunarder Mauretania appeared in Sunday's NEW YORK TIMES accompanied by a sketch of the monster.
PARIS, Feb. 12. -- One person was killed and many were injured during shooting and rioting in the provinces today in the nation's general strike.

SPARTANBURG, S.C., Feb. 12 (AP). -- Z.D. Granville, president of the Granville Aircraft Corporation of New York and Springfield, Mass., and designer of racing planes, was injured fatally today as his plane went into a spin above Spartanburg Memorial Airport and crashed from about seventy feet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Strict regulation of commodity exchanges was asked by Secretary Wallace today in presenting to Congress a bill which would outlaw bucketshops, wash sales, cross trades and all other transactions designed to cause a commodity price to be "reported, registered or recorded which is not a true bona fide price."
Two windows in the Savarin Restaurant, in the building of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, were struck by missiles last night during a demonstration of 1,500 hotel strikers.

OSWALD SPENGLER'S dizzying philippic, "The Hour of Decision (Knopf, $2.50), leaves us with the feeling that we have when we stagger from a Wagner opera -- drunk with sound and fury, and in no condition to think. But after the lurid lights and the deep, flashing colors have faded out, and after the sublime orchestration of mood has died away, one comes to feel a little contempt for Spengler.

LONDON, Feb. 12. -- In the view of the British Cabinet, today's events in Austria are most likely to put a new face on the whole European situation that will necessitate modifications of Britain's continental policy.
ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- Bootleg boxing and wrestling have been pretty well eliminated in the State, Secretary of State Flynn declared tonight in his annual report to the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- The $950,000,000 emergency appropriation for the Civil Works Administration and other relief agencies was moved another step toward passage today when the Senate approved a partial conference report on the measure.

VIENNA, Tuesday, Feb. 13. -- Socialists opposing a "Fascist threat in the government" and police and soldiers battled through a night of terror in many parts of Austria as the number of dead was placed early today at 129.
HAVANA, Feb. 12. -- Striking employes of the Compania Cubana de Electricidad returned to their jobs this morning in accordance with the recent decree outlawing strikes until after arbitration.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 12. -- Drawn by a program which includes Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Governor Lehman, hundreds of farmers from all parts of the State came to Cornell University for the twenty-seventh annual Farm and Home Week. With 839 registered this afternoon, indications pointed to a record attendance. Last year the first-day registration was 405.

BOSTON, Feb. 12. -- Reversing the result of the 1933 final, Neil Sullivan of Philadelphia staged a sensational comeback to upset Beekman Pool of New York, the defending champion, in a five-game match which brought to a close the 1934 national squash racquets tournament on the B.A.A. courts today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- The administration today made a direct move toward taking advantage of potential trade with Soviet Russia with the incorporation of the Export-Import Bank of Washington to finance trade between the two countries.

Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association of New York, announced yesterday that the organization had reached the conclusion after a thorough study that the Securities Act of 1933 was seriously interfering with the advancement of business and should be amended speedily by the present Congress.
A cross-section of coaching opinion, covering the nation from one extreme to the other, yesterday registered almost unanimous approval of the 1934 changes in the football rule book.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 12, -- The national airport conference, meeting in connection with the Pan American air races, has passed a resolution calling on the government for continued air mail appropriations for the further development of air mail passenger lines.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 12. -- J.R. Leonard of New York won the annual Tuxedo Gold Racquet tournament today by defeating Huntingdon D. Sheldon, also of New York, in straight games, 15 -- 7, 15 -- 6, 15 -- 3.

Mayor LaGuardia said yesterday that he had agreed with Governor Lehman last Saturday that his Economy Bill must be amended to meet some of the objections raised to it by civil service employes and members of the Legislature.

TRENTON, Feb. 12. -Governor Moore appointed twenty persons today to serve as members of the Grover Cleveland Birthplace Association to maintain the former President's birthplace at Caldwell as a public memorial.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12. -- Farmers are not selling hogs freely. Receipts here today were 30,000 head, the fewest since last September. Estimates for tomorrow are for 19,000. The government bought 6,400 for the day, paying $4.65 to $4.70. The market was 10 to 25 cents higher, with a top of $4.75, compared with $4.40 a week ago.

The New York State Brewers Association in a statement yesterday protested the regulation of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board prohibiting signs advertising beer and liquor brands on the exterior and inside of licensed premises.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 12. -- Three of the four members of the Banghart-Touhy gang arrested here yesterday were held in $60,000 bail each tonight on warrant charges made by the State's attorney, Herbert R. O'Conor. Mrs. Jessie Touhy of Chicago, wife of a brother of Roger Touhy, the fourth, was held in $32,500.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., Feb. 12. -- The Americanism and the efficacy of recovery measures undertaken by the Roosevelt administration were criticized here tonight by Henry P. Fletcher, former Ambassador to Italy, at the Lincoln's Birthday dinner of the Western Maryland Republicans.

Tchaikovsky's opera "Mazeppa" was revived at the Casino Theatre last night by the company which designates itself as "The Art of Musical Russia, Inc.," in conjunction with the Ukrainian Art Theatre, of which Dmitri Chutro is director.

Elimination of 5,000 of the 15,000 taxicabs now operating in New York City, as an essential step toward stabilization of the industry and improvement of wage and working conditions, was urged yesterday by Morris L. Ernst, Mayor LaGuardia's mediator in the recent taxicab strike, at the first of a series of hearings by the National Recovery Administration to set up a code for the industry.

The New Deal of the Roosevelt administration was compared, to its detriment, to the political and economic philosophies of Washington, Jefferson and Lincoln at the forty-eighth annual Lincoln Day dinner of the National Republican Club, held last night at the Waldorf-Astoria.

MUNICH, Feb. 12. -- The National Socialist side in the conflict between the National Socialist State and the Catholic Church was presented in an interview given to the writer by Hans Schemm, Minister of Culture and Education in Bavaria.

ATLANTA, Feb. 12. -- President Roosevelt suggested to the Emory University Institute of Citizenship today that "in considering our problems, the purposes or goals of our democracy should be kept constantly in mind."

The Westminster Kennel Club opened its fifty-eighth annual dog show in Madison Square Garden yesterday with 2,462 dogs benched in the exhibition hall. This was the third largest entry in the history of the premier show-giving organization in the country and fanciers from all over the United States and many foreign countries responded to the appeal of quantity and quality.

The heroism of members of the Police Department who died in service was praised yesterday at the annual high mass of requiem for policemen held in the Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church at 332 West Forty-second Street.

Plans for a gymnasium in the Welfare Island Penitentiary to provide physical exercise for the 85 per cent of the nearly 1,600 prisoners, for whom there is no work, were revealed yesterday by Commissioner of Correction Austin H. MacCormick.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Before it is settled, the legal game of hide-and-seek which Frank J. Hogan is having with the Senate may prove serious for Mr. Hogan's client, William P. MacCracken. It might even prove serious for Mr. Hogan, although it is notable in the annals of jurisprudence that clients, not their lawyers, pay the fines and go to jail.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Senator La Follette read into the record today a letter from Thomas W. Lamont of the firm of J.P. Morgan Co. which denied allegations made by the Wisconsin Senator in a speech on Jan. 30 that "J.P. Morgan Co. and their allied interests are seeking to destroy this administration and are seeking to prevent ratification of the St. Lawrence treaty."

From a study of civil suits in this county made by the New York Law Society it appears that lawyers are the chief delayers of justice in the matter of appeals. The interminable verbosities of records and briefs piled upon Appellate Courts have long been notorious.

Colonel LINDBERGH'S respectful protest to the President against condemning aviation companies without giving them a hearing evidently put nerves at the White House a little on edge. Here was a man who could not be held up to scorn as a mere tool of corrupt and privileged interests.

LEESBURG, Va., Feb. 12 (AP). -- George Crawford, a Negro, already serving a life sentence for the murder of Mrs. Agnes Boeing Ilsley, today pleaded guilty to the murder of her maid, Mrs. Nina Buckner, and again was sentenced to life imprisonment.
Clive Brook and Diana rynyard will be featured in the RKO Radio film production of A. A. Milne's play, "The Dover Road."

The Socialist uprising in Austria must be interpreted in the light of significant developments during the past weeks both within and without Austria, with particular stress to be laid on Chancellor Dollfuss's recent diplomatic negotiations with the great European powers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- More than seventy guests were present at a State dinner given by President and Mrs. Roosevelt at the White House tonight, which was followed by a musicale to which about 200 additional guests were invited. Senator Thomas and Mrs. Thomas headed the list of guests.

ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- Governor Lehman has informed the State Chamber of Commerce that he has no power to appoint a special Attorney General to investigate reports of the sale of narcotics at Welfare Island and other prisons.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 12. -- The Very Rev. Moses E. Kiley, who was appointed today Bishop of Trenton, will succeed the late Bishop John J. McMahon, who died Dec. 31, 1932. It is expected that Mgr. Kiley will be consecrated either in Rome or Somerville, Mass.
Two 8-year-old boys were drowned near Trenton, N.J., and another boy of the same age was drowned at Long Beach, L.I., yesterday when they plunged through thin ice on which they were playing.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12. -- Aiming once again at boxing's highest honor -- the heavyweight championship -- Max Schmeling of Germany tomorrow faces Steve Hamas, aggressive North Jersey youngster, as his first hurdle on the come-back trail.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Indications of another Investigation into War Department activities were reported unofficially tonight to point toward the leasing by the Mercur Corporation of the Port of Newark army supply base in New Jersey.

ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- Factory employment dropped 0.9 per cent, although payrolls increased 0.6 per cent from the middle of December to the middle of January, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, reported today. The State Labor Department's index number of employment fell to 65.6, while the payroll index increased slightly to 51.6 in that period.

With the New York and Chicago markets closed on account of the Lincoln's Birthday observance, the foreign markets and the New Orleans Cotton Exchange were the only sources of information by which financial sentiment could be judged yesterday.

ATLANTA, Feb. 12 (AP). -- Arthur W. Powell, lawyer, today said three men kidnapped him, demanded $10,000 ransom, and left him bound and gagged in a snow-filled gutter Saturday after fighting among themselves.

The Brooklyn Democratic leaders spent two hours behind closed doors yesterday trying to reach an agreement on a successor to the late John H. McCooey as Kings County leader, but their efforts were unsuccessful.

Tomorrow, St. Valentine's Day, in the form of tinsel hearts and darts and doves and little loves, will blossom in the florists' windows. Tomorrow the confiseur and the stationer will trot out their most bizarre, their least salable creations. And words of love (at so much a word) will go rippling out on the telegraph and cable wires, and on the ether itself, tomorrow.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12. -- Joseph H. Hazleton, former actor and writer, recalled today that as the program boy in Ford's Theatre, Washington, he witnessed the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.

ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- A bill to provide a new formula for apportioning State aid to local school districts was introduced in the Legislature tonight by Senator Mastick and Assemblyman Pratt. The bill carries a recommendation of the Tax Revision Commission headed by Senator Mastick, which conducted an investigation of use of State funds for education.

PARIS, Feb. 12. -- France's general strike passed off almost without incident today. Although a good many million workers throughout the country stopped work and public services were halted for periods of between one minute and twenty-four hours there was nothing that could be called revolutionary in the movement.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 12. -- Moving up from novice to senior racing this Winter, Ivan Brown of the Keene Valley Athletic Association drove to victory in the National A.A.U. two-man bob sled championship on the Mount Van Hoevenberg run today.

Samuel Seabury received a bronze medal from the students and faculty of Abraham Lincoln High School, Brooklyn, yesterday for his "distinguished services on behalf of the City of New York." The presentation took place in the school auditorium at Coney Island in the presence of more than 800 students and parents.

Domestic bonds resumed their advance on the Stock Exchange yesterday with many corporation issues up a point or more. The turnover, amounting to $13,529,000, was the smallest for a full five-hour trading day since Jan. 3. United States Government bonds finished generally higher, up 6-32ds to down 5-32ds point.

LONDON, Feb. 13. -- The stock markets were weak and irregular today, the result of Continental disturbances. Austrian and German bonds were dull in the foreign market. British funds opened firm but eased later.
WASHINGTON. Feb. 13. -- In commodity exchange legislation the administration is facing a test of its strength in the Senate.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,284,200 barrels, compared with 2,121,650 in the previous week, an increase of 162,550 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gains of 121,550 barrels in Oklahoma and 26,100 barrels in California were the most important changes.

Resuming business after the extended week-end, most of the markets showed yesterday further nervousness in which there was reflected the anxiety of traders in commodities and security holders over the prospect of Federal regulation.

Three witnesses, including a lawyer, testified in General Sessions yesterday that Felix Solomon, a prominent Tammany politician, obtained $4,000 from one of them in 1929 under promise of having the son of the man who paid let off with a light sentence on a burglary charge.

An offer to settle the strike of the hotel and restaurant workers on the basis of merit of employes and individual applications was submitted yesterday by the Hotel Men's Association to the Amalgamated Hotel and Restaurant Workers Union, the strike organization, through the regional labor board.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- A new policy to govern local trade and service industries of an intrastate character was announced today by General Johnson. Under it local trade and service industries, such as barber shops, laundries, building management, restaurants and local transportation, will be governed either by regional codes or by the President's Re-employment Agreements.

Price movements on local commodity exchanges were irregular yesterday, and the volumes of trading were also uneven. The turnover was large in some markets and small in others. Cash prices were irregular.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 13. -Frederick Carder of Coming, N.Y., art director of the Corning Glass Works, was presented here tonight the Charles Fergus Binns Gold Medal for eminence in artistic achievement during the last year. This is the tenth of the awards, five of which have been won by Americans.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 14 (AP). -- A foggy morning with a partially overcast sky gave Tokyo and most of Japan only a brief glimpse today of the solar eclipse which traced a vast arc over the Pacific Ocean. The eclipse was only partial in Japan.

In seeking support for his Economy Bill Mayor LAGUARDIA has shown willingness to meet honest criticism. When Governor LEHMAN sought to free the measure from all hints of a dictatorship, the Mayor endorsed an amendment lodging the authority to make the emergency bureau changes and salary cuts in the Board of Estimate instead of in his own person.

In divers parts of the country divers old-line Republicans mistook LINCOLN'S Birthday for Constitution Day. The Constitution has been destroyed. The Democratic party has been false to the principles of JEFFERSON. The States have given up their rights. Bureaucracy is swellin' wisibly.

The effect of changing monetary conditions on the funds entrusted to banks throughout this country for widows, orphans and dependants was discussed here yesterday at the mid-winter conference of the trust division ou the American Bankers Conference in the Waldorf-Astoria.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 13 (AP). -- Lieutenant John H. Murrel, former West Point football star, testified today that Miss Blanche Ralls was intoxicated and that he was taking her home to his mother at the time she alleged he assaulted her last Fall.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 13. -- In his first message delivered to a joint legislative session today, Governor Blanton Winship stressed the necessity of government economies, urging that at least $1,000,000 in estimated revenue be unappropriated as a reserve in case of emergency.

BERLIN, Feb. 13. -- Demand for certain specialties gave the Boerse a cheerful tone today, although the more important stocks were neglected and prices therefore moved in a narrow range. Salzdetfurth rose 2 points, I.G. Farben 1 point and Bavarian Motor Works improved more than 3 points.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP). -- In a telegram to all Senators, Colonel Frank Knox, Chicago publisher, said today that opposition to the St. Lawrence waterway "simply reverses the political technique of the pork barrel." He also expressed the belief that Illinois Senators who are against ratification of the treaty with Canada would find their position "repudiated at home."

The adoption of three important changes in the rules of the New York Stock Exchange was announced yesterday by Richard Whitney, president, following a meeting of the governing committee. at the same time Mr. Whitney gave out an interview, his first in more than a year, in which he criticized provisions of the proposed Federal bill regulating exchanges.

Cathedral Boys High yesterday clinched the New York division C.H.S.A.A. basketball title Horace Mann School for Boys made sure of at least a tie for first place in the Eastern Private Schools Basketball League, and Textile, Seward Park and DeWitt Clinton triumphed in P.S.A.L. games.

PARIS, Feb. 13. -- The opinion is expressed throughout the French press that events in Austria are of extreme gravity, not only for the future of that country but for their repercussion on the whole European situation.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 13. -- A petit bon marche, a postoffice, a dog show, under the auspices of the American Kennel Club; a tea house, tea dansant, fashion show, gymkhana and booths, selling food products, pottery and needlecraft articles, were all included in the tombola, annual major production of the Woman's Guild of Bethesda-by-the-Sea held today in the Cluett gardens.

In resentment against the destruction of the Rivera mural in the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center, a group of artists announced yesterday their withdrawal from the Municipal Art Show to be held in Rockefeller Center from Feb. 28 through March.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 13. -- Two nicely executed scores in the second period and another in the third, two of them by Lin Tiers, enabled the Princeton sextet to overcome the St. Nicholas Hockey Club of New York, 3 -- 2, in Baker Memorial Rink tonight.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13. -- A round-by-round description of the Max Schmeling-Steve Hamas bout tonight follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Continuing the trial of William P. MacCracken and his three co-defendants on contempt charges today, the Senate listened to a plea by Frank J. Hogan, Mr. MacCracken's attorney, and then went into executive session for deliberation.
A further explanation of what may be classed as "losses on stock transactions" for income tax return purposes was made public yesterday by the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 13. -- The struggle between the German National Socialist State and the Catholic Church may be described at present as being in that preliminary stage in which the leaders are still negotiating to avoid a conflict which neither side courts but in which the rival armies already are manoeuvring for position and making occasional forays into their opponents' ranks to test the strength of the rival position.

The Rev. Joseph A. McCaffrey, chaplain of the Police Department, advocated in a radio address last night the licensing of book stores as a means of suppressing the sale of obscene literature, and also urged a "reasonable censorship of the press" in matters of morals.
