WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP). -- Cotton consumed during January was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 508,034 running bales of lint and 57,769 bales of linters, compared with 348,393 and 51,624 for December and 470,182 and 55,328 for January last year.

A lease by the Union News Company for another unit in the RKO Building in Rockefeller Center was announced yesterday. This is the company's fifth contract for space in the midtown development and will result in the establishment of a restaurant and oyster bar occupying two shops on the ground floor and a sizable area in the basement of the RKO Building.

Stockholders of three insurance companies, controlled by the Equity Corporation through the Interstate Equities Corporation, have voted to merge. The actual merger now awaits the final approval of the New York State Superintendent of Insurance.

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation has paid off the entire amount of the $8,500,000 bank loans remaining at the end of 1933 and has $15,000,000 cash in its treasury, comparing with $10,000,000 at the close of 1933, it was ascertained yesterday.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Mayor LaGuardia joined last night in a plea for a tightening of the boycott on German goods as the only effective means of protesting against Nazi excesses under Chancellor Hitler.
Lenten services beginning yesterday, which was Ash Wednesday, were attended largely in denominational churches as well as in those of the Roman Catholic, Protestant Episcopal and Lutheran communions.
The Board of Education moved yesterday to eliminate multiple job holding in the public schools by adopting a plan whereby the "necessity" for one person holding an extra position must be certified.

The general roundup of druggists suspected of marketing and manufacturing spurious liquors continued yesterday afternoon by detectives assigned to aid the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board under Commissioner Edward P. Mulrooney.
VIENNA, Feb. 14. -- This is a new Vienna. It has been changed within three days in a manner calculated to make a foreign tourist rub his eyes.

Maybe after we have had enough of depressions and emergencies we may stop laughing at the old maxim that honesty is the best policy and discover that without a reasonable adherence to honesty business as we know it cannot be done. Especially does it become impracticable, without honesty, to some maintain the protection of a strong government, without which business must sink to a crude barter level.
PARIS, Feb. 14. -- The Bank of France statement for the week ending Feb. 9 will show a loss of gold approximating 2,000,000,000 francs, according to a reliable source.

Reports from Washington indicating that there might be formidable opposition to the proposed regulatory legislation for security exchanges stimulated the markets yesterday afternoon. Not only were early losses on the Stock Exchange wiped out, but the recovery carried so far as to raise the average level of prices well above that of the previous day.

As a result of large-scale demands for tinplate and for steel needed in the manufacture of automobiles, operations in the steel industry have risen this week to 41 per cent of capacity, according to The Iron Age's review. This publication predicts further expansion.

All investment security dealers and brokers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut who are subject to the investment bankers code have been invited to attend an informatory meeting in the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, 65 Liberty Street, at 10 A.M. on next Monday to consider the new draft of the proposed fair-practice regulations.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Thursday, Feb. 15. -- Four mongrel dogs, wagging their tails and yelping with joy over their release from barred cells in which they had been confined more than a week, were executed early today with a poisoned needle for their pack attack on Joyce Hammond, 6-year-old school girl.

A running break which carried prices on the Cotton Exchange nearly $2 a bale lower yesterday was followed by a recovery of the early loss, but profit-taking appeared at the close and left the list 5 to 13 points below Tuesday's final quotations.

Booing and hissing as they passed three hotels in the midtown section, 300 striking hotel employes, members of the Amalgamated Hotel and Restaurant Workers Union, paraded last night in the Times Square section during the early theatre rush.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The issue of $800,000,000 of Treasury notes offered yesterday has been subscribed more than four times, the Treasury announced late today. Officials were elated by the success of the offer, split evenly between notes with maturities respectively of three years and twenty-two months.

Obituary notices of Mr. JEROME have given all needed details about his picturesque career as a "raiding" Judge and District attorney. He devised new ways of exposing and prosecuting commercialized vice and gambling in this city. He was a sleepless enemy of racketeering long before we had the word.

Net income of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company jumped from $2,067,886 in 1932 to $6,032,312 in 1933, according to the annual report issued yesterday. The report called attention to increased business as a result of the legalization of beer and the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

Assets of the Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company increased $15,865,490 to $530,453,764, according to a statement covering some of the items in the 1933 balance sheet issued yesterday by William A. Law, president of the company.

By defeating the Yale Club last night, 4 to 1, while the New York Athletic Club was idle, having drawn a bye, the Columbia Club drew on level terms with the Winged Footers in the race for the Class A team championship of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League.

Russell H. Johnson Jr. of Philadelphia was re-elected president of the American Kennel Club at a meeting of the directors held in conjunction with the annual meeting of the club yesterday at its offices.

John T. Collins Jr. has retired from partnership in Samuel McCreery Co. of Philadelphia and with J. Sellers Kite and G. Leslie Carter has formed the John T. Collins Jr. Company to deal in investment securities. The new organization will include the sales and office personnel of the bond and unlisted trading departments of MeCreery Co.

There has been an encouraging subscription for the performance of "The Shining Hour" tomorrow night at the Booth Theatre. The showing has been taken over in behalf of the Yorkville Music School, Several dinners will be given in advance of the performance.

Oscar Shumsky, 21-year-old Philadelphia violinist, played at the Town Hall last evening to a New York audience in which were Efrem Zimbalist, his teacher at Curtis Institute, as well as Harry Kaufman, Ernest Schelling and other musicians.

VIENNA, Thursday, Feb. 15. -- A force of Socialists, estimated at 3,000, compelled to retreat by terrific government cannonading that for three days had contributed its share to a death toll put at 1,000 to 1,500, re-formed its shattered ranks on a high hill south of Vienna last night.

The Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company of Buffalo has obtained the award of a new issue of $340,000 of bonds of Central School District 1 of the towns of Kirkland, New Hartford, Whitestown, Marshall, Westmoreland, Vernon and Paris, N.Y. The bonds, due on Dec. 1, 1934 to 1966, brought a price of 100.15 as 4.60s.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 14. -- The Harvard varsity basketball team was beaten by the Tufts College five on the floor of the new Harvard gymnasium tonight, 49-31. The Tufts aggregation took the upper hand in the first half of the contest and held a lead throughout.
West Point will have an all-Army coaching staff in football this year for the first time since 1927.

A demonstration against the Dollfuss government and Austrian Fascism held jointly by Communists and Socialists in front of the Austrian Consulate office at Forty-second Street and Fifth Avenue late yesterday afternoon resulted in a riot that spread for several blocks along Fifth Avenue, blocked the steps of the Public Library and halted traffic for twenty minutes.
VIENNA, Feb. 14. -- Over the radio as this dispatch is being written a government spokesman is broadcasting a combined proclamation and appeal, saying:
The longest winning streak of the current basketball season ended at twenty games last night when St. John's toppled the hitherto unbeaten Long Island University quintet, 33 to 28.

William R. Maloney, for thirteen years an Assistant District Attorney, was called as a witness yesterday by District Attorney Dodge in the trial of Felix Solomon, prominent Tammany politician in Harlem, for defrauding a man of $4,000 in 1928.

The value of Chambers of Commerce in stimulating trade was stressed yesterday by George S. Messersmith, retiring United States Consul General at Berlin, at a luncheon given in his honor by the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce. The luncheon was held on board the Washington, through the courtesy of the United States Lines.

Dr. and Mrs. Zenas H. Ellis gave a St. Valentine dinner at the Central Park Casino last night to celebrate Dr. Ellis's birthday. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. George Ellis, Dr. and Mrs. John Harris, Mr. and Mrs. Edward McCabe and Dr. Eugene Moyle.

One of two men arrested yesterday morning as robbers was identified later as a man sought in connection with the fatal shooting of John O'Dwyer, brother of Magistrate William O'Dwyer, in a restaurant at 55 Fourth Avenue. Brooklyn, last Jan. 7.

The bill granting the Municipal Housing Authority the power to proceed on a program of slum clearance with a $25,000,000 Federal loan was warmly praised as "essential social reconstruction" and at the same time sharply condemned as "a short-sighted measure" yesterday at a meeting of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The administration's request for $950,000,000 to continue Civil Works operations until May 1 and for other relief purposes was finally granted today when the Senate passed the administration bill. Two moves that would have changed the whole structure of the CWA were rejected.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 14. -- Paraguayan forces captured Fort Cabezon, fifty-one miles west of Fort Platanillos in the disputed Chaco region, at midnight Monday according to a communique from Asuncion today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Efforts of the cotton trade to compose differences over proposed drastic changes in regulations of the New York Cotton Exchange ended tonight with a report to Chairman Smith of the Senate Agriculture Committee that agreement on the most important proposals was impossible.
VIENNA, Feb. 14. -- A great blue automobile crossed the bridge over the Danube near Floridsdorf this morning, passing in silence the military patrols that guarded it.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler took the first step yesterday to appoint trustees for defaulted guaranteed mortgage properties in New York when he held a hearing on an application to name trustees for the $27,000,000 issue of the New York Title and Mortgage Company and urged the certificate holders to suggest the names of persons or institutions to be considered.

The Shippers' Conference of Greater New York declared its opposition yesterday to the proposed transfer of supervision of intercoastal shipping from the Shipping Board to the Interstate Commerce Commission. The action was taken at a monthly meeting at the office of the Merchants' Association.

LONDON, Feb. 14. -- English stars had little difficulty defeating the Americans today at the Queen's Club in the first international women's squash racquets match ever played in England against a team from the United States.

QUEBEC, Feb. 14. -- Net profits of $4,555,968 were reported by the Quebec Liquor Commission for the year ended April 30. This represented a sharp decrease from last year's figures, and was only 50 per cent of the net during the boom years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The period during which direct obligations of the United States may be used as collateral security for Federal Reserve notes would be extended until March 3, 1935, under the terms of an amendment to the Federal Reserve Act introduced in the Senate today by Chairman Fletcher of the Banking and Currency Committee. It was referred to that committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- President Roosevelt was said by Representative McFarlane of Texas today to have agreed to issue instructions for laying before the House naval subcommittee the income tax returns of all persons connected with sales of aircraft to the navy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The period during which direct obligations of the United States may be used as collateral security for Federal Reserve notes would be extended until March 3, 1935, under the terms of an amendment to the Federal Reserve Act introduced in the Senate today by Chairman Fletcher of the Banking and Currency Committee. It was referred to that committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- President Roosevelt was said by Representative McFarlane of Texas today to have agreed to issue instructions for laying before the House naval subcommittee the income tax returns of all persons connected with sales of aircraft to the navy.

Debutantes of this season act as ushers at the concert to be given tomorrow night in the Great Hall of the Junior League of New York by members of the Junior League Glee Club, assisted by a large unit of the Yale Glee Club, under the direction of Marshall Bartholomew.

After dropping to 3 degrees above zero at 8:30 yesterday morning -- only 2 degrees above the low record for any Feb. 14 -- the temperature rose to 20 at 3:30 P.M. Then it started another descent, but turned upward again later in the evening.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Encouraged by a personal message of welcome from President Roosevelt, representatives of Governors from forty-four States began today the formulation of a program of labor legislation which will be acted upon tomorrow, the concluding day of a labor conference called by Secretary Perkins.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- George N. Peek, special adviser to the President on matters of commercial policy, tonight had under favorable consideration an offer from Mr. Roosevelt that he take over the direction of the Export-Import Bank of Washington, recently cremated under Executive order to finance foreign trade.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Postmaster General Farley today explained his reasons for the wholesale cancellation of domestic air mail contracts, with the charge that the law calling for competitive bidding was not carried out and that "the carriers secured contracts based on conspiracy or collusion."

CHICAGO, Feb. 14. -- Subpoenas for sixteen bankers, officials of Insull utility companies and others sought as witnesses in the hearings into charges of collusion in the Insull receiverships were issued today at the request of Samuel Ettelson, the attorney who instigated the inquiry in progress before Judge Walter C. Lindley.

An electric whipping machine for racketeers was suggested yesterday by Judge Joseph E. Corrigan of General Sessions. Addressing a luncheon of the Kiwanis Club attended by 100 at the McAlpin, he also advocated changes in criminal procedure.

Donald Hawley, New York University captain, seeded No. 2, advanced to the semi-finals, a round ahead of the field, as play in the second annual New York State intercollegiate singles tennis championship opened at the 106th Infantry Armory, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Retailers are now awaiting more definite consumer response before increasing their current ready-to-wear orders. Activity this week in either the dress or the coat trade has not been particularly marked, with the continued interest in suits the outstanding exception.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 14. -- Mrs. Floyd West's Cursor scored an easy three-length victory over Joseph Cattarinich's Pharatime in the mile of the Cabildo Purse at the Fair Grounds today. Mrs. A. Van den Ende's Black Peter was two lengths further back in third place.

MOSCOW, Feb. 14. -- The Arctic freighter Chelyuskin sank at 3:30 P.M. yesterday in the Arctic Ocean northwest of the Bering Strait at a point 156 miles from Cape Severny and 144 miles from Cape Wellen.
A neat shot under the basket by Bill Gorman in the final five seconds of the game gave Manhattan College a 16-to-14 victory over the Fordham basketball team last night.

VIENNA, Thursday, Feb. 15. -- Driven from their stronghold in the suburb of Floridsdorf, across the Danube, after the municipal apartments there had capitulated to a terrific bombardment, the main body of Vienna's fighting Socialists retreated southward along the river yesterday evening, took up new positions and held them against the onslaughts of government troops.

The Stock Exchange Bill before Congress, as now proposed, requires that the margin be maintained at 60 per cent of the current market value, or better at all times. Thus if the market declined so that the margin became less than 60 per cent, additional cash or securities must be put up.

The Stock Exchange Bill before Congress, as now proposed, requires that the margin be maintained at 60 per cent of the current market value, or better at all times. Thus if the market declined so that the margin became less than 60 per cent, additional cash or securities must be put up.

A tentative NRA code for the local taxicab industry may be ready for public discussion next week, William L. Allen, Deputy NRA Administrator, indicated yesterday at the close of public hearings extending over two and one-half days.

For all the sawdust, sprinkled beforehand along Mott and Pell Streets yesterday, the two Dragons-Who-Dance-For-Alms had all they could do to look dignified on the icy pavements. One was the On Leong dragon, the other, the Hip Sing dragon, and each was divided into two parts:

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 14. -- One of the closest finishes of the Hialeah Park meeting occurred in the Mariana Purse today when four horses finished noses apart with the Shandon Farm's Minton the winner. Eddie Litzenberger had the leg up on the son of Minton Drop and Aragon and just got him up to score t $10.90 for $2.

LONDON, Feb. 14. -- A combined Laborite and Liberal attempt to force the government to take immediate steps to prohibit the private manufacture of arms was severely defeated in the House of Commons this afternoon by the Conservatives, who, by 175 to 58 votes, adopted a resolution declaring the practical difficulties of such a scheme were too great.

LONDON, Feb. 14. -- The British Government feels about Austria today much as did Palacky, the Czech statesman, when he declared in 1848, paraphrasing a philosopher, that "if Austria did not exist it would be necessary to invent her."

Since 1920 the Keppel Galleries, 16 East Fifty-seventh Street, have presented, once each season, an exhibition of "Modern Prints." The fourteenth annual one is now in progress, its material equally divided between the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.

HARRISON, N.Y., Feb. 14. -- Supervisor Benjamin I. Taylor was engaged today in organizing a committee of six taxpayers to conduct an independent audit of the books of the town of Harrison, of which Mr. Taylor is the chief executive.

The screen of the Strand may be as near as most of us will ever get to Rangoon; if it is, "Mandalay" will make an adequate vicarious substitute. In the new film they have set the sultry' picturesqueness of the East down on the screen so neatly that a New Yorker is tempted to throw his overcoat and earmuffs away, and cut a bee-line through the opium smoke to Nick's.

If Napoleon had flourished in biblical times he probably would not have rated one line in the Bible, Dr. Nelson Glueck, Professor of the Bible at Hebrew Union College, Cincinnati, told a gathering of archaeologists last night at a dinner in his honor at the Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street, on the eve of his departure for Palestine to conduct an archaeological survey of Transjordan.

Mme, Marcella Sembrich, the famous coloratura soprano, who sang in the Metropolitan Opera House's opening week in 1883, observes her seventy-sixth birthday today. She will not allow the occasion to interfere with her plans for the day, which include lessons to a young dramatic soprano, a contralto and a tenor, and there will be no celebration.

Opposition to the Fletcher-Rayburn bill to regulate securities markets was being organized rapidly yesterday in many cities under the leadership of Wall Street wire houses. These Stock Exchange firms, which have branch offices in all large cities, were preparing to marshal public sentiment against the bill by informing persons how business and finance could be affected by passage of the measure.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- President Roosevelt became a sightseer today to inspect with a small boy's enthusiasm the streamline train developed by the Union Pacific Railroad which was parked for the day at Union Station.

Prices of bonds were bid up spiritedly yesterday on the Stock Exchange with issues of all descriptions generally participating in the rise. Total transactions in the listed market were the largest in several days, amounting to $22,689,700. Many domestic corporation bonds were up fractionally to a maximum of more than 7 points, and many foreign loans gained a point or more on the day.
LONDON, Feb. 15 (AP) . -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- Decreased purchases of light-weight hogs for relief purposes resulted in an easier undertone in the market today, with some sales 10 cents lower than on Wednesday, while heavier kinds and packing sows generally sold at steady prices, with some of the latter bringing 5 to 10 cents advance.

Pigeonholed in the files of the Senate Committee on the Judiciary is a bill (H.R. 5884), enactment of which would facilitate the progress of recovery. It is a measure intended to help insolvent corporations work out reorganization plans, avoiding slow and costly bankruptcy procedure and obstructive tactics on the part of small minority interests.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- Retail sale of newspapers, but not newspaper advertising, is exempt from the levy of a 2 per cent tax on gross receipts from retail sales of tangible personal property or some services, provided for in a bill introduced yesterday by Senator Fearon, Republican leader.

The challenge of Soviet Russia will compel the United States to abandon individualism for social control and economic planning, according to Professor Rexford G. Tugwell of Columbia University, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture and chief planner of the Roosevelt brain trust, and Professor Howard C. Hill of the University of Chicago.

Nathan Burkan, chairman of the Triborough Bridge Authority, signed yesterday a requisition for $1,500,000 of Federal Public Works Administration funds, to be spent for construction work on the bridge, payrolls and a parkway link in Queens that will serve as a bridge approach.

Expansion of stock brokerage firms in mid-Manhattan was marked further yesterday by a lease in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center, to J.S. Bache Co. for a new branch office. The firm now has a branch in the Chrysler Building. James Felt Co. arranged the new lease.

The Eastern Railroad presidents' conference authorized yesterday the appointment of two committees to study respectively the Dill-Crosser Bill for compulsory arbitration of railway labor disputes and the Barkley-Crosser Bill for railway signal inspection by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Joe Mangan of Cornell will make his first start in a two-mile race in New York tomorrow night, when he will compete against a strong field in the New York A.C. games at Madison Square Garden.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer ends a long period of indecision by announcing that Jeanette MacDonald will appear with Maurice Chevalier in the forthcoming production of "The Merry Widow." Ernst Lubitsch, who will direct it, plans to begin camera work in the next two weeks.

BOSTON, Feb. 15 (AP). -- After dropping a two-goal lead, the Boston Bruins checked the wild scoring drive of the Montreal Maroons and battled them to a 4-4 overtime tie tonight before a scant crowd of 3,500 at the Boston Garden.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States reports that at the close of 1933 total assets were $1,520,767,379, a gain of $49,010,372 in the year. Holdings of United States Government bonds were $96,910,342, an increase of $84,887,663.
The State Transit Commission made public yesterday its annual report to the Governor and the Legislature, listing its activities for the year ended Dec. 31, 1933.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 15. -The appointment of Adam Walsh, captain of Notre Dame's famous "Four Horsemen" eleven in 1924; Myles Lane, former Dartmouth all-around athlete, and Wesley Fesler, Ohio State's brilliant athlete, as assistant varsity football coaches at Harvard, was announced tonight by William J. Bingham, director of athletics.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- On his annual visit to Farm and Home Week at Cornell University tonight, Governor Lehman presented the master farmer awards before an audience which included Mrs Franklin D. Roosevelt and Mrs Henry Morgenthau Jr.

Catherine Breshkovsky, "the Little Grandmother of the Russian Revolution," has just had her ninetieth birthday. A nobleman's daughter, she early espoused the cause of the people and passed many years in prison and in exile. When the revolution broke out. she was brought home from Siberia in triumph.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 15. -- Thrills which were not on the official program accompanied three speed contests and a series of parachute jumps which were presented today as the second day's offering of the Pan-American air races at the Shushan Airport.

Indoor polo has set in motion the plans leading up to its climax for this season, the new East-West matches, which will take the place of the national championship. Thomas Brady, chairman of the handicap committee, issued a call yesterday for the regular February handicap meeting to be held next Monday.

George H. Earle 3d, United States Minister to Austria, sailed yesterday on the United States liner Washington for Vienna after hurriedly canceling plans for a longer leave here, to return to his post and rejoin his family.

BERLIN, Feb. 15. -- The upward movement of the Boerse continued at the opening today, but publication of a deficit trade balance for January caused a reaction which brought closing quotations down to approximately yesterday's levels.

Abraham Kaplan, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission and manager of Mayor O'Brien's campaign, sent his resignation to Mayor LaGuardia yesterday. The Mayor immediately named James E. Finegan of Brooklyn to succeed him.
ROME, Feb. 15. -- Italy regards the conflict in Austria as a purely domestic affair and intends to follow a "hands-off" policy, unless some other power intervenes.

GALVESTON, Texas, Feb. 15. -- Horton Smith, Oak Park, Ill., professional, and Johnny Dawson, Chicago amateur ace, won the amateur-pro event today in the preliminary round of the $2,000 Galveston open with 33, 82 -- 65, seven under par.

HAVANA, Feb. 15. -- Three men were killed and three wounded this afternoon when unidentified assailants opened fire with a machine gun and sawed-off shotguns on an automobile in which material witnesses and prisoners were being taken to a trial in connection with the assassination of the three Freyre de Andrade brothers during the Machado regime.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15 (AP). -- Jail bars tonight separated a newly wed couple here, thwarting plans for an airplane honeymoon trip to Havana.

With the stock market running on a 3,000,000-share schedule again, Wall Street was in a happier frame of mind yesterday. No one conceded the possibility that the drastic regulations which have been proposed in Congress will be defeated, but there was a widespread belief that the measures would be examined realistically and without any purpose of interfering with the essential processes of the capital market.
The reply of Walter F. Brown, former Postmaster General, to charges of collusion in connection with air-mail contracts is as follows:

The climax of the Beethoven cycle and of Mr. Toscanini's interpretation of Beethoven's works came with the concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, the Schola Cantorum and a quartet of distinguished soloists last night in Carnegie Hall.

About 5,000 CWA workers and representatives of organizations of the unemployed marched yesterday in protest against any curtailment of CWA activities. The parade included Socialists, Communists and many not in either party.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- City Manager John F. Donovan handed his resignation to the city counsel at a committee of the whole meeting this afternoon as the committee was about to consider a resolution for his removal.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade failed today to reflect the strength and activity in stocks and other commodities in general. Wheat held within a range of about 1/2 cent, with most trading between 90 3/4 and 91 1/8 cents for May. Offerings increased above the latter figure, while dips below it brought buying orders.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 15. -- The first step toward the creation of a new system of "prize fellowships" at Harvard College for students of "rare ability and promise" was announced tonight at University Hall by President Conant, following approval by the Harvard Corporation.

HENDERSON, N.C., Feb. 15 (AP). -- Two Staten Island women were killed, and Mayor George P. Dowling of Audubon, N.J., and his wife and daughter, Mrs. Robert Kirland of Philadelphia, were injured in an automobile collision in Vance County last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Workers on civil works projects throughout the country were assured of receiving their pay at the close of this week when President Roosevelt signed tonight the $950,000,000 appropriation providing an additional $350,000,000 for the CWA and $600,000,000 for the continuation of direct Federal relief work.

The mind insists on exploring all the possibilities when the United States Army starts carrying the air mails. Will there be a special division in the inspector general's office for reading postcards?

The New York Stock Exchange made public yesterday a list of 259 companies that have notified the Exchange of the number of their own shares they have acquired and are holding in their treasuries. Approximately 800 companies have stocks listed on the Exchange.

PARIS, Feb. 15. -- Premier Gaston Doumergue in the Chamber of Deputies today, with the authority of simplicity and good sense, put an end, for a time at least, to the Parisian strife and assured France an authoritative government for some time to come.
PARIS, Feb. 15. -- The Bank of France statement for the week ending Feb. 9, published today, indicates that France paid out about 3,300,000,000 francs in gold in the first ten days of this month.

A quick turnover of a Bronx housing property was made yesterday by Benjamin Winter, operator, who resold the six-story elevator apartment house at 1,220 Seneca Avenue. Mr. Winter bought the property ten days ago from the West Side Savings Bank and has now disposed of it to an investing client of the legal firm of Hannon Evans.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- The action of the British Government in imposing new duties on French imports in retaliation for French "discrimination'' against British goods was approved by a large majority in the House of Commons today, Only forty-four Laborites and Free-Trade Liberals voted against the new order.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15. -- One of the most startling upsets in women's golf in recent years was recorded in the semi-final round of the annual Florida championship today. Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L.I., metropolitan titleholder and former national champion, was eliminated by a 19-year-old girl who made her first appearance in a major golf tournament last week.

BERLIN, Feb. 15. -- "Within two years Germany will be a monarchy and her ruler will be called the Kaiser of the Germans," in the opinion of one of the shrewdest observers of events in Germany. He is an Anglo-Saxon and a Catholic, with exceptional sources of information, whom it is impossible to identify more closely.
John F. Curry has refused even to consider resigning as leader of Tammany Hall, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Colonel Lindbergh, former Postmaster General Walter F. Brown and officers of air-mail companies whose contracts have been annulled will have an opportunity to state their cases to the House Postoffice and Post Roads Committee before a permanent bill on the re-award of contracts is agreed upon.

That the character of Daisy Miller was suggested to Henry James by the young American girl Julia Newberry, whose diary and sketch-book have recently been discovered and published by Norton, is a theory put forth by Edgar Goodspeed, writing in the current Atlantic Monthly.

Reflecting the heavy gold imports of the last week, the Federal Reserve statement of Wednesday, issued yesterday, shows a gain of $70,238,000 in the total reserves of the System. The item of "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury," which now represents the Reserve System's gold holdings, rose $68,921,000 in the week covered by the report.

VIENNA, Feb. 15. -- This civil war in Vienna has been fought chiefly in the neighborhoods of workingmen's dwellings, inhabited mostly by Socialists. In the defense of these buildings the Socialist women played a considerable part in the actual fighting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Absorbed as this community is in the outcome of the administration's economic and social experiments to effect recovery, there is an influential capital group which each day attempts to relate events abroad with these experiments. In time, whether the national program fails or succeeds, this group will be at the forefront of the planners.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- The wholehearted espousal by Governor Lehman of Mayor LaGuardia's Economy Bill, defeated for the second time by Democratic votes in the Assembly yesterday, has brought the relations between the Governor and the bosses of his own party noticeably close to the breaking point.

What was characterized as the biggest labor demonstration ever staged in New York was promised yesterday by the joint Labor-Socialist Conference on the Austria situation for this afternoon. The leaders expected that 500,000 workers would quit for the day at 3 P.M. and that thousands would march to Madison Square Garden to attend a protest meeting against the Dollfuss regime.
Mayor LaGuardia's threat of payless paydays for the city became an actuality yesterday when 325 employes of the State Transit Commission went without the $35,000 due them.

PARIS, Feb. 15. -- France's new tone in diplomacy following the formation of the national government was well illustrated in the text of the French reply to Berlin in the disarmament discussion, which was handed to Wilhelmstrasse yesterday.

The city of Buffalo, N.Y., will formally advertise today for bids to be opened on Feb. 27 on a new issue of $3,000,000 of work and home relief bonds. The issue will be dated March 15, 1934, and will mature on March 15, 1944. Under the terms of sale, bidders will be asked to name the rate of interest at not to exceed 6 per cent.

IT was early yesterday afternoon and Herb Lewis and Larry Aurie of the Detroit Red Wings had just arrived in town by plane. They were among the players in the Bailey benefit hockey game in Toronto, and they had to fly here to keep their engagement with Joe Simpson's Americans at the Garden last night.

The strike of waiters, cooks and dishwashers in hotels of the city was ended last night with the acceptance by the strikers of terms of settlement worked out by the Regional Labor Board through Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, acting chairman, at conferences with representatives of the Hotel Men's Association.
Thank you for your editorial this morning commending Colonel Lindbergh's dignified protest to President Roosevelt.

People, seemingly intelligent, devote their attention to the "sensational press," to "exciting" novels or even to those movies or "funnies" designed only to pass the time. It must be only "the great people" who do not appreciate the news.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- Baron Georg Franckenstein, Austrian Minister to London, has sent an urgent appeal to Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss, begging him to end the slaughter of civil war and to call off the threatened wholesale executions.

Charley (Chuck) Dressen's signed contract arrived in Secretary Jim Tierney's mail at the Giant offices yesterday, leaving only two of the world's champions still to be heard from. The two are Hank Lieber, outfielder, and Frank Healey, catcher.

The trial to set aside the will of Mrs. Mary E. Blodgett, aged philanthropist, entered its third day yesterday before Surrogate James A. Foley and a jury. A group of relatives and religious institutions have asked the court to invalidate the will on the grounds that Mrs. Blodgett was not mentally capable of making a will and that she was unduly influenced by her physician, Dr. Edgar William White.

Free concerts sponsored by the Department of Education of the State of New York will take place today as follows: Manhattan Concert Band, Public School 126, Edgecombe Avenue at 135th Street, 8 P.M.; Capitol String Quartet, Hamilton Fish Library, 388 East Houston Street, 8:30 P.M.; Empire String Quartet, Library, 201 West 115th Street, 6:45 P.M.; Harlem String Quartet, 135th Street Y.M.C.A., 7 P.M., and University Chamber Trio, Psychiatric Institute, 7 P.M.

Another sharp increase in bank clearings throughout the country was shown in the weekly reports of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., covering results for the period ended Wednesday night. Total clearings at twenty-two leading cities were $4,161,357,000, comparing with $3,566, 791,000 in the same week last year, a jump of 16.7 per cent.

Encouraged by indications that there may be effective opposition to the more objectionable features of the proposed Federal regulation of Exchanges, the markets moved forward yesterday in confident fashion. Stocks, bonds and commodities joined in the upturn.

VIENNA, Feb. 15. -- When your correspondent departed from the Inner City for the battlefield today there was no indication there would be any change from yesterday's scenes of violence and destruction.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Feb. 15 (AP). -- Charles Backus broke under long hours of police questioning tonight and told how he slew his 8-year-old son and stuffed his body through the ice into the Rock River, Joseph Rank, State highway patrolman, announced.

MONTREAL, Feb. 15. -- Howie Morenz, centre and star of the Montreal Canadiens, was back in form tonight. The veteran, slow in regaining his strike after a long absence with an ankle injury, made two goals and an assist as the Flying Frenchmen defeated the Rangers, 5 to 2.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- As a further spur to the recovery program, the administration is considering means by which it may aid industry in obtaining long-term capital during the emergency. The subject was discussed today by President Roosevelt at a conference with Governor Black of the Federal Reserve Board, and one of the suggestions, it is understood, was the advisability of setting up intermediate banks along the lines of the system now functioning for agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Discussion about tax-exempt securities and the failure of the tax bills to provide publicity on all income tax returns marked the second day of debate in the House today. About eleven hours of debate remain before a vote is taken, and it is now certain that the $258,000,000 measure will not be approved before next week.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Increased activity in the commercial paper market featured. The supply was better than it had been and all offerings were quickly absorbed, Banks were good buyers. Discounts remained unchanged on the turnover. Elsewhere, Stock Exchange call loan market, maturity money and acceptances were quiet in tone.

Net income of the Mathieson Alkali Works, Inc., for 1933 totaled $1,224,078, after depreciation, depletion, obsolescence, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent, after dividend requirements on 7 per cent preferred stock, to $1.70 a share on 623,263 no-par shares of common stock outstanding at the end of the year.

VIENNA, Feb. 15. -- The Socialist resistance in Vienna wholly collapsed today. Occasional rifle shots from nervous sentries or from some sniper covered by darkness are still heard tonight. But the field guns no longer thunder. The white flag flies from the huge model housing blocks that only yesterday were strongholds of armed resistance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- President Roosevelt, thanking the Senate for its congratulations upon his birthday, Jan. 20, today sent his assurance that its cooperation in the recovery program meant that the coming years would be "those of confident hope and of definite achievement."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- In an effort to find a plan whereby the Federal Government may assist cities on the verge of bankruptcy, Secretary Morgenthau has asked Professor Simeon D. Leland of the University of Chicago to make a general investigation of the municipal situation.
TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 16. -- The Cabinet finds itself suddenly involved in an alleged financial scandal of a kind which, whether true or false, usually destroys governments.
Prices worked higher yesterday in dealings on local commodity exchanges. Trading in most instances was at a substantial level. Cash prices followed the trend of contracts to higher levels.

Mrs. George Spencer Eastwick gave a dinner 2ast night at the St. Regis. Her guests were Mrs. Henderson Robb, Mrs. Amory A. Lawrence, James Speyer and Samuel Keyser. A dinner was given there in the Seaglade by Mr. and Mrs. John Milton McMillin for Mr. and Mrs. Watson B. Robinson, Mr. and Mrs. Albert P. Armour, Mr. and Mrs. George L. Ohrstrom, Miss Josephine Copp and Harold P. Farrington.

A further rise, the eighth in as many weeks, carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices up to 106.8 on Tuesday, Feb. 13, from 105.9 (revised) the Tuesday before. The index is now the highest since April 4, 1931, with the exception of July 18, at the peak of last Summer's speculative debauch.

SAN JUAN, Feb. 15. -- Puerto Rico's Democratic party will ask for no appointments from Governor Winship. It believes all political parties should enter a truce to eliminate local politics from the insular government to insure efficiency and economy during the depression.

ROME, Feb. 15. -- Ready for any eventuality, 75,000 Italian troops are posted today at strategic points along the Austrian frontier. In addition, Fascist frontier guards are watching the Austrian situation closely from border points to prevent the entry of Socialist refugees, who are not wanted in Italy.

A plea for public support of the campaign by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York to raise $500,000 was made yesterday afternoon by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, at a meeting of subscribers and committees at the Waldorf-Astoria.
CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (AP). -- Chicago's Black Hawks gained ground in the battle for first place in the National Hockey League's American division tonight by trouncing the Ottawa Senators, 5 to 2.
UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- Utica Curlers won the W. Fred Allen Memorial Medal today when the rink skipped by W.C. Jenkins defeated the Caledonians of New York City, 21 -- 9, in the final.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The statement that the books of the Niagara Falls Power Company reflected in 1918, at the time of its capitalization, $17,531,621 in "appreciation and watered capital on the books of the constituent companies," was made at a hearing before the Federal Trade Commission today by M.C. Steele, an examiner.
VIENNA, Feb. 15. -- A picturesque incident in the grim Austrian drama was witnessed this morning by a correspondent for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- A plan looking toward the scrapping of some kraft board and paper board plants in the interest of "stabilization," and attacked by its opponents as "one that should be called a plan to tax consumers to pay for their own chains" was set before W.W. Pickard, NRA Deputy Administrator, today.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- John D. Rockefeller Sr. left his Pocantico Hills estate today for his Winter home in Ormond, Fla. He went by automobile with John D. Rockefeller Jr. to the Phillipse Manor station here. His special train, composed of an electric engine, a baggage car and a Pullman compartment car, left the station at 11:15 A.M.

WARSAW, Feb. 15. -- More than thousand Jewish refugees from Vienna have arrived in Warsaw and other Polish towns during the last few days, and many more Jewish Polish citizens are expected here from Austria.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 15. -- Two hundred delegates representing twenty countries attended the opening today of the meeting of the International Congress for the Defense of Peace.

VIENNA, Feb. 15. -- Some curiosity has been expressed abroad as to what part the Communists have played in the disturbances in Austria. The fact is the Communists, like the Nazis, have played no part whatever.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The Republic Steel Company, through counsel appearing before the National Labor Board, today declared that "the company is not willing voluntarily to submit anything here involved to the board for mediation, arbitration, determination or any other purpose."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Coincident with announcement in Chicago that the railroads had notified their union employes of a purposed 15 per cent reduction in basic rates of pay, President Roosevelt made public today a letter he wrote yesterday suggesting a continuance of the 10 per cent temporary reduction which has been in effect since June 21.
The 10,000-ton cruiser New Orleans, one of the most powerful ships of her type in the world, was commissioned at the navy yard at Brooklyn yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Wholesale commodity prices rose nearly .7 per cent last week, the seventh consecutive advance, the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Labor Department reported today. A continued rise in market prices of farm products and foods was largely responsible.

Confident expectation of a rise in the loan figures of the banks of the country was expressed here yesterday by Francis Marion Law of Houston, Texas, president of the American Bankers Association, in an address before the closing session of the trust division of the association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- An agreement whereby the Shipping Board will technically recapture part of the money paid to shipping lines for ocean mail contracts, this money to be applied to reduction of the debt to the Shipping Board on which six companies have technically defaulted, was announced today by Henry B. Heimann, director of the Shipping Board Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The tribulations of the New York Stock Exchange incident to "deception" practiced by some corporations to get over barriers set up in the Exchange's stock list committee, were told to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee this afternoon by Frank Altschul, of Lazard Freres, a governor of the Exchange and chairman of its listing committee.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, sent yesterday a letter to the presidents of more than eighty companies which have stocks listed on the Exchange, outlining features of the Fletcher-Rayburn Bill which the executives might regard as objectionable.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- It became known today that the Federal Trade Commission was studying the acquisition last year by the General Motors Corporation of North American Aviation, Inc., in the light of possible violation of the Clayton Anti-Trust Act.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 15 (Canadian Press). -- New-style wrestling tactics that have brought the game back to popularity on the North American Continent are too much for South Africans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today for an extension of the temporary Deposit Insurance Act until July 1, 1935, in a letter to Chairman Fletcher of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.
Small housing properties predominated in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday:

VIENNA, Feb. 15. -- Disarmament of the former Socialist defense corps made considerable progress late this afternoon. Several thousand rifles, forty machine guns, hundreds of hand grenades and large quantities of ammunition were delivered to the authorities.

OUR cream-puff literature is changing. Not so long ago, when the smart young things of London or New York got up nerve enough to visit the country, it was always to stage a weekend in imitation of life in an Aldous Huxley novel. The word "bucolic" somehow became a rhyme for alcoholic, and a Turner sunset was invariably glimpsed through the refracting body of a glass of pure gin.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Limitation of direct or indirect holdings of cotton by any concern or individual to 150,000 bales in any one trade month, or 700,000 bales in any year is vigorously opposed by a second committee of representatives of the cotton trade in a long report today to Chairman Smith of Senate Agricultural Committee.
The tour of the squash racquets team from the Jesters Club of London came to a close on the courts of the Harvard Club last night as the British players lost to a metropolitan team, 5 matches to 1.

Representatives of the steamship owners, longshoremen, trucking and merchant interests of the port reviewed the problem of pier loading practices yesterday afternoon at a closed meeting at the office of Dock Commissioner John McKenzie.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date, while total bills discounted were at the lowest. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure for the year.

P.A.S. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marine Company, expressed the belief yesterday that the question of mail subsidies for American flag lines would be worked out satisfactorily and that "the President will do the right thing."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Sikorsky Aircraft, Inc., a subsidiary of the United Air and Transport Corporation, lost $320,607 in 1933 on a single order for navl airplanes with a contract price of $172,157, the House Naval Committee was told today by Frederick Nelson, president of the company.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15. -- Appointment of three assistant professors at Yale was announced today by President Angell. Cornelius B. Osgood has been appointed Curator of Anthropology in the Peabody Museum of Natural History; Hugh M. Wilson has been named Assistant Professor of Radiology and Jean Boorsch has been appointed Assistant Professor of French.
BERLIN, Feb. 15. -- The German race legislation was expounded and defended tonight by Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Interior Minister, to foreign newspaper men and members of the diplomatic corps.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 15. -President Getulio Vargas has appointed Mauricio Nabuco Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs.

Major B.Q. Jones, Commander of the Eastern Zone of the Air Corps Air Mail Service, landed yesterday afternoon at Newark Metropolitan Airport with a roar of engines and a short but business-like display of airmanship.

Denouncing the Albany legislators who have twice defeated the City Economy Bill, Mayor LaGuardia characterized them yesterday as "a group of small-town politicians seeking to protect payroll padders and loafers." He spoke at the Members' Council luncheon of the Merchants Association of New York in the Hotel Astor.
PRAGUE, Feb. 15. -- Dr. Krofta, Vice Foreign Minister of Czechoslovakia, told the Foreign Affairs Committee of Parliament today:

Eugene S. Daniell Jr., Harvard graduate and lawyer, who formed his own National Independence party in Boston in 1932 to run for President, elected to serve thirty days in the workhouse rather than pay a $500 fine imposed upon him in General Sessions yesterday by Judge Corrigan.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- For the first time in the history of the Federal Labor Department, formed twenty-one years ago, action was taken here today formulating a modern State Labor Code.

Walter F. Brown, former Postmaster General, declared here yesterday there was no justification for the charge that any of the airmail contracts awarded during his administration were given out through collusion among the mail contractors "or by any other illegal method."
Prices on the Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday in a range of a dollar a bale under a large volume of business and ended unchanged to 5 points higher.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. - President Roosevelt today approved the recommendations of a board headed by Rear Admiral Harley H. Christy, selecting forty-six lieutenant commanders of the line of the navy for promotion to the rank of commander.

The taking of evidence designed to support the contention of holders of defaulted guaranteed mortgage certificates that trustees should be appointed for the realty underlying a $27,000,000 issue because the proceeds of the properties are being diverted began yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- A complaint issued today by the Federal Trade Commission charged the American Smelting and Refining Company of New York, one of the largest non-ferrous smelting enterprises, with violating Section 7 of the Clayton Act in acquiring the capital stock of the Federated Metals Corporation of New Jersey, a competing concern.

Richard Whitney, a member of the Jockey Club, has been re-elected chairman of the hunts committee of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association, according to an announcement yesterday by Frank J. Bryan who was re-elected secretary.

MOSCOW, Feb. 15. -- The Austrian workers' revolt has roused the warmest sympathy and admiration in this country, as press headlines and comment show, but the writer can state definitely that this sympathy will involve no change in Soviet foreign policy.

THE HAGUE, Feb. 15. -- The Fourth Chamber Court here, in the cases of the "Association of Stockbrokers" of Amsterdam against the Royal Dutch ad Batavia Petroleum Companies in the matter of payment of dollar bonds, decided today that the Royal Dutch Company must pay in gold, but not the Batavia Petroleum Company.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 15. -- Champion Covert Dazzle of Shelterock, the superb airedale terrier bitch owned by S.M. Stewart of Mont-clair, N.J., was awarded the President's Trophy, emblematic of best in show, in the final judging tonight at the twenty-first annual dog show of the Newark Kennel Club at the 113th Regiment Armory.
Cardini, the magician, has been engaged for "The Family Album," the forthcoming revue to be produced by the Shuberts.
State Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne will preside at a public hearing in Albany today, when the proposal to declare an open season on beaver in this State will come up for consideration.

VIENNA, Feb. 15. -- Amid the blood and confusion of a Socialist insurrection, a new crisis in the civil war abruptly developed tonight when the commander of the Fascist Heimwehr publicly accused politicians of Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss's own party of the real responsibility for the sanguinary conflict.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Serious thought was being given tonight by the administration to providing direct financial aid for aviation and thus encourage the continued development of the passenger-carrying branch of the industry.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- Governor Lehman today signed three bills extending the emergency banking and insurance powers of the Governor, the banking board and the insurance board until March 1, 1935, and validating all acts of the banking board since the laws were enacted during last year's emergency.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday net income for 1933 of $137,456,776, equal to $7.37 a share earned on 18,662,275 shares of stock, comparing with $145,906,909, or $7.82 a share, earned in 1932. The deficit after dividends of $9 a share was $30,503,699, comparing with $22,047,695 in the previous year.

The inhabitants of the "jungle" in Thirty-eighth Street between Tenth and Eleventh Avenues were at breakfast yesterday morning when the heavy green truck rumbled up on the curb and crunched through the ashes to the open space fronted by their slant-walled shacks.

The Central Trades and Labor Council, meeting last night in Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street, adopted a resolution boycotting German goods and German services following an address by Martin Plettl, exiled president of the International Clothing Workers Federation of Germany.

E. Ramey Donovan of Fordham took another step in the defense of his New York State intercollegiate indoor tennis title by defeating Lester Steifberg of N.Y.U., 6 -- 4, 6 -- 0, yesterday. The victory placed Donovan in the semi-final round.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15. -Raymond W. (Ducky) Pond, Yale's head football coach, admits in the current issue of The Yale Alumni Weekly that the Yale attitude toward football is different from that at many other institutions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- British assertions that European trouble and confusion were due to American failure to ratify the Versailles treaty were declared by Senator Borah in the Senate today to be "an ungracious libel."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Former Postmaster General Walter F. Brown is scheduled to appear voluntarily before the Black committee at 10 o'clock Monday to explain his part in the air-mail contracts which Postmaster General Farley annulled on allegations of "conspiracy and collusion."

More than five hundred members of the parish of St. George's Episcopal Church, Sixteenth Street, east of Third Avenue, gathered at the Edison Hotel for dinner last night to begin an effort to increase the church attendance and income.
Mayor LaGuardia and Aldermanic President Deutsch joined yesterday in attacking the relief methods of the CWA here as ineffectual.

Roy Worters's fine work in the nets saved the New York Americans from defeat last night. The diminutive local goalie played his position brilliantly and, although he let one drive get past him, was the outstanding factor in his team's 1-1 tie with the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden.

Your recent correspondents suggest some good reasons for going slowly with the proposed legislation for the "better control" of the public utilities. Our well-meaning Governor states that he does not understand why the enactment of his program was refused last year.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 15. -- Joseph Silverman, New York dealer in surplus army goods, called on Secretary Dern today to carry out a contract whose fulfillment he claimed was held up because of personal bias by "certain general officers."

CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- Railroad managers will be called at once to consider President Roosevelt's suggestion that the present wage agreement be continued another six months. This was announced tonight by W.F. Thiehoff, chairman of the conference committee of managers, which today notified the 900,000 union employee that the road proposed a 15 per cent reduction in the basic rate of pay.

The Municipal Housing Authority's plan for slum clearance, with a $25,000,000 Federal grant, was praised by municipal and civic leaders yesterday as the beginning of a movement that may rid the city of slums.

UNION CITY, N.J., Feb. 15 -- Charging that fifteen dress-manufacturing plants had been forced to close in this State because New York City interests were "dominating the market," the New Jersey Dress Manufacturers and Contractors Association, which has offices here at 404 Thirty-eighth Street, announced today it had sent a committee to Washington to lay the matter before NRA and other officials.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- A new marketing agreement for the packing industry has been submitted by the AAA to the Institute of American Meat Packers, the purpose of which is to "stabilize wholesale meat prices and to effect economies in distribution which will operate to the advantage of both producers and consumers of meats."

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 15. -- The fleet filly Coequel gained her third victory in four Florida starts in the featured Eau Gallie Purse at Hialeah Park today. Well handled by Silvio Coucci, Coequel was timed in 1:37 1-5 for the mile over a fast track and triumphed by a length at $9.80 for $2.

The five-story building at 605 Eighth Avenue and the adjoining four-story structure at 607 Eighth Avenue were sold by Herman M. Weaver to Home Estates, Inc., Martin H. Scott, treasurer, through Adams Co., Real Estate, Inc., brokers in the deal. The property is 50 by 100 feet and is assessed at $290,000.

The Controller of the Currency has recommended that certain changes be made in the Banking Act of 1933. A combination of much that was well thought out and much that was hastily put together, it was made law at the same special session which adopted the Administration's recovery program.

The award of a new issue of $2,400,000 State of New Hampshire bonds to the City Company of New York, Inc., and associates, set yesterday a new high price level for the municipal bond market. The bonds, bearing interest at 3 1/4 per cent and due on March 1 from 1935 to 1942, brought a price of 100.8399. Seven other syndicates participated in the bidding.
ANSFELDEN, Austria, Feb. 15 (AP). -- Governor Joseph Schlegel of Upper Austria was blamed today for the bloody Austrian civil war by Prince Ernst Rudiger von Starhemberg, commander of the Heimwehr.

Taking a firmer hold on first place, Jay N. Bozeman Jr. of Vallejo, Calif., the sensation of the tourney thus far, won his sixth consecutive game in the world's three-cushion billiard championship yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- A State tax of 5 per cent would be imposed upon all amateur and professional sports where an admission fee of more than 40 cents is charged, under a bill introduced today in the Legislature by Senator Kernan, Utica, Democrat.

Trial by jury is under suspicion in New Jersey because politicians and others have not scrupled to tamper with it. Engaged in what is called "a clean-up" in Passaic County, Deputy Attorney General CARPENTER has found glaring evils in the present method of selecting juries.

Representative HOMER CLING PARKER of the First Georgia District was elected in November to fill a vacancy. His "home town" is Statesboro. It is the undoubted and indefeasible right -- don't call it a privilege -- of a Representative in Congress to select the postmaster of his home town.

If "Queer People" is only a plodding travelogue in the performance which was put on at the National last evening, it is discouraging to think what it would be without Hal Skelly. He is such a remarkably good-natured clown that nothing in which he appears can he wholly lugubrious.

The Metropolitan Opera Company's fourth performance of Strauss's "Salome" took place last night, preceded by "Gianni Schicchi" of Puccini. Artur Bodanzky conducted the Strauss work, and the principals in the cast were Gota Ljungberg, Friedrich Schorr, Frederick Jagel, Dorothee Manski, Hans Clemens, Doris Doe and Arthur Anderson.

The New York State Advisory Board of the Federal Emergency Administration of Public Works approved yesterday twenty-one applications for loans in New York State, totaling $13,355,000, at a meeting at the office of State Engineer Arthur S. Tuttle, 2 Lafayette Street.

Appointment of a board to study the taxicab industry and submit recommendations for its regulation and improvement was announced yesterday by Mayor LaGuardia. Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, is chairman of the new inquiry board, on which are represented the fleet operators, independent owners, labor, the public and the Board of Aldermen.

Felix Warburg and James G. McDonald returned on the French liner Paris last night after brief stays in Europe, where they attended a meeting in London of the Committee on Jewish Refugees from Germany.

New York City and other communities that have not availed themselves of the millions in public works loans allotted to them by the Federal Government were warned yesterday that the loans might be transferred to other communities.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission consists of three members appointed by the Mayor for six-year overlapping terms. Not more than two of them may be of the same political party. Until yesterday the President of the commission was ABRAHAM KAPLAN, campaign manager for Mayor O'BRIEN, head of the Terence F. McKeever Association and high in the councils of Tammany Hall.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15. -- New York University's reign among the East's major undefeated basketball teams was continued tonight but only by a narrow margin. The Violet recorded its eleventh consecutive triumph, conquering Temple, 21 to 19, at Mitten Hall.

Under Tammany rule the city government was much more interested in paying large fees to experts hired in condemnation proceedings than in paying the just claims of those whose property was taken, Paul Windels, Corporation Counsel, charged yesterday.

Illuminating gas flowing from a two-inch pipe under Bickford's Restaurant in Forty-second Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues at noon yesterday caused the death of one man and overcame three other persons.
The Reading Company and Northern Pacific reported an increase in net income for 1933, but the Santa Fe and some other Western lines disclosed opposite results.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- The Public Service Commission charged today in its annual report to the Legislature that during the past year utility corporations attempted to break down its regulatory functions through concerted court actions.

An application by five Manhattan bus companies to compel Mrs. Sadye Greenberg, plaintiff in the taxpayer's suit to annual the franchises granted by the O'Brien administration, to furnish particulars of her allegations, was argued yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook.

Seward Park High replaced Textile as the leader in the Manhattan P.S.A.L. basketball competition by defeating Textile, 25 to 17, yesterday in the Seward gymnasium. It was the third victory in four league starts for Seward, which led, 11 to 8, at half time, and was the initial setback in three league contests for Textile.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- President Roosevelt in a letter to railroad executives requested that no further wage cut be made on July 1, as contemplated by the roads. He inspected a streamline train at the Union Station and signed the $950,000,000 CWA Relief Bill.
A trust fund of $50,000 for the benefit of the National University of Mexico was provided by Senator Dwight W. Morrow some time before his death, it was revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 15. -- The average daily volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding for the week ended Feb. 14, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,609,000,000, a decrease of $7,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $510,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1933.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- The importance of keeping alive the State's reforestation program, even though it may have to be curtailed or postponed, was stressed by Conservation Commissioner Osborne today in his annual report to Governor Lehman and the Legislature.

The total of brokers' loans declined $43,000,000 to $853,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the condition statement of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve Bank in New York City.

BERLIN, Feb. 15. -- Germany has at last fired a warning in the matter of Austria. It serves notice, in effect, that no matter what the outcome of the civil war there, Chancellor Dollfuss must go and be replaced soon by a Nazi government.

DES MOINES, Feb. 15. -- State police tonight guarded Jay N. Darling, newspaper cartoonist and sportsman nationally known as "Ding," following reports that he was next on gangdom's list of intended kidnap victims.

A study of tuberculosis in the city is to be made by a committee headed by Dr. Haven Emerson of Columbia University, to determine what should be done to provide properly for tuberculosis patients, Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, announced yesterday.

Local charge account collections during January showed an increase of 2.13 per cent, according to the index of twenty key stores issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc. The gain compares with 3.32 per cent in December and of 1.56 in January a year ago.

The trial of Felix Solomon, close political ally of Martin J. Healy, Tammany leader the West Harlem district, came to a temporary halt yesterday, when District Attorney Dodge completed the State's case and defense counsel fought for dismissal of the indictment.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Feb. 16 (AP). -- Chief Almgren, an early season winner here, returned to top form today even he ran seven furlongs in 1:24 2-5 to defeat the Northway Stable's Northgalis by a length and a half in the feature race. Mild, the choice, was third in the five-horse field.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 16 (AP). -- United States Airways, operating between Kansas City and Denver, will suspend operations Feb. 28 unless developments permit it to continue as an air-mail carrier, W.A. Letson, president of the air line, said today.

HAROLD F. CLARK of Teachers College boldly announces in Occupations that "we need more things and more "services than we can possibly "provide for ourselves." Others who write on employment opportunities for the same periodical are agreed. It is not the machine that is to be blamed for throwing men out of work, but society for failing to set up agencies which will periodically gauge the occupational needs of industry and the professions.

A syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers won the award yesterday of a new issue of $5,680,000 Erie County (N.Y.) tax revenue bonds, dated Feb. 15, 1934, and due from 1935 to 1939. The winning bid was 100.359 for the bonds to bear interest at the rate of 4 3/4 per cent. Under the terms of sale the interest rate could have been named as high as 6 per cent.
Mortgagees acting to protect their liens bid in eighteen properties in Manhattan and the Bronx at auction sales yesterday. Most of the bidders were representatives of banks and insurance companies.

About 350 of the 800 school children who received the Roosevelt Honor Medallion at their schools during the last year attended the annual reception for winners of this award yesterday at the Woman's Roosevelt Memorial Association, Roosevelt House 28 East Twentieth Street.

Several communities throughout the country which have not marketed new bonds in some time have scheduled new issues for award next week through competitive bidding. The total of the new bonds and notes on which bids will be entertained next week is $19,674,300, compared with this week's revised total of $13,217,739 and with the weekly average for the year thus far of $14,884,371.

VIENNA, Saturday, Feb. 17. -- The Austrian Government turned definitely toward fascism early today, and, amid a peace marred by fighting in the sewers of Vienna, struck another crushing blow at the Socialists.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Republicans opened a fight in the House today to have a manufacturers' sales tax put in the pending revenue measure. Led by Representative McGugin of Kansas, they declared that the $258,000,000 new revenue provided by the bill in its present form would fall far short of balancing the budget.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Securities issues totaling approximately $26,500,000 are proposed in ten registration statements filed under the Securities Act and made public today by the Federal Trade Commission.
PARIS, Feb. 16. -- A three-power warning to Germany that Austria must not be meddled with was reported virtually agreed upon tonight by Britain, Italy and France.

WEST BARRIER CACHE, Bay of Whales, Antarctica, Feb. 14 (via Mackay Radio). --The second Byrd Antarctic Expedition has all but cleared the greatest obstacle to the successful establishment of the Winter camp at Little America. With the exception of aviation gasoline, coal for the houses and a few odds and ends, the mounds of stores, which for a fortnight comprised this camp, are now leveled.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- A new Anglo-Soviet trade agreement was signed at the Foreign Office today, bringing the ten months' trade war between the two countries to an end and placing their commercial relations again on a normal footing.

BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia. Feb. 16. -- Blame for the hundreds of Austrian deaths caused by machine-gun and artillery fire was placed at the door of the present Austrian Government and its predecessors by Dr. Julius Deutsch, commander-in-chief of the Socialist forces and general secretary of the Austrian Socialist party, in an interview here tonight.

Current indices of business reveal a striking difference in conditions prevailing in two great groups of industries. In those producing goods for more or less immediate consumption there is comparatively little evidence of depression. This is shown in the figures compiled by the Federal Reserve Board.

Referring to your recent editorial "Lagging Justice" there is another matter relating to "interminable verbosities of records and briefs" on appeal which was not considered, and that is the problem of shelf space in our law libraries. Law librarians agree that the records on appeal, which must be bound and indexed to be of use, are simply "eating up" shelf space to an alarming extent.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16. -- Rules of fair practice for investment bankers, designed to eliminate abuses of the past through providing safeguards for the future and to stabilize the industry through the revival of a healthy, orderly market, were proposed here today by the Investment Bankers Association of America.

A legal move to prevent the Federal court from taking jurisdiction over the defaulted guaranteed mortgage situation was made yesterday when counsel for certificate holders now suing before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankthaler obtained an order restraining Federal Judge Frank Cooper of Albany from appointing temporary trustees for $34,000,000 in mortgages.

An interpretation of the Securities Act of 1933 by counsel for several large corporations is likely to lead to the retirement of large blocks of shares which these companies have acquired in recent years, or to the distribution of these shares among the stockholders as dividends, according to executives of several companies.

A suit against a matrimonial Bureau for $25,000 damages for false representations came before Supreme Court Justice Ingraham yesterday. The defendants sought to have the complaint dismissed on the ground that a contract with such a bureau was against public policy and void.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- Prime Minister MacDonald's personal intervention was reported today to have inspired the appeal for leniency that Baron Georg Franckenstein, Austrian Minister here, sent to Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss Wednesday night.

The Columbia wrestling team held off a gallant closing bid by Harvard to defeat the Crimson, 16-14, last night in the Morningside gymnasium. Each team won four bouts, but two of the Lions' victories were by falls, and the extra points regis tered by that method resulted in the Blue and White winning the meet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- President Roosevelt today approved codes of fair competition for the laundry and restaurant industries which the NRA estimates will add $250,000,000 to payrolls and several hundred thousand persons to the nation's employed. A third code, for the furniture slip-cover industry, approved by General Johnson, brought the number approved to date to 283.

The excellent pace which retail trade maintained practically all through the week proved highly gratifying to local store executives. Main-floor items, home furnishings, men's wear clearances and, to a more limited degree, women's Spring apparel, all shared in the brisk consumer demand.

The object of the National Recovery Act is to extend permanently to all business and industry a control over profits and operations like that established in recent years in public utilities, according to Secretary of Commerce Daniel C. Roper.

HONOLULU, Feb. 16. -- Six naval fliers from the air base at Pearl Harbor saved their lives with parachutes this morning when the plane in which they were flying crashed two miles north of the village of Haleiwa on the northwest coast of the island of Oahu.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 16 (AP). -- The strange experience of being bombarded from space by a meteor was described by an air-mail pilot, Hiram Sheridan, on his arrival here with the eastbound night American Airways mail plane from Fort Worth, Texas.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- Friends of Governor Lehman at the Capitol are urging him to invoke the aid of President Roosevelt in his fight to bring about enactment of the New York City Emergency Economy Bill asked by Mayor LaGuardia.

Columbia College's highest non-athletic award, the King's Crown, was awarded to seventy-five students yesterday following a meeting of the King's Crown board of governors, held in John Jay Hall of the University. Twenty students were recipients of the gold crown, while fifty-five received the silver award.
Massachusetts has just banned the importation of rabbits from Maine, according to an announcement from Raymond J. Kenney, Director of the State Division of Fisheries and Game.

CAMBRIDGE, Feb. 16. -- Declaring that he did not wish to be classed as a calamity howler but that he must assert that the universe was going to pieces, Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard College Observatory, discussed the "engineering problems and practice in the construction of galaxies'' as the Aldred lecturer at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology today.

An order was signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag directing the Chemical Bank and Trust Company to turn over to A.A. Berle Jr., City Chamberlain a $338,395.41 "war memorial fund" which the bank has held since 1922.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 16. -- The Horace Mann School for Boys of New York City captured the Eastern Private Schools Basketball League title today, defeating Princeton Prep, 33 to 24, on the latter's court. It was the ninth triumph in as many league contests for Horace Mann.

Making its first appearance since its twenty-game streak was broken, the Long Island University quintet turned back Rider College of Trenton, N.J., 30 -- 23, last night. An overflow crowd witnessed the contest at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium.
