As an anti-climax to the world's three-cushion billiard championship. Allen Hall of Chicago yesterday won the play-off for second place by defeating Welker Cochran of San Francisco, the 1933 titleholder, at the Capitol Academy, 50 to 43, in forty-one innings.

President Roosevelt's "good neighbor'' policy, increased interchange of cultural ideas, and results of the recent Inter-American Conference at Montevideo, prefigure a new era in Pan-American relations, according to speakers at a luncheon given by the Pan-American Women's Association yesterday in the Roerich Museum, 310 Riverside Drive.

THE police offensive recently launched against the policy game has resulted in numerous arrests and the raiding of a "bank" in which three sacks of "slips" were discovered. Central depots in Harlem have also been closed and many collectors and bankers driven to cover.

HELSINGFORS, Feb. 12, 1934. THE 9th of February, 1934, is a date that Finnish music lovers will surely note and long remember. For on the evening of that day two masterpieces of Jean Sibelius were revealed to his countrymen in a justness and resplendence till then not even approximated in Finland.

One of the strongest fields of recent years, combining youth and experience, with a foreign representation of more than customary size, is scheduled to start tonight in the fifty-sixth international six-day bicycle race in Madison Square Garden.

PARIS, Feb. 13. -- Little by little stories may be gleaned here of women of the American colony who merely expected to see the recent riotous excitement as spectators, but narrowly missed being drawn into it.

Two men arrested following the burning of a truck owned by the Spotless Dollar Cleaners, Inc., were held in $15,000 bail each by Magistrate Farrell in West Side Court yesterday on charges of arson and of assaulting the driver of the truck and his two helpers.

TO people who look upon music as something else than a fad, a pose, a distraction of a dilettante's hour, the type of opera and kind of thing represented by the Stein-Thomson "Four Saints in Three Acts" is depressing if not irritating. The trail of foppishness and pose and pseudo-intellectuality is over it all.

WHAT did Settle and Fordney find out about the cosmic rays when they ascended into the stratosphere eleven and a half miles last Summer? Professor Arthur H. Compton and Dr. J.J. Stephenson gave the answer yesterday before the American Physical Society.

With a meeting of the Kings County Democratic executive committee to elect a new county leader to succeed the late John H. McCooey scheduled for tomorrow afternoon, no candidate for the post had a majority yesterday. The only possibility of an agreement lay in the result of a series of conferences today with Postmaster General Farley, Democratic State and National chairman.

From Piccadilly Notes, issued by a London bookseller, it appears that autograph letters have been "considerably reduced in price." Still, catalogues of them may be called priceless as a register of comparative literary values. The Piccadillian asks ten shillings for an autograph letter of MATTHEW ARNOLD and a sixpence more for one of ALFRED AUSTIN, but the latter's is half a page longer.

Life-long friends and actors and actresses who served in his comlany and under his direction paid homage to Corse Payton, matinee idol in the Nineties, at the funeral service yesterday afternoon at the Walter B. Cooke Chapel, 117 West Seventy-second Street.

VIENNA, Feb. 24. -- One after another, the victors in the struggle against social democracy are putting forward their claims. The Austrian aristocracy, according to the Telegraf, is to receive satisfaction in the new Constitution on its constant demand that the titles of the monarchy shall again be introduced and that the laws inflicting disabilities on the Hapsburgs and confiscating their property for the benefit of the republic shall be repealed.

The American Commercial Alcohol Corporation and its subsidiaries have reported for 1933 a net income of $1,190,346 after making allowances for taxes, depreciation and other charges. This was equal to $4.56 a share on 260,890 capital shares.

MR. BARING remembers that as she poured out a cup of coffee in one of her plays. Sarah Bernhardt said: "Du sucre, deux morceaux?" and "all the charm of all the Muses seemed to be flowering in the four words of that banal breakfast question."

Secretary Wallace's prospectus on the planned American future is a message of despair. It assumes, contrary to experience and sound reasoning, that the country has reached its heights and that the decline must be managed to avert disaster. The Secretary of Agriculture, studying his surpluses and observing the idle industrial plant, can reach only the disheartening conclusion that America must submit to a permanent curtailment of activity.

MISS KEOWN'S books defy the ordinary methods of criticism. Faced with her reckless imagination, her mischievous humor, her bland disregard for the exigencies of plot and her charming inconsequences, one's preoccupations with matters of structure and form fade into nothingness.

PALM BEACH. -- A representation of the famous Florodora Sextet, a flash-back to the Gay Nineties, will be one of the high-lights of the annual Kiwanis benefit performance to be held on Tuesday night at the Paramount Theatre.

PARIS. NEW lines for old" is the perpetual cry of the fashion vendors, but they cannot always fulfill their promise of novelty. Neither is the feminine public always ready to accept it, for "the" silhouette of a period results from a fusion of forces, many of which are outside the sartorial realm.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 24. -- With two meet records broken, Cornell defeated Yale in their tenth annual indoor track meet tonight, 61 -- 52. It was Cornell's seventh victory in the series.

A nationwide effort has been initiated to secure signatures to a plea that the United States should state the conditions upon which it would be willing to consider membership in the League of Nations, and that meanwhile it should establish diplomatic representation at Geneva.

Revision of the Security Market Regulation Bill by the elimination of the section which would require a 60 per cent margin in favor of a more elastic method of controlling speculation is advocated by virtually all Stock Exchange brokers, it was revealed yesterday in a canvass of representative firms.

WHETHER we consider the recent rioting in Paris, which attended the downfall of the Chautemps and the second Daladier Ministries, as symptomatic or systematic, this little book is timely. While dealing specifically with the formative influences which produced one phase of the demonstration it reveals the forces at work which have made this and similar demonstrations inevitable since the days of the Revolution.

An alert and aggressive Poly Prep basketball team, which functioned smoothly at crucial moments, defeated Lawrenceville School, 29 to 25, in a closely contested encounter yesterday in the Poly Prep gymnasium in Brooklyn.

PARIS, Feb. 22. -- Fabric gloves continue to hold their chic position; they match new afternoon and evening gowns. Good all-round types are Chanel's of corded, checked taffeta; Mainbocher's of colored, cross-barred organdie, and Molyneux's plaid faille slip-ons.

HORACE B. DAVIS has written a book on the steel industry which, though extremely biased, presents nevertheless a provocative study of his field of labor. The author besides being a research student working for his Ph. D. was for a period -- how long he does not say -- a worker in a steel mill.

Criticizing leading European countries for having debased their silver coins and as being consequently responsible largely for the low prices of silver, Sir Henri Deterding, managing director of the Royal Dutch-Shell group of companies, says in a statement issued here yesterday that if these countries would restore their subsidiary coinage to its former silver content, the old parity between gold and silver of 1 to 16 soon would be accomplished.

Despite the tie-up of rail and motor transportation by snow and unusual cold in recent weeks, the 273 city-owned piers at which ships from all ports of the world arrive and depart with passengers and freight have continued to function as efficiently as in midsummer, according to Dock Commissioner John McKenzie.

Southerners in New York are interested actively in the annual Dixie dinner dance under the auspices of the New York Southern Society which will be held Friday in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. During the evening five parchments of distinction will be presented to persons "who have contributed unusual achievements in the perpetuation of the history and traditions of the South."

VETERAN pilots have expressed surprise of late at weather reports along the airways which proved at complete variance with conditions developed by further flight. In more than one case such reports, described by the pilots as "over-optimistic," have led the plane and its company into situations of difficulty and even of definite peril.

AMERICAN book rights to "The Life of Our Lord," by Charles Dickens, have been acquired by Simon Schuster, and the book will be published simultaneously in England and America after newspaper serialization has been completed.
ONCE more the streets of Paris have risen and a government as fallen. "The supreme master of the Legislature is the street," a French parliamentarian once remarked with some bitterness in his voice.

The Municipal Housing Authority should confine itself to projects that do not "infringe upon the field of commercial housing," the Merchants Association suggested to Mayor LaGuardia in a letter made public yesterday.

With the best weather conditions in the Eastern zone that it has had since it took over the air-mail service last Monday, the army air corps was moving the mails in and out of Newark Airport yesterday without cancellations. There were few delays, the mail being behind schedule slightly only on the Boston line.

IT was a small world that the map-makers of the sixteenth century had to contend with, and apparently not a very troublesome one. The periodic reports of the discoverers naturally brought about innumerable modifications in the earlier ideas of the geographers.

ATLANTA, Feb. 23. -- Spring will arrive unofficially next Monday in this section of the South and soon the weather will be as warm as politics in Alabama. Already, across the Chattahoochee, candidates have opened the tri-cornered campaign for Governor, in preparation for the Democratic primary, for this year the party balloting will take place on May 1, instead of in August as in the past.

WARSAW, Feb. 24. -- Ratifications of the Polish-German non-aggression pact signed in Berlin Jan. 26 were exchanged here today in Foreign Minister Beck's private apartment. Ambassador Moltke was the Reich's representative.

A new television super-microscope, which will enable science to see things far beyond the range of the most powerful ultra-microscopes now in existence and will increase the range of vision to include the forbidden realms of the ultra-violet and infra-red wave lengths, was described yesterday before a joint meeting of the American Physical Society and the Optical Society of America at Columbia University.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 21. -- With full confidence in the assurance from Washington that the government's cotton acreage reduction plan will become effective either through the voluntary sign-up campaign or the compulsory Bankhead Bill, farmers of the Mid-South are going forward with their farm operations in a spirit that is remindful of the flush days of the late Twenties when there was no depression.

THERE are three methods of printing -- by means of type, engraving and lithography -and it is only 100 years since the inventor of the third passed away. Alois Senefelder of Bavaria died, according to some records, on Feb. 24, and according to others on Feb. 26, 1834.

THE late Dr. Alfred Wegener, I who lost his life among Green-{ land's icy mountains, gave us] what is known as the continental drift theory. According to him the land of the globe was all of a piece eons ago. Some terrifi force broke up the single block, the fragments drifting apart to become the continents.

HAMILTON, Bermuda. -- Bermuda visitors will have the opportunity this week of seeing some of America's ranking tennis players and a number of lesser stars perform in the annual amateur tennis championship matches.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 24. -- Navy defeated Army at basketball today, 31 to 23, before 2,500 spectators, among whom were Major General William D. Connor, superintendent of the Military Academy, and Rear Admiral E.L. Land, chief of naval construction.

In a concerted campaign to stamp out gasoline bootlegging and tax evasion, representatives of ten Northeastern States at a conference at the Waldorf-Astoria adopted a a program yesterday calling for a uniform method of checking on the final disposition of gasoline shipped from one State to another.

The Investment Bankers Code Committee, now making changes in the draft of the fair-practice provisions of the Investment Bankers Code under the NRA, is expected to complete its task in a few days. The original draft was submitted on last Monday to investment bankers at meetings in twenty-six cities throughout the country.

The members of the women's United States squash racquets team start home from England on Tuesday, following their tour, and will consequently miss the opportunity of competing in the invitation squash racquets tourney of the Junior League of New York, which begins tomorrow.

THIS hearty chant suggests the contents of a Communist newspaper set into verse in the manner of John V.A. Weaver. It owes something to the technical method of Will Rogers in that "got to" is determinedly spelt "gotta," for example, in order to achieve certain effects that are no less artificial than any other purely literary affectation.

DUBLIN, Feb. 14. -- The Free State Government has set up a special commission to examine into the whole question of insurance. At present the vast bulk of Irish insurance business is done with British, Canadian and other companies outside Ireland.

ULTRAVIOLET rays, which lay an important part in enabling the body to utilize vitamin D and in the treatment of skin diseases, will not pass through window glass. Quartz, which is transparent to the rays, is expensive.

NEW ROCHELLE, Sunday, Feb. 25. -- John J. McGraw, vice president of the New York Giants, who had seemed to be improving after an attack of uremia brought him to the New Rochelle Hospital here a week ago Friday, fell into a coma early today. He had suffered a relapse last night and was said to be "very low."

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 24. -- St. Benedict's of Newark won the thirteenth annual New Jersey State interscholastic indoor track and field championship for prep schools at the ll3th Infantry Armory tonight with 36 points. Barringer of Newark won the high school title with 21 points.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 24. -- Princeton's wrestlers today gained their second consecutive victory over Yale, 17 to 9.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 2. -- Bound for unexplored mountain ranges in Western Szechwan and Kokonor Provinces on an expedition largely financed by the American Museum of Natural History in New York, Jack T. Young left here three days ago in a Yangtse River steamer.
RENO, Feb. 24 (AP). -- Under a physician's care and advised to take "a good rest," Mrs. Thalia Fortescue Massie was in a hospital today convalescing from a sudden illness.

A dramatic tale of the fishing fleet was unfolded yesterday when the Mary P. Mosquita docked at her pier off Fulton Fish Market with most of her superstructure missing as a result of the storm which swept the Eastern seaboard last Monday.

Although the action of the stock and grain markets exerted a weakening influence on prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, a demand for the spot month created resistance on slight recessions and the list ended unchanged to 6 points lower than on Friday.

ON several occasions listeners have observed that foreign rebroadcasts are clear, but the English translation that follows is the weak link in the chain of a perfect broadcast. The person who reads the translation is often a foreigner whose accent or too rapid reading makes it difficult to understand.

It is the present custom to run down local governments. They are called "relics of the horse-and-buggy age." The plea is for more centralized forms, with the counties taking over some of the towns' functions and the States some of the counties' -- the Federal Government having already obliged by taking over many of the States' earlier responsibilities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt refused today to be rushed away from a social welfare conference where she had spoken on the parole system just because there happened to be a fire next door.

State and city authorities joined forces yesterday to stop slot-machine gambling. Squads of detectives under the direction of Assistant Attorney General John F.X. McGohey and Deputy Police Commissioner Harold L. Allen made three simultaneous raids in different parts of the city.

BUFFALO, Feb. 21. -- Battle lines are forming for a fight on the Buffalo municipal police and firemen's pension fund. Generally the uniformed city employes favor a retention oof the present pension program, but an aroused army of taxpayers is calling for a halt on the ever-mounting expense of the fund.

THIS book is the record of what has perhaps been the most important assignment ever entrusted by a newspaper to a single correspondent over a considerable period of time. For more than twelve years it has been Walter Duranty's job to report for THE NEW YORK TIMES the story of a people in the process of one of the most sweeping and fundamental changes in the life of any nation.

A reduction from $15 to $10 in season golf permits for playing on courses in the city parks was announced yesterday by the Department of Parks in making public a new schedule of prices for golf, tennis and locker permits.

New York University's fencing team, intercollegiate champions, lost to the skilled blade wielders of the Fencers' Club yesterday in their team match in the Violet Salle d'Armes, 14 to 8, for the first defeat the Bronx collegians have suffered in three tests.

HENRY STEPHENSON, genial confidant to many a bewildered cinema star, is mixed up in "The Mystery of Mr. X" at the Capitol. He already owned a nodding acquaintance of twenty-three years with the drama's footlights when, in 1918, he was recruited for the films.
THE four overtures which Beethoven wrote for his only opera, "Fidelio," will be played this afternoon by the Philharmonic-Symphony under Toscanini, as well as Brahms's First symphony.

THE night I arrived in New York I went to see a comedy called "She Loves Me Not." Perfectly written, exquisitely acted and brilliantly directed, it was the best comedy I had seen or was likely to see. I left the theatre elated and a little depressed.

Glenn Cunningham and Bill Bonthron played a return engagement at Madison Square Garden last night, re-enacting their pulse-quickening finish of a week ago, but this time it was Cunningham who scored the victory.

Extreme cold, intensified by a northwest wind that blew as high as 54 miles an hour, continued in the city yesterday. It was expected last night that the cold wave would continue today, accompanied by snow tonight and possibly tomorrow.

IT will probably be the consensus of opinion that Jose Clemente Orozco's just completed murals at Dartmouth College immensely excel, in point of accomplishment, any fresco work that this artist has thus far done in America. I have seen neither his murals in Mexico (some of which are described as magnificent), nor the heroic Prometheus panel at Pomona College in California.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 2. -- Because the American Congress at Washington is dilatory in passing a bill for compensation which would give him an award of $1,500 in American money, Miao Miao, a Chinese here, is living on charity, and his life is in constant danger because riverman to whom he owes money believe he has been paid by the American Government and is refusing to meet his debts.
As a result of continued deficits, the school relief fund which provides food and clothing for needy children is threatened with curtailment, if not discontinuance.

American industry under the NRA is slipping into a cartel form of operation in which the consumer, for the present at least, is being victimized, Leon Henderson of the Russell Sage Foundation and personal assistant to General Johnson on consumer matters, told THE TIMES here yesterday.

Wall Street was as much in the dark yesterday as on the day before with respect to the causes of the current reaction on the Stock Exchange. Much was said in the brokerage comment about the disturbing effect of industrial strikes and of NRA adjustments, not to mention other rumors and developments, but the impression was that the threat of Federal regulation was still the most unsettling element in the whole market situation.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 22. -- More than 200,000 persons have applied for work or relief to Emergency Relief Administrator James R. Bourne and to the CWA, of which Mr. Bourne also is the head. More than 170,000 of the cases have been investigated and of this number more than 85 per cent have been found to be in actual need.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 23. -- In Belgium during this past week death, as so often has happened, put many things back into their proper perspective.

An elaborate entertainment in a tropical setting is being planned for the supper dance to be given Saturday night at the Plaza under the auspices of the Junior Federation of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies.

BARCELONA, Feb. 10. -- All male members of religious orders in Catalonia, whether priests or lay brothers, and all secular priests will be required to pay the bachelor's tax, according to an order just issued by the Catalan Councilor of Finance.

A FURTHER illustration of the marked progress made in British film production is "Catherine the Great," which is now enjoying the distinction of a special showing at the Astor. This successor to that grand picture, "The Private Life of Henry VIII," has as its leading players Elisabeth Bergner and Douglas Fairbanks Jr., and among those in the supporting cast are Flora Robson, Sir Gerald du Maurier, Irene Van Brugh and Diana Napier.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24. -- The gates of the old penitentiary at Joliet closed today on Roger Touhy and two members of his gang, once the rulers of Cook County Northwest beer districts. Two hours earlier Judge Michael Feinberg had sentenced Touhy, Albert Kator and Gus Schaefer to serve ninety-nine years in the penitentiary for kidnapping John Factor, wealthy speculator.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- President Roosevelt issued an executive order today modifying previous orders of approval of the Daily Newspaper Publishing and Graphic Arts Industries Codes in order to bring about uniformity.

The weather has not been favorable to the idea of a managed world. Few people today are bold enough to defend the vicissitudes of the business cycle, yet it is undeniable that the weather has been behaving exactly like a business cycle.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 24. -- Forever Young, a speedy son of Peter Pan, carried the pink and black-striped silks of the Greentree Stable of Mrs. Payne Whitney to a well-earned nose victory over E.C. Grogan's Wise Prince in the Nursery Stakes No. 1 at Hialeah Park today.

ASIDE from the President, who was the most useful citizen of the United States politically in 1933? A poll conducted by Harlan Eugene Read, WOR commentator, discloses that the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, the radio priest, led all candidates for this honor by a margin of 50 per cent of the total 22,000 votes cast.

WITH the coronation of Leopold III as King of the Belgians, the former ducal house of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha gives another ruler to the world. The new King bears the name of his great-great-uncle, Leopold of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, who became the first King of the Belgians.

WILLIAM MARCH is the author of "Company K," that prose "Spoon River Anthology" of the war which deserved the many good things said about it. His new book is a full-length novel, really a first novel, very well written and containing a number of fine passages.
PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Feb. 24. -- Mrs. R. Clifford Black will open her home here on Wednesday for a bridge tea to benefit the Pelham Woman's Exchange.

Boston's two-day exhibition last week concluded the annual February rush of dog shows in the East. During ten days seven exhibitions were held. In reality there were fifteen shows, as each of the specialty clubs exhibiting at the Grand Central Palace put on an event quite separate from every other.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 22. -- The order from Washington for a systematic reduction in Civil Works Administration personnel in Missouri came somewhat as a surprise to officials in charge and others at the head of city governments using such funds for civic improvements.

PARIS, Feb. 24 (AP). -- France will soon institute a four-day to five-day South American air mail service, designed to meet German competition. The new service will be established through shortening the steamer-served gap and by dropping mail by parachutes to boats.

SCHOOL executives of the nation meeting in Cleveland this week are faced with the practical problem as to how much permanent financial help and central control the public schools need and desire from the Federal Government. The principle of Federal aid and of a department of education with a Secretary in the President's Cabinet, which they have endorsed in the past, have suddenly become live issues.

ALTHOUGH this has not been a very healthy season for English plays in New York, the past fortnight has yielded two of the better ones -- "The Shining Hour," which has not yet appeared in London, and "Richard of Bordeaux," which is now in its second year there with John Gielgud in the title role.

HURRAH for the Black Shirts!" Lord Rothermere cried in three full columns of a recent issue of The Daily Mail. As The Mail has one of the Largest circulations in England and Lord Rothermere is one of the wealthiest newspaper proprietors in the country, this august "hurrah" has reverberated from one end of Britain to the other.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 24. -- Denny Shute of Miami and Paul Runyan of White Plains, N.Y., tied for the lead today in the $2,000 Gasparilla open golf tournament with par-shattering scores of 135 for thirty-six holes.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Feb. 24. -- The blizzard of Tuesday caused a suspension of classes at Mount Holyoke College for the first time in many years, but the senior class refused to abandon their dance, the final social event of the senior year, which took place lest evening with some 150 couples in attendance.

A great difference in the speech backgrounds of Hunter College students has been found by Professor Marguerite E. Jones of the department of speech and dramatics, who has been keeping a record of the speech ancestry of her students for several years.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 24. -- One hundred boys from ten schools participated in the second annual Penn-Jersey Private Schools Athletic Carnival, sponsored by Hun School today. Wrestling, boxing, fencing and foul-shooting comprised the program.

DECATUR, Ala., Feb. 24. -- Because the motions for new trials for Heywood Patterson and Clarence Norris in the Scottsboro case were not filed within the statutory time limit, they were overruled here today by Circuit Judge W.W. Callahan.

Revision of buying and selling budgets in line with the sales trend in each section, aggressive utilization of price appeal, restricted price rises and the investment of 10 to 15 per cent of newspaper advertising in institutional copy are among the recommendations made yesterday by Frank W. Spaeth, manager of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, in discussing sales promotion for the first half of this year.

VIENNA, Feb. 24. -- A march on Vienna by the pro-government Heimwehr was reported imminent tonight as dozens of freshly fueled trucks carrying Fascists sped out of Vienna for an unannounced destination.

OVER a wide area the storm of last week brought a very sharp cut in trade. The full effect here was felt on Tuesday, but the following day furnished sales figures in many instances that went ahead of last year's, although, of course, at that time business was very nearly at a standstill as the banking crisis deepened.

NEW cooling system, using the lubricating oil of the engine instead of water, has been developed by the Spontan Company of Stockholm, it is announced. The invention embodies a radiator system of new design, said to do away with disadvantages of the water-cooling system, such as freezing, clogging and boiling, while keeping the motor's temperature virtually constant regardless of whether the engine is doing light or heavy work.

THERE is rejoicing today in the old Teatro Carlo Felice. Under the sage administration of the Hon. Corrado Marchi, its progressive director and commissioner, Genoa's leading opera house is fast gaining artistic prestige and is now well in the Italian lyric limelight.

The scene is a New York residence street that has fallen on evil days. More specifically, it is a certain house in that street -- a house that has once been the home of a family whose happiness was abruptly terminated by a tragedy. To that house comes a young man who has lived there as a child, seeking lodgings in what has now become a shabby rooming house.

Plans for construction of additional buildings at Bellevue Hospital with $4,000,000 granted by the PWA are almost exclusively occupying his attention and that of his aides, Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, said yesterday.

VIENNA, Feb. 23. -- The tumult and the shouting of the Austrian civil war have died, but the captains and the kings remain greatly perplexed concerning what to do with their victory over the Austrian workers. Austrian democracy is destroyed, but what form of reaction is to succeed it is still uncertain.

One of the first things that Fleming Stone discovers is that the tiger is not guilty of killing Marcia Moore, although somebody has evidently wanted it to appear so, since Marcia's dead body was found in Bluebell's cage in the private zoo of Allan Moore, Marcia's husband.

THE title Mr. Hart has selected for his book is somewhat misleading. He says the Chinese call themselves by the term "pai hsing," the hundred surnames; but in reality it is the designation which was used by the emperors for the common people, including scholars, but not mandarins and persons holding official positions.
VIENNA, Feb. 25. -- Some idea can now be formed of the gigantic problems facing the absolute rulers of Austria, Chancellor Dollfuss and the fascist Heimwehr.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Feb. 25 (AP). --Pari-Mutuel, after finishing last in two previous starts, showed a distinct liking for the mud and raced to a nose decision over the Norman W. Church star, Gallant Sir, in a stunning upset today.

The promotion of friendship with America has been a leading activity all my life. Nine years before my birth your Commodore Perry was received by a Tokugawa Shogun and through my family negotiated the first treaty of any Western nation with Japan.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 25. -- Fort Riley maintained its superiority in jumping events on the final day of the Miami Biltmore Horse Show at Tropical Park today, but only after a hard-ridden jump-off with the Fort McPherson team for the Henry L. Doherty Cup and the inter-post championship.

The principal recommendations made to Governor Lehman in an interim report by George W. Alger, Moreland Act Commissioner investigating the State Insurance Department and the guaranteed mortgage and title companies, follow:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- When the Senate Banking Committee begins hearings tomorrow on the Fletcher-Reyburn Stock Exchange Regulation Bill, the battle over Federal control of stock and commodity exchanges will be definitely under way.

PARIS, Feb. 25 (By Wireless).-- The scandal following the Stavisky affair, which began with revelation financial frauds by the type of villain not unknown in other countries, is poisoning and inflaming political passion in France.

$44,150 in 1932, according to the Reading Company's report for 1933. However, the addition of $20,590 other income produced a net income of $10,860 for 1933. Gross revenues were $738,483 in 1933, against $695,927 in 1932.

People of this State who have at heart the good of our schools will be glad that Mr. OWEN YOUNG has been elected a Regent of the University of the State of New York. He has shown unusual devotion to education and at the same time loyalty to the village of his birth.

The city's right to use tax funds to pay all fixed charges arising out of operation of its new subway lines until three years after the entire Independent System is completed and in operation, will be defended before the Court of Appeals on Wednesday by Samuel Seabury, special counsel to the Board of Estimate in matters relating to transit unification.
The time has come for the teachers to cease our "unalterably opposed" position on the Economy Bill and offer something constructive in the form of a compromise.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25. -- Current business of Marshall Field Co. is running substantially ahead of a year ago, John McKinlay, president, said today in his annual report to stockholders. At the same time he reported that factory employment of the organization reached a new peak in 1933 and that the number of employes on the payroll at the end of the year was materially larger than at the close of 1932.

For the third time in four years, Neil J. Sullivan and Roy R. Coffin of the Germantown Cricket Club, national doubles champion, yesterday captured the honors in the Lockett Trophy invitation squash racquets doubles tournament.
CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP). -- Upward of $50,000,000 have been sheared off the cost of government in nearly a dozen States recently, a survey showed today.

Men well known in politics and sports joined yesterday in expressions of sorrow at the death of John J. McGraw. Messages of sympathy were received by the hundred at the McGraw home, 620 Ely Avenue, Pelham Manor.

Despite a private settlement agreed upon by Lee Shubert and Pola Negri, just before an arbitration hearing, for Mr. Shubert again to present Miss Negri in the star role of "A Trip to Pressburg," the production has been called off by mutual consent.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- With the temperature hovering about the zero mark and a 25-mile wind adding to the discomfort of the athletes, Allan Potts of Brooklyn carried off the New York State men's senior outdoor speed-skating championship today.

The moral necessity of each man bearing a cross was discussed yesterday morning at the Broadway Presbyterian Church, Broadway and 114th Street, by the Rev. Dr. William H. Matthews, secretary of the American Tract Society.

ST. KITTS, B.W.I., Feb. 25. -- Great Britain's Atlantic fleet, augmented by Canada's navy of four small cruisers was anchored today in Basseterre Bay, preparatory to starting manoeuvres within forty-eight hours that will end at Gibraltar.

The Atlantic City Sea Gulls advanced a step nearer the championship of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League by triumphing over the St. Nicks, 9 to 1, at the Coliseum yesterday. The league leaders need one more victory in their remaining two league games to clinch the title.

Felix M. Warburg told Jewish leaders from many parts of the country yesterday that it was difficult to contradict the charge that Jewish young men were trying "to take positions in life of the easier kind and that they are not working in hard muscle and pioneer activities which every country more or less needs."
" Ragged Army," with Lloyd Nolan in the leading role, will have its postponed premiere at the Selwyn Theatre this evening.

Arturo Toscanini and the Philharmonic-Symphony gave a provocative and richly rewarding program at the concert at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. The Beethoven "Leonore" overtures Nos. 1, 2 and 3 and Brahms's First Symphony were the day's staples, and a large audience that braved the new snow storm responded with enormous enthusiasm.
MOSCOW, Feb. 25 (AP). -- Four hundred fishermen and 190 horses were reported here to have been carried away on an ice floe that broke today from the main pack in the Caspian Sea.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 25. -- Production of steel has been rising more and more rapidly. January showed only a small gain over December, while last week's forecast, at 43.6 per cent of capacity, was one-fourth above the figure for the third week previous and the increase in the week was more than one-third of the average rise in the three weeks.

Opposition to several of the New York State Conservation Department's legislative measures has developed within recent days and those bills which have already been presented to Albany are not making much progress, according to a survey completed yesterday.

In THE TIMES recently I read that a mass meeting held in Madison Square Garden to protest "the slaughter of Austrian workers by the Fascists of the Dollfuss regime" broke up in pandemonium and a free-for-all fight between Socialists and Communists.

The general run of novels on the market today is detrimental to the development of a clean, wholesome mind, the Rev. John B. Champion of the Eastern Baptist Theological Seminary, Philadelphia, said in a sermon yesterday at the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street.

COLEANOR, Ala., Feb. 25 (AP). -- Four companies of National Guardsmen, ordered from Birmingham by Governor B.M. Miller after authorities here reported "disorders out of hand" in a mine strike, tonight patrolled the centre of the disturbance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The National Recovery Administration suddenly reopened its long-standing controversy with the Ford Motor Company today by serving public notice that it would make a "detailed investigation of the company's alleged refusal to bargain collectively with employes of its Edgewater, N.J., plant."

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 24. -- Gold holdings of the Netherlands Bank on Feb. 19 amounted to 813,000,000 guilders, against 833,000,000 a week before and 1,023,000,000 on Feb. 20, 1933. The largest holdings in 1933 were in January, amounting to 1,033,000,000, and the lowest were in July, at 741,000,000.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 25. -- Denny Shute, British open champion, put on a garrison finish at the Palma Ceia Club today and stroked his way into a first-place tie in the $2,000 72-hole Gasparilla open golf championship. In so doing, he duplicated his feat of last year.

The outstanding event on this, week's art calendar is the Municipal Art Exhibition, which will be opened by Mayor LaGuardia with a reception and private view tomorrow evening at Rockefeller Center. The show opens to the public Wednesday.

The Dow Chemical Company's eastern office is to move about April 1 to the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center. The space is about double that of the firm's present office in 60 East Forty-second Street, according to the Rockefeller Center rental office.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 25. -- Tommy Loughran tuned up today for his heavyweight title bout with Primo Carnera in the very ring where he will face the champion Wednesday night.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 (AP). -- The State reluctantly brings Manney Strewl to trial tomorrow as the alleged kidnapper of John J. O'Connell, whose release cost his family $40,000.
The resignation of the Rev. Dr. William B. Millar, general secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, effective March 1, was announced yesterday. His successor has not yet been chosen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- Six State flags will join the twenty-one now hanging in the triforium gallery over the great choir of the Washington Cathedral. They were accepted by the Right Rev. James E. Freeman, Bishop of Washington, at the services today when the donors or their representatives carried them to the chancel.

Many small dwellings and tenement houses changed hands in realty deals reported in New Jersey over the week-end. Most of the sales involved properties in Hudson and Bergen Counties. Two properties were taken in satisfaction Of mortgages.
The score is tied now with one run apiece, and apparently Glenn Cunningham and Bill Bonthron will not go into extra innings to decide the still disputed question of their supremacy.

HSINKING, Manchukuo, Monday, Feb. 26. -- Fearing plots against Henry Pu Yi, which might end in his death on the day of enthronement, Thursday, Japanese and Manchukuoan authorities redoubled their precautions today.

The plans for the restoration of Bryant Park proposed by Robert S. Moses, Park Commissioner, have been approved by the board of directors of the Park Association of New York City, Inc., whose acting president, Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger, has so advised Mr. Moses.
Transfer of the franchise of the Jersey City baseball club to Syracuse was decided upon unanimously by the directors of the International League yesterday after a session at the Hotel New Yorker.

In defiance of the blustering weather last night, the audience that assembled at the Guild Theatre for Martha Graham's recital was as large a one as the house would hold, and a number of potential spectators were unable to obtain so much as standing room.

President ROOSEVELT kept the" Newspaper Code" a long time on his desk before signing it. It was placed in his hands about two months ago. His final signature was accompanied by a statement which raised new questions. Good lawyers differed regarding the legal effect of some of the things stipulated by the President.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb 25. -- Seven persons were killed and ten injured today at Argentina's Grand Prize automobile race over dirt roads.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- A cautious approach to the problem of price-fixing has been urged by a large group of economists whose opinions were solicited by the National Recovery Administration and made public today.

No Christian is justified in "fearing and worrying his life away," the Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman said in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

Parr Commissioner Moses rebuked yesterday George Dyson Friou, chairman of the Emergency Committee on School Overcrowding, for the latter's criticism of expenditures for a new "monkey house" in the Central Park Zoo when new school buildings were needed.

The church has a definite role to play in preventing war, according to the sermon by the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray yesterday in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, better known as "The ,Little Church Around the Corner," 1 East Twenty-ninth Street. Be went on:
I noticed a letter signed T.R. in THE TIMES yesterday. The claim of the writer that the $37,000 investment of the barber in guaranteed first mortgages was wiped out completely is incorrect.

The Manhattan and Empire City Chess Clubs kept pace at the top in the annual championship series of the Metropolitan Chess League by scoring in the fourth round yesterday. The former defeated West Side, 6 -- 2, and the latter won from the Caissa team, 6 1/2 -- 1 1/2.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Feb. 25. -- A fire that csused damage estimated at $75,000 to the Red Stone Inn on Knollwood Road here routed twenty guests, including an elderly woman who had to be carried out, and caused two firemen to be overcome by the smoke.

Sympathetic understanding and keeping young were declared to be the secrets of successfully rearing children, in a sermon yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Augustus Steimle, pastor of the Lutheran Church of the Advent, Broadway and Ninety-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- Appointment of three additional members of the Board of Veterans Appeals and special instructions for the facilitation of appeals, were announced today by General Frank T. Hines, Veterans Administrator. The new members are:

New life insurance written by the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company increased by $53,125,041 in 1933, or from $138,768,997 to $191,894,08, according to the annual report issued yesterday. Insurance in force at the end of the year was $2,165,831,398, or a drop of $168,771,129 from the previous total of $2,334,602,527.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The restaurant code goes into effect tomorrow. As made public today, the code forbids premiums or giving away of food, banning the "free lunch" of liquor places licensed as restaurants.

A murder suspect, traced through the recharging of a storage battery by a cheek-up of garages, snatched a revolver from a detective when cornered yesterday in the lobby of the Hotel Lincoln, Forty-fourth Street and Eight Avenue, and while a dozen startled guests and as many employes looked on, attempted to fight off his captor.
BERLIN, Feb. 25. -- Led by the venerable Field Marshal, President von Hindenburg, all of Germany paused at the noon hour today to pay silent but impressive tribute to the German war dead.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The volume of industrial production in the United States increased by more than the usual seasonal amount in January and the first two weeks in February, the Federal Reserve Board announced today in the course of a survey of general business and financial conditions.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 25. -- Nine Dartmouth students were found dead in their beds in the Theta Chi fraternity house at 33 North Main Street here late this afternoon. They had been killed during the night by carbon monoxide poisoning resulting from an improperly banked furnace.

DETROIT, Feb. 25 (AP). -- Father Charles E. Coughlin called upon World War veterans today to demand nationalization of credit as the basis of immediate payment of the balance on their adjusted compensation certificates.

George Hohnhorst, 69 years old, night clerk, and Victor Cole, Negro porter, were alone on the main floor of the Edgewater Hotel at 650 West 125th Street, near Fort Lee Ferry at 4 o'clock yesterday morning when two young men walked in.

LONDON, Feb, 24. -- So far the withdrawal of United States capital has not affected the London markets to any appreciable extent. The only trace of disturbance or inconvenience is to be found in the money market, where extensive gold shipments to the United States in part represent the return of United States capital and are causing some pressure for loans.

This little group of islands which got so bad a name a few years ago now has prospect of better days. President ROOSEVELT has invoked the aid of several prominent citizens, in addition to two members of the Cabinet, in putting into effect "a comprehensive plan for "the social and economic advancement "of the people," to be financed from the public works fund.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $5,145,610,700. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has purchased a painting by Herbert Meyer, American artist now living in Vermont, according to an announcement by the Macbeth Gallery, 15 East Fifty-seventh Street, from which the purchase was made.

Re-examination of the foreign trade policy of the United States with a view to sweeping away some of the excessive barriers at home as well as abroad, may well be the next step in the recovery program in this country, according to the Guaranty Trust Company.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 25. -- Miss Marion Clark of Baltimore piloted the team that annexed the Adirondack Association junior bob sled title for teams of two today, covering the four one-mile heats down the slide on Mount Van Hoevenberg in a total title of 5:36.82.

HANKOW, China, Monday, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Chang Hsueh-liang, former war lord of Manchuria, arrived today to take up a new job of bandit-suppression as commissioner of the Provinces of Honan, Hupeh and Anhwei.

Four French tennis players are scheduled to arrive here Wednesday aboard the French liner Champlain to play in indoor competitions next month. They are Jean Borotra, Christian Boussus, Paul Feret and Andre Merlin, who are listed at Nos. 1, 2, 3 and 5, respectively, in the French rankings.

TORONTO, Ont., Feb. 25. -- Under the sponsorship of the Toronto branch of the Canadian Institute of Mining and Metalurgy, the Ontario Prospectors and Developers Association and the Ontario Mining Association, the Canadian mining industry, from prospector to capitalist, will pay tribute here on March 5 to Charles McCrea, who for ten years has been Minister of Mines of the Province of Ontario.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1934, as well as last prices for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

Another snowstorm which threatens to bring a repetition of conditions that prevailed early last week swept over the eastern seaboard yesterday after having blanketed the northern part of the United States from Nebraska to the Atlantic.

The busiest week of the season thus far in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League saw Princeton and Cornell emerge with the major share of the honors, and throw the struggle for title honors into a wide-open affair, with three teams still very much in the running.

Charles Laughton and Norma Shearer will have leading roles in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's film version of "The Barretts of Wimpole Street" under the direction of Sidney Franklin. Production on the film will begin as soon as Miss Shearer finishes work in "Rip Tide."
The New York State Symphonic Band plays at 11 A.M. today at the East Side Continuation School, 43 Oak Street. Anthony Giammatteo is the conductor.

PARIS, Feb. 24. -- The decrease of 447,000,000 francs in the Bank of France's gold reserve, shown by Thursday's statement coveting the week ended on Feb. 15, was less than the market had expected. The week's shipments to the United States had been offset partly by arrivals from Holland, Switzerland and elsewhere.

BUFFALO, Feb. 25. -- Competing in a field of nearly 700 entries, a French poodle was awarded the title of best dog in show as the tenth annual competition of the Buffalo Kennel Club closed tonight. The victor was Nunsoe Duc de la Terrace, owned by Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt of Katonah, N.Y.

Art's place in the modern industrial scheme promises to command a great deal of public attention here within the next few weeks. Two important exhibitions are being prepared. The first of these, assembled under the title, "Machine Art," is scheduled to open at the Museum of Modern Art on March 6 with a preview for museum members (to the public the following day).

The dollar declined to a new low for this movement last week, measured by the quotation for the French franc. The opening price of 102.0 cents was a slight improvement over the close on the preceding Saturday, but thereafter the rate dropped steadily until 100.9 cents was reached at the bottom of Saturday's trading, the lowest since Nov. 15 last. The close was 101.1 cents. The range last week, last year, was 99.34@99.22 cents.

Justice, mercy and humility are the things God requires of man and are the fundamental virtues that are the basis of all moral progress, the Rev. Dr. Howard Chandler Robbins of the General Theological Seminary declared in his sermon yesterday morning at St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street.

Headed by high police officials, more than 1,200 persons, including 500 members of Shomrim, religious organization for Jewish policemen, participated in the society's annual memorial service yesterday afternoon at Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street.
ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- Leaders on Capitol Hill prepared tonight to speed up legislative machinery this week and launch formal discussion of controversial subjects long held in abeyance.

It was with a sigh of resignation that Esau Richards, 40 years old, a Negro, tumbled out of a warm bed at 10:15 o'clock yesterday morning in his second-floor apartment at 71 East 114th Street to replenish the kitchen fire so his wife could make breakfast.
A hold-up gang from the Catskills and Adirondacks was operating yesterday on ice floes in the Hudson River and on the brink of the snow-clad Palisades, opposite Spuyten Duyvil.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 25. -- A $10 home-relief check that had been sent to their mother provided a Roman holiday yesterday for Richard Bryant, 12 years old, and his sister, Viola, 10, of 26 Hunter Street. The two children embarked on an all-night "spree" with the proceeds of the check after Viola had endorsed it with her mother's name.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 25. -- The death of John McGraw cast a pall today over the training camp of the world's champion Giants.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 25. -- A committee of the Mayors' Conference, in a message sent today to Governor Lehman and the Legislature on "the financial plight of the New York State cities," renewed the city executives' effort for enactment of a 2 per cent retail sales tax with a 90 per cent refund from the State to municipalities.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 25. -- Presidents and delegates of the Garden Club of America and members of the Garden Club of Palm Beach were guests of Mrs. George Alexander McKinlock, Mrs. John S. Phipps, Mrs. W. Seward Webb and the Hon. Mrs. Frederick E. Guest at an informal supper given tonight at the Piazza di Spagna and adjoining gardens in the Poinciana Conservatories, where the sixth annual flower show is in progress.

Urgent need of doing something quickly for the holders of guaranteed mortgages in default has led the Moreland Commissioner, Mr. ALGER, with his counsel, Mr. COOK, to submit to the Governor an interim report. It contains a plan not only for the relief of distressed holders of certificates, but for safeguarding and administering properties covered by the mortgages.

DETROIT, Feb. 25. -- Detroit's Red Wings widened their lead in the American division of the National Hockey League tonight by beating the New York Americans, 2 -- 1, in an overtime match before 10,000 fans.

Breaking 97 targets despite the handicap of snow, C.J. Winninger took the High Scratch Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. The High Handicap prize went to L.F. Sanman, who had 95-4-99. J.J.. Van Gonsic, 82-16-98, won the second handicap award.

If the Fletcher-Rayburn Bill establishes a margin requirement of 60 per cent on bank loans, as well as on brokerage accounts, the act will work great hardship on persons who bought stocks on what they considered an investment basis with the sanction of the Hoovet administration, according to a letter sent by Howard S. Cullman, Deputy Administrator of the CWA, to Ferdinand Pecora, counsel for the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

John J. McGraw died yesterday in the New Rochelle Hospital. The "Little Napoleon" of the baseball diamond, who led the New York Giants through thirty successful years, passed away at 11:50 A.M. in his sixty-first year.

HAMILTON BASSO is a native of New Orleans, a graduate of Tulane University and author of a biography of "Beauregard, the Great Creole." Unlike the "Tennessee Agrarian" school of writers, he entertains no perceptible rancor about the past; he is not engaged in fighting the Civil War over again whenever he puts pen to paper.
News of the fraternity house tragedy at Dartmouth caused sorrow last night in college circles of the metropolitan district, where many of the students live.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP). --Representative McFarlane, one of the Congressional investigators of American aviation, asserted today that "the United States has virtually squandered over $100,000,000 since 1921 and ended up with an inefficient air force."

The New Chamber Orchestra, directed by Bernard Herrmann, gave its second concert of the season last in Town Hall. Its all-American program comprised Ives's prelude and fugue from his fourth symphony, "Four Episodes,'' by Ernest Bloch; Henry Cowell's "Reel," Copland's "Prelude,'' from his first symphony; Percy Grainger's passacaglia, "Green Bushes"; "Two Irish Fairy Tales," by Dana Suesse; Jerome Moross's "Nocturne," Oscar Levant's "Sinfonietta" and Roy Harris's "Pastorale" for flute.
Thirteen persons were injured in Queens yesterday when ice on the streets caused two automobiles to skid into a wall and an elevated pillar.

QUEBEC, Que., Feb. 25. -- With trains running as much as twenty-nine hours behind time, after being snowed up in drifts thirty feet high, every available man engaged in shoveling snow off the tracks in various spots, and with all snow-plows in the region hard at work, the Quebec area is digging itself out of the worst snow in years.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 25. -- Nervousness and erratic price fluctuations, coupled with periods of active trading, featured the cotton market here last week. New from Washington relative to the progress of the Bankhead bill and the drift toward bimetalism were important considerations, although trading was influenced also by liquidation in the March position and the approach of the first notice day for that month, which was Friday.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- Following are the tabulated details of the Board of Trade's preliminary annual estimate on the balance of Great Britain's foreign payments for the calendar year 1933, compared with previous years. Figures are in millions of pounds sterling:
ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- Major crime in the State decreased in 1933 for the Second successive year, the Department of Correction reported today. The decline from 1932 was 11.5 per cent.

Despite the severe weather, which cut into retail sales, stores placed a fairly substantial volume of business in the local wholesale markets last week. Fill-in orders were received for a variety of merchandise and in general the total was sizable.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25. -- The markets here for hogs and cattle were disturbed last week by government operations. A processing tax of $2.25 a hundred pounds on pork products is to go into effect next Thursday and be paid by the farmer.

HAVANA, Feb. 25 (AP).--The first signs of trouble since the inauguration of President Carlos Mendieta appeared today when police announced the discovery of an anti-government plot, allegedly sponsored by former army officers, in league with Communist agitators.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 25. -- An audience of more than 5,000 subscribers saw the pages of a "publication" come to life today when writers appeared in person to read their contributions to the Rollins Animated Magazine, a Founder's Week feature at Rollins College.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 24. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 74.2, which compares with 73.7 the week before, 73.2 two weeks before, 72.8 three weeks before and 72.5 four weeks before.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- Although the profit obtainable on gold shipped to the United States is not nearly so substantial as it was immediately after the devaluation of the dollar, it is still sufficiently attractive, taking all costs and risks into account. All supplies offered in the London market continue to be bought for resale to interests in the United States.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25. -- Specialists in corn regard the markets for that grain as acting unnaturally. The government having lent about $194,000,000 to farmers who have held their corn, the pressure of corn for sale is light.

Last week was one of reaction in the local commodity futures markets. In some cases the declines were small, but no staple showed a clear gain. Trading was for the most part heavy. Cash prices were irregularly lower.

Rutgers added two more victories in the Intercollegiate Swimming Association last week and finished its season with four triumphs out of five. The Scarlet is now in second place and can still tie league-leading Yale for the championship in the event that Navy defeats the Elis in their meet.
Corporation Counsel Paul Windels and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. will go to Albany today for further conferences with the legislative leaders on the LaGuardia Economy Bill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP). --Representative McLeod, Republican of Michigan, said tonight that he would ask for a Congressional investigation of the Army Air Corps as a result of the series of fatal accidents that have overtaken army aviators flying the mail.
The small-home owners of Brooklyn and Queens will pay the highest tax rate in many years this year it was indicated by figures made public yesterday by Controller Cunningham.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 25. -- Charges being investigated by the Regional Labor Board at New York that the Whitney Blake Company of New Haven is violating an agreement made after a recent strike at the plant were denied tonight by Fred B. Kingsbury, secretary-treasurer of the company.

LONDON, Feb. 25. -- Lord Tyrrell, for forty years an outstanding figure in the British diplomatic service, has resigned the Ambassadorship in Paris, where after six years of service his health has broken down.

KNOXVILLE, Feb. 25. -- R.A. Lamar; general manager of Tennessee Public Service Company, told Knoxville's City Council yesterday that the company would he unable to meet a time limit imposed for the submission of a price on its electrical distribution properties here.

From 1914 to early last week Belgium's most distinguished citizen was King ALBERT. Who Was little Belgium's greatest personage before 1914, as measured by international reputation? On the same day that LEOPOLD III succeeded to his father's crown there was given at our Metropolitan Opera House the season's first performance of "Pelleas et Melisande." of which the music is by DEBUSSY.

The six-day bicycle race came back to Madison Square Garden last night. Despite the almost forbidding weather conditions that prevailed, about 10,000 persons made their way into the Eighth Avenue Arena in time to see Al Jolson fire the gun that started the fifteen teams on their way.

A digest of the opinions of the principals in the air-mail controversy, including the President, Colonel Lindbergh, former Postmaster Brown, Postmaster Farley and Senator Black, was offered informally in a radio talk last night by Will Rogers, talking as an aviation enthusiast.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 25. -- Tornadoes cut an erratic path of destruction across three Southern States tonight, leaving in their wake more than a score of dead and dozens of injured.

Prompt court action against slot machine vendors was promised yesterday by Assistant Attorney General John F.X. McGohey, in charge of the State Anti-Racket Bureau. Mr. McGohey announced that he would issue today subpoenas under which the 350 slot machines seized in three raids Saturday and now under police guard will be transferred to the custody of the State.

KILDARE, Irish Free State, Feb. 25 (Canadian Press). -- Civic Guards tonight scattered interrupters of a Blue Shirt meeting at which General Owen O'Duffy was speaking, charging into the ranks of hecklers and cracking heads with their batons. None was hurt seriously.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 26. -- While admitting the step, if taken, would have a vital bearing on future strategic conditions in the Pacific, a Navy Office spokesman this morning declined to comment on press reports that the United States was contemplating eventual abandonment of her naval and military bases in the Philippines.

WOODS HOLE, Mass., Feb. 25. -- Brought through the worst gale of the Winter by the heroism of one man and the endurance of six others, the seventy-foot Gloucester fishing schooner Margaret D. was feared breaking up on tiny No Man's Land Island tonight in a northeaster.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25, -- Breaking a path through jagged ice cakes, seventeen men on a fire boat battled the Delaware River for eight miles this afternoon to save the life of a dog.
The child labor amendment to the Constitution, which has been ratified by twenty States, was criticized and defended yesterday in radio addresses broadcast from WOR.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 25. -- Despite the determined efforts of the League of Nations Chaco commission to maintain the strictest secrecy regarding its peace proposal to Bolivia and Paraguay, it is learned in Latin-American diplomatic circles here that the proposal is in the form of a draft of a definite peace treaty.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- Dr. Leo Wolman has withdrawn his resignation as a member of the National Labor Board, Senator Wagner, chairman of the board, announced today. At the same time Senator Wagner, in a brief statement, denied that a division of opinion within the board had prompted Dr. Wolman's resignation.

A primary fight for control of the Kings County Democratic Organization was indicated last night on the eve of a meeting of the executive committee this afternoon to try to elect a county leader to succeed the late John H. McCooey.

BOSTON, Feb. 25. -- A large amount of police ammunition and a number of weapons, including all the State police equipment except one sub-machine gun that had been stolen from an exhibit at the recent automobile show here, were found today in a Dorchester garage that had been used by Irving and Merton Millen.

When the Republican party is so much out of joint, it is a pleasure to see even such small symptoms of unity as the consolidation of those two momentous bodies, the Republican Senatorial and Republican Congressional Campaign Committees, into a joint committee. Separate, these coaxers of the electorate have exercised an influence too subtle to trace.

Five men required treatment and dozens were less seriously injured yesterday afternoon when a marauding party of pro-Soviet Armenians attempted to break up a meeting of the Armenian Revolutionary Federation, the anti-Soviet faction, in the auditorium of the Metropolitan Life Building, 1 Madison Avenue.

LONDON, Feb. 25. -- Attacks on the royal family were cheered today when 1,600 hunger marchers from all parts of Great Britain converged on Hyde Park for a great demonstration against the government's new Unemployment Bill.

Trading by specialists on the New York Stock Exchange for their own account invites abuses which more than offset the market liquidity that may result from their operations, according to a third section of the report of the Twentieth Century Fund on security markets, made public yesterday.
VIENNA, Feb. 25. -- The German bid for the acquisition of Austria by some means which will not provoke outside reprisals is now being raised and the German Nazis are adopting a softer tone.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The Federal Reserve Board, in a report for January and up to Feb. 14, made public today, pointed to a slight increase in loans on securities and all other loans during this period, while bankers' balances showed a substantial gain.

SALISBURY MILLS, N.Y., Feb. 25. -- Competing in the face of a driving snowstorm and in near-zero temperature, Harald Sorensen gave his best performance this season as he won the Class A prize in a strong field at the annual invitation ski-jumping tourney of the Norsemen Ski Club of New York today.
CORNING, N.Y., Feb. 25. -- The mold for the 200-inch telescope mirror, the 17-foot wide "eye" which will see four times farther than before, is ready at the Corning Glass Works.

Communism and fascism are only "way-stations" on the road to social reconstruction, the Rev. Dr. Barnett R. Brickner, rabbi of the Euclid Avenue Temple, Cleveland, said in his sermon yesterday morning at Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, Reconstruction in this country, Dr. Brickner declared, would remain within the framework of democracy and would start a middle course between fascism and communism.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25. -- The grain markets are in a position where speculation on the part of the public is checked, except for moderate buying of wheat on weak spots by investors who expect a shortage of Winter wheat in the Southwest and Middle West.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 25. -- Prophesying a fundamental rebuilding of American school systems within the next decade, the joint commission on the emergency in education recommended today the drafting of a national educational plan.

Determined that the Whitney Blake Company of New Haven shall abide by an agreement to dismiss strike-breakers and reinstate former employes who had been on strike, the Regional Labor Board dispatched Mathew P. Maney, field investigator, to that city yesterday to check the payrolls of the company.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25. -- Encouraging reports regarding trade, labor and prices are coming to this city from almost all sections of the country. They indicate enlargement in buying for both immediate and future requirements, the latter holding the best promises in recent years.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Feb. 25. -- All eight occupants of the United Air Lines plane which left Salt Lake City for Rock Springs and Cheyenne, Wyo., Friday at 2 P.M., met instant death about fifteen minutes later. The big dualmotored monoplane crashed into the side of a mountain about 8,000 feet above sea level near the summit of the Wasatch Mountain Range, eighteen miles by air line from their starting point.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Feb. 25. -- President James L. McConaughy of Wesleyan University announced tonight the appointment of Jack L. Blott, All-America centre in 1923 and for ten years chief assistant football coach at the University of Michigan, as head football and baseball coach at Wesleyan to succeed Jim Oberlander.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP). -- Hearings on a long list of proposals which have been made to help the nation's schools through the next year will be begun this week by the House Education Committee.
The list of the steamship American Merchant, due today from London, includes:

Among the virtues of "Dodsworth," which opened at the Shubert Saturday evening, place Walter Huston foremost. After wasting his fragrance on the motion-picture air for the last five years he has returned to remind us that he is one of the best actors our theatre has developed.

The Real Estate Board of New York asked Mayor LaGuardia yesterday to "back up his statements of the purposes of the new Municipal Housing Authority by supporting the board's proposed amendments to the law to insure actual slum clearance and low-cost housing for those in need of it."

On page 19 of THE TIMES this morning there appears an article entitled "Portrait of Washington by Thomas Sully Found." The article, referred to as an announcement of the American Antiquarian Society, states, "Thomas Sully, early American painter who is best known for his 'Washington Crossing the Delaware.'"

AGADIR, Morocco, Feb. 25. -- Opening a "mopping up" drive against rebel Berbers in the stormswept deserts of the almost unknown Bani mountain regions, the French Foreign Legion today lost five men. Seven were wounded.

VIENNA, Feb. 25. -- Rumors of heavy fighting on the Austro-German border flitted briefly over the telephone wires of Austria today, but finally boiled down to the fact that one Nazi had been wounded and another captured in a skirmish with a border patrol.

Many dinner parties will be given in advance of the performance of "Richard of Bordeaux" tomorrow night at the Empire Theatre which has been taken over by a group of women interested in the New York City Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association to raise funds for that organization.

A manhunt by detectives of the Ralph Avenue Station in Brooklyn, which lasted for near five and a half years, ended yesterday when Joseph Marino, 58 years old, was brought back from Los Angeles to stand trial for murder. He is accused of having shot to death Charles De Presia, 34 years old, during a quarrel in front of De Presia's home at 74 Sumpter Street, Brooklyn, in August, 1928.
The text of Commissioner Alger's interim report to Governor Lehman on the mortgage situation follows:

One non-profit corporation to relieve distressed guaranteed mortgage certificates holders by means of a $100,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and a second non-profit corporation to restore neglected real estate to commercial status, are among the outstanding recommendations made by George W. Alger, Moreland Act Commissioner, in his interim report to Governor Lehman, who made public its contents yesterday.

The sanction and blessing which God has given to marriage since the very creation was stressed by the Rev. Michel Gasnier in a sermon in French yesterday morning at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent de Paul, Twenty-third Street west of Sixth Avenue. Father Gasnier spoke at the 11:30 A.M. mass.
HSINKING, Manchukuo, Feb. 25. -- General Kenji Doihara of Japan said today that there was widespread discussion among the powers of the possibility of recognizing Manchukuo.

A Te Deum in honor of the enthronement of Leopold III, the new King of the Belgians, was sung yesterday at 12:30 o'clock in St. Albert's Belgian Catholic Church, 429 West Forty-seventh Street. The congregation, which crowded the church, included diplomats, representatives of the army and navy, and World War Veterans' Associations.

All of the favorites survived as the second round of the Metropolitan Class B squash racquets tournament was completed at the Harvard Club yesterday. Twelve more competitors advanced to the third round to reduce the field to sixteen from the original fifty entrants.

Two police captains in Queens have applied for retirement March 17, it was learned yesterday. They are Captain Phillip F. Clifford, 67 years old, of the Glendale precinct, and Captain Jacob Ross, 66, of the Newtown precinct.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, speaking from the White House in Washington, made an appeal over the radio during the intermission of yesterday's concert for support of the Philharmonic-Symphony's campaign for a guarantee fund of $500,000.

BERLIN, Feb. 24. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's address to the Central Association of Bankers was received favorably. His new repudiation of designs to devalorize the mark induced a sharp advance in fixed-interest securities. Nevertheless, Dr. Schacht, who is the head of the Reichsbank, admitted that the desire for devalorization continued to be expressed in export circles.

Lawrence Tibbett singing "Old Man River," with all-star chorus by the "American Ensemble of the Metropolitan Opera Association," and a stage orchestra reinforced with professional jazz banjo, piano, xylophones and drums, ended a nearly three-hour "opera concert," which sent a loyal audience home, humming and whistling, from the Metropolitan in last night's blizzard-bound streets.

When John J. McGraw finally hung up his spangles a lot of color faded out of big league baseball. For a few years afterward he fidgeted on the bench and managed his Giants from there, but the McGraw in civilian clothes was not the same as the doughty little warrior bustling to the plate to bawl out an umpire or bait an opponent.

The cotton market here was moderately active last week. It was the opinion in the trade that the volume of business in the futures market was the smallest in several weeks, although there were periods of rather pronounced activity.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25. -- Edward G. Budd said today that the recommendations of the National Compliance Board in connection with the long standing labor dispute at his plant here were, as he understood them, "in line with the company's wishes throughout."

BERLIN. Feb. 24. -- Berlin bankers consider that the gold movement to the United States must weaken -- and not strengthen -- the motives, if such exist, for abandoning the gold standard by the European central banks. The view here also is that further deflationary measures or advances in the discount rates of gold countries are probable.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25. -- Philadelphia came from behind today to defeat New York, 3 matches to 2, in the inaugural team play of the intercity professional squash racquets competition.
In his attack on the Utilities Bill advocated by Governor Lehman, at the public hearing on Feb. 20, Floyd Carlisle, chairman of the Niagara-Hudson Company, is quoted as saying:

CLEVELAND, Feb. 25. -- Mrs. Hugh Fullerton, widow of a departmerit store executive, was visiting friends in Breeksville. this evening when word came at her home in Cleveland Ieights that her son William was a victim of monoxide gas at Dartmouth.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- The first national radio reunion of the Women's Overseas League, arranged and directed by Miss Mary Frances Hall of New York City, was held this afternoon.

New Jersey slipped and skidded and plowed through the snow yesterday, delayed and inconvenienced, but the main roads were kept open and streets in all of the larger cities were clear enough for traffic to proceed. Commuters' trains to and from New York were able to maintain both morning and evening rush schedules with only minor delays.

Mrs. Lottie Kreisberger Coll, widow of the gangster, Vincent Coll, and two codefendants pleaded guilty to lesser charges yesterday morning, unexpectedly bringing to an end their trial for murder in the first degree. The trial had lasted eight days in Judge Harry Stackell's part of Bronx County Court.

The Western Pacific Railroad announced yesterday that it had asked the holders of all its certificates of funded debt, except equipment trust issues, to forego until Jan. 1, 1937, the receipt of interest due in 1934. Interest due Thursday on the company's first mortgage bonds has been deferred.

More than sixty large banks in leading Eastern cities have become contributing members of the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., providing an aggregate of $70,000 a year for three years. The council estimates that it needs $150,000 a year and is now enrolling bondholders, country banks and producers of goods for export as contributing members.

The Board of Estimate yesterday appropriated $4,850,000 for purchase of supplies and materials for CWA projects for March and April. The appropriation was contingent upon a grant of $2,600,000 by the CWA for similar purposes. The latter amount was allocated by the Civil Works Administration.

Butler Brothers reported for 1933 a net income after depreciation, taxes, interest, reserve for doubtful accounts and other deductions, of $1,572,459. This is equivalent to $1.38 a share on 1,138,110 $10 par capital shares and contrasted with a net loss of $2,084,628 in 1932.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 26. -- An 8 on the eleventh hole, the result of a mixture of duffer's golf and ill fortune, blocked Horton Smith, the tall blond from Oak Park, Ill., in his effort to win the 1934 Gasparilla open golf championship at the Palma Ceia Club today.

Disregard of the Multiple Dwelling Law in lower East Side tenements was denounced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. George W. Grinton, superintendent of the Five Points Mission, in an address to 150 women at a luncheon in the Hotel George Washington celebrating the ninetieth anniversary of the mission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Senator David A. Reed of Pennsylvania accepted promptly today the challenge of Governor Gifford Pinchot, who announced his candidacy against him. When Governor Pinchot's statement attacking him was shown to him shortly after the Senate began its session, Senator Reed consulted several colleagues and then wrote this brief reply:
