MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 26. -- Long Island faced its second serious storm within a week partly prepared to meet its rigors and inevitable hardships. Unlike the severe situation last Tuesday, residents had been forewarned and were ready to cope with the problem.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Mrs. Roosevelt said today that her first year in the White House had been an educational experience of absorbing interest.

LONDON, Feb. 26. -- With the exception of British Government funds, which strengthened further, the stock market was dull today. There was profit-taking in industrials following the Chancellor of the Exchequer's statement concerning the coming budget. International issues were lower on weekend Wall Street news.

BOSTON, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Four murders, three bank and two theatre robberies and the theft of about $55,000 may be charged to two "ordinary young fellows" and their youthful boss by the police of six Massachusetts communities.

Dreda Aves and Aida Doninelli, formerly of the Metropolitan Opera Company, will sing the roles of Carmen and Micaela, respectively, in tonight's performance of "Carmen" by the San Carlo Grand Opera Company at the Casino Theatre. Aroldo Lindi is announced as the Don Jose and Mostyn Thomas as the Escamillo.
PASADENA, Feb. 26 (AP). -- The "money trust" still exists, Samuel Untermyer, New York lawyer, charged in a speech here tonight.

Total assets and net surplus of the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company reached high records at the end of 1933. Total assets were $25,014,253, against $23,953,121 a year earlier, and net surplus increased from $4,051,491 to $4,170,357 in the year.

While bus services to local and near-by points in New Jersey and Long Island were reported to have suffered little on account of the snowstorm, motor travel to Boston and other New England points virtually ceased yesterday.

Police Commissioner O'Ryan made known yesterday that forty-one members of the department had applied to date for retirement as a result of the recent decision to retire on pension all policemen over sixty-five years old unless they could show that they should be retained on duty.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 26. -President Angell of Yale University announced today the establishment of a Sala Italiana, together with a gift from the Italian Government of more than 300 books for the sala, which will form another centre for the foreign language groups, which already include El Centro Espanol, Les Thelemites and Der Deutsche Verein.

Cash dividend payments by the companies of the Standard Oil group for the first quarter of this year are estimated at $24,424,434, according to a compilation by Carl H. Pforzheimer Co. This compares with $42,457,920 in the preceding quarter and $32,406,332 in the first quarter of 1933.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on Feb. 21 shows increases for the week of $62,000,000 in loans, $332,000,000 in United States Government securities, $427,000,000 in government deposits and $28,000,000 in time deposits, and a decrease of $86,000,000 in net demand deposits.

There are nautical notes too, although fairly incidental, in J.W. Golinkin's show, which opens today at the Macbeth Galleries. A kind of jolly "Sailor Beware" (or everybody else beware) episode bears the incommunicative title "Sands Street Gate," and there are some riverside bathing scenes that, with variations, pursue the Bellows tradition. Of these "The Jack Knife" is especially arresting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- The administration will reach a decision this week as to what recommendations will be made to Congress relative to the establishment of Intermediate Credit Banks in the Federal Reserve Districts for the extension of loans to business and industry.
The first twenty-eight railroads to report for January more than tripled their net operating income compared with January, 1933, and more than quadrupled it compared with January, 1932.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

LINDSBORG, Kan., Feb. 26 (AP). -- Once more this little town in Central Kansas, the seat of Bethany College, prepares to welcome lovers of sacred music in their pilgrimages from far and near. The Bethany Oratorio Society, rehearsing its chorus of more than 500 voices for its traditional singing of the "Messiah," unites the generations of dwellers in the "Oberammergau of the Plains."

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop's signed statement that she accidentally killed her daughter-in-law, Rheta, and her alleged subsequent verbal admission that she did it "to save the poor dear," went into the evidence at her trial for murder today with no discernible effect on the defendant's composure.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- The Westchester County Advisory Finance Committee, headed by Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley, which has been working to straighten out the financial condition of Westchester towns and cities since December, made its report today to the Board of Supervisors.

ROME, Feb. 26. -- In a conversation of an hour and a quarter today, Captain Anthony Eden, British Lord Privy Seal, obtained Premier Mussolini's acceptance of the British disarmament memorandum of Jan. 29 as a basis for discussion. So successful did he consider his talk that he decided to cut short his stay in Rome and hurry back to Paris a day in advance of his original schedule.

Most of the markets met a further setback yesterday. Business, because of the difficult weather conditions, was curtailed. Prices were lower on the Stock Exchange, the Chicago Board of Trade and the Cotton Exchange. The bond market was also heavy.

Stating that no code or regulation so far drawn has proved strong enough to circumvent the schemes and methods which unscrupulous manufacturers and dealers will use to maintain volume in the face of falling prices, C. Bertram Plante, president of the Bond Electric Corporation, of Jersey City, yesterday appealed to President Roosevelt and General Johnson to remedy evils created by the "open price filing plan" in the electrical manufacturers' and other codes.

Four seeded players advanced to the quarter-final round of the national Class B squash tennis championship as a result of triumphs yesterday at the City Athletic Club. The surviving players were Seymour L. Samuels, Harold Ablowich, Edward L. Kemble and Ludlow Vandeventer.

The value of conservation in the United States never has been figured in dollars and cents, due to the inability of all States to corelate their financial statements. However, it is plain that if the program of national conservation is carried out -- and this seems certain now the ten-year plan has been arranged -- it will call for an expenditure of $100,000,000.

Miss Edith Woolsey of New Haven, winner of the women's New Jersey State championship, gained the quarter-final round of the fourth annual invitation squash racquets tournament of the Junior League yesterday as play started on the league courts on East Seventy-first Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP). -- For the country's natural resources, the Roosevelt Administration has a "twenty-five or fifty-year plan," Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, said in an address tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Civil Works Administration regulations prohibiting snow removal as a CWA project were relaxed today in thirty-three States, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, after a flood of requests for this work had been received by Harry L. Hopkins, Civil Works Administrator.

Twenty-two firms holding membership in the New York Stock Exchange which do an international arbitrage business in securities and also act as commission brokers have formed a committee to call the attention of Congress to the effect which the Fletcher-Rayburn bill would have on the arbitrage business.

All baseball authorities speak of the late JOHN J. MCGRAW in superlatives. CONNIE MACK called him "the outstanding manager of all time." A small man physically compared with ADRIAN ANSON of the old Chicago White Stockings, he was also a natural team leader. MCGRAW was the admired of the grand stand and the bleachers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Being composed chiefly of Washington people, who know more members of Congress at close range than any other American group, the audience in Senator Black's committee room Saturday naturally burst into a roar of laughter when ex-Postmaster General Brown finally told what his successor is supposed to have said to him about the Senator:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Creation of a Federal communications commission to control transmission by telephone, telegraph, wireless and cable was urged upon Congress today by President Roosevelt in a special message which followed the recent recommendations of his special interdepartmental committee.

All the European motorboat drivers who had gathered here left by train yesterday afternoon for Florida and the international races that start at New Smyrna on Saturday. The trials for the selection of the American team to meet the foreign contingent will start there tomorrow.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 26. -Three of eight men being tried for conspiracy to obstruct justice in the Passaic County jury-fixing investigation took the stand today as the defense opened its case. The three entered general denial of the charges that they had taken part in a conspiracy to keep out of the State three others wanted on jury-fixing charges.

VIENNA, Feb. 26. -- Under the presidency of Duke Max of Hohenberg, son of the former heir to the Austro-Hungarian monarchy, Franz Ferdinand, who was assassinated at Sarajevo in 1914, a monarchist demonstration of 4,000 persons was held tonight in Vienna.

NEWARK. N.J., Feb. 26. -- Vice Chancellor Berry today directed trustees of the Fidelity Union Title and Mortgage Company of Newark to make partial repayment promptly to those who had invested through the company. This action had been recommended by William H. Kelly, State Commissioner of Banking, and Merritt Lane, counsel to the trustees.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 26. -- New social teachings which, if adopted, would consign to the scrap heap many present-day text-books, were urged today from a dozen platforms upon 7,000 school executives from all parts of the country attending the annual convention of the National Education Association's Department of Superintendence here.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26. -- With Manager Bill Terry speeding Northward to attend the funeral of his illustrious predecessor, John McGraw, the Giants made a valiant effort today to shake off the air of depression that has settled over the camp the past twenty-four hours.

SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 25 (AP). -A mountain snowstorm, which investigators believe caused the crash of the United Air Lines plane in the Wasatch Mountains, near this city, Friday with a loss of eight lives, hampered an investigation of the tragedy and the recovery of one body today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 26. -- The newspaper Pravda continues its drive in behalf of the mastery of industrial technique and management by Russians, and it publishes today an interesting comparison of the work in the past three months of two railroad political sections.

Four Harvard Club men were among the players who gained the quarter finals of the Class B squash racquets championship tourney at the Harvard Club yesterday. Two from the Princeton Club, one from the Squash Club and one from Ardsley complete the bracket.

Reports that the Agricultural Committee of the House had made several important tentative changes in the Bankhead bill had a depressing effect yesterday on prices on the Cotton Exchange. The market was under pressure from the start, partly in sympathy with weakness in securities, and closed at the bottom, 21 to 26 points lower than on Saturday.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 26. -- Equaling the women's course record with her individual card of 37, 35 -- 72, Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L.I., former national titleholder, won low gross honors today in the mixed foursome competition over the St. Augustine links with John Dimick of Seawane as her partner.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26. -The patio of El Mirasol, with adjoining loggias and gardens, provided the setting today for a reception for more than 300 guests, with which Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury entertained in celebration of Mr. Stotesbury's eighty-fifth birthday.
The nation-wide death toll swelled to more than sixty yesterday as snowstorms pelted the northeastern quarter of the country and as rain, hail and wind storms continued to devastate the South.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 26 (AP). -- Taking some of the liberality out of Arkansas's ninety-day divorce law, the State Supreme Court today offered advice for patching up marital difficulties.

Joshua L. Cowen, director of the Bank of United States and uncle of Bernard K. Marcus, the president, has been eliminated from the $60,000,000 suit by Joseph A. Broderick, Superintendent of Banks, against the directors for alleged waste of the bank's assets, on an agreement to pay $5,000, it was announced yesterday.

MONTREAL, Que., Feb. 26. -- A financial statement for 1933 has just been mailed to shareholders of the Beauharnois Power Corporation, Ltd. It is the first statement issued since reorganization was sanctioned by bondholders and shareholders last May, when the Montreal Power plan was adopted.

Frances Hall and Rudolph Gruen gave a program of music for two pianos at the Town Hall last night. They began with a Scarlatti Suite of three sonatas, arranged by Felix Swinstead, and followed with Franck's Prelude, Fugue and Variations, in Mr. Gruen's transcription.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26. -- Governor Gifford Pinchot's statement announcing his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Senator was received in some quarters here with surprise, inasmuch as the Governor had indicated he would defer entering the contest until next month. His continued absence from Harrisburg on account of illness also had given rise to reports that his physical condition would make it impossible for him to wage a campaign.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 26. -- William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets of New York City, told the Rutgers University Institute of Rural Economics today that "even the new Tammany District Attorney, Mr. Dodge, I'm convinced, is going after the racketeers."

Dr. ELLSWORTH HUNTINGTON of Yale, who has experienced some very bad climates in Russian and Chinese Turkestan and Siberia, proclaims that the best climate in the United States -- that is to say, the most conducive to "steady efficiency" -- occurs along the Atlantic Coast from Boston to Atlantic City. The best mental work can be done, he says, when the temperature averages about 40 degrees.

Generally lower prices were registered yesterday in the listed bond market, with domestic corporation bonds suffering the most, many declining 1 to 4 points. The domestic industrials, rails and utilities averaged lower in the order named. United States Government bonds were generally lower, 12-32 point lower to 2-32 point higher.

BERLIN, Feb. 26. -- Premier Mussolini's "diplomatic invasion" of the Danube area continues to keep German editorial speculation on edge. Conjectures as to its ultimate ramifications envisage anything from a tripartite customs union to a Hapsburg restoration.

The Northwood School of Lake Placid administered the first defeat of the season to Poly Prep yesterday as the up-Staters triumphed in a hockey game at the Brooklyn Ice Palace, 4 to 0. The Brooklyn sextet had won seven games in a row before bowing to Northwood.
HSINKING, Tuesday, Feb. 27. -Conflict over preparations for the enthronement of Henry Pu Yi is upsetting officials here.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Feb. 26. -Miss Mary O'Connell, 45 years old, a buyer for a Youngstown (Ohio) store, told her story of tonight's train wreck here from a bed in Presbyterian Hospital. Her back and knee were injured.

On application of John J. Miller of Montclair, N.J., a holder of approximately $100,000 worth of guaranteed bonds, Federal Judge John C. Knox signed yesterday an order requiring three companies to show cause why they should not be declared insolvent and have receivers in equity appointed for them.

DUBLIN, Feb. 26. -- General Owen O'Duffy's Blue Shirt organization won another round today in the legal battle being waged between themselves and President de Valera's Government in a decision by Judge Johnston of the High Court of Dublin.

Two alternation projects totaling $300,000 were filed with the Manhattan Department of Buildings yesterday. The two four-story Sheffield Farms Company warehouses at 614-44 West 126th Street were listed for a $200,000 change by William C. Stohldreier and Robert C. Zetsche, architects.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Rapidly pyramiding commercial business was said today by Edward P. Warner, former Assistant Secretary of the Navy, to have been largely responsible for 40 and 50 per cent profits made on navy airplane engine contracts from 1926 to 1929.

Hobbies to "fill quiet hours" and to take one "into the open air" were suggested for every girl yesterday in a letter from Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt to the Camp Fire Girls. She accepted an invitation to speak at a reception and tea at the Waldorf-Astoria Thursday in celebration of the twenty-second birthday of the Camp Fire Girls.

Sir James Dunn, Captain Lionel Dawson, Wing Commander A.B. Beauman and Major Schoolfield Grace are among the passengers due this afternoon from England and France on the White Star liner Olympic. Others arriving on the ship are:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- James Stewart Co., Inc., of New York City, received today the contract for construction at a price of $4,287,700 of the main building of the New York Postoffice annex, adjacent to the Pennsylvania Railroad Station. The bid was the lowest of five received.

The cancellation of the air-mail contracts in such a summary manner appears to have aroused a wave of suppressed disappointment. Perhaps the reason for the lack of more widespread disapproval is that criticism of the administration is considered unpatriotic.

Funeral services for Edward F. and Alfred Moldenke, the two sons of the Rev. Dr. Alfred B, Moldenke, who died from carbon monoxide gas at Dartmouth College, will be held at 8 P.M. Thursday in St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, where their father has been pastor for thirty-eight years.
An army of 35,000 men labored all day yesterday under the direction of the Sanitation Department to keep the city's main traffic arteries cleared of the fast-falling snow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- The National Compliance Board today announced that a hearing would be held at Chester, Pa., in a few days on complaints that the Ford Motor Company's plant there had discriminated against employes who had struck.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 26. -Two Cabinet members and a former Secretary of State received honorary degrees from Rollins College today at Founders Day convocation. The recipients were Attorney General Homer S. Cummings, Doctor of Laws, and Secretary Daniel C. Roper and Frank B. Kellogg, Doctor of Humanities.
Snow that fell for more than thirty-six hours and was swept by a brisk nor easter into deep drifts in rural and suburban areas blanketed the northern part of the nation yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP). -Congress was told today by Representative McFadden that at the famous "log conference" between Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald of Great Britain and President Hoover at the latter's Rapidan camp, Mr. Hoover refused to accept the Bermuda Islands in part payment of England's war debt to this country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- A report, showing in detail the huge bonuses and other extra compensation paid to executive officers and directors by many of the great corporations of the country in the boom years, particularly 1928, 1929 and 1930, was transmitted to the Senate today by the Federal Trade Commission.

LORAIN, Ohio, Feb. 26 (AP). -Lieutenant Alber J. Harmon, Michigan national guard flier, fell to his death on the ice of Lake Erie east of here late today, soon after he took off from Cleveland for Detroit on an unofficial flight.

Announcement was made yesterday by the Regional Labor Board that on Thursday it would take a poll of the 1,450 employes of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company to determine whether they wished to remain affiliated with the company union maintained by the line or become members of the Amalgamated Association of Street and Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employes, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.

Heeding a last-minute request of the Washington administration, the Brooklyn Democratic organization yesterday named a triumvirate of district leaders to succeed the late John H. McCooey as county leader. They will manage the affairs of the organization until after the Fall primaries.
ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- The insurgency of Senator McNaboe, Democrat, of New York, led to the defeat in the Senate tonight of one of the bills recommended by Governor Lehman in his executive budget.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Feb. 26. -- Bucknell University tonight announced that E.E. Mylin had been selected as head football coach to succeed Carl Snavely, who has accepted the coaching post at North Carolina University.

There will be two performances of Richard Wagner's "Parsifal" at the Metropolitan Opera House this season. The usual Good Friday performance will take place on March 30, several days before the season ends, and the other performance is expected to be given on one of the evenings of that week, probably in a regular subscription series.

The greater experience of Mrs. William I. Seaman of Emerson Hill, S.I., the champion of the New York Women's Chess Club, enabled her to triumph when play was resumed yesterday in the deciding game for first place in the women's tournament at the Marshall Club.

Textile and Seward Park continued their drives for the Manhattan P.S.A.L. basketball championship yesterday by scoring triumphs. Textile defeated Stuyvesant, 23 to 19, at the Commerce gymnasium and Sewaro conquered Haaren, 31 to 18, on its own court.
MIAMI, Feb. 26. -- The first international sailing yacht race between Miami and Nassau, Bahamas -- approximately 220 miles -- will start here at noon tomorrow, with more than twenty craft entered.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday that he had received the completed architects' plans for the nine new zoo buildings to be erected in Central Park at a cost of more $400,000. The drawings were completed by CWA engineers and draughtsmen in sixteen working days.
Prices for commodity futures on local exchanges declined yesterday in sympathy with the general trend in outside markets. The volume of transactions ran at a high level. Cash prices also declined.

HALIFAX, Feb. 26 (Canadian Press). -- Isobel Wylie Hutchison does not mind the cold up in the Arctic Circle, but she says Winter in New York is a bit trying, even to one who has spent almost a year around the top of the world.

Governor Gifford Pinchot of Pennsylvania, for more than thirty years a thorn in the side of the Republican organization of that State, announced yesterday that he would run for United States Senator against Senator David A. Reed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP). -- The oil administration, with the approval of Secretary Ickes, today fixed the March allowable production of gasoline at 31,791,000 barrels, an increase of 4,651,000 barrels over the February total.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- The desultory House debate on the Agricultural Department Appropriation Bill was enlivened late today when Representative Blanton of Texas charged that some of the most influential men in charge of emergency relief work were Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Acquisition by the Chespeake Ohio Railroad of new equipment costing $16,876,480 with a loan of that amount from the Public Works Administration was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Declaring that the Republican party "has completely broken down" in the leadership of its forces in the State and nation, Chase Mellen Jr., chairman of the New York County Committee of that organization, urged yesterday its rehabilitation to deal with the problems now facing the national administration.

Several dinners will be given in advance of the performance of "Dodsworth" tonight at the Shubert Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the boys bureau of the Charity Organization Society and the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.
The inspiration for men's fashions for the coming year was derived from two major national developments -- the repeal of prohibition and the National Industrial Recovery Act.

BERLIN, Feb. 26. -- The Boerse opened the week with considerable irregularity, but gains predominated. The public bought considerably, the drop in the Reichsbank gold coverage below 10 per cent having been offset by Dr. Schacht's emphatic avowal of currency stability.

According to the authors of "Ragged Army," which was staged at the Selwyn last evening, the American Revolution was won by revolutionaries. This novel idea ruins the fastidious historical pageant which is being staged in Dunbury, New England, by the contemporary magnificoes of that venerable town.

PARIS, Feb. 26. -- So much that is not evidence or fact is being published and said in connection with the killing of Albert Prince, Paris lawyer, that it has become almost impossible to distinguish what is intentional falsehood and what is simply nonsense.

MOSCOW, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Facing death from drowning or exposure, 545 fishermen and 330 horses were drifting helplessly on two separate ice floes in the Caspian Sea today while an airplane from Moscow sped to their assistance.

In reading the letter headed "Sanitation Suggestions," especially paragraph 10, in which Mrs. Flora Spiegelberg would have the Health or Sanitation Department endeavor to penalize offending owners of dogs, I desire to call attention to the following taken from the present Sanitary Code:

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 26. -- The first trial growing out of the recent investigation into gambling conditions in Irvington was opened today by Prosecutor William A. Wachenfeld. He charged that August L. Lacombe, Director of Public Safety, and Andrew Coleman, suspended Chief of Police, knowingly allowed slot machines to be operated in at least thirty-five establishments in the town.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- An effort to break the holding company control of mail-carrying air lines and in so doing to force financial reorganization of most of the former holders of Federal air-mail contracts was begun today in the House Postoffice's Committee.

Except for a slightly easier tone in four months' money, a small amount of which came in and was done at 1 per cent, there was little else of interest in the day's money market. Stock Exchange call loans remained at I per cent, while Street trades were fractionally lower, Commercial paper and acceptances were quiet.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 27. -- The Daily Mail and The Daily Express announce that the long-discussed reconstruction of the national government has actually started with the decision by Prime Minister MacDonald yesterday to form a special Ministry to press on with slum clearance and house building.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- President Roosevelt wrote to Speaker Rainey today that he would not approve the Patman $2,400,000,000 bonus bill, and bluntly declared that if the measure was passed by Congress he would return it with his veto.

More than 20,000 independent retailers in the cleaning and dyeing industry who had closed their shops last week in protest against chain stores accused of violating the price fixing provisions of the industry's code resumed operations yesterday. They acted on the request of NRA officials, who assured them that everything possible was being done to enforce the code.

Eugene J. Shields, formerly a deputy fire marshal, was convicted of arson in the second degree last night by a jury before Judge Franklin Taylor in the Kings County Court. He faces a maximum sentence of fifteen years' imprisonment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- General Johnson today appointed Leon Henderson of the Russell Sage Foundation to the post vacated by Colonel Robert H. Montgomery, Chief of the NRA Research and Planning Division.

The prediction that eventually there would rise "a new Austria that will incarnate the hopes and ideals" for which Austrian Socialists died in the recent rebellion, was made yesterday by James Oneal in a radio address.
Variety marked the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday, the parcels including a church, several flats, taxpayers and dwellings.

McNEIL ISLAND, Wash., Feb. 26 (AP). -- Rather than take the pauper's oath and remain another thirty days in prison, Ralph Capone will pay a $10,000 fine, a reliable source reported today, and will obtain his release from the Federal penitentiary tomorrow.

Aided by an unfinished run of 111, Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia gained a substantial lead in his challenge match for the world's pocket-billiard title against Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland, defending champion, last night at the Capitol Academy.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 26. -- The question of how much financial help the nation's schools may be able to get from the Federal Government was the prime subject here today for thousands of school superintendents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Secretary Hull will appear before the Senate Finance Committee tomorrow morning, he said today, to answer questions about the State Department's attitude toward the pending Costigan Sugar Bill. The committee finished its hearings today and will advise with the Secretary in executive session.

William Frank McGee, partner in the bucketshop of E.M. Fuller Co., which failed for $5,000,000 in 1922, died in obscurity and under an assumed name last Saturday, it became known early this morning when his body was positively identified by Detective John Samuelson, a veteran of the Bureau of Criminal Identification.
President Roosevelt, naturally, is under criticism by those who wish to find justification for criticism for the transfer of air mail to the army.

BERLIN, Feb. 26. -- A "propaganda alliance" that is probably unique in international affairs has been concluded between Germany and Poland, according to an official announcement issued here today. The "alliance" was concluded in conferences held in Berlin between competent German authorities and M. Przesmaychi, chief of the press department of the Polish Foreign Office.

State and private agencies rushed yesterday to the aid of the State's wild bird and animal life, threatened with starvation by the two snowstorms. Lithgow Osborne, State Conservation Commissioner, announced in Albany that extensive plans had been completed to provide food and that several thousand dollars had been set aside to feed ducks, quail, pheasants and rabbits.
TURIN, Italy, Feb. 26. -- Twelve years ago Smerildo Gonnella, owner of a 1,000,000-lire farm near here, decided he was going to die and made due preparations.
LONDON, Feb. 26. -- A new play, "Windfall," by Robert C. Sherriff, author of "Journey's End," was produced a: the Embassy Theairo tonight.

Concerning the libretto of the Gertrude Stein-Virgil Thomson opera there is among the music reviewers what one might call a nonsensus of opinion. They all agree that the Stein text doesn't mean anything and couldn't possibly mean anything.

Jim Londos, former titleholder, added Sam Stein of Newark to his long list of victims for a second time last night. Londos threw Stein in 48:55 of the feature wrestling match at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.

Retail fish dealers of this city and vicinity put into effect yesterday a boycott against wholesalers which paralyzed Fulton Fish Market and led to a serious scarcity of fish throughout the affected area.

UTICA, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Six of sixteen occupants of the Marrone Hotel were burned to death in a fire that swept through the twenty-five-year-old wooden structure of four stories near the heart of the city early today. Before the smoke cleared a demand for the resignation of the fire chief and fire commissioner had been made by a Supervisor living in the ward.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 26. -Upper class eating clubs at Princeton University elected 437 members from the sophomore class today, the first of "Bicker Week."

Reviewing recent studies of school expenditures in its current bulletin the Public Education Association supports recommendations for full statutory State aid and regrets tendencies which might lessen educational standards.

The Metropolitan Opera Association's performance of "Faust," scheduled to take place tonight at Hartford, Conn., has been postponed until March 13 due to the weather. Although the unusual forehanded arrangements had been made as to trains and the shipment of scenery, reports of the blizzard from New England led the Metropolitan management to cancel the performance lest Mme. Rethberg, Mme. Swarthout and Mme. Wakefield and Martinelli, Pinza, Bonelli and Ananian be stranded on the way.

A railroad tie-up comparable with any on record caused complete disruption of the Long Island Railroad yesterday on all its divisions. The evening rush hour at both the Pennsylvania Station and the Long Island station in Brooklyn brought conditions suggestive of those at the New York Stock Exchange on one of its wild days.
BERLIN, Feb. 26 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Feb. 23 shows the following changes, in reichsmarks:

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 26 (AP). -- Brides have been known to delete the word "obey" from their marriage vows, but Mrs. Rex E. Buxton, University of Michigan co-ed, went a step further and devised a brand-new ceremony.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Lester Stoefen of California led the United States playing brigade into action in the annual Bermuda tennis championships today. He overwhelmed Sargeant Weller of Bermuda, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 26. -- The question was raised here today as to how the nine students at the Theta Chi house died of carbon monoxide while their windows were open. An explanation, in which the medical referee, the janitor and a professor of the college chemistry department, who asked his name be withheld, agreed, is something as follows:

PARIS, Feb. 26. -- Reflecting the general uneasiness that is felt regarding the political outlook, the Bourse today was heavy and inactive. This was the more surprising because the Senate, which today began discussion of the budget, is certain to ratify the full powers accorded the government by the Chamber of Deputies to impose by decree the economies necessary to balance expenditures with income.

The basic tax rate for 1934 would be $2.48 instead of $2.56 if the city had obeyed the Appellate Division's mandate that tax funds should not be used to pay debt service of completed independent subway lines, the Citizens Budget Commission declared yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 26. -- As a result of its 9-7 victory over Princeton in an overtime game on Saturday, Dartmouth is in first place in the Quadrangular Hockey League, with one game to play, according to the standings announced today by Asa S. Bushnell of Princeton, league secretary.

LONDON, Feb. 26. -- The hunger marchers, who demonstrated at Hyde Park yesterday, will attempt to send a delegation into the House of Commons tomorrow to protest against the government's unemployment bill.

A disgruntled barber prisoner slashed three keepers with his razor, seriously wounding two of them, yesterday in the Men's Detention Prison, which is in the Harlem Court Building in 121st Street, between Third Avenue and Sylvan Place. Then, realizing his fight had been futile, the prisoner cut his own throat.

Imports of $8,050,000 gold were reported by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday, indicating a marked slowing down in the pace at which gold is being cleared through the Assay Office. Including yesterday's official receipts, imports reported for February to date amounted to $328,433,900, against estimated actual arrivals in the period of about $360,000,000.

Municipal ownership of public utilities in New York State is inevitable unless present utility regulations are reorganized, Professor James C. Bonbright of Columbia University declared yesterday at a special meeting of the New York City League of Women Voters at the Studio Club, 210 East Seventy-seventh Street.

The dismissal of Mrs. Florence M. Grant, acting director of the City Free Employment Bureau, and of the bulk of the staff was announced yesterday by William Hodson, Commissioner of the Department of Public Welfare.

Beginning on Thursday retail liquor stores may sell consumers three gallons of liquor and an equal quantity of wine at one time under a ruling made yesterday by the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board.

TORONTO, Feb. 26 (Canadian Press). -- Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company, Ltd., report for January gross revenues of $2,346,166, against $2,305,568 in January, 1933, an Increase of $40,598; operating expenses of $1,153,957, an Increase of $68,407, and net earnings of $1,192,209, against $1,220,018, a decrease of $27,809.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- Liquidation developed again today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade and wheat fell 1 1/2 cents a bushel at the extreme to the lowest point since Jan. 13, while oats were the lowest since Dec. 4. Corn equaled last week's bottom mark, which was the lowest since Dec. 28.

DETROIT, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Although official explanation was withheld today at the Ford Motor Company's offices on the announcement that the concern had contracted for a $10,000,000 expansion program in its steel mills, it was reported authoritatively that the company had no intention of producing even the major part of its own steel requirements.

With practically its entire strength centred in the field events, Yale has nominated a team of forty-nine men for the thirteenth annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. championships at the Garden on Monday. This was announced by James A. Taylor yesterday upon receipt of entries by events, filed by Coach Frank Kanaly.

Hailed as "the greatest exhibition of paintings of the sea ever brought to New York," a group of forty-two marines by the well-known academician, Frederick J. Waugh, goes on view at the Fifth Avenue branch of the Grand Central Galleries with a private showing this afternoon from 3 to 6 o'clock. The canvases may be seen by the public beginning tomorrow.

Representatives of all branches of the garment trades attended a ceremony yesterday marking the first use of the Code Authority NRA label by the blouse and skirt industry. The observance followed a luncheon at the Hotel New Yorker.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 26. -- The Greentree Stable's Curacao snapped the four-race winning streak of Blessed Event in the featured Indian River Purse at Hialeah Park today.

Officials of the Bronx Gas and Electric Company defended its gas rates yesterday at the Public Service Commission's hearing on the city's complaint. They presented evidence that this company's expenses were higher than those of other system companies and that the frequently attacked joint facilities agreement with the Consolidated Gas Company resulted in savings to the Bronx company.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Feb. 26 (AP). -- One of the most ambitious homestead projects in the government's New Deal program was formally placed on the market today and prospective buyers literally swamped the offices of the Mahoning Homestead Gardens, Inc., with home-buying applications.

Resolved, That the snowfall in these parts has increased, is increasing and ought to be diminished. Snow is all right in its place. It raises the devil in cities. It is an expensive and dangerous nuisance and curse. It is distinctly rural. It is good for the crops, but it sticks in the crop of town-dweller and commuter.

SEGUIN, Texas, Feb. 26 (AP). -Gerald W. Peck, Chicago financier and grandson of George W. Peck Sr., author of "Peck's Bad Boy," was shot and killed by a disgruntled farmer, Tom Hollamon Sr., 67 years old, at a directors' meeting of the Texas Hydro-Electric Company here today.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., Feb. 26. -Aroused by the discussion of recent air-mail mishaps, Brig. Gen. William Mitchell, former Chief of the Army Air Corps, has come to the defense of the service aviators who have been flying the mails. He places the blame on poor equipment.

Purchases by operators in Manhattan and the Bronx featured the urban realty trading reported yesterday. Four Manhattan properties and three Bronx holdings offered at foreclosure auctions were bid in by the respective plaintiffs.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- Westchester County was gradually being snowed under tonight. The experiences of the last heavy snow had forewarned transportation companies, but as the snow continued during the night they began to fear that the storm was going to get the best of them.
Twelve young women began yesterday a three-weeks' weight reducing contest, the idea being to popularize grapefruit juice, the sponsors said.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 26 (AP). -Mayor F.H. LaGuardia of New York City asked the Supreme Court today to set aside an injunction prohibiting his police from seizing slot machines unless actually being used in gambling.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 26. -- Dartmouth's basketball team defeated Yale tonight, 23 to 19, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game. Stangle, right guard, set the pace for the victors with seven points.

OTTAWA, Feb. 26 (Canadian Press). -- The House of Commons tonight approved the world silver agreement negotiated at London last June, under which the producing nations took steps to stabilize prices. The pact received almost unanimous endorsement, only E.J. Young, Liberal of Weyburn, Sask., shouting disapproval. There was no record vote.

There are gratifying indications at Washington that the air-mail controversy will soon pass from the realm of passion to the rule of reason. One can understand the heat which has been generated. But it is time now for a cool reconsideration of the whole question and for amicable decision about the right thing to do.
In the old days when stout Uncle Robbie was the guardian of the Flatbush Flock and the antics of the rollicking team were mentioned lightly, Uncle Robbie would puff up and say:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Senator Costigan, Democrat of Colorado, tonight denounced the New York Stock Exchange for wrapping its financial operations in secrecy and asserted that the great market place, its policies and decisions were controlled by a "small handful of men."
Air-mail service out of the Newark Airport was resumed at 2:10 o'clock this morning, after having been suspended since 5:30 A.M. Sunday because of the storm.

VIENNA, Feb. 26. -- Lusty cheers were given for the Imperial Hapsburg family, Chancellor Dollfuss, and Prince Starhemberg, Heimwehr commander, at a mass-meeting tonight of monarchists who demanded the eventual restoration of the Austrian throne.
LIMA, Peru, Feb. 26. -- Emulation of the United States by Peru and closer relations between the two countries were advocated by President Oscar Benavides in an interview this morning.

The Shipping Board Bureau of the Department of Commerce started yesterday an investigation of practices, services and charges of the intercoastal steamship lines. About 150 representatives of ship lines, shippers' groups and port bodies from the East, South, Middle West and Pacific Coast were present at 45 Broadway at the first of a series of hearings ordered recently in an attempt to determine whether the Shipping Act is being violated in the intercoastal trade.

LONDON, Feb. 26. -- The Daily Mail's Vienna correspondent says that as a result of tonight's monarchist demonstration there are many who believe Archduke Otto of Hapsburg will arrive by airplane from Belgium tomorrow.

The Municipal Committee for the Relief of Home Owners, appointed by Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, to arbitrate difficulties between home owners and mortgagees and to prevent foreclosures, met yesterday afternoon at City Hall and will meet there again on Thursday afternoon to organize.

In a recent radio address Professor Irving Fisher told us that although our national debt appears to have risen from some $21,000,000,000 a year ago to over $25,000,000,000 now, it has actually decreased over 12 per cent. This, he says, resulted from the devaluation of the dollar to 59.06 per cent of its old parity, in terms of gold.

Stock Exchange member firms were engaged yesterday in drawing up new contracts for more than 6,000 customers' men in accordance with rules adopted by the Exchange in recent months. In many cases, brokers said, the contracts were being renewed on the same terms as have prevailed since Sept. 1, when the first contracts were drawn.

Proposals advocating additions to the public utility program now under consideration in the State Legislature, and urging the city to consider action on sewage disposal and the Delaware water supply project despite the financial difficulties involved, are to be laid before the State Chamber of Commerce at its meeting on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- The Banking and Currency Committee heard from what Ferdinand Pecora, its counsel, termed a "very frank stock exchange" today. This was the Mining Exchange of San Francisco, the report being made by Charles E. Hudson, president.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- New high levels for hogs for this season and the highest for this period of the year since 1931 were established today. Prices were 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight above those of Saturday and 20 to 30 cents above those of Friday.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

MADRID, Feb. 26. -- Elaborate preparations are being made by Premier Alejandro Lerroux's friends to celebrate his seventieth birthday next Sunday with a garden party and dinner, to be followed by a gala theatrical performance.

YONKERS, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- Medical Examiner Squire of Westchester today ordered the removal of electric equipment from the basement of Proctor's Theatre here for examination as to the cause of an explosion last Friday in which three persons were killed and eleven injured.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- Charges by Democratic Senate Leader John J. Dunnigan of racketeering at the New York tracks and abuses under Jockey Club control of racing were denied emphatically in a communication to the upper house of the Legislature tonight by the State Racing Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- The Senate Committee on Banking and Currency completed its investigation of the New York Stock Exchange today when it brought out that Richard Whitney, president of the Exchange, had addressed letters to the presidents of all corporations the stocks of which are listed on the Exchange calling to their attention the legislative situation in Washington.

MONTREAL, Feb. 26 (Canadian Press). -- A week of heavy scoring, in which Saturday night games were outstanding in the number of goals, found point leaders in the National Hockey League upholding their end, with the result the top positions are unchanged.

DETROIT, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Colonel Roscoe Turner, one of the few independents among the "big time" aviators, believes that irreparable damage to commercial aviation is imminent unless the air mail controversy is ironed out quickly.

PARIS, Feb. 26. -- Germain Martin, the Minister of Finance, twice today, once from the tribune of the Senate and a second time before the annual meeting of the Syndical Union of Bankers, denounced the idea of devaluating the franc and pledged its maintenance at its present value.

Meteorological heretics who have been preaching that Winters in the East were not what they used to be swamped city stores yesterday with an unprecedented demand for galoshes, skis, snowshoes, hip boots, ear-muffs and heavy underwear.

New financing for Monroe County, N.Y., in the amount of $2,750,000 is scheduled for tomorrow. The county plans to market $2,150,000 of tax revenue bonds due in from one to five years and 600,000 of emergency relief bonds due in from six to ten years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- The administration today definitely launched a trade program based upon extension of government credits to exporters, but one in which tariff rates will play a part to the end that exports and imports eventually may be better balanced.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 26. -- The conference of Latin American Chambers of Commerce, which has held daily sessions for the last two weeks at Valparaiso with the assistance of official delegates of South American countries, endeavoring to lay the foundations for a Latin American Conferation, closed this afternoon.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 26. -- All that can be done apparently has been done for the fifteen-round heavyweight title defense of Primo Carnera against Tommy Loughran Wednesday night.

TRENTON, Feb. 26. -- The legislative committee of the State Bar Association informed the Legislature today that the organization was opposed to a State income tax, which it declared "unthinkable," and to a mortgage moratorium.

" JEAN DE RESZKE and the Great Days of Opera," by Clara Leiser (Minton, Belch, $3.50), is something of a miracle to us; it is actually interesting. Not being what one might call musical, we have almost invariably been troubled by novels and biographies of singers. They have usually seemed confections for "the trade"; but that is not necessarily the fundamental trouble with them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Donald R. Richberg, NRA general counsel, speaking in the National Radio Forum tonight, made a last-minute appeal for public participation in the series of public meetings beginning tomorrow for the purpose of concentrating constructive criticism of the NRA.

It was no surprise to tape-watchers that last week's decline on the Stock Exchange was extended moderately yesterday. The force of the Saturday selling movement and the sentiment in speculative circles had foreshadowed a further reaction. Brokers said the greater part of yesterday's selling originated outside of New York.

Nine storm deaths occurred yes-six in New Jersey, two in Queens and one in Yonkers. One of the victims was a man who had collapsed in the snowstorm last week, but who had been without professional medical aid for four days in an isolated Vineland farmhouse.

The finding of the key to two ancient illuminated manuscripts of the Indians in Southern Mexico, dating back several hundred years before the coming of Cortez in 1519, was described last night at a meeting of the New York Academy of Sciences at the American Museum of Natural History by Dr. Herbert J. Spinden, curator of ethnology at the Brooklyn Museum and a noted authority on Pre-Columbian American culture.

As a result of voluntary salary reductions taken by License Commissioner Paul Moss and several of his aides, the annual salary of Mrs. Rosalie Loew Whitney, the department's first deputy, has been increased from $6,440 to $9,000, it became known yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 26. -- Five or more persons were killed and two-score others were injured when part of a Pennsylvania Railroad passenger train eastbound from Akron plunged off a viaduct at Merchant and Stockton Streets on the North Side tonight.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 26. -Dartmouth College, owed in grief, paid a sorrowful farewell today to the nine youths who lost their lives by carbon monoxide poisoning from a furnace in the Theta Chi fraternity house yesterday morning.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- Conferences which have been in progress this afternoon and evening between the Democratic members of the Legislature and representatives of Mayor LaGuardia over the LaGuardia Economy Bill have failed to bring about an agreement on changes to make it mutually acceptable.

Conferences are being held at the White House this week to consider methods of reviving foreign trade. The Departments of State, Commerce and Agriculture are represented, as well as the Tariff Commission and the recently created committee on trade policy, with Mr. PEEK as its chairman.

MOSCOW, Feb. 26. -- What the Bolsheviki really think of the Austrian question was revealed today by two complementary articles, one in the Pravda and the other in the Izvestia, the latter by the paper's shrewdest spokesman and specialist in foreign affairs, Karl Radek.

Partly activated by the belief that war may break out in the Far East a soon as the snow melts there, Doubleday-Doran are having prepared a book called "Empire in the East," which they will publish on March 21. Pearl S. Buck, Owen Lattimore and eight other writers who know about the Orient wrote the book on assignments. Joseph Barnes is editing it.

The amount of reorders coming into the local ready-to-wear markets yesterday was characterized generally as fair by manufacturers and resident offices. The mail was not heavy, but it was thought possible that the storms might have delayed some deliveries.

A telegram protesting against the proposed Dickstein Bill, which would bar alien actors from this country, has been sent to the Committee on Immigration and Naturalization of the House of Representatives in Washington by a group of prominent playwrights.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, appeared today before the House Education Committee and opposed the diversion of $50,000,000 from his $950,000,000 relief fund for State education relief.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- Methods to bring relief to the holders of guaranteed mortgage certificates in default will be discussed at a conference called today by Governor Lehman. It will be held in the executive chamber on Thursday afternoon.

ST. KITTS, B.W.I., Feb. 26. -- Glasses were turned seaward late this afternoon to catch a last glimpse of Great Britain's Atlantic fleet, the largest ever sent to the West Indies, before it vanished over the horizon headed homeward.

MOSCOW, Feb. 26. -- What the Bolsheviki really think of the Austrian question was revealed today by two complementary articles, one in the Pravda and the other in the Izvestia, the latter by the paper's shrewdest spokesman and specialist in foreign affairs, Karl Radek.

When the six-day bicycle race swung into its second twenty-four-hour session at Madison Square Garden last night before a crowd of 8,000 persons there were only fourteen teams in the grind. The original field of fifteen combinations was reduced by one when Norman Hill, the rugged pedaller from San Jose, Calif., was forced to withdraw because of injuries.

City authorities managed to squeeze an average of about 7 1/2 per cent out of real estate valuations this year. The bankers had previously secured enactment of a law which helped property owners by putting a limit on the total real estate tax levy. But with the budget swollen to its present proportions neither of these expedients proved sufficient to prevent an increase in the local tax rate.

A telegram protesting against the proposed Dickstein Bill, which would bar alien actors from this country, has been sent to the Committee on Immigration and Naturalization of the House of Representatives in Washington by a group of prominent playwrights.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, appeared today before the House Education Committee and opposed the diversion of $50,000,000 from his $950,000,000 relief fund for State education relief.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- Methods to bring relief to the holders of guaranteed mortgage certificates in default will be discussed at a conference called today by Governor Lehman. It will be held in the executive chamber on Thursday afternoon.

ST. KITTS, B.W.I., Feb. 26. -- Glasses were turned seaward late this afternoon to catch a last glimpse of Great Britain's Atlantic fleet, the largest ever sent to the West Indies, before it vanished over the horizon headed homeward.

This skirmishing account of the Municipal Art Show at Rockefeller Center should be dated morning and afternoon. It is prepared to offer no description of the gala opening night, which will be found reported elsewhere. The reviewer arrived soon after breakfast yesterday and walked for hours and hours through an energetic last-minute confusion.

Abolition of the United States Intercoastal Steamship Conference and a realignment of the intercoastal lines to classify tonnage and establish cargo rates were urged yesterday by H.W. Warley, vice president of the Calmar Steamship Company. Mr. Warley testified before an examiner of the Shipping Board at 45 Broadway, where a Federal investigation of all phases of the intercoastal service is under way.

Mayor LaGuardia flatly refused last night a compromise on his Economy Bill which involved the giving of positive assurance by him to the Legislature that the holders of jobs in county offices would be left undisturbed.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale Prices at New York.
Conveyance of a Kearny industrial plant in foreclosure featured the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- Except for a few loose ends the State today wound up its case against Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop. Tomorrow the 62-year-old physician's defense against the charge that she murdered her daughter-in-law, Rheta Wynekoop, for profit and for the love of her unhappily married son, Earle, is expected to open.

GERMANY PREPARES FOR WAR: A Nazi Theory of 'National Defense,' " by Ewald Banse (Harcourt, Brace, $3), frankly has us intimidated. The book is, to begin with, a highly intelligent rationale of the military implications of a renewed bid by Germany for hegemony on the European Continent. It is written by a Nazi who is Professor of Military Science at Brunswick Technical College.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 27. -- Colonel H.W. Hudson of Trenton submitted his resignation today, effective March 1, as assistant State highway engineer. He plans to take a post with the Triborough Bridge Authority in New York. The project calls for an estimated expenditure of $38,000,000.

MONTREAL, Feb. 27 (AP). -- The pace-setting Toronto Maple Leafs won their fifth game in six starts against the Montreal Maroons tonight, coming through with a 2-to-1 triumph in an overtime game in the National Hockey League.

VIENNA, Feb. 27. -- Austria is paying the usual penalty for destroying the independence of the press. The wildest rumors of troop concentrations, fighting on the Austro-German frontier, airplanes dashing to Belgium to fetch the deposed Archduke Otto to ascend the throne of a new Austrian kingdom are, as inquiries from abroad clearly show, setting foreign countries in ferment.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- The fight over legislation to restore prosiperity to the race tracks of the State, was swept today from the underbrush of committee room negotiation into a flare-up on the floor of the Senate.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 27. -- Abraham M. Faber, 24-year-old Massachusetts Institute of Technology graduate, today told the State police a story which led them to charge him and the Millen brothers, Murton and Irving, with murders in Fitchburg and Lynn in addition to the ruthless killing of two Needham patrolmen during the $14,500 robbery of the Needham Trust Company on Feb. 2.

The revision of commutation rates on railroads in the metropolitan area was urged yesterday by Public Service Commissioner George R. Lunn at the first of a series of hearings on rates and practices in the sale of commutation tickets.

Manufacturers in the garment and allied trades of the midtown area took most of the space in yesterday's reported rentals. Printers and restaurateurs were among the other lessees represented. The tenant list included the following:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Accepting amendments which loaded the measure with $354,000,000 in benefits for veterans and Federal employes and would, if enacted, almost wipe out the saving of $400,000,000 under the Economy Act, the Senate today passed the Independent Offices Bill.

It is more than twenty years since Governor PINCHOT first sought to increase the calibre and virtue of the Senate by adding himself to it. He is going to make a third offer this Spring. He will be a candidate in the Republican primaries against Senator REED. In Mr. PINCHOT'S view, "Republican Pennsylvania" needs "a Republican "Senator who will work with the "President to restore prosperity in-"stead of snapping and snarling at his "heels."
The James Madison High School basketball team remained in second place in the Brooklyn division of the P.S.A.L. by defeating Boys High, 32 to 22, in the Madison gymnasium yesterday.

The final phase of the settlement of the cleaners and dyers' dispute was attained yesterday when agreement was reached between representatives of the Cleaners and Dyers Board of Trade, representing about ninety wholesale plants, and the Cleaners, Dyers and Pressers Union, representing their employes, for a truce on the demands of the union affecting wages and working conditions.

I know people are giving generously for dependents in city and State and that the calls are many. Nevertheless, I make this urgent appeal for funds for homeless children who came to the child-placing and adoption committee of the State Charities Aid Association, 105 East Twenty-second Street.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 27. -- The clash over procedure which has held up the Constitutional Convention here for several days appears to have been settled by a compromise which satisfies the objections of the Sao Paulo delegation to election of a President before a new Constitution is adopted.

FLINT, Mich., Feb. 27. -- Automobile workers will end 1934 with about the same total earnings for the year as in 1929 if the current demand for cars continues, according to William S. Knudson, executive vice president of General Motors Corporation, in charge of car and body building operations in the United States and Canada.

Surplus to policyholders of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company increased in 1933 from $34,642,682 to $38,198,623, while total assets declined from $85,463,410 to $81,142,108, according to the annual report made public yesterday.

Alarm over the slowing up of the destruction of coffee in Brazil was allayed in local trade circles yesterday when the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange received a cable dispatch from the National Coffee Department of Brazil stating that there has been no change of policy.
American purchases of gold in London for shipment here halted yesterday for the first time since the restoration of the gold standard here and the establishment of a price of $35 an ounce for gold.
ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- Both Senate and Assembly took action today to lengthen the terms of the members of those bodies.

For the third consecutive week the number of buyers registered in the market showed a decrease. The number reported during the week ended yesterday, however, still remained well above the figures for the corresponding week last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

The ousting of John Theofel, Democratic leader of Queens and an ally of Tammany Hall, virtually was assured last night when the board of governors of his own club, the Jefferson Democratic Club, which he organized in 1910, unanimously endorsed James C. Sheridan as their new leader.
Allen M. Bernstein, Dr. Frederick R. Macaulay, Richard S. Conway and Lester Taylor compose the new investment counsel firm of Bernstein-Macaulay, Inc., at 250 Park Avenue.

Two business buildings in the midtown retail shopping section were sold yesterday by Mrs. Donald Carr, poetess, whose pen name is Blanche Shoemaker Wagstaff. The buildings are at 24 and 26 East Fifty-fourth Street, adjoining the southwest corner of Madison Avenue, and were acquired by Mrs. Carr more than a decade ago.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 27. -- S.S. Friedlein's Fortunate Youth returned to the form that once made him a contender in any event against the best sprinters in training when he won the featured six-furlong Solari Handicap at the Fair Grounds today.
A drive against the sale on newsstands of more than sixty magazines has been launched here by License Commissioner Moss in cooperation with the Police Department.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP). -- Full and immediate Federal payment of depositors in closed national banks was urged today as the government's duty before a House Banking and Currency subcommittee.
A luncheon was given yesterday at the Ritz Tower by Mrs. Leonard Burnham McKittrick for Mrs. George Jarvis Corbett. The other guests were:
Prices of futures turned firmer in a good volume of trading yesterday, with silver the feature. Cash prices were irregularly higher.

The National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters has reassumed its jurisdiction over the instalment paying of automobile casualty premiums after a lapse of several years. It has made public a schedule of regulations to become effective today among all stock casualty companies, except if a fifteen-day period of grace for making readjutsments is requested.
John W. Davis, who was Presidential candidate of the Democratic party in 1924, made his first criticism of the New Deal yesterday.

Additional lines of four months' money were offered and done at 1 per cent as on Monday. Nothing else of importance was reported, all sections of the market continued quiet and unchanged in quotation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The shadow of Presidential vetoes is upon the Capitol for the first time since Mr. Roosevelt was inaugurated, four days less than a year ago. The President has said in writing that he will veto the Bonus Bill, to be considered by the House on March 12.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 27 (AP). -- Sweeping increases in business in the Eighth Federal Reserve District in January, compared with the same month last year, were reported tonight by the St. Louis Federal Reserve Bank in its monthly review.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27. -- Primo Carnera tomorrow night will make his second defense of the world's heavyweight title which he won last June from Jack Sharkey. In the ring of the Madison Square Garden down here the huge Italian will stake his crown against Tommy Loughran in a fifteen-round bout.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Following in full is the address on the National Recovery Act delivered by General Hugh S. Johnson:

Bankers here will resume today their efforts to draw up rules for uniform practices under the Bankers' NRA Code, in accordance with the general provisions recently laid down by General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator. The banking code committee for Greater New York, which is headed by Merrell P. Callaway, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company, will meet this afternoon.

The sport of reconstructing the British Cabinet is now fully under way in the London press. Of course, The Daily Mail and The Daily Express already have the indicated Ministers reshuffled, or sent to the Lords, or asked to resign. The London Times is not carried away by this furor of creative journalism, and does not see any immediate Cabinet changes in prospect, though it admits that there is growing dissatisfaction with the Government.

NEWALRK, N.J., Feb. 27. -- Detective Lieutenant William Graef of the Irvington police force took the stand for the State today in the trial of August L. Lacombe, Director of Public Safety, and Andrew Coleman, suspended police chief, on an indictment for misfeasance, before Common Pleas Judge Walter D. Van Riper.
MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 27. -- To forestall his possible arrest by some zealous subordinate Nazi, the title of Papal Legate was conferred upon Michael Cardinal von Faulhaber today by Pope Pius.

President Roosevelt is giving the nation industrial democracy, just as the country's founders gave us political democracy, Grover Whalen declared last night in an address accepting the award of the gold medal of the Hundred Year Association in recognition of his work in behalf of the NRA.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Mrs. Curtis B. Dall, daughter of President and Mrs. Roosevelt, was the honor guest at the annual fancydress ball given tonight at the Willard by the Kentucky State Society. Representative Isabella D. Greenway of Arizona awarded the prizes.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday that he had ordered the demolition of the breakwater, bathhouses, pavilions and other structures at Orchard Beach, Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx. Improvements similar to those at Jones Beach, L.I., will replace the structures and the sea wall with its life-saving cottage.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- Offerings of hogs today were somewhat in excess of trade requirements and prices dropped 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight, although the processing tax will be increased 75 cents to $2.25 per 100 pounds at midnight tomorrow. Some underweight hogs were 50 cents under yesterday's top for this kind.

VIENNA, Feb. 27. -- All doubts as to the Fascist and anti-democratic character of the new Austria were finally removed this afternoon by Prince Ernst Rudiger von Starhemberg, leader of the Heimwehr, who gave an extremely frank talk to newspaper men in the Heimwehr headquarters.

For some time an urgent appeal has come from Republican newspapers and local chairmen for a reinvigoration of their party. New leaders are called for, but, above all else, sound principles and winning issues must somehow be found. On Monday the Republican members of the Senate of the United States stepped forward nobly to fill the order.
A pair of upsets eliminated two seeded players from the national Class B squash tennis championship tourney at the City A.C. yesterday.

Operating results of Standard Brands, Inc., in 1933 improved slightly over 1932, according to the annual report issued yesterday. Net income after all charges was $15,048,795, comparing with $15,001,491 the year before. The earnings in 1933, after preferred dividend requirements, were equivalent to $1.15 share on 12,645.374 common shares, comparing with $1.14 a share on 12,575,866 common shares in 1932.

It is good to learn that the Crime Prevention Bureau in the Police Department is to be "kept on probation" a while longer, and given a chance to prove its usefulness even to its critics. Mayor LAGUARDIA let it be known at the outset of his Administration that while he was sympathetic with its aims, he was not satisfied with its work.

Stockholders of the Chase National Bank, at a special meeting attended by several hundred persons and marked by unusually active discussion, approved yesterday the plan of recapitalization involving the issuance of $50,000,000 of 5 per cent preferred stock, almost all of which is to be sold to the RFC, and the reduction of the common stock from $148,000,000 to $100,270,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Following is the text of the statement made to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today by Thomas G. Corcoran, general counsel of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and one of the authors of the Fletcher-Rayburn Stock Exchange Control Bill, showing how the marginal provisions of the bill work and how they differ from the present marginal requirements of the New York Stock Exchange:

HSINKING, Feb. 27 (By Wireless). -- The final dress rehearsal before Thursday's enthronement of Henry Pu Yi as Emperor of Manchukuo, in response to "the will of Heaven," was held today in dusty, uninviting surroundings under a disconsolate sky, with the temperature below zero.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Feb. 27. -- John D. Mikel's consistent 7-year-old gelding Polyfon led home J. Nazworthy's Deepie in the five-and-a-half-furlong dash which featured today's program at Agua Caliente. King Caress was third.

Prince Carlo Maurizio Ruspoli, Count Theo Rossi Montelera, Count Rene Adalbert Dechambrun and Antonio Beechi are scheduled to arrive today on the Italian liner Rex to represent Italy in the motorboat races at Miami next month. Among other passengers on the ship arriving from Mediterranean ports are:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- New York State will seek tomorrow to bring about changes in the NRA and AAA regulations which would permit it to reduce its annual bill of more than $20,000,000 for supplies used in State offices and institutions.

DETROIT, Feb. 27. -- Scoring three goals within a minute in the first period and adding two more in the third, Detroit's Red Wings tonight routed the New York Rangers, 5 -- 1, in a fast, thrilling National Hockey League game.

The bondholders committee for Nueces County, Texas, and the special navigation and road districts therein, of which Natt T. Wagner and W.D. Bradford, both of 115 Broadway, are chairman and secretary, respectively, announced yesterday that a plan of debt readjustment has been approved by the commissioners court of the county and by the bondholders committee.

The job of clearing the city streets of the snow which fell during the thirty-six-hour week-end storm went ahead rapidly yesterday, with an army of 48,000 men working all day. By last night all the main traffic arteries and many side streets had been cleared.

The Episcopal Actors Guild held its annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the Vanderbilt Theatre and elected the following officers: Bishop William T. Manning, honorary president; George Arliss, president; the Rev. Randolph Ray, Edwin Milton Royle, Otis Skinner and Grant Mitchell, vice presidents; the Rev. Charles Breck Ackley, recording secretary; Thomas S. McLane, treasurer.

When 3,000 children from the public schools of Cleveland sing to an audience of 7,000 superintendents and teachers, and when two high school orchestras at the opposite ends of a hall -- a full city block in length -- play BACH in antiphonal sequence, these arts cannot be thought fads or frills.

The success of Postmaster General James A. Farley in bringing about the selection of a triumvirate to manage the affairs of the Brooklyn Democratic organization gave impetus yesterday to the suggestion that a similar course be followed in the coming attempt to displace John F. Curry as leader of Tammany Hall.

Controller W. Arthur Cunningham, in a radio address over WJZ last night, declared that "we cannot and should not agree to further compromises on the LaGuardia Economy Bill, since it has become manifest that the opposition to the bill is desirous only of protecting a handful of county officeholders, paid exorbitant salaries."

Free concerts today under the State Education Department are announced by G.A. Baldini to include the New York Civic Orchestra at the Museum of Natural History, University Concert Orchestra at Manhattan College. University Dance Orchestra at the Psychiatric Institute, Empire String Quartet at Brooklyn Museum and University Chamber Trio at the Third Avenue Brooklyn, Y.W.C.A.

Yesterday's temperatures remained well below the freezing point all day, the lowest reading of 9 degrees being only 5 degrees above the Feb. 27 record low of 4, established in 1900. The mercury touched 9 degrees at 7 A.M. and at 2:15 P.M. it registered 20 degrees, the highest reading during the day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- President Roosevelt formally created the new National Review Board to work with the NRA and conferred with the Land Policy Committee on a $25,000,000 program for marginal land purchases.

A customer of mine came in for hydrochloric acid. Having sold it to her many times before, I dispensed with the usual formality of asking her for what purpose she wanted it. Fortunately, she told me that the doctor had advised her taking the acid for her stomach.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Charles P. Bloom's complaint was against four banks that took away all his money, but he told it to NRA today because "it breaks my heart, and NRA ought to know about it." The Philadelphia small brass manufacturer, exporter and importer said at the NRA critics' meeting that his money was in one bank which failed.

William O'Brien, the professional tennis promoter, announced yesterday that two more amateurs have accepted terms with the Bill O'Brien Sports Promotion Corporation to play under the William Tilden banner.

PARIS, Feb. 27. -- After a hastily convoked Ministerial Council this evening, Minister of the Interior Albert Sarraut announced that Attorney General G. Pressard had been found largely responsible for the legal delays by which Alexandre Stavisky had escaped justice.

Efforts of the District Attorney's office to persuade Harry A. Vogelstein, a lawyer of 286 Fifth Avenue, to disclose who retained him to defend eleven men accused of policy law violations continued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The National Review Board was prepared today to receive complaints against monopolies and restrictions on small business under the operation of the National Recovery Administration, following an organization meeting at the White House.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade reversed their action today. Wheat, while easy near the start, advanced about 2 cents a bushel from the early low level because of an enlarged speculative interest, especially from houses with Eastern connections, and the market closed near the day's best figures.

Charging that the present regulations of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board are driving many drug-store owners out of business, the executive committee of the Retail Druggists Association of New York met in a militant mood yesterday and decided to send several thousand druggists to Albany next Tuesday to ask Governor Lehman and the State Legislature for a modification of the law.
ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- The fate of Mayor LaGuardia's Economy Bill still remains in the balance tonight.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27. -James Emory Foxx, successor to Babe Ruth as the champion homerun swatter of the major leagues, captured pretty much all there was to the spotlight as the Giants' odd assortment of batterymen and unattached rookies went through their fourth day of training today.

St. John's University played its best basketball of the season as it terminated its campaign with a 40-to-22 victory over Brooklyn College in the De Gray Gymnasium last night. The triumph gave the Redmen a record of sixteen victories against three defeats.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 27. -- The work of digging Westchester out of the snow continued today with thousands of additional jobs being given to unemployed. By this morning most of the main highways and parkways had been plowed and the work during the day was confined largely to the carting off of plowed snow and plowing out residential streets.

EUGENE, Ore., Feb. 27. -- A simple little trick in reading, such as turning the head slightly to the left or moving the page a few inches to the right, may mean the difference for backward students between gaining an education or remaining "dumb," according to L.K. Shumaker, supervisor of the English bureau, and Dr. H.R. Crossland, Professor of Psychology, at the University of Oregon.

Both department stores and wholesale establishments continued to make good gains over last year in the total volume of sales in January, according to the monthly report on credit and business conditions in this district by the Federal Reserve agent at New York. His report declares:
