Charges of intimidation, coupled with a veiled warning of prosecution, were made yesterday by the Regional Labor Board against the Fifth Avenue Coach Company following distribution by the company of a circular interpreted by the board as an effort to intimidate its 1,450 employes from participating in the union poll to be conducted by the board tomorrow.

In her piano recital last night in the Town Hall, Fay Ferguson played Beethoven's "Rondo a Capriccio," Op. 129, Busoni's arrangement of Bach's chorale "Ich ruf zu dir, Herr"; the Bach Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue; Schumann's "Traumes Wirren," "Des Abends," and Variations on the name "Abegg"; Chopin's B minor sonata and works of Debussy, Albeniz and Dohnanyi.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27. -- Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Henry Kroger have announced the marriage of his daughter, Mrs. Gretchen Kroger Barnes, to Bruno Graf of Berlin. The ceremony took place at noon today at Villa Sueno, their residence.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The twelve-point program of the National Recovery Administration as outlined today by General Hugh S. Johnson at the opening session of the general public meeting is as follows:

The first fifty-six railroads to report for January showed a net operating income of about $20,639,000, against $7,110,000 in January, 1933, an increase of 190.2 per cent, and against $6,708,000 in January, 1932, an increase of 207.6 per cent. In December their net income was $28,972,000, against $24,411,000 in December, 1932, an increase of 18.6 per cent.

An informal committee to help Jewish refugees settle in Soviet Russia, in line with the offer of the Soviet Government to set up an autonomous Jewish republic in Biro-Bidjan, was formed yesterday at a meeting at the Ritz-Carlton.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 27. -- Nassau County virtually had recovered today from the effects of yesterday's storm, mainly because the Street Cleaning Departments of the various communities began to remove the snow as soon as it began to fall.

CRISTOBAL, C.Z., Feb. 27. -- The first definite ruling that the Canal Zone is an "international trade enterprise" operated by the United States and that only those employed or engaged in business have a right in the zone was handed down today.

Plans for remodeling the interior of the old sheepfold building in Central Park, opposite Sixty-sixth Street and Central Park West, were made public yesterday by Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, coincidentally with his announcement that CWA workers already were engaged in the task of converting the picturesque building for use as a moderate-priced restaurant.

Retail fish dealers of the city, who started a boycott of wholesalers on Monday to protest price conditions, prepared yesterday to resume purchases and reopen their shops this morning, following settlement of their principal grievances.

Net income of the Electric Bond and Share Company for 1933 amounted to $10,735,268, equal, after preferred dividends, to 43.7 cents a share on 5,267,147 common shares, comparing with $13,566,666, or 98.9 cents a share, earned in 1932.

A general strike of ushers and other "front-of-the-house" workers employed in motion picture theatres of the city was voted yesterday morning by members of the Theatre and Amusement Employes Union at an all-night meeting in Palm Garden, Fifty-second Street near Eighth Avenue.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- Stocks were irregular today, and the volume of transactions was small. British funds generally were steady, led by consols and the Victory loan. Industrials were slightly more cheerful than yesterday and internationals buoyant.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- For the first time in the present financial year the total of national revenue exceeds expenditure. The surplus, according to tonight's revenue returns, is 3,380,784. The reckoning includes a debt payment to the United States of 3,304,392 and sinking fund payments of 5,518,653.

Several hundred pigeons, starlings, sparrows and perhaps other varieties wait daily at the Public Library for a little food. As no provision is made for their needs, the task of keeping them alive during these wintry days devolves on a handful of men and women who strive to get bread to them.

The New York Athletic Club quintet was upset by the Columbus Council K. of C. five in the Winged Foot gymnasium last night, 19 to 18, and was eliminated from any chance of winning the George V. McLaughlin Trophy. The N.Y.A.C. setback automatically clinched the cup for Union Temple.

From the speculative viewpoint, the share market at the close of business yesterday seemed to be arousing fresh interest. Traders were divided in their opinions as to the immediate course of the market, but they were of one mind in one particular.

A syndicate, headed by the Chase National Bank, obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $3,000,000 city of Buffalo (N.Y.) work and home relief bonds, dated March 15, 1934, and due on March 15, 1944. The winning bid was 100.322 for the bonds as 4 1/4s, a tender which topped those of three other syndicates.

About 1,555 of the 2,300 members of the New York Junior League are at present employed either as professional or volunteer workers in the welfare field or in business. This was revealed yesterday at a campaign luncheon at the league's headquarters, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

Civil service examinations for candidates for appointment to the New York Police Department began yesterday morning at the Central Opera House, Sixty-seventh Street, east of Third Avenue, with about 1,200 men in attendance. The first session was from 9:30 to 12:10 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP). -- Legislation to create a commission of seven to regulate interstate and foreign communication by wire and radio, as suggested by President Roosevelt, was introduced today in both the Senate and House.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- In connection with the proposed House investigation of army purchases Representative O'Connor of New York, a member of the Rules Committee, said today that "every one thinks that the graft has been from the inside of the War Department and it has been going on for twenty to thirty years and the same people have been responsible through several administrations."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP). -- The activities of former Senator Smoot of Utah and his son in behalf of an air-mail carrying concern were described today to the Senate Air-Mail Investigating Committee by James G. Woolley, a former vice president of Western Air Express.

Hundreds of thousands of ducks, quail and pheasants that had been threatened with starvation because snow and ice had covered their usual food, feasted yesterday in Long Island, New York City and Westchester and Putnam Counties. Due to the efforts of the National Association of Audubon Societies, 1,775 Broadway, the State Conservation Department and many fish and game clubs, the birds received liberal supplies of corn.
All utility reports are consolidated returns including subsidiaries unless otherwise specified.

Proceeds of the annual midseason luncheon of the League for Political Education held yesterday in the Hotel Astor and attended by more than 1,000 women subscribers will be donated to the fund for unemployed single women.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Immediate purchase of $25,000,000 worth of marginal farm land for withdrawal from production was decided today at a meeting of the Land Policy committee with President Roosevelt.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 27. -- The Penn swimming team handed Princeton its first defeat of the season in Brokaw pool tonight, winning by 39-32 in a meet which was decided in the final event, the relay. It was the first Penn victory over the Tigers in six years.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP). -- Tacking in great arcs, twelve sailing yachts tonight fought their way toward Great Isaacs Light, Bahamas, the initial hailing point of the first annual international race iron Miami to Nassau, Bahamas.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Charges that Senator Copeland had revised the Copeland-Tugwell Bill to exempt publishers, radio broadcasters and advertising agencies from the penalties against false advertising of food, drugs and cosmetics, were made today to the Senate Commerce Committee by Charles W. Dunn of New York, general counsel for the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., and the American Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Association.

Announcement yesterday that the Cities Service Company had been permitted to intervene in the receivership proceedings of the Richfield Oil Company of California was taken to mean that this company now has assumed a dominant position in the affairs of Richfield.

Another withdrawal reduced the field in the six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden to thirteen teams last night. Louis Cohen and Bobby Silver, finding themselves hopelessly trailing the leaders by eighteen laps, elected to quit just before the crowd of 10,000 appeared for the evening's program of racing.

The body of William Frank McGee, who was convicted with E.M. Fuller for operation of a bucket-shop that failed for $5,000,000 in 1922, lay unclaimed last night in the City Morgue. McGee died on Saturday night in St. Vincent's Hospital, penniless, and under an assumed name. The name he gave was Frank Welton.

Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia maintained a commanding lead at the end of the second day's play in his challenge match with Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland for the world's pocket billiard championship, with a margin of 503 to 322.
WASHINGTON, D.C., Feb. 27. -- Flew in here today. You got to fly back here to get over the tops of these snow drifts. And, brother, you got to have altitude.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27. -- The Coldstream Stud's 7-to-1 shot Fire Mask, ridden by Earl Porter, was a driving winner of the featured Ormond Purse through the mud at Hialeah Park today. Rain fell during the program, and the going was sloppy for the races.

Mayor LaGuardia called the opening of the Municipal Art Exhibition in Rockefeller Center last night the most pleasant duty assigned him since Jan. 1. So pleasant, in fact, did the Mayor find the show that he purchased twenty of the exhibits, virtually all prints.

Lauren Gilfillan, whose book, "I Went to Pitt College," is the Literary Guild selection for March, is one of the grateful authors who were helped through the depression by the Artists and Writers Dinner Club. The club, organized about sixteen months ago, has served hundreds of meals without charge in Greenwich Village restaurants.
At a cost of about $25,000 an hour New York City was digging itself out of whited rifts yesterday and resuming its normal routine. An army of 48,000 men was at work clearing the city's streets.

The Metropolitan Opera will go on next season, it became known last night. There is every indication that the Juilliard Foundation will continue its support and that the rest of the funds necessary to guarantee a season will be raised chiefly among the active friends and patrons of opera.

The merchant tailors in convention assembled have decided that men's clothes will be full of color and gayety because of the New Leisure. The merchant tailors have been saying this for years and years.

Another play dealing with the present form of government in Germany, entitled "Achtung," is being planned for immediate production by Hyman Adler, in association with the Shuberts. Leslie Reed is said to be the author of the play, and Guy Bates Post probably will appear in the cast.

After an early decline that carried May contracts to around 11 3/4 cents a pound, prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday recovered sharply a quarter cent and ended with a gain of 6 to a loss of 4 points on the day.

Winston F.C. Guest, who remains as the only man in the history of indoor polo with a top rating of ten goals, will have an Optimist trio in this year's national indoor championship to defend the title won by that team in last year's championship at Chicago, according to word yesterday from the Indoor Polo Association of America.

GENEVA, Feb. 27. -- League of Nations circles were disturbed today by publication here of a Washington dispatch strongly implying that Hugh Wilson definitely had replaced Norman Davis as disarmament delegate of the United States. Mr. Wilson denied here only a few days ago a similar report in an Italian newspaper at Milan.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- The proposed 2 per cent sales tax was assailed today by Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission, on the ground that such a levy placed an unfair burden on the poor and that it would result in "more extravagance'' by local governments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The National Recovery Administration's "field day" for criticism today evoked an outpouring of spokesmen for labor, consumer and the small business man, who swamped the deputies at five simultaneous conferences with an extraordinary variety of comment on the manner in which the codes were framed, criticism of how they are administered and suggestions for improvement.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 27. -- The gold medal of the associated exhibitors of the National Education Association was conferred upon Dr. Walter Damrosch, dean of American conductors, at the annual meeting of the department of superintendence here tonight.
PARIS, Feb. 27 (AP). -- A broad program to build up the military strength of France will be acted on soon by the Cabinet.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- Opposition to State regulation of private employment agencies by Mrs. Rosalie Loew Whitney, Deputy Commissioner of Licenses in New York City, resulted in criticism of her attitude at a public hearing by the Assembly and Senate labor and industries committees today.

Daily average production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,226,050 barrels, compared with 2,289,150 barrels in the receding week, a decrease of 63,100 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Declines of 4,700 barrels and of 19,600 barrels, respectively in the outputs of Oklahoma and California and a gain of 8,300 barrels in Texas were the most important changes.

Further indication that the government intends to demobilize the army of CWA workers by May 1 was given yesterday in an order received by the State Civil Works Administration from Harry L. Hopkins, Federal CWA administrator, for the dismissal by Friday of 24,000 more men now on CWA payrolls.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Unless unforeseen obstacles arise, Senator Wagner, chairman of the National Labor Board, will introduce in a day or two his bill to strengthen the power of the board. The finishing touches to the measure were completed at a conference last night, and it was understood that it had the approval of leaders of the American Federation of Labor.

On General JOHNSON'S invitation, critics of the NRA were invited yesterday to tell the Government "where the "codes are not working right, where "they bear unjustly, where they could "be improved." Five conferences were held simultaneously in Washington. Two considered trade practices; one, the organization of code authorities; another, matters relating to employment, and the fifth, operation of the codes in small industries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- A substantial amount of silver soon will be sold to the Cuban Government under plans now being drawn up to establish an export bank similar to the export-import bank for promoting trade with the Soviet Union, it was learned today.

Fernando Gonzalez Roa, the Mexico Ambassador to Washington, arrived yesterday on the Ward liner Oriente expressing bright hopes for the future of Mexico. He was optimistic on the outlook for increasing trade between his country and the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The agricultural rehabilitation of Puerto Rico will be studied by Rexford G. Tugwell and experts of the Department of Agriculture, Secretary Dern announced today, Mr. Tugwell will go to Puerto Rico to make a survey and recommend a program to be followed in the War Department's administration of the island under Governor Blanton G. Winship, recently appointed.
ROME, Feb. 27 (AP). -- Italy has agreed to accept the British disarmament memorandum, well-informed circles said tonight, as a basis for future arms discussions.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 28. -- The Japanese Government will protest to Moscow against alleged vio lations of the Korean frontier by Soviet planes. The Foreign Office spokesman states that a note will be transmitted to Ambassador Ota today to complain that the frontiers are being infringed and will demand assurances that the trespasses will cease.

Mme. Hulda Lashanska, Ossip Gabrilowitsch and Toscha Seidel were the artists at a concert at Carnegie Hall last night for the benefit of the medical department of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem. The concert was given under the auspices of the American Jewish Physicians Committee.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told a questioner in the House of Commons today that the recent decision of the House of Lords upholding the gold clause in the case of Belgian bonds did not apply to United Kingdom gold bonds issued in New York.

" Carmen," the forgotten woman of grand opera, whom all the queens of song couldn't put back on her Broadway pedestal from the abdication of Calve to the reconquest by Farrar, stole brightly into town last evening at Seventh Avenue and Fiftieth Street. Here in the former Earl Carroll Theatre, now the Casino, the touring San Carlo Opera Company revived Bizet's opera in French.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Plans for amendment of the Fletcher-Rayburn Bill toward modification were disclosed today at a hearing before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.
MOSCOW, Feb. 27. -- "You ask who really burned the Reichstag -- only those who did it can answer, not I -- and the truth will not be known until it comes out at a trial by a German Soviet court."

Frank Colton and Michael McCaffery were working yesterday on the slippery deck of the tugboat J.P. McAllister at Wall Street when McCaffery slipped and fell between the tug and a floating derrick into the icy water of the East River.
The full text of the statement by John W. Davis attacking the economic policy of President Roosevelt follows:

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 27. -- Three bandits armed with pistols and a machine gun held up a bank messenger on a crowded downtown street this afternoon, shot him dead, robbed him of $1,000 in cash and $206,294 in securities and escaped in an automobile believed to have been driven by a woman.
Tenement House Commissioner Post's statement that "every old-law tenement is a fire trip" is as dangerous as it is unwarranted.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 27 -- A demand for a Federal appropriation of $400,000,000, to be apportioned next year among schools in all States on "an objective basis," was made tonight by Dean William F. Russell of Teachers' College, Columbia University, speaking before thousands of school executives at the annual conference of the National Education Association's Department of Superintendence.
LONDON, Feb. 27. -- British manufacturers believe they have forestalled a Japanese attempt to flood the British market with bicycles selling for $12.50 apiece or even less.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27. -- Attended by a large audience of colonists, the ninth annual Kiwanis benefit for under privileged children of the county was held tonight at the Paramount Theatre under the direction of Arthur Hammerstein and William A. Brady. George Jessel was master of ceremonies, and C.W. Carroll of the Kiwanians assisted in the arrangements.

Prince Iyesato Tokugawa visited Columbia University yesterday morning, inspecting the collection of more than 10,000 hooks, manuscripts and other cultural materials at the Japanese Culture Centre of the university in the main library. He was welcomed by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia, at a ceremony in the trustees' room attended by members of the board of trustees, the university council and the faculty.

Before stepping aboard the train at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, headed for the Orlando (Fla.) training camp, Manager Casey Stengel of the Dodgers received the news that Len Koenecke, outfielder, had returned his signed contract.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- A legal test is planned by the Senate against the large concerns which failed to report the salaries of their officers and directors, as demanded in a Senate resolution.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- President Roosevelt is urged to take steps to bring restoration of air-mail contracts to the commercial companies in a resolution introduced today by Assemblyman James J. Wadsworth, son of Representative Wadsworth.

Eighteen properties put up at foreclosure auctions yesterday were bought in by the plaintiffs in the actions foreclosing the properties. Multi-family buildings dominated the list of parcels, which also included some vacant sites in the Bronx.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- Net profits of the William Wrigley Jr. Company in 1933 were $7,528,678, equivalent to $3.76 a share on 2,000,000 shares of capital stock, Philip K. Wrigley, president, reported today to stockholders. In 1932 the earnings were $7,095,667, or $3.55 a share.
ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- The Assembly Codes Committee took action today to broaden the ground for divorce in the State.
Because of the Board of Estimate's failure to provide funds, 271 instructors and clerical workers in the Board of Higher Education have not been paid since Jan. 1, it was disclosed yesterday.

The steam locomotive would be adapted to conform with the new theories of streamlining and light weight under plans being considered by the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific and the Baltimore Ohio Railway. Both are studying the new engineering project.
MIAMI, Feb. 27. -- The principal facts on the Carnera-Loughran title fight tomorrow follow:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The House Rules Committee today gave special right of way to the McSwain resolution calling for an investigation of alleged profiteering among aircraft manufacturers. At the same time the House Postoffice and Post Roads Committee completed drafting of the Kelly bill designed to protect the government in future air-mail contracts with private operators.

GREENWOOD, Miss., Feb. 27 (AP). -- Breaking the silence which she had consistently maintained since her arrest last August, Dr. Sarah Ruth Dean today denied from the witness stand the State charge that she poisoned Dr. John Preston Kennedy, her admirer, with a whisky highball.

NEW SMYRNA, Fla., Feb. 27. -- About twenty outboard motorboat drivers, hoping to qualify for the American team of four which will meet the Europeans in the international racing starting here on Saturday, tuned up motors and polished their boats today.

Former Mayor John P. O'Brien testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook in defense of the twenty-five-year bus franchises voted to five Manhattan companies in the closing days of his administration. The validity of the grants is under fire in a taxpayer's suit brought by Sadye Greenberg of Brooklyn.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- Admiral of the Fleet David Beatty, furthering the bigger navy campaign, told a gathering of business men today what he thought the Admiralty's task would be at the 1935 naval conference.

The sixty-meter dash at the thirteenth annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. indoor games at Madison Square Garden on Monday has attracted one of the largest and most representative fields ever to compete in this event. It was announced yesterday by James A. Taylor that seventy-seven sprinters from twenty-five colleges will take part in the dash fixture.

Two hundred and two years to the day after the birth of the boy who chopped down a cherry tree and could not tell a lie about it, a person less amenable to the dictates of conscience committed a bizarre crime in the reptile house of the Bronx Zoo.
While the law requires the filing of the federal income tax return not later than midnight of March 15, it is possible under certain circumstances to obtain an extension.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- The Court of Appeals today granted a new trial of the action of Hopwood Plays, Inc., against Collin Kemper and others to recover about $12,000 alleged to have been improperly deducted as expenses under a production agreement.

The Queens County grand jury, in a presentment handed up yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Frank F. Adel, condemned as inadequate many of the buildings rented by the city at an annual cost of $526,158 for courts and public offices in the borough.
With the passing of the snow storm, flying on almost normal schedules was resumed early yesterday by both the army air mail service and the commercial lines out of Newark Metropolitan Airport.

HAVANA, Feb. 27. -- Former Senator Wilfredo Fernandez, once a powerful political figure in Cuba and an intimate friend of former President Gerardo Machado, committed suicide this morning in his cell at Cabana Fortress, where he had been held prisoner for several months awaiting trial.

A dispute over alleged bargains for leniency arose yesterday between the Bronx District Attorney's office and the justices of Bronx Special Sessions when three men were brought before the court to be sentenced for illegal substitution of gasoline.

Charging that the Crime Prevention Bureau of the Police Department had failed conspicuously in many of its objects, Mayor LaGuardia wrote a stinging letter to Police Commissioner O'Ryan yesterday directing him to force the bureau to get results.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- Prince Chegodieff Youssoupoff, self-confessed assassin of the monk Rasputin, will take the witness stand in his wife's suit against a film producer, which opened here today. A hint dropped by his counsel, Sir Patrick Hastings, indicated the world might hear a new version of the grim events in the cellar under the Prince's palace in Czarist Petrograd.

Far from wanting war, either with the United States or with Soviet Russia, Japan ardently desires peace, friendly relations and the amicable settlement of disputes with both countries, Prince Iyesato Tokugawa said last night at the annual dinner of the Japan Society at the Waldorf-Astoria.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 27. -- A birdie 3 on the eighteenth hole today enabled Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City, Mo., to win the qualifying medal in the Florida East Coast golf championship for the Mrs. W.R. Kenan Jr. Cup. The former Western titleholder posted a card of 44, 37 -- 81 to lead a select field by a single stroke.

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 28. -- The unemployed hunger marchers received an unexpected advertisement last night when the House of Commons stayed in session two hours after the close of business and discussed their grievances.

Thoroughly aroused over reports of graft in snow-removal work, Mayor LaGuardia caused the suspension yesterday of Police Sergeant Peter J. Kelly for failure to make a proper investigation of a specific complaint that a worker had had to pay $2 of $5 received for his labor.

The cost of conservation in New York State is surprisingly large and may meet with the opposition of hundreds of sportsmen's organizations. However, one glance at the work which the Division of Fish and Game must do in the course of a year should serve to quiet the most zealous critic.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Feb. 27. -- The death toll in the wreck of a Pennsylvania Railroad train here last night was placed today at nine. Of the fifty-seven passengers, thirty-seven were injured. Most of them are in hospitals, some so seriously injured that they may not live.

In a spectacular battle the Long Island University basketball team defeated St. Francis College, 32 --28, last night at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gym. It was L.I.U.'s twenty-fourth victory in twenty-five games this season.

Although traders still seemed to be somewhat discouraged, the share market managed yesterday to overcome the reactionary influences, at least to the extent that the recent decline was halted. That is the most that can be said with respect to the lazy upward movement on the Stock Exchange.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP). -- Par was given a thrashing as the fourth annual St. Petersburg open golf tournament got under way today.

Mrs. Esther Canales, 41 years old, was discovered stabbed to death in the bedroom of her three-room apartment on the fourth floor of 22-07 Nineteenth Street, Astoria, by her 12-year-old daughter, Genevieve, shortly after noon yesterday.

BERLIN, Feb. 27. -- The Boerse continued firm today and the volume of trading expanded. Practically the entire list advanced, gains ranging up to three points, but Schubert Selzer, which dropped 12 3/4 points yesterday on the dividend reduction, fell off another 6 1/4 points. Potashes led the advance. Heavy industrials, electricals and chemicals followed, drawing the rest with them.

Your Washington correspondent, Arthur Krock, in his dispatch published in your editorial section called attention to the punitive tendencies beginning to appear in the activities of the Federal Government. At least two outcroppings of the past week clearly suggest that this desire to punish is becoming stronger than the desire to reform -- that the authorities are looking backward destructively instead of looking forward constructively.

Within a point of defeat in the third game, Miss Eileen Beresford of Short Hills rallied to pull out her match with Miss Charlotte Darling of Philadelphia yesterday in the invitation squash racquets tournament at the Junior League.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Michael J. O'Brien, president of the Chicago Stock Exchange; Charles A. Collins, president of the Boston Stock Exchange, and G. Hermann Kinnicutt, representing eighteen New York investment houses, asked today, in testimony given before the House Interstate Commerce Committee, for the elimination of what they described as paralyzing legislation from the Fletcher-Rayburn Stock Exchange Bill.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 27. -- A suit to compel payment of gold bonds in the amount of gold specified before the devaluation of the dollar, or in the equivalent in present-day currency, was filed in Federal court today by Milton Mermelstein of Newark, a lawyer associated with the firm of Guggenheimer Untermyer in New York.

VIENNA, Feb. 27. -- Mysterious troop movements that have been exciting rumors and conjectures in Austria and abroad recently were termed by Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss tonight a "natural aftermath" of the civil war.

Fox Metropolitan Playhouses and forty-three corporations which operate motion picture theatres in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx began suit yesterday in Federal Court for the possession of sound-reproducing machines used in their theatres.

Liquidation eased on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, and a further recovery carried early prices 35 points above Tuesday's low marks. Trade buying tapered off on the advance, and an afternoon reaction in other markets caused reselling that left quotations unchanged to 9 points higher on the day.

PARIS, Feb. 28. -- Instructions from the State Department in Washington today deferring payroll disbursements caused consternation among 1,300 embassy and consulate officials and employes in eleven foreign countries who were awaiting for their pay checks for February.

The necessity of raising a guaranty fund before the next season of the Metropolitan Opera Association is assured was stressed yesterday in a statement by Cornelius N. Bliss, chairman of the executive committee of the association. For this purpose a committee has been appointed with Miss Lucrezia Bori as the chairman.

The listed bond market failed yesterday to develop a definite trend. Domestic railroad bonds worked irregularly lower and industrial and utility issues higher. Leading foreign loans were a trifle improved on the day, while United States Government long-term issues were irregularly lower, 9-32 point down to 6-32 point up.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP). -Senator Schall, Republican, of Minnesota, said in a statement issued today that newspapers are confronted with censorship by the "demand" of President Roosevelt for a Federal communications commission.

BERLIN, Feb. 28 (By Wireless). -For three days since I have been here Berlin has been a city celebrating as a great victory the day fourteen years ago when Adolf Hitler started his campaign with a small group of friends in a beer hail in Munich, where last Saturday he made a speech as the ruler of Germany.

Although meeting with continued defiance from the Fifth Avenue Coach Company as to its right to hold such an election, the Regional Labor Board will conduct today a poll of the company's 1,450 employes to determine whether they desire to be affiliated with what the board characterizes as a company union, join the American Federation of Labor, or become members of any other union of their choice.

The two-day boycott of wholesalers by retail fish dealers ended early yesterday morning. The interruption caused so heavy a trade when business was resumed at the Fulton fish market that a committee to arbitrate differences postponed its meeting.

E.G. Buckland, president of the Railroad Credit Corporation, announced yesterday that the corporation's executive committee had agreed to defer the collection of interest or principal due this year on its $1,303,000 loan to the Western Pacific Railroad.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 28 (AP). -- Miss Florence LeBoutillier, third seeded player in the women's singles division of the Bermuda tennis championships, was eliminated today in a surprising upset by Mrs. William Freisenbruch of Bermuda.
Sergel Rachmaninoff said yesterday before sailing for England that the public appearances of the child prodigy, Ruth Slenczynski, were to be deplored because they might affect her future adversely.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Flagrant violations of NRA wage and hour codes in the New York area led to a proposal by Mrs. Elinor Morehouse Herrick, chairman of the New York Regional Labor Board, that industry "be policed by organized labor," it was revealed today.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- The grim story of a tragedy that rocked Russia and startled the world was told today in the tense atmosphere of a crowded London court room when Prince Youssoupoff related how he killed the sinister monk Rasputin.

PARIS, Feb. 28. -- With Captain Anthony Eden, the British Lord Privy Seal, due here tomorrow to renew his disarmament talks, it is believed the Doumergue Government will feel constrained to accept the British proposal, on which it is reported Germany and Italy already are in substantial accord.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Organizations of labor, consumers, retailers and Negroes joined today in asserting that the National Recovery program was endangered by practices permitted under the codes of fair competition approved by Administrator Johnson and President Roosevelt.

Representatives of banks and insurance companies were among those who bid at auction sales involving more than a score of Manhattan and Bronx properties yesterday. Twenty-two parcels were put up for bidding and all were struck down to the plaintiffs in the foreclosure proceedings, the successful bidders acting to protect their liens.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28. -- The advance yesterday in the grain markets on the Board of Trade proved today to have been of the soda-water variety. While there was scattered buying early, with a fractional advance from yesterday's closing prices, a heavy undertone soon developed in wheat and that market eased steadily, with a noticeable lack of aggressive support.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28. -- The Soviet pilot Bragin today located a group of seventy-nine fishermen adrift on the ice in the Caspian sea with their teams and dropped from his plane food and instructions which enabled them to reach shore safely.

Net profits of about $441,000,000 for 1933, contrasted with a net deficit of $46,000,000 in 1932, were realized by 810 corporations engaged in various lines of industry and trade and having aggregate net worth of $14,003,000,000, according to a tabulation prepared by the National City Bank and published in the current bulletin of that institution.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The Federal Trade Commission today announced filing of registration statements for ten new securities issues to a total of about $3,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Wholesale commodity prices showed the first decline of the present year in the last week, according to an announcement made today by Commissioner Lubin of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Following is the text of the new unemployment program made public today at the White House:

CLEVELAND, Feb. 28. -- A basic "crime prevention program" for public schools was proposed today by Senator Copeland of New York to the thousands of educators from all parts of the country gathered at the annual convention of the National Education Association's department of superintendence.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28. -Playing a distant, but no less sincere part in the funeral ceremonies that were being held 1,400 miles away for the late John McGraw, members of the New York Giants, encamped here for the training season, spent today paying silent tribute to their former chieftain. Several of the players, notably those of the Catholic faith, further paid their respects by attending their church.
COLUMBUS, Miss., Feb. 28 (AP). -Sylvester Harris, who believes in dealing with the man at the top (no understrappers for him) knew what to do to save his farm.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 28. -- Cornell's sharp-shooting five, led by Lou Freed, forward, and Nelson Houck, guard, defeated Dartmouth, 37 -- 21, before 1,800 spectators, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game tonight. Cornell's victory was its seventh in ten league games.

Currier Ives locomotives, with "diamond" stacks, ornate sleepers known as "palace cars" and dingy day coaches lit by oil lamps and heated by coal stoves, were recalled yesterday by Franklin T. Everett on the eve of his retirement as conductor of the Twentieth Century Limited.

The J.C. Penney Company nearly tripled its net income for 1933, compared with 1932. The net of $14,235,638, after all charges, reported for last year was the largest in the history of the company. It was equivalent after preferred dividend requirements to $5.51 a share on 2,468,984 shares of common stock, and compares with a net of $5,082,672, or $1.57 a share on the same number of common shares, in the preceding year.

The hotel strike begun more than a month ago was called off last night on terms laid down originally by the Regional Labor Board. Announcement of the action on these terms was made by B.J. Field, secretary of the Amalgamated Hotel and Restaurant Workers' Union, the strike organization.

The Police Department is planning to replace its $3,000-a-year patrolmen now working as telephone operators with women at $1,200 a year, it was disclosed yesterday by Chief Inspector Lewis J. Valentine.

MANAGUA, Feb. 28. -- Followers of General Augusto C. Sandino, erstwhile Nicaraguan leader, have recently been increasing their supplies of arms and ammunition, it is Indicated by evidence gathered by the National Guard. General Sandino was assassinated last Thursday following conversations with government officials on the surrender of his followers' arms, which had failed to take place as scheduled.

Though jobs and payrolls have increased substantially, and an added gain is indicated in steel, textiles, motors and other important industries, no one doubts that relief of unemployment will for some time be a serious problem. The statement issued at the White House yesterday is a definition of the policy to be pursued by the Federal Government after the Civil Works Administration has been demobilized a short time hence.

BERLIN, Feb. 28. -- Reichsbishop Ludwig Mueller declared tonight that "the German Christians will not rest until only national Socialists are found in the pulpits of the church and only national socialists sit below them."

Mayor LaGuardia, changing tactics in his drive to bring about the passage of his Economy Bill, revealed yesterday what cuts he will make in the Democratic-controlled county offices if the Legislature gives him the power he has asked.

The management of the Twin City Rapid Transit Company remained in control of the company yesterday after it had received a vote of 113,713 shares at the annual meeting, against 60,899 polled by the Fitzpatrick group. A.E. Ames of Toronto and E.W. Decker and T. Julian McGill of Minneapolis were therefore re-elected as directors, while P.W. Fitzpatrick, J.R. Stolze and J.S. Solmes were defeated.

The General Education Board, founded by John D. Rockefeller Sr. in 1902, appropriated $2,423,303 during the fiscal year ending June 30, 1933, it was revealed in the boards annual report made public yesterday.

Miles M. O'Brien, Assistant District Attorney, will begin submitting the State's evidence in General Sessions today in the trial of four men on a kidnapping indictment. The jury was chosen yesterday, and when the prosecutor finished his opening address, and defense counsel had waived that right, the court adjourned.

Whether or not misdemeanor charges shall be brought against high officials of the I.R.T. for failing to heat their subway trains properly during the recent cold spells will be decided at a conference today. Such charges, based on Section 304 of the Sanitary Code, would provide for $500 fines and six months imprisonment or both for each offense for the transit company officials should they be found guilty.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28. -- Three of the Soviet Union's best aviators were due in New York today on the steamship Olympic, on their way to join ships and other fliers in the rescue of 101 persons stranded on the ice in the Arctic Ocean, northwest of the Bering Straits.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- The British Chamber of Shipping and the Liverpool Steamship Owners Association, after years of discussion, have at last agreed on a common policy for the protection of British shipping.

ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- Early action on measures to restore open betting at the New York tracks appeared improbable tonight as members of the Legislature prepared to wait for at least another month before giving final consideration to the bills.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- A threefold relief program, designed to give special consideration to the varying needs of the unemployed and destitute in rural and urban areas, was announced by President Roosevelt today as the sequel to the Civil Works program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The value of United States exports declined 11 per cent to $170,000,000 in January, while imports increased about 4 per cent over December to $129,000,000. The values of December exports were $190,000,000 and of imports $124,300,000.

Welfare Island has had no less than six incipient prison riots in the last six days, Austin H. MacCormick, Correction Commissioner, disclosed yesterday in an address at a luncheon of the Kiwanis Club at the Hotel McAlpin. He described the island as "twin volcanoes ready to blow the roofs off the prisons."

The six-day bicycle race passed the half-way mark last night at Madison Square Garden, but the contestants continued to show the same sizzling brand of riding that has characterized the grind from the start.

Wall Street had high hopes for a time yesterday that the advance, so rudely interrupted when the threat of Federal regulation began to get on the nerves of traders, was about to be resumed. There was flurry of activity at slowly rising prices and the commission houses detected a quickening of the market pulse.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28. -- Demand for hogs was sluggish today with prices generally 10 to 25 cents lower a hundred weight, while underweights and pigs were off 25 to 50 cents, with the second-grade lights showing the most loss after having sold near the top quotations on Monday.

After a year of quiet negotiations, an investing and developing group has completed the purchase of about 1,000,000 square feet of land in Astoria, Queens, as the site for a proposed shopping centre, it was learned yesterday.

VIENNA, Feb. 28. -- The ultimatum by Theodor Habicht, German Nazi "Inspector-General for Austria," giving the Dollfuss government eight days to submit to Hitlerite demands, expired at mid-day today, but its expiration left Austria as quiet as before.

BOSTON, Feb. 28. -- A Norfolk County grand jury returned five indictments today against Murton and Irving Millen, Roxbury brothers, now under arrest in New York, and Abraham Faber, now held without bail in the Dedham jail in connection with the $14,500 robbery of the Needham Trust Company and murder of two Needham policemen on Feb. 2.

BERLIN, Feb. 28. -- The disarmament situation is viewed more hopefully in German quarters tonight than at any previous stage of the continental tour of exploration by Captain Anthony Eden, British Lord Privy Seal.
Ernest C. Howard, 52 years old, a master stone-cutter, and his wife, Mary, 50, were found dead early yesterday in a gas-filled apartment in the basement of 225 Foster Avenue, Brooklyn.

PARIS, Feb. 28. -- The Stavisky affair fills at least four-fifths of the news columns of today's papers. The investigation at Bayonne has taken new energy with the summoning of Albert Dalimier and Julien Durand, both former Ministers of Commerce, Mme. Stavisky and Rita Georg, a Viennese dancer, for questioning.

The Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra under Hans Lange last night in Carnegie Hall gave Honegger's orchestral arrangements of the French suites of Bach, Mozart's exquisite "Serenata Notturna for Two Little Orchestras"; the Mozart piano concerto in F major with Myra Hess as soloist and Rachmaninoff's Second symphony.

Mr. ROBERT MOSES has been Park Commissioner for only a little more than a month, but already the parks are beginning to show the results of his ability to get things done. Wherever there is an encroachment that can be dealt with in legal if summary fashion by a CWA worker with an axe, there its ring is being heard.

HSINKING, Feb. 28 (By Wireless). -- For the first time in his varicolored career, Henry Pu Yi, on the eve of his enthronement as Emperor of Manchukuo, granted an audience today to women outside of his immediate household.

While the local store controllers at their meeting on Tuesday night voted down the Clark method of figuring retail costs, they nevertheless favor changes in the current procedure which would better reflect retail costs to the public, it was said here yesterday.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP). -- Captain Wendell H. Brookley was killed and Captain Merrick G. Estabrook Jr. was seriously injured today when their two-seated training plane crashed near Boiling Field.

Money market was featureless. Business was small, and quotations unchanged for all classifications. Stock Exchange call loan rate continued at 1 per cent, while street trades ranged 3/4 to 1 per cent.

Arthur Turtle, State Engineer, announced yesterday that action had been taken on all remaining applications on had for Public Works funds in New York State. Ninety-four projects, calling for the expenditure of $65,448,481, were turned over yesterday to the New York State Advisory Board, he said at his office at 2 Lafayette Street.

Teams representing Barnard School for Boys, Trinity School, Lincoln School of Teachers College and Staten Island Academy triumphed in non-league schoolboy basketball games yesterday. All four won on their home courts.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- Hubert Scott-Paine, British motorboat designer and racer, today cabled the Yachtsmen's Association of America withdrawing his challenge for the Harmsworth Trophy, explaining he had been left unprepared by Canada's unexpected decision not to compete.

The New York University quintet advanced to its crucial game with City College on Saturday with its record for the season still unmarred by defeat as an aggressive Manhattan College combination became the fifteenth Violet victim last night.

Net profit of the Coca-Cola Company and subsidiaries in 1933 totaled $10,838,993, after expenses, Federal taxes, reserves .and other charges. This is equivalent, after dividend payments on the Class A stock, to $8.82 a share on 1,000,000 no-par shares of common stock and compares with $10,712,672, or $8.67 a common share, in the preceding year.

The pooling of freight revenues of the member lines of the United States Intercoastal Conference was attacked yesterday as an improper influence on the distribution of freight among competing lines, by Otis N. Shepard, vice president of the Shepard Steamship Line. Mr. Shepard testified at 45 Broadway before a Shipping Board examiner at the investigation of intercoastal shipping.

Three years ago, about the time that he finished the libretto of Jack and the Beanstalk, which Louis Gruenberg set to music, John Erskine also completed the book of "Helen Retires," which opera in three acts, with music by George Antheil, was given its first performance on any stage last night in the excellent little theatre of the Juilliard Graduate School of Music.

Two major radio networks and many independent stations scattered from coast to coast will begin this morning to confine all spot news broadcasts to two daily reports edited and supplied by the Press Radio Bureau of the Publishers National Radio Committee, headquarters of which is at 551 Fifth avenue.

George Allen Foster's "Two American Fiddle Tunes" will be produced by the Greenwich Sinfonietta tonight at the Spartacus Workers' Club, 269 West Twenty-fifth Street. The tunes introduced in the new work are "Napoleon's Retreat from Moscow," by a Tennessee fiddler in 1819, and another known as "The Devil's Dream."

The bleakest February in many years -- a month that smashed low temperature and snowfall records in many parts of the country -ended yesterday, after writing tales of death, suffering and distress over the entire nation.

DURHAM, N.H., Feb. 28. -- The University of New Hampshire varsity and freshman basketball teams defeated the respective Harvard University squads before 1,500 tonight. The varsity won, 44 to 21, and the freshmen triumphed, 28 to 19.

Criticism of West Point's methods of training was common enough in the World War among officers of the United States Army who had entered the service from civil life or from Plattsburg. It was often not discriminating, and in some cases it was mere prejudice.

For the last twenty-four hours the army air service in the Eastern Zone flew all schedules except the 11:15 A.M. flight to Boston, it was announced last night at Newark Airport. Lieutenant George S. Shulgen, in charge of operations, said all further flying to Boston would be cancelled until those in control of the airport there improved landing conditions.
Futures prices turned irregular yesterday on local commodity exchanges. Trading was in fair volume. Cash prices were mixed.

An application for the listing of $1,417,000 additional first-mortgage 5 per cent bonds of the Duluth Iron Range Railroad Company has been approved by the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange. The bonds were issued in 1911 by the railroad, which is a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, but through an oversight they were not formally added to the amount listed on the Exchange.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28. -- Walker Wynekoop, eldest son of Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop, went to the witness stand at his mother's murder trial today to try to save her from imprisonment or execution.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 28. -Favorites made a sweep of their first-round matches in the Florida East Coast women's golf championship for the Mrs. W.R. Kenan Jr. Cup on St. Augustine links today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Senator Gore of Oklahoma, a member of the Senate Finance Committee, in an effort to stop payment of excessive corporation salaries and bonuses, as revealed in the Federal Trade Commission's recent report to the Senate, offered an amendment to the Revenue Bill today to impose a heavy tax on bonuses and salaries the total of which is in excess of $75,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Speaker Rainey said today the army air corps was insufficient and poorly trained, and indicated that he would support the McSwain resolution for investigation of War Department procurement methods.

HSINKING, Thursday, March 1. -A new empire was ceremonially created today in the ancient domain of the Manchus with the enthronement of young Henry Pu Yi, the last of his dynastic clan, in a centuries-old ritual.

Returns to date indicate that net operating income of the Class I railroads in January was $29,200,000, against $13,265,000 in January, 1933, an increase of 120.1 per cent, and against $11,182,000 in January, 1932, an increase of 161.1 per cent. This result was obtained although the increase in gross over 1933 was only 13.4 per cent, or from $226,555,000 to $257,000,000.

President Roosevelt, after considering the report of his Committee on Wild Life Restoration, is expected to announce formal approval of the document within a few days. When and if he approves the program, it was announced yesterday, the Department of Agriculture is ready to buy 325,000 acres of land in seven States for breeding and nesting areas.

The threatened general strike of unskilled employes of moving picture theatres as voted by the Theatre and Amusement Employes Union, Local 118, of the A.F. of L., was averted yesterday as a result of the intervention of the Regional Labor Board.

HSINKING, Thursday, March 1. -- The populace of this Manchurian capital was lackadaisical, even under rigid military supervision, this morning as it watched Henry Pu Yi proceed from his antiquated temporary palace to the Temple of Heaven to become the Emperor Kang Teh of Manchukuo.
All leases for private concessions in city parks, except those absolutely necessary, will be revoked, Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday.

PANAMA CITY, Feb. 28. -- A futile appeal by General Augusto C. Sandino that his life be spared is revealed in a deposition, said to have been made by the Nicaragaan leader's father and smuggled out of the country despite the censorship. The statement is printed in The Panama American today.
Robert H. Hale and Edward S. Flash have formed the firm of Hale Flash to deal in United States Government securities at 30 Pine Street.

The American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., announced yesterday that the registration statement for its issue of $15,000,000 of 5 per cent convertible collateral-trust bonds, due on March 1, 1944, filed with the Federal Trade Commission, had become effective.

BERLIN, Feb. 28. -- Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda and Public Enlightenment, invited representatives of the foreign press in Berlin to the Wilhelmstrasse this afternoon, apparently with a desire to reach an understanding with them as to the broad lines upon which their dispatches to foreign countries should be predicated.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The House today, by a vote of 275 to 110, refused for a second time to grant funds for maintenance of the subsistence homestead project at Reedsville, W. Va., sponsored by Mrs. Roosevelt.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28. -- A strong wind swept the Pasadena course today, but it failed to hamper Paul Runyan of White Plains, N.Y., who equaled par with a 72 for a 36-hole total of 141, three under par, to carry off the St. Petersburg open golf championship. He had 69 yesterday.

PARIS, Thursday, March 1 (AP). -Premier Gaston Doumergue, exercising a "moral dictatorship," forced through his budget early today after an all-night session during which Parliament added special tariff regulating powers to the powers already granted him to make economies.
Relative to your editorial "Mortgage Relief," I suggest that Governor Lhman's plan be extended to also help the owners of property subject to mortgages issued by the defunct title companies.

ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- There is a growing conviction at the Capitol that if Mayor LaGuardia stands firm against compromise proposals from the Democratic leaders of the Legislature, the Mayor's Economy Bill, with some changes, but none unacceptable to the Mayor, will be passed by both the Senate and Assembly next week.

LONDON, Feb. 28 (Canadian Press). -- Oxford University, striving to break a ten-year string of defeats in the classic boat race with Cambridge University, suffered a blow to its hopes when one of its crew turned up today with an infected hand.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 28 (AP). -- Major Clyde C. Johnston, senior flight surgeon at Fort Sam Houston, testified today at a court-martial trying Major William C. Ocker, veteran army pilot and pioneer in blind flying, on charges of making derogatory remarks concerning a superior officer, that he had altered records which removed Major Ocker from flying status on grounds of physical disability.

A review of the business of the North American Company and its subsidiaries for 1933 "presents a two-sided picture of somewhat greater activity measured in terms of output of electricity, the principal class of business, yet of somewhat lower earnings," says James F. Fogarty, president, in his annual report.

With raw steel production estimated at 47 per cent of capacity, compared with 44 1/2 per cent a week ago, "the upward surge of activity has gathered added momentum," according to The Iron Age's mid-week review. Tht publication reports also that prices of scrap steel have reached a new high level for the movement and that "consumer demand has become more and more diversified."

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 28 (AP). -Some of filmland's leading stars of today might have been excluded from Hollywood if the measures approved today by the House Immigration Committee in Washington had been in effect several years ago.
Mayor LaGuardia and other speakers at the Yeshiva College dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria last night denounced the persecution of the Jews in Central Europe and urged religious tolerance here.

Assemblyman Steingut's latest proposal, suggesting a reduction in interest rate of certain of the city's obligations, is the utterance of a person totally ignorant of the adverse ramifications involved should such reduction be effected. Mr. Steingut further proposes a thorough study of the city's finances and the working out of some plan which would render financing through the public rather than through the banks.

BERLIN, Feb. 28. -- The Boerse continued its upward movement today, due to increased public interest in stocks which manifested itself in cash purchases. Gains ranged beyond four points. Potashes led the movement and heavy industrials, electricals, textiles and cellulose followed suit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP). -Responding to pleas of actors and singers that their jobs were being taken by foreigners of inferior qualifications, the House Immigration Committee today approved two bills designed to limit the influx of foreign performers.

TOKYO, Thursday, March 1. -- By two weeks of masterly inactivity Premier Saito has allowed the political storm that arose Feb. 16 over the charges that Ichiro Hatoyama, Minister of Education, corruptly accepted money from corporations to blow itself out without seriously injuring the government.
Yale, defending champion in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League, put on a sensational second-period rally last night to defeat Columbia, 34 -- 28, in the Morningside Heights gymnasium.

Mrs. Rollin Pierson Grant gave a luncheon yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Ten Eyck Wendell, Mrs. Elisha C. Tower, Mrs. Theodore Schumacher, Mrs. Ten Eyck Wendell Jr., Mrs. Lewis Latham Clarke, Mrs. Joseph B. Long and Mrs. Robert Morris Phillips.

Pressure against the speculative markets relaxed for a time yesterday and there was a partial recovery all along the line. Fresh weakness cropped out before the end of the day, however, and prices generally were lower at the close.

Plans governing play in the various circuits of indoor polo, the first phase of the national championship, were announced yesterday by the executive committee of the Indoor Polo Association of America. There will be no circuit elimination competition for teams in the senior and junior divisions, such play being confined to trios in the low-goal class.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- President Roosevelt will send a message to Congress, probably tomorrow, asking authority to negotiate and promulgate reciprocal tariff agreements for a period of three years with the limitation that present duties shall not be increased or lowered more than 50 per cent.

The first performance this season of Gotterdammerung" will take place at the Metropolitan Opera House on Friday afternoon next week as part of the annual matinee cycle of Wagner's operas, Mmes. Leider, Olszewska and Manski and Messrs.

Entries for the Star Class Spring championship and the Johnnie Walker open series at Nassau, Bahamas, were given out yesterday by George W. Elder, president of the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association.

Mayor LaGuardia's criticism of the Bureau of Crime Prevention was answered in several quarters yesterday as calling for an increased appropriation of at least $500,000 a year and as "unwarranted disregard of the bureau's many accomplishments."
The New York Curb Exchange has a new form of questionnaire, to be filled out by applicants for full listing, which delves into points that formerly were ignored.

San Francisco, Calif. The city and County of San Francisco. Calif., plans to market on Monday a new issue of $600,000 of relief bonds, due serially fron 1936 to 1947. This will be the final block of $6,500,000 of bonds authorized for the purpose. The interest rate on the block is not to exceed 6 per cent.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- The stock market continued active and firm today. Industrials were strong under the lead of Courtaulds which received renewed support following the excellent report of the company. British funds were stimulated by revenue returns. Foreign bonds were brighter.

Count Vasco da Gama, big-game hunter and explorer and a lineal descendant of the Portuguese mariner of the same name, was committed to jail for ten days yesterday by Magistrate Harris in West Side Court for killing a dog.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Representative Rayburn, one of the sponsors of the Exchange Regulation Bill, indicated today the possibility of a broad general revision of the measure.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- In the same week two administration counselors who could not agree -- when working together -- on the theory or method of disposing of the crop surplus are proceeding, each in his own way, to attack the problem. Each has been given broad powers, is in charge of an important administration policy and boss of a big show.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Ernest W. Smoot, son of the former Senator from Utah, testified today to a Senate committee that he received $13,000 for handling publicity for a favorable beet sugar tariff during 1929 when he was serving as clerk of the Senate Finance Committee and his father, as chairman of the committee, was directing the Hawley-Smoot tariff bill.

By mutual agreement, the city and Transit Commission will set in motion within the next few days litigation designed to test the constitutionality of the State law under which the commission, since 1921, has been exercising jurisdiction over rapid-transit unification matters.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 28. -- "Governmental regulation in industry will involve a limitation of national freedom against which the people will ultimately revolt," declared Professor Philip Cabot of the Harvard School of Business Administration, in an address read to members of the Baltimore Association of Commerce today.

The coming of a new cave-man age, with vast, air-conditioned, luxurious theatres and office buildings a mile or more underground, is a promise held out for the near future in a report on recent researches conducted jointly by Columbia University and the Engineering Foundation.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
Two business buildings in the garment area and a residence in the Lenox Hill section were purchased yesterday by Frederick Brown, operator.

The consolidated gross income statement of the Port of New York Authority for bridges and tunnels in 1933 shows a balance of $8,045,916 available for interest and reserves, a reduction of $20,600, or less than one-quarter of 1 per cent from that of the year before, it was announced yesterday.

Pu Yr was the last Emperor of China. He becomes after twenty-two years the first Emperor of Manchukuo. At the time of the proclamation of the Chinese Republic in 1912 he was 6 years old, and it is not likely that the change in his personal fortunes provided him with much food for thought.

In the March Atlantic, Mr. EUSTACE SELIGMAN dissects the extreme provisions of the Securities Act. He endorses the purposes of the bill. He points out that the popular notion of deliberately misleading prospectuses as the general cause for the losses by investors in 1929 is erroneous.

The production of "Helen Retires," to be repeated tonight and again tomorrow and Saturday, drew to the Juilliard School at 130 Claremont Avenue last evening an audience of social, musical, literary and stage folk of New York who filled all the 999 chairs in the orchestra floor and balcony of the hall.
ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- Governor Lehman today signed three bills. One continued the life of the Commission on the Administration of Justice until March 1, next year.

Helen Oelheim, contralto, included beautiful and infrequently heard songs on the program of her debut recital in the Town Hall last night. The recital opened with Meyerbeer's aria "Nobles Seigneurs, Salut!" from "Les Huguenots." Works of Lully, Marais, Rameau, Gretry, a group of Brahms, songs in English by Golde, Carpenter, Arensky and Gabrilowitsch, Mahler's lovely "Rheinlegendschen" and Korngold's brilliant, amusing "Standschen," his "Liebesbriefchen" and Kaun's "Dir Sieger" comprised the program.

TRENTON, Feb. 28. -- The State Department of Agriculture reported today that New Jersey's dairy farmers gained more than $5,000,000 in income last year. The increase was attributed to efforts of the State Milk Control Board.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday that CWA workers under Park Department supervision had begun construction of the seven-block playground from Canal to Houston Street, between Chrystie and Forsyth Streets. The land has been turned over to the Park Department by the Sinking Fund Commission to be made into a playground.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- House leaders decided today to stand by President Roosevelt and oppose the restoration of special veterans' benefits denied under the Economy Act. After, so deciding, Speaker Rainey and Representative Byrns called off the Democratic conference scheduled for tonight, at which the party was to decide upon some stand in the veterans' matter.

HSINKING, Thursday, March 1. -- Kang Teh, who became Emperor of Manchukuo today, declared that "it will be my constant aim to prove worthy of the divine mandate of kingship the Most High God has conferred upon me."

Charges made by Charles Franklin, counsel for the Manhattan Railway Company, in testimony last week before the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee investigating the Interborough receivership are described as "gross misstatements" in a letter made public yesterday by Hornblower, Miller, Miller Boston. solicitors for the receivers.

Total assets of the Prudential Insurance Company of America reached a new high total of $2,835,007,067 at the end of 1933, according to excerpts from the forthcoming annual report made public yesterday. This compares with $2,773,769,344 reported at the end of the preceding year.

Thirty-five years ago Pablo Gargallo, Mr. Brummer tells us, was just another of Europe's naturalistic sculptors, rounding out his forms with a thoroughness, a regard for the incorporation of detail, that one expects to find embodied in realism. Today a startling reversal of method is seen to have taken place.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 28. -- Jockey Eddie Litzenberger scored a triple at Hialeah Park today, including the featured Winter Park Purse in his sweep. He was up on L.M. Severson's Spicson, 25-to-1 shot, in the main event and came from behind with the son of Spic and Span to score by half a length.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP). -- The Kansas City Southern Railway agreed after a conference between officials of the line and Joseph B. Eastman, Coordinator of Transportation, to postpone until April 1 installation of a new plan of wage payments and working rules which had caused employes to threaten to strike tomorrow.

Howard Davis, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, was selected yesterday as a member and chairman of the Code Authority of the Daily Newspaper Code. Four other members of the Authority were also selected.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 28. -- The heavyweight championship battle between Primo Carnera, titleholder, and Tommy Loughran, Philadelphia challenger, scheduled for tonight in the Madison Square Garden Bowl, was postponed because of rain.

ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- The LaGuardia administration in New York City joined today with the Public Service Commission, the Power Authority and several consumer groups in urging approval of Governor Lehman's utility program.

The annual report of the Western Electric Company, Inc., for 1933, records sales of $69,511,000, 16.9 per cent of the total in the peak year of 1929, when sales were $410,950,000, and comparing with $117,850,000 in 1932.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Warned by Roosevelt leaders against embarrassing the administration through further complication of the uncertain war debt situation, the Senate by a 2-to-1 vote today buried in the Foreign Relations Committee the resolution by Senator Robinson of Indiana calling upon the President for details regarding debt negotiations.

ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- The Assembly Codes Committee, of which Assemblyman James R. Robinson of Tompkins County is chairman, will set a date for a public hearing without delay on the bill sponsored by Assemblyman Edward S. Moran Jr. of Kings, which would prevent banks, trust companies, insurance companies and any corporation or voluntary association from offering their services by means of advertising as counsel, administrators, executors, trustees, committees or guardians of any estate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- A charge that the Fletcher-Rayburn Stock Exchange regulation bill might have been written for the purpose of indirectly establishing a form of "nationalization of industry and business hitherto alien to the American theory of Federal government" was made before the Senate. Banking Committee today by Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe, presiding last night at a meeting of creditors of the New York United Hotels, Inc., owner of the Hotel Roosevelt, received an offer of $25,000 for the hotel after he had decided, in the face of opposition, to consider bids.

The Dodgers have signed Van Lingle Mungo. Announcement that the young fireball hurler, who didn't get a start against the Giants last season until July and then beat them five times, came from the Brooklyn offices yesterday.

Purchase of the thirty-two-acre William R. Spann estate in Loantaka Way, Morristown, by George A. Easley featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday. In addition to the sixteen-room and five-bath residence, a cottage and service buildings are on the landscaped plot. Mr. Easley lives in Morristown. Fred A. Barbanes and Mrs. E.H. Fanshawe were the brokers.

Three thousand women, members and guests of the Women's Association of the American Jewish Congress, crowded into the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore yesterday afternoon to attend a tea and reception in honor of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Prince Iyesato Tokugawa, former President of the House of Peers of Japan, was the guest of honor at a dinner given tonight at the Mayflower by the Japanese Ambassador and Mme. Saito. With him were his son, Prince Iyemasa Tokugawa, Japanese Minister to Canada, and the latter's daughter, Miss Hope Tokugawa, who arrived yesterday to remain until Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- President Roosevelt announced a three-fold relief plan to succeed the Civil Works Administration and prepared to ask Congress for additional tariff powers.

Prince Carlo Maurizio Ruspoli, Count Theo Rossi de Montelera and Antonio Becchi, the three drivers who will represent Italy in the international motorboat races in Florida, arrived yesterday aboard the Rex of the Italian Line.

Three thousand women, members and guests of the Women's Association of the American Jewish Congress, crowded into the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore yesterday afternoon to attend a tea and reception in honor of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Prince Iyesato Tokugawa, former President of the House of Peers of Japan, was the guest of honor at a dinner given tonight at the Mayflower by the Japanese Ambassador and Mme. Saito. With him were his son, Prince Iyemasa Tokugawa, Japanese Minister to Canada, and the latter's daughter, Miss Hope Tokugawa, who arrived yesterday to remain until Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- President Roosevelt announced a three-fold relief plan to succeed the Civil Works Administration and prepared to ask Congress for additional tariff powers.

Prince Carlo Maurizio Ruspoli, Count Theo Rossi de Montelera and Antonio Becchi, the three drivers who will represent Italy in the international motorboat races in Florida, arrived yesterday aboard the Rex of the Italian Line.

A three-point program for reforms in the concept and method of financing urban homes is advanced by John H. Fahey, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, in an article in the current American Bankers Association Journal.
After an absence of two years, Jean Borotra returned to the United States yesterday, leading a new, young French team in quest of indoor tennis honors.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 28. -- A brilliant second-half offense enabled the Penn basketball team to regain undisputed possession of first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League tonight. Princeton bowed to the Quakers, 37 -- 27.

BERLIN, Feb. 28. -- Ten years ago today a Berlin correspondent who had drifted to the Madeira Islands in search of a little Winter warmth and sunshine happened to wander into a whitewashed church stuck on a bare rock overlooking the blue ocean.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 6. -- Twenty-two years after his father, Prince Ch'un, acting as Regent, signed an abdication for him from the Dragon throne, 28-year-old Henry Pu Yi, who was the last of the Manchu Emperors to sit on China's throne, resumes imperial rank.

Two men, accused of being implicated in a new "shakedown" racket, were arrested by detectives yesterday in the brokerage office of Carleton Saunders at 605 Broad Street, Newark. The men, Benjamin Kahn, 28 years old, a salesman, who gave as his address the Second Avenue Baths, Second Avenue and Fourth Street, and Abe Metzger, 38, of 138 West Fifty-eighth Street.

Banks in this city have agreed to advance $1,000,000 to pay off tax arrears on properties covered by the $27,000,000 mortgage certificates in Series F-1 of the New York Title and Mortgage Company. This was announced yesterday by trustees appointed by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler to take charge of that series.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28. -Before an unusually large number of subscribers, Dr. Herbert Adams Gibbons and Colonel Frederick Palmer, both decorated for distinguished service as war correspondents, debated the subject, "Is the NRA Leading to Socialism?" at the fourth meeting of the current events series held this afternoon at Villa Flora, the home of Mrs. Edward Shearson. Tea was served after the discussion.

THE Carnera-Loughran open-air opus at Miami Beach was postponed, but there is no need to play the overture over again. In the meanwhile, there is the curious case of Herr Franz Deulberg of Germany who was observed yesterday free wheeling with whiskers in the six-day race at the Garden.

Miss Eileen Beresford of Short Hills, recent winner of the Ardsley invitation fixture, and Miss Betty Woolsey of New Haven, New Jersey State champion, gained the final bracket in the invitation squash racquets tournament at the Junior League yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- Without a flicker of emotion, Prince Felix Youssoupoff declared on the witness stand today that he had killed Russia's "mad monk," Rasputin, by battering his head with a loaded stick.

The official end of Theodore Brandle's rule as czar of Northern New Jersey labor circles was marked last night by the induction of his successor, John O'Neill, 30 years old, of 459 Jersey Avenue, Jersey City, as business manager of Local 45, International Association of Bridge, Structural and Ornamental Iron Workers Union.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 28. -- A telegram from Los Angeles published ira your issue of Feb. 22, apparently an Associated Press dispatch, unintentionally misrepresents the meaning of my address before the Los Angeles Breakfast Club on Feb. 20.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 28. -Bermuda is solidly opposed to being handed over to the United States as part payment for the British war debt.
" Yellow Jack," the new Sidney Howard play, which was scheduled to open this evening at the Martin Beck Theatre, has been postponed until Tuesday evening.
DUBLIN, Feb. 28. -- Sharp exchanges marked the debate in the Dail Eireann this afternoon on the second reading of the bill to ban the wearing of blue shirts or other insignia of political parties.
HSINKING, Thursday, March 1 (AP). -- The second anniversary of the independence of Manchukuo was observed with patriotic ceremonies today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The Senate adopted today the joint resolution passed in the House last April permitting the President to prevent shipment of arms or munitions abroad.

Again the public is hearing what a terrible thing it is for any man or company to work from a "profit-motive." Talk of this kind had quite a run when we were in the pit of depression, but with the general improvement in business and manufacture it has been dying out.

NEW SMYRNA, Fla., Feb. 28. -Rain washed out the trials today to select an American team of four outboard motorboat drivers to meet the European pilots in the international races that are to start here on Saturday.
Andrew Ponzi, 30-year-old Philadelphian, last night captured the world's pocket billiard championship by defeating Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland in the challenge match for the title, 750 to 607.

Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, former Governor General of the Philippines, was elected president of the National Health Council at the organization's annual meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday. The council is composed of seventeen national health organizations, and its objects are to promote the prevention of disease by acting as a clearing house for member organizations, unifying health education procedure, preventing duplication of work and bringing about economies of administration.

Herman Blume, Municipal Court stenographer, who hired a substitute to do his work for the last eleven years at a profit of $11,000 to himself, said yesterday that this practice was common and that it was not unusual for the substitute to be paid less than the theoretical incumbent.
