MADRID, Feb. 27. -- Two or three Ministers are reported to have offered their resignations to Premier Lerroux at a special Cabinet conference today, but no official confirmation was available tonight. A statement may be issued after the regular ministerial council at the Presidential Palace tomorrow.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- Hundreds of shabbily dressed hunger marchers went sightseeing today through the Gothic halls of the Houses of Parliament and had tea in the terrace rooms overlooking the Thames. Members of the House of Commons from industrial areas acted as guides, shepherding their hunger-marching constituents through the building.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28. -- Use of a plan similar to the National Recovery Act was predicted seventeen years ago by Representative Charles A. Lindbergh Sr., father of the flier, according to the preface to a book, "Your Country at War," written by the elder Lindbergh in 1917 and to be published here tomorrow by Dorrance Co.

Members of the Old Guard faction of the Republican party have decided definitely to make a primary fight against W. Kingsland Macy, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, who announced recently that he was a candidate for reelection.

On the night of Feb. 27, Major Gen. Foulois delivered a radio address in which he maintained that the army is perfectly capable of flying United States mails. In conclusion he said: "I should like also to ask you to discount as unfair, unfounded and untrue certain of the recent accusations and headline-seeking phrases which have reflected not only against the efficiency of the air corps personnel, but also against the present administration."
Joan Crawford, when she completes her ro1e in "Sadie McKee," will be featured in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's film version of "Sacred and Profane Love," based on Arnold Bennett's novel and play.

The plight of the city's unemployed was brought graphically to Mayor LaGuardia's attention yesterday when two young men applying for snow removal work collapsed from hunger in the Mayor's reception room at City Hall.

It was the slogan in an earlier Administration that civilization advances upon the feet of healthy children. From authoritative sources it is reported that child mortality has not increased during the depression. The gross death rate has actually gone down since 1929 and infant mortality has also decreased.

Air mail carried by the army from Newark Airport from Feb. 22 to March 1 inclusive totaled 9,288 pounds, it was made known yesterday. A check of the commercial air lines revealed that this amount was about half that carried by them from the same field in their last seven days of operation.
Mayor LaGuardia and Chief Inspector Lewis J. Valentine got out of the Mayor's car at 11:30 yesterday morning in front of the three-story brownstone rooming house at 807 Quincy Street, Brooklyn.

LONDON, March 1. -- The discovery of the body of a mysterious sea animal at Cherbourg has aroused the keenest speculation here as to whether it is the same animal that created excitement at Loch Ness last Fall.
MADRID, March 1. -- The coalition Cabinet headed by Alejandro Lerroux resigned today under circumstances which have drawn an issue between Monarchists and Republicans.
MIAMI, Fla., March 1. -- "Tommy Loughran is the greatest fighter I ever met."

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 1. -- An event of both cultural and social interest was the musicale with which Mr. and Mrs. Charlton Yarnall entertained today at the Everglades Club. Benjamin de Loache, baritone with the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra, was the artist.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- President Roosevelt sent his first veto message to Congress this afternoon when he disapproved a bill to give an honorable discharge to Beryl M. McHam, an army deserter who served in Company C, Twenty-sixth. Infantry, and Company C, Eighth Infantry, in France and Germany.

Excess reserves of the member banks of the Federal Reserve System reached a new high mark at about $1,100,000,000 this week, it was indicated yesterday upon publication of the weekly statement of the Federal Reserve System. The reserve balances of the member banks rose $263,000,000, the statement showed, one of the largest weekly expansions of bank reserves ever recorded.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., March 1. -- Evidence was heard secretly here today in a divorce suit, brought by Mrs. Mary Atwell Hitchcock of New York City, against Francis C.E. Hitchcock, brother of Thomas Hitchcock Jr., the polo player. Mrs. Hitchcock based her suit on charges involving an unnamed cloak model in a Fifth Avenue shop as corespondent.
LONDON, March 1 (AP) . -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

An investment loss of $44,000,000 in its purchases of listed securities is shown by the Pennroad Corporation, investment affiliate of the Pennsylvania Railroad, in its report for 1933. This loss is exclusive of those suffered in securities, of which a majority are owned by the company or in unlisted securities.

Harry F. Wolf of the New York A.C. set out on a campaign yesterday to carry off the national amateur squash tennis championship for the fifth time in a row, a distinction no player has ever gained in the sport.

PARIS, March 1. -- More than 3,000,000,000 francs have left the gold reserves of the Bank of France since the week ended on Jan. 19. Official figures published today cover withdrawals up to Feb. 23, completing six weeks of steady decline. Between Jan. 19 and the later date the bank's losses were 3,282,000,000 francs.

LONDON, March 1. -- A number of hunger marchers who obtained tickets to the Strangers' Gallery of the House of Commons tonight several times interrupted debate on the Russian trade treaty, wrestling with police and detectives, who ejected them.

The lead in the six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden shifted constantly last night as the teams rode into their fifth twenty-four-hour session. While a crowd of 10,000 persons cheered, the tireless pedalers churned away relentlessly, apparently with no regard for the grueling stretches that lay ahead of them.

Norman Thomas, who has just returned from a swing through nine Southern and Mid-Western States, studying the workings of the New Deal, said yesterday that he saw "no chance at all to get by without serious trouble on the basis of the present relief program or the President's revision of it."

Stocks moved narrowly and lazily yesterday in extremely quiet trading. Price movements in the bond market were irregular. Grain prices were reduced fractionally, but cotton showed modest gains. There was no quotable change in the dollar's position in the international market.

LONG BEACH, L.I., March 1. -- Robert E. Miller, representing holders of Long Beach City notes totaling $465,000, notified Mayor Charles Gold today that suit will be brought immediately to collect. The notes are demand instruments.

PARIS, March 1. -- By voting the 1934 budget in the early hours of this morning -- although according to Parliament's clock it was still midnight -- the French legislators unloaded the responsibility for balancing the budget upon Premier Gaston Doumergue.

Word that "Work of Art," by Sinclair Lewis, topped all of its previous sales records last week comes from the publishers, Doubleday, Doran. Two editions totaling 50,000 copies had been sold on the book's publication date, Jan. 24, and new carloads of paper were quickly ordered for more editions.

LONDON, March 1. -- Estimates of British Navy expenditures for the next financial year, approved by the Cabinet tonight, are understood to show a considerable increase, which is put at 2,000,000 to 3,000,000 above last year's figure of 53,570,000.

CHICAGO, March 1. -- The New York Rangers, taking advantage of every opening, conquered the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 to 1, tonight to gain undisputed possession of second place in the National Hockey League's American group.

Lieutenant Charles H. Eason of the Coney Island precinct announced last night that he had obtained an oral confession from Irving Millen that he and his brother Murton and Abraham Faber participated in the Needham (Mass.) bank hold-up in which two policemen were killed.

Although no official figures were available last night and will not be until after the polls close this morning, it appeared yesterday that fewer than two dozen votes were cast by employes of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company in the poll ordered by the Regional Labor Board on the question of their union affiliation.
Resale of a Hoboken business building featured the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday:

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Negotiations for a new contract for bituminous miners of the Appalachian region began today with a demand by the United Mine Workers of America for a "substantial" increase in wages and the seven-hour day and five-day week in place of the eight-hour day and five-day week.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP). -- The Federal Government today took over control of relief activities in North Dakota, Harry L. Hopkins, the administrator, said, because political contributions had been collected from employes of the State Relief Administration.

Mrs. Preston Davie announced yesterday her resignation as chairman of the finance committee of the Republican State Committee. She will devote her main political effort to the Republican Builders, which she founded and which hereafter will be national instead of State-wide in scope.
VIENNA, March 1. -- "Otto of Hapsburg, Emperor of Austria and King of Hungary, can never crawl over the fence like a thief to ascend the throne of his ancestors."

Rich with the exciting facts of 1933, one of the most momentous years in American history, the new issue of The American Year Book comes from the press today. Featuring it is a comprehensive survey of every aspect of the national recovery program.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Convinced that there was considerable truth in the outpouring this week of grievances against provisions in NRA codes, the National Recovery Administration began drawing up its suggestions today for the 519 Code Authorities and committees which will begin meeting here next Monday.

ALBANY, March 1. -- Governor Lehman, in conference with representatives of large moneyed institutions of New York City, reached an agreement today under which $10,000,000 will be advanced by the institutions to insure the supplying of $100,000,000 by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for the relief of holders of some $1,000,000,000 worth of guaranteed mortgage certificates.

After making public the list of county jobs he intends to abolish if his economy bill is passed, Mayor LaGuardia said yesterday that pay cuts and abolition of jobs would be extended through city departments as well on the same ratio.

The $340,000 war memorial fund collected in 1918 and then lost to sight until a few weeks ago will be spent to establish five playgrounds, one in a congested section of each borough, if court approval can be obtained, A.A. Berle Jr., City Chamberlain, announced yesterday.

The Guaranty Trust Company announced yesterday that it had been advised by the Ministry of Colonies of the Kingdom of the Netherlands that the new 4 per cent guilder loan into which the present outstanding Dutch East Indies dollar bonds may be converted had been authorized and that the subscription books in Holland would be officially opened from March 1 to 16.

The American Reserve Insurance Company of New York reported yesterday for 1933 a net premium income of $3,000,694, compared with $2,034,219 in 1932. After providing the required reserves to protect this volume to expiration of the risks assumed, the earned premium totals $2,817,351, an increase of $680,640.

Retail volume picked up sharply here yesterday with improved weather conditions. Store executives were confident of a quick resumption of the advancing trend in retail sales noted until the repeated storms seriously cut down volume.

No change was recorded for the last week by The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices, the index standing at 108.2 on Tuesday, unchanged from the revised figure of a week before. However, with foreign quotations for the dollar reflecting a decline in terms of the old dollar to 59.7 cents from 60.1, the index in terms of the old dollar declined to 64.6 from 65.0 (revised).

In his testimony before a House subcommittee yesterday, Secretary MORGENTHAU Was frank, modest and cautious. When questioned about the future monetary policy of the Government he said he did not know what it would be or ought to be, and added that he believed no one is "sufficiently "wise to tell you, because we haven't "had enough experience."
SHANGHAI, March 1. -- Chinese newspaper editorials on the enthronement of Henry Pu Yi as Emperor Kang Teh of Manchukuo call him "a monkey in a Punch and Judy show."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 1. -- City Treasurer John P. Nestler announced today the retirement of an additional $50,000 of the $1,250,000 tax anticipation certificates recently purchased by the Bank of Manhattan Company, reducing the outstanding loan to $1,000,000.

Six institutions will benefit under the will of Mrs. Mary Helena Tompkins, widow of William Wright Tompkins and daughter of the late Mayor Ambrose C. Kingsland, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday. One of the institutions will eventually receive more than $500,000.

Betty Jarvis, a comely, dark-haired girl of 20, pleaded at the police line-up yesterday as she was questioned about her attempt to hold up a Harlem delicatessen store that she had done it to get money to hire a lawyer for her husband, Lester, who was arrested for a hold-up Saturday.

BERLIN, March 1 (By Wireless) -- In England, France and other countries the revolution that has happened in Germany is bewildering and alarming. Here in Berlin, where I have been talking with well-informed people, trying to see into the minds of men and women who belong to the Nazi faith or live under its rule, it is even more bewildering.

NEW ORLEANS, March 1. -- Sir Koster, 3-year-old son of Sir Peter and Koster Girl, carried the colors of Mrs. A. Van den Ende to victory in the featured six-furlong sprint at the Fair Grounds today. Mrs. R.T. Flippen's Esperanto was second and John J. Robinson's Dessner third.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The government's monetary program was described as "distinctly" an experiment today by the Secretary of the Treasury, who said it would be better if Congress kept hands off for at least a year, so that "we may find out a little more about the situation."

BERLIN, March 1, -- According to information given out by the secret State police today the number of political prisoners still held in "protective custody" in Germany has decreased to between 7,500 and 18,000.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Opposition which, in the Senate, may assume the proportions of a filibuster was indicated among Progressive and Conservative Republicans today to President Roosevelt's reciprocal tariff program, by which power would be given to the administration to raise and lower duties by not more than 50 per cent in negotiating trade agreements to stimulate foreign commerce.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- President Roosevelt has ordered the Census Bureau to make a tabulation of the citizen and alien population of the five counties making up New York City, to be used as a basis for reapportioning the city's representation in the Legislature.

Edgar F. Luckenbach, dean of intercoastal shipping operators, termed the United States Intercoastal Conference yesterday a "big hold-up" designed to compensate the operators of slow ships for their lethargy at the expense of shippers. He testified before an examiner of the Shipping Board Bureau of the Department of Commerce at the investigation of the intercoastal shipping situation which is under way at 45 Broadway.

HSINKING, Friday, March 2. -- During a day filled with pomp and ceremony accompanying the establishment of the new monarchy an unexpected factor developed, doing more to arouse general enthusiasm than all the prearranged parades and celebrations.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles de Courcy Hughes gave a farewell dinner last night at the Gotham for Mr. and Mrs. Robert Anthony Green, who will sail soon for China. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Augustus G. Kellogg, Mr. and Mrs. Lambert Dunbar of Hongkong, Miss Nance Nieman, Miss Anne Harris, Samuel J.H. Fox, St. George R. Clark, Patrick D.M. Munro, Newton J. Stabb and Charles M. Cobb.

Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony men at the Brooklyn Academy tonight play Bach's third Branderburg concerto, Schubert's "Unfinished" symphony, Debussy's "Nocturnes" and Scriabin's "Poeme d'Extase."
Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe approved yesterday a bid of $25,000 offered for the purchase of the Hotel Roosevelt, a twenty-two-story structure, which was built in 1924 as a $10,000,000 enterprise.

At last Mayor LAGUARDIA has shown the Tammany tiger in its lair by giving a bill of particulars. Publication of sample lists of county positions he intends to ask the Board of Estimate to reduce in pay, or else abolish altogether, the moment the Economy Act is adopted, reveals the true cause of the stubborn resistance to that measure on the part of organization Democrats.
MIAMI, Fla., March 1. -- The round-by-round description of the Primo Carnera-Tommy Loughran fight follows:

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- A sharp difference of opinion between Secretary Dern and Representative McSwain, chairman of the House Military Affairs Committee, over plans to enlarge the Army Air Corps was revealed today. Mr. Dern made public a letter he sent on Feb. 21 to Mr. McSwain, strongly criticizing two bills the committee chairman has introduced and urging their immediate discard by the committee.
ALBANY, March 1. -- Bills to create a special term in the Supreme Court to deal with condemnation cases in New York City were introduced in the Legislature.

PARIS, Friday, March 2. -- Early this morning Albert Sarraut, Minister of the Interior, issued a communique to the press announcing that the stubs of checks paid out by Alexandre Stavisky which had been lost were recovered tonight through the intervention of the Surete Generale, France's secret service.
All sections of the money market were quiet, and rates unchanged from the preceding Say. Stock Exchange call loans were 1 per cent, street trades 3/4 @ 7/8.

The administrative board of the New York division of the Federal Civil Works Administration, headed by Alfred H. Schoellkopf, received a delegation of CWA workers and unemployed persons yesterday at 6 P.M. and listened to their complaints for an hour and a half.
WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Three amendments to the pending tax bill seeking to tighten it still further were prepared by Senator Borah today. They have these aims:

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date, while total bills discounted were at the lowest. The ratio of reserve for the New York bank also reached a new high figure for the year.

LONDON, March 1. -- The belief, shared by the public as well as by business and official circles, that Britain is making a decisive recovery from the depression was strengthened today by a variety of fresh evidence.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Feb. 28, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,574,000,000, a decrease of $16,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $11,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1933.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today to authorize $2,000,000,000 in bonds that may be exchanged for home mortgages as direct government obligations, just as farm mortgage bonds to the same amount have already been guaranteed.

If parliamentary government is decaying in England, at last one can understand the causing cause. In a letter to The London Times Mr. MICHAEL MAcDONAGH, that veteran parliamentary reporter, recalls his first view of the House of Commons from the Reporters' Gallery at the beginning of the session of 1887:
Further promotions and demotions in the detective division, involving some well-known members of the force, were announced yesterday at police headquarters.

That the general radio audience is interested in more of the "human side of the news" rather than in brief statements of events of political and economic importance was indicated yesterday following the morning broadcast of the first bulletin issued to subscribing radio stations by the new Press Radio Bureau of the Publishers National Radio Committee.

HAVANA, March 1. -- The labor situation in the Provinces of Oriente, Camaguey and Santa Clara is becoming more serious daily as agitation among the workers there increases and the sabotage of property is most frequent. Sugar men believe that unless some immediate improvement can be brought about by the government Cuba's sugar crop will fall far short of the 2,315, 000 tons fixed by Presidential decree.
The J.J. Newberry Company and subsidiaries reported for 1933 the best sales and share earnings on record. Total sales for the year were $33.146,574, against $33,121,669 in 1932.

ATHENS, March 1. -- Eleutherios Venizelos, Greece's "grand old man," declared today at a conference of Greek party leaders he was ready to make the last sacrifice for his country and go into exile to prove his love for Greece.
The sale and immediate renting up of a building in the wholesale coffee district of lower Manhattan was announced yesterday.
Futures trading fell off perceptibly yesterday on local commodity exchanges. Prices moved in a narrow range and closed irregular. Cash prices also were irregular.

ALBANY, March 1. -- Governor Lehman issued a proclamation today fixing the week of April 1 as Conservation Week. Citing the increased public interest in preservation of natural resources and beauty, the Governor pointed to New York State as one of the pioneers in conservation work.

The volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was slightly heavier than in January. The largest day's business since last July occurred on Feb. 5, when sales amounted to 4,941,310 shares. Sales for last month, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, amounted to 56,834,010 shares, compared with 54,567,209 shares in January, and 19,319,900 shares in February of last year.

" Linda di Chamounix," fifty-ninth of the sixty-six operas that Gaetano Donizetti composed, was revived yesterday afternoon, for the benefit of the Free Milk Fund, by the Metropolitan Opera Association. It had been stated in advance that this the first of was performance "Linda" in New York since Patti sang the title ro1e in 1890.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- President Roosevelt asked full guarantee for home-mortgage bonds, issued his first veto (of a private bill) and asked Congress for $1,165,000 to house United States officials in Moscow.

On the same day HENRY WADSWORTH LONGFELLOW'S daughter -- "laughing Allegra" -- died in Cambridge and MATTHEW -ARNOLD'S daughter died here in New York. The famous names are most completely representative of two literary traditions which have encountered rough going in the years since the war -- the "genteel" and the academic.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP). -- A protest of the country's private ship builders against government competition was voiced today by H. Gerrish Smith of New York at a hearing on the Shannon Cost Accounting Bill. He spoke before the House Committee on Expenditures in Executive Departments.
PEIPING, March 1. -- The Hsinking enthronement failed to arouse any special reaction in North China.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 1. -- A new plan to regulate elections of sophomores to upper class eating clubs at Princeton University was suggested today by The Daily Princetonian, undergraduate newspaper.

LONDON, March 1. -- A proposed new British shipping policy of subsidies and other means to protect British shipping was unanimously endorsed today at the annual meeting of the Chamber of Shipping after a bitter attack on the United States shipping system.

LOS ANGELES, March 1. -- The final petition asking Federal Judge James to assume jurisdiction and supervision over reorganization and sale of the Richfield Oil Company of California was filed today with the court by protective committees representing creditors.

CLEVELAND, March 1 (AP). -- Appointment of a receiver for the Locomotive Engineers Mutual Life Insurance Association, which has 65,000 members and policies totaling $139,000,000, is asked in a suit filed in Federal court today.

Keeping a watchful and anxious eye upon Washington, Wall Street slackened its pace even more yesterday than on previous days. Trades on the Stock Exchange footed up to 1,242 000 shares compared with 1,322,090 on the day before. The market had a heavy tone most of the day, but the net losses, even in the more volatile stocks, were small.

The rescue of hundreds of thousands of game birds and wild waterfowl in the Eastern region so sorely hit by recent storms is being effected by an army of several thousand regular wardens and volunteers, according to reports received yesterday, the first clear day after the latest storm.

BUDAPEST, March 1. -- Prominent county families and the Budapest aristocracy were in a ferment today over the issuance of a government communique implying that members of high society were implicated in espionage but not giving names or other details nor mentioning the foreign power for which the spies were alleged to have been acting.

VIENNA, March 1. -- Recruiting for the Austrian Army and its allied Heimwehr Corps spurted today as a Socialist official newspaper urged party members to be ready "for a resumption of our fight" against the government.

LONDON, March 1. -- Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade, had no difficulty in convincing the House of Commons tonight that the new British trade agreement with Russia was likely to prove useful to both countries, and it was therefore approved without a division.

Dividends declared in February did not make so favorable a comparison with those of the year before as did the ones announced for January, principally because of smaller payments in several of the major groups of industries. They aggregated $214,412,234 for 579 corporations, compared with $212,883,853 for 801 concerns in January and $226,492,948 for 609 companies in February, 1933.

Messages from President Roosevelt, Governor Lehman and Mayor LaGuardia were read last night over the radio in an observance of the festival of Purim, the holiday celebrating the deliverance 2,300 years ago of the Jews by Queen Esther. The messages stressed the need for emphasizing spiritual forces.

CHICAGO, March 1. -- Dr. Catherine Wynekoop, 25-year-old daughter of Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop, went before a jury in Judge Harry B. Miller's court today and testified amid tears and sobs that her sister-in-law, Rheta Wynekoop, could never have died at the hands of Dr. Alice, but might have killed herself.

Another of those adventures in contrast that a New York art season can so abundantly yield may be enjoyed just now by pilgrims who will visit, in turn, the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, and the Lilienfeld-Van Diemen Galleries, 21 East Fifty-seventh Street.
LONDON, March 1. -- T.O.M. Sopwith's America's Cup challenger, Endeavour, will leave Southampton for the United States about the end of July. She will be ketchrigged for the Atlantic voyage.
HSINKING, March 1. -- Under the aegis of 50,000 soldiers, the "radiance of the sun, moon and stars" and the boyish Emperor Kang Teh, the new "Great Manchu Empire" began today an era of construction.

Further gold imports of $47,148,300 were reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank as having been added to the monetary gold stocks of the country. This brought the total of imports since the restoration of a gold standard here to $418,495,000, and the total net gain in monetary gold stocks, exclusive of newly mined gold, to $407,844,800.

Representatives of the Corporation Counsel, the Health Department and the Transit Commission conferred yesterday on bringing charges of violation of the Sanitary Code against the I.R.T. and B.M.T. for failing to heat subway trains properly during the recent cold wave.

The refusal of the United States to pay its obligations in gold was challenged yesterday by the Republic of Panama. A check for $250,000 for rental of the Canal Zone was returned to the United States Treasury by John Foster Dulles, on behalf of Nelson Cromwell, fiscal agent of panama, with the explanation that Panama insisted upon compliance with the Treaty of 1904, which specified that payment should be in gold.

The Interborough has treated the elevated system, leased to it by the Manhattan Railway Company, as a "stepchild," and its failure to keep decent equipment on the line is responsible for the falling off of traffic on the elevated lines, according to an answer filed in Federal court yesterday by the Manhattan Company.

A potential source of a further large increase in the supply of "deposit currency" exists in the great rise in government deposits in the banks in the last month as the result of government borrowing, says the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly review, published yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 1. -- The New York Giants, who seem bent on demonstrating that baseball has not yet run out of innovations, again sprang something new in Spring training today. For the first time in the memory of the oldest baseball observer an admission fee was charged just to see an informal workout.

In a decision in the equity receivership proceedings against Land Estates, Inc., and Liberdar Holding Corporation, both subsidiaries of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, Judge Robert Patterson in the United States District Court has held that properties foreclosed by the title companies and purchased by a subsidiary belong to the certificate holders, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Arthur Kallett, secretary of Consumers Research, Inc., told the Senate Commerce Committee today that some trade-mark drugs were palmed off on the public by high-pressure advertising that differed from Socrates's hemlock only in that the consumers did not know what they were taking.

A woman and her three children lost their lives early yesterday when they were trapped by smoke and flames in their flat on the top floor of a five-story tenement building at 169 Carroll Street, Brooklyn. A fourth child, who was rescued by firemen, was critically burned.

Dr. O.M.W. Sprague, who resigned as adviser to the Treasury in protest against the monetary policies of the Roosevelt administration, said last night: "I am not nearly as critical of the administration as I am of a large proportion of the business executives of this country."

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP). -- Lehr Fess, Julius Kahn and "young" Philp, son of John Philp, former Fourth Assistant Postmaster General, were added today to the list of relatives of families well known in Washington officialdom who had a part in the dickering of airline companies for contracts to carry the mails.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

YONKERS, N.Y., March 1. -- Tabulated payments of 1934 taxes for the last day before the 8 per cent penalty for lateness becomes effective totaled $600,000, it was announced this afternoon by Controller Hushion here. Taxes could be paid up to this midnight without penalty.

MIAMI, Fla., March 1. -- The fleet mare Monel, owned and bred by Sylvester W. Labrot and a full sister to Mr. Labrot's Tred Avon, was an easy two-length winner of the featured Sanford Purse at Hialeah Park today.

BELLEAIR HEIGHTS, Fla., March 1 (AP). -- A1 Watrous of Detroit, scoring 139, today led the field in the West Coast open golf championship at the halfway mark. He was pressed closely by Paul Runyan of White Plains, N.Y., who put together two 70s for 140.

Repeating her victory of the New Jersey championship final, Miss Betty Woolsey of New Haven won the invitation squash racquets tournament of the Junior League yesterday when she defeated Miss Eileen Beresford of Short Hills in the concluding round.

The resume of the NRA appearing in THE TIMES on Sunday under the name of its general counsel would appear humorous if it was not so evident a portrait of the debacle as the result of the author's not having a sufficiently detached position to enable him to obtain a normal perspective.

NEW SMYRNA, Fla., March 1. -- While racing against time around the international motor boat course on Indian River late this afternoon, Hershel Turk of Tulsa, Okla., struck some object as he was traveling close to sixty miles an hour. A hole ten inches long and six inches wide literally was chewed out of the planking in the bottom of the frail boat.

Production of artificial radioactivity from non-radioactive substances, hailed as one of the most important recent triumphs of science, is reported by Science Service in a copyrighted article from the California Institute of Technology at Pasadena, Calif.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 1. -- Miss Lucille Robinson of Des Moines, Iowa, holder of the women's Western title, furnished the highlight of the quarter-finals in the Florida East Coast golf championship by defeating Miss Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., today. The score was 2 up.

MIAMI, Fla., March 1. -- Those who can afford or otherwise contrive to find the means for escaping the rigors of a record-cracking Winter in the North trooped rather tardily into the Garden Bowl tonight for Florida's first heavyweight championship fight since 1894.

LENINGRAD, March 1. -- Comrade Ivan Vosko, the sanitary inspector of one of Leningrad's downtown districts, met with signal failure today in his one-man campaign to eliminate beards from proletarian working men.

Bank clearings in twenty-two leading cities of the country for the week of five business days ended on Wednesday were $4,262,118,000, according to reports to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. In the corresponding week last year, which contained six business days, they were $5,145,808,000, with the figures for Baltimore and Detroit estimated as the banks in those cities were closed.
The Rev. Dr. Frank N.D. Buchman and about 100 members of the Oxford Group International Team, which visited London last Fall, will arrive here on the Europa on March 15.

The listed bond market again manifested irregularity yesterday with a further diminution in the volume of trading. Domestic corporation bonds moved slightly lower, on the average, United States Government bonds slightly higher and leading foreign loans generally higher.

The following table gives the amount of the dealings in the stocks from which the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in the rails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weekly transactions:

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The National Labor Board has again referred the Weirton case to the Department of Justice with a recommendation "for immediate action," Senator Wagner, chairman of the board, said today.

In line with Mayor LaGuardia's proposal to open beer gardens, copied after those of Europe, throughout the city, Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, announced yesterday that Park Department architects were working on plans for the conversion of Claremont Inn, in Riverside Park near Grant's Tomb, into a moderate-price restaurant in the nature of a beer garden.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 1. -- Governor Blanton Winship issued a statement today voicing a protest on behalf of Puerto Rico against an advertising campaign in newspapers and other periodicals of continental United States by continental sugar refinery interests which classify sugar refined in Puerto Rico as a foreign product made with cheap tropical labor.

Dr. William H. Gregory, curator-in-chief of living and extinct fishes at the American Museum of Natural History, after carefully examining the radio-photograph of the sea monster found on the beach at Cherbourg, France, stated in substance yesterday that "there ain't no such animal."

MIAMI, Fla., March 1. -- Sheer power brought the mountainous Primo Carnera, Italian who holds the world's heavyweight championship, victory over Tommy Loughran of Philadelphia tonight in their fifteen-round battle for the title in the Madison Square Garden Stadium.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- A $50,000,000 plan for the renovation of American homes under Federal stimulus is being worked out for the administration by Frank C. Walker, director of the National Emergency Council, and Winfield W. Riefler, central coordinating statistician of the New Deal.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 1 (AP). -- Two upsets marked the quarter-final round of the women's singles play in the fifteenth annual Bermuda tennis championships today, leaving Miss Jane Sharp of Pasadena, Calif., and Miss Gladys Hutchings of Bermuda, second and fourth seeded players respectively, on the sidelines.

Mayor LaGuardia, with a frank outline of his plans for solving some of the city's problems, won to his support yesterday the members of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, an organization which, he admitted in his opening remarks, had usually opposed anything he favored.

Bonds called for payment in February before they matured made the smallest total for a month in more than seven years. With the exception of the railroad and miscellaneous groups, the decline from the amounts of both the previous month and February a year ago embraced all classes.

The judgment for $364,054 obtained against Barron Collier and others by the Union Car Advertising Company for damages for alleged unfair practices in the bid for the advertising and vending privileges on the Boston Elevated Railway Company was reversed by the Court of Appeals on Tuesday, it was announced here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The cancellation of air mail contracts will probably have a far-reaching effect upon the development and coordination of commercial and military air services.

The program given by the Boston Symphony, Serge Koussevitzky, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall, and very brilliantly presented, was rich in contrast and contained a novelty that had interest and showed talent. This was the Symphony 2, opus 18, by Nicolai Berezowsky, performed for the first time in New York.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The Independent Offices Appropriation Bill, in which the Senate on Tuesday smothered administration economies by adopting provisions for more liberal treatment of war veterans, was temporarily shelved in the House today.

PARIS, March 1 -- Completing his tour of the principal European capitals in search of armaments agreements, Anthony Eden, British Lord Privy Seal, returned to Paris today and had a two-hour conversation with Premier Doumergue and Foreign Minister Barthou.

CHICAGO, March 1. -- Buying of lightweight hogs for relief purposes developed today. This class was quoted as steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday. Others were weak to 25 cents lower, with packing sows showing the greater loss.

An investigation of the methods used in hiring emergency workers for snow removal jobs was ordered yesterday by Mayor LaGuardia after more complaints that men had been forced to pay for their jobs were received at City Hall.

DeWitt Clinton High School's basketball team clinched the Upper Manhattan-Bronx Division P.S.A.L. title by defeating Evander Childs High, 33 to 14, yesterday in the Clinton gymnasium for its fifth victory in as many league games.

CLEVELAND, March 1. -- Powerful unions of teachers campaigning to "create a new climate of economic social understanding" among both adults and school children were urged today upon thousands of educators from all parts of the country at two conventions, that of the National Education Association's Department of Superintendence and that of the Progressive Education Association.
While I am no longer in Wall Street, I resent the implied slur cast on all Wall Street men by the recent government investigations. Wall Street was my college.

DUBLIN, March 1. -- A dramatic offer of a political truce was made by President de Valera in the Dail Eireann tonight in the course of debate on his bill to ban Blueshirts. Speaking passionately before the crowded, tense Chamber, the President said:

The official portrait of President Roosevelt -- without the smile -- was formally approved yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt. Having, as usual, eluded her escort, Mrs. Roosevelt paid a hurried visit yesterday afternoon to the studio of Mrs. Ellen Emmet Rand who has been working on the portrait since August.
Tammany -- the cat who can look at a Mayor and frequently does -- disrupted a meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday when the oratory in the body broke into his peaceful slumbers.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- A list of members of the New York Stock Exchange who sold aviation stocks short just before the air-mail contracts were canceled was ordered today from Richard Whitney, president of the Exchange, by the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency at the suggestion of Senator Kean of New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The text of the bill to create a National Labor Board offered in the Senate today by Senator Wagner was as follows:

CHICAGO, March 1. -- Local statisticians issued today their reports on Winter wheat and surprised the trade by showing a rather general improvement in the outlook compared with Dec. 1. The condition was placed at 73.5 to 77.8, compared with 74.3 by the government last Fall, and with 58.5 a year ago, when the trade was already fairly certain that almost a failure would be the result in the Southwest.

New securities offered publicly here in February were more than double the number marketed in the previous month, and were mostly State and municipal bond issues, of which the total was the largest for a month since October. The two stock offerings were both for industrial companies.

Plans for the gradual demobilization of the army of 160,000 CWA employes here have been completed by the Civil Works Administration in cooperation with the Department of Welfare, it was learned yesterday. Although no official announcement was made, it was learned that the demobilization will begin within two or three weeks and will be completed by May 1.
CHERBOURG, France, March 1. -- Nothing even remotely resembling the sea monster that was washed ashore at Querqueville, two miles west of here, has ever been seen before in this part of the world.

ALBANY, March 1. -- The wide Spread between the price the farmer gets for his milk and what the consumer pays is due to high distribution costs and not to distributers' profits, the Milk Control Board said in a statement today.

Interest rates for call money on the two Stock Exchanges here in February were the same as in January and, except for a slight change in ninety-day rates, time money quotations also corresponded. The 1 per cent call-loan rate on the New York Stock Exchange and the 1 1/2 per cent on the New York Curb Exchange, in effect since Dec. 7, compared with the same rates in February, 1933.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- A method of Stock Exchange regulation, different from that provided in the Fletcher-Rayburn bill, was proposed before the House Interstate Commerce Committee today by Henry I. Harriman, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Creation of a permanent national labor board, empowered to settle labor disputes by arbitration, abolition of company unions and recognition of majority representatives of labor unions in collective bargaining were proposed in a bill introduced in the Senate today by Senator Wagner of New York.

Independent milk distributers of the State are faced with financial ruin unless the Milk Control Board rescinds its recent order withdrawing its schedule of prices on sales of milk and cream to stores and restaurants.

An observer in the cozy pilot station on the tip of City Island spied an American flag flying upside down yesterday morning on the mast of Stepping Stone Lighthouse, a bleak little point of rock in the ice-dotted waters of Long Island Sound, a mile south of the island.

Among the prominent passengers booked to sail for Europe tonight on the White Star liner Olympic are Lord Essendon, chairman of Furness, Withy Co.; Lord Marley, Deputy Speaker of the House of Lords; Samuel (Roxy) Rothafel, former director of Radio City Music Hall, and F.P. Culbert, European manager of the Radio Corporation of America.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Amendment of the Federal criminal code to make "racketeering" in interstate commerce a crime punishable by a maximum of ninety-nine years' imprisonment and a fine commensurate with the profits derived from "racketeering" transactions was advocated today by Joseph B. Keenan, Assistant Attorney General, before a Senate Judiciary subcommittee.

After minority members of the Board of Aldermen had attacked the previous administration for making the budget so high that a basic tax rate of $2.56 per $100 of assessed valuation was necessary, the board formally adopted the 1934 rate at that figure yesterday.

Joseph Dragoni, owner of a restaurant at 46 East Fifty-second Street, testifying yesterday at the trial of Lieutenant Philip Murphy and Detectives Irving Frey and Emanuel Blog in General Sessions, told how, at the suggestion of Murphy, he, Dragoni, agreed on Dec. 21 last to pay $200 for his liquor license so that he might have it for the Christmas holidays.

The opening of "Brain Sweat," a Negro play by John Charles Brownell, which had been scheduled for the week of March 12, has been postponed because of the illness of James Montgomery, director and co-producer of the production.

A nation-wide group of forty-five banks and banking houses headed by the City Company of New York, Inc., the Bankers Trust Company, First National Bank of New York and the Chase National Bank, won yesterday the award of a new issue of $30,000,000 Commonwealth of Pennsylvania war veterans' compensation bonds.

PITTSBURGH, March 1. -- The 5,000 workers of the Aluminum Company of America, owned by the Mellon interests, went on a "holiday strike" today, but their representatives will be heard by the Regional Labor Board tomorrow. Every effort will be made to have the workers return to their jobs pending the result of the meeting.
LONDON, March 1. -- Prince Felix Youssoupoff refused to be shaken today in his gruesome story of how he killed the monk Rasputin in a Petrograd cellar in 1916.
Leases of space in buildings in scattered sections of the city were reported yesterday.

LONDON, March 1. -- Anthony Eden, Lord Privy Seal, declared his visits to the three capitals had been "useful." He arrived from Paris tonight. The personal contacts he established had been particularly valuable, he said, and they might facilitate future discussions.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- When Speaker Rainey today sent the Independent Offices Bill back to committee, after the measure returned from the Senate with its extra load of 350 millions, it was evident that the President is determined to fight to retain the principles of his economy program.

ABOARD S.S. BEAR OF OAKLAND, Northbound From Little America, Feb. 28 (Delayed). -- With the temperature 30 below zero and the ship's rigging a mass of ice, the Bear of Oakland got under way from the Bay of Whales at 8:30 Monday morning.

Value of Dollar on Exchange Market The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The Medical Society of the County of Queens announced yesterday the adoption of a resolution exonerating three of its members of any unethical or unprofessional conduct in the alleged monopoly in the handling of CWA workmen's compensation cases.

Another delay in reporting the Bankhead bill out of the committee caused a sharp contraction in trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange. Liquidation eased the list a few points when buying orders appeared to increase on recessions, and a recovery left quotations 1 to 7 points higher than on Wednesday.

Peter J. McGuinness, Democratic leader of Greenpoint, testified before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook yesterday that he was guided by "the great wisdom of George McAneny and the Hon. John Patrick O'Brien" when he voted to award bus franchises to five Manhattan companies in the closing days of the last Board of Estimate.

YALE won the indoor intercollegiates last Winter and N.Y.U. took the title in 1932. The boys in blue expect to be "up there" again, especially those Yale vaulters who, some night, will get off to an extra fancy start and go shooting right through the roof of the Garden. Coach Emil Von Elling of N.Y.U. will have the track and field sprinkled with Violet athletes and the team should score well.

Lew Stanly, an automobile salesman, and his wife, Madeline, who said they were part gypsy, testified yesterday in General Sessions against four men accused of having kidnapped Stanly in his own automobile at Broadway and Forty-fifth Street on Sept. 23.

Northern New Jersey has had many warnings that new sources of water supply must be provided if that part of the State is not to be confronted in the next few years with an insufficiency for both households and manufacturing plants. Construction of reservoirs and diversion aqueducts beyond the New York line may become a necessity ultimately, in the judgment of the Hackensack Water Company.

Yale, Harvard, Princeton, Pennsylvania Military College and West Point once more will compete in the intercollegiate championship, according to the entries filed with the Indoor Polo Association of America.

Several hundred passengers in a B.M.T. West End express train were led to safety last night when a shoe beam on the first car grounded as it was nearing the Ninth Street station in the Fourth Avenue subway in Brooklyn. A fire started that filled the cars and subway with clouds of smoke.

This is the anniversary of one of the outstanding incidents of the banking crisis of 1933. One year ago today the Federal Reserve Banks failed to issue at the customary hour their regular weekly statement showing gold holdings and money in circulation. Rumors of an alarming character were current.

Conditions favorable to the advance existed yesterday in all speculative markets. Traders did not overlook this fact and prices rose wherever there was an opportunity. Uniform strength was shown in stocks, bonds and commodities. The dollar was a trifle easier in the foreign exchange market.

The high excellence of the cast and the glowing music of "Siegfried" made an eminently successful occasion when Wagner's opera was performed yesterday in the Metropolitan Opera House as one of the leading features of the special cycle of his music-dramas, presented in unexpurgated form.

The Manhattan College basketball team ended its season with a victory over Columbus Council, K. of C., last night at the latter's gymnasium, 27 to 16. The Jaspers, trailing at the half, 12 to 11, clinched their triumph by holding the Knights scoreless for the first fifteen minutes of the second period and running up twelve points in a row.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 2 (AP). -- Four seeded players went through to the semi-finals today in the first day's play on the Trinity College courts in the third annual inter-collegiate squash racquets championship.

PARIS, March 2. -- Today's sensation in the Stavisky case was the arrest of the young and beautiful Mme. Alexandre Stavisky for keeping in her possession the stubs of checks covering money paid out by her dead husband. He committed suicide when the Bayonne pawnshop collapsed with heavy losses to the public.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The United States desires to supplement any general disarmament convention with a universal pact of non-aggression, it was revealed in the State Department's reply, made public today, to the British disarmament memorandum of Jan. 29.

Margaret Mullany, who went to work as a maid forty-seven years ago in the Grand Hotel, Thirty-first Street and Broadway, was found dead in her room in the maids' quarters at the hotel yesterday morning. "Maggie," as she was called, was reputed to be the oldest hotel woman employe in the country in length of service.

CHICAGO, March 2. -- A ban upon newsreel scenes depicting mob violence was revealed today when one of the film companies stated it was preparing to contest the censorship in the courts. A canvass of the other companies showed they believed that the city had sufficient authority for action under the motion picture censorship ordinance.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- In a review of the past eight months of code control under NRA, the American Federation of Labor, in its monthly survey of business today registers a distinctly optimistic note, pointing out that the wage-earners' total income in January, 1934, was $566,000,000 above that of January, 1933.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- A greatly revised edition of the Bankhead Bill for control of cotton production, increasing the crop total for 1934-35 to 10,000,000 bales, placing a tax of 50 per cent of the central market price on cotton produced, above farm allotments and placing broad powers of crop control in the hands of the Secretary of Agriculture, was reported out by the House Committee on Agriculture today.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 2. -- Wilmer Allison, Davis Cup veteran from Austin, Texas, and Lester Stoefen, big Californian, gained the final round of singles in the fifteenth annual Bermuda tennis championships today.

CHICAGO, March 2. -- Overcome by the strain of four hours on the witness stand in which she denied the State's charge that she killed her daughter-in-law, Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop collapsed late this afternoon in her cell in the Cook County jail.
WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's tariff message to Congress today:
TOKYO, March 2. -- A bill investing the government with extensive powers over foreign trade as an international weapon has been drafted for submission to Parliament.

The 1933 medal of honor of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects was awarded last night to Robert D. Kohn, director of housing under the Public Works Administration. This annual award for "distinguished work and high professional standing" was presented by Ralph Walker, president of the chapter, at a dinner meeting at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 2. -- The Belmont Manor, formerly the Summer home of the late Mrs. Oliver H.P. Belmont here, was burned to the ground this afternoon. All that remained of the thirty-three-room mansion was six brick chimneys standing erect among the smoldering ruins.

Actual negotiations with the B.M. T. and Interborough for the purchase of their rapid transit properties for inclusion in a unified system have not yet been started, City Chamberlain Adolf A. Berle Jr., disclosed yesterday, Professor Berle, who is one of Mayor LaGuardia's principal advisors in unification matters, declared that negotiations would not begin until "fact finding activities," now in progress, are completed.
BERLIN, March 2 (By wireless). -- For the world outside Germany there is one question of paramount importance: Does a Nazi Germany mean peace or war?

Joseph Arbona, 36 years old, a road foreman of Pembrook Street, Bridgeport, Conn., was shot and instantly killed about 1:45 o'clock this morning as he was sitting in his parked automobile in a lonely neighborhood on Riverside Drive land 183d Street.
WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress on independence of the Philippine Islands:

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 2. -- The elimination of the defending titleholder, Miss Kathleen Garnham of England, featured the semi-finals of the Florida East Coast golf championship for the Mrs. William R. Kenan Jr. Cup on the St. Augustine links today.

President Roosevelt has ordered a new trial for Corporal Robert Osman of Brooklyn, who was adjudged guilty recently by court-martial in the Canal Zone of divulging military secrets to Communists, according to a letter received yesterday by Louis Waldman of 302 Broadway, who was Osman's attorney.

On behalf of the government United States Attorney Howard W. Ameli filed suit in the United States court in Brooklyn yesterday for $1,787,799.36 against the Bank of Rockville Centre Trust Company as administrator of the estate of John M. Phillips, the "sewer pipe king" of Queens County.

Edward R. Larigan of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, who ranked fourth nationally a year ago, was eliminated from the national amateur squash tennis championship last night on the courts of the Princeton Club.

A sharp increase in the number of buyers in the market here is expected next week. Many store representatives who postponed their trips because of the adverse weather conditions at the start of the current week have indicated their intention of arriving next week.

" Seven Gothic Tales," by a European writer who uses the pen name of Isak Dinesen, is to be the Book-of-the-Month Club choice for April. Smith Haas will publish it, with an enthusiastic introduction by Dorothy Canfield. The Literary Guild book for April will be "The New Dealers," an anonymous volume about the Roosevelt administration -- a book that already has drawn comment from General Johnson.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 2. -- Peter Fick of the New York A.C. provided the feature performance of Yale's annual swimming carnival tonight by shattering the world's record for the 100-meter free-style event.

Mayor LAGUARDIA'S speech before the Chamber of Commerce makes good reading, especially the part in which he promised to deal promptly with sewage disposal and harbor pollution. The Chamber had before it a report by Dr. SOPER lamenting the fact that this city had done so little about that problem and had taken such an unconscionable amount of time doing it.

LONDON, March 2. -- Those who are clamoring for bigger British air armaments received little or no satisfaction in the estimates announced today by the Marquess of Londonderry, Secretary of State for Air.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP). -- An uprising of House Democrats that drove their leaders from the field in disorder prevented passage tonight of a bill to extend for another year the power of Federal Reserve Banks to issue currency backed by government bonds.

In your editorial "Science and Jobs" I find that you have come to grips with our economic maladjustments instead of sparring with partial truths, as did a few of our scientists who, without first explaining the cause of the slump in industries using technical inventions, helplessly declared that science creates jobs.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, March 3. -- The Legislative Council at Nanking, after a three-hour fiery discussion, decided today to submit a resolution to the Central Political Council to the effect that the Chinese Government had decided to issue a mandate ordering the Military Affairs Commission immediately to dispatch troops for a punitive campaign against the "rebel State of Manchukuo."
The complaint from the Loughran camp in the wake of the Miami merriment is that Carnera Carnivorous (horribilis) took steps to protect his title and was careless as to where he put his feet.
BERLIN, March 2 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Feb. 28 shows the following changes, in reichsmark:
George Arliss's new film, "The House of Rothschild," will be presented for a special two-a-day showing at the Astor when "Catherine the Great" concludes its engagement there.

CHICAGO, March 2. -- Rising prices and improved buying power among consumers combined to lift the business of Sears, Roebuck Co. out of red-ink figures in 1933. Rapid recovery in sales and profits in the last half of the year brought the net income to $11,249,295, General R.E. Wood, president, disclosed today in making public results of the company's operations.
PARIS, March 2. -he widow. OI Alexandre Stavisky was arrested by Secret Service police today in connection with the Stavisky pawnshop scandal

The city basked in comparative warmth yesterday after a month of extreme cold, the temperature rising to 45 degrees above zero at 3 o'clock in the afternoon. It will be even warmer today, the Weather Bureau said, and the warm spell will continue at least for several days.

Employes of the Triborough Bridge Authority who have not been paid since , Feb. 1, because a Federal check for $1,500,000 failed to arrive from Washington, were informed yesterday that they would get their money Monday or Tuesday. The grant of $1,500,000 was approved yesterday afternoon by Secretary Ickes.
The CWA concert division today announces free concerts at 11 A.M. and 3 P.M. in the Brooklyn Museum. The New York Civic Orchestra will play under the direction of Antonia Brico.

VIENNA, March 2. -- The government tonight issued an order preparing for the dissolution of all trade unions before forming a new central trade union including all workers. The Socialist trade unions, with 500,000 members, were dissolved two weeks ago, so this measure was directed against the Christian Social party's trade unions.

Loans on securities made to members of the New York Stock Exchange and carried in New York increased $34,935,720 in February to $938,010,227, according to the monthly compilation of the Exchange. At the end of January, loans were $903,074,507.

The quarter-century mark in basketball victories was reached by Long Island University last night, with Brooklyn College the latest victim, 36-19, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gym. It was L.I.U.'s twenty-sixth game of the season.

Elimination from city employ of all persons who are not bona fide residents of New York City was proposed yesterday in a local bill introduced in the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly by Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx.

CHICAGO, March 2. -- Self-possessed except for one emotional collapse, Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop today denied on the witness stand any knowledge of the gruesome "operating-room murder." How her daughter-in-law met her death in Dr. Wynekoop's surgery was as much of a mystery to her as to any one, she insisted.

RICHMOND, Va., March 2 (AP). -- Six armed bandits today held up a guard of the State-Planters Bank and Trust Company, and robbed him of $60,000 in currency. Officials said that the robbery occurred presumably while the guard, William H. Coghill, was on his way from the Federal Reserve Bank.

The task of restoring New York University's football fortunes to their once high estate has been entrusted to Dr. Marvin A. (Mal) Stevens. With the flat statement that it was not veering away from its policy of de-emphasis, the N.Y.U. board of athletic control announced yesterday through its chairman, Philip O. Badger, that it had reached out to Yale for its new gridiron mentor.

Another interesting one-man show is current at the Rehn Gallery, succeeding Mr. Burchfield's water-colors. The present exhibitor, Peppino Mangravite, swells the list of the season's returned Guggenheim fellowship artists.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 2. -- Despite Winter weather and a snow-white landscape, the Spring Dance at Smith College will be held tomorrow. About 1,000 college and business men are expected to attend the hops in twenty-seven college houses.

NEWARK, N.J., March 2. -- After three hours' deliberation, a jury in Essex County Court acquitted tonight August Lacombe, Director of Public Safety, and Andrew Coleman, Police Chief, both of Irvington, of misfeasance in office. The indictments resulted from an investigation into gambling conditions in Irvington.

Lord Marley, one of the Deputy Speakers of the House of Lords and chairman of the International Committee for the Relief of Nazi victims, for which he has been lecturing to collect funds, sailed for England last night on the White Star liner Olympic.

The La Salle M.A. and Riverdale Country Day School sextets prevailed in Intercounty Scholastic Hockey League games at the New York Coliseum yesterday to retain first and second positions, respectively.

Robert L. Clarkson, the last of the four executives who operated the Chase National Bank before its merger with the Equitable Trust Company in the middle of 1930, has retired from the Chase organization, it was announced last night.

The clans and Scottish societies gathered 300 strong at a testimonial dinner last night for Colonel Walter Scott, past royal chief of the Federation of Scottish Societies. Among them were the MacDonalds, the MacKenzies, the MacDuffs, the Stewarts, the Campbells, the Skye Association, the New York Caledonia Club, the Daughters of Scotia, the Flora MacDonald Society, the Lady MacKenzie, the Hamilton Grahame, the Lady Chisholm, the Lady Bruce and the Celtic Society.

ALBANY, March 2. -- Justices of the municipal court were scored today for not working hard enough, in a report of the Commission on Administration of Justice made public by Senator John L. Buckley, the chairman.

BUENOS AIRES, March 2. -- General Geronimo Zubizaretta will formally present to the League of Nations Chaco commission tomorrow Paraguay's rejection of the commission's proposed peace treaty. At the same time Casto Rojas is expected to present Bolivia's acceptance.

Kensuke Horinouchi announced yesterday his retirement as Japan's Consul General here to take up the post of director of the Division of Research and Planning, and of the Bureau of American Affairs of the Foreign Office.

Reorganization of the American Export Steamship Line, operators of ships between the North Atlantic, Mediterranean and Black Sea ports, was announced yesterday. Henry Herbermann, president, was succeeded by W.H. Coverdale and J.E. Slater was elected a director to succeed H.E. Frick, who remains as vice president.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- American holders of Panama obligations will benefit by whatever "profit" the Government of Panama makes out of its claim for gold payment of the $250,000 due annually under the treaty of 1904, the legation announced today.

For the first time the National Academy of Design permitted spectators yesterday to watch the operation of its jury of twenty-five artists selecting pictures for the academy's exhibition to be opened to the public on March 14.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The House approved by a viva voce vote today the McSwain resolution providing for a broad investigation of all phases of army procurement and the leasing of government buildings. It will apply particularly to airplane purchases during the last eight years.
Sales and leases reported yesterday indicated a demand for housing properties in scattered sections of the city. Deals were closed in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, March 2. -- The market for hogs was unsettled again today, with weights desired for relief purposes advancing 10 to 25 cents, while heavier kinds were slow and 10 to 25 cents lower. The top was advanced 20 cents to $4.90 a hundredweight, or within 5 cents of the recent peak, while the day's average of $4.50 was 5 cents higher than yesterday's and 25 cents below Monday's.

Reaffirming their belief that national prohibition is "the best method" for the control of the "vicious liquor traffic," leaders of the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union announced last night a new "militant" drive to convert the nation to the benefits of abstinence from alcohol.

Four labor union officials convicted last week of racketeering in the destruction of upward of $50,000 in glass advertising signs to compel the manufacturers to employ none but union workers were sentenced yesterday to indeterminate terms of from six months to three years in the penitentiary.

Stocks opened fractionally higher in quiet trading yesterday, but it was not until the last fifteen or twenty minutes of business on the Stock Exchange that the tempo increased sharply and the price level began to advance with any rapidity. The upturn in the late dealings was quite pronounced, particularly in industrial issues.

An injunction suit to restrain Paul Moss, License Commissioner, from barring the sale of allegedly indecent magazines on news stands was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by three publishers of ten periodicals.
Engineering awards last month (excluding CWA work) were 31 per cent above those in February, 1933, The Engineering News-Record reported yesterday.

The 1933 Lamme Medal of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers has been awarded to Dr. Lewis B. Stillwell of New York, consulting electrical engineer, for his distinguished career in connection with the design, installation and operation of electrical machinery and equipment."

An order to show cause why they should not be held in criminal contempt of court was issued yesterday by General Sessions Judge Freschi for Kermit F. Kip, a lawyer, with an office at 2 Lafayette Street, and James J. Park, keeper in the Great Meadow State prison at Comstock, N.Y.

The proposal to use the fund raised for a war memorial in providing additional playgrounds for children offers a happy issue of a plan conceived in patriotic purpose. There is something to be said for a memorial that serves only to recall the service of those to whom it is dedicated.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

With the bill providing for a tax of 50 per cent of the market value on all cotton ginned in excess of 10,000,000 bales finally reported to the House yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced nearly $1.50 a bale.

LONDON, March 2. -- The stock market was cheerful today, with British railways and industrials in heavy demand. British Government funds continued to gain on investment buying. Motors again were active, Courtalds advanced sharply on a flood of orders and many other leading issues made substantial gains.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 2. -- With Manager Bill Terry back in high command once more, the training manoeuvres of the world's champion Giants moved into double-quick time today, even though the unsettled weather of the past few days persisted in remaining a trifle balky.

The adoption of uniform educational standards for aliens desiring to become American citizens was urged last night by Colonel Daniel W. MacCormack, Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, in an address at the annual dinner of the National Council of Naturalization and Citizenship, and the New York Committee on Naturalization, at the Hotel Shelton.
Housing properties made up the bulk of the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.

The "Pilgrims' Pavement" in the nave of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, the laying of which has just been finished, will be dedicated by Bishop William T. Manning Sunday afternoon, March 11, at 4 o'clock. He will be assisted by the Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, the dean, and the other clergy of the cathedral staff.

Ponchielli's "La Gioconda," which was presented for the first time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, the thirty-third opera of the current repertoire, brought the Ponselle sisters, Rosa and Carmela, into one production.

The Army Air Mail Service in the Eastern Zone was informed yesterday that it was a violation of postoffice regulations to make public the poundage figures carried. This secrecy regulation was explained to the officers at Newark by Joseph Menthe, assistant superintendent of the air mail, with headquarters in New York, who went to Newark yesterday to instruct the army on its publicity policy.
The largest crowd of the week turned out to see the riders go through their paces as the six-day bicycle race swung into its last twenty-four hours at Madison Square Garden last night.

Moderate recoveries were made yesterday by domestic corporation bonds on the Stock Exchange. Leading foreign loans continued upward trend. United States Government long-term bonds were generally weaker on indications that the Treasury's financing on March 15 may run as high as $1,500,000,000 and presumably will include some intermediate-term obligations.

CHICAGO, March 2. -- Prices of grains on the Board of Trade were on the upgrade from the start today and there was marked enlargement in the speculative interest. While the buying was mostly in small lots, it was effective, as an oversold condition apparently had existed in all pits.
WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Following is the text of the administration tariff bill introduced in the House after the President's tariff message was received:

DUBLIN, March 2. -- President Eamon de Valera proposed in the Dail Eireann today that all arms in the Irish Free State be placed under neutral control until after a general election, when the victors at the polls might have the arms to execute their policy.

With an aggregate of $53,820,000, this week's new bond and note financing bulked the largest of any week since that ended on June 30. 1933, when the figure was $94,594,000 by virtue of the fact that an issue of $60,000,000 of Canadian Government obligations was included.

I was very much interested in reading about the plan proposed by Mr., Alger to have certain bankers advance $10,000,000 and the Federal Government advance $90,000,000 to make loans to destitute certificate holders, provided that these bankers be permitted to form a non-profit-sharing corporation to service the 22,000 mortgages, aggregating about a billion dollars, held by certificate holders.

An extensive survey of the cancer situation in Brooklyn during 1933 has "revealed tragic problems presented by the late and hopeless cases of cancer and the lack of social service work among cancer patients and of cancer centres in Brooklyn."

OMAHA, Neb., March 2. -- The army is handling the mail very sensibly now. I arrived Chicago at 5 A.M. Weather in and around Chicago was bad. They held us there until noon. No mail in or out. You see both army and commercial are very careful.

Non-operating income of the Southern Pacific Company decreased from $20,635,053 in 1932 to $18,398,913 in 1933, or by 10.8 per cent, chiefly because of a reduction in dividends by the Pacific Fruit Express Company, according to the report for 1933 issued by Hale Holden, chairman of the parent company.

Several communities that have not borrowed in many months have scheduled new issues of bonds for award next week. The total is $12,396,603, of which $3,500,000 tax-revenue, relief and land-purchase obligations by Nassau County, N.Y., is the largest issue.

Joseph W. Harriman, former head, of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, must go to trial with Albert M. Austin, former vice president, who was indicted with him for misapplying funds of the bank and causing false entries to be made on its books.

One of the most unusual horse events in New York's history is planned for Squadron A Armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Madison Avenue, tonight, when the first pony express race of the East will be held after the polo match between Pennsylvania Military College and the First Division.

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 2. -- Vadim Makaroff's Vamarie II, which was first to complete the 200-mile course, today was declared the winner of the Miami, Fla., to Nassau yacht race. The Vamarie II finished the long thrash on Wednesday night.

BALBOA, C.Z., March 2. -- President Arias asserted today that no deadlock existed in negotiations with the United States over settlement of the canal annuity. In a statement at his weekly press conference he expressed the belief that the question can be solved as differences between friends should be solved.

The directors of the General Electric Company declared yesterday a dividend of 15 cents a share on the common stock, against 10 cents a share paid in each quarter since the first quarter of 1932, when 25 cents was paid. The regular quarterly dividend of 15 cents a share on the special stock also was declared.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Congress was asked by President Roosevelt today for a grant of authority which would enable him to establish a new tariff policy designed to stimulate America's foreign trade by reciprocal agreements with other nations.
Three five-game matches featured the opening round of the metropolitan Class C squash racquets championship at the Downtown Athletic Club yesterday.

The fate of capitalism was debated last night at Mecca Temple, in West Fifty-fifth Street, near Sixth Avenue, between Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, and Senator Huey P. Long of Louisiana, author of a seven-point program for the redistribution of wealth which consisted principally of a plan to "soak the rich."

GREENWOOD, Miss., March 2 (AP). -- A Circuit Court jury received at 8:30 o'clock tonight the case of Dr. Sarah Ruth Dean, accused of murdering Dr. John Preston Kennedy, her surgeon associate, last Summer by giving him a "farewell" drink of poisoned whisky.

The fishing season will open next month in most of the Eastern States. It seems a bit early to talk about fishing, with snow covering the ground and most of the streams and lakes ice-bound, yet there is one angle which is worthy of consideration at this time because it is a legislative one.

BOSTON, March 2 (AP). -- Miss Rose Knellar, 23-year-old fiancee of Abraham Faber, and Mrs. Norma Brighton Millen, 19-year-old bride of Murton Millen and daughter of a former clergyman, today joined the group under arrest as a consequence of the ruthless Needham Trust Company hole-up killings and other crimes.

Holding that delinquent taxpayers should be induced to pay their arrears instead of being penalized for them, Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx introduced a local law in the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly yesterday which would waive all interest penalties on back taxes and water rates paid within three months after the law became effective.

March relief funds amounting to $6,306,650 were appropriated yesterday by the Board of Estimate under an arrangement whereby the city will be reimbursed for about two-thirds of the outlay by the State. The city's share will be $2,294,317 of the total.

The suggestion that violators of the anti-litter ordinances be sentenced to three hours cleaning parks instead of being fined was made by Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch last night in a radio address over Station WOR. He spoke under the auspices of the Clean City Committee.

After the lull brought about by adverse weather conditions, current reports reveal the resumption of the general upswing in both trade and industry this week, according to the review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

PARIS, March 2 (AP). -- The hastening of a Paris-New York air-mail route was seen today in the signing between French and German air lines of a pool for a five-day air service to South America. The accord is subject to government approval.

NEW ORLEANS, March 2. -- Flying Cadet continued his enviable Fair Grounds record today when he came from behind to win by a nose from Mrs. Floyd West's Don Vern in the featured six-furlong claiming handicap which was fifth on the card.

With both undefeated this season, City College and New York University will bring their 1934 basketball schedules to a close tonight when they clash in their annual game at the 102d Engineers Armory at 168th Street and Broadway.
