In a preliminary game, starting at 8 P.M., the C.C.N.Y. junior varsity will oppose the N.Y.U. freshmen.

Tammany's dominance of the Democratic organizations of New York City, already shattered by defeat in the last city election and the recent separation of the Brooklyn and Queens organizations from their former alliance with John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, is threatened permanently by the prospective reapportionment of the Senate districts of the State.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Opposition to various provisions of the Fletcher-Rayburn Stock Exchange Regulation Bill was voiced before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today by representatives of the New York and Los Angeles Stock Exchanges, the Curb Exchange of San Francisco and representatives of investment houses in Philadelphia and Pacific Coast cities.

ALBANY, March 2. -- Lieutenant John J. O'Connell, member of a politically powerful family, leveled an accusing finger at Manney Strewl today and told a jury "that man right there" was one of his kidnappers.

A drop in the rate for five months' money and a cut in tile discount on commercial paper featured. The bid on five months' funds declined 1/4 to 3/4 and some small-size trades were done at 1 per cent, a new low for the year. The revision downward followed a recent shading of the near-date quotations without employment of funds offered, necessitating a drop in bank rate to meet the bid.
WASHINGTON, March 2. -- President Roosevelt today approved in tentative form plans for drastic legislation to curb politicians in the use of their influence for monetary gain.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP). -- Everett Sanders, Republican National Committee chairman, said tonight that the reasons given by the Democratic National Committee for its withdrawal of a review of President Roosevelt's first year in office "must rank as the outstanding piece of fiction so far this year."

MIAMI, Fla., March 2. -- The consistent gelding Miney Myerson won for the fourth consecutive time when he captured the featured Tropical Claiming Handicap at Hialeah Park today. The victor equaled the six-furlong track record of 1:101-5 over a track that was fast after the recent rains, but there was general surprise when the time was made known.

The State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board announced yesterday the revocation of three wholesale wine and liquor licenses and twenty-five retail store and restaurant licenses to sell beer. It was the first big batch of license revocations to be announced by the board since it began the issuance of licenses and permits.
So many American manufacturers, business men, engineers and bankers crowded a luncheon in honor of the Soviet Ambassador yesterday at the Bankers Club that half of them were put in an overflow room.

MILWAUKEE, March 2. -- In the heart of an alien taking the oath of American citizenship there is no room for any loyalty but to the Constitution of the United States, Federal Judge F.A. Geiger ruled today in revoking the citizenship of Emil Gardos of Cleveland, Communist organizer, chemical engineer and editor.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Because Franklin D. Roosevelt can keep smiling he has come through his first year healthier than when he became President, the White House physician says. Dr. R.T. McIntire, pronouncing Mr. Roosevelt in "fine shape," said today:

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- While Congressional opponents of surrendering more tariff powers to the Executive are preparing to make a hard battle against the President's new bill, some members of his own administration see in the proposal a mere transfer of a political tariff log-rolling from the Capitol to the White House.
LONDON, March 2. -- Commander Oliver Locker-Lampson, Member of Parliament, startled a crowd in London's High Court today by saying he had been asked to kill the monk Rasputin in Russia in 1916.
The North German Lloyd liner Bremen arrived in port yesterday after a collision with a whale in which the stub-nosed vessel won the right of way with a faint shudder or two.

City College's swimming team closed its dual meet season last night, downing Manhattan, 42-29, in the Lavender tank. This was C.C.N.Y.'s second victory in eight meets, the other having been scored over Fordham at the start of the season.

NEW KENSINGTON, Pa., March 2 (AP). -- Howling down suggestions of their collective bargaining agents that they accept an 11 per cent wage increase, a mass meeting of Aluminum Company of America employes tonight directed picket lines be re-established about the huge plant.

HITLER'S attitude toward the Nazi cause must now and then impress some of his admirers as rather lukewarm. One still meets visitors returning from Germany who assure you that 98 1/2 per cent of the nation are ardently with the Nazi regime.

MILWAUKEE, March 2. -- An unexpected major development in Wisconsin politics came today when Francis E. McGovern, former Governor, a life-long Republican, announced himself as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator in the Wisconsin primary next September.

The first of the monthly index numbers of commodity prices, compiled by Dun's Review, figures an advance in the general average of one-third of 1 per cent for February bringing the index number as of March 1 to the highest since Nov. 1, 1930.

An investigation of charges that the city for years has been getting inferior grades of coal at exorbitant prices and that short weight coal has been delivered is being carried on by Irving Ben Cooper, special counsel to the Commissioner of Accounts.

PARIS, March 2. -- Andre Citroen, the French Henry Ford, has been forced by financial difficulties to submit to a reorganization which will take dictatorial control of his huge automobile factory from his hands.

VIENNA, March 2. -- Silent crowds stood today outside the central Vienna prison in the Alserstrasse, ominously known to the populace as the "gray house," to watch the removal of the city's ousted leaders, the well-known Socialist chiefs of the municipality, who were being transferred to the police prison in the Rossauer Lande.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers:

President ROOSEVELT'S tariff message yesterday was much as forecast, except that it was stronger and more emphatic in tone than had been expected. What he asks of Congress is authority to make "executive commercial agreements.'' This obviously does not mean reciprocity treaties of the kind that have to be submitted to the Senate for ratification.

Stockholders of the Midvale Company, most of whose shares are owned by the Baldwin Locomotive Works, will vote at their annual meeting on April 3 on a proposal to reduce stated capital from $14.574,621 to $10,574.621 and to distribute the $4,000,000 surplus thus created to the shareholders at the rate of $20 a share.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Improved conditions in Argentina were reported by the Department of Commerce today in its weekly survey of foreign business conditions based on advices from commercial attaches abroad.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Reports that President Roosevelt, through Secretary Dern, had ordered an investigation of charges of sabotage against army planes flying the mail were denied tonight by the War Secretary and by Stephen Early, secretary to the President.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 2. -- Eleven of the Westchester municipalities affected adversely by the recent decision of the State Tax Commission, which granted Scarsdale, Greenburg, Yonkers and Pelham refunds totaling about $400,000 in their appeals from the Westchester equalization tables for 1932 and 1933, appealed to the appellate division today from the commission's decision.

Five City College students, charged with the falsification of scholastic records in applying for Federal relief jobs, were suspended for the remainder of the term by a joint faculty-student discipline committee, it was disclosed yesterday. The committee also decided to censure publicly another student on the same charge.

German "Lohengrin," well sung in its original language by the San Carlo Opera Company at the Casino last evening, marked an advance in this company's versatility, hitherto shown in an English "Hansel and Gretel" and a French "Carmen." To these today the singers also add "Faust."

MIAMI, Fla., March 2. -- In the wake of the biggest financial flop since heavyweight championship boxing was a fugitive sport, ponderous Primo Carnera decided definitely today to make a fistic tour of South American capitals.

The report of Stone Webster, Inc., for 1933 shows a net loss of $85,907, after all charges and taxes, comparing with a net income of $1,015,367 for 1932. Dividends received from subsidiaries were $297,713, comparing with $1,394,763 in 1932, and other income was $502,544, against $663,295.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The National Labor Board ruled today that the terms of an agreement made by spokesmen for a majority of workers of a company "must apply alike to all employes of the company.''

BELLEAIR HEIGHTS, Fla., March 2. -- Playing two brilliant rounds of 68 today, Paul Runyan, White Plains (N.Y.) professional spread-eagled the field, winning the West Coast Open championship by eight strokes.

Responding to criticism of the Brooklyn city prison made yesterday by the February Kings County grand jury, Mayor LaGuardia said the jury had been misinformed when it made the statement that dangerous felons from Welfare Island were treated as trusties and permitted to mingle with young prisoners unconvicted of crime.

PARIS, March 2. -- No decisions affecting rates were taken by the meeting of the North Atlantic Passenger Conference which closed here today. At this two-day session only routine matters were discussed, according to an official of the conference who declined to add anything to the press communique which was as follows:
The Baltimore Orioles triumphed over the New York C., 6 to 2, in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game at the Coliseum last night before a crowd of 2,000. It was the winners' final league contest.

The New York Reserve Bank reports the gold actually received by this country from abroad during February as footing up $371,347,000. Two other ships bringing gold had actually docked, but their gold had not been officially reported. Probably it would be safe, including them, to reckon the month's receipts at $400,000,000.
NEW SMYRNA, Fla., March 2. -- Selection of the American outboard motor boat drivers who will make up the team to meet the Europeans in the international races starting here tomorrow was made tonight.

PARIS, March 2. -- Before the French Government takes a position on the disarmament proposals which have been made, the advice of the Council of National Defense will be taken, it was announced today after a Cabinet meeting.

Baron George von Zedlitz, Lord Cochrane, Count Pehr Sparre and Countess Sparre, Colonel Munro Cuthbertson and John Doty are among the passengers leaving tonight for Channel ports on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. Others sailing are:

Eleven properties, most of them tenement houses, were bought in by the plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday in Manhattan and the Bronx. All the parcels were taken over by the bidders to protect their liens.

Plans for beautification of the park strips in the centre of Park Avenue north of Forty-fifth Street were announced yesterday by Robert Moses, Park Commissioner. The grass plots will be renewed and shrubbery and flowers will be planted.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- In connection with the publication of salaries and other compensation received by directors and executive officers of corporations, the Federal Trade Commission has received this telegram from W.W. Winter, vice president and general manager of the Atlanta Gas Light Company, Atlanta:

Stockholders of the Sun Oil Company at their annual meeting on March 13 will vote on increasing capital stock to 2,300,000 shares of[ common stock of no par value. The company has 1,800,000 shares of common stock authorized.

HSINKING, March 2. -- Shark fins, octopus tentacles and lily roots may be all right for the average Manchu, but give Emperor Kang Teh ham and eggs any day. Big banquets and rare native foods irk the youthful ruler who mounted the throne of the new Manchurian Empire yesterday, amid traditional pomp and colorful ceremonies.

William Pikarsky, 25 years old, of 986 DeKalb Avenue, Brooklyn, who collapsed from hunger Thursday in the Mayor's reception room at City Hall, had returned yesterday to his old routine of looking for a job.

With a view to preventing corners in stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange, the committee on stock list has adopted a new form of agreement that holders of substantial amounts of the stock must sign when applications for listing are made.

Mayor LaGuardia insisted yesterday that his personal inspection of the three-story rooming house at 807 Quincy Street, Brooklyn, had disclosed conditions warranting police action, and late in the day Christian Klossett, owner of the house, was arrested on a charge of bookmaking.

Karl Schafer, the slim Austrian figure skater who recently retained his world's championship at Stockholm, arrived here yesterday aboard the North German Lloyd liner Bremen and lost no time in putting on his skates.

The Regional Labor Board invalidated yesterday the vote of the employes of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company on their union affiliation and announced that the matter would be laid before the National Labor Board today for "energetic action."

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- President Roosevelt, in sending to Capitol Hill today a message dealing with tariff law changes to permit the writing of reciprocal agreements and another dealing with Philippine independence, virtually completed transmission of his legislative program to Congress.
Commodity futures prices were generally higher yesterday on local exchanges. Trading volumes remained at about the same level as on Thursday. Cash prices were mostly higher.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Gold profits resulting from revaluation of the dollar were transferred from "general and special fund" receipts of the Treasury to "trust funds" on Feb. 28, bringing about a deficit of $2,352,170,000 on that date as compared with a surplus of $478,961,717 the day before, Treasury figures showed today.

Struggle for the succession in Mr. McCOOEY'S principality has not been settled, but postponed. Mr. FRANK V. KELLY, representing the McCooey tradition, was supported by the majority of the district leaders. The District of Columbia interposed its tireless hand. Mr. FARLEY, maintaining the necessary and vital connection of postal with political affairs, insisted that Postmaster SINNOTT was the man of men to lead the Brooklyn Democratic organization.

Stock prices moved irregularly during most of February, but early in the month they reached a new high point for the movement, which started abruptly in mid-January. The movement was within a narrow range until the closing week, when a definite reactionary trend wiped out what little gain had been made previously in the month.

Five persons who "contributed unusual achievements in the perpetuation of the history and traditions of the South" during 1933 received parchments of distinction from the New York Southern Society last night at its annual Dixie dinner dance in the Waldorf-Astoria.

BEAR OF OAKLAND, Northbound from Little America, March 2. -- Rolling heavily in mountainous rough seas, with solid green water breaking aboard her, the Bear of Oakland speeded her retreat out of Ross Sea, reaching at noon today 71.07 South, 179.30 East, 540 miles from Little America, having escaped being frozen in all Winter.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Closing today the NRA's field day for criticism, General Johnson thanked his critics, with the exception of Mrs. Gifford Pinchot, wife of the Pennsylvania Governor, and said he had found as a result of the meetings that these were the five main problems confronting the NRA:

BERLIN, March 2. -- The German Government as represented by the Nazi party has found it advisable to change its methods in the Saar Basin Territory and henceforth violence apparently is to be eschewed.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- President Roosevelt recommended to Congress in a special message today the abandonment by the United States of all military bases in the Philippine Islands as a further concession to the movement for Philippine independence.

The Corn Products Refining Company reported yesterday a net income of $11,504,941 in 1933, after the deduction of taxes, depreciation, interest and other charges. This is equivalent, after providing for the regular dividend on the 7 per cent preferred stock, to $3.87 a share on the outstanding common stock and compares with $8,761,638, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $2.77 a share on 2,530,000 common shares in 1932.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The American University announced tonight the establishment of a School of Public Affairs to serve as a laboratory for the study of government through direct contact between students in round-table discussions with government officials.

LONDON, March 2. -- The Daily Telegraph's naval correspondent, Hector Bywater, reports that Italy has decided not to introduce any new naval program this year, in view of the disarmament conversations and as a friendly gesture toward other nations.

Leading throughout the contest, Thomas Jefferson High School's basketball team remained in first place in the Brooklyn P.S.A.L. race by defeating Boys High, 31 to 17, yesterday in the Jefferson gymnasium. Morris Silverstein with 11 points topped the Jefferson scorers.

MADIRID, March 2. -- Alejandro Lerroux was asked by President Niceto Alcala Zamora this afternoon to form another Cabinet, and the governmental crisis resulting from the resignations yesterday of the Minister of the Interior, Diego Martinez Barrios, and Minister of Finance Antonio Lara because they disapproved of the Premier's concessions to Right Wing elements in the Cortes may be terminated tomorrow morning.

REPORTS in seed and nursery trade papers indicate that this Spring, for the first time in years, there will be a shortage in many items before the planting season is over. Most experienced gardeners have already obtained their supplies of seed and have ordered plants for later delivery.

The Princeton Club player, I.L. Lee Jr., seeded No. 1, was among the ten to gain the third round yesterday in the metropolitan squash racquets Class C championship at the Downtown Athletic Club courts.

Continued improvement in industry was noted throughout the country last month, according to the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, which made public its February findings yesterday. The committee again recommended a policy of extended protection on commodities to all purchasing agents.

NINE Dartmouth students die in their sleep, overcome by carbon monoxide from a defective furnace in the cellar of their fraternity house. Because of their number and their youth the country is shocked, asks questions about carbon monoxide, wonders how great a peril it is and demands alarms that will ring when the air becomes too dangerous to breathe.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3. -- Lehigh University, Eastern intercollegiate wrestling champion for the last three years, gained its twentieth straight dual meet victory by subduing Pennsylvania in the Palestra today, 31 to 3.

The sharp increase in the number of stockholders in the United States which occurred throughout the first three years of the depression was arrested in 1933 and replaced by a downward trend, compilations by THE NEW YORK TIMES reveal.

THIS is not only a remarkably interesting book which makes you captive to its milieu and atmosphere; it is also the work of a truthful and powerful writer. Few other novels of our time, whatever the materials they have dealt in, have exhibited the clarity of purpose, the niceness of emphasis, the neatness of detail displayed by Miss White in "Frost in May."

LIMA, Ohio, March 3 (AP). -- Sheriff Don Sarber was ordered tonight to "shoot" three henchmen of John Dillinger in jail here if the fugitive gang leader tries to liberate them and the attempt appears likely to be successful.

BERLIN, March 3. -- Franklin D. Roosevelt a year ago was swept into the White House by a mighty movement. Beginning in the West and in the Middle West, the movement was fed by two sources of power, the energetic, pure, magnetic personality of the President and his program of social, economic and political reforms.

As the joint work of two poets, there is sufficient variety of mood and subject in this book to satisfy the most omnivorous. And in addition there are two individualities present, each to some degree supplementing the other. Geraldine Wolf cares rather more for her art than does her husband; he is rather more eager to say something vigorous, and to say it with a maximum of vigor, than is she.

At its Students' Concert last night in Carnegie Hall the Philharmonic-Symphony, under Hans Lange and assisted by Gregor Piatigorsky, 'cellist, played the Bach-Honegger arrangements from the French suites, Saint-Saens concerto for 'cello No. 1, Op. 33, and Rachmaninoff's Second symphony.

PROBABLY the day is not far distant when somebody will write about the community life of a manicure set or a vegetable plate. Boats, boarding houses, hotels, hospitals, jails have all been subjected to the same technical manoeuvre and half a dozen people who have nothing in common except propinquity have been wound up and set in motion.

Mr. and Mrs. Marsden B. Candler gave a dinner last night at the Rockaway Hunting Club, Cedarhurst, L.I., for Mr. Candler's brother, Flamen B. Candler, who celebrated his birthday yesterday, and Mrs. Candler. Among the other guests were:
Throughout the United States during the last few months armies of CWA and other Federal employes have been aiding conservation in one way or another.

SEA ISLAND BEACH, Ga. -- Looming high among the season's sporting events is the annual Seniors' Tournament, which will be staged at the Sea Island Golf Club on March 7, 8, 9 and 10. Amateur golfers who have passed the half-century mark will be eligible and representatives of more than thirty Eastern, Canadian and Southern clubs are expected to take part.

EDUCATORS are becoming conscious that the large schools have outgrown the small-college type of organization in which the president is responsible for most of the operating details. The faculties are stirring uneasily as they discover that a rigid, vertical line of executives appointed by a board of trustees inevitably means in a large school stereotyped instruction and the submergence of individuality.

THE glamour of the medieval pageant is on "The Fool of Venus" if not quite in it. The splendid follies of the Crusaders cover the intrigues of Emperor, Pope and Doge. The ambiguous Courts of Love, with their great ladies of easy virtue and troubadours whose gay songs brighten the pages, codify adultery in the Laws of Love and excuse faithlessness in a tenson.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 3. -- Two interscholastic records were broken and one world's mark equaled in the fourteenth annual Rutgers interscholastic swimming meet today.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 3. -- Long runs featured both events at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. In the skeet contest, J. White, who finally won the high scratch cup, broke 113 straight targets, a record for skeet shooting at the traps. In the regular event, R.H. Helsel, scratch-prize winner, continued on for an unfinished run of 107.

THE army and navy have had a busy year under the New Deal, with both services taking a new lease of life. The army has entered into the national life of the country to a greater extent than ever before in peacetime, and the navy is busy building up its forces to the strength authorized under the London Naval Treaty.

It appears that some radio artists and newspaper columnists are playing the part of propagandists and political sycophants. When their activity is directed to a matter of such vital national consequence as carrying the air mail, it is fitting that the man on the street be heard.

NORMA SHEARER and Charles Laughton have been nominated by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer officialdom for leading roles in one of the studio's more significant enterprises, the screen version of "The Barretts of Wimpole Street."

DALLAS, Texas, March 2. -- Industrial recovery has proceeded with quickened pace during the last week. Reports show a healthy and well-maintained volume of business, both wholesale and retail. Some department stores report increases in the volume of sales amounting to 50 to 75 per cent as compared with the same period of 1933.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 3. -- The Dartmouth hockey team won a close decision from Princeton in the Baker Memorial Rink tonight to finish in the leading position of the Quadrangular Hockey League. The score was 4 -- 3.

Transferred to a new track and a new setting in Madison Square Garden, the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. will conduct its thirteenth annual indoor track and field championships tomorrow night with twenty-nine colleges battling for the team championship.

OMAHA, March 1. -- As the first year of the New Deal closes the Corn Belt finds itself much better off. Not only has its material condition improved, its state of mind also has undergone a change for the better. For every tangible point of advancement it can record its morale has gone up two.

MADRID, March 3. -- Premier Lerroux announced today the formation of his third Cabinet under the republican regime. It is another minority government lacking the collaboration of the strong Catholic party in the Cortes.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, before sailing on the Italian liner Rex yesterday, praised President Roosevelt's position on the disarmament problem as expressed in the State Department announcement of Friday, and characterized it as "a first-rate thing to do."

Prominent members of the Georgian-Circassian former nobility who comprise the personnel of the Georgian-Circassian Club of this city are completing plans for the Allaverdy Ball, which takes place Friday night at the Plaza. Prince Georges Matchabelli and Prince Irakli Orbeliani are, respectively, president and vice president of the sponsoring organization.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 3. -- Five universities in this country are outstanding leaders in graduate research in physics, chemistry and mathematics, a recent study by the Princeton Alumni Weekly shows.

TORONTO, Ont., March 3. -- In reporting the production of gold for January, the Ontario Department of Mines takes the metal at the current price in computing values. It says that on the announcement of President Roosevelt on Jan. 31 that the United States thereafter would pay at least $35 a fine ounce for gold, arrangements were made for marketing Ontario's gold in New York.

THE question of subway unification is once more before the public of New York. A.A. Berle Jr., City Chamberlain, is acting for the LaGuardia administration in the negotiations with the transit companies. The issue has been raised many times Before; Mayor O'Brien and his predecessors tried to solve it; the public has long demanded it, but nothing has resulted.

THE carved ebony throne installed for Henry Pu Yi for his enthronement as Emperor of Manchukuo him famous precursors in history. From time immemorial it has been the custom of Oriental monarchs to construct for themselves elaborate thrones, whose beauty and value have become proverbial.

The Butterfly Ball, a feature among the entertainments of each Spring in New York, is to be a dinner dance this year instead of a late supper dance, it has just been announced. The event will take place on the night of April 3 at the Ritz-Carlton and is expected to be one of the largest parties of the Easter season.

ONE of the largest of President Roosevelt's problems when he took office a year ago was that arising from the existence of some 12,000,000 unemployed. To meet the situation he established the Federal Emergency Relief Administration, with $500,000,000 to spend in direct aid, and included in the National Industrial Recovery Act clauses appropriating $3,300,000,000 to be spent for public works.

WORCESTER, Mass., March 3 (A). -- Four men were burned to death and twelve persons were injured in a fire which destroyed the Hotel Pleasant early today. The loss is estimated at $125,000. The blaze was brought under control after a three-hour fight.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 3. -- Another reduction of the Yale baseball squad today by Head Coach Joe Wood brought it down to fifty. Nine have been dropped from the squad since it reported a fortnight ago.
WASHINGTON, March 3. -- After one year of President Roosevelt's administration, what is the score in the struggle against continuing economic depression?

CHICAGO, March 3. -- Eli Daiches, 45 years old, president of the Thomas M. Bowers Advertising Agency, was shot to death this morning by machine-gun assassins, who fired a dozen bullets into him as he was riding in his automobile, driven by a chauffeur, a half block from the Sherry Hotel, where he lived.

OTTAWA, March 1. -- At ten-mile intervals along the 354-mile highway which joins Toronto and Montreal first-aid stations are being equipped for passing motorists. Three hundred miles of this highway are in Ontario and is part of what is known by law as the King's Highway.

BIVALVE, N.J., March 3. -- The men who sail from this picturesque riverfront village to dredge oysters from the Delaware River and bay hope that settlement by the United States Supreme Court of the boundary dispute between New Jersey and Delaware, a controversy that has flared intermittently since the seventeenth century, will help to speed recovery in the oyster industry, upon which rests the economic well-being of Southern Cumberland County.

Such a book as this reminds us to what extent a child's training in esthetic appreciation is usually left to chance. While gallery and museum facilities are greater, of course, in a large city, there are opportunities to see paintings and sculpture in many smaller places.

WHERE this novel differs from the ordinary crime story is in the placing of the emphasis not upon the murder with which the story deals but upon the manner in which a hitherto peaceful English village reacts to that murder and to the events following upon it.

PARIS, March 3. -- Henry Cheron, Minister of Justice and director of the far-flung judicial and parliamentary investigations into the Bayonne pawnshop scandal and its sequels, tonight issued a highly significant communique. He said:

CROWN POINT, Ind., March 3 (AP). -- Sheriff Lillian Holley, flustered when she first received the news that John Dillinger had escaped, quickly regained her poise and took charge of the jail. She directed the dispatching of messages to surrounding cities, called the roll of her twenty-three deputies and divided them into hunting squads.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 20. -- The new Belgian Minister of Commerce, Franz Van Cauwelaert, was formerly burgomaster of Antwerp. He is the owner of the Flemish newspaper De Standaard and has organized the Flemish party in Belgium, reducing the many dialects to a single language, which he calls Netherlandish.
WARSAW, March 2. -- At the close of 1933, Soviet diplomats suggested that Poland and Russia guarantee the Baltic States' independence, which was said to be menaced by Nazi Germany.

BY virtue of diligent and unremitting effort extending over a decade, Germany finally succeeded in ridding herself of the burden of reparations payments. With the same methodical thoroughness and the same fixed determination, she has now concentrated her attention upon the task of escaping from the restrictions imposed by the peace treaty, particularly as they affect her armaments, and upon the problem of whittling down the debts that she owes to foreign private creditors.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 3. -- Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L. I., women's national golf titleholder in 1931, won the Florida East Coast championship on the St. Augustine links today by defeating Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City in the eighteen-hole final, 2 and 1.

AMID the booming of guns, the clangor of bells and fanfare of trumpets, a new sovereign has ascended a throne in Europe. Monarchs may not be what the Hapsburgs the Hohenzollerns and the Romanoffs were at the height of their autocracy.

THERE has been developed during the past year a new and simple method of securing accurate data on traffic behavior, an exact knowledge of which is necessary for the correct design of highways and for the proper regulation of traffic.

INITIATIVE is at a greater premium than ever in the job-hunting world nowadays, and the earlier in school life it can be developed, the luckier the boy or girl; so at least agreed experts at the recent convention of the National Vocational Guidance Association at Cleveland.
PHILADELPHIA, March 3. -- Columbia gave Penn a merry battle in an Eastern League basketball game at the Palestra tonight, but the Red and Blue came through with a victory, 29 to 24.
James C. Sheridan of Astoria was named yesterday as Democratic leader of Queens County, in place of John Theofel, by the executive committee of the county committee.

One of the most graceful sports, figure skating, will occupy a place in the national spotlight this week. The two-day tests that decide the national titles in senior, junior and novice divisions will be held in Philadelphia on Friday and Saturday.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 3. -- "Inside baseball as it was played twenty years ago may be all very interesting for those who were brought up with it or take the time to find out what it is all about, but what the fan today wants is action and plenty of good, solid socking.

I think it is wiser to leave a reviewer's criticisms unanswered, un less they include obviously erroneous and misleading statements and impressions. This certainly is the case in Dr. Koiransky's review of our "Red Medicine." He has confined his comments to isolated points and has failed to bring to your readers the faintest conception of the vast revolutionary change in medical care in Soviet Russia.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP). -- Three basic principles were laid down by Secretary Ickes, the oil administrator, tonight as controling factors in considering plans for development of new oil pools.

Improving weather conditions in some sections of the country took immediate effect last week in an upward swing of retail trade, indicating that buying power remains strong and that expectations for good Spring business have not been overrated.

Before the largest crowd of the season at Squadron A Armory the Pennsylvania Military College polo team continued its unbeaten record and clinched the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League championship last night by defeating the First Division, 10 -- 9.

TWOSCOPE pictures by Richard Ederheimer, who began painting at 40, are on exhibition at the Newhouse Galleries. The artist avowedly distrusts technical facility. If some of his critics regret a lack in that direction, it is considerably balanced by a forthrightness and directness of approach and, in the portraits, by a very real grasp of the sitter's character and individuality.

THE special interest of Belgium's new King, Leopold III, in the Belgian Congo -- he has visited this African colony twice to study its possibilities for development -- directs attention to the impressive transformation which has taken place in this jungle land in recent years.

Overnight buying orders advanced prices on the Cotton Exchange 10 points yesterday, but the best quotations were made on the opening call. The rise of $3 a bale from the low levels of the week attracted Southern selling, while the delayed introduction of crop-control legislation in the House failed to stimulate consumer buying.

BERLIN, March 3. -- The purposeful optimism that the German Government maintained on the disarmament negotiations during the tour of the European capitals by Captain Anthony Eden, British Lord Privy Seal, has given way to anxious pessimism relieved only by the consideration that technically Germany stood with Britain and Italy against France.

THE depression has not dealt kindly with the Pullman porter. A usually generous public has not been so ready to tip smiling George. Moreover, pay envelopes have been considerably thinner and jobs have been fewer.

RICHMOND, Va., March 1. -- Dixie salutes President Roosevelt as the first year of the New Deal comes to a close. Improvement in agricultural, industrial and general business conditions that has taken place in this region during the past twelve months makes the South even more solidly pro-Roosevelt than in 1932.

Mrs. August Belmont has accepted the active presidency of the Motion Picture Research Council, according to an announcement by the organization yesterday. Under her leadership, and with the cooperation of Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell, who now becomes honorary president of the council, plans will be developed for a widespread campaign to eliminate block-booking and promote the use of motion pictures for educational and cultural work.

Secretary of Agriculture Wallace will be the principal speaker at the opening session of the Commission of Inquiry on National Policy in International Economic Relations tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

THE machine age has been hailed as an authentic source of inspiration for today's decorative design, but the results achieved by the designer too often suggest that a greater understanding of it is necessary and a more careful selection of motifs.

PATERSON, N.J., March 3. -- Six of the eight men tried here on indictments charging conspiracy to obstruct justice in connection with the Passaic County jury-fixing investigation were found guilty today in Quarter Sessions Court, where their trial started Feb. 19.

LAUREN GILFILLAN is a young woman who graduated from Smith College in 1931 and finding herself stranded in a world that had little use for her gifts, literally went to seek another. Today she is a graduate of Pit College, and it is safe to assume that the diploma she carries from there will open more doors to her than her academic scroll.

MIAMI. -- International yachting events, which were inaugurated here with the Miami-to-Nassau sailing race of last Tuesday, are engaging the interest of the Winter colony. Throughout the month there is to be much entertaining in honor of the visiting yachtsmen from Nassau, Cuba and Europe, competitors who will come for the finals of the Southern international motorboat regattas, which are to feature the Biscayne Bay regatta of March 16 and 17.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 3. -- The worst of the depression is over in Chile, in the opinion of the Central Bank, although warning is given that a long period must elapse before the normal purchasing power of the people is fully restored.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- A statement that commercial airlines are trying "to magnify army airplane mishaps and minimize their own deficiencies," was made by Clarence D. Chamberlin in a letter to Postmaster General Farley, made public today.

Mayor LaGuardia will be the guest speaker at the twenty-eighth annual meeting of the Girls Branch, Public Schools Athletic League, at 3:30 P.M. on March 14 in the assembly room of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, Lexington Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street.

A 3-to-2 defeat of the hitherto unbeaten James Madison High School team by Textile featured the competition as the annual P.S.A.L. championship fencing tournament was resumed at Washington Irving High School, Manhattan, yesterday. Textile also gained 3-o-2 decisin over Lincoln, while Madison, in its other meeting, vani quished Seward Park, 4 -- 1.

While the rate of advance slackened somewhat, manufacturing and wholesale activity in the metropolitan area during the week was higher than in the previous period, according to the report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the New York Credit Men's Association.

CHICAGO, March 3. -- Yesterday's talk of inflation of the currency proved to be a one-day factor in the grain markets on the Board of Trade, and operations today became listless again. Wheat held within a range of around a cent a bushel and corn 1/2 cent without the market getting far in either direction.
WASHINGTON, March 3. -- By executive order President Roosevelt today cut the one remaining tie that bound the National Labor Board to the NRA.

Representatives of De Witt Clinton High School captured only one first place on the sixteen-event program but won the eighteenth Manual Training High School interscholastic track and field meet yesterday at the Fourteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn.
Making her first American appearance since the last Olympic Games, Miss Stella Walsh set a new world's indoor record for the 60-yard dash last night.
RADIO showmen have reached a point where they boast about the length of time a show runs on the air. It is surprising how many programs have crossed the 500 mark.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Republican lines were drawn tighter today against President Roosevelt's reciprocal tariff proposal, with indications that Senator Borah and others of the progressives would align themselves with the conservatives opposing the administration's program.

FOR the first time in twelve years, the Metropolitan Opera Company will go to Boston for a week's engagement. The engagement is made possible by the Boston Opera Association. The repertoire, casts and directors for the week are as follows:

LOUISE DRESSER, after twenty-two years in light opera, musical comedy and vaudeville, went to Hollywood in 1922 and has been in the films ever since. One of the cinema's best known delineators of reasonably downtrodden wives and mothers, Miss Dresser may be seen at the Radio City Music Hall with Will Rogers in "David Harum."
BERLIN, March 3. -- Hundreds of German newspapers today lauded President Roosevelt in syndicated articles as "the man who gave a new meaning to the American State."

MOSCOW, March 2. -- The Chelyuskin disaster -- the sinking of a freighter in the Bering Sea and stranding on the ice of 101 men, women and children -- calls attention to an increasingly important phase of Soviet home policy, namely, the development or, to use a favorite Bolshevist expression, "mastery" of Arctic possessions.

Excessive speculation would be curbed more effectively, with less liquidation and fewer disturbances to useful trading, by the margin requirements proposed by the survey staff of the Twentieth Century Fund than by provisions of the Fletcher-Rayburn bill, according to a supplementary report made yesterday by Evans Clark, director of the fund, which is sponsored principally by Edward A. Filene.

Incalculable destiny, strange web and woof of fate! The Hermit Kingdom now goes out to talk with her enemies in the Eastern Gates and presses westward sword in hand to challenge the very people who summoned her to a part in life.

THE nation's New Deal has brought with it a renaissance of American sea power. To the steps taken since March 4 to strengthen our fleet has now been added the Vinson bill -- which is awaiting final approval in Washington -- keystone of the most comprehensive plans for strengthening and maintaining the American Navy that ever have been formulated.

Verdi's "Aida" will open the Associated Artists season of opera at the Cosmopolitan Theatre on Columbus Circle on Friday evening, according to announcement by the cooperative company which is casting a repertory of twelve operas there.

COPENHAGEN. ONCE again the thousand-odd letters of Esaias Tegner, the popular Swedish poet whose Viking cycle "Fritjof's Saga" has been translated into every language of the civilized world and found its way into English in more than twenty versions, have been made the subject of critical study.

The Federal Trade Commission's report on salaries paid the executives of business corporations is certain to promote a lot of resentment. At the same time, however, we believe most Americans do not begrudge generous compensation to leaders of business who prove their ability.

YONKERS, march 3. -- A contest to service about $10,000,000 of participating mortgages that had been sold by the closed Westchester Trust Company bank of this city has been started by two groups of mortgage certificate holders.

Spokesmen for retail interests at the NRA open hearings during the week brought back from Washington the impression that headway has been made in their fight against provisions of the manufacturers' codes which "radically affected" relations between producer and retailer, which had a "monopolistic tendency and raised prices unduly" and which altered established discount terms.

QUERQUEVILLE, France, March 3. -- M. Petit, Assistant Professor of Comparative Anatomy in the Museum of Paris, came here today to inspect the sea monster thrown up on the beach last Thursday. He said the creature was "absolutely extraordinary."

Fog and conditions of low ceilings and poor visibility kept the airmail planes of the Army Air Corps on the ground yesterday over most of the Eastern zone. Out of Newark Airport only the runs to Boston and to Richmond, Va., were flown. The run from Miami to Jacksonville, Fla., was also open.

THE publishing house of Covici-Friede announces that it has become the official publisher in America of the works, both scientific and nonscientific, of Professor Albert Einstein. The first book to be issued under this agreement will be "The World As I See it," a translation from the German, which will appear either late this Spring or early next Fall.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT comes through his first year smiling. The Presidency in the best of times is one of the hardest jobs in the world. Mr. Roosevelt took office in the worst, of times. By common admission, he has had as stressful a year as any President since Lincoln, and, by one way of measuring Executive labor, he has carried twice the ordinary Presidential working load.

NEW ORLEANS, March 3. -- Slapped, the 4-year-old son of Pompey and Smack, which races for Leonard Wilson, scored his fourth consecutive victory at the Fair Grounds today when he led home a fast field in the mile and a furlong of the $2,000 added New Orleans Handicap.

A campaign to advertise the school system of New York -- to "put the schools in the hearts and souls of the people" -- was strongly urged last night by three speakers at a dinner of the New York Principals Association at the Hotel Astor.

WEST POINT, March 3. -- In a thrilling hockey game which was witnessed by a capacity crowd of 2,000 spectators in the West Point skating arena tonight, the Royal Military College of Kingston, Ont., defeated Army, 6 to 4.

A line of praise in an ancient canticle speaks of one as the "chiefest standard bearer among ten thousand." Of no one in the academic world of today could this be more deservedly said than of ADAM LEROY JONES. He will be gratefully and affectionately remembered by thousands to whom he was the teacher and friend.

Warning against prejudicing more valuable markets elsewhere through possible concessions granted Russia in a reciprocal trade agreement, James A. Farrell, president of the National Foreign Trade Council and former head of the United States Steel Corporation, yesterday sent a statement to government officials in which he minimized the possibility of this country securing permanent benefits through trade arrangements with the Soviet.
ST. PETERSBURG Fla., March 3. -- Johnny Allen, right-handed ace of the Yankee pitching staff, capitulated today, adding to the number of the team's regulars signed.
President Roosevelt's views on some outstanding issues of the day are set out in the following extracts from his public utterances made in the course of the first year of his administration.

NEW YORK CITY'S statues, which are to be cleaned by the unemployed artists of the metropolis, honor our nations heroes and those of other lands as well as literary and musical celebrities. There are also symbolic figures.

The search for Mrs. Rufus Leighton MacDuffie, 63 years old, of Lucust, N.J., who disappeared Feb. 15 from a sanitarium at Stockbridge, Mass., known as the Dr. Riggs Foundation, where she was under treatment for a nervous breakdown, spread to this city last night.
A proposed industrial code for the taxicab industry in New York City, upon which a hearing is to be held at City Hall March 12, was made public yesterday by representatives of cab operators.
AIKEN. -- With the advent of March, the major events of Aiken's season are drawing near. A varied program of Spring sports is in prospect.

ATHENS, March 3. -- A new crisis in Samuel Insull's troubled Grecian sojourn was created today when the Foreign Minister signed an order calling for the speedy expulsion of the former Chicago utilities operator.

NEW YORK always has been hospitable to the panhandler. He has never found it difficult to pick up sufficient cash for a bed in a flophouse, a mess of beans and a nip of liquor on the side. When tapped on the shoulder and taken into court, he could usually expect leniency from the magistrate.

Mayor LaGuardia's plan to establish beer gardens in Central Park and in other recreational centres on city property was criticized as "deplorable" and as tending to "debauchery" by leaders of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union yesterday.

Candor demands that we take note of one serious omission in our review of President ROOSEVELT'S first year in another section of today's paper. Dozens of problems and events are there discussed, with a wealth of text, picture and diagram.

CROWN POINT, Ind., March 3. -- John Dillinger, notorious bank robber and murderer, walked out of the heavily guarded and supposedly escape-proof Lake County jail this morning in a daring escape that rivals the exploits of the heroes of Wild West thrillers.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The Recovery Act provides potentially a constitution for limited self-government for industry by trade groups subject to governmental supervision, but if administration on that plane does not accomplish the desired results the constitution "may be one not of self-government but of highly autocratic control of business men by the government," according to members of the Brookings Institution, which will issue tomorrow "The ABC of the NRA."

Additional gold imports of $34,875,600 were reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, making a total of $466,621,400 of reported gold imports since Feb. l, and an indicated net gain in monetary gold stocks, exclusive of newly mined gold, of $456,222,700 in the period.

BLACK RIVER" is like a furiously written morality play. It is a novel of the Mexican oil fields in those days -- now some fifteen years ago -- when American and British interests were taking millions upon millions of dollars out of the soil of Mexico.

About 1,500 editors, staff members and faculty advisers of school publications throughout the country are expected to attend the tenth annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association at Columbia University on Thursday, Friday and Saturday, it was announced yesterday by Joseph M. Murphy, director of the association.

THE thesis of this book is that America always has been ruled -- indirectly, if you like, but nevertheless ruled -- by thieves. Mr. McConaughy's demonstration does not go further back than the foundation of the government under the Constitution, but he implies in his introduction that his decision to go no further back is arbitrary.

The present national administration through its New Deal program is endeavoring to foster a feeling of individualism which will allow the individual "to develop his life according to his own special program," Adolf A. Berle Jr., City Chamberlain, Professor of Law at Columbia University and former member of the "brain trust," declared in an article in The Independent Journal, published yesterday by the Columbia School of Journalism.

DISCIPLES of the New Deal await with keenest interest the outcome of the New York State milk case in the Supreme Court -- perhaps tomorrow. Should the court uphold New York's law fixing milk prices there would be almost general agreement that the court is decidedly liberal in sentiment.
The proposed child labor amendment is opposed in a letter written by Elihu Root, former Secretary of State, addressed to William D. Guthrie, attorney.

Manchuria of late has been an item in the war which many people see imminent in the Far East. The debut of an Empire of Manchukuo is discussed primarily in terms of Russia and Japan. Yet there is one interested party which as late as three years ago would have been considered the one chiefly concerned in the march of events in Manchuria.

THIS interpretation of the work spirit of the Mahatma Gandhi offers to American readers needed enlightenment concerning his aims and achievements. For to most of them he is merely a much-talked-about man of India who works industriously at a spinning wheel and wears next to no clothing.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 3. -- With Al Bonniwell setting the pace, Dartmouth's basketball team handed Harvard its ninth straight setback in the Eastern Intercollegiate League by a 46-to-28 score in the Indoor Athletic Building tonight.

BERLIN, March 3. -- A year ago this week, in an election which culminated the terrorism following the Reichstag fire, the National Socialists in Germany attained the full power that had been their goal during the fourteen years of their movement.

MIAMI, Fla., March 3. -- E.R. Bradley's Blessed Event won the featured Jockey Club Handicap at a mile and a quarter at Hialeah Park today and set a new track record of 2:02 4-5 for the distance. The odds-on favorite, Springsteel, held at 9 to 10, was second, a length back of the Bradley racer and two before Big Beau.

The report of the Railroad Credit Corporation for March 1 shows that railroads to which it extended aid have reduced their debt from $72,379,928 to $66,701,319, a decrease of $5,677,709. The company has repaid in five dividends 12 per cent of contributions made to its loan pool.

Directors of the Catholic Young Women's Club headed by Miss Constance Armstrong, daughter of Sir Harry Gloster Armstrong, former British Consul General at New York and Lady Armstrong, have arranged a luncheon, followed by bridge, in behalf of the organization which will be held Thursday at the Central Park Casino.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Forecasts of the future and obsequies for the past featured the annual White House Correspondents Association dinner, given in honor of President Roosevelt at the Willard Hotel tonight.

NEW SMYRNA, Fla., March 3. -- Horace Tennes of Chicago, 21-year-old amateur driver who is a student at Northwestern University, today won the first of the international motorboat races. The event was witnessed by 12,000 spectators.

NEW YORK'S annual guests, the European opera stars, like Washington's accredited diplomats, having retained through prohibition years their early or extraterritorial tastes for light wines and ales, were among the first to welcome repeal.

OTTAWA, March 1. -- American States, busily developing satisfactory liquor systems in the enthusiasm of the post-repeal atmosphere, may find some interesting bases of comparison in statistics of drinking and the cost of drinking as compiled for the past year by the Ontario Liquor Control Board.

While returning to England on the Orient Express, Hercule Poirot is offered the Job of protecting a rich American who calls himself Ratchett and who says that his life has been threatened. Poirot refuses the job because he does not like the man's face. Later on, while the train is snowed up somewhere in the Balkans, Ratchett is brutally murdered in his own compartment in the Calais coach.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Business activity has continued to expand and the movement of the weekly statistics indicates a further rise in the indices of production and primary distribution for February, according to the weekly review of business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.
BUDAPEST, March 3. -- Once again Eastern Europe has justified its reputation of being Europe's danger spot.

CERTAIN correspondents accuse us of an inverted chauvinism -- whatever that may be -- when American compositions are not favorably mentioned. We are snobs, who believe that everything European is good, and anything American bad.

A remarkable change has occurred in the economic viewpoint in most European countries, according to E.F. Davies, delegate of the Royal Bank of Scotland, who after a business tour of Europe, arrived here a few days ago.

This is the fourth of Miss Taylor's stories about Asey Mayo, the Cape Cod detective whose native shrewdness and humor make him a delightful companion for an evening's excursion into the world of crime. But Asey is not the only entertaining character in this book.

CHICAGO, March 3. -- In a two-hour session packed with dramatic incident, Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop today completed her testimony on the witness stand at her trial in Judge Harry B. Miller's court for the murder of her daughter-in-law, Rheta.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- The Pinehurst sports program is entering its final stage. After the next two weeks of Tin Whistle and Silver Foils golf contests the thirty-second annual North and South amateur championship for women will be contested, starting March 19.

HOLLYWOOD. THE return of a once popular star to the spotlight is a difficult road. Gloria Swanson is about to attempt her return to the screen, probably in "Three Weeks," perhaps in "Heavenly Sinner," dealing with the history of Lola Montez.

BOOKS designed to give information to children have appeared in many forms since Mrs. Trimmer wrote "An Introduction to Knowledge" in the late eighteenth century and Priscilla Wakefield devised her "Mental Improvement" and "Juvenile Travelers" for young readers.

DURING the twelve months since President Roosevelt's inauguration the nation has witnessed an epoch-making series of developments affecting its fiscal affairs, domestic and international. Abandonment of the gold standard, nullification of the gold clause in existing and future contracts, segregation of gold stocks in the Treasury, devaluation of the dollar, capture of $2,800,000,000 profit on gold by the government and adoption of a modified "gold-bullion" standard were events which few forecasters could have visualized.

WITH the Legislature in session, various organizations eager to protect the countryside against billboards and other structures that violate the scenery and create hazards are seeking the enactment of laws that will provide some degree of restriction.

Professor JOHN L. GERIG, holding the chair of Celtic Literature at Columbia, announces a "world revival" of interest in Irish culture. To begin with -- and that means going back seventy centuries -- excavations made by the second Harvard archaeological mission to Ireland have revealed that the island is a "veritable mine of untouched archaeological treasures."

John J. Dorman, former Fire Commissioner, was honored by Alfred E. Smith and other notables at a reception yesterday afternoon marking Mr. Dorman's induction as director and executive vice president of the Modern Investment and Loan Corporation.

Opposition to the bill to require consent of the County Chairman of a political party for the incorporation of an independent political club using the party name has been expressed by the Knickerbocker Democrats and the City Fusion party through accredited representatives.

ONCE more the ancient triangle is drafted into service, to provide here the motive for a young newspaper man's drinking himself nearly to death, for his beloved lady to do likewise, and for the elderly deceived husband to suffer his shame in stoical, brooding humiliation.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 22. -- A new Brazilian tariff, it is expected, will be soon put in force, probably early in the second half of this year.

CASTING up the accounts of New York's "old-fashioned" Winter, one finds that it has been notable in several respects. It has set the record for the coldest day in the annals of the local Weather Bureau; it has witnessed a succession of heavy February snowstorms, accompanied by low temperatures, and it has been on the whole a cold Winter, though not so cold as the Winter of 1917-18.

In his message to Congress last week, President ROOSEVELT said that "important branches of our agriculture," as well as "those branches of "American industry whose mass-pro-"duction methods have led the world," stand to gain greatly through a revival of our lost foreign trade. In the first group he mentioned specifically cotton, tobacco, hog products, rice, cereals and fruits.
OMAHA, Neb., March 3. -- The Rev. Patrick J. Mahan, S.J., president of Creighton University, believes "big-time football is crooked."
WASHINGTON, March 3. -- In November, 1932, a few days after the election, I wrote President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt a letter which read, in part:

WHEN the curtain fell on the third act of "They Shall Not Die," at the Royale Theatre one night recently, I experienced a sensation the theatre never had given me before. I had not seen a dream walking, but I had seen reality in grease-paint; history which the footlights only faintly distorted.

NOW and then America has been singularly fortunate in her interpreters. A good many Europeans have written about her in the course of her short history, it is true, with little knowledge and less understanding.

CHICAGO, March 1. -- In this Great Lakes region of the United States a year of the New Deal has evoked a reaction as multicolored as the kaleidoscopic nature of its many aspects and activities. The magnitude of the issues involved in its program, the vastness of the figures that express its aims and activities in terms of dollars, the complexity of the problems that it attacks baffle the minds of ordinary men and women.
LONDON, March 3. -- The British press signalizes the end of President Roosevelt's first year in Washington with the most approval yet shown for the President from this side.
HARRISON, N.Y., March 3. -- Ottar Satre of the Salisbury (Conn.) Outing Club further added to his honors by annexing the Class A prize at a benefit ski-jumping competition today.

Six of the eight seeded players advanced to the quarter-final bracket in the national amateur squash tennis championship last night on the courts of the Princeton Club. The other two ranking stars are still in the competition, but have only reached the third round.
Mr. Richberg's article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine deals very superficially with the problems of the NRA, which he discusses.

PRECISELY as the rhythms of labor and the cadences of machinery have inspired musical compositions ranging from the "Anvil Chorus" to Arthur Honegger's "Pacific 231," so man's conquest of the air with soaring plane and roaring engine has spurred composers to the production of songs and instrumental pieces.

PARIS, March 3. -- Definite assurances were given today that the largest French automobile factory would be maintained in operation, but not, it was asserted, any longer under the sole direction of Andre Citroen, who is known as France's Henry Ford.

CHICAGO, March 2. -- Trade continued to move forward on a broad basis, with wholesale dry goods houses reporting sales as high as 50 per cent over last year's totals for the period. Retail department store sales for the month just ended averaged only a little below the 1931 totals, according to competent estimates.

As a result of the large subscription for the performance of "As You Like It," the annual Shakespearean production of the Junior Players of the New York Women's League for Animals, to be given on the night of March 12, the young players will repeat the performance the night of March 15.

PALM BEACH. -- Sports interest this week has shifted from the golf and tennis championships of preceding months to the Gold Cup speed-boat races scheduled for Saturday and Sunday, March 10 and 11, on Lake Worth.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 3. -- Outscoring Brown by 23 -- 11 in the second half, Yale triumphed in tonight's basketball game by 38 to 26.

MESA VERDE National Park in Colorado is looking forward to an important expansion of its museum through funds allotted to it from the PWA. An addition is to be built to the museum, and a number of archaeological specimens and collections, including the famous Nordenskiold collection of Mesa Verde material now in the museum at Helsingfors. Finland, will be presented to the institution.
The death of two more persons in a tenement house fire yesterday drew from Mayor LaGuardia sharp criticism of the courts for permitting the continued use of old-type tenements.

THIS wild, witty and frankly improbable story of amorous adventure seems an amazing book to have come out of Australia, which we are accustomed to associate with a very different type of fiction. Consistently amusing, mildly satiric, always just hovering on the brink of the risque with a delicate mocking humor, this is one of the few books that provide a really good occasion for using that poor overworked word, "sophisticated."

THE "good neighbor" pledge, given by the President in his inaugural address and repeated at frequent intervals by him and Secretary Hull, has been the guiding policy of the Roosevelt administration in the field of foreign affairs.

Despite the recent unfavorable weather conditions in many sections of the country, which retarded expansion of consumer interest in Spring merchandise, a substantial amount of orders covering almost every department was received during the week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

TOKYO, Sunday, March 4. -- With Premier Makoto Saito acting as Education Minister, all risks of an early Cabinet crisis are over. The emergency Cabinet hurriedly installed in May, 1931, when Japan's constitutional system was rocking under the attacks of Fascist-minded nationalists, has lasted nearly two years and seems capable of lasting indefinitely.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1. -- There was a time during prohibition when the speakeasy proprietor felt relatively secure from annoyance by the policeman on the beat. Then repeal brought with it, at least in Philadelphia, the speakeasy under the more respectable guise of the "club."

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28. -- Looking backward through the mists of a foggy year, the Pacific Coast is counting its toes to make sure they are all intact, licking a few sore spots, rearranging its stock of hopes and fears and doing a bit of shadow boxing with the big, bad wolf.

TO Sir Napier Shaw, a former Director of the British Meteorological Office and one of the leaders of our time in meteorology, God is not only the mathematician of Jeans but an accomplished dramatic artist, and the weather therefore "a sequence of events in the sky * * * quite as interesting for students of nature as some which achieve popularity on a smaller stage."

GOVERNMENTAL undertakings without precedent in the history of American agriculture marked the shaping and development of the agrarian policy of the Roosevelt administration during the past twelve months.

THE sixth annual Palm Beach Flower Show differed from its predecessors in one important respect. While quite as beautiful as any of the former shows, a large number of the exhibits were, according to many competent observers, such as to have a definite influence on planting, not only in Florida but throughout much of the South.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 3. -- In an all-Harvard final, E.R. Sargent won the intercollegiate squash racquets championship today, defeating his teammate, Germaine Glidden, 15 -- 12, 9 -- 15, 17 -- 14, 9 -- 15, 15 -- 0.
ITHACA, March 3. -- Cornell defeated Princeton, 36 to 27, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game tonight. The victory gave Cornell undisputed possession of second place.

LONDON, says the cable, is also having her postponements, or at least one of them. Mr. Cochran's "Magnolia Street," which was supposed to open last week, didn't. They'll try it again in a couple of days, probably. Colin Keith-Johnston and Beatrix Thomson are in the cast.

ROME, March 3 (AP). -- Seven Italians, including Professor Gaetano Salvemini, who has lived in the United States in recent years, were bound over today for trial on charges connected with the explosion of a bomb in St. Peter's Cathedral last June 25.
PARIS, Feb. 23. -- An ingenious effort to restore the confidence of the French people in the destinies of the nation is seen in a three-minute propaganda film that has been showing in French cinemas.

THROUGHOUT the past year increasing emphasis has been placed by the Departments of the Interior and of Labor on the development of social welfare activities, both through existing agencies and through the creation of new ones.
FORT SMITH, Ark., March 3 (AP). -- Ford Bradshaw, wild-shooting smart aleck who fancied himself the outlaw king of the Cookson Hills, died early today at the back door of a little Oklahoma roadhouse.

A "consumer referendum" on the proposed 2 per cent State retail sales tax will be held this week under the sponsorship of merchants of the State in an effort to gather ammunition to be used at the next hearing on the tax proposal, to be held in Albany March 13.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 3. -- Radio owners soon may be relieved of the annoyance caused by the interference of one station with another through the development of a new research apparatus, announcement of which was made today by Dr. Paul L. Hoover, Associate Professor of Engineering at Rutgers University.

The all-pervading war-debt propaganda as seen by America today means simply that the European nations involved have combined in their own interest and to the detriment of the American taxpayers to bring about a cancellation of the public debts justly due the American Government.

A settlement in behalf of the twenty-third of forty directors of the Bank of United States sued by the State Banking Department for $60,000,000 on the ground that they approved illegal and improvident loans, was approved yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente.

A Watch-Tower article from Escanaba, Mich., in THE TIMES of Feb. 11, headed "Michigan Railways Fight Seaway," repeats the charge that the Michigan Railroad Employes and Citizens League is financed mainly by the State's railroads, and asserts that it is acting as their lobby.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3. -- Columbia and Pennsylvania divided honors in the Intercollegiate Swimming Association meet at Hutchinson pool today, the Red and Blue winning the swimming meet, 44 -- 27, but losing to the smooth-working Blue and White water polo team, which is still undefeated in the Eastern intercollegiate ranks, 29 -- 14.

The Einstein Institute of Physics at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem will be dedicated on Tuesday by its donor, Mrs. Dora Monness Shapiro according to word received here by Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach, president of the American Friends of the Hebrew University.
MOSCOW, March 3. -- Soviet medicine has borrowed and developed scientifically a remedy that had been used in Tibet, China, for thousands of years-namely, the antlers of spotted Siberian reindeer.
A good deal of criticism has been directed against the commercially sponsored broadcasts of the Metropolitan Opera Company performances.

FREDERICK WAUGH'S exhibition of marines, at the Fifth Avenue branch of the Grand Central Galleries, is a reminder that marine paintings very seldom are shown in numbers here. In comparison with figure and landscape subjects, they occupy a negligible space in the exhibition field.

For months now the eyes of the world have been centred upon Austria. After months of civil strife no stability has yet been achieved. The political fate of the republic appears as uncertain as it was a year ago when the rise of Hitler implied the immediate Anschluss of Austria and her political and economic union with Germany.

Radical changes in the city's methods of sewage disposal and incineration were promised yesterday by Walter D. Binger after he had been appointed a deputy commissioner in the Sanitation Department by Mayor LaGuardia.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., March 3. -- About 100 boats of the Provincetown fishing fleet, valued at $100,000, and $500,000 worth of waterfront property faced destruction tonight as the ice menace at the tip of Cape Cod reached the most serious proportions of the Winter.
Hunter College clubs announced yesterday the election of 152 student officers for the Spring term.

A young American pianist, Leonard Shure, played the Brahms First Piano Concerto with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, when that remarkable body of instrumentalists gave its second concert of the week yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

Alice Duer Miller writes with the gracious air and charming manner of a graduate of her own "Charm School." Her latest book, a collection of short stories, is typically light, polite and amusing. The title story is the longest, an airy novelette about an engaging young English lord.

These poems by a young woman who has just passed her twenty- third birthday gain an especial interest from the fact that Audrey Wurdemann was a protegee of George Sterling. As it is stated that the poems all were written in the past six years, and as Sterling died (by his own hand) in 1926, none came under his eye.

ON March 4 last year industry, commerce and labor were deep in a morass of competitive price and wage cutting that, combined with the plight of agriculture and finance, threatened to engulf the nation's economic system.

CHICACO, March 2. THE condition of the Second City as a scene of play-going activity is something to groan over and pass by with averted head. For months it has been a disheartening spectacle. Almost total ruin and decay is the prospect that greets the eye.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 3 (AP). -- For the second time in recent months John Ringling, the circus owner, today filed suit for divorce against his second wife, formerly Mrs. Emily Haag Buck, whom he married in 1930. The first suit, filed about eight months ago, was dismissed at Mr. Ringling's request.

IT speaks well for Hollywood that they have succeeded in transferring to the screen the play, "Death Takes a Holiday," in a thoroughly dignified fashion and without changing the title. To say that it is one of the most engrossing pictures of any year is but giving this film its due, for it has been directed with the necessary imaginative touch by Mitchell Leisen, who did so well with the pictorial version of "Cradle Song."

The regulations governing the issuance of liquor licenses effective April 1 will be issued soon by the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, according to announcement yesterday by Chairman Edward P. Mulrooney.

Domestic corporation issues continued yesterday to lead the recovery in the listed bond market. In the two-hour trading on the Stock Exchange important corporation issues moved up, gaining from fractions to more than 3 points. Foreign loans continued higher.
