Because of the competition of the new city subways the receivers for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, with the consent of the Transit Commission, have made substantial reductions in service on all the company's elevated lines. The commission has also approved, for the same reason, some cuts in the Interborough subway service.

ALBANY, March 4. -- Chafing at the delay caused by the deadlock of the LaGuardia economy bill, legislators returning to the capital tonight planned to devote more attention this week to other problems confronting the lawmakers.

Passage by the Legislature of a bill to enable the Board of Estimate to readjust the budget and enable the city to meet all its financial obligations was advocated yesterday by the Recovery party Democrats of Brooklyn, who met at the Towers Hotel to celebrate the first anniversary of the inauguration of President Roosevelt.

GENEVA, March 4. -- The League of Nations officials are struck especially by two points in the League commission's Chaco peace proposal. One is that the preamble flatly describes the situation existing between Bolivia and Paraguay as a "state of war."

President Roosevelt's new book will have a first printing in excess of the total sale of his book of last year, "Looking Forward," which sold 30,000 copies, the John Day Company announces. The President is more popular now than he was last April the publishers say.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1934, as well as last prices for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

In the study of the Municipal Court of this town by the Commission on the Administration of Justice the tone in regard to the labors of its sixty-three justices must be deplored by every sympathetic heart. They are so overworked that there has been insistent pressure for the appointment of four more in the Bronx, which has fewer in proportion to the population than Manhattan.

The supreme right of the church to be dogmatic was asserted yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. W.H. Rogers, newly elected pastor of the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street, in his sermon, "The Ministry in New York."
Two of the companies that were major units in Drug, Inc., issued yesterday their annual reports for 1933 as independent concerns. They are Sterling Products, Inc., and Vick Chemical, Inc.

" The one crushing blow which we can lay on the shoulders of our present administration is the burden of a country at war with itself," declared the Rev. Stephen F. Bayne Jr., of Scarsdale, N.Y., in his sermon yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street.

Mrs. Eva Pabst, 50 years old, and her daughter, Anna, 20, came to the Morrisania police station late yesterday afternoon to tell the detectives why William Pabst, 18, had fractured his father's skull with a hatchet in their home, at 691 Wales Avenue, the Bronx.

Philip Barry's first motion picture work will be an adaptation of Elinor Macartney Lane's novel, "Nancy Stair," which Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will produce with Norma Shearer in the leading role. Mr. Barry will leave soon for the Coast.

Harry Diamant, an American citizen who was released recently from a prison near Breslau, Germany, after having been sentenced last Aug. 22 to two years for having "spread derogatory remarks" about the Hitler government, arrived here yesterday.

Failure of the Connecticut Legislature to give to the State Board of Fisheries and Game the power to alter seasons has brought about an acute problem, according to a statement made yesterday by Arthur L. Clark, superintendent of the department.

The tale of ancient "rackets" practiced on the Mexican Indians 400 years ago by Martin Cortez, son of the conqueror of Mexico, is told in a reproduction of a series of Mexican manuscripts, published recently by the Mexican Government and just acquired by the American Museum of Natural History.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- An important decision strengthening Section 7 (a) of the National Industrial Recovery Act and clarifying the long-standing dispute concerning majority and minority representation has just been made by Nathan R. Margold, chairman of the Petroleum Administrative Board.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 4. -- If early conditioning has any direct bearing whatever upon a pennant campaign -- and such eminent baseball tacticians as the late John McGraw always insisted that it did -- the Giants can he counted upon almost for a certainty to get away to another strong start this year.
Futures prices moved irregularly higher last week on local commodity exchanges. There was a marked decrease in the volumes of trading on most Exchanges. Cash prices were mixed.

Mrs. Julia Barton, 36 years old, and her daughter, Gladys, 9, of 54 Van Nostrand Avenue, Jersey City, were killed instantly last night in Jackson Avenue, Jersey City, when they were crushed beneath a car which had mounted the sidewalk and toppled over after striking a taxicab.

An entertainment is now being arranged for the Easter holidays as a means to aid a project that is of much interest to young people in society here. On the night of March 29 a dance will be given in the grand ballroom of the Pierre for the benefit of the Groton School camp and Brantwood camp of St. Mark's School.

CHICAGO, March 4. -- In four States policemen and other peace officers searched the highways today for John Dillinger, escaped desperado, while detectives here staged wholesale raids in Chicago's underworld seeking a clue to the fugitive's movements.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- As President Roosevelt prepared tonight to address a national meeting here tomorrow of NRA Code authorities with one of the most important pronouncements since the Recovery Act became law, the NRA Consumers Advisory Board submitted a report to General Hugh S. Johnson, the administrator, calling for reforms in policies and methods.

The very spread of nationalism which has bred widespread fear of another world war may lead, on the contrary, toward world peace, according to Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large and representative at the Disarmament Conference.

MIAMI, Fla., March 4. -- The elimination of Gene Sarazen, Johnny Farrell and Tommy Armour and their respective partners featured the first round of the annual international four-ball golf tournament over the Miami Country Club course today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 4. -- Professor Halford E. Luccock of the Yale Divinity School declared today at the Yale public worship in Battell Chapel that the Vinson naval bill appropriating a half-billion dollars for naval construction imperiled world peace.

Guarded by a large detail of police and plainclothes detectives, more than 3,000 Socialists met last night in Carnegie Hall and heard a speech by Max Winter, a former Vice Mayor of Vienna and now a refugee. At the meeting a fund of more than $2,000 was raised to send to Vienna for relief among the distressed Socialists in that city.

CHICAGO, March 4. -- With packers and government buyers in the market for hogs here last week, there was an unsettled feeling and a liberal range in prices. Government buyers preferred hogs weighing around 240 pounds each and prices for these advanced at the close, while quotations for others were draggy and declined 10 to 25 cents a hundred pounds.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- President Roosevelt spent the first anniversary of his inauguration surrounded by his family, old friends and members of his Cabinet. The day was devoted to rest and to consideration of the future legislative program.

Paul De Bruyn of the German-American A.C., Mel Porter, unattached, and William Ruckel of the Millrose A.A. finished in a triple tie for first place in the Bronx Y.M. and Y.W.H.A.'s ten-mile scratch road race around the Crotona Park course yesterday. They were clocked in 57:19.

PARIS, Monday, March 5. -- France's foremost airman, Dieudonne Coste, is missing. The man who returned Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's visit to France by flying with Maurice Bellonte from Paris to New York in September, 1930, has disappeared on a short trip from Paris to Copenhagen.

A demand by investors for apartment houses in Manhattan and the Bronx was shown in transactions reported over the week-end. Several multi-family buildings in the two boroughs were sold, brokers also negotiating leases of many houses.

One of the most important tasks confronting the church today is to "Christianize America," the Rev. Dr. Merle H. Anderson, pastor of the North Presbyterian Church, 527 West 155th Street, said in his sermon yesterday.

More than 3,000 men and women crowded Mecca Temple yesterday afternoon to listen to a debate between Clarence A. Hathaway, editor of The Daily Worker and Lawrence Dennis, editor of The Awakener, American Fascist publication, on the question "whether communism or fascism is preferable in the United States as the new social order to supplant capitalism."

VIENNA, March 4. -- Chancellor Dollfuss addressed 20,000 supporters in Villach in the strongly Nazi Province of Carinthia today. He met with an enthusiastic reception, but thirty Nazis arose one after another and waved swastika banners in his face. Twenty-five arrests were made.
The victory of N.Y.U.'s surprising basketball team over one of the strongest C.C.N.Y. fives in the Lavender's history was the highlight of the week in intercollegiate basketball circles.

The dollar was held within a comparatively narrow range last week, measured by the quotation for the French franc. Business was light, and fluctuations small. However, the undertone was firm. The high was 101.1 cents, the lowest 100.7, and the final, 100.8, a loss of .03 from the preceding week. Range a year ago was 99.28 @ 98.78 cents.

The police of the Clinton Street station were baffled yesterday when an investigation led to the discovery of the death of Reuben Yanofsky, 25 years old, and the serious illness of his brother, Abraham, 33, of 36 Attorney Street. What caused the death of the younger man remained a mystery last night and Abraham, in Gouverneur Hospital, was still unconscious, apparently affected by some poison.

VILLACH, Austria, March 4 (AP). -- Chancellor Dollfuss, speaking here today, declared the new Austrian Constitution would be based on the Pope's encyclical "Quadragesimo Anno" and would be maintained inviolate against any efforts of "those who follow false prophets."

Support for a drive to raise $40,000 for the settling of German Jewish children in Palestine was pledged yesterday by 200 representatives of Jewish organizations with a membership of approximately 250,000. At a conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania called by the Council of Jewish Organizations on Palestine, the delegates heard the lot of Jewish children in Germany described as "intolerable."

The Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. decided against the return to the yardage system of track measurement last night, but only by the narrowest of margins. One vote was all that stood between the retention of the meter and its complete abandonment.

The Royale Theatre in West Forty-fifth Street was filled yesterday afternoon by more than 1,000 subscribers to the Theatre Guild attending a symposium on the Guild's latest play, "They Shall Not Die" and on the Scottsboro case with which the play is concerned.

Lotte Lehmann, distinguished soprano of the Metropolitan and other opera companies, gave her only New York recital yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall before a capacity audience which she immediately roused to a sustained and tumultuous enthusiasm.

The United States should adopt a policy of "orderly international economic cooperation" if it would avoid a dictatorship, preserve its democratic institutions, speed domestic recovery, and forestall another world war growing out of trade rivalries, according to the joint committee on Commercial Policy of the Foreign Policy Association and the World Peace Foundation.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 4. -- Climaxing four days of brilliant golf, the metropolitan team of Richard Ciuci of Flushing, L.I., and Charles Whitehead of South River, N.Y., won the annual Miami Biltmore invitation fourball amateur tournament today.

It takes some courage to run out and tackle a group of big fellows, but the track official who finally pushes those shot-putters and weight-lifters out of the way of the runners will deserve well of his country. Perhaps what is needed is that will separate legally the track from the field athletes.

The Mural Atelier of the Beaux-Arts Institute of Design is holding its annual exhibition at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street, until next Thursday, the hours 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. This exhibition, in which each artist is represented by detail studies, rendered drawings of problem solutions and in some cases photographs of already executed work, illustrates the thoroughness with which this special study is conducted.

Hit by unfavorable weather, retail trade fell off throughout the country last week and as a result reorder volume in the wholesale markets here was reduced. Store stocks are ample to take care of immediate needs. Few items of women's apparel were reordered, exceptions being two-piece swagger suits in monotone tweeds, black dresses with white trim and dress coats which were purchased in fair volume.

MOSCOW, March 4. -- Today, the sixteenth anniversary of the founding of the Communist International, is greeted by the Soviet press -- with the notable exception of the government organ Izvestia -- with a lavish display of photographs and special articles depicting the future triumph of the proletariat.

PARIS, March 4 (r9. -- Friends of Dieudonne Coste, French flier who is believed down on the North Sea, recalled tonight his aversion to flying over water, despite his flight to A/nerica in 1930. Years ago, pilots recalled, he evaded several attemptS of the Air Union to transfer him to the Paris-London line.

The Committee on State Legislation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York made public yesterday an additional report on legislation pending in Albany. Most of the bills reported on were disapproved.

The Merchants Association of New York recommended yesterday the enactment of Federal legislation to authorize free ports and foreign trading zones in the United States as part of President Roosevelt's general plan for the extension of foreign trade.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, March 4 (AP). -- Riskulus, racing for the Northway Stable owned by Norman Church of Los Angeles, won the Agua Caliente Derby today by a nose in a thrilling stretch duel with Bissagos, filly owned by John D. Spreckels 3d. Riskulus and Bissagos led the rest of the field by ten lengths.

MADRID, March 4. -- Premier Alejandro Lerroux declared this evening that "if the Socialist minority persists in its obstructionist tactics in the Cortes we shall invoke the closure rule to silence its filibustering, pass the budget bill and get ahead with necessary reform legislation."
BUENOS AIRES, March 4. -- The text of the League of Nations commission's proposed Chaco peace treaty follows:

The New York Americans are still in the running for a play-off berth in the international group of the National Hockey League. The Simpson sextet registered a much-needed 3-0 triumph over the Ottawa Senators in Madison Square Garden last night, and by so doing crept to within four points of the Canadiens of Montreal, holders of third place in the group.

BASLE, Switzerland, March 4. -- The monthly statement of the Bank for International Settlements, giving its position on Feb. 28, was issued today, showing a 3,551,184 gold-franc rise in its funds to a total of 657,144,774 Swiss gold francs.

More than 1,000 organizations in the country are conducting educational programs for adults which are of "more than local interest," according to the first national survey of adult education in the United States, published today by the American Association for Adult Education.

Modifications in the administration of the retail code and of codes affecting retailers are suggested in resolutions adopted by the Retail Code Authority of New York and forwarded yesterday to the National Retail Code Authority in Washington.

In outlawing exploitation, Russia has struck at the roots of social maladjustment and has created a new philosophy of mental hygiene, according to Dr. Frankwood E. Williams, who spoke last night at a dinner of the American Association of Hospital Social Workers in the Hotel New Yorker. Dr. Williams is a former director of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene.

BUENOS AIRES, March 4 (AP). -- The coalition of conservative parties behind the government of President Augustin P. Justo claimed continued control of the Argentine Congress with a substantial working majority as a result of countrywide elections today to fill eighty-one of the 158 seats in the Chamber of Deputies.
Card parties in behalf of various charitable organizations have been arranged for the near future.

Playing at great speed the Port Colborne Sailors, one of the crack teams of the Senior Ontario Hockey Association, defeated the New York Athletic Club sextet in the feature game of the amateur double-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. The score was 5 to 1.

The only change in the last week's program at yesterday afternoon's Carnegie Hall concert by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra was the performance of the Brahms Double Concerto, with Nathan Milstein, violinist, and Gregor Piatigorsky, 'cellist, as soloists.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Ten new security issues involving $9,500,000, filed with the Federal Trade Commission, were announced today. The projects include timber operation, foundry products, copper mining and chain stores.

PITTSBURGH, March 4. -- Demand for steel has broadened and mills are able to pick out additional lines of consumption whose requirements have reached considerable proportions. In January the only lines named specifically were the automobile industry and fabricated structural steel work, other demand being referred to simply as miscellaneous.

Reminiscence, not only of Wall Street but of every plain citizen, is bound to revert this week to the nation-wide moratorium of a year ago. So notable a financial landmark will doubtless be recalled during many years hereafter, whenever the same week in March recurs -- just as survivors of the Great Blizzard of 1888 still hold anniversary meetings on the 12th of March.

A determined attack on the proposed taxicab code as "equally objectionable and obnoxious to labor and to the public," was begun yesterday by Jacob Panken and Matthew M. Levy, advisers to the Taxicab Drivers Union of Greater New York, which was Organized as a result of the recent strike.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, March 4 (AP). -- With a bullet in the head, the body of Spencer B. Smith, 50 years old, of 78 Clarkson Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y., was found today in a bedroom of a dwelling owned by Mrs. Nora Martin at Friendship Beach, near here. Coroner Ross M. Gault said that preliminary investigation indicated suicide.
The Rev. John Corbett, in his sermon yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier in West Sixteenth Street, warned of a growing danger to Catholic religious education.

JOHN DILLINGER, with a good claim to the honor of being our most eminent desperado, used a dummy wooden pistol to gain access to the prison warden's arsenal. Thence he and a companion made their way to freedom with the aid of a couple of machine guns.
AMARILLO, Texas, March 4. -- Amarillo husbands bought flowers today for their mothers-in-law.
IMPERIAL, Calif., March 4 (AP). -- A "pileup" in a fifty-mile automobile race at the Imperial fair today caused the deaths of a driver and a mechanic and critical injuries to another driver.

Marcel Guimbretiere and Paul Brocardo, winners of New York's fifty-sixth international six-day bicycle race which finished Saturday night in Madison Square Garden, are now on the high seas sailing for home. They left immediately after the race was over on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., March 4. -- R.H. Helsel triumphed in the invitation shoot of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today. He broke 96 targets to lead a field of thirty gunners.

Samuel Untermyer's recent attack on the plan for relief of guaranteed mortgage certificate holders, submitted to Governor Lehman by George W. Alger, Moreland Act Commissioner, and his counsel, Alfred A. Cook, was renewed on Mr. Untermyer's behalf yesterday by his law firm, Guggenheimer Untermyer.

BERLIN, March 4. -- Liberal thought in Germany, reviewing the year since the voters of the Reich confirmed Adolf Hitler as Chancellor and recalling in calmer perspective those months of physical, mental and spiritual violence, feels that the world has not sensed Germany's greatest tragedy -- the loss of free speech and liberal leadership.

Warm temperatures accompanied by rain loosened masses of snow and ice throughout the Eastern Stakes yesterday and sent swirling currents of ice-clogged water down streams and rivers with a threat of serious floods.
WASHINGTON, March 4. -- President Roosevelt has commended the National Labor Board for its work in peacefully solving labor disputes.

ALBANY, March 4. -- With the Senate and Assembly waiting for the appearance of the complex legislation to be recommended by Governor Lehman for the relief of some 500,000 holders of guaranteed mortgage certificates in the State, Senator Desmond of Orange County has entered the scene with a vigorous demand for favorable action on his Mortgage Authority Bill.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 4. -- Having been told that his slogan should be "one surprise a day from now on," Casey Stengel, the Dodgers' new manager, sprang the first one early this afternoon.

Although originally in favor of the appointment of Arthur H. Roberts, an alumnus, as head football coach at N.Y.U., the two most prominent graduate organizations at the university have pledged their wholehearted support to Dr. Marvin A. (Mal) Stevens, the new Violet gridiron mentor, it was learned yesterday.

" Annina," with Maria Jeritza, will open at the Shubert Theatre, Boston, on Saturday night, instead of tonight at the Boston Opera House. The operetta's Philadelphia opening has been postponed from March 12 to March 19, at the Forrest Theatre there.

Upset because of a family quarrel Grace Brown, 17-year-old daughter of George H. Brown, a broker, and a former student at Temple University, plunged fifteen stories to her death last night, landing in the courtyard of the apartment house at 33 Riverside Drive.

Broadening his campaign against the slot machine racket by an educational drive, Mayor Fiorello H. LaGuardia is sponsoring an exhibition of the devices in the concourse of the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center, it became known last night.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP). -- Called to consider the proposal that a system of intermediate credit be established to supply credit for capital goods industries, the governors of the twelve Federal Reserve districts will meet here tomorrow with Treasury Department officials.

NOME, Alaska, March 4 (AP). -- Prompt action to rescue the 101 shipwrecked refugees on the shifting icepack between Siberia and Wrangall Island was urged today by Alaskans, mindful of the region's reputation as the "death trap of the Arctic."

ALBANY, March 4. -- With the State's personal income tax payable on April 15, the Legislature so far has failed to take any action on Governor Lehman's recommendation that the personal exemptions applicable in computing the amount of "regular" tax be allowed also in computing the 1 per cent emergency tax on "gross" incomes.
ALBANY, March 4. -- The fight to scrap Governor Lehman's $81,000,000 tax reduction program and substitute a 2 per cent sales tax rapidly crystalized here today.

NEW ORLEANS, La., March 4. -- The volume of trading in the cotton contract market here fell off materially last week, owing mainly to the general disposition of operators to await the action of Congress on the Bankhead Bill, the silver problem and the bill to regulate stock trading.
YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, March 4. -- America's New Deal is linked directly with President Roosevelt's physical disabilities by Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

NEW ORLEANS, March 4 (AP). -- Bourbon Prince, owned by Mrs. F.P. Letellier of New Orleans and trained by her husband, today won the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Inauguration Anniversary Purse at the Fair Grounds. Bob Weidel finished second, a nose behind the winner, with Just Imagine' third.

Glowing praise for the Roosevelt administration on its first anniversary and condemnation for the Hitler regime in Germany, whose first year ends today, were the dual topics of the sermon preached yesterday by Rabbi Stephen S. Wise to the Free Synagogue congregation at Carnegie Hall.

SELL 'em all; they're not worth anything," said Bernard E. Smith, the Wall Street bear, when the Coolidge market was about to collapse. If Davy Crockett, the coonskin Congressman from the cane-brakes of Western Tennessee, had been privileged to hear Mr. Smith, he would have removed his fur cap, scratched his head, and said: "Can this be my America?"

On the first anniversary of the day when he was sworn in as Secretary of the Treasury in President Roosevelt's Cabinet, William H. Woodin returned to his home here yesterday from the sanatorium in Tucson, Ariz., where he has been undergoing treatment for a throat ailment.

A colonial officer home in Paris on leave from the French Congo was talking with a lady about prices of food. How much did she pay now for a pound of beef? "I don't know exactly. You "will have to ask the cook. But I "know it's dear -- horribly dear." A little comparison led to the conclusion that the price was about twice what it was before the war.

LONDON, March 4. -- Hundreds of policemen standing shoulder to shoulder prevented disorder in Trafalgar Square today when a noisy crowd of 10,000 assembled for the last of the hunger marchers' demonstrations.

PARIS, March 4 (AP). -- France's desire for dominance of the air caused a hitch today in government ratification of the recent accord between the principal air lines of France and Germany for cooperation in South Atlantic air-mail service.
LONDON, March 4. -- A new picture of Russia's "Mad Monk" Rasputin is drawn by Alexander Kerensky in his book. "The Crucifixion of Liberty," to be published here tomorrow.

BERLIN, March 4. -- President Roosevelt's first year in office is reviewed with sympathy in the German press, and it is conceded that he has succeeded as no other President in giving American policies the impress of his personality.
LONDON, March 4. -- A new picture of Russia's "Mad Monk" Rasputin is drawn by Alexander Kerensky in his book. "The Crucifixion of Liberty," to be published here tomorrow.

BERLIN, March 4. -- President Roosevelt's first year in office is reviewed with sympathy in the German press, and it is conceded that he has succeeded as no other President in giving American policies the impress of his personality.

Sixteen teams of four officially opened the 1934 Eastern championships at contract bridge yesterday in the Hotel Commodore. The tournament will last six days. Forty pairs of novices, none of whom has finished first or second in a national tournament, also played in another event for the Liberman Trophy.

The Convent of the Sacred Heart of Mary at Tarrytown, N.Y., gets a bequest of $100,000 and the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum, the offices of which are at 24 East Fifty-second Street, $10,000, under the will of James Butler. The testament of the founder of the first American chain of grocery stores and prominent owner of race horses, was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 6. -- The prospects for a successful issue of the Chinese Eastern Railway sale negotiations between Russia and Manchukuo are improved as a result of Foreign Minister Hirota's decision to take a more active part.

ALBANY, March 5 (AP). -- The Legislature tonight asked the State Milk Control Board to report immediately on its work during the last ten months and to state whether in its opinion the emergency warrants the continuation of the board for another year.

The army of CWA workers employed in the Park Department will work under flood lights so that about 1,000 projects in as many areas may be completed on or before May 1, it was announced yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 5. -Franklin Millman, 33 years old, chief of the Newark bureau of The Associated Press, died this morning in the Elizabeth General Hospital of internal injuries suffered when an automobile he was driving was in collision with a motor truck on State Highway Route 25 at North Avenue, this city.

Your correspondent George E. Larrabee, in his attack on NRA, first complains of Donald Richberg's lack of "detached position," and then promptly shows his own lack of detachment by sailing into NRA hammer and tongs.

One mild spell in early March does not usher in Spring, especially when snow holds the fort in the back country. Winter still has two weeks and more to go. The bulletin of the new Health Commissioner, Dr. JOHN L. RICE, issued on Saturday on the subject of taking care of one's self while Winter lingers is therefore worthy of consideration by old and young.

New Jersey authorities, in their effort to wipe out gambling and to discourage an influx of gamblers into the State from New York City, where a similar campaign is under way, made an elaborate gesture yesterday by arresting eighty-four men as they tried to enter Jersey City via the Holland Tunnel.

Hans Kampfer of Germany, hailed as a new heavyweight wrestling sensation, last night threw Ed (Strangler) Lewis, former holder of the world's title, before 3,000 persons at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory. The time was 17:14.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 5.-A large and brilliant event of midseason was the dinner and dance with which Wolcott Blair, Charles A. Munn, Herbert Pulitzer, Milton W. Holden and Richard B. W. Hall entertained tonight in honor of Miss Nancy Yuille and Viscount Adare, whose marriage will be quietly held Wednesday afternoon at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Blair.

Raymond Miller, unattached, out-pointed George Brothers, Salem Crescent star, in the 175-pound special bout which featured the semi-monthly amateur boxing program at the New York A.C. last night. A crowd of more than 800 was present.

The American Tobacco Company reports for 1933 a consolidated net income of $17,401,207, after all charges, reserves, and taxes, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $3 a share on the 4,743,831 combined common and Class B shares.

MIAMI, Fla., March 5. -- On the strength of their brilliant play in the second round of the international four-ball golf tournament today, during which they set a new record for the tourney in the morning session, Paul Runyan of White Plains, N.Y., and Horton Smith of Oak Park, Ill., are favored to retain their laurels.

PARIS, March 5. -- Albert Prince, the magistrate whose murder at Dijon has been linked with the Serge Stavisky pawnshop scandal, was drugged before his death, according to a new medical report issued today. A previous examination had brought a negative result, but longer and more minute tests by a different method are said to have brought distinct evidence of organic poison.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP). -- A Democratic challenge to Republicans to propose a recovery program of their own was met in the Senate today with the assertion that President Roosevelt's relief measures were only temporary and at the expense of permanent recovery.
ALBANY, March 5. -- The decision of the Supreme Court upholding the New York Milk Control Law was hailed today by Charles H. Baldwin, Agricultural Commissioner and chairman of the Milk Control Board.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- While the Senate Banking and Currency Committee was studying today a list of all trading in aviation stocks short and long, for the two weeks preceding cancellation of air-mail contracts, Senator Robinson, Democratic leader of the Senate, expressed doubt that Congress at its present session would authorize Federal regulation of security exchanges.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.
ALBANY, March 5. -- Governor Lehman came out strongly tonight against efforts of the Republicans to impose a 2 per cent sales tax.

The New York Churchmen's Association and the Long Island Clerical League, meeting yesterday in joint session, commended the Mayor for his economy bill. The session, bringing together Protestant Episcopal clergymen, was held at the Fraternity Clubs Building, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street.

Social insurance, including unemployment insurance, with better provision for the care of the chronic sick and for the rehabilitation of the handicapped, was advocated yesterday at the closing session of the Eastern coast regional conference of the American Association of Hospital Social Workers in the Hotel New Yorker.

The Monte Carlo Ballet Russe will open a return engagement at the St. James Theatre on Friday evening with three ballets new to its repertoire here. They are "The Three-Cornered Hat," with music by De Falla and settings and costumes by Picasso; "The Sailors," with music by Auric and settings by Pruna; and "Swan Lake," with music by Tchaikovsky and settings by Prince A. Schervachidze.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 5. -Brooklyn's batterymen learned something about a workout today from their new manager, Casey Stengel, and tonight sore muscles were as prevalent on the squad as oranges are in this State.

ABOARD THE HAVANA SPECIAL EN ROUTE WITH MRS. ROOSEVELT, March 5 (AP). -- While sentimental melodies were played in a jolly, crowded lounge car, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt knitted away today, thoroughly enjoying a relaxing interval between Washington's problems and those of Puerto Rico.
BERLIN, March 5. -- A sweeping order for the removal of all non-Aryans from the German stage was issued by Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda, today.

TRENTON, March 5. -- Newark Representatives in the New Jersey Assembly were successful tonight in blocking passage of legislation which would permit construction of a huge freight terminal at Thirty-fifth Street, Bayonne, which they contend would injure severely an investment of $22,000,000 at the Port of Newark.
Mail orders picked up sharply here yesterday, with leading resident buying offices reporting the volume of new business as much heavier than a week ago.

Signs of Spring have brought renewed hopes to those who have had the responsibility of game in the Eastern States in their hands. Yet none of the officials or volunteers is willing to say that the crisis is past. Hazards still remain and it will require weeks to right things.

A committee of large holders of and dealers in railroad securities has been formed to press for higher freight rates or other means of improving the earnings of the railroads. One member of the committee is said to be prepared to argue that if its suggestions are not carried out, the alternative will be government ownership of the carriers.

Trading in United States Government bonds in the over-the-counter market, where most of such dealing is done, is now on a larger scale than in the war-time markets, according to a statement made yesterday by C.J. Devine, president of C.J. Devine Co., Inc., a firm specializing in United States Government securities.

WE have never felt particularly drawn to historical romance. From Winston Churchill's "Richard Carvel" down to the last novel of Stanley Weyman's "The Lively Peggy" (which seemed a genuine anachronism when it came out a few years ago), a consciousness of wooden characters, moronic psychology and general historical imposture always spoiled our pleasure in whatever exciting action might be going on in these books.
LONDON, March 5. -- Damages of 25,000 and costs were awarded to Princess Youssoupoff today in her libel suit against the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Pictures, Ltd., for the film, "Rasputin, the Mad Monk."

A warning that "warring class interests" may drive the United States to "genuinely uncontrolled inflation" unless the nation chooses a definite course and sticks to it was sounded here yesterday by Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, in a symposium on national destiny at the Bar Association.

Detective Irving Frey of the East Fifty-first Street station, who, with two other detectives, is being tried in General Sessions on a charge they conspired to obstruct the operation of the State liquor law through the alleged "shaking down" of restaurant owners for licenses, testified in his own defense yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- A report criticizing War Department practices, including the purchase of airplanes, was made to the House with the Appropriation Bill.

Two months ago, in a budget message bristling with enormous figures, President ROOSEVELT forecast a Federal deficit on June 30 of more than $7,000,000,000 and an increase of the national debt during the first half of 1934 from a little less than $24,000,000,000 to about $30,000,000,000.

MONTREAL, March 5 (Canadian Press). -- Any doubt as to who would lead the National Hockey League scorers this season practically vanished during the week-end, when Charley Conacher scored three goals and an assist, and increased his leadership over the field to a clear nine points.

A contention that Paul Moss, Commissioner of Licenses, has no legal right to prevent owners of newsstands from selling nearly sixty magazines which he asserts are indecent, and that the courts have ruled against the attempted exercise of such authority in the past was made before Supreme Court Justice Cohn yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 5. -- Sentence of death in the electric chair for Dr. Alice Lindsay Wynekoop was demanded today by the State in the trial of the 63-year-old physician for the murder of her daughter-in-law, Rheta Gardner Wynekoop.

A brilliant opening attack paved the path for a Dartmouth basketball victory over Columbia last night by a 24-22 score in the Lions' gymnasium. The Green five, with the veteran Jake Edwards starring, led at the intermission and apparently was headed for an easy victory.

Unless the Legislature enacts a city economy bill soon, making possible a balanced budget and qualifying the city to receive the pending. Federal loan of $23,160,000 for subway construction, about 786 employes of the Board of Transportation will be dropped from the payroll, Mayor LaGuardia declared yesterday.

James C. Sheridan, newly designated Democratic county leader of Queens, moved into Democratic headquarters yesterday in the Crescent Plaza Building, Long Island City. John Theofel, chairman of the Democratic Executive Committee and county leader until last Saturday, did not appear at headquarters. Although deposed as county leader, Mr. Theofel retains his executive chairmanship.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- President Roosevelt today told a large audience of business and industrial leaders that the recovery program as represented by the NRA and other government agencies was here to stay; that the reorganization of a "disintegrating system of production and exchange" undertaken last Spring must be "permanent for all the rest of our lives."

Mayor LaGuardia disclosed last night an eight-point program he had prepared to combat the threat of a wholesale abandonment of tenement houses, which was made on Sunday by Joseph Goldsmith, president of the Council of Real Estate Associations.

Unless their demands for the recognition of their union, a closed shop and increased wages are met by their employers within the next two days, more than 1,000 dental technicians, members of New York Dental Technicians Equity, will go out on strike Thursday, officials of the organization declared last night at a special meeting at the Irving Plaza, Fifteenth Street and Irving Place.

Wall Street paid close attention yesterday to President Roosevelt's address before members of the industrial code authorities in Washington, but the markets were unable to shake off their lethargy. Business was at low ebb on all the security and commodity exchanges, with prices showing a sluggish disposition to drift toward lower levels.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -Opposition to the reciprocal tariff bill has become so strong that Senator Robinson today conceded that it would be necessary to confine the President's authority to negotiating and promulgating tariff treaties specifically to three years.

Work was started officially yesterday on the third section of the superstructure of the West Side Express Highway from Thirty-eighth to Forty-sixth Street, Samuel Levy, Borough President, announced. Under the contract the section must be completed within six months.

President Roosevelt's request for authority to negotiate reciprocal tariff treaties spurred foreign trade and protectionist organizations into action here yesterday. For the first time in the history of legislative tariff battles exporters here were prepared yesterday to join the import interests to block the American Tariff League's fight against the President's proposal.

George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, must show cause on Thursday before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler why he should not turn over bonds, mortgages, certificates, moneys and records to the three trustees appointed by the court for the $27,892,000 F-1 series of guaranteed mortgage certificates issued by the New York Title and Mortgage Company.

H.W. Warley, vice president of the Calmar Steamship Line, asked the Shipping Board yesterday to rule on the rights of intercoastal lines to charter their ships for the transportation of bulk cargoes between Atlantic and Pacific Coast ports.

Confirmation of the prevailing belief in Wall Street that the Van Sweringen brothers of Cleveland and their associates were in default on $40,000,000 of bank loans against which they had pledged working control of their $2,000,000,000 railroad system was given yesterday in a sworn statement to be filed with the Federal Trade Commission by a protective committee for bonds of the St. Louis, Iron Mountain Southern Railway, one of the Van Sweringen units.

Magistrate Thomas F. Casey reserved decision yesterday, in Gates Avenue Court, Brooklyn, in the case of Christian Klossett, charged with bookmaking, following a "raid" by Mayor LaGuardia on Klossett's home at 807 Quincy Street, Brooklyn.

The mystery of the Bronx Zoo's stolen snakes was solved yesterday. Eight of the sinuous creatures which vanished from their cases in the reptile house on Washington's Birthday were recovered, the ninth was dead, and two young herpetologists, according to the police, ruefully had confessed the robbery.

President ROOSEVELT reaffirmed yesterday his faith in the NRA and restated the principles which he believes should guide it. Since the basic purpose is "to "increase the purchasing power of the "public," he urges that employers do all they can to raise wages and to add to their employes.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- In an opinion which is regarded as of great significance in relation to the emergency powers of the New Deal, the Supreme Court by a 5-to-4 decision upheld today New York State's right to fix milk prices.
WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Following is the text of the majority opinion in the New York Milk Law case.

The city's slot-machine racket is "through" and the "numbers game" or policy racket is "pretty well smashed up," Police Commissioner O'Ryan declared last night at the opening of an educational slot-machine exhibit in the concourse of the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center.

VIENNA, March 5. -- It was learned today that the primary obstacle to the return of the Hapsburgs to Austria -- the decree of 1919 which forbids their return unless they swear loyalty to the republic and renounce their claim to rule -- is likely to be removed soon by the cancellation of two paragraphs of the decree.
Futures prices moved irregularly lower yesterday in reduced trading on local commodity exchanges. For the most part, movements were listless and within a small range. Cash prices were irregular.

The appointment of Dr. Marvin A. (Mal) Stevens as head football coach at N.Y.U. has brought forth conflicting opinions by the various university student publications. They are unable to agree on the significance which should be attached to the naming of Stevens.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, campares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Exports and imports into the United States by classifications during January, as given out by the Department of Commerce, compare as follows with the corresponding period of 1933 and 1932. Exports as given in the subjoined tables cover only domestic exports.

The third meeting this season of the Lenten sewing class which works in behalf of the New York Nursery and Child's Hospital will beheld this morning at the home of Mrs. Frank S. Witherbee, 1,148 Fifth Avenue, the treasurer of the class.

More than 5,000 drivers and inside workers employed in wholesale cleaning and dyeing plants returned to work yesterday with the reopening of seventy-seven of these plants controlled by the Cleaners and Dyers Board of Trade, in accordance with the truce reached in the recent stoppage in the cleaning and dyeing industry.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The House voted today, by 77 to 18, to suspend the rules and passed the Dies bill authorizing deportation of alien seamen illegally in the United States. It now goes to the Senate.

ALBANY, March 5. -- The Democratic leaders of the Legislature arrived here tonight, expecting that Mayor LaGuardia's Emergency Economy Bill, which has been pending since early in the session, would be disposed of, at least in the Assembly, before the end of the week.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- In line with President Roosevelt's plea, a 10 per cent slash in hours of labor and a corresponding increase in pay for industries under NRA was outlined tonight by Hugh S. Johnson at meetings called to discuss methods of reinvigorating the recovery unit.

Sponsored, as it were, by quotations in, respectively, the original Greek and the original Latin, from Plato and St. Thomas Aquinas, the exhibition of twentieth century Machine Art will open with a private showing today at the Museum of Modern Art and to the public tomorrow.

BERLIN, March 5. -- As the 40-year-old Bishop Theodore Heckel assumed his duties today as head of the newly created "office for foreign affairs" of the German Evangelical Church, other important changes were announced in the Nazi hierarchy.

ST PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5. -- A harbinger of another baseball campaign, the crack of bat meeting ball, was in evidence at Huggins Field today as the Yankee batterymen opened their training for 1934, directed by Manager Joe McCarthy.

The first robin of the year was not observed in Times Square yesterday. The first crocus was still coyly hiding beneath the splashy turf in Central Park. But the season's first hurdy-gurdy was reported in West Seventy-second Street, and a Bock Beer sign was observed to have flowered overnight in West Forty-third, like another Miracle of the Roses.
HAVANA, March 5. -- Four officials of the Machado regime were sentenced today to die for acts charged to them when they were in power.

CHICAGO, March 5. -- Hogs were in narrow demand today, and while offerings were not large, much of the trading was at prices 10 to 20 cents a hundred pounds less than on Friday, except in packing sows, which were steady. The spread between light and heavy kinds was the widest since early in February.

The third of the series of Beethoven sonata recitals for violin and piano which Ossip Gabrilowitsch and Albert Spalding have been giving at the Town Hall took place last night before a warmly approving audience that filled the auditorium. The program comprised the Op. 12, No. 1, in D major, Op. 24 in F major, and the A major, Op. 47, known as the "Kreutzer."

Popular taste in art is good taste, and the people, if left free to chose between good art and bad, will prefer the good, according to Walter M. Grant, executive secretary of the American Art Dealers Association. Mr. Grant will open an exhibition today in his gallery at 9 East Fifty-seventh Street, to illustrate popular taste.

MIAMI, Fla., March 5. -- Earl Porter, leading rider at the Tropical Park meeting, scored with four mounts today at Hialeah Park. One of his winners was Mrs. J.M. Whitney's Crowning Glory, which took the featured Lake Jackson Purse.

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 5. -Paul Shields's Gull, representative of the Peconic-Gardiner's Bay fleet, won the final race of the Johnnie Walker Cup series today. It was the second triumph of the competition for Shields's yacht.

It is well to view the problem of reducing the fire hazard in "old-law" tenements practically, as the Welfare Council tries to do in the latest statement from its Housing Section. These abominations have been with us a long time. There were 82,000 of them in 1901; there are still 67,000 of them today.

Edward Corsi, former United States Commissioner of Immigration at Ellis Island, was appointed yesterday by Public Welfare Cormmissioner, William Hodson to succeed Miss Mary L. Gibbons as director of the department's Home Relief Bureau. He will take office March 15.

HAVANA, March 5. -- The government today made preparations to tighten its military control throughout the island as additional unions joined the strike movement and labor leaders struggled to bring about a general walkout.
Trading on the Cotton Exchange fell off materially yesterday and after unusually narrow fluctuations prices ended with changes ranging from a loss of 1 point to a gain of 4 points on the day.

Ninety persons, including players and coaches, attended the second annual dinner of the Eastern Private Schools Basketball League last night at the Hotel Astor. The members represented were Blair Academy, Poly Prep, Horace Mann, Princeton Prep, Irving School and Trinity School.

The Seward Park basketball team captured the Manhattan division championship of the P.S. A.L. by defeating Textile, its closest rival, by a 29-to-22 margin in the Textile gymnasium yesterday. The victory, which was its seventh in eight starts, marked the close of Seward's regular league campaign.

The field of sixty-four teams in the first annual invitation mixed doubles tournament of the Island Tennis Club was narrowed to thirty-three last night when play ended on the club courts at Queens Boulevard and Forty-fifth Street, Long Island City.

Opposition of thirty State and national organizations to the proposed 2 per cent State sales tax was announced here yesterday through the Sales Tax Committee of 1,000, of which Grover A. Whalen is chairman. The organizations will be represented at Albany next Tuesday at a hearing on the Fearon-Wadsworth 2 per cent sales tax bill.

MADRID, March 5. -- President Alcala Zamora presided today over the first meeting of the third Cabinet formed by Alejandro Lerroux under the Republic. Tomorrow the new government will be presented to the Spanish Cortes.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 5. -The forces of Pliny W. Williamson, chairman of the equalization committee of the Westchester Board of Supervisors and champion of "scientific" tables for the apportionment of State and county taxes, were victorious today in preventing the upset of the equalization table which was passed last week by a narrow majority.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The Civil Works program, the expedient used by the administration to carry 4,000,000 unemployed through the Winter is expected to end March 30, a full month ahead of the scheduled closing announced last week by President Roosevelt.

A new issue of $1,200,000 Ramsey County (Minn.) public welfare bonds was awarded yesterday to a syndicate comprising Blyth Co., Inc., Kelley, Richardson Co., and Roosevelt Weigold, Inc. The group topped a field of six other bidders, naming a price of 100.61 for the bonds to bear interest at 4 per cent.

Posing as a glazier, a detective gained access yesterday to an apartment in 1,944 Andrews Avenue, the Bronx, where newly imported drugs were being cut for the wholesale trade and seized two trunks which contained, the police charged, heroin and cocaine valued at $50,000.

St. Augustine's High, Brooklyn Prep and St. Cecilia's of Englewood, N.J., triumphed in second-round games of the Metropolitan Catholic High Schools basketball tournament at Columbus Council, Brooklyn, last night.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- A charge that the munitions manufacturers of the world, particularly those of America, were spreading propaganda in the Orient concerning a possible war between the United States and Japan, to spur the sale of more armament to the latter was made in the Senate today by Senator Borah.

Edward McLoughlin, foreman for the T. A. O'Rourke Plastering Company, owned by his uncles, was found guilty of extortion by a jury in General Sessions this morning. The jury gave its verdict at 12:45 A.M. after deliberating for nine and one-half hours.
Police Commissioner John F. O'Ryan joined police radio cars in responding to an alarm early this morning and met a former soldier associate who had barely escaped from two hold-up men.

PARIS, March 5. -- Amid the turmoil of French affairs, with their unsolved mysteries and uninvestigated scandals, what is happening outside of this country has been getting scant attention recently in the Paris press. The Temps, however, tonight devotes its principal column to President Roosevelt and his experiments on the occasion of the first anniversary of the President's accession to power.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP). -The Supreme Court today refused to pass on the validity of a Federal order -- which never went into effect -- suspending the Chicago Board of Trade as a contract market for sixty days in 1932.
ALBANY, March 5 (AP). -- Counsel for Manney Strewl pried today into the private and political life of Daniel P. O'Connell, up-State politician, whose nephew Strewl is charged with kidnapping.
Philip Hale, music critic emeritus of The Boston Herald, celebrated his eightieth birthday yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP). -Only a few hours after President Roosevelt today told industrial leaders his hopes for NRA, Everett Sanders, chairman of the Republican National Committee, called the recovery administration a "dictatorship" and a "blind experiment."

Inspection of the official party enrollment lists for the city election last Fall showed yesterday that Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3d, wife of the eldest son of John D. Rockefeller Jr., was recorded as a member of the Socialist party.
The old Hippodrome played to a packed house last night as a crowd of 6,500 witnessed The Daily News Golden Gloves amateur boxing bouts.

Strictly speaking, all that the Supreme Court of the United States decided yesterday was that a law enacted by the New York Legislature was valid, and that the judgment of the Court of Appeals at Albany upholding it should be affirmed. No Federal statute was involved.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Renewed interest in the recessed World Economic and Monetary Conference, which met in London last Summer, was indicated by the announcement today of the appointment of Richard Washburn Child, former Ambassador to Rome, as a special adviser to visit Europe.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- In some respects the most exciting place in the New Deal capital is not the White House, the NRA or AAA headquarters or either Congressional chamber. It is the small, stuffy room where sits the Supreme Court of the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The War Department appropriation bill for the fiscal year 1935, carrying $279,391,505, was reported to the House today after the Appropriations Committee had rejected a subcommittee proposal that would have prohibited expenditure of Public Works funds heretofore allocated to the War Department.

The steamship City of Montgomery of the Savannah Line, with twenty-nine passengers and a crew of ninety, is speeding toward this port with a fire in the cargo of the after hold. The fire is being kept down by steam and is under control, according to a radio message sent out yesterday by Captain Bertrand H. Garfield, master of the ship.

Total admitted assets of the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company increased to $998,295,363 in 1933 from $996,003,967 at the end of 1932. Last year the company wrote ordinary insurance totaling $191,002,509, compared with $254,465,390 the year before.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on Feb. 28 shows increases for the week of $275,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $152,000,000 in net demand deposits, $49,000,000 in government deposits and $69,000,000 in investments, and a decrease of $163,000,000 in loans.

A new track power came catapulting to the forefront last night as Manhattan College culminated its four-year rise to prominence by winning the team championship at the thirteenth annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. indoor carnival in Madison Square Garden.

Aside from an upturn in the metal stocks, particularly those with a gold flavor, there was little in yesterday's market on the Stock Exchange to entertain tape-watchers. The volume was only 952,000 shares; the combined averages declined 41 cents.
BERLIN, March 5. -- From one of the ablest Aryan lawyers in Berlin this correspondent received the following:

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Receipts of silver by mints under the new coinage plan adopted Dec. 21, amounted to 1,417,710 ounces up to March 2, the Treasury announced today. A total of 271,800 ounces were received last week.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 5. -The current problems of transportation are those arising from unregulated, subsidized competition. Edward G. Buckland, chairman of the board of directors of the New Haven Railroad system, said tonight in an address before the student chapter of the American Society of Civil Engineers at Yale University.

Now there is a treaty before the United States Senate about the St. Lawrence waterway, which is practically a treaty for the benefit of Canada and particularly for Montreal. A glance at the map should convince any American that this treaty should not be favored.

HOCKEY officials should keep a sharp eye on the legislative conferences in Washington, D.C. The drive to help native talent by hampering or barring foreign competition may reach the point where Congressmen will be rushing out on skates and asking distinguished performers like Ching Johnson and King Clancy to display United States citizenship papers or start heading for Canada immediately.

If Thomas G. Corcoran's contribution to the Fletcher-Rayburn Stock Exchange Control Bill is on a par with his statement, "Rules on Margins," as reported in THE TIMES this morning, I'm all for burning it up.

Twelve jurors were selected tentatively yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Samuel Hofstadter in the Bronx for trial of a suit for damages totaling $575,000, brought by nine women who lost their husbands in the Observation disaster on Sept. 9, 1932.

LONDON, March 5. -- Preliminary talks on sugar problems started here today in an effort to discover whether it would be of any use to hold a world conference to extend the scope of the Chadbourne restriction agreement.

MOSCOW, March 5. -- Ten women and two children were rescued today from the camp of the marooned Chelyuskin survivors on the ice of the Arctic Ocean near the Bering Strait by Pilot Lapidevsky with Mechanic Petroff, flying the big plane ANT-9 from Cape Wellen and back.

BUENOS AIRES, March 5. -- Paraguayan troops occupied Fort La Senora yesterday, according to a communique from Ascuncion today. La Senora is about three miles north of Fort Linares, which the Paraguayans occupied Saturday. It is situated on the upper of two roads paralleling the Pilcomayo River.

A.G. Macdonell, whose "England, Their England," has won the James Tait Black Memorial Book Prize as the best novel published in England in 1933, is coming here in the early Fall to wander about and fulfill a commission to write a similar novel about the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Here are the leading contentions advanced in the majority and minority opinions handed down today by the United States Supreme Court regarding the constitutionality of the New York State Milk Law:

A substitute amendment for the proposed child labor amendment, similar to the Twenty-first Amendment in leaving the question to the States, is proposed by former Governor Alfred E. Smith in his leading editorial on "Child Labor" in today's issue of The New Outlook.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 5. -- American tennis stars completed a clean sweep of the Bermuda championships today.

More loans were made by the Provident Loan Society in 1933 than in any other year of its existence, according to the annual report made yesterday by Frederick H. Ecker, president. Jeremiah Milbank has been chosen president for 1934 and Mr. Ecker has been made treasurer.
WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Following is the text of the minority Supreme Court opinion in the New York Milk Law Case:

Jesse L. Livermore, celebrated stock market plunger, is bankrupt for the fourth time in his spectacular career. He filed a petition in Federal court yesterday listing liabilities of $2,259,212.48 and assets of only $184,900, which includes the face value of insurance policies totaling $150,000.

CHICAGO, March 5. -- John Dillinger was believed tonight to be in Chicago following a disclosure by the police that the sheriff's automobile in which he escaped from the jail at Crown Point, Ind., on Saturday morning was found that same evening in front of a northwest side apartment building.

That sturdy annual, The American Year Book, has just come out with its 1933 tale of the life and labor, the triumphs and tribulations, the hopes and fears of the American people. This time it is a story in which the tribulations may overshadow the triumphs, and the lack of labor may stick out more prominently than the labor, but it is also one in which the hopes outrank the fears.
A day of springlike warmth, which saw the temperature in New York City rise to 60 degrees at 4 P.M., heightened the menace of floods throughout the East yesterday.

North American Aviation, Inc., which is controlled by General Motors Corporation, sold all its holdings of Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., capital stock, during February, in the open market, it was announced yesterday.

A record for Municipal Court procedure in this city was established yesterday when a calendar of 400 negligence cases, involving amounts up to $1,000 each, was disposed of by Acting President-Justice Pelham St. George Bissell.

ALBANY, March 5. -- After a spirited debate, in which President Roosevelt and Postmaster General Farley were accused of playing favorites with one of the large commercial airlines, the Assembly tonight adopted a resolution asking the National Administration to restore the air-mail service, under temporary contracts, to the private companies.

Eugene J. Shields, former deputy fire marshal, and Samuel J. Wurzberg, his partner in a Brooklyn firm of fire loss adjusters, were sentenced yesterday to twelve and one-half to twenty-five years in Sing Sing for second-degree arson.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 5. -Forty-four candidates for the Princeton varsity baseball team reported to Coach Jack Jefferies for the initial practice in the open-air gymnasium today.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 5. -- By train and automobile the international motorboat drivers and their boats arrived here today from New Smyrna, where the first three races between the Americans and Europeans were held.

Milton Baron, Fraternity Club ace, registered an impressive triumph over J.B. Quincy of the Yale Club, 15 -- 4, 15 -- 5, 15 -- 6, to gain the quarter-final round in the national amateur squash tennis championship at the Princeton Club last night.

Imports of $25,597,400 gold, of which $20,213,400 represented additions to the monetary gold stocks of the country and $5,384,000 gold previously acquired in France by the Treasury, were reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Complete reorganization of the supervisory force of the Sanitation Department is necessary, Mayor LaGuardia declared yesterday. He charged that this force was "simply rotten and in many cases dishonest."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 5. -Professor Gaetano Salvemini, Professor of Italian Literature at Harvard University, today denied that he participated in the exploding of a bomb in St. Peter's Cathedral in Rome last June. He cabled Premier Mussolini that he would welcome the opportunity extradition proceedings would give him to prove his innocence.

BERLIN, March 5. -- The Boerse today showed considerable firmness in several specialties, although the principal stocks were rather neglected. Gains ranged beyond 3 points, which were partly offset by some minor losses. Profit-taking also caused declines toward the close.

A series of informal teas for new members and prospective members of the Women's City Club will be given at the clubhouse, 22 Park Avenue, on Tuesday and Friday afternoons of this month, beginning today. The teas have been arranged in connection with the special expansion program now being conducted by the club.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 5. -The training manoeuvres of the Giants took on a touch of real business today. For the first time this year Memphis Bill Terry clustered his regulars under one banner in pretty much the same battle formation they are likely to use on opening day in New York, with one possible exception, and pitted them against a team known as the Yannigans.

ATHENS, March 5. -- Samuel Insull's chances of further residence in Greece were blasted tonight when Minister of the Interior Metaxas signed an order for him to leave the country within forty-eight hours. If he fails to obey, the former Chicagoan will be placed on a ship bound for the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- President Roosevelt, in conference with Attorney General Cummings and Secretary Ickes, today took up the question of whether a request should be made to modify or abrogate a Federal court decree governing the California oil industry in favor of a cartel written by the oil companies under the terms of the National Recovery Act.
LONDON, March 5. -- Norman H. Davis is flying tomorrow or Wednesday to Copenhagen on his way to Stockholm as a representative of the American creditors of the late Ivar Kreuger.

The fixation of temporary emergency gas rates to be charged by the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company and the New York and Richmond Gas Company was announced yesterday by the Public Service Commission.

The money market was quiet. Rates for all classifications were unchanged on a minimum of business, most of which represented replacements of expiring obligations. Stock Exchange call loans ruled at 1 per cent, Street trades 3/4@1 per cent.

Prices of bonds were steady in quiet trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday. United States Government bonds provided a feature, advancing 1-32 to 13-32 point, now that the March 15 financing has been determined definitely for announcement on Thursday.

The adoption of at least six preventive, measures by the Long Island Railroad to avert breakdowns in service such as occurred during the recent heavy snowstorms, was urged yesterday by Colonel William C. Lancaster, chief engineer of the Transit Commission.
WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Following is the text of the address delivered by President Roosevelt today in opening the General Conference of Code Authorities and Trade Association Code Committee:

ALBANY, March 5. -- With Senator McNaboe declaring he was being "gagged," the upper house of the Legislature voted down tonight an attempt to bring out on the floor of the Senate a bill to restore open betting at the New York tracks.
WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Striking statements by President Roosevelt today in his address to NRA Code Authorities were:

The American Smelting and Refining Company reports for 1933 a consolidated net income of $6,010,384 after all charges and reserves. This was equivalent, after dividend requirements on the two classes of preferred stock, to 77 cents a share on 1,828,764 no-par shares of common stock.
WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Ten bankers drew salaries of $100,000 or more, and 370 others more than $25,000 in the year ended last June, according to data disclosed today by the Senate Banking Committee.
The complete personnel of the Davis Cup Committee for 1934 was announced yesterday by Walter Merrill Hall, president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.
" Yellow Jack," Sidney Howard's play, based on a chapter in Paul de Kruif's "Microbe Hunters," will open tonight at the Martin Beck Theatre.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 5. -- Robert Robertson's Lynx Eye led home a high-class field of six sprinters in the five and a half furlongs of the featured Public Utilities Purse at Oaklawn Park today. Mrs. F. Fieldhouse's Adobe Post was second and Samuel Molay's Otterrop third.

There was almost the sadness of farewell in the beginning of the speech with which Representative FINLY GRAY of the Tenth Indiana District witched the House last Saturday. He is a recurrent member. He served in the Sixty-second, Sixty-third and Sixty-fourth Congresses, came back in the Seventy-third and begins to feel the pangs of another separation.

Standing in a group of children at a Brooklyn school crossing, Patrolman Philip Clarius, 32 years old, was shot in the chest and seriously wounded yesterday by a fleeing hold-up man. The assailant and an accomplice escaped. The patrolman is in a critical condition at Holy Family Hospital.

The Milbank Memorial Fund has undertaken to complete the task left unfinished by the committee on the costs of medical care and is now working out a comprehensive program to put adequate medical care within the reach of all, it is revealed in the annual report of the fund, published today.

A flashy finish enabled the Ottawa Senators to beat the New York Rangers, 5 to 4, in the teams' final meeting of the season last night. The courageous athletes from the north played their best game of the year in Madison Square Garden, and thrilled a crowd of 6,000 persons with their performance.

CHICAGO, March 6. -- General mortgage bondholders of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad, now operating in bankruptcy, made a demand today in the Federal District Court here that their claims be recognized as "payable in gold coin of the standard and fineness prevailing Jan. 1, 1898.

BERLIN, March 6. -- The Boerse was quiet today. Specialties were firm at the opening and registered gains beyond 3 points. Reichsbank, however, slumped 3 1/2 points which caused profit-taking that forced some quotations below yesterday's closing levels.
ATLANTA, March 6. -- Primo Carnera and Al Capone waved long-distance greetings today within the Federal prison here.
WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The Public Works Administration sold at a premium today four blocks of municipal bonds of a total par value of $737,000.

The most elaborate impromptu show that is presented on Broadway in the course of a season, the Metropolitan's annual operatic surprise party, is assured of a capacity audience Sunday night, it became known last night. The last of the reserved seats were disposed of yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP). -- Arthur F. Mullen requested the Nebraska Democratic Central Committee tonight to accept his resignation as national committeeman because, as he informed President Roosevelt, his continuance in office pending legislation against the practice of law before governmental agencies by men of influence "might be construed as indicative of opposition to you."

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 6. -- Tommy Goodwin, 20-year-old Monroe (N.Y.) star, and his partner, J. Scott Glenn of Buck Hill Falls, Pa., won their first-round match in the best-ball golf tournament over the Palm Beach Golf Club course today.

There was a curious State-wide conference of the Wisconsin Progressives on Saturday. Usually a Progressive conference is a meeting of select leaders. A "call" was sent out for this gathering. It had the air of a convention without the wicked name. The ostensible purpose was to decide whether the La Follettians should stick to the Republican label or start a third party.

Our neighbor The World-Telegram is fortunate in having the opportunity to give to the public the latest work from the pen of a highly gifted writer named CHARLES DICKENS. That he is destined to enjoy a long period of fame may be argued from the fact that he has already done so for very nearly a century.

Baseball practice at Manhattan College got under way as fifteen battery candidates reported to Coach Bert Daniels yesterday. A brief workout was held indoors, with eight pitchers and seven catchers participating.

PARIS, March 6. -- The Chamber of Deputies spent most of today's session discussing proposals for the regulation and taxation of single price stores, which in emulation of the American five and ten cent stores have been appearing in all parts of Paris.

One of the largest deal in the midtown East Side district in recent months was reported consummated yesterday with the purchase of the eighteen-story office building and three-story extension at 7-11 East Fortieth Street by Daniel A. Brener, operator.

Lottie Kreisberger Coll, widow of the gangster Vincent Coll, and two co-defendants were sentenced to prison yesterday on their pleas of guilty of killing Mollie Schwartz, 17 years old, a bystander, during a hold-up on June 21.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP). -- As part of the economy move by the department, Postmaster General Farley has instructed postmasters throughout the country to curtail mail service.

In a dramatic scene last night Mayor LaGuardia turned to Postmaster General James A. Farley, seated a few feet away from him at a dinner at which both were guests, and demanded that he supply the votes needed for the passage in Albany of the City Economy Bill.

BOSTON, March 6 (AP). -- The Boston Bruins tonight wrote the last chapter of their tragic 1933-34 experiences with the Toronto Maple Leafs by overwhelming the International Group leaders, 7 -- 2, before 12,500, the largest crowd of the Boston Garden season.

In one of the speediest proceedings on record in the Federal Building in Brooklyn, Mrs. Clara Megeran, 40 years old, of 195 Daniel Low Terrace, St. George, S.I., was arrested yesterday by postoffice inspectors, indicted by the Federal grand jury on a charge of violation of the "Lindbergh Law" in sending a letter through the mails in an attempt at extortion and pleaded guilty in the United States District Court.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 6. -- Dr. John McDowell of New York, moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, declared today that the nation's hope in the future lies with the Christian church.

Daily average gross crude-oil production in the United States last week was 2,183,300 barrels, compared with 2,226,050 in the preceding week, a decrease of 42,750 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Declines of 35,850 and 13,200 barrels, respectively, in the daily average in Oklahoma and California and a gain of 6,000 in Texas were the principal changes.

TRENTON, N.J., March 6. -- After a public hearing that lasted nearly three hours, a legislative committee decided today to refer to a conference of the Republican majority next Monday the question of reorganizing the State's judicial system.

The strongest field to compete for the national indoor tennis championship in years will start Saturday morning at 11 A.M. in the thirty-fifth annual tournament at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

The money market was dull and except for some small-size trades in six months' money at 1 per cent there was virtually little else but renewals arranged. Inquiry for money was light, and as for the supply, while it was not pressing the market, there was ample to take care of the bidding when made.

A warning against indiscriminate spending on "too many silk stockings" as general economic conditions improve under the New Deal, was voiced by Lawson Purdy, who was elected president of the American Provident Society at its annual meeting at Busto's Restaurant, 11 Stone Street, yesterday.

FORT MYERS, Fla., March 6. -- Comfortably seated in his garage-workshop, Henry Ford today voiced agreement with President Roosevelt's recovery program and, commenting on the President's advice to industry, said "the only way to hire more men is to create more markets."

Warning against any let-down in efforts to kill the proposed 2 per cent State sales tax because of reports from Albany that the tax was doomed, Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Sales Tax Committee of 1,000, condemned yesterday any compromise on the measure and declared merchants of the State would fight until the present sales tax also was "definitely, completely and finally wiped off the books."

William A. Brady, accompanied by his wife, Grace George, has returned to New York after spending two months in Florida, where Miss George had been convalescing from a serious illness. According to Mr. Brady, Miss George is now in the best of health.

Your leading editorial entitled "Republican Principles" wins from this reader immediate and unstinted praise. In my belief it discusses the current political situation with unequaled precision and incisiveness.

Bringing its home schedule to a close with an undefeated record, the Long Island University basketball team routed the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy five, 38 -- 23, last night in the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium. It was L.I.U's twenty-sixth victory in twenty-seven games. Both teams use the gym for home games.

In a suit to replevin 550 taxicabs for failure of the buyers to comply with selling agreements, 548 of them were seized in four garages by Deputy Sheriff Hyman Bernstein and nine assistants between Saturday and Monday, it was announced yesterday at the office of Sheriff Daniel E. Finn.

The belief that carbon monoxide poisoning may be responsible for a great many automobile accidents to which other causes have been assigned was advanced yesterday at the Fifth Annual Greater New York Safety Conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania by L.T. White of the Cities Service Oil Company.
Frank Williams, New York State amateur lightweight champion, scored a quick knockout at the Hippodrome last night in the semifinals of the Golden Gloves amateur boxing tournament.
Preliminary plans for the organization of a sportsmen's council in Connecticut were announced yesterday by the State Board of Fisheries and Game at Hartford.

Additional city revenue of $1,000,000 a year is sought in an amendment to the code of ordinances introduced yesterday in the Board of Aldermen, which would place a city tax on vaults located under city sidewalks.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 6. -- The Democrats again succeeded in blocking Mayor LaGuardia's Emergency Economy Bill when, after its two defeats in the Assembly, it was brought up for a third vote in that branch of the Legislature late this afternoon.
