KANSAS CITY, March 14 (AP). -- Two Chicago contenders were ousted from the National A.A.U. basketball tournament today by the Hutchinson (Kan.) Renos and Wichita (Kan.) Gridley Chieftains, who tied for last place in the Missouri Valley A.A.U. race this season.

The New York Public Library announced yesterday the gift of a collection of several thousand volumes on the history and development of engineering, given in memory of General William Barclay Parsons, their collector, by his wife, Anna Reed Parsons, and his children, Sylvia Parsons Weld of Brookline, Mass., and Dr. William Barclay Parsons of this city.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 14. -- The Princeton University Triangle Club will present "Good-Bye Again," recent stage and screen success, in the McCarter Theatre here tomorrow, Friday and Saturday.

The New York Stock Exchange authorized yesterday the listing, upon issuance, of 138,000 additional shares of common stock of National Distillers Products Corporation, to be issued in connection with the acquisition of 125,000 shares of capital stock of Penn-Maryland, Inc., a Delaware corporation, and in connection with the acquisition of $1,700.000 of demand notes of Penn-Maryland.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Increases in the dollar value of foreign trade in January, amounting to $51,585,459 for exports and $32,529,562 in imports over the corresponding month of last year, were shown in revised foreign trade figures made public by the Commerce Department.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 14. -- A purse containing $14,000 in cash, stock valued at $1,300 and jewelry worth $1,000 was snatched tonight from Mrs. John M. Lewis of 209 Bendemere Avenue, Interlaken, near here, as she walked to a relative's home a block away.

FRANKFORT, Ky., March 14. -- The House of the Kentucky Legislature by resolution today levied a fine of $25 and costs on Vance Armentrout, associate editor of The Louisville Courier-Journal, for alleged contempt of a lobby investigating committee.

Miss Maria Bowen Chapin, educator and founder of the Chapin School of 100 East End Avenue, who died on March 8, left a large part of her estate to that Institution and to the Scholarship Foundation, Inc., which she also founded.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14. -- A hope that "better things may be in store" for the Pennsylvania Railroad and its stockholders in 1934 is expressed in a letter from W.W. Atterbury, president, which accompanies cheeks for the company's 200th dividend, which is 50 cents a share.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Income taxes for the first twelve days of March show a decided increase over the same period of 1933, partly because last year, owing to the banking holiday, the Internal Revenue Bureau had extended to the end of March the time for filing of returns.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Admiral Frank B. Upham, Commander-in-Chief of the Asiatic Fleet, reported to the Navy Department today from Manila that the gunboat Fulton was believed to be a total loss, but that all the crew were safe.

Observing that "mixed tendencies in steel production and in scrap prices indicate a leveling off of the upward surge of activity that got under way in the latter part of January," The Iron Age in its midweek review estimates the current operating rate for the industry at 48 1/2 per cent of capacity, compared with 49 per cent a week ago.

The weather in February was the worst with which the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad management ever had to centend and cost the company $600,000, J.J. Pelley, president, said yesterday. He estimated that this resulted in a deficit of $850,000 to $900,000 for the month before allowing for guarantees, compared with a deficit of $796,112 in February, 1933.
Returning yesterday on the Majestic of the White Star line were four members of the United States women's squash racquets team which participated in tournaments in England beginning in January.
ALBANY, March 14. -- A bill to establish an unemployment insurance system in the State on lines backed by the Federation of Labor was advanced to final reading in the Senate today.

ALBANY, March 14. -- On the plea that general municipal insolvency throughout the State was imminent unless relief came from the Legislature, proponents of the Fearon-Wadsworth 2 per cent sales tax bill joined in a plea that this measure receive favorable action, at a public hearing before the Senate and Assembly Committees on Taxation and Retrenchment this afternoon.

Cardinal Hayes in a pastoral letter has asked that all the priests of the Archdiocese of New York assemble at designated churches this afternoon at 3 o'clock for "an hour of solemn adoration before the Blessed Sacrament" in commemoration of the institution of the Blessed Sacrament 1,900 years ago and forms part of the special services of the Holy Year marking the nineteenth centenary of the redemption, which closes the day after Easter.

Irving Bitz, one of Colonel Lindbergh's underworld contact men in the effort to regain the aviator's kidnapped child, was found guilty last night of jumping his 25,000 bail last October. A jury that reported to Judge Corrigan in General Sessions at 10:55 o'clock had deliberated ten hours.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- The moral of the President's defeat in the matter of the St. Lawrence waterways treaty is that he who fights and runs away will live to fight another day. That day is coming soon when Congress will consider the call for a large loan of its tariff powers to the Executive and vetoes of expansive grants to veterans and government employes.

The "cut-throat competition" of chain stores was attacked as one of the chief causes of business depression during a public hearing yesterday on the proposal to bring chain stores under a city licensing system.

FREEHOLD, N.J., March 14. -- Charged with attempting to murder his wife prior to the birth of a daughter last Sunday. Robert C. Miller, 38 years old, a contractor of Spring Lake, was held today in $50,000 bail and lodged in the Monmouth County jail.

A bondholders' suit to void the proposed reorganization of the Chanin Building, Lexington Avenue and Forty-second Street, was filed yesterday in the Supreme Court. An injunction is sought and the appointment is asked of new trustees for first and third mortgages, aggregating $11,392,000, to replace the Continental Bank and Trust Company.

The international team of the Oxford Group, under the leadership of Dr. Frank N.D. Buchman, will arrive tomorrow on the North German Lloyd liner Europa to meet with followers of the movement here in a two-day session at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP). -- The Senate today passed the War Department appropriation bill, carrying $342,268,748 for the next fiscal year, and the Agriculture Department bill, appropriating $64,000 000. Both measures now go to conference with the House.

Elliott C. Baker of the Garden City Casino was eliminated by S. A. Hartshorn of the Central Badminton Club in a second-round singles match as the metropolitan association badminton championships got under way yesterday at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory.

LONDON, March 14. -- Sir John Simon, former free trader but still leader of one faction of the Liberal party, made a formal confession of his conversion to tariffs today. The Foreign Secretary did it at a luncheon in London's chief stronghold of free trade, the National Liberal Club, and received loud applause from the throng of liberals of all factions who heard him.

LONDON, March 14. -- The hope of an American victory in the Grand National was left to five horses when the list of thirty-four final acceptances, including all of the favorites, was posted today for the steeplechase classic at Aintree on March 23.

The uninhabited city which has been discovered in the desert, even if it never knew the charms of the Queen of Sheba except through legends, still "affronts the waste" with proud memories. Its time-whitened relics and "bright, broken beauty," as the late Laureate of England said of Baalbec and Palmyra, "atone with rich thought" the melancholy of their doom and people the solitude with gorgeous presences of our imaginings.

BERLIN, March 14. -- The new decree appointing Dr. Kurt Schmitt, the Minister of Economics, virtual dictator for the reconstruction of German business was published today. It is entitled "A Law for the Organic Upbuilding of German Economy," and confers upon Dr. Schmitt the widest powers to do whatever is necessary to complete his task.
Legislation affecting salt water angling and commercial fishing was discussed at a special meeting of the Salt Water Anglers of America held at the Gramercy Park Hotel last night.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP). -- A bill telling defaulting nations they cannot obtain any more credit until they pay up was beaded for enactment tonight after unanimous approval by the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

Amid the acclaim of the largest crowd that has ever witnessed a figure-skating carnival in this country, Miss Sonja Henie of Norway made her appearance in the gala show presented last night in Madison Square Garden.

SAN SALVADOR, March 14. -- More than 250 persons were killed and at least 1,000 injured, it is estimated, when seven tons of dynamite on a freight train blew up in front of an explosives warehouse at the port of La Libertad, twenty-two miles south of here, at 7:15 this morning. It is feared the toll may exceed these figures when a check-up can be made.

LONDON, March 14. -- European governments, discounting failure of the disarmament conference, are busy preparing to meet a new state of affairs. The most important event in this respect is the offer now made by Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy to the French Government.

Advocating "definitely planned and organized promotion of peace," Frank E. Gannett, newspaper publisher, proposed yesterday, in a radio address, the creation of a Federal Department of Peace. His address, arranged by the international committee of the Young Men's Christian Association, was broadcast over Station WEAF and an NBC network.

State Senator John C. Barbour, who had been the sponsor of John McCutcheon, New Jersey Controller, for renomination, announced last night in Paterson that he would neither nominate nor vote for Mr. McCutcheon. "

Harry Hoffman, the brilliant N. Y.U. anchor man, yesterday was added to the field that will start in the Casey 600, one of the features of the Knights of Columbus games at Madison Square Garden Saturday night. The admission of Hoffman by Meet Director John J. Downing brings the field to six.

Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday that within a few weeks he would institute a plan for rotation of assignments of all deputy chiefs and battalion chiefs in the department. This is a radical change in department policy.

Announcement of the personnel of the British Walker Cup team recalls the fact that in a month's time the American team, announced at the time of the annual meeting of the U.S.G.A., will depart for the event.
When there is such a wide difference of opinion among intelligent people as there is about the sales tax, there must be truth on both sides of the question.
HONGKONG, March 14. -- Haggard, tired and unshaven, Commander Harry McHenry of the gunboat Fulton told The Associated Press this morning his story of the battle with flames aboard the vessel.

BERLIN, March 14. -- The Stahlhelm organization of war veterans, which only a year ago boasted a membership of 1,000,000, but which has gradually been edged out of the German picture, is now scheduled for complete dissolution.

The report of the Federal Water Service Corporation and subsidiaries for 1933 records that it was necessary to provide in the year for maturing securities for $4,381,000, of which $3,426,000 was in public hands, without recourse to the public sale of new securities.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 14 (AP). -- Six of seven 1933 winners of individual titles in the Intercollegiate Swimming Association will dive into the Rutgers pool Friday and Saturday in the twenty-eighth renewal of the championships.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 14. -- The twenty-fourth annual society baseball game was played today on the Poinciana-Breakers diamond between amateur teams made up of New fork and Philadelphia colonists for the benefit of the Palm Beach Police Pension Fund.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Failure of Congress to enact the bill creating a permanent national labor board and outlawing company-dominated unions would jeopardize the recovery program and make it difficult for the nation to cope with an epidemic of strikes now threatened, Senator Robert F. Wagner, author of the measure, told the Senate Education and Labor Committee today.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Applicants for relief through the numerous agencies of the Federal government will be able, beginning tomorrow morning, to obtain immediate information as to the agency, the official, and the office where their case should be presented.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Losses to income-tax payers resulting from the closing of banks may be deducted from gross income in the preparation of Federal returns, when they are definitely determined to be a loss.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., March 14. -- Miss Helen Waring of Pinehurst, continuing the pace she set on the first day of play, carded a 165 for the 36-hole tournament and won the women's sixth annual mid-South golf tournament today.

LONDON, March 14. -- Pessimism as to the prospect of war was rejected in the House of Commons today by Captain Anthony Eden, Lord Privy Seal, in answer to Laborite criticism of British foreign policy.

LONDON, March 14. -- With almost complete absence of ceremony, the Laborite majority took possession of the London County Council today, thus giving London the distinction formerly held by Vienna of being "the biggest Socialist municipality in the world."

The City Company of New York Inc., cornpeting with eleven other bidders, won yesterday the award of a new issue of $427,000 city of Schenectady (iNT. Y.) general municipal and park bonds. The issue, due serially on March I from 1935 to 1953, fetched a price of 100.239 with interest at 3% per cent.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Jack (Catch 'em Alive) Abernathy, frontier marshal in the days when the West was wild, is back again on the Broadway where he and Al Jennings, one-time train robber, cut a handsome swath twenty-six years ago.

BERLIN, March 14. -- Hugh A O'Donnell, studying leisure time developments in Germany with a view to adaptation of similar ideas to the United States, was assured today by Theodor Lewald, honorary chairman of the International Olympic Committee, that all amateurs, Jew or Gentile, German or otherwise, who are qualified to compete in the coming Winter Games and Olympics to follow, will be welcomed in Germany.

Cyrl S. Newton, vice president and general manager of the Artloom Corporation, was elected president yesterday to succeed Joseph Wasserman, who was elected chairman of the board. John T. McDade, formerly assistant treasurer, was made treasurer.
Subwayitis is not a very dangerous disorder, though it occurs in a somewhat aggravated form with a great many of our subterranean travelers.
" New Faces," the revue marking the return of Charles B. Dillingham to managerial ranks, opens this evening at the Fulton Theatre.

By winning the last two bouts, the Manhattan College boxers defeated City College, 5 to 4, in a closely contested meet before 500 spectators at the Jasper gymnasium last night. Sol Resinol, sophomore, scored the deciding victory by outboxing Oscar Bloom, C.C.N.Y. welterweight, in the final bout.

ROME, March 14 (By Wireless). -- As many times before in history, the Eternal City dominates the political situation in Europe, and Mussolini is the master mind whose policy is pulling all the strings. Rome is the centre of the stage in this drama which has war or peace for its plot.

The proposal to change the present jib of the Atlantic Class yachts was voted down at the annual meeting of the Atlantic Class Association held last night at the Union League Club, according to an announcement from J.F. Watkins.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- A petition signed by more than 250,000 American citizens of various faiths and all stations of life protesting the persecution of the Jews in Germany and requesting President Roosevelt to forward it to the Hitler government with a diplomatic note was left at the White House today by Alfred N. Cohen of Cincinnati, president of B'nai B'rith, and Representative Sabath of Illinois.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Walter J. Cummings, a Chicago banker, who put into operation the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, became treasurer of the Democratic National Committee today after the position was declined by John S. Cohen, newspaper publisher of Atlanta.

LONDDON, March 14. -- The Hon. Michael Scott, 56-year-old holder of the British amateur golf championship, has been appointed captain of the British Walker Cup team which meets the United States squad at St. Andrews on May 11 and 12, it was announced today.

CHICAGO, March 14. -- Desirable hogs were 5 to 10 cents a hundred-weight higher today than yesterday, while medium grades were relatively inactive and closed weak to slightly lower. Some heavy butchers' kinds were quoted as much as 20 cents higher, with some of medium weight off 10 cents.

ROME, March 14. -- Italy's efforts to save Austria and Hungary from German domination and to safeguard their freedom by establishing a solid economic base for their independence were continued today at two long conversations between Premier Benito Mussolini and Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss of Austria.

LONDON, March 14. -- The negotiations between the British and Japanese cotton exporters broke down completely today and the Lancashire delegates promptly laid the deadlock before their government for action.

LONDON, March 14. -- A plucky Oxford crew dogged by misfortune during the long training grind will make a desperate attempt on Saturday to stem the string of Cambridge victories in the historic series. It is expected that 1,000,000 persons will watch the race.

LONDON, March 14. -- The negotiations between the British and Japanese cotton exporters broke down completely today and the Lancashire delegates promptly laid the deadlock before their government for action.

LONDON, March 14. -- A plucky Oxford crew dogged by misfortune during the long training grind will make a desperate attempt on Saturday to stem the string of Cambridge victories in the historic series. It is expected that 1,000,000 persons will watch the race.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 14 (AP). -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who will return to the United States tomorrow by airplane, reviewed the Reserve Officers' Training Corps of the University of Puerto Rico today.

The Fox Film Corporation reported yesterday for the thirty-nine weeks from April 1, 1933, the effective date of its reorganization, to Dec. 30 last, a net profit of $1,410,793 after all charges. These earnings were equivalent to 58 cents a share on the 2,436,409 combined Class A and Class B shares outstanding.

POUGHKEEPSIE, March 14. -- The will of Mrs. Anne Coleman Rogers, widow of Colonel Archibald Rogers, yachtsman, of Crumwold Hall, Hyde Park, was filed for probate today with Surrogate Daniel J. Gleason. It disposes of an estate valued at more than $3,000,000.
The national indoor tennis championship tournament resolved itself into strictly an American affair yesterday with the elimination of the representatives of France from both the singles and doubles.

Thomas A. Morgan, president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, in a statement issued Yesterday concerning the present condition of the aeronautical industry, pledged cooperation of the industry with the Federal Administration in working out a constructive program.

Flushing High retained possession of first place in the P.S.A.L. city championship fencing tournament by defeating New Utrecht, 3 to 2, in one of the nine matches at the C.C. N.Y. Commerce Centre gymnasium yesterday. The victory was the eighth in nine starts.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 14. -- Officials of this city at an emergency conference this morning in City Hall decided there would have to be an additional 1934 tax levy of about $1,000,000. Experts had been urging such a supplementary levy for several months.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 14. -- Despite the clean sweep of the Europea drivers yesterday, the Unitedt States still leads in the point scoring in the international motorboat races. The series will be resumed Friday.

A better opportunity for Cuba to operate its raw sugar industry profitably and protection for American refiners against the increasing shipments of refined sugar into this country from Cuba and the insular possessions of the United States are urged by Earl D. Babst, chairman of the American Sugar Refining Company, in his annual report to stockholders for 1933.

Dr. George W. Kirchwey's indictment of the children's courts, as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES, would strike any one familiar with the situation as unreasonable. In my personal observation of several years these courts give the children every opportunity of adjustment, inviting the cooperation of every possible helpful agency, and only when these completely fail is the child placed elsewhere.

Arthur W. Morse of the brokerage firm of Clinch, Morse Co., 48 Wall Street, was held without bail yesterday by Magistrate Lindau in Homicide Court in connection with the death of Mrs. Edna Field Leavitt of Brookline, Mass. The case will go to the grand jury today.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- The House voted tonight to send the Independent Offices Supply Bill to conference, after an eight-hour session in which many of the Senate's anti-economy amendments were rejected or modified. The fight to save the President's economy program is now transferred to a committee room, where in secret session the House and Senate managers will seek a compromise acceptable to Mr. Roosevelt.

Charges that officials of the Long Island Railroad Company "gambled" with the weather report of Feb. 19, the day of the severe snowstorm, were made yesterday by Colonel Charles G. Blakeslee, counsel to the Public Service Commission.

Yesterday's news budget was exceptionally rich in items about the American Indian. At Glacier Park, Mont., there died Chief TWO-GUNS-WHITE-CALF, a venerable Blackfeet warrior, whose handsome, rugged features, with more than a suggestion of MUSSOLINI, appear on our buffalo nickel.
Hunter College classes have elected sixty students to manage Sing, the annual competitive interclass song festival, which will be held at the Metropolitan Opera House on Friday, May 4.
WASHINGTON, March 14. -- President Roosevelt announced a plan for a general study of government aviation with the object of coordination.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 14. -- Two gifts of $50,000 each have been made to Harvard University by Earl Willson Bemis, retired engineer, of Worcester.
May I add to the editorial in last Sunday's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES? Neil Munro, writing of the so-called Canadian Boat Song, "From the Lone Shieling of the Misty Island," in The Looker-On, says:

Park Commissioner Robert Moses accused Samuel Levy, President of the Borough of Manhattan, in a letter to him yesterday of refusing to cooperate in the development of the Chrystie-Forsyth Street playground project.

The figures on passenger traffic on rapid transit lines of the B.M.T. and Interborough for the first twelve days in March show that rapid transit travel, for the first time in nearly three years, is developing a marked upward trend, the Transit Commission announced yesterday.

For technical reasons alone our electrical communication systems ought to be unified. We talk and telegraph by electric waves. We transfer them from wires to space and back again with ease. A dozen telegraph messages and as many telephone conversations may course over the same circuit without interference.
SAN SALVADOR, March 14. -- The explosion of 250 cases of dynamite at the port of La Libertad this morning was heard clearly in this city.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- A new Federal policy involving the transfer of income tax cases from individual Federal officials to grand juries wherever a question of motive might be involved in disputed returns, was announced at the White House today.

MTAMI, Fla., March 14 (AP). -- The 36-foot Marconi-rigged ketch Melody, owned by Wirth Munroe of Miami, today won the sixth annual Sir Thomas Lipton Challenge Cup handicap sailing race, covering the 25-mile ocean course with a corrected time of 3:12.41 1/2.

I read with interest the account in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the luncheon meeting to discuss crime prevention. What Dr. Kirchwey says is only too true; children are rarely at fault. It is the environment and education that need to be changed. The city schools can help, because nearly all delinquents attend public schools.

Miss Madeline Mason-Manheim gave a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's for the Polish Ambassador, Stanislaw Patek. The other guests were Colonel and Mrs. Edward M. House, Mr. and Mrs. Schuyler Schieffelin, Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Crawford,

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 14. -- While thirty-four Rutgers University students were at luncheon today in the Lambda Chi Alpha fraternity house here, a truck driver pumped what he thought was 700 gallons of fuel oil into the tank of an oil-burning furnace in the basement.

The twenty-seven-story apartment hotel at 1 Fifth Avenue, corner of Eighth Street, will be remodeled and refitted, it was learned yesterday, when the sale of the building land leasehold on the property to Wertheim Co., bankers, was announced.

Print lovers will doubtless lose no time in visiting the just-opened exhibition at Knoedler's, in which are assembled all of Anthony Van Dyck's etched portraits. These plates have come from the Sir Peter Lely and the Prosper Henry Lankrink collections.
LONDON, March 15 (AP). -- England, the native land of Samuel Insull Sr., watched with special interest tonight the sensational hunt for the former Chicago business man.
LONDON. March 15 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
PARIS, March 15 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

The smallest advance order received so far for "The Life of Our Lord," by Charles Dickens, is for fifty copies, Simon Schuster report. The largest is for 2,500 copies. No orders have been placed in any city of more than 500,000 population.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 15. -- William K. Vanderbilt Jr. and his brother, Harold S. Vanderbilt, are to receive an additional $583,160 each from the estate of their father, William K. Vanderbilt, under a decree entered today in the Suffolk County Surrogate's Court levying an additional State transfer tax of $46,652.80 on the estate.
Two goals by Nels Stewart in less than a minute enabled the Boston Bruins to triumph over the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- President Roosevelt today excluded from future government contracts any and all corporations or persons that do not actually certify compliance with the codes of fair competition for their industries.

Dr. Chang Sei Kin, 41-year-old Korean physician known in this country as a student and lecturer, was found dead of gas poisoning yesterday in the kitchen of his three-room apartment at 56 West Fifty-fifth Street, where he had lived for the last month.

In one of his most scintillating NRA speeches last year, General JOHNSON warned organized labor not to imperil recovery by exorbitant demands. He foresaw, apparently, conditions as they are taking ominous shape at present. Just now the chief conflict, or trouble, is centred in the automotive industry.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- Government economy today caused the abandonment of eight of eleven Coast Guard bases and the scattering of their patrol boats to numerous ports on the Atlantic, Gulf, Pacific and Great Lakes coasts.

A break in the price of silver and an unsettled tone in several other markets caused a loss of 10 points in prices on the Cotton Exchange at one time yesterday, but reports that the House had resumed consideration of the Bankhead Bill steadied the market.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The fire which burned the gunboat Fulton near Hongkong yesterday was caused by the ignition of oil on her Diesel engine when exhaust pipes from the latter's cylinders were carried away, the Navy Department was informed today in a preliminary report from Commander H.D. McHenry, her commanding officer.

The first annual report of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation to be drafted under the terms of the agreement made last July with the New York Stock Exchange was issued yesterday. The agreement was reached after prolonged discussions in which the Stock Exchange demanded a more detailed report.
Rear Admiral Paul Oras, Naval Attache at the Russian Embassy in Washington, arrived yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia accompanied by his wife and two children.

Employes of subsidiary plants of the United States Steel Corporation, in an election held recently, adopted by substantial majorities a revised employes' representation plan. It is said to correct some features of the old plan, which went into effect last June, and provides for the recall of the representatives selected by the employes and also assures the permanence of the plan so far as the management of the corporation is concerned.

Lily Pons, unfeignedly sad, said farewell yesterday to yellow-eyed Ita, the pet Brazilian jaguar that had been her constant companion, on tour and at home, for nineteen months. The parting took place at the Bronx Zoo, where Ita has now become a permanent resident.

CHICAGO, March 15. -- Prices of choice hogs here today were strong to 10 cents a hundred-weight higher than yesterday, with other kinds somewhat irregular. The extreme top of $4.65 and the day's average of $4.40 were each 5 cents above those of yesterday.

The money market was without feature. With virtually no demand for new money, only renewals being arranged, quotations for all classifications remained unchanged. Stock Exchange call loans were 1 per cent, and outside money 3/4 @ 7/8.
PARIS, March 15. -- Germany reiterated her views on armaments in her latest note to France, it was learned authoritatively tonight, and made a new demand for a regular German Army.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 15. -- In a letter of declination, gallantly phrased in the Old World manner, Nicholas N. Solodsoff, former Divisional Chief Engineer of the Imperial Murmansk Railways of the Russian Empire before the revolution, informed the compensation department of the CWA that he could not accept compensation for a slight injury received while working in Freeport.

A resolution requesting the creation of a Federal undersecretary-ship of the fine arts was adopted last night by more than 500 persons who attended a dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt to inagurate the newly formed Fine Arts Foundation.

More than half the staff of the Bronx Terminal Market will be discharged on April 1 with a resultant payroll reduction of 54 per cent or $56,727.65, William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Markets Commissioner, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended March 14, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,535,000,000, a decrease of $24,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $1,101,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1933.

Floor space of 12,000 square feet in the Beaver Street side of the New York Produce Exchange Building, 2 Broadway, has been leased to the Two Broadway Corporation for a restaurant to be known as Kellogg's Cafeteria, it was announced yesterday by the Finchley Realty Company, Inc., broker in the deal.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Prospects that important steps would be taken soon by the administration for further monetary use of silver grew dim today when Secretary Morgenthau said that he still was "to be shown that silver alone is a cure-all."
The estate of Mrs. Adelaide H.C. Frick, widow of Henry Clay Frick, art collector and capitalist, was appraised yesterday at $4,376,954 gross and $4,048,634 net. She died Oct. 4, 1931.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 15. -- One hundred and ten crack swimmers representing eighteen colleges and universities in the East have been entered in the twenty-eighth annual renewal of the Intercollegiate Swimming Association's individual championships at the Rutgers University pool tomorrow and Saturday.

MONTREAL, March 15 (AP). -- The Montreal Canadiens dropped a 4-1 decision to the Detroit Red Wings tonight and lost a chance to clinch second place in the National Hockey League's international division. The Canadiens, however, remained in a tie for that place with the Montreal Maroons.

ALBANY, March 15. -- Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Legislature today stressing the urgent necessity of providing for some form of liquor control to continue after April 1, when the powers of the present temporary Alcoholic Beverage Control Board will expire.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- A declaration that "fraud and collusion'' had tainted the granting of annulled air mail contracts, awarded with the "connivance" of former Postmaster General Brown, was made today by Senator Robinson of Arkansas, Democratic leader of the upper house.

Prince SIXTUS of Bourbon-Parma, brother of ex-Empress ZITA, early in 1917 laid before RAYMOND POINCARE, President of the French Republic, a letter from the Prince's brother-in-law, Emperor KARL of Austria.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Postmaster General Farley will relinquish his post as chairman of the New York Democratic State Committee in September, when his term expires. He also said today that he would retire as chairman of the national committee as soon as the President had selected a successor.

MIAMI, Fla., March 15. -- The 9-year-old gelding Judge Schilling won the featured Governor's Purse let Hialeah Park today in the presence of Governor Sholtz and other prominent Floridians. The proceeds were donated to charity, as was the case on the same occasion last year.

Three women were dragged from a Parmelee company taxicab at Broadway and Thirtieth Street at 10 o'clock last night, the driver beaten and the machine's windows smashed by a group of 300 striking Parmelee drivers marching from a meeting on the East Side.

Mrs. Wolcott Sayre gave a luncheon yesterday at her home at 2 East Eighty-sixth Street for Mrs. M. Chesnut Snow, daughter oil Judge and Mrs. W. Calvin Chesnut of Roland Park, Baltimore, whose marriage to Mrs. Sayre's cousin, Malcolm Webster Ford of Forest Hills, Queens, will take place the night of April 2.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Following is the text of the joint statement made by J.C. Williver, first vice president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, on behalf of the cable and radio companies to the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee today in reply to charges made yesterday by G.M.-P. Murphy for the Cable and Radio Users Protectice Committee:
TOKYO, March 15. -- The government is not considering any immediate steps in connection with the breakdown of the London textile negotiations.

A four-story building to house its activities in behalf of the blind will be erected by the American Foundation for the Blind in West Sixteenth Street, opposite the New York Hospital, on a site just presented to the Foundation by Moses C. Migel, its president.

After inspecting the Health Department bacteriological laboratories in Willard Parker Hospital on his way downtown yesterday, Mayor LaGuardia described the trip as the first satisfactory inspection he has made since he took office.

SALT LAKE CITY, March 15 (AP). -- Four earth tremors, one strong enough to shake buildings and rattle dishes, were felt here today and some thirty new shocks were reported about the north end of Great Salt Lake where muddy water flowed afresh from wide cracks opened in the earth's crust by Monday's quakes.

Is this the same Lindbergh who flew across the ocean into the hearts of the peoples of the world? Is this that fear-less, charmingly naive young man who asked for letters of introduction to present when and if he arrived in Paris?

VIENNA, March 15. -- An official communique issued today on the results of the three-day conference of Heimwehr leaders in Vienna, which has just come to an end, revealed one conflict between the Heimwehr and other supporters of Chancellor Dollfuss and concealed several more that there is reason to believe came to light during the congress.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- A supplemental code of fair trade practices for investment banking was described by its sponsors at NRA hearings today as going much further than the National Securities Act. The business is already operating under a wages and hours code signed by the President.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 15. -- Notable among the many and varied affairs featuring today's social program was the large tea which the Hon. Mrs. Frederick E. Guest gave at Villa Artemis, honoring members of the French team here for the international gold cup races.

The Shippers' Conference of Greater New York drafted a list yesterday of proposed rates for loading cargo from waterfront piers to trucks, which it will recommend for adoption on all city-owned piers in the port. The schedules were drawn at the request of Dock Commissioner John McKenzie, who is investigating charges of an alleged racket by freight loaders, and will be studied with the suggestions of other shipping groups.

ATHENS, March 15. -- Samuel Insull Sr., the former Chicago utilities operator, whose age and ill health had been emphasized in his fight against extradition to the United States, vanished from his apartment before dawn today, leaving behind him a possible Cabinet crisis.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- President Roosevelt accepted today the presidency of a national committee to determine the historical subjects to be carved on the west wall of Mount Rushmore in South Dakota.

The sports department basketball team of THE NEW YORK TIMES won the championship of the Metropolitan Sports Writers League yesterday on the Union Temple court by defeating the Brooklyn Eagle quintet, 38 to 22, in a play-off for the title.
PARIS, March 15. -- A decree published in today's Official Journal establishes quota restrictions upon a number of important United State exports to France which have never hitherto been limited.

Although they stepped off the Majestic only the day before yesterday, Mrs. H. Stuart Green of Tarrytown and Mrs. Ary J. Lamme of Rye are now in the final round of the women's metropolitan squash racquets championship.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 15. -- After a few motor-turning spins around Lake Worth today, all the drivers of the international motorboats had their craft tuned up for a renewal of racing here.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- As a curtain raiser the Senate, when it met today, had for entertainment what many Senators referred to as a one-act comedy entitled "Save the Republican Party" in which Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska, cast as a regular, castigated Senator Nye for criticizing those regular Republican Senators who voted against the St. Lawrence treaty yesterday.

Some of the most important rule changes of recent years in the ancient sport of polo became official today with the release of the new edition of the Year Book of the United States Polo Association. This is the official manual of the game and it includes the new rules.

A new issue of $2,750,000 Monroe County (N.Y.) tax revenue and general purposes bonds, due on March 1. 1935 to 1944, was awarded yesterday to a syndicate comprising the Chase National Bank, Guaranty Company of New York, N.W. Harris Company, Inc.; Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc.; L. F. Rothschild Co., Blyth Co., Inc.; R.H. Moulton Co., Inc.; Kelley, Richardson Co., Inc., and Wallace Cal.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Company unions were denounced as "pseudo labor organizations" today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and other speakers in urging the Senate Committee on Education and Labor to take favorable action on Senator Wagner's labor disputes bill if the nation is to be spared a series of disastrous strikes that would impede the recovery program.

All parties concerned in the attempt to stage the world's heavyweight championship bout between Primo Carnera and Max Baer were in accord yesterday, and the fight is as good as signed, according to Madison Square Garden officials.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Hugh S. Johnson, who was called into the automobile industry's labor trouble tonight to forestall a strike, offered to representatives of the companies, tentatively, a plan calling for establishment of an impartial grievance committee and an election to determine the actual representatives of labor in the industry.

The President has tried to remedy the exorbitant prices put upon liquors and wines by lifting the import quotas. In New York State this will be unavailing because of the manner in which the State has bolstered up the liquor distributing racket.
A faint touch of opera bouffe a l'Americain was added to the history of the Cuban troubles yesterday as the contribution of the battleship Wyoming, now in the Navy Yard in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Commodity prices continued their upward movement last week, advancing three-tenths of 1 per cent, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The prices at the end of the week were 73.8 per cent of the 1926 average of 100, as compared with 73.6 per cent the previous week.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Spokesmen for the nation's 160 Class I railroads today temporarily abandoned their demand for a 15 per cent wage reduction and asked the twenty-one standard railway unions to extend the present 10 per cent deduction until April 30, 1935.

Under the law as it stands the new city subway is to be operated for a trial period of three years, from Sept. 10, 1932, to Sept. 10, 1935, at a five-cent fare. Later, the fare is to be adjusted in such a way as to make the enterprise self-sustaining. Meanwhile deficits are to be funded.

BERLIN, March 15 (London Times Dispatch). -- Despite recent functions purporting to mark the dawn of a new and more agreeable era in the relations between the government and the foreign press, another example of the high-handed methods that completely clouded those relations last year has occurred.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Faced by threats of a strike in the Detroit automobile industry that might seriously cripple the recovery program, General Johnson intervened tonight in an attempt to evolve a formula that would be acceptable to employers and employes.

The New York Curb Exchange removed yesterday from unlisted trading twenty-one stock issues of eighteen companies and removed from listing United States Financial Holding Corporation common stock, with warrants, with a par value of $1.

BUCHAREST, March 15. -- Corneliu Zelea Codreanu, long-sought leader of Rumania's anti-Semitic Iron Guard, was arrested today as he was entering the building in which military courts were sitting with the intention of surrendering the public prosecutor.

BUENOS AIRES, March 15. -- The League of Nations Chaco Commission has taken a first step to put on the American nations instead of the League of Nations the responsibility for failure of the peace negotiations which the League commission took away from the Pan-American Conference at a moment when success seemed within easy reach.

ATHENS, March 15. -- Mrs. Lilie Kouryoumdjoglou, who has been taken into custody in the Insull case, is the sister of one of Mr. Insull's confidential agents. She has been one of his close advisers and protectors in recent weeks.

New faces being agreeable to see at this time of the year, Charles Dillingham has convened a number of them into a light revue entitled "New Faces," which was put on at the Fulton last evening. If you can remember as far back as the freshman antics of the "Garrick Gaieties," you know how refreshing youthful fooling can be.

Raymond Leslie Buell, president of the Foreign Policy Association, declared here last night that "the outside world has badly mismanaged its relations with the Hitler government." He spoke at a meeting of the Phi Beta Kappa Alumni in the Savoy-Plaza Hotel.

DANZIG, March 15. -- The German-Polish political rapprochement must be followed by a mutual spiritual understanding, Dr. Hermann Rauschning, President of the Danzig Senate, today told the Society for the Study of Poland, founded by himself.

The Committee for the Creation of a State Mortgage Authority, of which M. Morgenthau Jr. is chairman, estimated yesterday on the basis of an impartial survey by its members that $20,000,000 and probably less was the maximum amount necessary to relieve the distress among guaranteed mortgage certificate holders.

Sales of the W.T. Grant Company in 1933 were the largest ever made in a year by the company and net income was the second largest in its history. The sales amounted to $78:206,119, against $73,086,856 in 1932, an increase of 7 per cent.

Mayor LaGuardia, called as a witness yesterday before Supreme Court Justice McCook in the taxpayer's suit to set aside the bus franchise granted on Dec. 22 last by the Board of Estimate in the closing days of the last administration, drew the admonishment of the court several times when he sought to elaborate on answers to questions.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The Senate today refused to accept the two major amendments to the Independent Offices Supply Bill adopted by the House yesterday, and the measure will be brought back to the House for its approval or rejection again tomorrow.

PARIS, March 15. -- The Stavisky scandal caused the downfall of another official today when M. Blanchard, director of agricultural services of the Ministry of Agriculture, was removed from his post. M. Blanchard admitted before the Parliamentary commission of inquiry that he had acted as a director of several of Stavisky's companies while connected with the Ministry.

TRENTON, March 15. -- The United States is playing a "dangerous game" of military retrenchment, Governor Moore told the New Jersey Society, Daughters of the American Revolution, today. The annual State conference of the organization opened this morning in the Assembly chamber at the Capitol and will be continued tomorrow.

LONDON, March 15. -- Neville Chamberlain, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, assured the House of Commons today that legal action threatened by P.A.S. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marine Company, could not prevent the merger of the Cunard and White Star Lines and should not in any way interfere with passage of the government's North Atlantic Shipping Bill.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP). -- Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee tonight agreed tentatively on five important amendments to the administration's reciprocal tariff proposal.

Lieutenant David Jerome Sheahan, who retired from the Police Department on March 2 after thirty-eight years of service, was honored by his former associates last night at a farewell dinner in the Greenwich Village Inn, 5 Sheridan Square.

The newspapers state that in California it is claimed that in one or more Federal court receiverships the receiver and counsel got very large fees but the creditors got nothing. In Chicago there is a big court contest on to find out who really selected the receivers of some of the Insull companies.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 15. -- Seventy-two men from nine Eastern colleges are entered in the thirtieth annual tournament of the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association, which will take place here tomorrow and Saturday.

MANNFORD, Okla., March 15 (AP). -- Hot on the Bremer kidnap trail, Federal and State manhunters today trapped eight persons, some of them linked closely by association with the suspected abductors, in a sudden raid on an Osage country hideaway near this hamlet.

Arthur W. Morse, 34 years old, vice president of Clinch, Morse Co., brokers at 48 Wall Street, was indicted by the grand jury yesterday on a first-degree murder charge in the death of Mrs. Edna Field Leavitt, 26 years old. She was found badly hurt in his apartment at 7 Macdougal Alley early last Tuesday.
Mayor LaGuardia served notice last night that he expects every individual in his administration to sever his active political connections.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 15. -- Although a conference this afternoon with Borough President Lyons of the Bronx over the Mount Vernon-Bronx boundary line prevented Mayor Leslie V. Bateman from signing the city's new tax lien law, he said tonight he would sign it the first thing tomorrow morning.

A meeting of several members of the committee to maintain the Metropolitan Opera was held yesterday at Miss Lucrezia Bori's home, and it was decided to send out the following letter to friends and patrons of opera who subscribed to last year's guarantee fund:
ORLANDO, Fla., March 15. -- Manager Casey Stengel put a commendable idea into execution today with results that brought chagrin to several of his players.

VIENNA, March 15. -- Baron Friedrich R. von Wiesner, leader of the Austrian legitimists, declared in a press conference that legitimism has no connection with party politics but is a movement above political parties which includes citizens of all races, religions and social classes.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 15. -- Top-notch boxers of Harvard Army, Pennsylvania, M.I.T., Penn State, Western Maryland and Syracuse, including two individual champions, title defenders, were quartered here tonight in readiness for the eleventh annual Eastern intercollegiates.

Louise Richards Farnsworth of Salt Lake City has brought to the Montross Gallery between fifty and sixty oils in which she records her impressions of Rocky Mountain landscape. One cannot but feel that Mrs. Farnsworth, although frequently her method of suggestion may fall short of realizing what she desired to convey, has very definitely a point of view of her own.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 15. -- Handsome Dan 2d, the bulldog mascot of the Yale football team, was kidnapped from his New Haven home in the early morning hours today and tonight he is secreted in the environs of Harvard by his confessed abductors, editors of The Harvard Lampoon.

The LaGuardia administration is considering proposals to add $10,000,000 to $11,000,000 to the revenue available to meet the city's obligations under the next budget by imposing new taxes and fees and by sweeping economies.

Informal views of Thomas A. Edison and his friends are given in "Thomas A. Edison: A Modern Olympian," by Mary Childs Nerney. The author was employed near the close of the inventor's life to prepare material for an official biography.

Comparing the United States' position today with that of England in the nineteenth century, William L. Thorp, director of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Department of Commerce, in an address before the National Foreign Trade Council yesterday, said that this country, as a creditor nation, must open its market to imports.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 15 (AP). -- An unexpected delay today forced Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, speeding homeward by air from Puerto Rico, to spend her wedding anniversary Saturday with the President, to remain overnight in this city.

Vincent Astor's offer to sell his East Side tenements to the city at a price below their assessed valuation was amended yesterday in a letter to Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, who is chairman of the Municipal Housing Authority.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh agreed today to testify before a Senate committee tomorrow on permanent air mail legislation, but again refused to serve on a committee named by Secretary Dern to investigate the carrying of air mail by the army.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- "Radical" changes in the navy were opposed by the department's Board on Reorganization in a report approved in general today by President Roosevelt and Secretary Swanson. Their approval is interpreted as indicating that the administration will not endorse Representative Vinson's bill for sweeping changes.

The recent proposal of President Roosevelt for the establishment of a Federal Communications Commission with authority to coordinate, fix rates and supervise service by wire, radio and cable raises numerous important questions. Waiving all constitutional considerations and also the expediency of radical interference with such an important private business, it would seem desirable to delay such action until the alleged beneficial results of the recovery acts appear to be permanent.

The American Steamship Owners Association will demand that the proposed new shipping code provide stabilization of rates on waterborne traffic, it announced yesterday. In resolutions adopted by its members and a statement issued by Ira A. Campbell, its counsel, the association urged foreign-flag lines to agree to the stabilization terms of the code as a means of avoiding further governmental control.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Broad recommendations for code administration and enforcement in the consumers' goods industries were made in a report tonight to General Johnson by the Consumers Industries' Committee, the first of the big committees named by him at the recent code authority conference to study NRA problems.

PEPING, March 15. -- The National Government's long-delayed punitive campaign against Sun Tien-ying's 50,000 rebels was finally launched today as advance detachments of the Shansi and Suiyuan Province armies assaulted General Sun's defenses in Eastern Ningsia.

ROME, March 15. -- The first of the widely-heralded three-cornered meetings of Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy, Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss of Austria and Premier Julius Goemboes of Hungary which are expected to result in a series of bilateral agreements designed to assure the political status quo in Central Europe was held this afternoon and lasted two and three quarters hours.
WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The Stock Exchange regulation bill, carrying some modifying and clarifying amendments, will be taken up again tomorrow by the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency.

A gain of 77.1 per cent in sale for the first fourteen days of March was reported here yesterday by the head of a large department store chain, marking One of the largest increases over a year ago thus far noted. The increases were well diversified in the member stores of the chain throughout the country, with the largest unit in the organization having an increase of 96 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The code for grain Exchanges, the subject of conferences between the AAA and officials of the Chicago Board of Trade for nearly a year, probably will be approved soon, Secretary Wallace said today. It is being scrutinized by the NRA for possible conflicts with the codification policies of that agency.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that, effective yesterday, it had adopted a new form, known as Form F-1, to be used in registering voting trust certificates under the Securities Act, and that in this connection it had adopted rules as to the use of the form and instructions as to its preparation.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- A threat that the recovery administration would impose a code on the wire communication industry unless the industry comes to terms was read between the lines of a notice issued today setting a public hearing for April 2.

LONDON, March 15. -- There is a pleasant-spoken English woman in London who would have the world believe Samuel Insull was spirited out of Athens by English friends, not at about midnight last night as the Athens police declare, but four days ago.

Jonas Lie has, for several years, shown increasing desire to explore esthetic values that transcend those involved in decorative design alone. His present exhibition at the Macbeth Galleries produces evidence of a sometimes signal success in this larger undertaking.

The Treasury spent an additional $50,000,000 of its "free" gold in the last week instead of drawing upon its deposits with commercial banks, it was disclosed in the report of the Federal Reserve Banks, issued yesterday, for the week ended on Wednesday.

Two gunmen, members of one of the city's most desperate band of robbers, were sentenced to long terms in Sing Sing yesterday by Judge Nott in General Sessions. With three others, including William Sutton, a fugitive from Sing Sing at the time, they obtained $23,835 on Jan. 8, 1933, in the hold-up of a branch of the Corn Exchange Bank and Trust Company at Broadway and 110th Street.

Strength in United States Government issues featured an otherwise irregularly lower market for bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Trading in all groups was considerably less than on the previous day, aggregating $16,335,900, against $19,410,500 on Wednesday.

Sir EDWARD ELGAR was a Worcestershire man by birth. His home was at Marl Bank in that shire. At its Broadway, long a colony of artists and literary men, lived and lives Mrs. ALFONSO DE NAVARRO, affectionately remembered in the United States as MARY ANDERSON.

Weakness in silver futures affected nearly all the other commodity markets yesterday, with the result that losses on the day were the rule. Trading was in good volume. Cash prices showed a downward trend.

About 250 priests and monsignori from Roman Catholic parishes throughout the city attended a special "Holy-Hour" service yesterday afternoon in St. Patrick's Cathedral to mark the closing weeks of the Holy Year decreed by Pope Plus XI.

The plan to suspend performances of "The Wind and the Rain," current at the Ritz Theatre, from March 26 through March 30 has been canceled. It is now announced that there will be no interruption in the engagement.

PARIS, March 15. -- There is no great confidence in Paris that the Rome conversations will lead to more than an appearance of success. As Pertinax describes them in the Echo de Paris, the texts that will be adopted "have every likelihood of being remarkable only by their facade."

The Bank of New York and Trust Company celebrated yesterday its first 150 years, receiving felicitations from President Roosevelt, the bank's depositors and the financial community generally. John C. Traphagen, president, greeted employes with the announcement of the payment of a bonus amounting to one-half of a months' salary in connection with' the celebration.

President Roosevelt is expected to sign the three national conservation bills -- the Duck Stamp measure, the Refuge Bill and the Coordination Bill -- very shortly. The duck stamp proposal, after a somewhat curious passage through Congress, now is before the President after its second course in the Senate.

CHICAGO, March 15. -- Prices of grains declined today on the Board of Trade with fairly general selling in wheat, due to the breaks in silver and stocks and to scattered liquidation by longs in the May delivery. An undercurrent of bearishness in trade comment was not counteracted by the continued complaints regarding lack of subsoil moisture in both the Winter and Spring wheat belts.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- From the NRA codes are excluded members of the learned professions, domestic servants and agricultural workers. There are two reasons for this. One relates to the problem of replacement, it having been agreed that in these categories it was insoluble from a practical viewpoint.

In your issue of March 4 appeared a letter from Fred G. Condict, national publicity director of the American Legion, dealing with your review of my book, "Soldiers -- What Next!" He refers to a passage on page 167 reading as follows:

BERLIN, March 15. -- The German Statistical Office announced today that Germany's foreign trade balance for February closed with another deficit, amounting to 34,600,000 marks. This is the first deficit for that month in five years and follows the deficit in January, which was first put at 31,200,000 marks but later corrected to 22,200,000 by a reduction of the import figures.

The Frank F. Pels Company has contracted to sell its silk and bleaching plant in North Bergen to the Palisade Piece Dye Works for $27,500, an agreement filed yesterday shows. The two and three story brick building is on a plot 400 by 125 feet at the southeast corner of Rowland Place and Dell Avenue.

Songs that a new group of Negro singers believed to be authentic African originals possibly for much of the most characteristic of American folklore were presented in Stienway Hall last night by the Mwalimu Festival Chorus of New York.
A last-minute rush of income tax returns swamped Internal Revenue offices throughout the country yesterday, as belated taxpayers scrambled to file before the deadline at midnight.

ALBANY, March 15. -- Republican leaders were amazed today to find on the Assembly calendar one of the important bills in the public utility program recommended by Governor Lehman. They quickly sent it back to a committee.

Free concerts of the CWA today include the Gotham Dance Orchestra at the Seamen's House, Manhattan Concert Band at Public School 136, Capitol String Quartet at Hamilton Fish Library, Empire Quartet at West 115th Street Library, University Chamber Trio at Psychiatric Institute, Brooklyn Trio at Ashland Place Y.W.C.A., Har lem Trio at 135th Street Y.M.C.A., Lucile Collette at Brooklyn's Danish Church, Louise Stallings at Madison House and Seraphima Strelova at the East Side Continuation School.

A total of thirty-nine entries has been made for the three races to be held tomorrow on the estate of Thomas Hitchcock at Aiken, S.C., according to an announcement yesterday from Frank J. Bryan, hunts official. The Aiken Cup, which has attracted a field of fourteen, will be the feature event and is third on the program.

BALBOA, C.Z., March 15. -- The fire which followed the explosion that wrecked the port of La Libertad in El Salvador is now under control, but it is still impossible to estimate the extent of the disaster. Some persons consider the destruction greater than that caused by the earthquake at Managua last year.

A second performance of last Wednesday's International Skating Carnival at Madison Square Garden will be given on March 26 at the same place in aid of the Frontier Nursing Service. The program will feature the same performers, including Sonja Henie of Norway and Karl Schaefer of Austria, world champion figure skaters for many years.

The Rev. Simon Schlager will complete today thirty years as cantor of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, of which for the last few years he has been cantor-emeritus. In celebration of the anniversary he will have a special part in both the service at 5:10 P.M. today and the service at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow.

Kenneth G. Ridgway of the Garden City Casino eliminated Gilbert Carpenter of the Darien B.C., defending champion, 15 -- 6, 17 -- 18, 15 -- 7, to gain the final round in the Metropolitan Association Badminton championship at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory yesterday.

BERLIN, March 15. -- Weakness on the Boerse was accentuated today. Most of the heavy industrials sagged. The market, however, was rather erratic. The electricals showed resistance and a number of specialty stocks and I.G. Farben registered gains.

A seasonal decline in bank clearings took place in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the weekly reports from twenty-two leading cities to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The clearings totaled $4,807,916,000, a decline of $442,980,000, or 8.4 per cent, from the preceding week. Because of the bank holiday last year, no comparison with the corresponding week then can be made.

Assurance that no one in real need now employed under the CWA will lose his job was given yesterday by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Civil Works Administrator, who conferred here with officials of the State CWA and Mayor LaGuardia. Plans for readjustment of the present CWA set-up after its demobilization April 1, as ordered from Washington, were discussed.
ROME, March 15 (By Wireless). -- Here in Rome public opinion expressed privately is, I find, very skeptical of any important result from the conference among the rulers of Italy, Austria and Hungary.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 15 (AP). -- Elwyn Evans of Wilmington was appointed receiver today for the American Electric Power Corporation, which controls through stock ownership the Pennsylvania Gas and Electric Corporation, the Sioux City Gas and Electric Company, and other subsidiaries in Iowa and Pennsylvania.

The development of a vaccine powerful enough to protect mice against from 1,000 to 1,000,000 doses of the virus of the type of encephalitis, commonly known as sleeping sickness, that broke out in St. Louis last Summer, was announced last night by the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses informed the park committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the Rockaways at a conference yesterday in the State Building that he planned extensive improvements for Jacob Riis Park costing about $1,700,000, according to George Wolpert, executive secretary of the chamber.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 15. -- The blow dealt last month to W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, by the Nassau County Executive Committee which voted to prevent the State organization from soliciting funds in that county, was ratified tonight by the Republican County Committee at a heated session here.

LITTLE AMERICA, Antarctica, March 14. -- The single-engined Fokker monoplane, Blue Blade, one of the four planes of the second Byrd Antarctic Expedition, crashed at 12:30 P.M. today, 500 yards south of Little America. The pilot, Lieut. Commander Isaac Schlossbach, U.S.N., retired, and three passengers were severely shaken up and suffered slight cuts, but otherwise were uninjured.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 15. -- Ky Laffoon, young Denver pro who won the Atlanta metropolitan open last Sunday with a great finishing spurt, came through with a fine 68 today in the opening round of the Charleston Tournament of Gardens golf championship.

A rise of $79,000,000 in the total of brokers' loans was reported yesterday by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City in their condition statement for the week ended on Wednesday. The advance, which followed a decline of $14,000,000 last week, brought the total to $923,000,000.

Admiral BYRD'S first accident in the air on his present expedition occurred on Wednesday. The single-engine Fokker, which was wrecked almost as soon as it took the air in a preparatory flight, did not involve its four men in a serious crash. Aside from minor cuts and bruises, no one suffered injury.
Investors were active in the purchase of housing properties in Manhattan yesterday.
TAMPA, Fla., March 15. -- The bus-ridden and somewhat muscle-cramped New York Giants piled into some more National League opposition today and again came out on the short end of the battle.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15. -- Colonel Jacob Ruppert, owner of the Yankees, arrived here today, too late to see Babe Ruth get his first hit of the season in a scrub game at Huggins Field.

The list of the North German Lloyd liner Europa, arriving today from Bremen, Southampton and Cherbourg, includes the Rev. Dr. Frank N.D. Buchman, founder of the Oxford Group, accompanied by fifty-four members of the international team which visited London last Fall and which will now hold a series of meetings here and in Canada.
Lieutenant William B. Kunzig of Fort Meade, Maryland, won the national junior saber championship in the final of the competition at the New York Athletic Club last night.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed total gold holdings and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date, while total bills discounted reached a new low for the year.

A ship-to-shore broadcast by wireless telephone from the Europa brought the voice of the Rev. Dr. Frank N.D. Buchman and other members of the international team of the Oxford Group into the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night to address the meeting of the local Oxford Group which was to have welcomed the visitors in person.

Competition for the business of Henry Goldman Jr. on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, which began shortly after he sent a letter to Senator Fletcher recommending changes in Stock Exchange operation late last year, has ceased to exist, it was learned yesterday.

The Annalist index of business activity shows a rise of 3.4 points for February to 76.5 (preliminary) from 73.1 for January. The gain since the low of last year amounts to 18 points, while the decrease from the high has been cut to 13 points.

The final Wagner performance of the special matinee series in the Metropolitan Opera House was given yesterday afternoon, with an interpretation of "Meistersinger" that was of an uncommonly high standard, and capped with the Eva of Lotte Lehmann.

OTTAWA, March 15. -- Alex Connell, one-time king of National Hockey League goalies, replaced Roy Worters when the net-minder for the New York Americans was injured tonight and helped beat his own team, the Ottawa Senators, 3 -- 2.

Asserting that its income was insufficient to meet current interest obligations, the Alleghany Corporation announced yesterday that it proposed a financial plan of readjustment to avoid the possibility of a forced sale of its holdings in the Van Sweringen railroad system.

The LaGuardia administration renewed yesterday the warfare between the city and the "interests" that has been waged, off and on, for two decades. At the same time an administration measure designed to protect the five-cent fare on the city's subways was introduced in the Legislature.

PATERSON, N.J., March 15. -- John McCutcheon announced today that he would not be a candidate for reappointment as State Controller of New Jersey. He issued his statement after State Senator John C. Barbour had said that he would not nominate him or vote for him.

Augusto Rosso, Italian Ambassador at Washington; Antonio Grossardi, Italian Consul General here, and other prominent New Yorkers are interested in an Italian festival to be held tonight on board the Conte di Savoia at West Eighteenth Street for the benefit of the Dante Alighieri Society and the Leonardo da Vinci Art School.

Stephen F. Voorhees, architect and chairman of the NRA code for the construction industry, urged builders and allied interests yesterday to support the new regulations. He spoke at the March luncheon meeting of the New York Building Congress in the Hotel Commodore.

The Phillips Petroleum Company and subsidiaries report for 1933 a net profit of $1,500,695, including a profit on the company's bonds acquired, a refund of Federal taxes and 2,320,727 inventory credit adjustment, and after providing for taxes, interest, intangible development costs, depletion, amortization and depreciation.

If the public of this city had no other debt to Arturo Toscanini, it would be under immense obligation for his interpretations of such works as the Haydn "horn signal" symphony, performed last night by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall.

Edgar L.G. Prochnik, Austrian Minister to the United States, declared in an address yesterday at a luncheon of the Merchants Association in the Bankers Club, that the peace of Europe depends on the stabilization of Austria through trade relations with the rest of the world.
U.S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

HAVANA, March 15. -- Many arrests were made today in the city of Camaguey by the military authorities among employes of the Consolidated Railways following the dynamiting of a train which resulted in the injury of three soldiers.

LONDON, March 15. -- The Oxford-Cambridge boat race Saturday will be set to music and the tinkle of bells from the racing craft will indicate that the rowing giants are struggling with an ear cocked for secret signals.

Announcement was made yesterday of a plan of reorganization of Realty Foundation. Inc., which has been approved by the reorganization committee. It calls for the formation of a new corporation to be known, probably, as Foundation Properties, Inc.
Substantial progress in clearing up the defaulted mortgage and mortgage certificate situation, which confronted him when he took office was reported yesterday by A.A. Berle Jr., City Chamberlain.

The general principles of a comprehensive plan for bringing adequate medical care within the reach of most American people were outlined and discussed yesterday at the annual meeting of the Advisory Council of the Milbank Memorial Fund at the New York Academy of Medicine.
PHILADELPHIA, March 15. -- Philadelphia will have no Metropolitan Opera presentations during the next season.

LOUISVILLE, March 15 (AP). -- A demand from the Kentucky House that President Roosevelt recall Robert W. Bingham, United States Ambassador to London, unless his newspaper revealed the author of "The Psalm of Politics" came late today in a renewal of the warfare over whether a newspaper man should violate a confidence.
Reliance Pictures, currently represented on the screen with "Palooka," announced yesterday the signing of Claudette Colbert for one picture.

Tom Iannicelli of the Essex Club, runner-up for the title a year ago, advanced to the quarter-final round of the Metropolitan open squash tennis championship at the Hotel Shelton last night. Iannicelli vanquished Ed Standing of the Yale Club in straight games, 15 -- 6, 15 -- 6, 1 -- 3.

The Treasury announced yesterday the result of its latest offer. Short-term certificates amounting to $460,000,000 were due to mature on March 15. Last week the Treasury invited their exchange for new four-year notes bearing interest at 3 per cent. It is now announced that holders of $455,000,000 of the maturing paper accepted, leaving only $5,000,000 to be redeemed in cash.

BARCELONA, Friday, March 16. -- The regional government was forced to man with police reserves and soldiers all plants supplying both gas and electric light as well as electric power to Barcelona, Saragossa and all towns and villages in Catalonia and the province of Aragon when 28,000 members of the Socialist and syndicalist workers' unions struck at midnight.
ATHENS, Friday, March 16. -- Greek police charged early today that the sensational escape of Samuel Insull from Athens was engineered by an international criminal gang operating from Rumania.

The Metropolitan Opera Company's third performance this season of "Madama Butterfly" of Puccini brought forth a new Sharpless in the person of George Cehanovsky, baritone, who has been for a number of years a member of the Metropolitan's large family.

Squadron A's indoor polo team won its way to the final round of the Manhattan circuit championship with a second-round victory over the Riding Club at Squadron A Armory last night, 13 1/2 to 2. The winners were in control of the game throughout.

Consolidated net income of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries for 1933 amounted to $694,126, equal to 11 cents a share on 6,399,002 common shares, in contrast with a loss of $3,934,960 in 1932. Net income of $7,654,001 was reported for 1931.

PARIS, March 15. -- After a careful examination of the extensive remains of the "sea monster" found on the shore near Cherbourg, Professor Petit and his colleagues of the French Museum of Natural History have definitely concluded that this fish is a basking shark, selache maxima, called pilgrim shark in France.

After hesitating for two days, the share market turned definitely reactionary yesterday afternoon. Stocks pointed downward at the beginning of the fifth hour, led by the mining and metal group. There was a partial recovery just before the close, however, and the net losses averaged only about a point.

YONKERS, N.Y., March 15. -- A bomb which exploded on the front porch of a large eight-room house here tonight blew the front door from its hinges, splintered near-by woodwork and shattered the windows as well as those in homes near by.

Because The Louisville Courier-Journal had published an article reflecting on the Kentucky Legislature, the editor was summoned by a committee of the sensitive Assembly, which demanded that he give up the name of the author. This he refused to do. He held that it would be, in the first place, a violation of confidence, and, besides, would be against a fundamental principle of journalism.
A hold-up man was shot and wounded critically last night in a chase on Lexington Avenue at East Eighty-sixth Street amid a crowd of several thousand persons, a number of whom joined in the pursuit.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 15. -- A police guard has been placed at the home of Mrs. Fredericka Fry Del Guercio, heiress to Timken millions, following receipt of a warning that plans were being made to kidnap her and Eligio, her 2-year-old son.

Palmer H. Graham, acting dean of the New York University Washington Square College, announced yesterday that 128 students have been commended for high scholarship during the first semester of the academic year. An average of more than 91 per cent is required for recognition on the commended list.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
WASHINGTON, March 15. -- President Roosevelt issued an executive order barring from sales to the government all business men or corporations that have not signed NRA codes.

TAMPA, Fla., March 15. -- A lot of wild-eyed fellows have been going through Tampa for weeks past and the Tampa police haven't stood in their way. In fact, the police have been helpful to the extent of giving them directions for the happy continuation of their journeys.

LONDON, March 15. -- The existence of triple weight hydrogen, hitherto suspected but not proved, may be demonstrated by an atom-smashing experiment just made by Lord Rutherford, Drs. M.L. Oliphant and P. Hartleck in Cambridge's Cavendish Laboratory and scheduled for announcement to the scientific world through the forthcoming issue of Nature.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Legislation giving broad powers to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for direct loans to private industry and for financing foreign trade was submitted to Congress today by the RFC.

The ranking tennis player of the country and the one who has been most prominently mentioned with him as a candidate for the 1934 Davis Cup single assignments, were eliminated from the national indoor championship yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16. -- Everything was perfect for the Yankees today. Colonel Jacob Ruppert made a successful last round-up of his hold-out problem by signing Catcher Bill Dickey and Infielder Lyn Lary. The Yanks opened their Spring exhibition tour against the Boston Braves at Waterfront Park with a 6-to-4 victory.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.
