To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just seen a copy of the questionnaires distributed by the CWA to its employees. Never have I seen so humiliating and so debasing an instrument.

A labor union official accused of agreeing to discontinue a strike in a Brooklyn wood-turning plant for $250 was arrested yesterday in front of a restaurant at 64 East Thirty-second Street on a charge of extortion.

Judged by the commission-house comment as well as by the firm tone of the share market, Wall Street did not take so seriously yesterday as it did on Thursday the threat of a crippling strike in the flourishing automotive industry. The average price of industrial stocks showed a net enhancement of about one-half point and there were gains of several points in specially favored issues.

The number of employes of the International Business Machines Company was increased 23.8 per cent in the second half of last year and the average hourly rate of wages was increased 17.8 per cent, according to the annual report of the company issued yesterday.

MOSCOW, March 16. -- Several members of the British Consulate's staff tonight were reported killed or wounded and 2,000 Ulgurs, comprising most of the civil population of the town of Kashgar in Sinkiang, Chinese Turkestan [just north of Kashmir, India], were massacred in fierce fighting between rebellious Tungan natives and forces of the newly proclaimed "independent government."

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 16. -- The electric light boycott at San Juan, ineffective some days ago, is becoming progressively successful, with fully 75 per cent of the advertising signs and store windows dark last night or dimly illumined with kerosene lamps and lanterns.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 16. -- A bond Issue of $2,437,000 of the county of Westchester was authorized today by the budget committee of the Board of Supervisors. The issue, to be sold the first week in April, is the smallest annual county bond sale in many years.

CHICAGO, March 16. -- Colonel Frank Knox, publisher of The Chicago Daily News, speaking over a National Broadcasting Company radio hookup tonight, discussed the Wagner bill in terms of "sound labor policies."

In furtherance of the "Church-wide Endeavor, 1934," which was opened on Jan. 21 by the Most Rev. James De Wolf Perry, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, a special parish corporate communion service will be held tomorrow, Passion Sunday, in every church of that denomination in the world.
" Wild Cargo," Frank Buck's sequel to "Bring 'Em Back Alive," will be nationally released by RKO Radio Pictures on March 30. The date of the Broadway opening has not been announced.

Even if the city obtains legislation offsetting the recent ruling of the Court of Appeals on the financing of the debt service on its subway lines now in operation, it cannot use tax funds to pay interest and amortization already accrued, transit experts contended yesterday.

DUBLIN, March 16. -- As head of the Irish Government I am happy to respond to an invitation from THE NEW YORK TIMES and send greetings to our kindred and friends in the United States on this day when the minds of Ireland's exiled children will be turned to the motherland.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh denounced as unjust the pending bill for returning the air mail to private operation when he appeared today at a hearing held by the Senate committee on post offices. As in his recent telegram to President Roosevelt, he condemned the cancellation of air mail contracts held by private carriers.

Amid the Virgilian landscapes of Central Park, the shy goatherds of Manhattan will bathe in the sweet light of publicity this morning, when they assemble at 11 o'clock to consecrate the choicest of their flocks to Bacchus. Their goats, all of them distinctly masculine, and rather belligerent about it, too, will lock horns (but only figuratively, the judges hope) in a beauty contest to determine the winner of the title, "Mr. Manhattan."

Of the $10,262,475 of new issues of municipal bonds scheduled for award next week, $4,548,000 will represent refunding of primary road bonds by eighteen counties in Iowa. Forty-six of the forty-nine counties in that State will endeavor to refund their primary road obligations this month.

It is good to learn that the "demobilization" of the CWA army in this State is to be carried out in such a way as to work the least possible hardship. Civil works were originally intended as a measure of recovery as well as relief, but conditions in and about New York were such that the new "recruits" turned out to be mostly veterans.

AIKEN, S.C., March 16. -- Mrs. T.H. Somerville's Trouble Maker, the aged gelding which has annexed the Maryland Gold Cup, Carolina Cup and Meadow Brook Cup and which was among the finishers in the Grand National last year, is expected to go to the post as the favorite in the Aiken Cup Steeplechase tomorrow.

MIAMI, Fla., March 16. -- Striking suddenly on the eve of the big Florida Derby classic, 125 horsemen at Hialeah today protested against past procedures of the Florida Racing Commission in its crusade to stamp out the stimulation of horses.

CHICAGO, March 16. -- Major Gen. Benjamin D. Foulois, chief of the Army Air Corps, will report tomorrow to the War Department upon the ability of the army air mail service to resume flying of the mails. After a conference this afternoon with the three commandants directly in charge of the mail flying the general indicated that he would recommend the immediate resumption of the mail flights.

MIAMI, March 16 (AP). -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt arrived here by commercial airliner soon after noon today, completing an eleven-day economic survey flight to Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands in which she covered 2,836 air miles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Why should it be necessary for pedestrians in crossing the street, with a green light in their favor, to have to hop, skip and jump or beat a hasty retreat to the curb in order to avoid being hit by some arrogant driver, who has no intention of stopping, simply because he intends to turn to the right at the intersection?

BERLIN, March 16. -- Addressing the American Chamber of Commerce of Berlin tonight at its annual dinner at the Hotel Adlon, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, delivered a plea that was also an ultimatum to Germany's creditors for the further writing down, if not entire wiping out, of her commercial debt on the ground that its inception was political.

LONDON, March 16. -- The stock market was dull today. Home rails were weak on talk of action to obtain restoration of wage cuts, while rubber shares were affected adversely by reports of possible labor troubles in the United States motor industry. Silver mines declined sharply on reports concerning the United States silver policy, the price of the metal falling to 20 1-16d an ounce.

ATHENS, March 16. -- Samuel Insull is on his way back to Greece tonight on the 1,700-ton Greek freighter Maiotis, on which he had tried to escape to Persia. His bold gamble against return to the United States ended ingloriously today when his ship was crossing the Mediterranean, bound for Basra, Iraq, near the head of the Persian Gulf.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- E. Edward Horja, administrative assistant to Secretary of the Interior Ickes, was appointed today by Postmaster General Farley as his assistant in the office of the Democratic National Committee. He will assume his new duties about April 1 and be the actual directing head under Mr. Farley.

Brig. Gen. John J. Byrne was elected president of the Military-Naval Club at a meeting yesterday at the clubhouse, 3 West Forty-third Street. Colonel Alexander J. Macnab was elected vice president; Lieutenant Clarence A. Ludlum Jr., treasurer, and Commander H. McCoy Jones, secretary.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 16. -- Raymond W. (Ducky) Pond, new head coach of Yale football, put seventy-five candidates for the 1934 team through the hardest early practice Yale has seen in many years as the first Spring workout got under way today in the Yale Armory.

Familiar landmarks are discernible here and there above the swirling tides of change. American industry is being revolutionized, but the editors of The Harvard Lampoon have kidnapped the Yale football team's mascot bulldog.

In disciplinary proceedings brought against fifteen lawyers as a result of the Seabury investigation of the Magistrates' Courts four years ago the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday disbarred Abraham Karp and Emanuel A. Busch, censured Mark Alter and cleared William J. McAuliffe by a vote of three to two.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 16. -- The eleventh annual tournament of the Eastern Intercollegiate Boxing Association started today in the gymnasium of Syracuse University.

Appearing refreshed and in good spirits, Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of New York, returned to the city on the Rotterdam yesterday after a six-week visit to the Bahama Islands. He went there to induct as a Bishop the Most Rev. Bernard Kevenhoerster, Prefect Apostolic oil the Bahamas.

The Rev. Dr. Frank N.D. Buchman, leader of the Oxford Group, arrived on the North German Lloyd liner Europa yesterday with fifty-three members of his international group, who will meet with followers of the movement here and in Boston and later in the month attend a "house party" at the Chateau Frontenac in Quebec.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 16. -- Horace Tennes of Chicago, Jean Dupuy of France and Antonio Becchi of Italy captured the honors as the international motorboat racing was resumed today on Lake Worth before 10,000 spectators.

Kenneth J. Ridgway of the Garden City Casino triumphed over Mills P. Baker of the same club, 12 -- 15, 15 -- 8, 15 -- 11, to capture the second annual Metropolitan Association badminton championship at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory yesterday.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 16. -- Craig Wood of Deal, N.J., shot a fine sub par 70 today to add to his opening round 69 for a thirty-six hole total of 139 and a one-stroke lead in the Charleston open golf tournament.

The Passaic County grand jury which investigated Judge William B. Harley's charge that his appointment cost him $25,000 declared in a presentment handed up in Paterson, N.J., yesterday that if the judge had not made the contribution "the job would have gone to the highest bidder."

MOSCOW, March 16. -- The record stratosphere flight of the Soviet balloon, Osoaviakhim 1, ended in the crash of the gondola on Sept. 30 because the three aeronauts had expended too much ballast and because of a structural defect, according to the report of Air Commander Prokovieff, a member of the inquiry commission.

TORONTO, Ont., March 16. -- Martin J. Insull, former Chicago utilities magnate, and a brother of Samuel Insull, must go back to Illinois to face trial on theft charges, the Court of Appeals at Osgoode Hall ruled today. It was held that there was a prima facie case on charges of misuse of corporation funds which were used to protect stock trading accounts.
High school teachers now employed as substitutes cannot compel the Board of Education to appoint them as regular teachers, under a ruling of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday.

Income tax returns were filed by approximately 370,000 Manhattan taxpayers, including between 160,000 and 170,000 in the Second Internal Revenue District below Fourteenth Street, who paid upward of $20,000,000, according to a check of the first quarterly instalment of the 1933 income tax made yesterday by Collectors of Internal Revenue.

Margarete Dessoff and the Vecchi Singers, assisted by a group of instrumentalists, gave a program of distinctive attractiveness at the French Institute last night. It was the second concert of the Desoff Choirs, and was devoted almost entirely to music of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries. Walter Porter, John Bull, Monteverdi, Michelangelo Rossi, Domenico Scarlatti and Clement Jannequin were the composers represented.

The French liner Paris, sailing today for Plymouth and Havre, will have on board Prince Georges Matchabelli, Mr. and Mrs. J.R. Wiersdma Sr., director of the Holland-America Line; Dr. Homer Gage, president of the Worcester (Mass.) Welfare Foundation, and Jeanne Aubert, actress.

Celebration of its one hundred and fiftieth anniversary by the Bank of New York and Trust Company was an interesting reminder of the fact that, even in this country, there are banking institutions whose history stretches back into the distant past. We are accustomed to think of a New York bank whose charter dates even to Civil War times as a venerable institution.

The directors of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company declared yesterday a dividend of $2.50 a share on the 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock. This payment, which is to be made on April 1, covers the $1.50 a share due on July 1, 1933, while the remaining $1 a share is in part payment of the $1.50 distribution which was due on Oct. 1, 1933.

WARSAW, March 16. -- The Parliamentary budget session was closed today by decree of President Moscicki without the Senate's having made into law the new Constitution so unexpectedly passed by the Sejm.

Models of four historic New York buildings made by unemployed architects were presented to the Museum of the City of New York yesterday as a gift from an anonymous donor. They will form the nucleus of a future gallery to be devoted to New York architecture, and will go on view in May.

Sales of electric power throughout the United States in January amounted to 5,910,809,000 kilowatt-hours, an increase of 10 per cent over January, 1933, when sales were 5,372,566,000 kilowatt-hours, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

The executive committee of the North American Yacht Racing Union has approved the selection of trustees to handle the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Trophy and is seeking a club to conduct the final races next Summer, it was learned yesterday.

Frederick D. Thompson, secretary of the uptown branch of the Y.M.C.A. at 74 West 124th Street, was elected Republican leader of the Thirteenth Assembly District early yesterday morning after a stormy session of five hours at which twelve ballots were taken.

Confidence in American liberal education, as opposed to the "thought-moulding processes of certain European countries," was voiced last night by several speakers at a dinner of 450 New York alumni of Phillips Academy, Andover Mass., in the Hotel Roosevelt.

The last of the major indoor track meets will be staged in Madison Square Garden tonight and, like its four predecessors, the fifteenth annual Knights of Columbus games are expected to attract a crowd of more than 15,000.

Austria's position in relation to world peace as "a place of gravitation in Europe" was stressed by Edgar Prochnik, Austrian Minister in Washington, at a luncheon given by members of the Austrian Trade Commission on the eve of their departure for Europe after a brief visit to the industrial centres of this country.
LONDON, March 16. -- Reports reaching here from the Continent today declared that France and Italy had reached an agreement concerning both disarmament and the affairs of the Danubian States.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Following is the text of the bill drawn by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and submitted to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee to authorize the RFC to make loans to industry and business:
ROME, Saturday, March 17 (AP). -- Mgr. Moses Kiley was consecrated Bishop of Trenton, N.J., this morning in Santa Susanna, the American Church, by Raffaello Carlo Cardinal Rossi.

What is sure to prove of most interest in the current one-man show of recent paintings by Joseph Pollet at the Downtown Gallery (remaining until the end of the month) is the series known as the "Composers' Group." For this series Mr. Pollet has chosen four great masters; Bach, Mozart, Beethoven and Wagner.

Celebrating the second anniversary of its existence, the Midtown Gallery is holding a group show of canvases by a score of artists, water-colors by nearly as many more, and sculpture by two others. Isabel Bishop and Saul Berman are missing from the roster, but most of the rest of the Midtown members are typically represented by new work.

Deals reported yesterday indicate a continuance of the demand for apartment houses in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn. Investment transactions of this type have featured the real estate market in this city in recent weeks.
DETROIT, March 16. -- Directors of the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce today denounced the Wagner Labor Bill as a threat to the welfare of the country.

" One More Honeymoon," a new farce by Leo F. Reardon, will open at the Little Theatre on March 31 or April 2. "Furnished Rooms," which had formerly been announced for that theatre, will open elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Angered by Secretary Morgenthau's statement of yesterday that some silver advocates were not entirely disinterested, Speaker Rainey announced today that he would call up Monday the Dies silver bill, which provides for the exchange of American surplus farm products for foreign silver.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., March 16. -- Chicora Sensation, a black and white ticked English setter, owned by George W. Cole of Bridgewater, Conn., today captured the Derby Stake, featured event of the first day's program of the North Shore Game Protective Association's annual field trials.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Commissioner O'Ryan's plan of ostracism for professional criminals seems to me a very common-sense method of ridding New York City of habitual felons. I was very much impressed at a Senate hearing on crime-prevention laws a few years ago by Mayor Frank Hague, who described his method of ridding Jersey City of gangsters.

The authorization sought from Congress by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to make direct loans to industrial and commercial concerns recalled to bankers yesterday the experiences of the Federal Reserve Banks with such loans.

A landscape by Corot, "La Barque a la Pointe de l'lle," painted between 1860 and 1865, brought $4,100 last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., at an auction sale of paintings from the collection of Stanford White, Mrs. Annie D. Drake and Miss Helen V. Drake of Chicago and others. The Corot painting was bought by a private collector who used the buying name D.C. Crawford.
ALBANY, March 16. -- Signing by Governor Lehman of the Steingut bill to permit municipalities to distribute cash relief to the needy was announced today at the executive office.

Mayor LaGuardia and members of the Board of Estimate inspected yesterday seven sites in Queens that have been recommended as locations for the borough civic centre. Before the inspection the group attended a luncheon at the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing as the guests of District Attorney Charles S. Colden of Queens.
WASHINGTON, March 16. -- President Roosevelt conferred with Governor Lehman on New York State's relief problem.

PARIS, March 16. -- The unremitting vigilance of the Ministry of Finance prevented Alexandre Stavisky from foisting his Hungarian optants bonds on the French public, and this ended his career as a swindler, Georges Bonnet, former Minister of Finance, told the parliamentary inquiry commission today.

PARIS, March 16. -- Exercising for the first time the full tariff powers granted by Parliament, the French Government today increased the duties on many imported products, including some American goods. These increases take effect immediately without Parliament's approval.

Postponement of the public hearing on fishing and hunting bills from next Wednesday until Tuesday, March 27, as announced yesterday by the State Conservation Department, will permit sportsmen and Commissioner Lithgow Osborne and his staff more time to draw up additional measures and to study those which already have been formulated.

DOORN, Holland, March 16. -- Although the inmates of Doorn House are not inclined to confirm reports of a Hohenzollern family conference, which according to reliable information was held there this week, no effort is made to deny that there are financial troubles because of measures taken by the present German Government.

The Monte Carlo Ballet Russe last night gave by far the best program it has yet given in its season at the St. James Theatre, consisting of a revival of Fokine's "Carnaval," the first performance here of Balanchine's "Cotillon," and a repetition of Massine's "Le Tricorne," with himself this time in the principal role.

Stocks of refined copper throughout the world in February declined about 19,000 tons to 612,500 tons, according to estimates in the trade. Supplies in North and South America, most of which are held in the United States, decreased 16,000 tons to 511,500.
LONDON, March 16. -- The launching of T.O.M. Sopwith's America's Cup challenger, Endeavour, likely will be delayed from the original date to April 14 to April 19, it was learned today.

The Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise, founder and rabbi of the Free Synagogue, will celebrate his sixtieth birthday today. The anniversary will be the occasion for a celebration by friends throughout the nation, who regard Dr. Wise as one of the outstanding leaders of world Jewry.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 16. -- Cornell's tennis forces today led six other colleges into the semi-final round of the singles and doubles play in the invitation intercollegiate indoor tennis tournament on the courts of the Cornell drill hall.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.
GENEVA, March 16 (AP). -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler was represented as an apostle of peace, not war, in an arms memorandum sent to Paris last Tuesday and made public here tonight.

All efforts to end the intermittent warfare between Bolivia and Paraguay over the Chaco have thus far failed. High hopes were held that the friendly offer of good offices by the League of Nations, supplemented by a definite plan of settlement, would bring about peace. But that intervention was also frustrated.
Upper Fifth Avenue will echo to Irish tunes this afternoon as 20,000 Irishmen pay tribute to the patron saint of Erin in the annual St. Patrick's Day parade.

With the closing of entries, the tournament committee of the Indoor Polo Association announced yesterday complete schedules for the Eastern, national intercollegiate and interscholastic championships, which start in New York City next Saturday and run through April 7, with a total of twenty matches to be played in the various classes.

The performance of Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" last night in the Metropolitan Opera House was given particular interest for a curious and attentive public by the first appearnce of Paul Althouse in one of the title roles. The rest of the cast included the finely composed and nobly conceived Isolde of Frida Leider; Mme. Olszewska's rich voiced and effective, if uneven, Brangaene: Mr. Hoffman's Mark and Mr. Schutzendorf's Kurvenal.
Mayor LaGuardia may be asked to appear before the Kings County grand jury to explain the circumstances of his recent "raid" on the home of Christian Klosset of 807 Quincy Street, Brooklyn.

An appeal to Chief Justice Hughes of the United States Supreme Court and probably to Congress for the return of the famous Gellatly art collection to the estate of the collector is planned by Edward A. Alexander, counsel for Mrs. Charlyne Whitely Gellatly, the widow, it was disclosed yesterday.

A statutory court, in a decision on conditions under the New Deal, ruled yesterday that loss of business caused by regulation of industry by government did not mean that regulation was unconstitutional.

ATHENS, March 16. -- Samuel Insull, whose sensational attempt to escape on a Greek tramp steamer was frustrated today by irate government officials, will be arrested immediately on his return tomorrow and turned over to United States authorities.
Protests against any limitation on the number of taxicabs here were voiced at a hearing yesterday conducted by the Mayor's Taxicab Survey Committee at City Hall.

A bill of foreclosure against the elevated lines of the Manhattan Railway Company was filed yesterday with Federal Judge Julian W. Mack by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as trustee of $40,683,000 of Manhattan Railway consolidated mortgage bonds.

Retail trade during the week developed a faster pre-Easter pace, with consumer interest in women's Spring apparel and accessories gaining sharply. As in other sections of the country, the best suit business in several years is now being done.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass, March 16. -- Yale can have its Handsome Dan if Harvard gets back its Sacred Ibis.
Lester Stoefen, the giant Los Angeles youth, will be a party to both of the national indoor tennis finals today at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 16. -- Led by David Livingston, who qualified in three events, Yale University's championship Intercollegiate Swimming Association squad gained ten places in tomorrow night's finals during today's preliminary competition in the association's twenty-eighth annual individual title meet at Rutgers University.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Setting a precedent in such cases, the Interstate Commerce Commission ruled today that it would not withhold approval of loans to railroads for buying new equipment, even if these loans might result in furloughing of workers.

Secretary MORGENTHAU has turned a cold shoulder to the enthusiasm of the silver bloc in Congress. After a conference with members of the House, he made it clear that the administration does not desire additional monetary legislation at this time. To newspaper correspondents he expressed the opinion that so far as currency measures are concerned "it's a good time to sit tight."

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Enactment of the pending Stock Exchange control bill in its present form would be "a national disaster," states a hitherto undisclosed report to Secretary Roper by the Business Advisory and Planning Council. The report is now before President Roosevelt in connection with other proposals which would drastically modify the measure.

BERLIN, March 16. -- The Boerse was dull and sagging today. Some specialties, like cellulose, breweries and I.G. Farben, scored minor gains, but the majority of the list turned down. Most changes were merely fractional, but reached one to two points in individual instances.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Obituaries of Herman Behr, while noting his success, probity and philanthropy as a manufacturer, have usually limited a knowledge of his avocation of art and literature to an intimate circle -- his achievements to those of an amateur.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Senate amendments increasing veterans benefits and Federal pay $354,000,000 in the Independent Offices Supply Bill were rejected today by the House, which by the narrowest margin insisted upon the House amendments that cut the increases to about $243,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- President Roosevelt intervened personally today to break the deadlock which has held the New York City Economy Bill in the Legislature at Albany. He told Senator John J. Dunnigan and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut, Democratic leaders in their respective houses, that action should be taken soon.

While rumblings of labor unrest developed some irregularities in the heavy industries during the week, distribution and production of consumer goods continued to show heavy percentage gains over the same period a year ago, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The New Deal consumer was put under the business microscope yesterday at the packaging clinic of the American Management Association at the Hotel Astor, when outstanding advertising and merchandising authorities expressed their opinions as to his present-day attitude.

The strange adventures of Mr. INSULL recall the fate of WILLIAM M. TWEED. It was on Dec. 4, 1875, that Boss TWEED escaped from Ludlow Street jail, where, after serving a year in prison on criminal charges, he was being held in $3,000,000 bail to await trial in a civil suit.

United States Government bonds featured the bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday, with gains ranging from 1-32 to 10-32 point as domestic corporation issues and leading foreign loans moved irregularly lower. Comparative scarcity of offerings rather than heavy buying sent the Treasury long-term bonds higher.
Conveyance of two store buildings in the downtown shopping section of Jersey City featured the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Strikes in automobile and accessories plants in Detroit, Pontiac, Flint, Cleveland and St. Louis next Wednesday morning will depend upon the outcome of a conference of the executive committee of the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce in New York on Monday.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- More than $4,000,000 worth of commercial and industrial securities are filed for registration under the Securities Act in a group of ten registration statements announced today by the Federal Trade Commission.

The demand for new money being very light, the market was quiet and rates remained unchanged. Stock Exchange call loans renewed at 1 per cent, with some business being done on the outside at 3/4 per cent.

CHICAGO, March 16 (AP). -- The Daily News says it has learned that suit to break an $8,000,000 trust fund set up by John D. Rockefeller for his daughter, the late Edith Rockefeller McCormick, will be filed in New York next week by Mrs. Muriel Hubbard, Mrs. McCormick's daughter, who lives in the East.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Virtual agreement on a code was reached today by various groups in the investment banking business at conferences with A.D. Whiteside, division administrator. The code is expected to go to President Roosevelt for approval soon.

ATHENS, March 16 (By Cable). -- According to the extradition treaty between Greece and the United States, Samuel Insull's case was legally closed after two verdicts in the Greek courts against extradition.
Futures prices moved irregularly yesterday on local commodity exchanges. A feature of the dealings was partial recovery in silver. Trading was somewhat reduced. Cash prices were mixed.

There will probably be no public celebration tomorrow of the anniversary of the birth of GROVER CLEVELAND, but he is not forgotten and will be remembered among the great Presidents of the United States. When Mr. CLEVELAND reached his seventieth birthday the flags for the first time in a half century were ordered raised by the Mayor of New York in honor of a private citizen.
BUENOS AIRES, March 16. -- Argentina will withdraw from the Pan-American Postal Union on April 1 and double the postage after that date on letters going to other American republics.

MADRID, March 16. -- Naval electrical engineers were rushed to Barcelona today from Cartagena to operate light and power plants. It was officially denied, however, by the Catalan regional government that martial law had been proclaimed there as a result of the gas and electrical workers' strike.

Although the possibility of serious labor difficulties in the automotive industry had a chilling effect upon financial sentiment, the share market recovered its composure yesterday and resumed its slow and indecisive movement. Trading on the Stock Exchange was a little less active than on Thursday when the market passed through a rather sharp reaction.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 16. -- Holder of the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association championship for the past three years, Lehigh saw its leadership seriously challenged tonight as the first day's competition in the thirtieth annual tournament came to a close.
ALBANY, March 16. -- Passage of a State law paralleling the National Securities Act was urged today by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. in his annual report to the Legislature.

LITTLE AMERICA, Antarctica, March 16. -- The past forty-eight hours have been among the busiest and most exciting periods since Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd arrived here at the head of his second expedition to the Antarctic.

The largest owner of tenements in the city is the city itself, with about 400 buildings, many of them firetraps, on its hands, which it has acquired through condemnation proceedings, Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, revealed yesterday.
The New York Curb Exchange yesterday removed from unlisted trading eleven stock issues. On Thursday, the Exchange removed from listing twenty-one issues. The following issues were removed yesterday:

LOS ANGELES, March 16. -- Katharine Hepburn, youthful Bryn Mawr graduate, who came to Hollywood after a short stage apprenticeship in New York, was voted tonight the outstanding motion picture actress of the last year and a half for her performance in "Morning Glory," an RKO Radio production.

PARIS, March 16 (AP). -- The proposal to permit amateurs to compete against professionals in open tennis tournaments was embodied in a proposed change in the defini tion of the term "amateur," and was flatly rejected by a large majority, but the door was left slightly open for amateurs to meet pros in occasional exhibition matches.
Miss Cornelia Van Auken Chapin gave a dinner last night in the Regency Room of the Carlyle for Mr. and Mrs. Sandford Jaques of Pass Creek Ranch, Wyo. The other guests were:

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Authority to sell $1,200,000 of Northern Central Railway Company general and refunding 4 1/2 per cent bonds to Kuhn, Loeb Co. was requested by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company today in an application to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

ROME, March 16. -- A complete agreement on all points that have been discussed in the conference here of Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy, Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss of Austria and Premier Julius Goemboes of Hungary will be signed tomorrow, it was announced tonight.

CAMDEN, N.J., March 16. -- Following an argument over the proposed expenditure of a son's first pay check, Robley M. Wood, 50 years old, of 1,530 Park Boulevard, a water filter salesman, shot and killed his wife and his son, Wilbur, 22, and then committed suicide at their home tonight.

The International Mercantile Marine Company's injunction suit in the British courts against the merger of the White Star and Cunard steamship lines is to be followed by the construction of a sister ship to the cabin liners Washington and Manhattan, and possibly a second ship of the same type, for the United States Lines.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Authority for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to enter the banking business on a large scale in granting loans up to five years' maturity to industries which are under NRA codes, as well as important powers dealing with its part in the reorganization of railroads and the financing of exports, are sought in the bill which has been placed before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee by the RFC.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers:
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The new Municipal Housing Authority will have its main offices at 10 East Fortieth Street and hopes to be functioning by the end of next week, Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch, president of the National Housing Conference and member of the authority, disclosed yesterday.

Mayor Heber Ermentrout of Reading, Pa., headed a party of 405 fellow-citizens who journeyed to Manhattan yesterday, heard one of their home-town boys sing the hero of "Tristan" at the Metropolitan Opera House, were photographed with the singer on the stage after the performance of Wagner's music drama, and at midnight returned to their special train at Jersey City. due home in Reading at 4 o'clock this morning.

ALBANY, March 16 (AP). -- Colonel James Taber Loree, general manager of the Delaware Hudson Railroad, accused the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers today of trying to interfere in the road's dealings with its employes.
WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The RFC's explanation of the bill it has drawn to authorize loans to industry and business reads as follows:

Consolidated gross earnings of the Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries for the year ended on Jan. 31 were $41,756,990, against $44,145,175 in the preceding year. Net operating revenue was $18,246,992, against $20,082,868.

The suggested "occupational tax" which is understood to be under consideration by members of the LaGuardia Administration drew the fire yesterday of representatives of the medical and legal professions. The proposal would place a $3 tax on professional men and a graduated tax on industries and tradesmen.

The Ohio Oil Company last year purchased an additional 4,306 shares of its 6 per cent preferred stock at an average price of $86 a share, it is disclosed in the annual report of the company. At the close of the year the company held in its treasury 18,821 shares of its preferred stock and 84,945 shares of common stock, the total cost being $4,166,465.

PORT HURON, Mich., March 16. -- John Dillinger's Negro aide in his sensational wooden-gun escape from the Crown Point (Ind.) jail lay dead here tonight, the victim of his own boasting and the guns of four St. Clair County officers, three of whom were wounded, one fatally, and the trail of Dillinger himself again was hot.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- General Johnson announced today that the Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company of Philadelphia, maker of motor accessories, had agreed to an independent election of its employes for collective bargaining on March 20.
Liquor may be drunk at bars in New York State by April 1 if a report at a legislative committee meeting here yesterday should prove true.

A falling off in highway construction work brought a drop in this week's engineering contract awards, the Engineering News-Record reports. The total of awards for this week is $18,993,000, as compared with last week's high of $34,023,000. The total is below the year's average to date, below the previous four-week average, but 64 per cent above the average March week last year.

The management of the Kelly-Springfield Tire Company, headed by W.H. Lalley, president, succeeded yesterday in a close proxy battle in retaining its control against the opposition of a stockholders' protective committee. All ten directors named were under the sponsorship of the present management.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Wilhelm Thorleif von Munthe af Morgenstierne, Consul General of Norway in New York, was designated by his government today to be Minister to the United States, succeeding Halvard H. Bachke, who is to become Minister to France.
Five Manhattan properties and three parcels in the Bronx were bid in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday, as follows:

The Alaska Juneau Gold Mining Company reported yesterday for 1933 a profit of $1,497,253, after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges but before depiction. This was equal to $1 a share on 1,491,700 shares of $10 par capital stock. It compares with $820,370, or 57 cents a share on 1,440,000 shares, earned in 1932.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude oil at the close of last week totaled 338,491,000 barrels, a decrease of 625,000 barrels from a total of 339,116,000 barrels on hand at the end of the preceding week, Secretary Ickes announce today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Commissioner Moses' plans for remodeling New York's parks and beaches are certainly worthy of praise; only, it seems that in all his planning esthetic considerations prevail over social ones. As regards the beaches, I have read a great deal about demolishing and remodeling, but not a single word about enlarging them.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- General William Mitchell, who resigned from the army in 1926 after a dispute over the aviation service, said tonight that he had been sued by the Curtiss-Wright Corporation in Alexandria, Va., for libel. The corporation asks for $200,000 damages for recent statements made against it which it alleges were libelous.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Witnesses before the Senate Education and Labor Committee filled the record today with cases of alleged flouting of Section 7a of the Recovery Act and asserted that non-compliance had so endangered faith in the law that the Wagner trades dispute bill was urgently required to restore confidence in the government's assurance that workers might organize for collective bargaining without interference by employers.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The Ways and Means Committee by a straight party vote of 15 to 10 ordered a favorable report today on President Roosevelt's reciprocal tariff trading bill. Chairman Doughton immediately obtained permission of the House to file the formal report by midnight tomorrow, a preparatory step to taking the measure up on the floor Wednesday.
Uncertainty over the outcome of legislation for control of the cotton crop dominated trading on the Cotton Exchange again yesterday, and the market lost 9 to 13 points.

CAPE MAY, N.J., March 16. -- A divorce action started several weeks ago by Mrs. Mary A. Kelley, 77 years old, of 5,209 Park Boulevard, Wildwood, mother of nineteen children, against her husband, John J. Kelley, 78 years old, former Philadelphia broker, was dropped today when the elderly couple effected a reconciliation in court amid a flood of tears.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 16. -- A trifle more leg-weary than if they had walked twice the distance, the Giants returned to their training base today after their 340-mile bus jaunt through the Everglades from the west coast.

CHICAGO, March 16. -- Five separate indictments await the return of the fugitive Insull brothers, Samuel Sr. and Martin J., from Greece and Canada respectively. Two of them were voted by the Federal and three by the Cook County grand jury.

LONDON, March 16. -- Unless their shell springs a leak or some other calamity overtakes them, Cambridge's powerful crew will enter its eighty-sixth rowing contest with Oxford on the Thames tomorrow favored to sweep to its eleventh straight victory.

The work of sifting the lists of CWA employes in this city with a view to eliminating those not in need, in preparation for the transfer of the CWA to the jurisdiction of the city on April 1, was begun yesterday by the Department of Public Welfare.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 16. -- The recently organized Junior Assembly held the second of its series of dances at the Everglades Club tonight with Mrs. Henry Haven Windsor Jr., Winthrop Williams, Minford Wolcott Bond and James Bell Dobyne in charge of arrangements.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Following is the text of the letter from Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC, to Chairman Fletcher of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, transmitting the bill drawn by the RFC to authorize it to make loans to industry ant business:

PARIS, March 16. -- A tumultuous session of the Chamber of Deputies today demonstrated there was strong opposition to the government's plan for a two months' holiday. Though Premier Gaston Doumergue's majority was much reduced, he won by a vote of 376 to 198.

To the Editor of The New York Times: No self-respecting member of the bar could read your editorial commenting upon the McNaboe bill to prohibit the Irving Trust Company from acting as receiver in bankruptcy without feeling that lawyers who are sponsoring this legislation have placed the entire bar of the State in a most unfavorable light.
ORLANDO, Fla., March l6. -- Van Lingle Mungo, ace of the Dodgers' pitching staff, found his real form today in a practice game that saw the Regulars defeat the Yannigans, 10 to 0.

R.H. Macy Co. announced yesterday that it was closing its office in Berlin as a result of "consumer resistance" to German goods. The announcement said that the store's orders from Germany had declined 98 per cent in the six months ended Feb. 28.

Inhalator crews from the Police Department and the Kings County Lighting Company worked more than two hours yesterday morning to revive eight of nine chimpanzees that had been overcome by coal gas in a stable at 8,365 Shore Road, Brooklyn.

TAMPA, Fla., March 16. -- Mine Host of Homosassa, better known as Dazzy Vance, was seated in the handsome concrete grand stand of the combination race track and ball park here today, watching the toiling of a flock of ball players under the watchful eyes of Manager Bob O'Farrell and Coach Burt Shotton.

The Eastman Kodak Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday, for the year ended Dec. 30, 1933, a net profit, after all taxes and charges, of $11,119,044, equivalent, after 6 per cent preferred dividends to $4.76 a share on 2,255,921 no par shares of common stock outstanding at the end of the year.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., March 16. -- Recipients of two European fellowships, one foreign scholarship and nineteen graduate resident fellowships were announced today at ceremonies at Bryn Mawr College.

Gertrude Hrdliczka will conduct two free concerts of the CWA with the New York Civic Orchestra in the Brooklyn Museum at 11 A.M. and 3 P.M. today, the programs including Smetana's "Bartered Bride" overture and "The Moldau" and Dvorak's "Slavonic Dances" and "New World" symphony.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 16. -- Prince Carlo Maurizio Ruspoli of Italy escaped death today when his powerful speed boat Niniette IV caught fire in the international races on Lake Worth.

ATHENS, March 16. -- Mrs. Samuel Insull, wife of the fugitive utilities operator, in a brief interview today expressed resentment at the treatment accorded to her husband and herself in Athens and said she was quite willing to leave Greece.

Simon Schuster have increased the number of their employes and have jumped their Spring promotion appropriation as early steps in the coming publication of "The Life of Our Lord," by Charles Dickens. The size of the first edition of this book has not yet been decided, but advance estimates run between 75,000 and 100,000 copies. "The Life of Our Lord" will be published on May 15.

LONDON, March 16. -- The discovery of still another form of hydrogen -- the third found so far -- was announced very tentatively today by Lord Rutherford and two of his fellow-workers at Cavendish Laboratory, Cambridge.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the obituary notices of the untimely death of Colonel Gordon Johnston, U.S.A., it is surprising to note little or no reference to one activity of this excellent officer which should go down in history as an outstanding contribution to his country.

Elementary school teachers throughout the country must attempt to "more fully understand what is happening today" in the social, economic and political fields so they can present to their students a critical analysis of the changing social order, said Professor Edmund de S. Brunner of Teachers College, Columbia University, in an address last night to the opening session of a two-day conference of elementary school workers.

Teachers College Common at Columbia University echoed to the tramp of heavy brogans at dusk yesterday as the first group of a detachment of 1,070 policemen marched toward the gymnasium to take the intelligence test that may result in new standards for the department.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Park Commissioner Moses has decided to rehabilitate Pelham Bay Park, and has determined to evict all the campers at Orchard Beach and convert the grounds into a golf course.

Moderate declines were recorded in the principal commodity futures here yesterday. Trading was desultory. Cash prices of corn, rye, oats and eggs were firmer. Rubber was lower, while duty-free spot sugar sold at the lowest level since April 13, 1938, or 3.08 cents a pound, off 7 points on the day after one sale at 3.10 cents.

THE disturbances of Feb. 12 and the days following put a wet blanket on musical as well as on practically all other forms of Viennese diversion. Martial law, which shut up all the coffee houses and restaurants at 8 in the evening, closed down the opera house, the concert halls and the theatres for a week.

Dropping only one decision in five bouts Donald Cetrulo, captain of the Barringer High School fencing team, took the interscholastic foils competition staged at the Fencers Club under the auspices of the Amateur Fencers League of America yesterday.

Enforcement of prohibition laws has been practically abandoned in those States that remained dry after repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment became effective early last December, a nation-wide survey discloses.

Instead of their annual gambol, which has been a customary theatrical event, the Lambs theatrical club gave a St. Patrick's Day dinner, gambol and ball at the Waldorf-Astoria last evening. More than 1,200 persons filled the grand ballroom.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., March 17. -- A modern version of outdated gymnastics called "A Century of Progress in Physical Education" was presented yesterday by 200 Mount Holyoke College undergraduates in a gayly decorated gymnasium.

EVEN if Justice Black's assumptions of general ignorance of the Constitution are not wholly justified, there is ample need for the very admirable and interesting book he has written on the way it came into being and its subsequent modifications.

LONDON. THE need of unremitting circumspection has once more been brought home to writers of fiction by an unusual case just heard in the High Court. The ground of the action was a novel purporting to deal with modern life in India.

MONTREAL, March 17 (AP). -- The Maroons closed their regular National Hockey League season tonight by playing a 2-2 tie with the Ottawa Senators. The draw gave the Maroons second place in the International division by one point over the Canadiens, but they can retain the position in the final standings only if the Canadiens lose to Detroit tomorrow.

A strict curb will be placed on sabbatical leaves for school teachers in September under new regulations approved by the Board of Superintendents and now being studied by the law committee of the Board of Education.

ROME, March 17. -- The Palazzo Venezia agreements were signed at 5 o'clock this afternoon by Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy, Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss of Austria and Premier Julius Goemboes of Hungary.

IN a perusal of the current Victor list one is confronted with a veritable embarrassment of riches. The reason for this lies in the fact that the company has chosen this month to inaugurate two, somewhat related, revisions of policy.

A new profession, that of "certified public statistician," whose practitioners would be licensed by the government to gather impartial statistics from industry, was suggested to NRA officials in Washington last week and is getting serious consideration, business men reported here yesterday.

Furniture and other objects collected by the late Stanford White and consigned by Mrs. White will be included in an auction sale on Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc.

A VAST network of communications -- cable and telegraph lines, telephone and wireless circuits -- is embraced in the system which the President has asked Congress to place under a Federal board of control with the purpose of studying the business of the present companies in this field and making recommendations for further regulations.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- General Johnson informed President Roosevelt today that he felt hopeful that a compromise solution of the dispute in the automobile industry might avert the strike which has been tentatively set for Wednesday.

Australia is once again "riding to prosperity on the sheep's back," says The Sydney Morning Herald of Sydney, Australia, in its annual finance and commerce supplement. Wool is giving the country its chief chance, the paper declares, adding that although the commencement of the recovery pre-dated the rise in wool prices, it was nevertheless wool which gave the first impetus.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17. -- Trying to dodge a head-high inside ball at Waterfront Park today, Frank Hogan, pinch-hitting for Pitcher Lew Krausse in the ninth inning, accidentally hit a high pop fly with the handle of his bat, and ended a Braves' uprising.

FOLLOWING reports of expanded production at the automobile plants comes word of increasing activity in the retail field in many cities throughout the country. . . . Ford reports "a steady increase in all sections" in sales of its cars and trucks, with March probably showing a sizable gain over February in deliveries, as well as in output, which calls for building 85,000 units this month. . . .

LONDON, MARCH 3. A STRANGE, discursive week of playgoing recently included a journey to Norwich for a new piece by John Masefield, the poet laureate, a revue called "Here's How!" in which George Robey excels himself, and "The Big House" by Lennox Robinson, a serious and formidable study of the life of country gentlemen in Ireland during the recent upheavals there.

PRAGUE, March 17. -- The minorities problem is still one of the most difficult which Eastern Europe has been unable to solve, even in cases of minorities belonging to the same race and the same political system.

SWEDEN seems to be sitting pretty. Other nations, bedeviled by disasters, look enviously at her state of comparative felicity. Some of them have turned their hopes backward to the lost salvation of the unrecapturable past.

Many special features are being adapted to plans for the Dolphin Dance which will be given March 21 at the Pierre under the direction of several younger members of society. Although the majority of young people on the various committees are away at schools and colleges until the Easter holidays, many of them are working enthusiastically toward the success of this party which is to inaugurate a new series of dances for juniors in society.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 17. -- Yale issued an ultimatum today that unless its dognaped mascot, Handsome Dan 2d, is returned by Monday, legal action will be taken. From Harvard came the offer: "The bulldog for the ibiz."

HUNTINGTON, L.I., March 17. -- Rosedale Bob, a lemon and white pointer, running one of the best races of his long career, which has entailed thirty-three stake victories, today captured the all-age stake at Huntington.

In the Latin-American Hall of Archaeology and Ethnology, the Brooklyn Museum in Eastern Parkway has placed on exhibition for the first time several collections of antiques, folk and decorative art of Arizona, Mexico and Central America.

LONDON, March 17. -- An attempt to Americanize the British ether by seizing control of the British Broadcasting Corporation's radio monopoly is attributed by The Sunday Dispatch to S.L. (Roxy) Rothafel, who is now returning to New York on the liner Manhattan, and David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, who came to London in September.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 16. -- The controversy that has taken place in political circles in Athens regarding the Balkan pact since its signature Feb. 9 created surprise in other countries, inasmuch as the leaders of all parties in Greece had worked equally hard in the last three years to improve the relations of the Balkan States.

TO make room for Park Commissioner Moses's proposed popular-price tavern in what was once the old sheepfold in Central Park, in from Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street, the herd of forty-nine pure-bred Dorsets that was formerly quartered there was sent across the East River to join their hornless brothers, the Southdowns, in Prospect Park.

FOR one thing, the 109th annual academy exhibition, which opened with flowers, music and a receiving line last Tuesday afternoon in the American Fine Arts Building, is too large for its accommodation. Carpenters and decorators were called in, weeks ago, to transform the ancient and honorable galleries into a realm of smartness where the National Academy might achieve its apotheosis.

Wporteseveral seals were red recently off Fire Island Inlet on the south or ocean shore of Long ?lnd, the beachcombers duly entered the record in their logs, although thee northern visitors are by no means rare in metropolitan waters.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 17. -- A big margin with the epee gave the Navy a victory over the crack team of the New York Fencers Club, 15 to 12, today. The visitors gained a margin of 5-4 with both foils and saber.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- The President and Mrs. Roosevelt celebrated the twenty-ninth anniversary of their wedding with a dinner at the White House tonight. Mrs. Sara Delano Roosevelt, the President's mother; Mrs. Curtis Dall and John Roosevelt, children of the President, were the only members of the family who could attend.

MIAMI, Fla., March 17. -- The horsemen's strike, which threatened yesterday to curtail the closing day's program at Hialeah Park, apparently had spent its course today following drastic action taken by the Miami Jockey Club against four men said to have been instrumental in persuading the trainers not to enter their horses.

A definite improvement of American speech on a scale never before attempted is seen by the International Committee on the American Speech in an announcement of the dedication on Thursday of its experimental laboratory, which has been designated The Speech Centre, at 126 East Thirtieth Street.

LONDON, March 17. -- Decent housing for the poor and near-poor has swung into British politics this week as a major issue, with more likelihood than ever before that mere planning will result in actual building for several millions of people.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 17. -- Important remnants of prehistoric and classical civilizations have been unearthed by a Harvard University archaeological expedition in Eastern Yugoslavia.

The scientific approach is the best method for tackling the different problems of life, about 1,000 persons were told yesterday by several scientists speaking at the tenth annual science luncheon at the Hotel Biltmore.

VIENNA, March 17. -- The famous Viennese surgeon Dr. Julius Tandler, professor at the University of Vienna, returned today from China, where he spent several months at the invitation of the Chinese Government as adviser on surgical questions. Dr. Tandler was arrested immediately by the Vienna police.

LONDON, March 17. -- The stock market again was dull today with a small Saturday attendance. There was continued demand for West African mining stocks and some coppers were supported on the improved statistical position of the metal.

CONCORD, N.H., March 17. -- The decoration Les Palmes d'Officier d'Academie has been awarded by the Government of France to Henry Metcalfe Fiske, head of the French department of St. Paul's School here.

Ray Lev, pianist, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall, though she has played with the National Orchestral Association here last October and has appeared in concert elsewhere in the country. The young pianist won the American Matthay Prize four years ago and has spent most of the intervening time studying with Tobias Matthay in London.

PARIS, March 17. -- Roger Langeron was named prefect of police today, succeeding M. Bonnefoy-Sibour, who was rushed into the prefecture on Feb. 3 when Premier Daladier dismissed Jean Chiappe. M. Bonnefoy-Sibour was in charge of the police during the street fighting Feb. 6 and had to bear the brunt of much ill-will and asked to be transferred to the prefecture of Seine-et-Oise, which post he received today.

IN this age, when machine industry is recognized as an important inspiration of modern decorative art, it seems paradoxical that the centenary of the birth of William Morris should be celebrated. A great designer, he spent his life in revolt against machine-made products and in trying to resurrect the beauty of medieval handwork.

GEORGE AUGUSTUS ANDREWS, better known as George Arliss, has been installed at the Astor as two of the leading moneylenders in "The House of Rothschild." It was back in 1919 that Warner Brothers piously imported Mr. Arliss to Hollywood as a burnt offering to the higher cinema gods.

The charitable enterprises of the Society of Stoopnocracy will benefit from the receipts of the two-day opening of the new Flamingo Lounge at Sherry's on Thursday and Friday. Members of the society -- who call themselves Stoopnocrats -- have decided to donate net receipts of the sales on those two days to the Actors Fund of America and the Catholic Boys Clubs of New York, Inc.
DUBLIN, March 17. -- No note of political rancor or bitterness marked the orderly and dignified observance of St. Patrick's Day in the Free State today.

THIS year, for the first time, the New York International Flower Show will give an important space on the main floor to a purely educational exhibit. The exhibit will be made by the Brooklyn Botanic Garden and will be devoted to a demonstration of means and methods of pruning.

A NEW and brilliant feature of American flower shows is a representative display of Daffodil varieties. Flower lovers in crowds hail the inclusion of such an exhibit with grateful delight, and the philosophical horticulturist views their enthusiasm as one of many hopeful signs that this country is far on its way toward fine gardening.
Notice to vacate three of the more than 400 tenements owned by the City of New York were posted yesterday by order of Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post.
CONTINUED operation of automobile factories beyond March 31 was thrown into the balance last week while existing differences between manufacturers and labor were under crucial debate at Washington.

ALBANY, March 17. -- Greatly encouraged by the direct intervention of President Roosevelt, supporters of the LaGuardia emergency economy bill, thrice defeated in the Assembly through a shortage of Democratic votes, are now preparing to bring it up for another test in the lower house, either Monday or Tuesday.

SOME three or four years ago -- it couldn't have been more than that -- the wires brought hot news from the West that America's own Elsie Janis, ever-popular comedienne and erstwhile toast of the A.E.F., had definitely retired from the stage on which she had been appearing almost without cease for twenty-five years.

In the intelligent and persuasive attacks directed against the Fletcher-Rayburn Bill to regulate the security exchanges perhaps the most effective argument has been that such legislation is likely to retard the administration's recovery program. Competent witnesses have emphasized repeatedly, in the hearings conducted by the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency and by the House Interstate Commerce Committee, that to put the capital markets in a straitjacket at this time would be a dangerous step.

CHICAGO, March 15. -- Professional pride marks the experts on the bomb squads employed by racketeering business. One such recently arrested admitted having bombed a building with a shop on the first floor and apartments above. The shop was wrecked, but aside from one or two persons tumbled out of bed, no' injury was done to flat-dwellers.

Marking the second anniversary of the founding of the Women's Division of the Architects' Emergency Committee, a new campaign for $100,000 relief fund has just been inaugurated by this group of architects' wives and sisters in an effort to create and finance special work and otherwise provide relief for needy architects and draftsmen.

PARIS, March 16. -- Needed comic relief for the Stavisky case has been supplied this week by the trial at Aix-en-Provence of the Mayor and corporation of the little Rhone Delta fishing village of Saintes Maries de la Mer for squandering millions of francs and irregularities in the village administration.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker, World War ace, criticizing the administration's air policy in testimony before a Senate committee today, called on President Roosevelt "to purge his official family of traitorous elements."

ANOTHER Canadian province is seeking an emblematic flower. Nova Scotia has adopted the trailing arbutus; Manitoba, the wind flower; Alberta, the wild rose; now Ontario, which has a profusion of wild flowers, is trying to find one which will symbolize that province.

TORONTO, March 17 (Canadian Press). -- The value of gold production in Ontario in February jumped almost $1,000,000 over the total in the same month last year, according to the bulletin issued today by the Ontario Department of Mines. Total gold production in February was 160,540 ounces with a value of $5,569,210.

Except for the addition of one more assistant, the New York University football coaching staff practically is complete. Dr. Marvin A. (Mal) Stevens, new head coach, yesterday announced six of his seven aides and promised to name the final member within the next few days.
LONDON, March 17. -- Lord Rutherford held members of the Royal Institution enthralled today with a modern version of the old alchemist's problem, the transmutation of matter.

Beet sugar interests which have up to the present blocked efforts to legislate President Roosevelt's sugar allotment program, while seeking a larger quota for themselves, may be jeopardizing seriously their own interests, according to B.W. Dyer, sugar broker and economist.

GINA KAUS is to be congratulated on her translators, who have rendered this novel into such clear, idiomatic and agreeable English; but it is abundantly evident throughout that the lucidity, headlong straightforwardness and charm of the narrative are inherent.

OUTSIDE, pressing against the great doors, the crowd mills and jams, good-natured, but momentarily growing more impatient. Inside, the judges, standing in little knots, arguing energetically, scurrying back and forth, and comparing competing entries, try to complete their complicated -- and thankless -- task before the hands of the clock (now apparently moving at several times normal speed) approach the final minute -- 2 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- At the same time Secretary Ickes, Public Works Administrator, estimated today that the wage-earning public would be receiving by June an average of $164,000,000 a month in PWA funds, he said that the PWA expenditures would amount to $1,382,000,000 during the year, exclusive of statutory and executive allotments amounting to about one-third of the entire PWA fund.

THE advent of Easter recalls the J. King's Cock-Crower, who functioned in the olden days in England. This official had to be in the precincts of the royal palace every night from Shrove Tuesday till Easter, crowing the hours as they passed -- presumably in allusion to St. Peter's denial.

Within the last few weeks the Federal Reserve System has begun rapidly to retire from circulation the emergency currency known as Federal Reserve Bank notes, which it was authorized to issue without gold backing.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP). -- Selection of Harrie T. Lindeberg of New York as architect to prepare preliminary sketches and designs for the American Embassy buildings in Moscow was announced today by Representative McReynolds, chairman of the Foreign Service Buildings Commission.

THIS book by the father of his famous flying son has behind it an unusual history. The elder Lindbergh, who was a Congressman from Minnesota, prepared it for publication soon after our entrance into the World War and its first edition was in process of being printed in Washington when, in the Spring of 1918, government agents entered the office of the establishment which was publishing it and ordered all the plates destroyed.

We are pleased to see so sound and carefully documented an opinion as that .0f Mr. Desmond G. Jobity appearing in your column, "Opera and Orchestra," on Sunday March 1I, 1934, regarding the appeal for funds by the Metropolitan Opera Company and the Philharmonic Orchestra.

IN his introduction to the articles that compose this book, after brief but trenchant summary and exposition of Nazi aims and methods and their implications, Mr. Wise, saying that "Hitler has made clear by word and deed that what he has enforced at home he will seek to impose abroad," concludes:

THE talk that evening, like most conversations in Moscow when Americans are present, turned on the still lively subject of the Soviet-American accord, and from that point drifted into the wider field of Russia's changing attitude toward the word.
My ci-devant colleague, the amiable Raymond Lee Ditmars, serves a full-flavored zoological "schnitizel" in THE NEW YORK TIMES magazine.

IN reports made last year to the Citizens Budget Commission and the Lamer Hardy Committee, the writer recommended that the city's incinerators be made the subject of thorough engineering study in connection with a comprehensive investigation of the whole large problem of the proper collection and disposition of the city's solid wastes.

LONDON. SCOTLAND YARD again! News from Washington indicates the increase in racketeering has led the President to consider the advisability of creating a Federal police and detective force of a character described as "somewhat akin to Scotland Yard."

A non-resident goat from Hastings-on-the-Hudson won out over twenty-three nervous but native competitors yesterday in the Bock Beer Beauty Contest in Central Park. The other goats had citizenship, but Pretzels had beauty, which overleaps the barriers of time, space and nationality.

The contention that corporations, which at all times maintain in banks cash balances of several million dollars, are entitled to as full a knowledge of the true condition of these banks as the banks require of corporations that go to them for loans, has been advanced and demonstrated by Francis B. Flahive, treasurer of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation.

READING, Pa., March 17. -- A jury of three women and nine men found Miss Frances Sepse, 27 years old, guilty of murder in the first degree today for the slaying of Dr. Paul R. Hess, prominent Reading physician, in front of his office the night of Jan. 8. The penalty was fixed at life imprisonment.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 17. -- Lehigh's quest for its fourth consecutive championship of the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association terminated successfully tonight as the Bethlehem grapplers came from behind to outscore eight other teams.

EVENTS in Germany have crowded fast upon each other during the last year and a half. Feuchtwanger, in exile, his books at home consigned to the flames, is in the thick of a fight -- and intentionally so. Do not expect his new novel to have the same wealth of fascinating detail, the same subtlety of characterization, the same detachment or the same dramatic effectiveness that went into the making of "Power."

BOSTON, March 15. -- Two electric shocks have been administered to the Commonwealth of Massachusetts within the last ten days. The one issued from an extraordinary meeting of citizens of Greater Boston, called to give expression to an aroused public opinion, caused by what the chairman described as a "real emergence" of an "orgy of crime which menaces our homes and families and challenges our law-enforcement personnel and channels throughout the Commonwealth."

MINEOLA, L.I., March 17. -- The story of how Mrs. Fannie Coddington Browning, daughter-in-law of Robert Browning, the poet, placed $325,000 irrevocably beyond her reach three years ago, was revealed here today in a Supreme Court ruling denying her the right to use the principal of the fund.

PARIS. ONE of the most interesting (and characteristic) things about modern fashions is that they are created in relation to movement, contrary to the styles of "carriage days," when, if we are to judge by photographic records of overstuffed ladies, the sartorial ideal was the wax figure.

APPARENTLY the old adages were right and there is no peace for or with women. If they do not raise ructions on their own account, somebody does it for them. Hardly had they won citizenship in Germany when Herr Hitler shoved them all back to the kitchen.

IT IS now abundantly clear that most of the estimates of our future population made prior to about five years ago are going to prove considerably too high. The two factors which have upset earlier calculations are the more rapid decline in the birth rate than was anticipated, even by the initiated, and the dwindling (at present the reversal) of the stream of immigration.

You know your business, undoubtedly, but I think you are forgetting your theatre when you stand up in defense of the propaganda play. You may know a perfect definition of propaganda, but to the American public propaganda has a popular meaning.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Thirty-five registration statements under the Securities Act, covering proposed issues amounting to $75,940,093 exclusive of reorganization securities, became effective during February, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

Members of the Motion Picture Research Council, of which Mrs. August Belmont is president, will hold their first national conference and luncheon on Wednesday at the Roosevelt. Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell, president emeritus of Harvard University, is honorary head of the council, and the honorary vice presidents are Mrs. Calvin Coolidge and Mrs. James Roosevelt.

PARIS, March 16. -- "If I Had a Million" is being acted in real life in France just now, and the drama of sudden wealth is no less strange and sometimes tragic than it was when represented on the movie screen.
The following is a copy of a letter received by Giulio Gatti-Casazza, general manager of the Metro politan Opera Association, from Richard L. Stokes:

THE battle is between principles and politics. President Roosevelt, in a speech before the American Legion in Chicago last Fall, laid down sound and comprehensive veteran policies. The politics have been furnished by the veteran lobbyists, Congress, and the election next Fall.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Less than seasonal increases in automobile and steel production last week were noted by the Department of Commerce in its weekly survey of domestic business, made public today. Major production series, however, continued to move upward.

ONE of the smallest, and at the same time one of the most interesting, of the exhibits at the New York Flower Show will be a display of those diminutive insect-eating plants, the Sundews. This collection has been raised from seeds from Australia and the Cape of Good Hope by T.H. Everett of the New York Botanical Garden.
BOSTON, March 16. -- Manufacturers and wholesalers of both men's and women's clothing have experienced a substantial improvement in business during the last week.

MOSCOW, March 17. -- One of the most important decisions of the recent Communist Party Congress was to carry out a wholesale reform of the organization of Soviet Industry and agriculture. This decision was formulated in a long speech by L.M. Kaganovich, assistant secretary of the party, which developed four main lines of action:

Five thousand Negroes and white sympathizers rioted in Harlem yesterday afternoon when detectives used tear-gas bombs to disperse an unauthorized meeting staged at Lenox Avenue and 126th Street to protest the Scottsboro case.
BERLIN, March 17 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of March 15 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

THE myriad novels which have realistically portrayed men and women in the toils of the depression have generally followed one or the other of two patterns. The first of them requires that the characters -- nearly always affluent and seldom including "the lower classes" -- must lose their money, but ultimately recover a fair measure of the original, without psychological benefit to them from either experience.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 17. -- Yale defeated Harvard, 37 -- 21 in the final game of the Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball season in the Payne Whitney gymnasium tonight.

Business activity in the metropolitan area continued to move ahead last week, according to the report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the New York Credit Men's Association. Of the replies to the group's weekly questionnaire 57 per cent reported increases in orders, 33 per cent indicated no change and 10 per cent mentioned losses.

CHARLESTON. -- The first annual Azalea Festival, which opened here on Friday, will hit its full stride this week with a program of carnival and social events. Visits to magnolia and cypress gardens and Middleton Place will be increasingly popular as the azalea and camellia japonica blooms approach their peak.

Representatives of bar associations, chambers of commerce, sixteen State Legislatures, leading women's organizations and farmers' associations will gather in Washington on Friday to urge adherence by the United States to the World Court.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- The annual Old Folks' Frolic, sponsored by the Three-Quarter Century Club, will take place tomorrow afternoon in Williams Park and, like similar picturesque parties of preceding seasons, is assured of a record throng to greet the aged principals.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Wholesale commodity prices rose in February to the highest level in nearly three years, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today in revealing another 2 per cent increase last month over January.

In the belief that the proposed code of fair practice for investment banking would adequately regulate the activities of over-the-counter dealers in securities, members of the New York Security Dealers Association of New York are advocating that regulation of their market be transferred from the proposed Stock Exchange control bill to the investment banking code.

Bernard F. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., announced yesterday that the store has discontinued buying German goods and has been using its Berlin of rice recently "for contact and observation purposes only and not for purchases." His statement follows:

CAIRO, March 16. -- How deeply Greek influence penetrated the Nile valley during the five centuries following the accession of Ptolemy I is shown by discoveries just made in the Graeco-Egyptian necropolis at Tuna-el-Gebel, where the Egyptian University is now completing another season's excavations.

NO more intelligent forecast of the future is possible today than through an honest hindsight over the immediate past. "Hindsight" is Walter Lippmann's modest description of the method which guides his extraordinarily perspicacious review of the pre-recovery period which sets the tempo and whets the appetite for this year's product of the fine craftsmanship of Mr. Scroggs and his fellow-workers on the Council on Foreign Relations.

Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler granted an application yesterday for the appointment of a trustee to take over the apartment house on the southwest corner of Broadway and Ninety-fourth Street on behalf of the mortgage certificate holders.
ITHACA, N.Y., March 17. -- Tennis stars of the University of Pennsylvania captured major honors in Cornell's indoor invitation tournament today.
